HEADLINE: Shaking Up Air Fares' Status Quo;
Entrepreneur Seeks Break for Last-Minute Business Fliers

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
It's an expensive anomaly for corporate America: the biggest customers getting stuck paying the highest rates. But when it comes to the airline industry, and the steep fares that companies face for most last-minute travel, it has long been the normal state of affairs, seemingly impervious to even the most committed challenges.
Just ask Kevin P. Mitchell, an entrepreneur who has spent the last five years trying to give big companies more leverage. 
 Battling a system that he calls "inefficient and dysfunctional," Mr. Mitchell ran into a wall of opposition from the airlines and many big travel agencies, and appeared at several points to be heading for failure.
But now, in an outcome that serves as a reminder to entrepreneurs of the value of persistence and resourcefulness, Mr. Mitchell finally seems to be on the verge of shaking up the status quo. His solution: give the companies a way to fly without relying on the major airlines.
The rationale is clear. The average round-trip business fare increased 86 percent, to $820, over the nearly five-year period from May 1992 to January 1997, according to American Express Travel. And though business travelers account for more than half of the major airlines' revenues, they typically pay two to four times as much for last-minute tickets as leisure travelers who can book ahead.
Mr. Mitchell, who has the financial backing of blue-chip companies like Chrysler, Procter & Gamble and Black & Decker, expects to announce shortly an agreement with Frontier Airlines, Reno Air and possibly a third low-fare carrier that would guarantee them revenues for three years in return for starting service in cities sorely in need of airline competition.
Frontier executives said they liked the idea of minimal risk while entering a new market. "It's not a no-brainer, but it's as close as you can get to one in this industry," said Jeff Potter, marketing vice president of the Denver-based carrier.
The consortium that Mr. Mitchell runs -- the Business Travel Contractors Corporation of Lafayette Hill, Pa. -- has also been negotiating with operators of corporate jets to start a kind of flying car pool. Under one plan, a company like the Flight Services Group of Stratford, Conn., would fly small jets on routes chosen by the consortium's 45 member companies. They would depart at certain times each weekday, and seats would be available only to those companies' employees.
How much might all this save? The full fare between Philadelphia and Chicago is now about $800 round trip, although some corporate customers that regularly use that route might get discounts, which are common throughout the industry and typically range from 10 to 15 percent. By guaranteeing revenues to an airline to start serving that route, Mr. Mitchell anticipates a fare for all last-minute travelers of $220 round trip, with a further 15 percent discount offered to companies that join the consortium for a fee of about $3,000. The fare would be guaranteed for the term of the contract, except for adjustments to account for higher costs, such as a spike in the price of jet fuel.
Mr. Mitchell has become "the Ralph Nader representing the corporations in business travel issues," said Peter Buchheit, director of travel and meeting services for the Black & Decker Corporation.
But Michael E. Levine, executive vice president for marketing and international operations at Northwest Airlines, said the plan was doomed because the participating carriers would not be able to offer the frequency of flights that companies needed to get their people places at the last minute.
"It is moral and legal and well within the spirit of deregulation," Mr. Levine said of Mr. Mitchell's effort. But, he added, "I think it's impractical and won't work."
In any event, some Government officials recently started paying attention to Mr. Mitchell's consortium. Senator Bill Frist, a Republican from Tennessee, has agreed to speak this month at a conference that the consortium is organizing on airline competition. And Patrick V. Murphy, Deputy Assistant Secretary for aviation at the Department of Transportation, said his agency supported anything that promoted competition.
"We find it to be a very exciting idea," he said of the revenue-guarantee proposal.
It is not the first time that companies have tried to gain more control over business travel. As long ago as 1984, the Kimberly-Clark Corporation was frustrated enough to get into the airline business itself, founding Midwest Express, a low-cost carrier that provided the only direct service between Appleton, Wis., its headquarters at the time, and Atlanta, then its most heavily traveled route. The company, a paper-products maker now based in Dallas, took Midwest public in 1995 and sold its final stake last year.
These days, companies are trying a number of ways to rein in travel costs as part of an overall effort to contain expenses. Corporate travel budgets are a fat target since they are more discretionary than many other expenses. The efforts have ranged from cutting back on the number of trips to encouraging employees to stay over on a Saturday night to get a lower fare.
For all his more ambitious plans, Mr. Mitchell said there were moments when he considered ending the consortium venture, wondering whether he had made a mistake by walking away from a good job at the Cigna Corporation, the Philadelphia-based insurer where the idea for the consortium was born.
Mr. Mitchell's saga began in the summer of 1992. During a meeting with his division president, Mr. Mitchell, then a Cigna vice president responsible for a $60 million travel budget, explained that because of American Airlines' widely publicized "Value Pricing" plan, most corporate discounts had been wiped out. "What are we going to do about this?" he was asked.
Mr. Mitchell did not know. But the more he studied the industry, the more he was struck by how money traded hands in so many directions. Airlines were paying extra commissions to travel agencies to steer corporate customers their way, for example, and the agencies were giving rebate checks to corporate travel managers in return for the business.
When he called travel managers at other large companies, Mr. Mitchell heard similar complaints. Even some airline executives he reached confessed that they too would like a new way of doing business.
Mr. Mitchell shared his findings with top executives at Cigna, and they gave him a $250,000 budget to work on an idea. By the spring of 1993, Mr. Mitchell said, he had 20 Fortune 100 companies urging him on in his research.
Mr. Mitchell hatched an unusual plan -- he wanted airlines to offer corporate customers guaranteed fares that were stripped of all unnecessary costs, such as commissions and fees for computer reservation systems. He also wanted a simplified fare structure based on the length of trips. He thought companies could pay travel agencies flat fees for their services rather than airlines paying them commissions. Executives at a number of airlines -- also annoyed by the inefficiency of the system -- were intrigued and encouraged him to keep going.
After an antitrust lawyer suggested that he set up an independent company to pursue the idea, Mr. Mitchell faced the question of whether he should leave Cigna. That would depend, he decided, on whether he could get financial backing. He calculated that he needed $400,000 a year to get started, and asked each of the 20 companies that had supported his efforts for $20,000. Within a week, the first check arrived, and 19 more soon followed.
To Mr. Mitchell's surprise, word of his efforts had not leaked out to the media or to travel agents. But that changed in June 1994, and the reaction was swift and sharp. Airline industry pundits said Mr. Mitchell was trying to put travel agencies out of business. The consortium -- and a raft of supposed reasons why it would never get off the ground -- was the talk of travel industry conventions. Most observers soon wrote off the venture as moribund.
"The arrows were flying thick and fast," Mr. Mitchell said.
In hindsight, he said, the ridicule served a purpose. Since no one considered the venture a serious threat, no one sued, as Mr. Mitchell feared they might, on a claim that the group was planning to abuse its collective buying power. Although Mr. Mitchell was confident the consortium could withstand legal challenges, he worried that even the threat of litigation would scare away members.
By July 1995, the consortium won the blessing of the Justice Department, giving it a measure of protection. Mr. Mitchell then started developing proposals for individual airlines.
But some carriers were not interested in hearing from the group, contending that its proposal would force them to hire more administrative people and thus increase costs.
Other airlines considered the proposal but expressed concerns about the pace of change and the loss of control over pricing. Still, Mr. Mitchell thought that if he could get just one big carrier interested, others might follow.
He set a deadline of March 29, 1996, for formal responses. Southwest Airlines agreed to the proposal, but it was already a low-fare carrier. The reaction from every other major carrier was the same: no.
"This was now years of work leading up to this great climax," Mr. Mitchell said. "It was clearly a disappointment."
Mr. Mitchell was no longer convinced it was worthwhile to keep trying. But the remaining members of the consortium -- a number had dropped out -- disagreed. They said the main reason they supported the effort was that it was a thorn in the side of the airlines.
Charles Braswell, manager of general services for the Chrysler Corporation, said that he had already seen benefits in the form of deeper fare discounts that he attributed to membership in the consortium. "I looked at it as a long-term initiative from the start," he added.
Mr. Mitchell regrouped, and set his sights lower, hoping to get airlines to agree to offer guaranteed fares for six months on specific routes. The airlines rejected that plan last August.
Mr. Mitchell then switched gears, using the guarantee of revenues to entice carriers like Frontier and Reno Air to enter new markets. Once he completes contract terms, he hopes to get new service into Philadelphia, Detroit and Cincinnati this summer.
In the meantime, he is talking to operators like Flight Services to see if the economics of a corporate-jet airline would work.
"The market is so big, and the problems are so varied, there is room for multiple solutions," Mr. Mitchell said.
He added that he could not guess what he would be doing a year from now. The consortium's story has been one of "complete unpredictability," he said. But once the program is up and running, he may start tinkering with something else.
And what might that be?
"Health care," he said, quickly adding, "Imagine the enthusiasm."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Money From Stocks Buoys Short-Term Issues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the exception of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond, Government securities were mostly higher yesterday, as investors moved money out of a plunging stock market to the more secure short end of the Treasury market, temporarily at least.
The results of yesterday's Treasury bill auction were stronger than expected, and for the same reason, analysts said. The bidding outstripped the amount of available securities. 
 Rates dropped modestly at the auction, with the three-month bill averaging 5.18 percent, down from 5.26 percent last week, and the six-month issue at 5.31 percent, down from 5.33 percent.
The 30-year bond fell 5/32, to a price of 94 7/32 to yield 7.09 percent, up from 7.08 percent on Thursday. The market was closed on Friday.
The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index was released yesterday morning, but market analysts said it gave no real clue about what to expect from today's release of the report of the National Association of Purchasing Management for March. Investors holding securities with long maturities did express some fear of a strong national purchasing report and an even stronger Friday employment report, which led to a mild selloff at the long end of the market.
David Shabelman, Treasury market analyst at MMS International, San Francisco, said the two reports would be the focus for the Treasury market this week. "A strong N.A.P.M. would increase concerns of a strong jobs report," he said, "but traders do not expect sellers to be too aggressive until the market's oversold condition is alleviated."
He added that "new lows will promote profit taking and short-covering, as traders position themselves in front of the employment report."
The Chicago purchasing managers index was 57.5 in March, above the 56.2 in February and the forecast of 57. However, the component that measures the length of time it takes to make supplier deliveries dropped to 46.8 from 56 and could be interpreted to mean that demand was down.
Patrick R. Dimick, Treasury market analyst at UBS Securities, said the technical picture was continuing to deteriorate, and for the second trading session the market had set new lows. "Closing near those lows today suggests the bears are still firmly in control," he said.
"I think that a 6.50 percent yield on the two-year note is a popular objective," Mr. Dimick added, "which means that investors looking to bargain-hunt probably won't surface until we back yields up to that level."
Currently the big game in the market is trying to identify support levels and recognize the buy levels, he said. "The success or failure of bargain-hunting strategies, I believe, will be dependent on economic data rather than technically dependent," he said.
The consensus for today's report from the purchasing managers index is 53.5, while the consensus for the unemployment report on Friday is that about 190,000 jobs will be added to the economy.
"The next Federal Open Market Committee meeting is not until May 20," Mr. Dimick said, "and we will have two full data cycles from which to handicap the outcome of that meeting."
Other data reported yesterday included personal consumption, up three-tenths of a percent in February. January's figure was revised upward to 1 percent from seven-tenths of a percent, suggesting that first-quarter consumption will increase to above 5 percent.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said: "It's well worth emphasizing that many important economic statistics, including consumer spending, inevitably move in spurts that invariably trigger financial market overreactions. The January consumption spurt this year reminds us of the February and May spurts last year that were followed by two much softer months."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: HIGH COURT RULES CABLE MUST CARRY LOCAL TV STATIONS

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
A deeply divided Supreme Court awarded a major economic and political victory to the broadcast television industry today by upholding a Federal law that requires cable television systems to carry the signals of local over-the-air broadcast stations.
The 5-to-4 decision, with a majority opinion by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy and a crucial concurring vote by Justice Stephen G. Breyer, rejected the cable industry's argument that the 1992 law was an unconstitutional intrusion on cable operators' editorial autonomy, a form of Government-compelled speech that violates the First Amendment. 
 But today's ruling focused less on free-speech issues than on supporting Congress's right to judge what approach would best insure a competitive communications marketplace. And the ruling means that even with the prospect of new competition from satellite television and other technologies, Federal regulators can continue to treat cable operators as local monopolies that control the public's access to television programming.
Justice Kennedy said that in imposing the "must carry" requirement after years of hearings and debate, Congress had acquired sufficient evidence that cable systems had both the economic motive and the practical ability to inflict serious economic injury on broadcast stations simply by refusing to carry their signals into the 60 percent of American homes that are wired for cable.
As to whether local broadcasters would suffer economic harm if the must-carry law was overturned, the evidence was less than conclusive and was subject to conflicting interpretations, Justice Kennedy wrote. But, he wrote, "we are not at liberty to substitute our judgment for the reasonable conclusion of a legislative body."
Typically, households that subscribe to cable do not have aerial antennas for receiving over-the-air signals from local broadcast stations. And in the case of densely settled urban areas with high-rise buildings, like Manhattan, over-the-air signals of some weaker stations can be difficult to receive even with an aerial antenna.
Congress passed the must-carry law in an effort to insure that the broadcast stations could be viewed on cable subscribers' television sets. The law requires cable systems with more than 12 channels to reserve one-third of their channels for the retransmission of local broadcast signals.
Because the must-carry rule has been in effect since 1992, television viewers are not likely to notice any immediate impact from the decision. And, cable operators, for the most part, had no immediate plans to remove many local broadcast channels, anyway.
The true impact may come a year or two from now, when a national satellite television network planned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is to begin offering at least some local broadcast channels to its subscribers. It remains unclear whether the News Corporation's system will be obliged to observe the must-carry rules -- a technical impossibility, since the 500-channel satellite network could not carry signals from all of the nation's 1,544 local broadcast stations.
Today's decision, in Turner Broadcasting System v. Federal Communications Commission, No. 95-992, ended a five-year legal battle whose outcome remained in doubt until the last minute. The case produced two 5-to-4 Supreme Court decisions, totaling 147 pages, in addition to tens of thousands of pages of testimony and documents produced in two hearings before a special three-judge Federal District Court.
The District Court had twice upheld the must-carry provision, which is part of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992. Three years ago, a Supreme Court opinion by Justice Kennedy vacated the earlier of the District Court decisions, ruling that the Government had to present more evidence to justify the law's assumption that the broadcast industry's economic viability was in jeopardy without guaranteed retransmission of its signals by the increasingly dominant medium of cable.
While the Court's initial decision led many people to conclude that the cable industry had the upper hand and would ultimately prevail, there were two aspects of Justice Kennedy's 1994 opinion that proved crucial to the broadcasters' victory today.
One aspect was a matter of First Amendment doctrine. The Court concluded then, as now, that the must-carry provision was "content neutral," meaning that the Government was requiring retransmission of the broadcast signals without respect to the actual programming. As such, the law had to pass only an intermediate level of First Amendment scrutiny: that it further an "important governmental interest" without burdening speech more than necessary.
The second important aspect to the 1994 decision was the economic theory that the Court offered as a potential justification for the regulation: a view of cable television as an anti-competitive "bottleneck" through which broadcast signals had to pass and from which the broadcast industry needed protection. Justice Kennedy wrote today that it was necessary only to regard this theory as a reasonable one for Congress to have embraced, without necessarily putting the Court's own "imprimatur" on it.
While agreeing with the result today and joining most of Justice Kennedy's opinion, Justice Breyer wrote a separate opinion to say that he did not agree with the Court's economic analysis. He said that in his view, the law was justified by the need to insure that the broadcasting industry remained financially healthy enough to provide "a rich mix of over-the-air programming" for the 40 percent of American households that do not subscribe to cable.
That "speech-enhancing" consequence of the law, Justice Breyer said, would help these viewers more than it would hurt cable subscribers who might lose access to some cable channels as operators complied with the requirement of devoting one-third of their channels to broadcast retransmission.
One cable network in particular, C-Span, which carries the proceedings of Congress and other public affairs programming, has complained that cable operators have often squeezed it out to comply with the must-carry requirements. Brian Lamb, C-Span's chief executive, said today that his network had lost access to 3.5 million viewers since the must-carry requirement took effect.
Justice Breyer's vote was the focus of intense interest because he is the only Justice who was not on the Court at the time of the 1994 decision. His predecessor, Justice Harry A. Blackmun, had joined the majority in voting to apply only the intermediate level of First Amendment scrutiny. So it was evident that if the other Justices all adhered to their positions -- as in fact they did today -- then Justice Breyer would be in a position to control the outcome.
The others in the majority today were Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices John Paul Stevens and David H. Souter.
The dissenters were Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice O'Connor wrote a 32-page dissenting opinion, which the others joined. Three years ago, these Justices had argued that the law should be analyzed under the strictest First Amendment scrutiny. Today they said that the law failed even the less-demanding constitutional test that the majority had applied.
Far from being a "measured response to Congressional concerns about monopoly power," Justice O'Connor said, the law was based on bad economics, unproven assumptions and inadequate attention to technological developments.
Justice O'Connor said that because "marginal" broadcast stations were the only ones that cable operators would not voluntarily carry, the notion that the viability of the broadcast industry as a whole was at stake was "entirely mythical." She said the Court "trivializes the First Amendment issue at stake in this case" by deference to "a highly dubious economic theory."
Further, Justice O'Connor said, "growing use of direct-broadcast satellite television also tends to undercut the notion that cable operators have an inevitable monopoly over video services entering cable households."
The principle of judicial deference to Congressional judgments, Justice O'Connor said, "does not require wholesale deference to judgments about rapidly changing technologies that are based on unquestionably outdated information."

HEADLINE: Crime Reports Drop Sharply In New York

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
New York City's falling crime rate continued to plummet during the first quarter of 1997, according to preliminary police statistics released yesterday, and the decline was fueled by particularly steep drops in two of the crimes that by turns most frighten and annoy New Yorkers: murder and car theft.
Murder dropped more precipitously than any other major crime: 194 people were reported killed during the first three months of the year, a 27 percent decrease over the same period last year, when 266 people were reported killed. The next steepest drop was in car thefts: 13,004 cars were reported stolen during the first quarter of the year, down 20 percent from the same period last year, when 16,329 cars were reported stolen. 
 Overall, reports of the seven major crimes -- murder, rape, robbery, assault, burglary, grand larceny and car theft -- dropped by 15.6 percent over the same period last year, despite the milder winter. Experts say that harsh winters, like last year's, are much more likely to keep criminals from venturing outdoors.
And once again the crime statistics provided welcome news to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is making the drop in crime that has occurred on his watch the centerpiece of his bid for re-election. In the last four years, reported crime has dropped by more than 43 percent in the city. The drop in car thefts, in particular, may be of interest to voters in Queens and Staten Island, strongholds for Mr. Giuliani where that crime has been an issue. The new figures reinforce a perception that the city is safer, and virtually eliminate any hope that Democrats had for making crime an issue in the mayoral race.
Although reported crime dropped in commands across the five boroughs, some areas experienced greater drops than others. The steepest declines were in northern Brooklyn, the Bronx and northern Manhattan; the smallest were in Staten Island, Manhattan south of 59th Street and southern Brooklyn.
Of special interest to police officials was the fact that the steepest crime drop in the city was in northern Brooklyn, where the Police Department is running a pilot program that consolidates all its divisions -- housing, narcotics, detectives and others -- under the control of one locally based commander, Assistant Chief Joseph P. Dunne. Crime reports there dropped 21.3 percent.
In other boroughs, detectives answer to the Chief of Detectives at One Police Plaza in Manhattan, narcotics detectives report to the commander of the Narcotics Division, and housing officers are accountable to the chief of the Housing Bureau. In Brooklyn North they all answer to the same man.
In the neighborhood covered bv the department's other major new initiative, the anti-drug campaign in northern Manhattan, the drop in crime, 16.3 percent, also outpaced that in the rest of the city. In northern Manhattan, Federal, State and local law enforcement agencies are working to drive out drug dealers with aggressive policing tactics.
Given the unusually mild winter, especially compared with the previous one, some criminologists expressed surprise at the continued decline in crimes that are usually committed outdoors, like auto thefts and shootings.
"The police have an old maxim, something to the effect that the best cop is a cold day or a snowstorm," said Andrew Karmen, a professor of criminology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. "It is in a severe winter that you expect a drop, not a mild one."
If any statistic offered a sore point for police officials, it was that ticket-writing by police officers was falling faster than the crime rate. Many officers have been staging an unofficial ticket-writing slowdown since contract negotiations between their union and the city broke down in January.
The statistics released yesterday showed that summons writing was still way down. There were 591,974 parking tickets written so far this year, a 36.2 percent decrease over the same three months in 1996, when 927,866 were written. And there were 201,728 moving violations issued, a 34.5 percent decrease over the previous year, when there were 307,771.
Commissioner Howard Safir sent high-ranking supervisors into the field to make sure officers wrote tickets and summonses, even suspending firearms training for weeks at the police shooting range while its supervisors were sent to the streets. But the figures showed that despite these moves and others, the slowdown appeared to be persisting.
Otherwise the news was welcome. "This is terrific; crime continues to drop across the boards," Professor Karmen said. "And as long as the factors that influence it continue to remain, there's no reason to think the drop won't continue."
Among the factors Professor Karmen cited were the decline of crack, the economic upturn and the more aggressive policing strategies.
In Brooklyn, Deputy Chief Joseph J. Esposito said that the strategies appeared to be paying dividends, strategies like the focus on "quality of life" crimes, the beefed-up warrant enforcement, flooding drug-infested areas with officers and questioning everyone who is arrested and put into the system. "When you concentrate on the little things, the big things fall into place," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Manages a Slight Gain After Showing Early Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied to end slightly higher against most currencies yesterday, recovering from a decline caused by another stiff drop in American stock prices.
Traders attributed the dollar's comeback partly to a growing economy and rising American interest rates. The higher rates have helped depress stock prices. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 157.11 points, or 2.3 percent, yesterday. 
 Currency trading was thin yesterday in the aftermath of the Easter weekend; most markets were closed Friday, and many European markets remained closed yesterday. The light volume exaggerated price movements, so currency traders were reluctant to read too much into the behavior of the dollar.
"We piggybacked on the asset markets for much of the day, but the dollar rallied and we're closing right about where we opened up," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York.
In New York, the dollar settled at 123.80 Japanese yen, up from 123.48 yen on Thursday. The dollar was at 1.6770 German marks, up from 1.6736. The British pound cost $1.6395, up from $1.6315.
The dollar weakened sharply when the stock market opened and the Dow Jones average immediately tumbled, raising fears that investors would flee American assets and cause a diminishing demand for dollars. At its lows of the day the dollar cost 1.6620 marks and 123.65 yen.
The catalyst for the stock market's drop was another batch of stronger-than-expected economic data, including a report showing that personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, the biggest monthly gain since June 1996.
The figures strengthened expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again at its next policy-making meeting, in May, to try to slow the economy and impede inflation. Last Tuesday, the Fed raised rates for the first time in more than two years.
The dollar showed some strength against the yen early yesterday on further weakness in Japan's stock market and expectations that the Bank of Japan's quarterly economic survey due tomorrow would show that the economy was still recovering slowly from its long slump.

HEADLINE: U.S. Incomes Accelerate, Led by Wages

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Growth in Americans' incomes accelerated during February, led by gains in wages and salaries, a reminder of the concerns raised by the Federal Reserve's chairman that rising wages could add to inflationary pressures.
The Commerce Department said today that personal income rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, while personal spending crept up three-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News had expected a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in personal income and of four-tenths of 1 percent in spending. 
 Wages rose by $50 billion at an annual rate last month, the largest gain since April 1994.
 February's income gain came on the heels of a January spending spree. While incomes rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January -- the gain was revised upward from the three-tenths of 1 percent reported initially -- spending jumped a revised 1 percent. The spending gain was previously reported as seven-tenths of 1 percent.
"You're going to see an increase in spending in the months ahead," said William V. Sullivan, a Dean Witter economist. "This is a vibrant economy."
Americans' personal outlays make up roughly two-thirds of economic activity, and consumers' eagerness to spend is spurring the economy at a pace that worries investors and Federal Reserve policy makers. Last week, when they decided to push up the overnight bank lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, they cited "persisting strength in demand" that could eventually cause economic imbalances and spur inflation.
 Demand, spurred by job growth, near-record consumer confidence and exceptional gains in stocks, helped push economic growth to a 3.8 percent annual rate during 1996's fourth quarter. In the first quarter, growth has been running at close to a 3.3 percent pace, said Evelina Tainer, chief economist at IndoSuez Carr Futures in Chicago. "The first quarter is just zooming along," she said before today's report.
Given the income gains and other signs of economic growth, consumers are likely to continue to spend, and the Fed policy makers may feel the need to push up rates further to cool their enthusiasm. Last week's quarter-point increase "is a drop in the bucket given the economic momentum we have," she said.
 In today's report, the Commerce Department also said disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased eight-tenths of 1 percent in February. The savings rate rose to 5.5 percent from January's 5.1 percent, the highest since a 5.6 percent rate last September.
 Consumers' interest payments to businesses, which are counted separately from the overall spending figures, increased half a percent during February, slower than a gain of nine-tenths of 1 percent in January.

HEADLINE: Altering Labels, Not Clothes, China Sidesteps Trade Limits

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Every day, shiploads of clothing cranked out by China's prodigious textile industry are unloaded on the docks of this commercial crossroads and taken by truck to back-alley factories. Nimble-fingered workers add a few finishing touches and, most important, a label that reads, "Made in Hong Kong."
Thus altered, the garments are sent to retailers in Europe and the United States as the exports of Hong Kong in what American officials say is a vast effort to circumvent European and American limits on imports of Chinese textiles. 
 This clandestine traffic in suits, shirts and gloves has long roiled trade relations between the United States and China. And American officials fear that it could expand further after July 1, when Hong Kong comes under Chinese control and movement of goods through the former colony may become even easier.
Billions of dollars are at stake. A painstaking study by the United States Customs Service found that in 1992, while China's textile exports totaled $13 billion, the world's countries reported importing more than $23 billion worth of textiles from China.
In a section titled "The China Syndrome: Clothing That Multiplies En Route," the study said that only some of the discrepancy could be explained by statistical confusion.
American officials say the illegal exports harm American workers and the dwindling domestic textile industry. Critics of China also say the long history of evading the rules calls into question Beijing's willingness to abide by terms under negotiation, the most important of which involve China's drive to join the World Trade Organization.
The issue's prominence is another sign of a major shift in Asia's economy. Textile manufacturing fueled the growth of Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea after World War II. But today, clothing companies in the region have shifted their factories to China, where workers are paid $50 a month, as against $1,300 a month in Hong Kong. American officials say China's textile empire produces far more than it can legally export, though it, too, is facing pressure from even lower-wage countries like India. China, said one American official, "would clothe most of the world if we let it."
There is no intention to allow that.
Nearly all of the world's developed nations set limits, or quotas, on the quantity of textiles that they import from any single country. Those rules reflect the production patterns of an earlier era, and places like Hong Kong and Macao are allowed far more exports than they now produce.
International trade laws will continue to treat Hong Kong and China as separate entities for the next seven years, with separate quotas, even though Hong Kong will become part of China this year. "We're waiting to see how it plays out," said one American official. "If we don't have the same level of cooperation, we'll have to look very hard at what our next step would be."
The quotas themselves are a vestige of a previous era, and will eventually be phased out.
In its annual report on foreign trade barriers, the Clinton Administration argues that China's illegal shipments are still a major problem, but expresses hope that they will be reduced under a four-year pact signed this year. That agreement lowers China's quota for 14 apparel and fabric categories and calls for stronger enforcement measures.
Hong Kong's underused quotas have long provided an opening that many Chinese factories and Hong Kong companies cannot resist.
In some instances the phony label -- "Made in Fiji," "Made in Macao" -- is sewn into the garment before it even leaves the factory in China. In other cases, once the garments reach Hong Kong, the "Made in China" label is taken out and replaced with one that reads, "Made in Hong Kong." Other times, the labels are sewn in Hong Kong and the garments repacked in their original boxes, with a piece of tape that says, "Made in Hong Kong" slapped over the "Made in China" markings on the outside.
Trade and employment statistics suggest the scope of illegal exports through Hong Kong. While Hong Kong's textile work force has declined by two-thirds in the last decade, its exports to the United States are mysteriously up by almost 50 percent, according to Hong Kong government data. At least 90 percent of the textiles and garments sold in the United States with a "Made in Hong Kong" label are in fact made in China, said two senior Hong Kong textile executives, who sell different types of textiles.
The three largest Hong Kong exporters of men's suits and jackets to the United States have a combined work force today of some 400, people in the industry say. Yet those companies exported nearly 200,000 suits and jackets to the United States in 1994.
Hong Kong companies shipped 60 million pairs of work gloves to the United States last year, even though the companies employ fewer than 100 workers, a senior executive in the industry said. Nearly all of the gloves were in fact made in China, he said.
In a complaint that runs to nearly 300 pages, the American Textile Manufacturers Association has accused The Limited Inc., which operates retail outlets like Abercrombie & Fitch, Victoria's Secret and Lane Bryant, with falsifying documents, smuggling and other violations of American laws to get Chinese-made goods into the United States via Hong Kong, say American officials and persons close to the association.
The Justice Department and Customs Service are investigating the allegations before deciding whether to file criminal charges against the company, the officials said. If the Government does not act, the association plans to file a civil action against The Limited, officials close to the institute said.
The Limited, a publicly held company based in Columbus, Ohio, would not comment directly on the allegations. A company official said that he had heard that the industry had filed a complaint, but that he had not seen it. The company's general counsel, Samuel P. Fried, said The Limited was "committed to full compliance with the spirit and letter of all legal requirements of goods into the United States."
After years of prodding from the United States, trade officials in Hong Kong have begun to crack down on some of the local companies that export Chinese-made textiles as their own.
And for the first time, American customs agents have been allowed to inspect Hong Kong factories where false labels are said to be sewn on, though the agents are allowed into factories only if the company permits. They are not allowed to examine a company's books.
Illustrating the scale of the problem, and the difficulty of curbing it, American officials and Hong Kong textile executives point to Penisula Knitters, which is headed by Henry Tang Ying-yen. He is one of Hong Kong's most powerful political leaders, and he has been implicated in export violations.
A few years ago, Mr. Tang was fined $250,000 by the British authorities after being caught trying to smuggle Chinese-made cashmere sweaters into England, American officials said. The sweaters were destined for the United States, the officials said, where with a "Made in England" label they would have fetched a far higher price than with a "Made in China" one.
Mr. Tang is chairman of the Federation of Hong Kong Industries, a quasi-governmental business organization, and has been appointed to the executive council that will come into power when Hong Kong reverts to Chinese control on July 1.
The United States is investigating whether Mr. Tang illegally shipped four million Chinese-made sweaters to the United States last year, American officials said. Mr. Tang declined to discuss any aspect of either case, other than to say that he had paid a fine in England. "We don't engage in transshipping," he said, using the term for the illegal exporting of goods originating elsewhere.
Mr. Tang, who said Peninsula Knitters sold "tens of millions of dollars" of sweaters to United States companies annually, dismissed the issue as a minor problem, the result of a few "unscrupulous operators." And he called American efforts to curb it "barbaric."
The Customs Service has primary responsibility to stanch the flow. But several senior agents said illegal textile exports were not a high priority for the agency, which also handles higher-profile cases involving drug trafficking and money laundering.
Justice Department lawyers find the cases difficult, time-consuming and expensive. And the State Department has been reluctant to be too vocal in its criticism of China or Hong Kong, critics of the Administration's record said.
One of the most contentious issues is whether an American importer knows that the garments have been made in China and not Hong Kong.
"They know where the stuff comes from," said an American law enforcement official. "Proving it in court is another matter." The companies generally insist that they do not, saying they buy from Hong Kong manufacturers or through Hong Kong agents.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Signs Bill Favoring Rent Regulations

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Joined by an array of elected officials who vowed to wage war in Albany to protect rent regulations, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday signed a bill declaring that the state laws are still necessary for the 1.2 million rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments in New York City.
The action essentially informs the State Legislature that a housing emergency continues to exist in the city, and urges that the current rent laws be extended to protect "public health, safety and general welfare." 
 But the largely symbolic legislation does little more than clear the way for the bitter partisan battle to begin in earnest in Albany, where the Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, has proposed eliminating almost all rent regulations -- except those for the poor, elderly and disabled -- by mid-1999. Mr. Bruno has threatened to let the current laws expire on June 15 if the Democratic-controlled Assembly defies him.
Before signing the bill yesterday, Mr. Giuliani gave no indication of what he would like to see happen in Albany should a compromise be forced on the issue. But he said his administration was pushing for a faster resolution to avoid 11th-hour bartering that could chip away at current protections and to end the "psychological torture" that he said delays would cause for renters.
The Mayor stressed yesterday that the city's determination that the laws were necessary should, in an ideal political world, be honored in Albany. "The State Legislature and the Governor should give great deference to this decision," he said. "This is the political will of the City of New York."
The city makes the determination every three years by surveying the supply of rental apartments in the city. This year, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development found that there were slightly more than two million rental apartments and that the vacancy rate was 4.01 percent. Under city law, if the rate is below 5 percent, a housing emergency exists, making rent regulation necessary to protect renters from the market pressures that such a shortage creates.
The rent-regulation laws cover about one million rent-stabilized apartments in the city and an additional 100,000 that are rent-controlled. Rent control applies to about 100,000 prewar apartments, where tenants have no leases and where rent increases are usually limited to 7.5 percent a year. Under rent stabilization, renters have leases and increases are tied roughly to inflation and to the landlord's maintenance costs.
The Republican Mayor was joined yesterday by two of his most important allies on the issue, State Senators Frank Padavan, a Queens Republican, and Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican, both of whom have staked out a position against their party leadership on rent regulation.
The two face their first battle next Monday, when the full Senate is scheduled to vote on whether a Democratic-sponsored bill extending the current regulations should move from a committee to the Senate floor.

HEADLINE: Interest Rate Increase Scarcely Harms Workers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Greenspan's Whim" (Op-Ed, March 27) by Prof. James K. Galbraith:
So much silliness has been published since the increase in a key interest rate that it is discouraging to see Professor Galbraith weighing in with more of the same. 
 Professor Galbraith suggests a harm done to "the American worker" and a windfall for the banking industry, which he identifies as the constituency of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
But the resulting quarter of a percentage point increase on credit card balances and some loans is of slight consequence when weighed against the beneficial effects for both labor and capital of maintaining the economic expansion and high employment without serious inflation.
Professor Galbraith says Mr. Greenspan has "hinted that he wants to deflate the stock market."
But no one knows whether the interest rate increase will help forestall a bursting of the stock-market bubble. Surely Professor Galbraith knows that "the American worker" is in the stock market up to his eyeballs, directly and by way of his Individual Retirement Account, 401(k), pension fund and other retirement savings.
I hope we don't get a chance to experience a real bust in stocks. All these new "investors" and their 30-something mutual fund managers are likely to panic at the wrong moment, and the consequences could inflict more permanent pain on the average American worker than a small interest rate increase could do.
 
RALPH T. BIRDSEY
Atlanta, March 27, 1997

HEADLINE: Federal Insurance for Pensions Has a Surplus of $869 Million

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The Government corporation that insures the pensions of 41 million Americans announced today that its largest insurance fund had posted the first surplus since the agency was created in 1974.
In its annual report to Congress, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said that at the end of 1996, its single-employer pension insurance fund had a surplus of $869 million, based on assets of more than $12 billion and liabilities of a little more than $11 billion. 
 The financial health of the insurance program marked a turnaround since 1993, when it had a deficit of $2.9 billion. At the time, some economists raised alarms about the long-term economic security of millions of workers and predicted that taxpayers might have to pay for a bailout of the corporation that would dwarf the rescue of the failed savings and loan industry.
Today, President Clinton -- who has been holding near-daily events to showcase small-scale Administration initiatives -- used the change in the Federal agency's fortunes to promote his record on pension protection and call on Congress to pass legislation that languished last year, which would require more thorough audits of pension funds.
"Our people deserve to know that if they work hard throughout their lives, the money they worked for and that they saved is not being squandered or left unprotected," Mr. Clinton said, after officials announced the corporation's surplus in the Old Executive Office Building.
The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation insures that if employers who pay premiums to the corporation are granted bankruptcy protection, the Government will meet the companies' obligations to their retirees. The agency insures the pensions of more than 42 million people in about 50,000 private pension plans.
The corporation's multi-employer pension insurance program, covering industries like trucking and construction, has had a surplus since 1982. But its main program, the single-employer pension insurance program, covering about 34 million people, has run a deficit until now.
Administration officials attributed the surplus in the program at the end of 1996 partly to the healthy economy and the fact that there had been no major losses from agency takeovers of failed pension plans. In addition the corporation's investment income exceeded $900 million.
Officials also said that legislation pushed by Mr. Clinton and passed by Congress in 1994 gave the agency new enforcement tools and required that private companies with underfinanced pension plans pay higher premiums. Income from premiums paid to the program totaled more than $1.1 billion in 1996.
Despite the rise in its own fortunes, the corporation reported that inadequate pension plan financing persists across all industries; 15 million workers and retirees are covered by underfinanced pension plans.
In fact, the corporation reported that the gap between promised pension benefits and the money set aside to pay for them increased in 1995, the last year for which figures are available, to $64 billion, more than double the gap reported at the end of 1994.
Officials attributed the growing gap largely to a drop in interest rates in 1995. When interest rates drop, the projected revenues of private pension funds also drop.
Ellen Seidman, a special assistant to the President, said that the legislation passed in 1994 was expected to lead to more fully financed pension plans in the next decade, and "dampen down this kind of fluctuation you get with the interest rate changes."
With dozens of Labor Department employees as his audience today, Mr. Clinton also announced that new Government rules went into effect last month requiring employers to deposit employee contributions to 401(k) plans within 15 business days after the end of the month in which the contribution was made.
And he said that the Labor Department was setting up a toll-free number -- (800) 998-7542 -- that workers could call for information on pension rights.

HEADLINE: Where Africa's Hopes Lie

BYLINE: By Chester A. Crocker; Chester A. Crocker, a professor of diplomacy at Georgetown University, was Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As with any crisis, the civil war in Zaire points to both danger and opportunity. Zaire, with nine neighbors, is the continent's third-largest state -- four times the size of France. What happens in Zaire can make or break sub-Saharan Africa. If the country remains a vast zone of economic decay and political failure, it limits and threatens a whole region. A Zaire on the road to reconstruction and development could open the way to a regional renaissance. There is no more important challenge in Africa.
If this were not Africa, we might be having a serious strategic debate. But Zaire epitomizes a region Americans treat as a strategic backwater. As African states have increasingly differentiated themselves into winners and losers, economically and politically, Zaire has helped to anchor the losing team (along with comparably vast and illgoverned Sudan and Nigeria). 
 Mobutu Sese Seko and his Ngbandi clan may have cornered the market for parasitic kleptocracy and sheer bad governance. But they have no monopoly on African corruption, brutality or economic shortsightedness. In fact, it took foreign intervention, and the spillover effects of the Rwandan genocide of 1994, to spark the current rebellion in Zaire.
Historically, foreign intervention (French, Belgian, American, Moroccan) has primarily favored the Zairian Government. Now, the pattern is reversed: Those neighbors of Zaire that felt the sting of Mr. Mobutu's meddling have turned the tables by backing the Tutsi-dominated rebel alliance led by Laurent Kabila. For Uganda, Rwanda and Angola, it is payback time.
But if the Zairian parties to the conflict fragment and continue fighting, the country's neighbors could become mired in the chaos, adding weight to Africa's losing team. On the other hand, a negotiated transition to a stable post-Mobutu Zaire could bring a powerful boost to the entire region. Failure to capture this potential would be a real lost opportunity not only for Africa but for the rest of the world as well.
Here's why. Zaire is the bridge between the 11 nations of Southern Africa with real potential for development and the rest of Africa, including pockets of progress in East Africa. Zaire's enormous hydropower capacity could meet the electricity needs of much of Central and Southern Africa. The copper belt, which Zaire shares with Zambia, could catapult the African copper mining industry to world-class status.
Mr. Mobutu's recent return to the spotlight in Kinshasa does not mean that a political comeback is in the works or that we have to choose between him and Mr. Kabila. Mr. Mobutu, who has dominated and misruled Zaire since 1965, has been disengaging from real authority for years and may soon be history. His "regime" is less a government than a collection of security services loosely linked to an ineffectual cabinet and an unpaid civilian bureaucracy sharing the capital with nearly 800 fractious parliamentarians and members of the elite political class.
But before we celebrate Mobutu Sese Seko's political demise, we should look at the larger picture. This is not about Mr. Mobutu, who, as a cold-war partner of the West, was at best a truculent and difficult client. It is about how and when he goes, what and who fills the vacuum and whether the Zairian military and political establishment breaks apart, sowing seeds of future turmoil not only in Zaire but throughout the region. It is by no means certain that the political status quo will fall like one ripe fruit into the hands of the rebel alliance. Nor is it guaranteed that the alliance will hold together as it positions itself to take over the country.
Then there is the question of whether Zaire remains intact. For more than three decades, Mr. Mobutu sounded this very theme to extract support from abroad, and we largely accepted his warnings. Given the cold-war competition and the secessionist challenges to the unity of the former Belgian Congo in the early post-independence years, this was understandable. But now that Mr. Mobutu is gravely ill, the threats to national unity and territorial integrity are barely visible. Interestingly, none of the major figures on the Zairian stage are calling for secession. One legacy of the Mobutu regime may be a surprising level of national consciousness among Zairians.
Some argue that Zaire is ungovernably large. But Zairians do not appear to want their country dismantled. And besides, where would the new boundaries be drawn? Who would decide this?
In any case, Africa does not need more mini-states. It most certainly does not need outside encouragement for ethnic opportunists and tribal militias. Warlordism, not self-determination or liberty, would be the result. A divided Zaire invites neighbors to assert and protect their interests. Already, forces from Angola, Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi are operating on Zairian soil.
The United States must choose a strategy for dealing with the conflict in Zaire, a challenge it has so far studiously avoided. American statements, signals, actions and inactions have left important partners, such as France, South Africa and Ethiopia, mystified if not wary. Are we, as the French-speaking rumor mill has it, tacitly supporting Mr. Kabila or his backers? Do we, as some seem to believe, want Zaire dismembered? If not, what are we doing to stop it? Are there circumstances in which we would support a multilateral humanitarian mission, as Canadian, French and United Nations officials have proposed?
We have consulted with European and African allies. We have supported the United Nations wish list for Zaire, which includes a cease-fire, troop withdrawals and elections. We have also made preparations for a military evacuation of Americans from Zaire. This is the foreign policy equivalent of sending in the director of FEMA.
Instead of waiting for events to take their course, we should decide to prevent Zaire from being torn to pieces -- and make that goal a high priority. This means exerting the political will to create and sustain a united front of Zairians, Africans and Western allies committed to a negotiated transition from chaos to a stable post-Mobutu era. The full weight of American influence should be directed at anyone who stands in the way.
Because precious few players in the region have real clout, the closest possible coordination with the Europeans -- and especially France, the other major power in Central Africa -- will be critical. There are policy-makers in both Paris and Washington who continue to view each other's approaches to Africa with distaste and suspicion. This has only aggravated the divisions among some 20 African countries over the conflicts in Zaire and Sudan.
Squabbling between France and the United States over influence and prestige, as well as strategic differences, is an unacceptable luxury in today's Africa. Working together would help unite the Zairians, and Africans in general. This is what leadership and leverage are all about.

HEADLINE: Welfare Recipients Taking Jobs Often Held by the Working Poor

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Josephine Araujo was already an hour into her shift when Sarah Thompson punched in for work on the 17th floor of the towering Jersey City Medical Center. Ms. Thompson was not happy to see Ms. Araujo, but she hid her annoyance in small talk. And soon the women were going about their duties, taking patients for X-rays, rehabilitation, blood tests.
Ms. Thompson and Ms. Araujo, near in age and engaged in the same tasks, nevertheless see themselves at opposite ends of the work force. Ms. Araujo, 42, is on welfare and has been working at the hospital since last summer, but not for wages. Ms. Thompson, 44, had been a full-time, salaried employee for 27 years, until December, when her hours were cut to 20 a week from 40, and her pay to $11,000 from $22,000. Ms. Araujo picked up some of her work. 
 "What infuriates me," said Rex Reid, an administrator of the welfare program in the Jersey City area, "is that you read in the newspapers that hospitals like the Jersey City Medical Center are laying off workers, or cutting their hours. And at the same time, we get requests from the Medical Center for welfare people."
Job displacement is entering the debate over welfare reform. Across the country, thousands of people on welfare are going to work, but often not at new jobs created for them, as President Clinton envisioned when he signed the welfare-to-work legislation last fall. Frequently they do work once done by regular employees, like Ms. Thompson. Under the new Federal law and a proliferation of state laws, welfare officials are required to send people on aid out to jobs, even to jobs that do not pay during indefinite training periods.
Many others on welfare compete successfully for low-wage jobs that might otherwise have gone to the working poor not on welfare, nearly 30 percent of the work force. And although they are coming off welfare, many have the advantage of a year or more of child-care subsidies and transportation allowances.
"What we have is a limited number of chairs," said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, "and there are a lot of potential workers circling these chairs, waiting for someone to get up."
Regardless of who gets the job, wages are held down, economists say, contributing to the income inequality that is such a national issue today. With the American economy thriving and unemployment low, employers frequently find themselves scrambling to find enough entry-level workers. Normally, they raise wages to lure people who would not otherwise be willing to take these jobs. But with the injection of so many welfare recipients as workers, the wage pressure is dulled.
That's evident at SOS Staffing Services, based in Salt Lake City, which placed 70,000 people in temporary jobs in Western states last year. Earning $6 to $8 an hour, these people worked on factory assembly lines, in warehouses, as office clerks and in telemarketing. Five thousand of the 70,000, or 7 percent, had come to SOS Staffing while still collecting welfare benefits, and roughly the same percentage are coming off welfare this year into temporary work through SOS, said Richard Reinhold, the company's chairman.
"Without the welfare people," Mr. Reinhold said, "we cannot fill all our orders for temps. To get enough people without them, we would have had to raise the wage -- not by a lot, maybe 5 percent -- but we would have had to pay more."
The migration to work is required under laws that penalize welfare recipients for failing to move into some sort of work before their eligibility for welfare is up. But President Clinton spoke against job displacement, calling instead in recent speeches for millions of new jobs to accommodate welfare workers.
Some of the latter do move into newly created jobs. "Empowerment zones" in downtown Detroit, for example, are attracting small companies like GFC Industries, an auto parts maker. GFC has trained and hired 21 neighborhood people, many of them on welfare, to work in a recently opened factory. But more often, welfare recipients move into existing jobs, or they hold down wages simply by coming into the work force, as the SOS temps are doing, or they remain on welfare for an unpaid training period. In New Jersey, Ms. Araujo's state, that period can last two years or more without an employer's ever being required to hire the trainee.
Clinton Administration officials recognize the problems, but say they see the glass as more than half full.
"Of course, sometimes individual workers get jobs that otherwise might have gone to someone else," said Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, "but the economy expands as they go to work and other firms hire more people. There is every reason to believe that helping welfare recipients get back to work raises the total number of jobs."
Mr. Summers added that the working poor not on welfare got help from other Federal programs, like the earned-income tax credit.
Displacement falls most heavily on the 38 million working poor holding jobs that pay $7.50 an hour or less. The majority of these workers, like the majority of people on welfare, have only high school educations or less. They have faced competition in the past from immigrants and from groups of disadvantaged Americans who have benefited from earlier public jobs programs.
But no federally subsidized jobs program since the Depression has involved as many people as does the welfare-to-work push. And none have pressured state officials to shift welfare recipients to work so quickly. Each state is required to meet annual job quotas, or lose some of its Federal block grants for welfare. By the turn of the century, nearly 50 percent of all adults receiving welfare assistance must spend at least 30 hours a week in some sort of work. As a result, more than four million people on welfare will go to work, according to various estimates.
Economists say they have not devised ways to measure the job displacement that is already part of the transition.
"There is no research at all yet," said Rebecca Blank, a labor economist and poverty expert at Northwestern University.
But the anecdotal evidence is accumulating. In Baltimore, nine public schools brought in welfare recipients at $1.50 an hour, well below the minimum wage of $4.75 an hour, rather than renew contracts with agencies that supplied cleaning people at $6 an hour. The new workers continue to receive federally financed welfare benefits, at no cost to the schools.
Similarly, the Citywide Bus Company, which transports children to the Baltimore public schools, is training welfare recipients, also at $1.50 an hour, to be aides. That makes Veronica Jiggetts nervous. She has been an aide for eight years on a bus for disabled children.
"One of the welfare workers was on my bus one morning," said Miss Jiggetts, who earns $6.60 an hour and works 25 hours a week. "I had to show her how to lift these kids and buckle them into their seats, and I felt bad because I thought she could take my job from me.
"So I went to the office and asked, What were they trying to do, take away my job? And they said, 'No, Miss Jiggetts, we are not trying to take you off your job.'
"But the way it looks to me, I might not be invited back for September."
The Industrial Areas Foundation, which is organizing low-wage workers in Baltimore, drew a thousand people to a rally in the city on March 16, the largest protest thus far of worker displacement from welfare changes. Their protest was directed, in part, at the fact that people like Ms. Araujo and the bus aides on welfare are allowed to work without being covered by the minimum-wage law and the various protections of the Fair Labor Standards Act.
Marriott Hotels, held up frequently as a model in implementing welfare to work, recognizes that those coming from welfare into housekeeping, reservations, the kitchen and other Marriott jobs have an edge over the working poor without welfare. The chain has trained and hired 650 welfare recipients nationwide since 1991, but once on the job, earning $6 to $8 an hour, these workers continue for months to receive child care and transportation subsidies that inflate their incomes, said Joan Tully, director of Marriott's community employment and training programs.
The chain also gets a tax credit to employ people from welfare in jobs that, as Ms. Tully notes, might otherwise go to non-welfare applicants for whom the hotel can get no tax credit.
"Something has to be done to offset the extra cost of hiring these workers," she said, "but, yes, the jobs we have pay off more for them than for working poor not on welfare. The working poor are getting the short end of the stick."
Similarly, the City of Richmond, starting today, will send 2,000 people on welfare into existing but unfilled jobs at more than two dozen companies that have signed up to participate, at wages of $7 an hour or less. Some 4,000 additional welfare recipients, in need of training, will be fed into jobs more slowly. The participating companies include AT&T, National Car Rental, restaurants, nursing homes and Norrell Services, a temporary help agency.
This influx of workers will stabilize pay scales in the city, said Keith Wine, Norrell's manager in Richmond, who noted that the metropolitan area, with an unemployment rate of 3 percent, suffered from labor shortages.
"Everyone has been raising wages to get people," Mr. Wine said, "and this will make it possible to hold pay steady."
The displacement issue shows up most vividly in the programs that send people out, ostensibly for training, to do tasks without pay that once were done by regular employees who have had their wages reduced or their hours shortened. That is the situation Ms. Araujo and Ms. Thompson find themselves in. In New York City, they show up by the thousands in the Parks Department or as street cleaners or in sanitation or as receptionists, often handling work that laid-off city workers once did.
But while Ms. Thompson hopes that her hours will be restored so she will not have to take a second job to pay her mortgage, and Ms. Araujo yearns to be hired by the hospital, the medical center's managers say neither will happen. Budget constraints forced a cut in Ms. Thompson's hours, the managers say, and Ms. Araujo is listed not as a trainee but as a volunteer.
"The workfare program is to get welfare people into the rhythm and habits of going to work," said Jonathan M. Metsch, the medical center's president, "and we folded it into our volunteer operation. This is work volunteers normally do in hospitals. There is no issue of displacement."
The Giuliani Administration in New York City has a similar stance. The cuts in the regular work force cannot be reversed; the city lacks the money, said Richard J. Schwartz, who until February was Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's senior adviser on welfare reform.
The workfare people -- 36,000 in New York City -- are a windfall, Mr. Schwartz said. If they were not out cleaning streets or working in parks, he said, the streets would simply be dirtier and the parks more unkempt than they now are.

HEADLINE: Debt Issues Fuel Gain in Underwriting

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Stock and bond underwriting rose 12 percent in the first three months of 1997, even as rising interest rates indicate a potential slowdown in sales over the coming year.
The first-quarter surge was fueled by the sale of bonds and other debt, which rose to $239.3 billion in the first quarter, compared with $214.6 billion in the similar period of 1996. 
But higher interest rates, a weakness in technology stocks and investor trepidation about corporate earnings growth dampened underwriting volume in other areas. Sales of common stock in the United States declined 7 percent, to $21.3 billion, according to the Securities Data Company. The most drastic drop in equity issues came in the underwriting volume for initial public offerings, which fell nearly 30 percent, to $5.9 billion, from $8.6 billion in the first three months of 1996.
"The recent volatility in the marketplace and the rise in interest rates has begun to affect the new issue market," Brian Hehir, co-chief of global equity markets at Merrill Lynch & Company, said. "It had its most impact on the I.P.O. volume, which is down. And the new-issue backlog is only about $13 billion at a time when we should be approaching our seasonal peak."
In the first quarter, the securities industry underwrote $273.3 billion worth of domestic debt and equity issues, up from $245 billion in the comparable period last year, according to Securities Data.
Merrill Lynch remained the top debt and equity underwriter over all, a position it has held since 1988. Merrill underwrote 312 deals worth more than $44 billion. Goldman, Sachs & Company came in second, followed by Salomon Brothers, J. P. Morgan & Company and Lehman Brothers. The five firms collectively accounted for nearly 60 percent of all underwriting fees.
The total disclosed fees collected by all underwriting firms fell by 9.8 percent in the first quarter to $1.8 billion, according to Securities Data. At Morgan Stanley Group Inc., underwriting fees fell almost 42 percent in the first quarter to $132.6 million. But Merrill; Goldman; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a unit of the Equitable Companies; Lehman Brothers and J. P. Morgan reported higher income for the three-month period, indicating that the largest firms, with the most access to global markets, are tightening their grip on underwriting and are able to offset declines in the United States with activity in Europe, Asia or Latin America.
Interest rates rose in the last month as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's decision last week to increase the overnight lending rate in an effort to stem inflation. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, a benchmark for setting prices on other debt, climbed above 7 percent for the first time since September. The 4 percent drop in the Nasdaq composite index in the last month only increased the uneasiness among investors.
"We've seen a weakness in the secondary markets in telecommunications and technology areas, traditionally a big part of the markets," said Marc L. Paley, the managing director at Lehman Brothers who is in charge of equity syndications. "To the degree that the secondary market is volatile, it'll hurt the new issue market in a major way."
But interest rates are not yet so high as to discourage companies like Raytheon and Norfolk Southern and other companies engaged in strategic acquisitions from entering the bond markets, said John Massad, a partner at J. P. Morgan in charge of debt syndication. Certainly the cash is there. Attracted by the higher interest rates, insurance companies, pension funds and mutual funds continue to funnel money into bonds.
"The rise in interest rates has been relatively modest, and relative to historic levels, interest rates are still at attractive levels," Mr. Massad said. "So companies are still issuing debt. The volume may be off as much as 20 percent in the coming quarter, but we don't expect a dramatic decline. These rates are still attractive to issuers."
But rising interest rates may affect the junk bond market, which saw a 20.6 percent jump in offerings in the first quarter. Donaldson, Lufkin, the leading firm in the field, underwrote the largest high-yield bond so far of the 1990's, the $2 billion sale of debt by Tenet Healthcare.
"This was a very attractive time to issue long-term capital," said Bennett Goodman, who heads the high-yield bond department at Donaldson. "Interest rates were very low, and the typical high-yield bond had a 9.5 precent coupon, while Treasuries were yielding 6.5 percent."
But with interest rates rising on high-yield bonds, corporations may opt to go elsewhere for money. "High yield bonds may not be as attractive as bank debt or selling equity related security," Mr. Goodman said. "Right now there's a very hot bank-debt market, and that'll begin to cannibalize the high-yield market."

HEADLINE: Newt Gingrich on China

 BODY:
It would be understandable if the Chinese leadership were confused about America's China policy after the recent visits by Vice President Al Gore and House Speaker Newt Gingrich. Mr. Gore arrived with a conciliatory message about improving relations and seemed hobbled by the White House fund-raising mess. Mr. Gingrich delivered a forceful statement of concern about China's human rights abuses and suppression of dissent, and even threw in a gratuitous commitment to defend Taiwan militarily if it was attacked by China.
Mr. Gingrich is entitled to his views, and his comments about China's record were refreshingly candid compared with the oblique criticism favored these days by the Clinton Administration. But Mr. Gingrich was presumptuous to speak for the United States, particularly on the sensitive issue of Taiwan. It is not for Congressional leaders to set the terms of American foreign policy or to make blanket commitments about the use of force. 
 That said, Mr. Gingrich's comments on the Chinese political scene were in some ways more honest than Mr. Gore's anemic formulations. The Clinton emphasis on engagement and trade has severely undercut American support for human rights and democracy in China.
Mr. Gore seemed to go out of his way last week to praise "a significant advance in the process of democracy" in China that few others have been able to detect. He also appeared to downplay American concerns over China's heavy-handed approach to Hong Kong, which will revert to Chinese control on July 1.
In contrast, Mr. Gingrich chose Hong Kong as his platform to warn Chinese leaders that attempts to confine freedom to economic issues while refusing to allow it in politics would surely fail. He referred explicitly to "the lack of basic freedom -- speech, religion, assembly, the press" in China today. The Speaker maintained this same blunt tone in his talks with Chinese leaders. It would not be a bad idea if Administration officials adopted the same straight-speaking approach.
The Administration, like its predecessors, has wisely left the Chinese to think hard about how America would react to an invasion of Taiwan by the mainland. Washington and Beijing have long understood that good relations depend on China's dealing peacefully with Taiwan. Beijing is not likely to mistake a lack of specificity for softness, particularly after the dispatch of two American aircraft carrier groups to waters off Taiwan during last year's Chinese missile tests.
That Mr. Gore and Mr. Gingrich offered such divergent messages may well be explained by the political predicament each man faces in Washington. Mr. Gore, eager to protect his Presidential aspirations in 2000, was cautious to a fault while in China, so anxious to appear evenhanded that he ended up looking ineffectual. Mr. Gingrich, battered by his ethics case and virtually invisible in Washington in recent weeks, returned to center stage in China carrying the banner for a more assertive China policy.
Some China specialists have encouraged the Clinton Administration to keep the Chinese off balance by mixing conciliation and confrontation. That may work in theory, but after the Gore and Gingrich visits the idea looks untenable. The only impression the Chinese got was that the United States does not have a coherent China policy, or even a clear chain of command.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
