HEADLINE: TALKING BUSINESS WITH: Joseph B. Rose;
Governors Island: A Gift That Bears a Close Look

 BODY:
Is Governors Island slipping away?
"They are dithering," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said last week, complaining that city and state officials had failed to respond to a 1995 offer from President Clinton to help transfer the island for $1 if New York would present a plan for its public use. Now, the Senator said, without a plan in place, many in Congress want to sell off the scenic 173-acre tract in New York Harbor as excess Government property, and have been encouraged by a Federal estimate of its value to developers: $500 million. 
 Advisers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, who have engaged in sporadic infighting over control of economic development projects, insisted that internal rivalries were not affecting Governors Island, which is to be vacated by the Coast Guard this summer. The island, less than a half-mile from Manhattan and Brooklyn, has been a military installation for over 200 years, and combines a historic district of elegant 19th-century buildings with broad open spaces and sweeping views of the city.
At City Hall, officials acknowledge that their response to the President has been slow, but not for lack of attention to an economic equation that they say is far more complex than most New Yorkers realize.
Joseph B. Rose, the director of the Department of City Planning, is one of the top strategists creating a plan for Governors Island. He discussed the island's prospects yesterday in an interview with Thomas J. Lueck:

Q. Why not simply jump on the President's offer of a spectacular public space for $1?
 
A. Just to maintain the historic buildings and infrastructure on Governors Island would cost somewhere between $30 million and $60 million a year, and the city is not in a position to make that kind of expenditure. I don't mean to sound ungrateful for the President's willingness to make it available, but the Federal Government is unloading a financial responsibility that is not acceptible unless we have uses for the island that will cover the expense of operating and maintaining it.
 
Q. But if the island is worth $500 million to developers, by one Federal estimate, don't you run the risk that private interests will grab it?
 
A. Nobody who has any familiarity with the island, its condition, the constraints on development and the realities of the real estate market would take a number like $500 million seriously. When the Coast Guard said it was leaving, there was some speculation about large-scale real-estate development but when people saw what they were up against they headed for the hills. In fact, we haven't encountered anybody who is willing to make an offer at any price, and it is not clear that the island could be sold. It is important that we make it clear to the Federal Government that it is not going to sell this thing and make a lot of money.
 
Q. Other islands in big cities, like Roosevelt Island in the East River, have been developed. What is the problem here?
 
A. Access is the big one. You can only get to Governors Island by ferryboat, and that service has been costing the Coast Guard $6 million a year to operate. We have examined the idea of building a bridge, and that would be incredibly expensive because it would go over important navigational channels. A bridge would require vertical clearance of 150 feet, and it just won't be built.
 
Q. If we are limited to ferry service, couldn't the city expect a private ferry operator to step in?
 
A. Yes, any plan is likely to rely on privatized ferry service. But to justify frequent service, you have to have the appropriate uses on the island. Bed-and-breakfast accommodations wouldn't make it work.
 
Q. Since it already runs Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, shouldn't the Federal Government turn Governors Island into a national park?
 
A. That would certainly be consistent with the responsibilities of the park service, but it has expressed no interest in extending the Federal obligation to Governors Island. Perhaps that is why the White House is willing to dispose of the island so cheaply.
 
Q. So you are looking for nonprofit organizations that would use the island and pay for its maintenance. Can you be more specific?
 
A. The island is designed as a campuslike setting, and the easiest transition for its historic buildings would be to some kind of educational complex. Perhaps with accessories like a hospital. What is required would be a large institution that would find the island attractive and would have residential and facility needs sufficient to justify a large investment.
 
Q. The public has been kept off Governors Island since the Revolution. Would it finally have access?
 
A. Yes, that is a top priority. It matters less to us that the city owns the island than that its historic buildings are protected and it is opened up for public access.
 
Q. Senator Moynihan said the city and state must act quickly, suggesting that a plan for the island should be submitted by the end of the year. Will you be ready?
 
A. I don't know if there is any particular deadline, but the Senator's sense of urgency is appropriate. That is not so much because Congress can turn around and sell it for $500 million, but because the maintenance and reuse of the historic buildings on the island could be jeopardized after the the Coast Guard leaves. Even though there is a Federal obligation to maintain them, history shows that buildings like these tend to fall apart when they are not being used. And the bureaucracy involved in the disposition process at the Federal level is certain to take time. So time is the real enemy here, and we expect to have a plan in place well before the end of the year.
 
Q. The Regional Plan Association has made proposals for what it wants on the island, like a marina and bed-and-breakfast accommodations. Will those ideas be considered?
 
A. We are always ready to listen. But those proposals are vague and irresponsible, because they are being made without any recognition of the realities and costs confronting the island. We know from history that rhetoric without any grounding in economics is a recipe for disaster. In this case, the R.P.A. has provided very little of value.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph B. Rose, the director of New York City's Planning Department, is one of the top strategists working on a city plan for Governors Island. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Bad First Quarter for U.S. Stock Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The average mutual fund investing in American stocks had its worst performance in more than two years during the first quarter, and funds specializing in United States high-technology companies were particularly weak, losing an average of more than 6 percent. But a mutual fund that invests in heavy industry in the former Soviet Union gained more than 40 percent.
If the first quarter of 1997 left American investors without a gyroscope, there is likely to be more confusion in store. Since last week, when the Federal Reserve lifted interest rates for the first time in two years, the stock and bond markets have suffered a small convulsion of selling, capped by the biggest two-session decline since August 1990. 
 That has some financial advisers telling investors to dig in and expect the rough time to continue for several months.
"We're getting more defensive," said Louis Stanasolovich, president of Legend Financial Advisors of Pittsburgh. "We certainly are not telling people to sell their entire portfolio, but we are advising them to look to put new cash to work in different areas, making sure their portfolio is diversified away from the S.& P. 500."
So far, mutual fund investors have stayed the course, slowing their pace of new mutual fund purchases since the beginning of the year but not yet pulling money out on a broad scale. Some sectors of the fund industry, though, have already started to suffer redemptions -- technology funds and, more recently, the most aggressive types of general equity funds -- raising once again the question of how investors will react to a broader, or extended, market downturn.
Over all, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund tracking organization, the average domestic equity fund gained 2 percent in the first quarter. That is the weakest quarterly performance since the fourth quarter of 1994, when domestic stock funds lost 1.3 percent on average.
Thus far in 1997, the best-performing mutual funds have been those that cast their nets overseas. According to Morningstar, funds specializing in Latin America gained about 16 percent on average since Jan. 1, while more general emerging market funds gained about 9 percent. And the fund that invests in Russian heavy industry, Lexington Troika Dialog Russia, gained 46 percent in the first quarter, making it one of the period's best performers.
Among funds that invest in a broad array of American stocks, those following a "value" style performed better than those investing in "growth" stocks, and large-capitalization funds did better than their brethren that invest in companies with smaller market values.
Large-cap value funds, which buy shares of big companies that are trading at relatively low price-to-earnings ratios, and large-cap funds that buy a blend of value and growth stocks, outpaced the field, gaining an average of about 3 percent, according to Morningstar. Funds favoring small growth companies, or those whose sales and earnings are growing quickly but which often trade at high price-earnings multiples, took the hardest hit, losing about 11 percent on average.
Some sectors that performed most poorly, like technology, have also suffered net redemptions. According to AMG Data Services, an Arcata, Calif., company that tracks mutual fund flows, investors have withdrawn more money than they have placed into technology funds for seven of the last eight weeks.
And in each of the last two weeks, both aggressive growth funds, which buy shares of the smallest, fastest- growing companies, and broader growth funds, which buy the stocks of slightly bigger companies, have suffered net outflows, AMG said.
What has some people on Wall Street worried is that it might not take huge redemptions by mutual fund investors to erode some of the stock market's strongest underpinnings. Rather, a pronounced slowdown in new purchases of mutual funds by individuals could be enough to trouble a broad array of investors and thus damage the market.
Melissa Brown, a quantitative analyst at Prudential Securities, said she was not yet worried by the trickle of money exiting certain fund categories. "Some people could make the case that liquidity is going away," she said. "But I'm more concerned with cash levels of equity funds," which gives an indication of their future buying power.
At the end of February, domestic equity funds held 5.3 percent of their assets in cash, the lowest level since January 1977. Over all, including international and specialty funds, cash levels in stock funds equaled 5.7 percent of assets.
Even if funds are not hit with redemptions, forcing them to sell shares to raise cash, their current low levels of cash might cause problems, Ms. Brown said. "They might not be set up to buy anything," she said. "All of the support that's been going to the market could go away."
The question of how investors will react to a market downturn is a subject of constant debate within the mutual fund industry. The Investment Company Institute, a trade group, last year produced a study showing that stock fund owners had not liquidated shares en masse in any stock-market setback since 1944.
Rather, the trade group said, investors spread out their response over time. A shift from inflows to outflows of cash was traced to adjustments in the pace of share purchases rather than in changes in rates of redemptions.
But with the rapid growth of the mutual fund industry in the last few years, many market analysts wonder whether investors will continue to be as steadfast as in previous market downturns.
Indeed, the amount of money in equity mutual funds at the end of 1990, just after the stock market experienced its last broad decline of 10 percent -- an event Wall Street calls a correction -- was about $247 billion. That is only 13 percent of the $1.8 trillion invested in stock funds at the end of February.
"Almost all of the money in equity mutual funds hasn't really been through a bear market," Ms. Brown of Prudential said. "It's hard to say what those people will do" if stock prices continue to decline.
 Because of the erroneous calculations, the chart also misstated the return for the Vanguard Index 500 fund. It gained 2.6 percent in the quarter, not 4.92 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 2, 1997, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart in Business Day yesterday about how mutual funds did in the first quarter misstated the performance of domestic equity funds because of calculation errors by Morningstar Inc. The average equity fund lost 1.6 percent of its value in the quarter; it did not gain 2 percent. A related article appears today on page D2.

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant 

 BODY:

An Ecce Panis for Columbus Ave.
A new Ecce Panis bakery opens today at 282 Columbus Avenue (73d Street). It is the third store for the company. The other Ecce Panis bakeries are at 1260 Madison Avenue (90th Street) and 1120 Third Avenue (65th Street). In addition to the sourdough, Tuscan, raisin, ciabatta and rosemary breads, and sweet and savory focaccias for which the company is known, the bakeries will also sell baguettes and a new olive bread. The company's new wholesale bakery in New Jersey has made the expansion possible.

Culinary Careers
Career opportunities in the food industry will be discussed on Monday from 6 to 9 P.M. at the French Culinary Institute, 462 Broadway (Grand Street). It is free, but reservations are necessary: (212) 219-8890. 

Beer and Food to Taste
Beers from more than two dozen of this country's microbreweries and food from 21 New York restaurants will be offered for tasting at Bridgewaters in the South Street Seaport on April 14 from 5 to 8 P.M. The occasion, an American Institute of Wine and Food benefit, will admit nonmembers at 6 P.M. Tickets are $30 for members, $40 for nonmembers. Information: (212) 447-0456.

Off the Menu
 
Not Coco Pazzo Clones
The conversion of the restaurants in the Sfuzzi chain to Coco Pazzos has started with the opening tomorrow of Coco Opera, 58 West 65th Street. Pino Luongo, whose company, Toscorp, owns the restaurants, is not creating Coco Pazzo clones, despite similar frescos on the walls and some recipes in common. He has simplified the name to avoid confusion. Coco Marina, in the World Financial Center, is also to open this month.

A Hop From Market to Table
Milos Estiatorio (Greek for Windmill Restaurant), opening in May at 125 West 55th Street, will be a market-restaurant with a difference. Diners can select fish or shellfish displayed on ice and priced by the pound, and then watch as it is grilled in the open kitchen. Seafood prices will start at $18 a pound for farmed salmon. Vegetables and other dishes will also be on display.
Costas Spiliades, who has owned Milos, a similar restaurant in Montreal, since 1980, is spending $4 million to build the 150-seat Milos Estiatorio, designed by Charles Morris Mount. It will occupy 9,000 square feet of space with 26-foot ceilings.

More Choices From Sofia's
Sofia's Fabulous Pizza, on the second floor at 1022 Madison Avenue (79th Street), will open a cafe this week at street level, with coffee, juices, sandwiches, gelati and, yes, pizza. Sofia's expects to open a second spot this spring, at 29 East 61st Street.

Triplets for World Trade Center
Tony May, who owns San Domenico on Central Park South and Hostaria in Port Chester, N.Y., plans to open Gemelli at 4 World Trade Center. Although Gemelli means twins, the 9,500-square-foot restaurant will have three parts. The first, a midprice Italian restaurant, Gemelli, is to open in June, to be followed by Pastabreak, for quick-service pasta on the Trade Center's concourse. In the fall, Mr. May plans to add a self-service restaurant.

Dining Companions
Two new dining guides to New York City fill some gaps. "The Authoritative New York City Kosher Dining Guide" by Bela Flom (Bela Flom Enterprises, $19.95) covers all boroughs with descriptions and evaluations of 220 restaurants, including prices, hours and information about the type of kosher supervision and how strictly it is enforced. Neighborhood maps are also given. The book is available in bookstores or by mail by calling (718) 332-8547.
With reviews of only 400 restaurants, "Passport to New York" by Peter and Amy Meltzer and John F. Mariani (Passport Press, $10.95) is hardly encyclopedic. But the listings in this pocket-size guide are fairly detailed and include some places, like Patroon, Quilty's and Firebird, that opened late last year. The guide also offers previews of places that are due to open.

HEADLINE: Success on Recycling

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Yes, recycling is growing in Manhattan. But left unsaid in your March 31 news article were two bits of good news: First, the best-performing community districts will now reach 35 percent or more diversion of recyclables from total waste, showing that the requirements of the recycling law are achievable. 
 Second, all wastepaper collected in Manhattan will be delivered by barge to the city's first paper mill on Staten Island. If a second mill, being developed by the Natural Resources Defense Council, gets built in the Bronx, every ounce of wastepaper collected by the Sanitation Department will be recycled into new paper products within the city's borders.
Those jobs and economic activity sure beat shipping garbage -- and dollars -- to landfills outside New York City and are a testament to the importance of staying the course in expanding the recycling collection system.
 
KENDALL CHRISTIANSEN
Chairman, Citywide
Recycling Advisory Board
Brooklyn, April 1, 1997

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on U.S. Warning Over Japan's Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday, hurt by a warning from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin about Japan's trade surplus and by expectations that a Japanese economic report would show surprising strength.
Those factors fueled speculation among currency traders that the two-year-old retreat against the dollar might be coming to an end. That helped push the dollar to a three-week low against the yen, a six-week low against the mark and a 10-week low against the pound. 
 Uncertainty about the direction of the United States stock market after two days of heavy losses also weighed on the dollar. But traders said Wall Street's mixed finish on Tuesday was a secondary influence and the primary force driving currency dealings was the yen's strength.
"We've broken away from levels where we've been at for weeks," said David Becker, senior dealer at Bank Austria in New York. "Once we breached some technical levels, it just propelled itself. That's what's been dominating the market today."
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 121.76 yen, down from 123.80 yen on Monday and the lowest level since March 10. The dollar fell to 1.6656 marks, from 1.6770 marks Monday, and was the lowest since Feb. 10. The pound rose to $1.6528 from $1.6395 and was the strongest since Jan. 21.
The yen was bolstered by expectations that the Bank of Japan's widely watched quarterly survey of business sentiment, known as the Tankan survey, would show unexpected optimism about Japan's economic outlook and could presage rising interest rates in Japan. Those rates have languished at record lows since September 1995, depressing demand for yen. The Tankan report is due to be released today.
Mr. Rubin hurt the dollar further in remarks to reporters in Washington before his three-day Asian tour, which begins Friday in Tokyo. He said Japan had made progress in reducing its trade surpluses "but the issue is not to have it go back the other way."
The remarks were viewed as a warning that Japan should not use a cheaper yen to export its way back to strong economic growth. A lower-priced yen makes Japanese goods more competitive abroad.

HEADLINE: Unfazed by Gingrich, China Agrees With Some of What He Said

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 1

 BODY:
The Government indicated today that it was essentially pleased with remarks over the weekend by Newt Gingrich, who said last week during a visit to China that he accepted a one-China policy but asserted that the United States would defend Taiwan militarily if it was attacked.
The one-China policy has been at the heart of relations between the United States and China since President Nixon established ties with Beijing in 1972. In signing the Shanghai Communique then, the United States and China effectively deferred the issue of a resolution to the simmering civil war that has kept Taiwan and the mainland divided since 1949. In the meantime, a robust economic boom in the region has drawn the two enemies close together. 
 At a news briefing today, Shen Guofang, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, said of the House Speaker's visit: "Mr. Gingrich mentioned several times in Beijing that he opposed Taiwan independence and approved the principle of one China. He also expressed that the American Government and the American Congress will stick to the principle of one China."
With little rancor, Mr. Shen highlighted the positive points in Mr. Gingrich's remarks, which were made to reporters in Shanghai on Sunday, before the Speaker and his party of 12 members of Congress left for Tokyo and a final stop in Taiwan before returning to the United States.
Mr. Shen did not take issue with Mr. Gingrich's pointed warning that if the mainland should use military force against Taiwan, "we will defend Taiwan. Period." The Chinese spokesman said: "Referring to what he said in Shanghai, China has always stood for the position of peaceful unification" with Taiwan.
"However," Mr. Shen said, "the Chinese side will take necessary measures if Taiwan declares independence or if foreign powers interfere in the Taiwan issue." What those measures might turn out to be, he said, "is the internal affair of China."
Mr. Gingrich's remarks on defending Taiwan seemed to undermine the "strategic ambiguity" by which the United States has avoided issuing a direct warning to China over the use of force, in part because such a warning might incite the pro-independence forces on Taiwan.
The White House issued a statement on Sunday that while it did not rebuke Mr. Gingrich, said that he "was speaking for himself." The statement reiterated that the United States was committed by the Taiwan Relations Act to provide an "adequate self-defense" for Taiwan, while also insisting that both parties "peacefully address the Taiwan issue."
But some China specialists argued today that Mr. Gingrich's formulation, balanced between his public commitment to "one China" and a determination that no party can solve the Taiwan issue by force, amounted to a clear statement of American political sentiment in the wake of the 1996 Taiwan crisis. In March of last year, China carried out military exercises off Taiwan as the island was holding its first direct popular vote for President. Beijing viewed the election as undermining the one-China principle.
Other specialists worry that Mr. Gingrich's remarks were not sufficiently nuanced. Kenneth G. Lieberthal, a China scholar at the University of Michigan, said Mr. Gingrich seemed to commit the United States to defending Taiwan even if Taiwan took provocative steps like making unilateral statements that could be construed as declarations of independence.
"If this point is left unclear in Taiwan, there are potential downside risks to his statements in China," Professor Lieberthal said.

HEADLINE: Merrill Investigating Derivatives Accounting

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 1

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company said today that it was investigating some "unreconciled balances" in its equity derivatives accounts in Britain after a change in reporting lines for the derivatives business last year.
Merrill said no clients' funds were affected by the inconsistencies in the accounts and that they would not result in any material impact on its business or earnings. 
 "This matter is entirely about internal accounting at Merrill Lynch," a spokesman, Richard Silverman, saud. "No clients have been affected financially in any way, and there will be no meaningful repercussions from this matter."
The investigation comes amid increasing concern in Britain about derivatives accounting after the disclosure last month by National Westminster Bank P.L.C. that a former trader had built hidden losses of as much as 90 million ($147.6 million) in interest rate derivatives during the last three years.
Mr. Silverman said there were no such losses in Merrill's accounts. He said Merrill had informed Britain's Securities and Futures Authority of the unreconciled balances and would keep it apprised of the inquiry.
The inconsistencies in the balances were discovered after Merrill changed its accounts reporting structure late last year to have the equity derivatives business in London report to Merrill Lynch International, a Britain-regulated entity, from Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.

HEADLINE: Data Point to More Growth, But With Inflation in Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Evidence mounted today that the economy accelerated markedly in recent weeks, though inflation appeared to remain in check.
In what analysts considered the most important of three fresh sets of strong figures, corporate purchasing executives reported that their index of factory activity climbed in March to match its highest reading in more than two years. 
 The employment component of the index rose after 24 consecutive months of contraction in the number of factory jobs, and suppliers needed more time to deliver goods.
But the report, by the National Association of Purchasing Management, also showed an easing of the group's prices-paid component, a gauge of inflation.
That at least temporarily offered some hope to the securities markets that another increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve was not imminent and perhaps not inevitable. The Fed raised rates last week for the first time in more than two years because of fears that strong growth would lead to a resurgence of inflation. Today, the stock market recovered from an early setback and the Dow Jones industrial average finished with a gain. Bond prices rose slightly.
The economy is displaying "really robust growth," said James E. Annable Jr., chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago. But the figures showing inflation still well contained, he said, mean that the Fed still lacks "a smoking gun to be aggressive" about further increases in interest rates.
And while more economists, including Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch, decided today to raise their estimates of first-quarter growth to 3.5 percent or more, he and others expressed confidence that the economy would slow significantly in the quarter that began today.
"The economy's going to cool down," declared Maury N. Harris of Paine Webber, contending that it was being temporarily buoyed by the actions of home buyers worried about mortgage rates moving up further and employers afraid to delay hiring for fear that workers would soon become unavailable.
Also today, the Conference Board, a business research group, reported that the index of leading indicators rose strongly in February. And the Government reported that construction spending that month posted the biggest gain since March 1994.
But it was the surprisingly large increase in the purchasing managers' index, to 55 points in March from 53.1 in February, that captured most of the attention since this gauge is not only more current but contains price and supplier data that policy makers consider particularly useful.
But the report's price index fell to 50.9 points from 55.1, "indicating a slower rate of price increase," the association said. Only 15 percent of the corporate buyers reported paying higher prices, down from 18 percent in February, while the proportion of those paying lower prices climbed to 16 percent from 9 percent. The rest found prices unchanged.
The supplier deliveries index, which rose to 53.6 points from 51.3, showed 8 percent of executives reporting vendors less able to meet order schedules, compared with 5 percent in February. At the same time, 4 percent reported faster deliveries, up from 2 percent.
And factory jobs, reversing a two-year decline, surged in March to a reading of 51.6 from 45.4 percent, suggesting that Friday's Government report on the March labor market will show revived growth. In the association's report, a reading over 50 indicates an increase while one of less than that represents a decline.
The Conference Board's index of leading indicators, intended to predict turns in the business cycle, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in February, after a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent in January; it was the biggest since February 1996. Nine of the 10 components in the report contributed to the increase, paced by a reduced number of people making first-time claims for unemployment insurance and by slower deliveries by vendors.
The only negative was the interest-rate spread, a recent addition calculated by subtracting the Federal funds rate from the rate on 10-year Treasury bonds. A narrower differential suggests slower growth ahead or, should short rates exceed long ones, recession.
The Commerce Department's tally of new construction showed activity rose 2.3 percent in February from January, to an annual rate of $603.8 billion, the fastest in almost a year, as warm weather aided projects.
Today's statistics seemed to conform with a quarterly survey of 3,000 executives by Dun & Bradstreet that pointed to "a strong upturn" in the economy this spring.
"After more than a year of very stable expectations, business optimism has rapidly increased to a level comparable to the peak expectations set in 1994," said Joseph W. Duncan, the company's chief economic adviser. "In nearly every key industry, the proportion of firms that expect higher sales and profits is rising."

(Source: The Conference Board)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Inflation Data Help to Lift Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices for Treasury securities rebounded from early losses yesterday as new data suggested that inflation was still subdued, even as manufacturing continued to hum along.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 94 16/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 7.07 percent, from 7.09 percent on Monday. GovPx, a bond pricing service, said that the trading volume was about 40 percent above average for a Tuesday; by late in the day, the value of securities traded was more than $100 billion, only the eighth time this year that level had been reached. 
 Among the reports released yesterday that showed a strong economy was one from the National Association of Purchasing Management, whose index of manufacturing conditions rose to 55.0 points in March from 53.1 in February, a bigger gain than expected.
Another report, on construction spending, showed a 2.3 percent rise in February, which was also more than expected. And the index of leading economic indicators increased for the 13th consecutive month during February, rising half a percent, a bit more than expected.
The strength of the reports combined to put early pressure on the bond market. Investors sold on visions of more rises in interest rates by a Federal Reserve concerned about inflation because the economy shows no signs of slowing down.
But prices recovered after investors took a closer look at the purchasing managers' report, noticing that the prices-paid component, a gauge of inflation, fell to 50.9 points from 55.1 last month. The market's gains were held in check because of traders' wariness about the employment report set for release on Friday; strong monthly job reports in the current expansion have caused concern in a bond market already worried about an overheated economy.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that, like the purchasing managers' report, the other economic releases were not quite as unfavorable for bonds as they initially seemed.
The leading indicators were strong, he said, but that index "has not been the best guide to the economy's recent performance, as it certainly gave no indication beforehand of the economy's strength over the past two quarters." And while the construction report was strong, he said it might have been skewed by unusually mild weather in February.
In any event, bond prices recouped their early losses and then some.
Still, more strong economic news may be headed the market's way. Mr. Fine said that the report on factory orders for February, set for release today, is expected to mirror the performance of its largest component, orders for durable goods, which were earlier reported to have risen sharply.
"While this will not surprise the market," Mr. Fine said, "it will nevertheless add further credence to the concept that G.D.P. growth during the first quarter continued to advance at a pace well above the Fed's desired trend rate of maximum, noninflationary growth. Most assuredly, the expectation of another Fed tightening move on the horizon is alive and well."
Elsewhere, the Treasury sold $10 billion of 14-day cash management bills and $17 billion of 19-day cash management bills through auction to cover the Government's short-term cash needs outside the regular borrowing schedule.
The average rate for the 14-day maturity was 5.37 percent and the average for the 19-day maturity was 5.42 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of 14-day and 19-day cash management bills:

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Violence Leads Netanyahu To Plan a Washington Trip
Two explosions occurred in Gaza, each of them killing a Palestinian man. The Israeli authorities said they were botched suicide bombings. In the West Bank, Israeli police officers fatally shot two Palestinians. As the sense of crisis heightened, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu abruptly scheduled a visit to Washington on Monday, and King Hussein of Jordan called for a more active American role. A1 

Israel Favors Conversion Bill
The Israeli Parliament gave preliminary approval to a bill that would give Orthodox rabbis sole authority to conduct conversions to Judaism in Israel. Conservative and Reform rabbis in Israel and abroad denounced the bill, saying it would alienate the majority of diaspora Jews. Non-Orthodox conversions that took place abroad would still be recognized in Israel. A6
 
Pakistan Curbs Its President
Pakistan's Parliament unanimously eliminated a law allowing the country's appointed president to dismiss elected Governments and to appoint chiefs of the armed forces. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, who sought the change, said it had been approved by President Farooq Leghari. The law, in effect since 1985, had previously been used to dismiss, on charges of corruption and misrule, Governments led by both Mr. Sharif and his rival, Benazir Bhutto. A7
 
Chinese Reporter Is a Suicide
A Chinese journalist committed suicide in Beijing shortly after being recalled from his post as Washington bureau chief of the New China News Agency. Colleagues said he had been discovered arranging for himself, his wife and daughter to defect to the United States. The journalist, Wei Gouqiang, had written critically about the United States. A4
 
China Sidesteps Gingrich
The Chinese Government took remarks made by Newt Gingrich in Beijing last weekend in stride. It emphasized the House Speaker's acceptance of the one-China policy and played down his blunt assertion that the United States would come to Taiwan's military defense if the island were attacked. The White House said that Mr. Gingrich was "speaking for himself," but did not rebuke him. A4
 
Bosnia Orphans Leave Germany
Germany sent 30 Bosnian children back to Sarajevo, four years after they were dramatically rescued from an orphanage during the siege of that city. State officials said the children's guardians had repeatedly pressed for their return. Germany has said it will deport tens of thousands of Bosnian Muslim refugees, but many of their homes lie in territory now controlled by Bosnian Serbs. A8
 
New Prime Minister for Zaire
Zaire's Parliament elected Etienne Tshisekedi as Prime Minister. Mobutu Sese Seko, the dictator who twice dismissed Mr. Tshisekedi for refusing to yield to his wishes, was expected to approve the decision. A5
 
NATIONAL A10-18
 
Top White House Aides Tried to Help Hubbell
President Clinton's chief of staff and other top advisers and confidants mounted a campaign in 1994 to help find lucrative employment for Webster L. Hubbell, one of Mr. Clinton's closest friends who was facing a criminal investigation, the White House acknowledged. Aides said Mr. Clinton may have been told of the effort, but was not involved in it. A1
 
Presbyterians Bar Gay Clergy
The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) said a majority of its regional groups had voted to amend the church's constitution to block anyone who is sexually active outside of marriage from being a clergy member, elder or deacon. The vote was intended to settle a debate within the 2.7 million-member denomination about ordaining non-celibate homosexuals, but some opponents of the measure promised a campaign to repeal it. A1
 
Winter Arrives in New England
Boston and the rest of New England struggled under the indignity of more than two feet of snow in April -- the region's third-biggest winter storm on record. Hundreds of thousands were without power, and schools and offices closed throughout the region. Snowdrifts blocked highways as far south as Pennsylvania. A10
 
Rules on Health Benefits Issued
The Clinton Administration issued rules preventing employers from denying health benefits to new employees because of pre-existing medical problems like heart trouble. The rules put into effect a law passed by Congress last year to make health insurance more easily available to people who switch jobs. A15
 
Suicide Note Cites Cult
A 58-year-old man was found dead under a purple shroud in his home in Northern California. He left a suicide note suggesting that he hoped to join members of the Heaven's Gate cult on a space ship in the trail of the Hale-Bopp comet. But officials said they knew of no other link between the man and the 39 cult members who committed mass suicide. A16
 
Labor Begins Political Push
Organized labor began a weeklong advertising campaign against its political foes. Unusually, it aimed at seven Democrats along with a dozen Republicans. The ostensible issue was $20 billion in corporate tax breaks, but the A.F.L.-C.I.O. seemed to be trying to take advantage of what it perceived as a leadership vacuum in Congress. A18
 
Shuttle Launching Is Delayed
The space agency delayed a launching of the shuttle Columbia by one day to install thermal insulation on a coolant loop. The shuttle is now scheduled to lift off on Friday. (AP)
 
Social Security Chief Chosen
President Clinton has settled on Kenneth S. Apfel, a former aide to former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, to be Social Security Commissioner, a White House official said. Mr. Apfel, 48, is the associate director for human resources at the Office of Management and Budget. (AP)

Arbitrator Backs Giving New Jersey Most of Ellis I.
An arbitrator recommended splitting Ellis Island between New York and New Jersey. The museum and major monuments would go to New York, but New Jersey would get the 22 acres built on landfill that it claimed, plus a share of the taxes generated by the island's staff and visitors. The United States Supreme Court must ratify the division. A1
 
U.S. Approves School Changes
The Justice Department agreed to let New York City proceed with the most sweeping overhaul of its public school system in three decades, strengthening the hand of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew at the expense of the city's 32 community school boards. B1
 
Meningitis Outbreak Is Halted
A meningitis outbreak that killed two toddlers in New Jersey has apparently been halted by giving preventive medication to 200 people, the authorities said. They said the disease, which left a relative of one of the toddlers in a coma, spread when babysitters let them play together. B2
 
Culkin Custody Trial Averted
A custody trial over the child actor Macaulay Culkin was averted when the actor's father decided not to contest custody of Macaulay or his seven siblings. The father, Christopher (Kit) Culkin, said he wanted to spare the children a trial. B3

HEADLINE: Solomonic Ruling Would Divide Ellis Island

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
Ruling in a dispute that has kept New York and New Jersey at loggerheads for 200 years, an arbitrator appointed by the United States Supreme Court recommended yesterday that Ellis Island be divided between the two, drawing the line largely where New Jersey wanted it.
The recommendation, which invites inevitable comparisons to King Solomon's ruling dividing the baby, leaves the museum and the major monuments of the famous immigration station in New York's hands. But New Jersey would gain control over about 22 acres of landfill added to the island, starting in 1890, for the construction of hospital and administration buildings. 
 Since the island is a national park, the recommendation is not expected to change its day-to-day operations.
But the change would be a blow to New York, which has claimed bragging rights over the island that has become the symbol of the immigrant experience. Forty percent of Americans trace their roots to someone who arrived in the New World via Ellis Island from 1892 to 1954.
New Jersey wants to claim any economic benefits if restoration plans lead to a hotel or convention center, and wants to build a footbridge to attract tourists. The state would also gain a share of the taxes generated by the 425 people who work on the island and the $5 million in food and souvenirs snapped up by 1.65 million annual visitors.
New York officials and preservationists attacked the decision, claiming it would create a jigsaw-puzzle-like pastiche of divided control that would become a legal nightmare.
"Beyond our legal proof, New York's claim to Ellis Island is clearly and indelibly inscribed in the hearts and beliefs of the millions of immigrants who set foot here," said Dennis C. Vacco, State Attorney General of New York. "This recommendation is not just contrary to the history of Ellis Island, but if allowed to stand, could threaten its future as well. For the first time, Ellis Island would be exposed to a hodgepodge of preservation rules."
New Jersey officials gloated, and wasted no time in ranking themselves right up there with New York as an immigrant gateway.
"This is a recognition of New Jersey's place in history," said Gov. Christine Todd Whitman. "It is a matter of pride for the state. It's a recognition that both New York and New Jersey have served as a gateway for millions of Americans who have made a real difference in the state and across the nation. We are very pleased with it."
The recommendation is expected to be reviewed by the full Supreme Court in its term starting in October. The Constitution, envisioning the day that states might summon gunboats to settle their disputes, gave the Supreme Court jurisdiction over such border skirmishes.
Lacking the time to hear full-blown trials, the Court appoints a special master to serve essentially in the role of trial judge and jury, listening to evidence and making finds of fact and law. Since the nation's birth about 175 disputes have been handled in this manner. The hearings in the Ellis Island case were held in summer 1996.
After reviewing any responses to yesterday's recommendation and hearing brief oral arguments, the Court can accept, modify or throw out the recommendation of the special master. In theory, the Justices do not have to defer to the master's recommendations. But in practice the recommendation is almost always accepted.
The recommendation by the special master in this case, Paul R. Verkuil, a law professor who started work yesterday as dean of Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, would give New Jersey virtually everything it claimed. An 1834 agreement to settle three decades of squabbling drew the border down the middle of the Hudson, giving New Jersey underwater rights over what became the landfill portions. Mr. Verkuil emphasized a 1908 ruling by Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes that gave New Jersey the right to tax a railroad on landfill on its side of the Hudson River.
No one disputed that the original rock given to New York in that treaty, sometimes referred to as prototypical Ellis Island in court documents, should remain in New York's hands. Mr. Verkuil chose to give New York about five acres, defined by the low tide mark. Otherwise, not only would the boundary have split the main building, but tourists coming off boats would have had to cross through New Jersey territory to get to the museum.
New Jersey treated the case as a boundary dispute, while New York attempted to show that it was a property case, with the Empire State's long connection to the island giving it the right to claim sovereignty over all 27.5 acres. The landfill was added in 1890, 1899, 1908 and 1936, during the island's heyday as the country's main immigration station.
The two sides marshaled obscure annals of history, law, immigration, geography, tidal flows and marine biology in their arguments, excavating a mountain of documents from historical archives across the nation.
New York used evidence from postcards to poetry to bolster its case. Mr. Verkuil was dismissive of much of this, incredulous over testimony from a man who said he remembered his family's ties to New York when his father lived on the island. The man would have been 1 at the time. The special master also said he could not give weight to the New York argument that starry-eyed immigrants were focused on the New York City skyline when they entered the harbor.
"Because no poll was taken, we will never know for certain in which state most immigrants perceived they were landing," he wrote, again stressing the importance of the 1834 border pact. "It hardly matters in any event."
New York officials were stunned by this aspect of the ruling.
"It must have been a fix," said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "Ellis Island is obviously part of New York. My recollection is that all those people who were coming here were coming to New York."
New York State officials, including Gov. George E. Pataki, noted with some satisfaction that the heart of the island remained in its hands and vowed to try to overturn the special master's recommendations.
"We kept the good stuff," said Judith T. Kramer, the assistant attorney general who led the presentation of New York's case. "But this nightmare is exactly what the preservationists wanted to avoid."
The special master ordered a survey to determine boundaries. But critics noticed that pieces of the main buildings, including the kitchen and laundry, would be in New Jersey. That raises the question whether workers in those buildings would pay taxes to New Jersey, or whether anyone injured there would seek compensation from New Jersey.
It also raised the hackles of preservationists, who argue that New Jersey's preservation laws are weaker than New York's. Many compared the decision unfavorably to the Biblical ruling by King Solomon.
"I think splitting the baby doesn't do much for the baby, and I think this is a mistake," said Peg Breen, president of the New York Landmarks Conservancy. "You cannot go out there without getting a sense of fear, a sense of hope that the immigrants felt. It is not just the main hall, but all those buildings that are haunting."
She said New York had more stringent laws that would protect those buildings, some of which have been threatened with destruction to make way for a proposed hotel and convention center that was later dropped.
"It should not just be petty squabbling over who is going to get more tax revenue but over who can best protect it," Ms. Breen said. "I suspect New Jersey's interest is mainly economic and that bodes ill for the future."
New Jersey officials took umbrage at the charge that this was their main motivation.
"Money has never been the main point," Governor Whitman said. " The public at large seemed a little bit baffled by the whole thing.
"It seems like they should have better things to argue about," said Dennis Corrigan, a Michigan resident visiting the island with his wife and two young sons.

HEADLINE: New Strife Leads Netanyahu To Schedule a Visit to Clinton

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, April 1

 BODY:
Two explosions in Gaza early this morning that Israel said were suicide bombing attempts and the fatal shooting of two Palestinians in the West Bank gave fresh impetus to the spiral of violence between Palestinians and Israelis, even as the political front continued to crumble.
Each explosion killed a Palestinian man. 
As the sense of crisis worsened, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu abruptly scheduled a visit to Washington to meet with President Clinton on Monday.
In Washington, King Hussein of Jordan said the crisis required "a more active U.S. role."
"Minds have to be put to work and heads need to be knocked together," King Hussein told a small group of journalists at his Washington hotel. "The United States is in the position to be the arbiter and the partner of all concerned. But the United States should not be just the messenger. That's what a new phase requires."
With the United States offering few new ideas publicly on how to break out of a dangerous impasse, the Israelis and Palestinians seemed unable to do more than trade blows and recriminations and brace for more trouble.
The explosions in Gaza occurred 15 minutes apart near Jewish settlements inside the Gaza Strip and along roads used by the Israelis, at an hour when children were about to set off in school buses. But no Israeli vehicle was passing by, and the casualties were all Palestinian, including several people riding in a taxi.
A suicide bombing at a Tel Aviv cafe on March 21 that killed three Israeli women and the Palestinian bomber broke a yearlong lull in such attacks.
An anonymous caller to Israel Radio claimed responsibility for today's explosions -- the first near the settlement of Netzarim and the second near Kfar Darom -- in the name of Islamic Holy War, a militant Palestinian group that has struck in Gaza before. The caller said the attacks had been carried out in the name of the "Abu Ghneim commando." Abu Ghneim is the Arabic name for the hill in southeastern Jerusalem on which Israel began breaking ground two weeks ago for a controversial new housing project.
But in Gaza, Palestinian officials and witnesses said the explosion near Kfar Darom appeared to have been caused by a grenade thrown or fired from an Israeli Army jeep at a man in a Palestinian police uniform standing by the road.
A witness said the man had been waiting for a lift when a soldier fired the grenade at him and he was killed. Five passengers in a passing Palestinian taxicab were wounded.
Israeli officials insisted that both explosions had been attempted suicide bombings. They said one of the bombers had been in uniform.
Mr. Netanyahu said the explosions "proved that the green light hasn't changed, and that appropriate measures have not been taken by the Palestinian Authority." The reference was to Mr. Netanyahu's charge last month that Mr. Arafat had given an indirect "green light" to Islamic terror groups to unleash attacks on Israel.
Mr. Arafat, sitting down to a meeting with representatives of countries that donate money to the Palestinians, treated the charges with the same disdain with which he has reacted to all of Mr. Netanyahu's charges of recent weeks: "What will be the reaction from our side, to control more and more?" he asked. "For every pressure there is a reaction. This is natural law."
A resolution by Arab League ministers recommending that Arab countries retreat from relations with Israel and resume economic and political boycotts, though threatening few immediate consequences, added to a sense of a Middle East flashback to the dismally familiar state of confrontation.
In the West Bank, Israeli soldiers shot two Palestinians to death. One, outside a Jewish settlement near Hebron, was said by the Israeli authorities to be trying to commit a robbery.
The more portentous killing occurred outside Nablus, where a Palestinian police officer in civilian clothes was shot to death during a stone-throwing melee near an Israeli checkpoint that began with a student protest against the Jerusalem housing development.
Palestinian hospital officials said he had been hit by a real bullet. Israeli Army officials said they had used only rubber bullets, which are in fact metal slugs encased in rubber.
Nablus is regarded as a dangerous flash point because of the presence inside the Palestinian-ruled town of Joseph's Tomb, a walled site used by Jewish militants for religious study. Six Israeli soldiers and two Palestinians were killed there during rioting in September. This time, Israel has stationed tanks and personnel carriers around the town in a sign that it is prepared to go in if the shrine is endangered.
Palestinian security officials said the victim, Haitham Mansour, 20, was an undercover officer and was standing near the protests when he was hit.
The incident was on the 13th day of violence over Israel's decision to proceed with the housing development in Jerusalem, with no sign yet of a way out.
In Israel, an American initiative has come to be viewed as the sole possible solution to the crisis, since Mr. Netanyahu is effectively trapped between the hard-line demands of his conservative coalition and the refusal of Mr. Arafat to continue any contacts.
Mr. Netanyahu's charge that Mr. Arafat has given a "green light" for terror attacks -- which he has angrily rejected -- has further exacerbated relations. Israeli officials say cooperation on security matters has deteriorated.
The prevailing expectation is that Washington will try to build an initiative around Mr. Netanyahu's proposal to set aside the existing framework of agreements and plunge directly into intensive talks on a final settlement, perhaps bringing the two sides together in a setting like Camp David, which President Carter used in 1978 to broker the Israeli-Egyptian peace.
Senior American officials in Washington said they were intrigued by Mr. Netanyahu's proposal to move quickly to an accelerated negotiation on the final status of the West Bank and Gaza Strip and of Jerusalem. At a meeting with The New York Times in New York on Monday, King Hussein said he was open to the idea.
In Washington today, the Jordanian King called on Mr. Netanyahu to deliver on promised confidence-building measures for the Palestinians like an airport in Gaza, access to ports for trade, quicker transit for goods and safe passage between the West Bank and Gaza.
Mr. Netanyahu contends that the existing process, established under the 1993 agreement in Oslo that outlined the negotiation process, will only create one crisis after another.
The search for a new approach has led to considerable speculation that Mr. Netanyahu might form a "national unity" government with the opposition Labor Party, which would potentially make him less dependent on right-wing support. In an interview with Israeli army radio today, Mr. Netanyahu said he was "definitely considering" the option but had not come to a decision.
The "big question," Mr. Netanyahu said, was whether such a coalition would actually create a broad consensus, or would paralyze the Government instead. "Would it be a government of unity or two governments?" asked Mr. Netanyahu.
In an interview published today in the Israeli daily Maariv, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said, "By God, this is the worst situation in the peace process since 1977," the year in which his predecessor, Anwar el-Sadat, made his historic visit to Israel. "You have succeeded in frightening the world," Mr. Mubarak said. "You have pushed all of us into a very difficult situation."
To which Mr. Netanyahu retorted that Egypt was "doing its utmost, I am sorry to say, in a pretty systematic way, to shut the gates of normalization and openness."

HEADLINE: Private Schools to Share in Giuliani's Extra Textbook Aid

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
In November, facing criticism of his cuts in the education budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he was giving $70 million to the Board of Education to replace the dog-eared, outdated textbooks used by thousands of public school children. But school officials now say that because of a provision in state law, more than a fifth of that money will go to buy books for students in parochial schools.
Board of Education officials said they had initially assumed that they could use the entire $70 million to replace woefully outdated textbooks for the city's 1.1 million public school students. But as parochial school officials swiftly pointed out, state law requires that any government money earmarked for books be distributed to all children in the city -- including those in nonpublic schools. 
 About 21 percent of New York City children attend private schools, a vast majority in Roman Catholic schools; hence, about 21 percent of the Mayor's money, or about $14.7 million, will be used for books for private school students, according to a March 31 memo from board officials to school superintendents.
"The law is the law is the law, and this is what the law requires," said Lewis H. Spence, the deputy chancellor for operations. "I think most of us thought it was for the public schools."
Giuliani administration officials said yesterday that they were initially unaware of the state requirement that dollars designated for textbooks had to be offered to all children living in the city. Under state law, city education aid that is not earmarked for books does not have to be shared with private school children, state education officials said.
"The Mayor intended to make books available for public school children," the Mayor's spokesman, Jack Deacy, said yesterday. "They are being made available. Within that, the law requires us to make allocations for other needy students who need new books, and we're going to do that."
Mr. Deacy said the Mayor had no further plans to increase textbook financing for now.
While independent private schools like Dalton and Riverdale would also be eligible for a share of the aid, Mr. Spence said none had requested it.
Catherine Hickey, Superintendent of Schools for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which has about 73,000 students in Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx, applauded the Board's decision to share the textbook dollars. But she also noted that unlike textbooks in many public schools, textbooks in the Catholic schools were relatively new, written about five or six years ago.
"We are not in a situation where our textbooks are 20 to 30 years old," Dr. Hickey said.
She added that the private-school share of the textbook money, roughly $65 to $70 a child, would be used to buy supplementary materials and literature. The money cannot be used to buy religious materials.
The Board of Education will divide its $55 million share based on the needs of each school, rather than allocating an equal amount per student, officials said.
Discussions about sharing the $70 million began shortly after the Mayor announced in November that he would grant the extra money to the board. At that time, the Association of Non-Public School Officials pointed out to Board of Education officials the state regulation that requires textbook money to be made available to nonpublic school children, said Dr. Hickey, a member of the association.
State money earmarked for textbooks, totaling $35 a student each year, has always been available to nonpublic school children. But city education aid is generally not designated for particular items, like textbooks, and therefore does not have to be shared, school officials said.
But last year, the City Council voted to earmark $12.5 million a year for textbooks over the next four years. After complaints from Dr. Hickey's group, the Board of Education agreed to share that money with private schools. The major beneficiaries will be students in the Archdiocese schools and the Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, which has about 73,800 students.
Board of Education officials also released new regulations yesterday intended to give district superintendents and school principals greater flexibility in buying books with the money allocated by the Mayor.
According to the March 31 memo, schools may buy books directly from wholesalers and bookstores, instead of sometimes lengthy and cumbersome contracts made by the central Board, if that is "more economically beneficial" to the school. Nor do they have to go through a competitive bidding process, as they do now for purchases over $250.
State money, the biggest share of dollars spent on books, can be used to buy books only from a catalogue approved by the Board of Education. The list includes only those books that are reviewed by Board officials. Under the new rules, teachers will be able to recommend books to be included in the catalog.
The memo says the regulations apply to the Mayor's special allocation. But Karen Crowe, a spokeswoman for the Chancellor, said, "We're going to use this as a template for all future purchases."

Fiscal Oversight for Camden

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The final straw came last November, when Mayor Arnold W. Webster of Camden refused to lay off 67 city workers to balance his 1997 budget, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. Convinced that the city was unable to cope with its financial crisis, the Governor said she would submit legislation to create a fiscal oversight board. 
 The board, made up mostly of state officials, would have final approval on hiring decisions and contracts, said Christopher B. Wolf, a spokesman for the State Department of Community Affairs. Mayor Webster welcomed the board as a step that might help solve the city's problems.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
For Now, Pettitte Puts Money Matters Aside

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 1

 BODY:
When Andy Pettitte strolls to the mound against the Mariners on Wednesday night, his focus will be on their mighty lineup. Fortunately for his own team, Pettitte said he would not be thinking about the way in which the Yankees have treated contract matters in his brief career.
"All I want to talk about is baseball," Pettitte said before the Yanks lost tonight's season opener at the Kingdome. "The other stuff bothered me at first, but I'm over it." 
 It does not take an accountant to realize that Pettitte has reason to be miffed. A person familiar with Pettitte's situation said the Yankees were poised to sign him to a three-year, $4.2 million contract last year when George Steinbrenner suddenly squashed the plan. The Yankees probably wish they had signed the 24-year-old left-hander to that deal, because it would be very economical right now.
"That's still an option," General Manager Bob Watson said of the possibility of signing Pettitte to a long-term deal. "What was going through everybody's mind about Andy around the All-Star break last year? His elbow. You have to wait and let the things shake out. He went through the post-season and answered all the questions we had about him in spring training."
But Pettitte won an American League-high 21 games and finished second to Toronto's Pat Hentgen in the Cy Young Award race, so his price has surely escalated. He may prefer to wait for arbitration after the 1997 season.
Like Bernie Williams, whose opening-day deadline for a multiyear extension was likely to pass today without an agreement, Pettitte has enough evidence from his performances on the field to dramatically increase his salary through arbitration. Williams and the Yankees agreed in February to a one-year, $5.25 million deal to avoid arbitration. With another season of 17 victories or more, Pettitte could ask for more than $3 million in arbitration and win.
"That's the price you pay," Watson said. "We would have looked bad if his elbow blew out. I've always said, I'll pay for performance. If you put up the numbers, I'll pay you."
Randy Hendricks, Pettitte's agent, would only say that he is not averse to discussing a long-term deal during the season before adding, "I don't want to comment on anything."
Hendricks watched the Dodgers sign Hideo Nomo to a three-year, $4.5 million contract after his rookie season, and must wonder why Pettitte has not been given similar treatment by the Yankees. Granted, Pettitte was not as dominating or as much of an icon as Nomo, but he was the premier rookie pitcher in the American League when he went 12-9 with a 4.17 earned run average in 1995.
And after the multiyear contract failed to materialize last season, Pettitte found himself lumped together with Mariano Rivera ($550,000, a 328 percent raise) and Derek Jeter ($540,000, a 350 percent raise) when the Yankees signed him to a $600,000 contract for 1997.
In 1995, Pettitte won 12 games, while Rivera was 5-3 with a 5.51 earned run average in 19 games and Jeter had only 48 at-bats. So why was Pettitte, a two-year player, given financial treatment similar to that of the one-year players following the 1996 season? And when Pettitte's contract was revised after his first year, it was increased by only 38 percent, from $109,000 to $150,000. That was enough reason to be miffed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Data Show Strong Growth But Little Inflation
Evidence mounted that the economy accelerated markedly in recent weeks, though inflation appeared to remain in check. 
 Purchasing executives reported that their index of factory activity climbed in March, and separate reports showed that construction spending and the index of leading indicators rose in February. But an inflation gauge in the purchasing managers' report declined, comforting the stock market, where a selloff was stemmed after two days. [Page D4.]
 
The prices of Treasury securities rebounded from early losses as investors realized that the economic reports raised no red flags about inflation. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 7.07 percent from 7.09. [D20.]
 
Chrysler Light-Truck Sales Slip
Sales of Chrysler's high-profit light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks --fell two-tenths of 1 percent last month from March 1996. Honda's sales fell 6.6 percent, but its new CRV, above, proved to be a big hit. Analysts said that flattening sales of the Big Three's trucks would hurt their profits. [D4.]
 
Prince Buys Apple Computer Stake
Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia said he had bought a 5 percent stake in Apple Computer for $115 million. [D2.]

Shares of Bre-X Minerals Rise
The shares of Bre-X Minerals rose after a selloff last week ignited by doubts about the Canadian company's Indonesian gold find. In Toronto, trading in Bre-X lasted only 24 minutes before heavy volume overwhelmed the exchange's computer system. [D2.]
 
On-Line Service Stocks Surge
Shares of America Online and Compuserve, its chief rival, rose sharply on talk that a merger of the two was being explored. [D4.]
 
What Triarc Brings to Snapple
Can Nelson Peltz and Peter W. May, the entrepreneurs who run Triarc, succeed with Snapple after Quaker Oats failed? Analysts say Triarc has a double-barreled advantage: It owns Mistic Brands, a smaller competitor in fruit juice and tea, and it hired Michael Weinstein, the former president of A&W Brands, to run it. Market Place. [D10.]
 
For Car Rentals, No Debit Cards
The big car rental companies, including Hertz and Avis, have stopped letting people rent cars using just debit cards from Visa or Mastercard. The card companies, the banks that issue the cards and some customers are furious. [A1.]
 
Columbia/HCA in Labor Violation
An administrative law judge in Washington ruled that a hospital owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare in Louisville, Ky., had violated Federal labor laws. [D2.]
 
Worries About Japan Hurt Dollar
The dollar fell sharply, hurt in part by a warning from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin about Japan's trade surplus. [D17.]
 
Revised Report Lifts Soybeans
Soybean prices surged after the Agriculture Department said it had previously overstated stockpiles. [D17.]
 
What Will Mr. Jenkins Say?
Schieffelin & Somerset, which introduced a vodka under the Tanqueray name in 1989 with great fanfare only to see the brand fail to catch on, is trying again. New ads for the vodka introduce a saucy young British woman named Mel and borrow from the imagery of the campaign for Tanqueray vodka, which features a natty roue, Mr. Jenkins. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]
 
Wired Hotels in Hong Kong
Unfazed by the uncertainties of Hong Kong under Chinese rule, hotels are racing to add technology to rooms, mostly to please business travelers. Business Travel. [D9.]

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A Class-Action Struggle: Can Air Be Too Clean?

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Despite a couple of jokes about the spotted owl, no one on the affirmative side of tomorrow night's meandering "Firing Line" debate -- "Resolved: The Environmentalists Are Going Too Far Too Fast" -- comes out flatly against pure air or water or for killing elephants. Led by William F. Buckley Jr., they maintain that their opponents are making mountains out of molehills, or maybe it's the other way around.
The environmentalist contingent (Mr. Buckley calls them "eco-freaks") retort that untrammeled industrial growth is throwing nature off balance with dire consequences for the future of the human race. 
 The encounter shifts ground depending on who is leading the charge. Jerry Brown (he's the fellow without a tie or jacket) issues jeremiads against even trammeled growth, except perhaps of trees. He comes out for "a happy asceticism."
Speaking for the corporations mistrusted by the environmentalists, Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, grants that some Government regulation is needed but expresses confidence in his clients to behave responsibly, make money, make jobs and make life pleasanter for all without ravaging the land or polluting the air and the water. His assurances are greeted with some skepticism.
If Mr. Jasinowski has rarely met a corporation he could not defend, the professional environmentalists -- George M. Woodwell, the director of the Woods Hole Research Center, and Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club -- have never met an ecological cause they could not champion. Mr. Pope uses some of his time for fund-raising pitches: "At the Sierra Club we don't believe there's such a thing as water that's too pure for our kids to drink, air that's too clean for our parents to breathe." Debaters on both sides make obeisance to the American People as if they were running for something.
Richard L. Schmalensee, director of the Center for Energy and Environmental Policy Research at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, labors to get the argument off the rhetorical plane and onto ground where trade-offs might be found between the bottom line and higher aspirations. He does not have much success.
Along the way there are smoggy exchanges about global warming, developing countries, cost-benefit analysis and political pressures. One issue mentioned now and then, some international treaty awaiting approval, remains as murky as an algae-topped lake. It might have been helpful if Michael Kinsley, the entertaining moderator, had now and then taken a moment from cracking wise to explain what was being talked about.
 
'Debates/Debates'
'Does Paula Jones Deserve Her Day in Court Now?'
PBS, tomorrow night
(Channel 25, New York, at 8)
Warren Steibel, the producer of both "Firing Line" and "Debates/ Debates," offers an appetizer tomorrow, an argument about whether President Clinton, or any President, should be discommoded by being sued while in office.
The political right, represented here by Arianna Huffington, has been chiding feminists for not being as caring toward Paula Jones, who says the President came on to her without provocation, as they were toward Anita Hill; the left, represented by Susan Estrich, has been maintaining that the Presidency must be allowed to carry on the nation's business without distraction. Ms. Huffington and Ms. Estrich have allies tomorrow night, but if you have encountered these two opinionizers before -- and they are hard for viewers of television talkies to avoid -- you will know what to expect.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Japanese Data And Talk of a U.S. Rate Rise

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded yesterday from Tuesday's losses against the yen and the mark, bolstered by a modest Japanese economic report and by expectations that the Federal Reserve would again raise interest rates.
Expectations that the Japanese central bank's quarterly economic survey, called the Tankan, would show strength had helped depress the dollar earlier this week. 
 While the report, released yesterday, did show some improvement in the mood of Japanese corporations, it also pointed to insecurity about the future, leading to sales of yen. "The market was looking for more strength in the Tankan report than they got," said Dominick Presa, chief foreign-exchange dealer at Dresdner Bank.
The report's key index rose to +2 in March from -3 in the previous survey in November, the first positive reading since November 1991. But this strength contrasted sharply with the mood outside manufacturing industries, where the index plunged beyond most expectations to -6 from zero in November.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 123.25 yen, up from 121.76 yen on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 1.6765 German marks from 1.6656. It also gained against the British pound, which fetched $1.6431, down from $1.6528. The dollar was higher, as well, against most other currencies.
Also helping, dealers said, were news reports that heightened expectations of further interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve. An article in The Washington Post quoted a Fed governor, Laurence H. Meyer, as saying that the United States economy was "really strong" and suggested that recent data pointed to another rate increase in May. A report by Bridge News, the former Knight-Ridder financial service, quoting unnamed Fed informants also cited the prospect of further rate rises.
Higher United States interest rates tend to make dollar assets comparatively more attractive.
The dollar gained yesterday even as stocks again fell sharply. "I think the market got caught leaning the wrong way" after the selloff in the dollar on Tuesday, Marc Chandler, senior currency analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said.
