HEADLINE: Russia Dilutes A Treaty With Belarus, Then Signs

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 2

 BODY:
The Presidents of Russia and neighboring Belarus initialed a charter today that would pave the way for a union of the two republics.
But the charter, hastily rewritten in Moscow on the eve of the meeting, was a watered-down version of the more ambitious document on full integration that President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Belarussian counterpart, Aleksandr R. Lukashenko, had been prepared to sign. 
 The charter is not yet binding. Under pressure from liberals inside Mr. Yeltsin's Cabinet, both Presidents agreed to hold off ratification for a month, to allow public scrutiny -- as well as additional amendments by Kremlin aides intended to lessen Moscow's responsibility for its indigent neighbor.
Russia and Belarus have been negotiating closer economic and political ties since 1993. Lately, some of Mr. Yeltsin's top foreign policy advisers, including Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, had been lobbying to speed integration as a geopolitical response -- at least a symbolic one -- to the West's plan to expand NATO eastward.
But other presidential advisers worried about the huge cost to the Russian budget and market reform efforts that closer ties to Belarus's faltering and still tightly centralized economy would bring.
Mr. Lukashenko, who has spoken admiringly of Hitler and Stalin, only deepened doubts with his increasingly authoritarian behavior. He disbanded Parliament late last year when it declined to approve constitutional amendments aimed at increasing his power.
More recently, he angered Washington by expelling an American diplomat he accused of being a spy. The Belarussian President also outraged the Russian press by expelling a Russian television journalist, whose supposed infractions included his Israeli citizenship.
Russian television reported that Stanislav S. Shushkevich, a well-known democratic Belarussian politician and a former Speaker of Parliament, was detained today by security forces in Minsk, the capital.
Mr. Lukashenko's agreement with Mr. Yeltsin, intended to help Russia restore a portion of its collapsed empire, ended up serving mostly as an illustration of the growing influence inside the Kremlin of liberals loath to be too closely identified with Belarus.
After the signing, Mr. Lukashenko talked about the inevitability of unification. Mr. Yeltsin emphasized what kept the two republics apart.
"The union does not create a single state," he said. "Each side maintains its sovereignty." He noted that though economic links would be strengthened, adopting a common currency would take years, not months.
Mr. Lukashenko did not hide his disappointment that Russia had backed off at the last second from a closer union.
"Preparations for the document unfortunately did not take place without bitter opposition," he said at the signing ceremony in the Kremlin.
A predominantly Russian-speaking country of 10 million, Belarus formed, along with Ukraine and Russia, the Slavic heartland of the Soviet Union. It has neither oil nor a nuclear arsenal, but it does have a growing, if ill-defined, sense of nationalism.
In Minsk, riot police officers brutally beat dozens of demonstrators during a clash outside the Russian Embassy as thousands of other protesters marched through the capital chanting, "Independence!" to underscore their aversion to a union with Moscow.
In Russia, where polls suggest that closer ties to Belarus are more popular, the most fervent opposition was displayed inside Kremlin walls.
In a last-minute flexing of his political muscle, Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais and other economic reformers in the Government persuaded Mr. Yeltsin to overrule his foreign policy advisers and back away from a tighter embrace of the troublesome Belarussian President.
The Kremlin turnaround on the treaty was so quick that it took the Russian Parliament, dominated by nationalists and Communists, by surprise. Parliament had already debated and approved the earlier version, which called among other things for a supreme council -- an executive panel made up of representatives of both countries -- to make decisions affecting both republics.
Chairmanship of the council would have alternated between the Presidents of Belarus and Russia every two years, a provision that opponents painted as an invitation to Mr. Lukashenko to set policy in Moscow.
Even though they were not informed of the last-minute changes in advance, Communist and nationalist leaders praised today's agreement as a sign of progress in the move towards reunification. The leader of the Communist Party, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, called the treaty "the most sober step by President Boris Yeltsin in the last five years."

HEADLINE: New Orders To Factories Rose Again In February

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
New orders received by United States factories rose in February for the second consecutive month, the Government reported today in the latest sign of strong economic growth.
Orders rose eight-tenths of 1 percent -- to a seasonally adjusted $325.9 billion -- after an unrevised 2.5 percent gain in January, the Commerce Department said. Analysts had expected a gain of 1 percent for February. 
 The manufacturing strength in February was driven by orders for industrial machinery, electronic equipment and fabricated metals. Factory inventories, meanwhile, increased four-tenths of 1 percent in February after rising five-tenths of 1 percent in January.
"The factory sector is bubbling at an increasingly rapid pace," said Christopher Low, an economist with HSBC Securities Inc. in New York. And Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York, said, "We're seeing a solid pace of order flows."
On Tuesday, a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed manufacturing activity strengthened in March from a month earlier to the fastest pace in two years. The purchasing managers' index rose to 55 points in March from 53.1 in February. But the report's price index fell to 50.9 points from 55.1.
"There appears to be a turnaround in the manufacturing sector, but it doesn't appear to be accompanied by any significant pickup in inflation," said Cary Leahey, senior economist at Lehman Brothers in New York.
Still, today's factory orders report heightened concerns on Wall Street that Federal Reserve policy makers would follow up last week's increase in interest rates with another tightening.
The data "could lead them to tighten in the future, if not in May then certainly in July," Mr. Moran of Daiwa Securities said. Fed policy makers meet next on May 20.
Outside of the volatile category of aircraft and other transportation equipment, orders rose 1.6 percent in February. Excluding the military industry, factory orders climbed nine-tenths of a percent in February.
By category, orders for durable goods, made to last three or more years, advanced 1.5 percent in February, as previously reported, after increasing 3.8 percent in January. Orders for nondurable goods, including food and clothing, increased a tenth of a percent in February after rising nine-tenths of a percent during January.
The Commerce Department also reported that shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose nine-tenths of 1 percent. Unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, increased nine-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices End Mixed Ahead of Job Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices for Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the bond market remained concerned that continuing strength in the economy would lead to more interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to a price of 94 17/32, a slight enough move that the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, remained at 7.07 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. The yield on a seven-year note rose a hundredth of a percentage point, to 6.83 percent. 
 Bonds were relatively unchanged partly because investors were unwilling to make big bets on the market's direction before the release of the unemployment report for March, which is scheduled for tomorrow.
Because recent data have sketched an outline of a robust economy, many economists have raised their expectations of the strength of the job market report. The bond market watches the monthly report closely because it is one of the best gauges of whether the economy is growing quickly enough to increase inflation, which erodes bonds' value.
A report on February factory orders, which was released yesterday, was weaker than expected, but investors largely ignored it because other economic figures have been so strong recently. Orders to United States manufacturers rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government said. That was less than the increase of 1 percent that economists surveyed by Bloomberg News had expected. In January, orders climbed 2.5 percent.
Carroll J. Delaney, research director at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said, "It should be fairly obvious to even a casual market observer that the bears are definitely at the controls of this train for the moment."
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the private bank of BankBoston, said, "Just about everyone is focused on Friday's employment numbers, and I think the other thing bond investors are watching is the stock market, trying to figure out if the least Fed action will have an impact on corporate profits."
Stock prices resumed their declines yesterday after steadying the day before, with most major indexes falling more than 1 percent. The drop in stocks began after the Fed, as a pre-emptive strike against inflation, adjusted the target Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent. Banks, in turn, almost immediately raised the prime lending rate that they charge their best customers to 8.50 percent, from 8.25 percent.
Mr. Ablin said that the bond market expects the Fed to raise interest rates again, in May.
"From a strategy point of view, we are looking at this as an upgrade opportunity," he said, meaning that investors should consider investing in longer-term securities. "We think that the longer-term interest rates will be a lot more stable than the short end going foward. We could eventually see a narrowing of the yield spread between the short maturities and the longer maturities."
The Treasury said yesterday that it planned to sell $8 billion of its 10-year inflation-indexed notes on Tuesday, $1 billion more than at its initial auction of such securities in January.
Rather than issue securities with a new coupon rate, the Treasury said it was reopening the inaugural issue, which has a maturity date of Jan. 15, 2007, and a real, or inflation-indexed, coupon of 3.375 percent. The move is intended to build liquidity.
At the January auction, demand for the inflation-indexed notes exceeded supply by 5 to 1, which is about double the demand for a typical Treasury sale. Yesterday, the inflation-indexed notes traded at a price to yield 3.57 percent.

HEADLINE: Consultant Barred From Fed Meetings

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve, still smarting from the unauthorized disclosure last September of highly sensitive financial information, has acted to clear up what it called a "misunderstanding" that resulted in an outside consultant taking part in a meeting at its Chicago regional bank where classified data were discussed.
The action came after Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, a longtime critic of the Fed who is the ranking Democratic member of the House Banking Committee, complained that the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago had allowed a Northwestern University professor to participate in two policy briefings early this year. 
 The professor, Martin Eichenbaum, confirmed today that he attended the meetings and said that he had been notified that his presence would no longer be allowed. He said he had found the rules about the permitted role of consultants vague and thought that people like him had participated in policy sessions at some of the other 12 regional Federal Reserve banks.
But Joseph R. Coyne, a spokesman for the Fed, contended that the rules were clear and that Mr. Eichenbaum's experience in Chicago resulted from a "misunderstanding."
There appears to be no connection between Mr. Eichenbaum's attendance at the meetings and a highly publicized news report last year that eight district banks had requested approval from Washington to raise their discount rates. That report was widely seen as based on a leak from Chicago, prompting an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

HEADLINE: Toyota Seeks To Halt Buying Of Dealerships By Republic

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 2

 BODY:
Toyota took legal action today to block Republic Industries from buying up its dealerships, the first attempt by an auto maker to slow the rapid consolidation of automotive retailing by publicly traded companies.
Toyota filed a petition today asking the Texas Motor Vehicle Board, a state agency that rules on disputes between auto makers and their franchises, to halt Republic's recently announced deal to acquire a Toyota dealership in Houston. But the petition was broadly worded, asking the board to affirm Toyota's position that it is not in the public interest to allow anyone to acquire a lot of dealerships quickly. 
 In addition to the Houston dealership, Republic bought a Toyota dealership in Miami at the beginning of this year and announced another deal on Monday to buy a Toyota dealership in Tempe, Ariz. James E. Press, a senior vice president for sales at Toyota, said that Republic had notified Toyota of plans to acquire 59 of its dealerships over the next 18 months, accounting for 20 percent of Toyota's nationwide sales.
Mr. Press said that Republic had not yet proved that it could run even a few dealerships, much less dozens, with the quality of customer service and repair work that Toyota requires. "They're not operating a dealership that we know of for more than four or five months," Mr. Press said in a telephone interview. "Isn't it reasonable that we would want to slow things down and see how things work before we turn over 20 percent of our volume?"
Republic, which has already become the nation's largest automotive retailer, was quick to criticize Toyota's move. "We think the action is without merit," said J. Ronald Castell, Republic's senior vice president for marketing and communications. Republic has already completed without difficulty the acquisition of a dealership in Midland, Tex., that sells Chevrolet, Buick and Mazda cars, said Mr. Castell, who declined to comment on Toyota's specific concerns.
Toyota has a policy of trying to prevent any person or company from acquiring more than one dealership every nine months. Toyota has also maintained a policy until now of barring any person or company from owning more than seven Toyota dealerships and three Lexus dealerships.
Franchise agreements with car dealers give auto makers the authority to veto the transfer of franchises to anybody the auto makers deem unsuitable. But state laws put many limits on the auto makers' ability to exercise this veto, so most dealership transfers are routinely approved. State regulatory agencies like the Texas Motor Vehicle Board administer these laws.
Auto industry officials expressed surprise that Toyota had chosen to make its stand in Texas, where the vehicle board has a reputation for siding with dealers against auto makers. Because Republic bought its second dealership in Texas less than three months after its first purchase, Mr. Press said, Toyota had to take action there.
"We're playing the hand that has been dealt to us," he said.
According to Automotive News, an industry publication, Republic reached agreements through March 20 to acquire 73 dealerships with $4.7 billion in combined 1996 sales.
Republic has already concluded broad dealership acquisition agreements with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company and less formal arrangements with other auto makers, although not with Toyota. The agreements provide a legal framework for the auto makers to approve each acquisition quickly as they come along.
In exchange, auto executives say, Republic has promised at least some of the auto makers that it will continue to participate in regional advertising purchases with smaller, independent dealers. That limits Republic's ability to use its greater sales volume to demand better rates for advertising than its competitors can negotiate.
In a filing a month ago with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Republic also disclosed that it had agreed to sell its G.M. and Ford dealerships back to the manufacturers if a change of control occurred at Republic that either manufacturer viewed as unacceptable.
Chrysler officials have already said they will not allow any individual or company to buy more than 10 of their dealerships nationwide, more than 6 in any of the company's 25 sales regions or more than 2 in any market. Other auto makers have not disclosed any limits on the acquisition of dealerships but are widely thought to have them.
G.M. and Ford have been particularly receptive to Republic because they want to reduce the number of their dealerships. Ford has close to 90 dealerships in the Los Angeles area alone, and they tend to compete with one another instead of going after Japanese rivals. Toyota has no need or desire to reduce the number of its dealerships, Mr. Press said.
H. Wayne Huizenga, Republic's chairman, said in an interview last month at the company's headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that Republic would be able to find economies of scale from running many dealerships.
But consumer advocates are beginning to worry about the consolidation of automotive retailing. "Consumers may end up with higher prices and fewer model choices if a significant segment of the market is controlled by Republic or any other group," said Mary Ponder, a senior projects director at the Consumer Federation of America.
Republic has been buying large dealerships with good reputations for customer service. While some big dealers have welcomed Republic's acquisitions as a chance to sell their operations for a handsome price, many smaller dealers have been worried that Republic will monopolize some markets and drive them out of business.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
When the benefits are mostly modest, what price clean air?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
CLEANER air: it's the law, but it may not always be a good idea. That appears to be the view of officials from the Treasury, the Office of Management and Budget and the President's Council of Economic Advisers, whose recently disclosed comments question the rationale for the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed air quality standards for ozone and soot.
Criticism from insiders -- notably, the council's estimate that the costs of the ozone standard would exceed the measurable benefits by at least 11 to 1 -- will likely feed Congressional efforts to block the standards, and may yet lead the White House to compromise. But win, lose or settle, the battle illustrates both the escalating stakes on environmental policy and the inadequacy of the law as a guide to how much is enough. 
 The Clean Air Act requires the E.P.A. to set maximum exposure standards for six pollutants. The standards are purely health based: the goal is to reduce exposure to the point where no one is harmed.
This sounds great, and certainly played well politically when the law was written. But the current debate suggests just how hard it is becoming to translate the wishes into rational policy. Take ozone, which can exacerbate lung diseases -- notably childhood asthma. According to the E.P.A.'s independent Science Advisory Committee, there is "no bright line" beyond which exposure is harmless to those at risk. Even natural background levels of ozone exceed the legal limit.
What to do? After pointing out that all the possible options on the table would have a very small impact on asthmatics, the board labeled the choice a "policy judgment." The current ozone standard is 120 parts per billion. Of the eight members willing to stand up and be counted, three favored a reduction to 80 parts per billion, one favored a range of 80 to 90, three favored 90 and one favored a range of 90 to 100.
The committee was equally at sea on a standard to cover soot particles ranging in size from 2.5- to 10-millionths of a meter in diameter. Their failure to find a consensus was driven by what George Wolff, the chairman, called the "many unanswered questions and uncertainties" in separating the health impact of very small particles from those of larger soot particles and the other pollutants typically found in smog.
The E.P.A.'s response to all this was better safe than sorry. While the proposed rules would relax the standards on transient spikes in pollution that are less likely to be serious health hazards, new controls would greatly increase compliance problems for relatively dirty regions, including Southern California, New York City and Houston. And they would push hundreds of counties with relatively clean air into noncompliance. Business interests, along with a number of governors, cried foul.
Denying E.P.A.'s call to virtue is no small matter, however, since few members of Congress are ready to be seen as running dogs of coal, oil and auto interests. Indeed, the proposed standards might have easily slid into the rule books were it not for the skepticism in internal Administration documents.
An analysis by the Council of Economic Advisers is particularly troubling. The E.P.A. estimated that the costs of compliance would run from $6.6 billion to $8.5 billion annually, while the benefits would be worth $51 billion to $112 billion. Alicia H. Munnell, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, demurred.
By her estimate the costs of the ozone standard alone would run between $11.6 billion and $60 billion a year. And the benefits, she argued, would be modest, with hospitalizations for asthma in New York City falling by less than a half percent. Translating health benefits into dollars, she estimated that for the nation the annual benefits would run to less than $1 billion.
There is room for compromise, particularly on ozone: keeping the proposed standard at 80 parts per billion while lengthening the averaging period from eight hours to a full day and permitting more days of noncompliance would be no harder to meet than the current, 120-parts-per-billion standard. And while the E.P.A. has not tucked tail and run, the agency's administrator, Carol M. Browner, is quick to point out that "we haven't made a final decision."
The much bigger question here is whether Congress will ever rewrite the law, allowing the E.P.A. to weigh dollars against lives. Some day, some way, Americans will have to come to terms with the fact that they can't have it all.

HEADLINE: PATAKI TO COMMIT $100 MILLION SHARE TO A HUDSON PARK

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki has decided to commit $100 million in New York State money toward construction of a long-delayed waterfront park on crumbling piers along the heart of Manhattan's neglected Hudson River shoreline, officials said yesterday.
The $300 million Hudson River Park, conceived after the defeat of the Westway highway and development project in 1985, would lie along five miles of waterfront like green beads on a string of bicycle paths and walkways. Interspersed with open space would be commercial enterprises. 
 Disputes over proposed designs, the cost and the appropriate mix of green space and commerce have stalled action until now, with the area between Battery Park City and 59th Street remaining mostly a gloomy gap of temporary roads, parking lots, barbed wire and sagging piers.
Now, though, many longtime proponents of a waterfront park say everything is finally in place to break the deadlock. "The Governor's commitment is really the linchpin for moving ahead," said Carol Ash, the executive director of the Nature Conservancy of New York State, a private conservation group.
The $100 million contribution, which Mr. Pataki is expected to announce today, would be generated over the next six years from both the Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act and the state's Environmental Protection Fund.
Even with the pledge of state funds, a number of hurdles remain for the park plan. A draft analysis of the environmental impact of the project is scheduled to be released by the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation later this month for public comment. The plan must also go through New York City's land-use review process and will be subject to Federal and state environmental permits before the first construction can begin -- at the earliest next spring if it is not blocked by lawsuits, according to several state officials.
Under the administrations of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins, the state and New York City had each agreed to commit $100 million to the park project, which would occupy a mix of land, piers and waters controlled in part by the state and the city. But until now, only the city had formally committed money to the park. The source of the remaining $100 million has yet to be spelled out.
In his printed statement, Mr. Pataki said, "The Hudson River Park is a project whose time has come." He qualified his endorsement of the plan, saying he would reserve specific comments until a review of the environmental impact of the park plan is completed later this month. He said the remaining $100 million would come from income from leases and from private sources. Pataki administration officials declined to elaborate on the nature of the private sources.
The city's $100 million commitment is already in the budget, said David Klasfeld, chief of staff to Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro. He said the Giuliani administration looked forward to working with Mr. Pataki on creating the park. "This is a terrific project that will allow people to make the greatest utilization possible of the waterfront," he said. "We're enormously pleased that the Governor has stepped forward."
Mr. Pataki's planned announcement is to come one week after he met with the Hudson River Park Alliance, a coalition of a dozen environmental and civic groups that has pressed for the long-delayed state money since last November.
Several people who attended the meeting, which had first been sought four months ago, said Mr. Pataki told the group that the amount of retail business mixed in with green space in the latest park plan would be the most that he would support, raising hopes of some environmental groups that commercial interests would not cut into the percentage of public space in the plan.
In his prepared statement, Mr. Pataki elaborated on that pledge, saying he would create a task force, including community groups and state agencies, to insure that existing and future leases for commercial purposes in the planned park area mesh with the goal of the park -- which is to invigorate and open up the waterfront.
He also responded to another concern of community groups, saying he would order the State Transportation Department, which controls the piers and waters south of 34th Street, to account for rent received since 1982 from commercial enterprises that have occupied some piers. The money, as much as $45 million, was supposed to be devoted to park expenses, but much of it appears to have gone into other projects. Some Manhattan civic groups suspect that the money went to transportation projects in other parts of the state.
In his statement, Mr. Pataki said any past revenue that flowed elsewhere would be made up for with new payments into a dedicated account for the future park. He also proposed that income to the state from future leases go directly to park projects.
Members of the Hudson River Park Alliance hailed Mr. Pataki's support for the park, saying it could be the move that spurs action.
"The city and the state have always been a bit like Alphonse and Gaston on this," said Barnabus McHenry, the chairman of the Hudson River Valley Greenway Communities Council. "It's always been, who steps first?"
Mr. McHenry said the plan could vault New York City from a laggard on waterfront revitalization into a leader. "No city has ever built a park on piers like this," said Mr. McHenry, whose group helps coordinate shorefront revitalization from the Battery to Troy, N.Y.
But even with Mr. Pataki's support and the prospect of state money, the riverfront park still faces a host of problems, said Albert K. Butzel, a lawyer who worked on the legal challenge to the Westway plan for the riverfront two decades ago and who now heads the park alliance.
The New York State Department of Transportation has been issuing leases for so-called temporary uses of the waterfront, like the Aquamarine Restaurant, he said, that could become so entrenched that they will not easily give way to the park plan once it begins.
Mr. Butzel complained that while the state had been quick to approve commercial operations like parking lots and restaurants, it had turned down requests for interim uses of some piers and adjacent land for sports or recreation. Mr. Butzel also raised concerns about a decision by the city in 1995 to create television studio space on Pier 92 and Pier 94 at the north end of the Passenger Ship Terminal, when both had been designated for a mix of public and commercial uses. As part of that lease, the park would also lose a tree-lined four-block esplanade along the river between 52d and 54th Streets.
He said Mr. Pataki's proposed review of leases might help prevent further loss of parkland.
Mr. Klasfeld, in the Mayor's office, defended the plan for television production space. "Studios are greatly need in the city," he said. "And the park needs economic development to support itself." If a current proposal for studios fails to gel, then the city could reconsider what to do with those piers, he said.
Once reviews of the project's environmental impact are complete, with the state and city money flowing, the first phase of shorefront rehabilitation -- west of Greenwich Village -- could begin as early as next spring, Mr. Butzel said. "It's been a long wait," he added.
H. Claude Shostal, the president of the Regional Plan Association, a private urban planning group in Mr. Butzel's alliance, said the main threat to the park plan was this kind of "nibbling away."
Right now, he said, the Hudson River Park Conservancy, the state agency responsible for the plan, has no binding powers. The cut in public space on Piers 92 and 94, for example, came after an informal letter of agreement between the city and the state, with no outside review, he said.
"Even though the Governor is making an overall large commitment," he said, "unless the city and the state can work together to firmly defend this park, it could suffer incremental death, one bite at a time."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Gephardt Vs. Gore

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
I can't believe I'm writing this sentence, but it's true: The race for the Democratic Presidential nomination for the year 2000 is already having a profound, and unhealthy, affect on Clinton foreign policy.
Here's what's going on. One of the biggest foreign-policy questions before the Clinton Administration in its second term is: Do we want to keep expanding Nafta throughout South America, and sign more free-trade agreements with other countries around the world? 
 You'd think this was a no-brainer. President Clinton hailed Nafta as one of the great achievements of his first term, and Vice President Al Gore led the Summit of the Americas in Miami in 1994, which proclaimed free trade throughout the hemisphere as its goal. But since then, Nafta and "free trade" have become almost dirty words for the Clintonites, thanks to some foul political winds that have swirled together recently.
First, the anti-globalization movement, led by Pat Buchanan, is still with us, arguing that free trade and global integration cause stagnating wages. (Wrong. What primarily hurts lower-skilled workers is rapidly advancing technology that replaces them with machines, computers and voice mail, not free trade.) Combined with this is a growing sense that Mexico has become a drug-infested, financially strapped state and that somehow Nafta is to blame. And combined with this is a sense that China, with its human rights abuses, low wages and closed markets, is the new archenemy of American labor and should be punished. All this has put advocates of free trade on the defensive.
Now add the politics. Representative Richard Gephardt has emerged as the leading challenger to Mr. Gore in 2000. Mr. Gephardt, long a critic of Nafta, smells the new public mood. He is positioning himself to take advantage of it and to saddle Mr. Gore with the free-trade argument. Mr. Gephardt hasn't come out explicitly against more free-trade accords, but on Feb. 26 he circulated a 12-page letter to his Democratic Congressional colleagues that attaches so many labor, environmental and political conditions to any new free-trade agreements as to make them virtually impossible. Noting in his letter that "many Americans see themselves as victims, rather than beneficiaries, of recent trade agreements," Mr. Gephardt urged that Congress go slow in granting the President any new "fast-track" authority to negotiate more free-trade agreements. That's a pretty good strategy for tying up the anti-Nafta labor vote and A.F.L.-C.I.O. endorsement for 2000.
Said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics: "Gephardt is playing to the losers from globalization. He isn't playing to all those Americans working in export jobs which pay much better, not to mention the millions who benefit from low-priced imports of shoes, clothing and other attractive products. Clinton must confront this issue directly."
For now, though, the Clintonites, who are rightly focused on getting the budget passed, have been reluctant to take on this extra battle. The Administration has stopped talking about extending Nafta to Chile, which last year was considered a slam-dunk. So Chile is signing its own free-trade accords with Canada, Europe and Mexico and leaving the U.S. behind.
But the battle is coming. Congress has to decide this year whether to give Mr. Clinton fast-track authority, and that's going to really turn into a national debate on how we feel about globalization. Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore should come out swinging, not ducking. At a time when the U.S. is the job-creating envy of Europe and Japan, at a time when U.S. companies dominate their European and Japanese competitors in virtually every post-industrial business -- from software to package delivery -- the U.S. has everything to gain from more free-trade agreements. Our market is already the most open, so we only gain from getting more access to others'. And there is no reason we can't accompany more free-trade accords with reasonable programs to assist and retrain the minority of lower-skilled U.S. workers who might lose jobs in the transition.
Mr. Gore's defeat of Ross Perot in the Nafta debate was politically his finest hour. He and Mr. Clinton could demolish Mr. Gephardt on this issue if they really engaged it. Without their leadership, though, the country that led the world to liberalization and market access agreements is going to end up leading the world in retreat, and we will all be poorer.

HEADLINE: Anti-Tobacco Groups Push for Higher Cigarette Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In a drive to reverse a recent surge in teen-age smoking, anti-tobacco forces are pushing for a combination of state and Federal tax increases that could raise the cost of a pack of cigarettes by more than $1.
Buoyed by public revulsion at disclosures that tobacco companies have been aiming at teen-agers for years with sophisticated advertising and marketing techniques, advocates are lobbying for tax increases in 19 states and hope to have campaigns going in all 50 by next year. 
 Also, Congress is considering a bill introduced last month by Senators Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to nearly triple the Federal excise tax on cigarettes, to 67 cents a pack from 24 cents.
With polls showing that a vast majority of Americans -- and even most smokers -- support raising taxes to discourage adolescents from lighting up, politicians from both parties are rushing to attach their names to that rarity, a tax rise that seems not only safe, but positively virtuous.
"Raising tobacco taxes is our No. 1 strategy to damage the tobacco industry," said John D. Giglio, manager of tobacco-control advocacy for the American Cancer Society. "The tobacco industry has found ways around everything else we have done to reduce smoking by teen-agers, but they can't repeal the laws of economics."
The anti-tobacco lobby's goal is to raise state cigarette taxes to a uniform $2 a pack nationwide in the next several years, from the current range of 2.5 cents in Virginia to 82.5 cents in Washington State.
If the Federal Government increases its tax to 67 cents as well, the average cost of a pack of cigarettes would rise to $4.23, from $1.80, as the result of the tax increases alone. That, opponents of smoking believe, would be enough to drive millions of smokers, adults and teen-agers alike, to kick the habit and dissuade hundreds of thousands of young people from taking it up.
Utah and Arkansas have already approved small cigarette-tax increases this year, and increases of as much as $1 a pack are being debated in Maryland, Alaska and Maine. Anti-smoking forces say chances are good for passage in those states and in Alabama, Hawaii, New Hampshire and perhaps New Jersey, Wisconsin and Wyoming as well. South Dakota, Virginia and Wyoming have rejected cigarette tax increases this year, but the Wyoming measure is expected to be revived.
While the number of states considering higher taxes is lower than in some previous years, both advocates and opponents of the measures say the energy and money behind the current effort make it more formidable than ever.
"Any legislator can introduce a bill," said Walker Merryman, a vice president of the Tobacco Institute, the industry trade association. "What is different is the seriousness of these efforts.
"Our industry is the subject of a coordinated, energetic campaign to raise cigarette taxes. All we can do is redouble our efforts."
The anti-tobacco forces say the campaign has strong grass-roots support. State Representative Con Bunde, a Republican who is sponsoring Alaska's bill, agrees. Three years ago, he would have got nowhere if he had pushed such a measure, he said.
"But now the debate is not about if we will raise the tax, but whether it will be a dollar a pack or $1.29," Mr. Bunde said.
Mr. Bunde, a bush pilot, said he thought the same forces that shaped the debate in his state were at work across the country.
"What changed is that Republicans went home for the election last fall and found that while generally speaking, no one likes more taxes, tobacco taxes are an exception," he said.
Opponents of smoking say they turned to the cause of higher cigarette taxes after the industry blunted efforts to limit cigarette vending machines, restrict where people can smoke and, in California and Massachusetts, broadcast government-financed anti-smoking messages intended for teen-agers. By next year, they say, they hope to have campaigns under way in every state. They expect support for their cause to grow as the result of the Liggett Group's break with the industry last month. Liggett, the maker of Chesterfields and L & M's, acknowledged that nicotine was addictive and that the industry had long picked young people as targets.
The movement to make cigarettes more expensive comes as many states, flush with budget surpluses, are considering cuts in income or sales taxes or one-time refunds. But even champions of lower taxes like the looks of this increase. In Maryland, Gov. Parris N. Glendening, a Democrat, is backing a bill to double cigarette taxes in tandem with a bill to cut state income taxes by 10 percent. Last week, Maryland legislators rejected the cigarette tax increase, but the bill could be revived this week.
"The issue the Governor is raising is, What can we do to prevent kids from starting to smoke and to get those who have started to stop?" said Ray Feldmann, a spokesman for Governor Glendening.
The two main groups behind the current drive are the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J., which has committed $100 million to anti-smoking efforts, and the American Cancer Society, which has committed $10 million. The money is being used to hire organizers, distribute voter education materials, hold conferences and take surveys. The two organizations are also the main financial backers of the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, a national tobacco-control advocate.
"Legislators read polls," said Dr. Steven Schroeder, the foundation's president, "and the polls tell them that this is probably the only tax that has widespread appeal. People know it is a deterrent and that the longer you can delay kids from starting smoking, the less likely they are to become smokers."
That is a truism that the tobacco industry has long understood -- and worried about. An internal memorandum at the Philip Morris Companies from 1981 said the company should "take seriously" a statement by the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., that higher Federal excise taxes could be used to reduce smoking by young people.
"It is clear that price has a pronounced effect on the smoking prevalence of teen-agers," the memorandum said, adding that the bureau's estimate that a 10 percent increase in cigarette prices would lead to a 12 percent decline in the number of teen-agers taking up smoking was "of greatest significance to the company."
Asked about the memorandum, a Philip Morris spokeswoman, Mary Carnovale, said, "We don't want kids to smoke and we want stricter enforcement of state laws, restrictions on vending machines, stopping cigarettes through the mail, stopping sampling, things of that nature."
An informal survey of teen-age smokers in New Jersey, however, suggests it will not be easy to get them to stop. At the Monmouth Mall in Eatontown, Wanda Morales, 18, of Long Branch, said a 50-cent or $1 increase would be enough to make her discard her pack-a-week habit because "I want to quit anyway." But hardened puffers said they would be more resistant. Thirteen-year-old Karl Becker of Atlantic Highlands, who started smoking at the age of 11 when a friend offered him a cigarette, conceded that $5 a pack "would make me rather upset." But, he added, an extra dollar or two would not bother him.
And in Union City, teen-agers taking lunchtime drags at a bodega two blocks from their high school said nothing could induce them to quit.
"It kills all the stress, you know?" said Robert Diaz, a 17-year-old sophomore. "It makes me feel good."
One of his friends, Mike Perez, 14, pulled a package of Djarum cigarettes out of his pocket.
"These cost $4 a pack already, but that's what I like," he said. "Those companies, you know, they make it all look so nice -- bright colors, lots of kids smiling. I just can't let my grandma find out I smoke."
In Albany, bills that would raise cigarette taxes from a nickel to a quarter per pack, with the money going to finance health care for children of the working poor, have been introduced by Democrats but are not moving toward passage.
Smoking by teen-agers had been declining for years, but that trend has reversed in the 1990's. According to annual surveys by the University of Michigan, the portion of high school seniors who indulge went up to 34 percent last year, from less than 28 percent in 1992.
Part of that increase, Mr. Giglio of the American Cancer Society said, reflects an upward swing in drug and alcohol use, but part of it results from steep price reductions on Marlboros and other heavily advertised cigarettes in 1994. The median price of a pack of cigarettes, including taxes, has fallen since 1993, a Tobacco Institute report shows, to $1.80 last year from $1.84 in 1993. Adjusted for inflation, the decline would be even greater.
Even William F. Shughart, who has served as an expert witness for the cigarette industry, said that raising cigarette taxes would reduce teen-age smoking. "They are more price-sensitive than adults," said Mr. Shughart, a senior fellow with the Independent Institute, a libertarian research center in Oakland, Calif., and the Self Professor of Economics at the University of Mississippi. He added, though, that higher taxes could not be justified because the costs to society of smoking were more than covered by existing cigarette taxes.
Mr. Merryman of the Tobacco Institute complained about the anti-tobacco lobby's embrace of popular programs to spend the extra tax money on, like mandatory kindergarten in New Hampshire.
"Who is going to say they are against kindergarten for kids?" he asked.
But Eric Gally, an organizer with the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, said public awareness that cigarette companies had sought to attract children was "beginning to erode the enormous clout that the tobacco industry has in state legislatures, and it is no secret how they have gained that clout -- through decades of contributions, by hiring the best lobbyists, by wining and dining legislators, sponsoring golf outings, giving tickets to sporting events."
Most teen-agers do not smoke, and some are vocal in their distaste for tobacco. Joe Lewis, 17, a senior at Wootton High School in Rockville, Md., and a member of a local group, Students Opposed to Smoking, says bumping up taxes by a nickel or a dime would have little effect. He advocates the full shock treatment.
"If cigarette prices went up by a dollar, a lot of kids would still try cigarettes once, like I did," he said. "But the younger ones, the seventh and eighth graders, couldn't afford it and wouldn't become addicted."

Economists say that for every 10 percent rise in the overall price of cigarettes, 12 percent fewer teen-agers will start smoking. Chart shows the current excise tax on cigarettes and the proposed increases, state by state. (Sources: Tobacco Institute; American Cancer Society)

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Officials' Doubts Grow On Saudi Held in Canada
United States officials said they were increasingly doubtful that a Saudi arrested in Canada could provide a breakthrough in the investigation of the bombing last year that killed 19 Americans in Saudi Arabia. Senior Administration officials said that it was not clear that enough evidence existed to warrant bringing the man, Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, to the United States. Canada rebuffed a request by the F.B.I. to interview Mr. Sayegh until a decision is made on whether he should be deported. A6
 
Israeli Truck Is Firebombed
A firebomb caused a truck carrying Israeli soldiers to plunge off an embankment, overturn and burn near a Palestinian refugee camp in the West Bank. The driver and 12 soldiers were injured. Elsewhere, two Jewish settlers were arrested for allegedly beating a disabled Palestinian man after their car was stoned. In Gaza, the Palestinian police reportedly arrested about 30 members of Islamic Jihad, a group that claimed responsibility for attempted suicide bombings on Tuesday. A6
 
Zaire Rebels Block U.N. Airlift
United Nations officials said rebel forces in eastern Zaire had blocked their plan to airlift 20,000 to 30,000 exhausted and hungry Rwandan refugees back to their homes from Kisangani. The proposed airlift is part of a broader attempt to rescue 100,000 Rwandan refugees who fled their camps when they were overrun by the rebel forces. A5
 
Russia-Belarus Pact Signed
President Aleksandr R. Lukashenko of Belarus initialed a charter with his Russian counterpart, Boris N. Yeltsin, that if ratified will pave the way for a union of the neighboring republics. But Mr. Yeltsin heeded pressure from liberals in his Cabinet, who oppose close identification with Belarus' centralized economy and the authoritarian ways of Mr. Lukashenko, and insisted on a weaker version stressing that both countries would remain sovereign. A9
 
Famine Near in North Korea
Red Cross officials warned of imminent famine in North Korea. They said kitchens were bare, children were weak and cattle were being slaughtered to save grain. A similar report was released by the United Nations World Food Program, which said it planned to double its $41 million aid appeal for North Korea, citing fears of starvation "on a massive scale." (Reuters)
 
Crew Innocent in Ferry Sinking
The international commission investigating the sinking of the ferry Estonia, which killed 852 people in September 1994, exonerated the crew, according to Swedish radio. The commission's report instead blamed the weak construction of the boat's bow door and vehicle ramp and heavy seas. The Estonia was en route to Stockholm from Tallinn when waves ripped off the door by which vehicles entered the ship. The German company that built the ferry blamed poor maintenance. (AP)

Democrats Are Shown Coordinating With Clinton
The White House released documents showing that President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore received a constant stream of very detailed information about party fund-raising before the 1996 election. Mr. Clinton has tried to separate his campaign from the fund-raising efforts of the Democratic National Committee, but the documents show the two were closely coordinated. A1

Strawberries Blamed in Illness
Strawberries imported from Mexico have caused 153 cases of hepatitis A infection among schoolchildren and teachers in Michigan, Federal health officials said. Thousands more children in Arizona, California, Georgia, Iowa and Tennessee were advised to get gamma globulin shots to help prevent the viral liver ailment. A1
 
Scientists Still Believe in God
Forty percent of American scientists say they believe in a God who actively communicates with humankind and to whom one may pray "in expectation of receiving an answer," a survey found. An identical survey in 1916 found similar results. A14

HEADLINE: Disney Unveils Restored New Amsterdam Theater

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
So what if Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, referred to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as Mayor Cuomo? There were no hard feelings. And anyway, no less a personage than Gov. George E. Pataki reassured Mr. Eisner that the Mayor did not plan to retaliate "and refer to you as Chairman Ovitz."
It was that kind of day. In an ebullient, even frisky, news conference yesterday that displayed the unusual bond between the public sector and a private company, the three men officially unveiled the $34 million renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street in Times Square. 
 The New Amsterdam, an Art Nouveau playhouse that opened in 1903, had devolved into a seedy movie house by the time it closed in 1981 and started to fall into colossal disrepair. It was two years ago that Disney signed a 49-year lease on the theater with 42d Street Development Project, a state agency, and yesterday's event -- which featured an erstwhile "Phantom of the Opera," singers in white togas and waiters with trays of lobster and salmon canapes circulating among the reporters and photographers gathered on the theater's stage -- was a lavish celebration of that occasion, which Mayor Giuliani referred to as "the turning point" in the revival of Times Square.
The city and the state, which helped subsidize the renovation, presented Mr. Eisner and Disney with a plaque; Mr. Eisner, for his part, presented the Mayor and the Governor with seats that had been salvaged from the wreckage of the old theater.
But ceremony was only a small part of things; the rest, of course, was promotion. Amid the mutual backslapping -- "It sounds like we are all congratulating each other, which in fact we are," Mr. Eisner said -- came the announcement that Disney would not only hold the world premiere of its newest animated film, "Hercules." in the New Amsterdam on the evening of June 14, but that afterward, a Hercules-themed parade would take to the streets, marching east along 42d Street to Fifth Avenue and then north to 66th Street, effectively claiming midtown for the Disney Company on a Saturday night.
David Klasfeld, the chief of staff for Rudy Washington, the Deputy Mayor for economic development, said that the city's costs for the parade, about $500,000, would be paid by Disney. "It might be unusual," Mr. Klasfeld said, for a commercial entity to claim the city's streets for a promotional event, but not unheard of. After the World Series, he said, the Yankees paid for the ticker-tape parade the city held in their honor.
Marcus Lovett, one of the many past stars of "Phantom of the Opera," began the festivities with a song from "King David," a musical oratorio by Alan Menken and Tim Rice that will be the first show performed in the New Amsterdam Theater; it opens a nine-day run on May 15 with Mr. Lovett in the title role. The news conference concluded with the curtain rising to reveal the spectacularly refurbished theater, and a choir perched in the balcony, singing two songs from the stage version of "The Lion King," which Disney is to open at the New Amsterdam in the fall.
It was in the spirit of show business that the Mayor and the Governor spoke. Far more animated and off the cuff than is his wont, Mr. Pataki chided the Mayor, saying that the singers in togas -- who were all women -- must have taken a cue from his appearance in drag at the Inner Circle dinner last month. Mr. Giuliani said he could teach the singers a thing or two, noting that they weren't wearing high heels.
In his closing remarks, Mr. Eisner hit upon the real theme of the day: the allies that opportunity makes. He told a story about walking along 42d Street with the Mayor more than two years ago, when Times Square was still on the rank and seamy side. He said he expressed his reservations about bringing Disney's family-style entertainment to a street dotted with pornography parlors. Mr. Giuliani fixed him with a stolid gaze, Mr. Eisner said, and stated more than once: "Michael, they'll be gone."
"I don't know where they went," Mr. Eisner said. "Fifth Avenue?"
Mr. Pataki couldn't help himself.
"New Jersey," he said.
While the assembled reporters tittered, Mr. Giuliani reached behind Mr. Eisner's back to shake the Governor's hand, though Mr. Eisner himself seemed a bit nonplussed.
"I didn't say that," he said. "The Disney Company loves New Jersey."

HEADLINE: Stocks Resume Their Slide; Dow Drops Another 94.04

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
A late selling wave swept stock prices down for the third time in four sessions yesterday, bringing the Dow Jones industrial average to within 70 points of where it started the year.
The Dow fell 94.04 points, or 1.42 percent, to close at 6,517.01. Broader indexes slid by comparable percentages. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.53 points, or 1.25 percent, to 750.11. The Nasdaq composite index slid 15.93 points, to 1,201.00. 
 The downturn is now the most severe since early 1994, when the Dow fell 9.6 percent during a period of rising interest rates. The Dow has fallen 8 percent since March 11, when it peaked at 7,085.16.
While most analysts believe that stocks are merely going through a "correction," or a modest adjustment after a sharp run-up in prices, others believe that rising interest rates, inflationary pressures and declining corporate profitability are starting to shake the underpinnings of one of the greatest bull markets in history.
"The basic fundamentals of the bull market are eroding dramatically," said Michael Metz, the chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company, who has long been bearish on the market. "The next big nail in the bull coffin will be a shift in asset preferences away from equities."
Yesterday's selling sent 27 of the 30 component Dow stocks lower. Those included I.B.M., down 3 a share, to 133 3/4; J. P. Morgan, down 3, to 96 7/8, and the Travelers Group, which lost 2 5/8, to 47 1/4. In the last five sessions, as the Dow has lost about 3.3 percent, only one component stock -- McDonald's -- has gained ground.
Stocks of banks and financial-services companies, which many analysts believe will be hurt by higher interest rates, were hit again. The S.& P. Financials index, which is down 9 percent in the last month, lost more than 2 percent of its value yesterday. Among the biggest losers were Chase Manhattan, down 2 5/8 a share, to 92 3/8; BankAmerica, down 3 1/4, to 100 1/8, and Citicorp, down 2 1/4, to 109 7/8.
Technology issues were also hard hit. The technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 index lost 1.6 percent, in part because of drops by Intel, which was off 2 5/16 a share, to 137, and Microsoft, which tumbled 1 1/4, to 92.
Yesterday's decline, which saw the Dow fall as much as 111 points late in the session, was once again exacerbated by heavy program trading, analysts said.
According to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn., there were 12 large computer-driven programs yesterday that took more than 79 points off the Dow. The biggest, which came at 3:27 P.M., was the sale of about 400 stocks worth an estimated $110 million. That trade alone took about 51 points off the Dow, Birinyi said.
"It's been mostly programs," Greg Schoenleber, an analyst at Birinyi, said. "The down days recently, if you look at the net effect, it's all programs."
But analysts said that computer-driven trades are not creating a downturn, they are simply quickening its pace.
The rise in interest rates -- and the fear of further increases -- has been the primary culprit, analysts say, because of investor concerns about what effect the rise might have on corporate profits as companies are forced to pay more for loans.
The plunge in stocks accelerated last week after Federal Reserve officials raised short-term interest rates as a pre-emptive strike against inflation. Though there have been few signs of inflation, investors are worried that the Fed will slow the economy, or even send it into recession, by continuing to raise rates.
In the meantime, analysts believe that as bonds see their yields rise, they are becoming more attractive investments relative to stocks.
Since the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond reached 7 percent last Thursday -- it closed at 7.07 percent yesterday, unchanged from Tuesday -- the stock market has struggled.
Even as worries of future Fed action stifle stocks, some analysts believe that interest rates in the bond market will fall later in the year, giving rise to another rally.
"When the Fed raises rates, you usually get a knee-jerk reaction from the market," said Richard Bernstein, director of quantitative research at Merrill Lynch & Company. "And that's exactly what we got."

HEADLINE: High Schoolers Taking Longer To Graduate

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
While dropout rates are continuing to fall in New York City's high schools, more students are taking five, six or even seven years to earn a diploma or pass an equivalency exam, according to Board of Education statistics released yesterday.
The percentage of students who graduate on time has remained constant. For instance, fewer than half the students who were scheduled to graduate in 1996 did, the report said. More than 35 percent of that class were still enrolled this year, in their fifth year of high school, and 16 percent had dropped out. 
 In the class of 1986, by comparison, a similar proportion -- about 47 percent -- graduated on time. But a significantly higher percentage of that class, nearly 25 percent, dropped out, while fewer -- just 28 percent -- stayed in school beyond four years.
Board officials applauded the figures. "Staying in school longer is not a negative for many students," said Margaret Harrington, chief executive for school programs and support services. In the past, she added, students who didn't make it in four years felt stigmatized and dropped out. "We said, 'We want you to stay in school,' " she said. " 'We want you to earn a diploma. If that takes five years, it takes five years.' "
The board statistics presented the most detailed profile of the students who began ninth grade in 1989 and should have finished in 1993. Just under 50 percent graduated in four years, while nearly 63 percent finished high school by the end of the fifth year. By the end of the seventh year, more than 70 percent had earned a diploma or passed an equivalency exam: the highest overall graduation rate since the board began tracking the numbers in 1986.
Robert Berne, the vice president for academic affairs at New York University, who has written extensively about the city schools, said that nationally, dropout figures appear to have stabilized, in part because of curricular changes and reform efforts that were started years ago but have now begun to yield results. Given the large pool of poor and immigrant students in New York, he said, the increase in graduation rates over all, he said, ought to be commended.
"The fact that students are finishing, in the end, is the important part of the equation," he said. "While there might be some disappointment citywide that it's not in the traditional four years, it still speaks highly of a system, given our diversity -- language, income and the like -- that graduation rates are going up. In the end, it's what people learn and not how fast they learn it."
Dr. Harrington, the former Queens high school superintendent, said that students were taking longer because many of them entered high school "over age and under prepared in reading and mathematics." In the 1995-96 school year, about a third of all 9th- and 10th-grade students in the city were older than the norm, 14 for freshmen and 15 for sophomores. Moreover, 15 percent of all high school students were classified as speaking limited English and 17 percent had arrived in the United States in the previous three years, according to the school-by-school report cards released yesterday.
Immigrant students actually graduated on time in slightly greater percentages than their native-born peers in the class of 1996: 51 percent of immigrants who came into the school system in middle school graduated from high school in four years, compared with 48 percent of non-immigrant students. Their dropout rate was also lower: 13 percent, compared with 17 percent among the native-born.
But limited-English speakers took longer to graduate, and a greater share of them dropped out. In the class of 1996, nearly 50 percent of English-speaking students graduated on time, while 41 percent of limited-English students who entered the school system before ninth grade finished on time. Board officials said that schools would have to offer at least three periods of English instruction in addition to the other academic subjects to raise their graduation rates, but that not enough money was available.
In the 1995-96 school year, the city spent nearly $1 billion of its $8.2 billion budget on the high schools, or $6,831 per student.
As in the past, graduation and dropout rates were marked by racial and sexual disparities. In the class of 1996, for instance, 53 percent of the girls graduated on time, compared with 43 percent of the boys. In the same class, nearly 70 percent of white students and 64 percent of Asians graduated on time, while only 38 percent of Hispanic and 44 percent of black students finished in four years. Ten percent of white students and eight percent of Asians dropped out, compared with nearly 22 percent of Hispanic students and 17 percent of black students.
At Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers in lower Manhattan yesterday, Sateima Powell, 17, discussed the quandary she had faced over staying in school or dropping out. Ms. Powell, a junior, had spent much of her sophomore year skipping and then failing her classes. She straightened out, she said, because she did not want to stay in school forever. "I'm just doing what I got to do," she said.
Down the street, Iris Romero, a 16-year-old sophomore, was doing what Ms. Powell regrets having done: skipping class and soaking up the sun. Many students drop out as sophomores, Ms. Romero said, because classes are boring and the outside world alluring. Even so, Ms. Romero and her friend, Patty Curo, a sophomore on her lunch break, said they would stick it out. "I want to stay in school, but I wish they would make it fun," Ms. Romero said.
Besides, said Ms. Curo as she sucked on a red lollipop, the economics of a high school diploma were clear. "I don't want to get a G.E.D. and work at McDonald's," she said.
In addition to dropout rates, the reports released yesterday showed that more ninth-grade students were passing the Regents examination in math: nearly 24 percent in the 1995-96 school year, compared with under 20 percent two years ago. Ninth-graders passing the Regents test in science also increased to 18 percent in the 1995-96 school year from 15 percent two years ago.
Those figures are increasingly important as state and city officials raise the high school graduation requirements. The bar has already been raised in recent years: students now have to complete three, instead of two, classes in math and science. In 1995, Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines eliminated low-level arithmetic classes and required Regents-level math courses of all high school students. And starting this year, all students must take a Regents-level English class.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
The Appeal Of Modest Durability

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
One line of thinking advanced by the new production team at the New York City Opera is to stage standard repertory works less expensively than in the past so that the productions can be discarded and restaged more often. Operagoers who find it difficult to imagine some of the company's stagings becoming even less elaborate may find this alarming; yet its presentations of contemporary operas, mounted inexpensively because the prospect of their return was slim, have shown that inventiveness can be had on a tiny budget. And there is much to be said for the flexibility this approach can offer.
The alternative, after all, is for the company to continue to build durable but conventional productions meant to last decades. Harold Prince's 1989 staging of Mozart's "Don Giovanni," now at the New York State Theater, is one of those. Neither objectionable nor fresh and insightful, it is a good, basic "Don Giovanni" that strives to be nothing more. 
 The sets and costumes, by Rolf Langenfass, are attractive in their modest way and undoubtedly economical. Leafy trees frame the set, and a collection of pedestals is reconfigured for each scene, with flown-in elements (a bridge, for instance) and backdrops suggesting, however vaguely, Mozart's 13 changes of location. Albert Sherman, the stage director, moves the singers around the set with sensible efficiency, and Guido Ajmone-Marsan, who conducted on Wednesday evening, moved the production along briskly.
The singing was never less than serviceable but only intermittently better. Robert Perry was a frustratingly uneven Don. When he sang in his lower range, his singing was wonderfully rounded and full of character. But in the role's more lyrical moments -- in "La ci darem la mano" or "Deh, vieni alla finestra," for example -- his intonation and phrasing were slightly clumsy. There was, however, some admirable teamwork between Mr. Perry and Herbert Perry (no relation), whose vocally solid, comically agile portrayal of Leporello was a highlight of the performance.
Amy Johnson, who made her company debut as Donna Anna, has a lot going for her in terms of sheer vocal power, and if her soprano edged toward stridency on occasion, she mostly produced an attractive, well-focused sound. She also played Donna Anna more sympathetically -- that is, less icily -- than is typical. As her paramour, Don Ottavio, Mark Thomsen made all the right phrasing moves, but his constricted sound limited the warmth of his portrayal.
Deanne Meek's Zerlina was sweet-toned and graceful, and Jeff Morrissey, in his company debut, was a dramatically and vocally flexible Masetto. Oksana Krovytska was a fine Donna Elvira. Jonathan Prescott, in another debut, was a little awkward in his sword fight with the Don but delivered the Commendatore's lines in the finale with a suitable gravity and depth.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols 

 BODY:

Under the Waves Again
In World War II, German U-boats sent merchant vessels to the bottom of the North Atlantic and occasionally retreated there themselves to escape depth charges. On the surface, survivors fought for their lives. At 800 feet, rivets popped, air was scarce, toilets were taxed, and 21-year-olds turned into old men in a grinder of depression and fear. 
 One of the more memorable antiwar films, Wolfgang Petersen's "Das Boot" ("The Boat") does as realistic a job as one can imagine of documenting life aboard a U-boat. The film, which was released in 1982, has been restored, with an hour added to its already formidable 145-minute length. (In its earliest incarnation, the movie was a 6 1/2-hour television show.) It opens today in New York and will play in 13 other cities. For that, there is home video to thank. "We had Petersen here working on 'Air Force One' with Harrison Ford," said Ben Feingold, the president of Columbia Tri-Star, the studio's video division. "We figured he could do a director's cut of 'Das Boot' at the same time."
Lured by the current "Star Wars" phenomenon, studios and their video divisions are increasingly looking to their libraries for a revenue-producing one-two punch, of big-film revivals in theaters that then do double duty in video reissues.
The longer "Das Boot" will be released on tape in the next few months. In the process, Mr. Feingold added, the studio is also cleaning up a venerable property for digital video disk and eventually digital television.

 
 
Familiar Tale Retold
 Cinderella has roamed home video in a panoply of animated and live-action guises, but no glass slipper ever slid on more opportunely than it has for "A Tale of Cinderella," a musical mounted by the New York State Theater Institute that is to be released on tape by Warner on April 15.
After taking a student production to Moscow in 1974, the institute, which is based in Troy, N.Y., received public financing to stage plays and musicals and send instructors and repertory actors into schools to work with students.
In the 1980's that led to "His Honor, the Mayor," a musical about Fiorello La Guardia that the institute produced with the public television station WNET. The show won five Emmys and was staged on Broadway, where the reviews were lukewarm, but, thanks to some hard-nosed economizing, investors got their money back.
"We went in there with low overhead," said Patricia Di Benedetto Snyder, the institute's director. Equally important, the show attracted Warner/Chappell Music, the music publisher, which in 1994 provided $400,000 to produce five musicals.
The first of these is "A Tale of Cinderella," a good-looking, award-winning rendering of the tale. Warner Home Video will share revenues with the institute. It's not Disney, but it is a money-raiser. "We won't hit with all five productions," Ms. Snyder said, "but it is funny it happened to a property called 'Cinderella.' "
 
KEEP IN MIND
 
Grit, Trauma and Myth, From New Jersey to Ireland
The work of John Sayles, whose film "Lone Star" will be released on Tuesday, is known for its warm, subtle intelligence. Here are some of his other films on tape.
 
 BABY, IT'S YOU. It's the 1960's in New Jersey, and a Roman Catholic lad called the Sheik is pursuing a smart Jewish girl. 1982. Paramount. $79.99. 105 minutes. R.
 
 MATEWAN. Mr. Sayles's film blends myth into a recounting of a 1920's rebellion and massacre in the West Virginia coal fields. 1987. Out of distribution but rental copies available. 130 minutes. PG-13.
 
 EIGHT MEN OUT. Mr. Sayles's film takes a close, poignant look at Shoeless Joe Jackson and the rest of the Chicago "Black Sox," who threw the 1919 World Series for $80,000. 1988. Orion. $19.95. 120 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.
 
 CITY OF HOPE. There's still some optimism in Hudson City, N.J., although people are getting killed, racial unrest is growing, money is running out and government doesn't seem to work anymore. 1991. Columbia Tri-Star. $14.95. 129 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
 
 PASSION FISH. Paralyzed in an auto accident, a former soap opera star (Mary McDonnell) goes home to Louisiana to deal with her self-pity. 1992. Columbia Tri-Star. $19.95. 136 minutes. R.
 
 THE SECRET OF ROAN INISH. In a blend of nature and myth, young Fiona (Jeni Courtney) returns to her family's village and rediscovers her baby brother, who years earlier was swept out to sea in his cradle. 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $19.95. 102 minutes. Closed captioned. PG.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Mark and Yen Ahead of Report on U.S. Jobs

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark and the yen yesterday after the release of strong German economic data and a report from the International Monetary Fund that said the yen had room to rise.
Nervousness ahead of American employment data for March and meetings between Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and top Japanese Government officials today also weighed on the dollar. 
 "The market is very afraid about whether Rubin will say more about trade in Japan and we're also cautious ahead of the nonfarm payrolls number on Friday," said Bob Near, a vice president on the corporate foreign exchange desk at the Bank of New York.
The currency market has been preoccupied for much of the week with United States concern about the size of Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which has risen in part because of the dollar's two-year rise against the yen. This has made Japanese goods more affordable in the United States.
In New York, the dollar settled at 122.65 yen, down from 123.25 on Wednesday. The dollar cost 1.6685 marks, down from 1.6765. The British pound cost $1.6464, up from $1.6431.
Strong German industrial output figures for February were behind the mark's strong performance. German production, driven by manufacturing strength and a seasonal rebound in construction, rose 1.9 percent in February from January and by 7.1 percent from February 1996.
The dollar weakened against the yen after release of an International Monetary Fund paper scheduled to be presented at a meeting of finance officials from the Asia-Pacific region over the weekend.
The report said that the yen's depreciation since reaching post-World War II highs in early 1995 had corrected misalignments, but also said that some of the yen's fall could be reversed. "The I.M.F. comments gave the market an excuse to sell the dollar against the yen," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York.
Over all, however, Mr. Waxman said that trading was fairly subdued ahead of today's March jobs report, which is expected to clarify prospects for another interest rate increase.
