HEADLINE: Market Place;
A good omen? Chief executives are holding on to their options.

BYLINE: By Judith H. Dobrzynski 

 BODY:
THE stock market has been nothing if not jittery in the last few weeks. But here is a positive omen that might comfort nervous investors: Most chief executives, loaded with stock options granted in the last several years, decided to exercise few, if any, during 1996. They passed up sure gains from the market's stunning 1996 rise, and took their chances on the ride in 1997 and beyond.
Consider George M. C. Fisher, the chief executive at Eastman Kodak, whose company's stock has plummeted by more than 20 percent in recent weeks in reaction to Kodak's flattened sales so far this year. At the end of 1996, Mr. Fisher could have used options to make a $27.6 million profit. Instead, he held on to all of them. 
 The actions of chief executives who did the opposite -- unlike their peers, cashed in a lot of options -- might be equally telling. They include Alan F. Shugart of Seagate Technology, who emptied his till of options and took a $7.3 million gain, and Norman R. Augustine of Lockheed Martin, who took 81 percent, or $20.3 million, of his possible gain.
Individuals have their own reasons for choosing whether or not to exercise options, of course. They may need cash to buy a new house or a painting. But the message sent by the collective action of the chief executives at 215 large companies can be read as a measure of confidence in their companies. Of all the options they could have cashed in, the median portion they chose to exercise was a mere 6 percent, according to an analysis by Graef Crystal, a pay expert based in San Diego.
The average gain from options among those 215 chief executives is higher -- 16.9 percent of the total gain possible if every option available had been exercised, Mr. Crystal calculated. That figure is up, from 11.7 percent in 1995 and 14.2 percent in 1994. But the average gain for 1996 is down significantly from what it was earlier in the 1990's -- 39.3 percent of the possible total gain in 1992 and 45.9 percent of total possible gain in 1993 -- when the stock market's outlook was not as bullish.
Before taking too much heart from these statistics, though, investors need to consider a few caveats. Compared with insider trading -- purchases or sales on the open market -- options trading is not as good a market indicator. Executives usually have plenty of time to use options, so much of the downside stems from leaving money from bigger gains on the table, rather than losing money used to buy stock. Most people who have options, experts say, exercise them too early, and financial advisers regularly tell clients to hang on longer.
"But," Mr. Crystal noted, "if the stock drops below the strike price, and stays there, option holders lose the whole thing." The difference between the strike price -- the price at which options are awarded -- and the exercise price represents the profit.
Taxes are another consideration. To avoid tying up money, option holders usually buy and sell the stock simultaneously. If they do, or if they buy and hold for less than a year, the gain is taxed at the ordinary income rate, which is about 40 percent for most chief executives.
"The gain is pretax, but an individual can only reinvest the after-tax sum," said Mikel M. Rollyson, a tax expert and former Treasury Department official who is a managing director at Morgan Stanley. If the stock is held for more than a year, any profit above the initial gain is taxed at the lower rate for capital gains.
Nonetheless, if an executive believes that his company's stock is going to plunge, on its own or with the market, he may lock in some profits. "Most C.E.O.'s have confidence in their companies," Mr. Rollyson said. "Personally, I think it would be a good time to diversify."
And some chief executives may be doing that. A look at the proxy statements of several companies showed several chief executives in the same camp as Mr. Shugart of Seagate. Charles R. Shoemate at CPC International cashed in 100 percent of his options for a $3 million gain, as did Drew Lewis at Union Pacific, with a $14.3 million gain, Hans Becherer at Deere & Company, with a $2.1 million gain, and James B. Williams at the Suntrust Bank with a $1.6 million gain.
Not far behind are two chief executives who exercised 94 percent of their available options: Arnold G. Lanbo of Kellogg, who made a $1.5 million profit, and Peter I. Bijur of Texaco, who took a $2 million gain.
John H. Bryan Jr. of Sara Lee exercised 88 percent of his available options for a $3.5 million gain, and Donald B. Marron of Paine Webberexercised 78 percent of his options for an $11.2 million gain.
Many corporate chieftains besides Mr. Fisher exercised none of their options, even though their payoffs could have been big. They come from many sectors of the economy and from companies whose futures may not be easy. They include Edward R. McCracken at Silicon Graphics, who could have pocketed $33.1 million; W. J. Sanders 3d at Advanced Micro Devices, with a potential profit of $17.3 million; Paul B. Fireman at Reebok, $60.3 million; Charles R. Schwab at Charles Schwab, $28.8 million; William W. McGuire at United Healthcare, $36.4 million; Roger A. Enrico at Pepsico, $12.5 million, and Arthur C. Martinez at Sears, Roebuck, $7.2 million.
Some chief executives seem to be hedging, by taking a few gains. Among them are Harvey Golub at American Express, who cashed in 10 percent of his options for a $3 million gain; Lawrence A. Bossidy at Allied Signal, who exercised 16 percent of his options for a $7 million profit, and Paul H. O'Neill at the Aluminum Company of America who used 58 percent of his options for a $6.1 million gain.

GRAPHIC: Table: "Cashing In" lists chief executives who exercised some of their stock options in 1996, according to proxy filings.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Government Securities Prices Remain Mixed for a Second Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government securities prices remained mixed for a second session yesterday, as investors waited for today's report on unemployment to see whether the risk of another interest rate increase should be priced into bonds.
The Federal Reserve moved to raise rates last week after strong economic reports, in an effort to head off inflation. If the employment numbers for March are strong, the Fed may be more likely to continue tightening monetary policy. 
 Traders said Treasury bills, the securities with the shortest maturities, were most strongly bid yesterday after the Fed went into the market to buy bills of several maturities. The move, known as a bill pass, was intended to permanently add $4 billion in reserves to the banking system. Though that did not signal any change in monetary policy, the prices of bills were up substantially because of the move.
But the 30-year bond was unchanged at a price of 94 17/32 to yield 7.07 percent, while the yield on a two-year note fell to 6.37 percent from 6.39 percent. Yields and prices move in opposite directions.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said predictions about the number of nonfarm jobs added to payrolls, the most closely watched figure in the employment report, "are all over the lot, ranging from a modest rise of 100,000 to another sharp gain of 300,000."
"An increase of 240,000 or more will clearly be strong and disturb an already unsettled bond market," he said. "Whereas a considerably more moderate rise of say, 150,000, is likely to produce a favorable, though tempered, reaction simply because first-quarter employment growth will still be quite substantial."
Furthermore, he said, it would be difficult to determine whether a weaker-than-expected payroll number implies a trend or simply a partial offsetting of the strong growth seen in January and February.
And while the payroll number is the most closely followed, he said, market reaction is also highly influenced by other components of the report, including the unemployment rate, average hourly earnings and the index of aggregate hours worked.
"The unemployment rate, currently at 5.3 percent, is generally expected to drop a notch to 5.2 percent, which would make the Fed and the bond market squirm a bit," he said.
Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management Inc. in Hartford, predicted that the payroll number would come in on the strong end of the range of predictions, at about 250,000 to 300,000 new jobs.
If that is the case, he said, short- sellers, who sell borrowed securities in the hope that they can later buy them back and make a profit, will feel no pressure to cover their short positions, contributing to the market's downward trend.
"Bulls may have to wait a while for the softer economic and/or inflation data they need so badly," he said.
Mr. Whelan said that if the report showed a strong gain in payrolls, a drop in the unemployment rate and a gain in hourly earnings, the yield on the long bond might soon reach 7.20 percent.

LENGTH: 713 words

HEADLINE: In America;
Bogeyman Economics

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
God help us, there's a chance the unemployment rate will ultimately fall below 5 percent.
Can you imagine worse news? 
 The abject fear that this has engendered was captured in the lead story in The Washington Post on Wednesday. You could almost hear the knees of financial analysts knocking as you read that the Federal Reserve will probably have to raise interest rates again next month if this rampaging monster of an economy doesn't hurry up and slow down.
The Post story said: "The surge in growth, which began late last year and surprised both Fed officials and private forecasters by continuing undiminished into this year, is strong enough that it could soon drive the nation's jobless rate below 5 percent for the first time in nearly a quarter century, the analysts warned."
Warned. This news comes as a warning. It's as if the nation were faced with the threat of a cure for cancer. Be on the alert: Prosperity for the jobless is just around the corner. We have no choice but to confront it, turn it around and chase it out of the neighborhood altogether. In short, we have to get the unemployment rate up.
Inflation is the bogeyman. No one has seen it in several years, but the mere thought that at any moment it might spring back to life -- the financial markets' very own Freddy Krueger -- is enough to keep the well-heeled on constant edge.
"Not only do we have to stop inflation when it happens, but the Greenspan position is that we have to anticipate it and stop it before it starts," said Robert Borosage, co-director of the Campaign for America's Future, a progressive advocacy group.
Whatever motives are driving Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the result is a brutal Catch-22 for the nation's working classes. The route to a brighter future for most men and women -- raises for those already working, and increased employment opportunities for those who want to work -- is economic growth. There is a consensus on the left and the right that growth is the answer to the persistent and potentially dangerous problem of economic inequality. The top 20 percent of Americans get nearly half of all the income. Fifty percent of American families have less than a thousand dollars in financial assets.
For a majority of Americans to do better, an expanding economy is essential. And yet, whenever there is evidence of anything beyond an anemic rate of growth, the policy is to step in and ruthlessly head it off. The effect is to slam the workplace door on millions of men and women in the bottom half, and especially the bottom fifth of the socioeconomic scale.
For those who think the so-called experts are doing anything other than flailing about in a theoretical thicket, consider their track record. These nattering nabobs of Nairu (the acronym for the nonaccelerating inflation rate of unemployment) have for the longest time been trying to pinpoint the lowest level of unemployment the economy can sustain without triggering an acceleration of inflation. In other words, without raising Freddy from the dead.
For a while it was thought that the official unemployment rate had to remain above 6 percent to keep inflation still. But the jobless rate came down, broke the 6 percent barrier and nothing happened. The theory had to be adjusted. Perhaps 5.8 percent was the magic figure. Wrong. Unemployment fell through that barrier without a peep from inflation. Well, maybe 5.5, or 5.3, or 5.2.
There is still no evidence of accelerating inflation. But there is plenty of evidence that an awful lot of people are in need of jobs and can't get them. The Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan placed ads in local newspapers last month seeking applicants for 700 positions. More than 4,000 men and women showed up. The line of eager applicants stretched for many blocks.
And already there is evidence that the working poor are being forced into a cruel head-to-head competition with welfare recipients for precious low-wage jobs. Eventually more than four million welfare recipients will be sent into the job market.
The policy makers are masters of obscurity on the crucial issue of employment. For those at the bottom who are desperate for work, an honest look at current economic policies is a glimpse into the abyss.

HEADLINE: Layoffs Stun Bakery Staff At Melba Toast Company

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
When Reese Grosett went to his bakery production job Wednesday at CPC Specialty Foods, the country's leading manufacturer of Melba toast, he noticed his name on a freshly printed list of about 45 names posted on a wall.
It announced that today would be his last day in the job. 
 "There was no warning, nothing," said Mr. Grosett, 32, who has worked at the Bronx factory on Eastchester Road for nine years. "They just put up the list. I'm still in shock."
He was not alone in his surprise. Yesterday, as word got out about the layoffs -- mostly in the bakery production department, and starting with those lowest in seniority -- senior company executives paid an unexpected visit to announce that the company's $26 million-a-year Melba toast and flat breads business was for sale. The division includes the brand names Old London, Devonsheer and JJ Flats.
Gale Griffin, vice president of corporate communications at CPC International in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said that the layoffs and the sale were not connected: the layoffs were seasonal, and the company hoped to sell the business to someone who would continue producing Melba toast. But the official line failed to quell the concerns of the 150 or so remaining employees, who said they feared that the two actions presaged the closing of another manufacturing facility in the city.
So yesterday, the employees, through United Industry Workers Local 424, appealed to city officials for help. "We're going to make every attempt to keep them in the Bronx," said Clint Roswell, a spokesman for the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer.
Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said: "The city had previously reached out to CPC to discuss how we could help keep these 200 jobs in the Bronx. Unfortunately, the company has not yet met with us to discuss the many resources we have available and have explained to them. Of course, we will do everything we can to keep these jobs right where they are."
The mere possibility that manufacturing jobs could be lost is a sensitive one in a borough that has been trying to bounce back in recent years. There have been successes, like the renaissance of the South Bronx; there have been disappointments, like the closing of the Farberware plant -- which is down the road from the CPC factory -- last year.
CPC hopes to sell the squat, white-brick factory, which it has owned since 1987 but which has been around since 1968, within a month, Ms. Griffin said. The Melba toast business has been profitable, but the company felt that "the business will be better served by a strategic buyer who can devote the resources and attention to further grow its sales and profits," according to a company statement.
The sale is part of a strategy under which the $10 billion company will focus more on its core businesses, which include soups, sauces, bouillons and such brand names as Hellmann's and Skippy, Ms. Griffin said.
But this explanation did not sit well with employees. By afternoon, as the smell of toast spread into the parking lot, some of the workers who had had a chance to assess the situation were clearly not happy.
"I asked them, 'Why did they wait so long to tell us?; What's going to happen to us?' " said Iris Garcia, a bakery production worker whose name was on the list. "I didn't get a good answer, and now I'm worried."
For many employees, the factory, where jobs pay about $10 to $18 an hour, has been like another member of the family: about 80 percent of the employees are Hispanic, many are women, and many have worked there for 10, 20 or 30 years, said Frank DeFilippi, area director of United Industry Workers Local 424.
"That's what makes this tough," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Production workers at the CPC Baking Factory in the Bronx took a break yesterday after learning that today would be the last day for many. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Shubra el Kheima Journal;
Under the Cairo Sun, the Leaden Skies Can Kill

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: SHUBRA EL KHEIMA, Egypt

 BODY:
Just upwind from downtown Cairo, the air on the dirt streets here is so thick with smoke that even the sheep have been blackened by soot. But a greater danger lies unseen: airborne lead in concentrations of up to 30 times the world health standard.
Part of the district is known as the Green City, but only out of nostalgia. From Dickensian factories manned by grimy men, what wafts southward is a toxic cocktail that by most estimates shaves four points from the I.Q. of the average Cairo child. 
 Under a 1994 law, such pollution is patently illegal. But the law has yet to take effect, so smelters still operate virtually without restriction less than 10 miles from the center of one of the world's most densely populated cities. They produce thousands of tons of lead each year from discarded car batteries that are imported in vast heaps from Europe and around the Middle East.
Attempts to catalogue pollution in Cairo produce a long list led by garbage, sewage and industrial dust. But almost everyone agrees that lead is by far the most worrisome, so ubiquitous in what people eat and drink and breathe that studies have found its concentration in the average person's blood to be higher than in any other city in the world.
Until recently, every one of the half-million cars that clog the capital burned highly leaded gasoline, and most researchers assumed that they bore principal responsibility for the problem, which the United States Agency for International Development has said is probably responsible for more than 800 infant deaths and more than 6,000 deaths from cardiovascular illness every year.
But more precise efforts to monitor air quality have found that at least half the responsibility lies with the smelters in places like Shubra el Kheima, where industry and residents share quarters with a heedlessness common across Greater Cairo.
"I think it could cause some illness," said Khalid Abdel Tawab, 26, a grimy-faced worker. He was eating a lunch bought from an outdoor stand across the street from a factory where batteries are sawed open and their innards melted in ovens to separate the lead.
Even at levels far lower than those present in the factory and its surroundings, experts say, lead causes significant health problems, most conspicuously by retarding brain development in children and, in adults, increasing the likelihood of strokes.
But Mr. Abdel Tawab, who works 10 hours a day, 6 days a week, for about $120 a month, insisted that he had not suffered any health problems in his 12 years on the job. He spoke with the kind of fatalism that has often made Egyptians slow to address health hazards. "I may start coughing in the future," he said. "Only Allah knows, and if it happens, it will be the will of Allah."
Until the late 1970's or so, the district's roads led only to agricultural fields along the Ismailia canal, and in an afternoon of conversations, many people complained about what has replaced the farms. The factory smoke stings the eyes, clogs the chest and, they said, produces so much soot that walls must be repainted three times a year.
But few knew anything about the dangers of lead, confirming a recent finding of researchers at the American University in Cairo.
About one-fourth of Egypt's 62 million people live in Greater Cairo, most of them packed into an area no more than 10 miles across. But even more stunning is how heavily the country's polluting activities are now concentrated in and near the capital city, where they account for about 41 percent of Egypt's thermal electric generating capacity, 48 percent of the country's motor vehicles, and a full 64 percent of industry.
With so many people and so much pollution in so small a space, experts say, the lead is present not only in the air in most quarters of the city, but also in food and water. And in part because no more than an inch of rain falls in an average Cairo year, the concentration of lead in some playground dust has been measured at levels that would qualify as contaminated at an American hazardous waste site.
In recent months, Egypt's Ministry of Petroleum has stopped adding lead to gasoline in most of its refineries, substituting a safer additive to provide an octane boost.
With the support of the Agency for International Development, the Government wants either to move or clean up the country's two major lead smelters, including the operations in Shubra el Kheima owned by Sayed Awadallah, which churn out 30,000 tons a year of lead pipe, lead sheets and lead ingots.
But so far, the effort has been stalled by a tension that runs through most environmental protection efforts in Egypt and is typified by the fact that the Environment Minister, Atef Obeid, is also Minister of the Public Sector, and thus oversees the state-owned enterprises that are among the heaviest polluters.
The environmental law approved in 1994 is not due to take effect until 1998, and even then companies deemed to have tried hard to meet new standards can win three more years' grace. And while the new anti-lead plan calls for Mr. Awadallah's factories to be transplanted outside the capital, his sons make clear that they are in no mood to pack up and leave.
They have demanded the right to continue importing old batteries, even though the environmental law lists them as hazardous waste. And even if they are helped to start up new, cleaner operations elsewhere, they have insisted that the factories in Shubra el Kheima will definitely stay in place.
"This is an industrial province," said Abdelnabi Awadallah, one of the sons, who said the installation of basic filters in the factories three years ago showed that the family was already doing its share to reduce emissions.
"There are 1,500 factories, and I doubt any of them have done as much," he said. "Why should we have to pack up and leave just because we make lead?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Smelters in Shubra el Kheima spewing out pollution as a passenger ferry crossed the Ismailia canal. The lead-laden air is estimated to shave four points from the I.Q. of the average Cairo child. (Josef Polleros for The New York Times)
 
Map of Egypt showing the location of Shubra el Kheima: In Shubra el Kheima, just upwind of Cairo, soot turns sheep black.

HEADLINE: Slight Rise Posted In Jobless Claims

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
More Americans applied for state unemployment benefits last week, Government figures showed today, but the fact that claims have held fairly steady suggested that the United States job market remained tight.
First-time jobless claims rose by 1,000, to a seasonally adjusted 314,000 in the week ended last Saturday, the Labor Department said. Analysts had expected an increase of 2,000 new claims. 
 That claims have held steady is "a cue that we're not getting any slackening in the labor market," said David Munro, chief U.S. economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y.
Last week's increase comes after a revised 1,000 drop in claims, to 313,000, for the previous week, initially reported as a drop of 4,000. The four-week average for new claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, rose to 312,500 from 312,000.
Both new claims and the four-week average have remained below 320,000 for eight weeks in a row, the longest stretch under that level in eight years.
"The only question is how long will it be before we see significant wage increases," said Lynn Reaser, the chief economist of Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., and whether the Fed will act again soon to push up short-term interest rates.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
From Offices to Apartments in Lower Manhattan

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Leasing has begun at the first two major office buildings being converted to apartments in downtown Manhattan, bringing the vision of turning the area into a 24-hour community one step closer to reality.
Together, the projects are bringing a total of 780 studio to four-bedroom rentals onto the market. 
 A rental office opened on Tuesday at 45 Wall Street, which is being converted into 435 apartments. The $75 million conversion of the 28-story building, spanning the blockfront on William Street from Wall Street to Exchange Place, is being done by the Rockrose Development Corporation, an experienced Manhattan converter and developer, with Whitehall Street Limited Partnership, an affiliate of Goldman Sachs & Company.
Occupancy is expected to begin sometime in June, said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager at Rockrose.
Leasing is also under way at the 21-story building at 25 Broad Street at Exchange Place, though the official opening is set for May. It is being turned into 345 apartments at a cost of about $55 million by Crescent Heights Investors, a Miami-based concern that has converted 6,000 units, mostly in South Florida.
Occupancy of the rentals at 25 Broad Street, which marks the company's first foray into Manhattan, will start in August, said Russell W. Galbut, its chief executive officer.
While the projects are the first large-scale conversions ready for leasing, several other conversions are also under way. Since New York City's Lower Manhattan Revitalization Plan was enacted in October 1995, about 2,600 apartments in 17 buildings have been planned and are in various stages of development, according to the Alliance for Downtown New York, the local business improvement district.
Among the incentives that are part of the city's revitalization plan are a 14-year phased tax abatement program for the conversion of office buildings to housing. Zoning changes include reducing the minimum unit size in older buildings to an average of 900 square feet, from 1,800. Projections are that a total of 7,000 units will be created downtown through the year 2002, when the incentives end, said Carl Weisbrod, president of the alliance.
Financing for 45 Wall Street came from the Goldman Sachs Mortgage Company and the partners' own equity. For 25 Broad Street, it came from Ullico, the Washington-based labor union fund in cooperation with CS First Boston.
Both have started leasing at a time when Manhattan's rental market is tight. Because of that, along with offering large apartments at rents that are expected to be 20 percent lower than those in established uptown locations, the projects are likely to draw tenants quickly, brokers said.
The building at 45 Wall Street was built in 1959 as offices for the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company and U.S. Trust. Last June, Rockrose bought the empty building from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, betting, Mr. Singleton said, that "there will be a burgeoning residential neighborhood downtown." Since then, the company has acquired 127 John Street, which it expects to convert to 576 apartments.
The conversion of 45 Wall Street, now more than 90 percent complete, will result in studio to four-bedroom apartments with 575 to 1,800 square feet on average. Some will have outdoor terraces provided by the natural setbacks of the wedding-cake-style building. Initial rents average $1,390 to $3,200 a month.
Most of the units will be studios and one-bedrooms "for the urban professionals we are targeting and believe will want to live close to where they work," Mr. Singleton said.
Twenty-five percent of the apartments have been designed as live-work spaces and 20 to 25 percent more will be marketed as corporate rentals. Amenities will include a golf driving range and putting green, a fitness center, two conference rooms and garage parking for 75 cars. There will also be Club 45, where tenants can gather or conduct meetings. Two apartments have already been leased, Mr. Singleton said.
At 25 Broad Street, the Italian Renaissance building that was built in 1897 as the headquarters of Paine Webber, the newly fashioned apartments will be mostly one- to three-bedroom units with luxury finishes and 10- to 15-foot-high ceilings. On average, the apartments will range in size from 800 to 2,400 square feet and initially rent for $1,750 to $4,800 a month.
"Our concept is to give people who could only afford rents of $1,700 to $1,800 the feeling of living in a white-glove building," said Bruce A. Menin, president of Crescent Heights, the developer. The original marble-clad lobby will be kept intact.
The three-bedroom units have been designed as live-work units and, at this point, "our concept is to have no more than 15 to 20 percent of the units" as corporate rentals, Mr. Menin said. Among the amenities planned are a health club, business center and storage space and laundry rooms on each floor. So far, leases have been signed on eight apartments.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leasing has begun for two buildings in lower Manhattan being converted to apartments. They are at 45 Wall Street and 25 Broad Street. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales In March Highest In Eight Years

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3

 BODY:
Despite a decline at the Ford Motor Company, March car and truck sales were the strongest in at least eight years, getting the spring selling season off to a robust start.
Ford, the last of the Big Three American auto makers to report, said today that its sales fell 2.6 percent in March from a year earlier, when its sales were strong. But over all, cars and trucks were whisked out of dealerships at the brisk, seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.8 million vehicles in March. Auto makers sold 1.4 million vehicles last month, up 1.5 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, when sales were also strong. 
 The robust results signal that the economy is still going strong, despite the Federal Reserve's modest interest rate increase last week, analysts said.
"The strength we're getting now runs the risk of turning into weakness in late 1997 or early 1998," said Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "The complication here is that the Fed is going to raise rates again."
"These are terrific numbers," said David Bradley, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. "There's an underlying, fundamental strength in the economy that is manifesting itself in higher car sales."
Despite the decrease in overall sales at Ford, its pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans proved popular in March, with sales rising 3.5 percent. But Ford's car sales slumped 9.9 percent.
Other American auto makers reported March results earlier this week. The Chrysler Corporation said its sales fell 3.4 percent in March. The General Motors Corporation said its sales rose 4.1 percent.
Besides Ford, Toyota Motor Sales reported results yesterday, and its United States sales were strong, rising 5 percent last month, with truck sales rising 11.8 percent and car sales rising 2.1 percent. The Toyota Camry recorded its best March results ever, with 40,217 sold.
Judging by the results so far, the Camry is likely to be the best-selling car of 1997. Toyota has sold 105,338 Camrys this year, well ahead of the Ford Taurus, with 88,135 sold this year, and far ahead of the Honda Accord, with 76,929 sold during the first quarter.
"Ford has already given up the best-selling car race for 1997," said Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. "It ain't over till it's over," he cautioned, but "it sounds like Camry's going to win."
Wall Street is delighted by that development because, analysts said, it shows that Ford has shifted its focus to winning profits, not sales contests. In past years, Ford has placed discounts on the Taurus, helping to spur sales results but thinning its profit margins. "That is a sea change for Ford to start putting profitability ahead of market share," Mr. Girsky said.
Other analysts agreed. "Ford management has made a fundamental shift in its thinking -- these guys have decided that profit is more important than market share," Mr. Bradley of J. P. Morgan said. "They have given up trying to make the Taurus No. 1."
While the Big Three lost 1 percent of market share to foreign auto makers -- mainly Japanese and European makers -- there were some signs of strength. The largest American auto maker, G.M., saw its market share climb again this month, as its redesigned cars and trucks started to reach dealer showrooms.
G.M.'s market share reached 31.2 percent of industry sales in March, up from 30.5 percent in February and 30.1 percent in January. "There is a modest upsurge from its trough in November of 29.6 percent," Mr. Bradley said.
Auto sales have been running better than expected so far this year, economists said. In February, the seasonally adjusted annual rate was 15.2 million. In January, autos sold at a 15.4 million annual pace. Economists expect sales to slow later, but Ford slightly raised its estimates for the year as a result of the robust sales.
At the beginning of the year, both G.M. and Ford said annual industry sales would likely fall between 14.7 million and 15.2 million cars and light trucks. Martin B. Zimmerman, executive director of government relations and corporate economics at Ford, said he now expected sales closer to the high end of his range, rather than the middle. Chrysler expects the industry to end the year with sales of 14.9 million.
"People are feeling very good about the economy and their own personal economic condition," said G. Mustafa Mohatarem, chief economist for G.M. "People are out there buying cars."
None of the Big Three's economists voiced complaints about the Fed's rate increase last week, even though higher rates eventually slow the economy, and thus auto sales.
For American auto makers, the only real cloud on the horizon is the stubbornness of the strong dollar, which makes Japanese cars less expensive, economists said. Japanese auto makers, helped by a weak yen, started the year with robust sales. "We do worry about the strength of the dollar," said Mr. Zimmerman.

HEADLINE: Tomoyuki Tanaka, the Creator of Godzilla, Is Dead at 86

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 3

 BODY:
Tomoyuki Tanaka, who frightened and fascinated generations of children with his series of films featuring an outsize, outdated creature named Godzilla, died on Wednesday at a hospital here. He was 86.
Mr. Tanaka was a prolific film producer with a serious edge and a flair for the experimental, and he worked on six films with the Academy Award-winning Japanese director Akira Kurosawa. But he is most remembered for creating the giant Godzilla, who swallowed bullet trains and knocked down buildings as he lumbered through the streets of Tokyo. 
 Years before Japanese cars and computers flooded the stores in the United States, Godzilla was among the first images that struck Americans when they thought of Japan. In his early days, Godzilla was mean, vicious and hideous, destroying everything and everyone in sight.
But in the later years, Godzilla sometimes took on a more benevolent role, defending the world from even more destructive prehistoric creatures like Megaro and Mothra. In a touch of anti-Americanism, Godzilla outdoes King Kong in one film in the series, though in the American version King Kong wins.
Godzilla became one of Japan's most memorable creatures, spawning a steady business in dolls, puzzles, video games and other toys for youngsters. In the United States, Godzilla films became so popular that by some accounts, a Godzilla film has been broadcast by some television station in the country nearly every week since 1960.
Just two years ago Mr. Tanaka, a former chairman of the Toho film studio, announced that he would make his last Godzilla film, "Godzilla vs. Destroyer." It capped a se ries of 22 such movies over four decades, seen, according to Toho, by a combined 85 million Japanese.
Mr. Tanaka was born in Osaka in 1910. He studied economics before joining Toho in 1940 to produce his first films.
Mr. Tanaka turned out more than 220 movies, only about one-quarter of them echoing war themes and exploring science fiction. His first Godzilla film, in 1954, was born of a desire to express the horror and fear that enveloped Japan after the American atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. At the time Japan was weak and poor, trying to recover from the devastation of World War II, and many Japanese were resentful of the American soldiers who then occupied the country.
In the early 1950's, a Japanese fisherman strayed too close to the Bikini atoll in the South Pacific when an American bomb exploded, and he was ultimately killed by radiation. In 1954, as Mr. Tanaka was returning home from a trip to Indonesia, his plane passed over Bikini and he suddenly came up with the idea of a story about a dinosaur aroused from millenniums of slumber by American nuclear testing.
Mr. Tanaka's plans to make a film with Indonesian partners had collapsed, partly because Japan had no diplomatic relations with the country at the time and the Foreign Ministry had therefore barred a deal.
"My plans to make a movie had failed, and so I returned disappointed," Mr. Tanaka said in an interview in 1984. "I felt like doing something big. That was my motivation. I thought of different ideas. I like monster movies, and I was influenced by 'King Kong.' "
"That was just the beginning," he said, describing the creation of Godzilla. "I went through many hardships. The first problem was the title."
After scribbling dozens of possibilities on a blackboard, Mr. Tanaka and his team came up with "Gojira," a mixture of gorilla and "kujira," the Japanese word for whale. (For the American market, the name was transliterated as Godzilla.) Then he and his team had to decide what Godzilla would look like. "We collected many pictures of dinosaurs," he told an interviewer. "The hardest part was the forehead. It took us 10 days to decide on the forehead."
Up to 1975, the Godzilla movies often suffered from poorly written scripts. The creature was put into slumber so Mr. Tanaka could reintroduce him to movie audiences in 1984.
Mr. Tanaka is survived by his wife, Chieko, and three sons.

No On-Line Busy Signal, But Fine Print: $6 an Hour
Hundreds of subscribers have complained about unexpected charges on their bills from America Online, stemming from their use of an "800" number to gain access to the service. In New York State, the Attorney General's office is looking into the situation.

HEADLINE: Civic Groups Warn State Over Pier on Houston Street

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
When Gov. George E. Pataki pledged yesterday to contribute $100 million in New York State money to help build a 50-block-long park along Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront, the last big roadblock to that long-delayed project fell.
But even before construction begins -- next spring at the earliest -- a fight is brewing over one of the first pieces of waterfront slated for rehabilitation under the plan: Pier 40, a 14-acre peninsula on stilts where Houston Street meets the river. 
 Even as they applauded Mr. Pataki's move, representatives of a variety of Manhattan civic and environmental groups warned that state transportation officials, who had temporarily leased the pier for parking lots and other commercial uses, were forgetting what the Hudson River Park project was all about: creating sun-spangled open space along the western fringe of crowded neighborhoods like Greenwich Village and Clinton.
After leaving Pier 61 in Chelsea, where Mr. Pataki announced the state's financial commitment, Tobi Bergman, a member of the board of the Greenwich Village Little League, headed to the New York State Supreme Court, where a lawsuit against the state's lease of Pier 40 was in its early stages.
He said his sports group and others had asked the state Transportation Department to set aside some land on the pier for temporary ballfields, to help introduce the community to the riverfront and to reinforce the idea that recreation remains the core of the park plan.
But last month the state denied the ballfield request.
Mr. Bergman is a member of a coalition of baseball and soccer leagues that joined in the suit with the Environmental Defense Fund, a private conservation group, charging that the four-year lease of the pier had not had a sufficient environmental review.
Mr. Bergman said: "People have been hearing for so long about the great parks that are coming that they give up. It's really important to get people excited about the waterfront and using the waterfront. These interim uses can help do that."
The dispute over Pier 40 is representative of a larger problem with the Hudson River Park, according to a variety of environmental and civic groups, many of which endorsed the plan yesterday.
The key weakness in the plan, they say, is the lack of any concrete defense against the increasing intrusion of commercial development.
The park plan was drawn up by the Hudson River Park Conservancy -- a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation, a state authority that promotes economic development -- and has always included a mix of open space and commercial activity like restaurants and marinas. But several times in recent years, the groups complain, public space has been eliminated with little public oversight, and they fear that a short-term focus on commercial uses increases the possibility that the park, when finally built, will favor commerce over recreation. .
Pier 40 is particularly important because it is one of the first areas scheduled for restoration, said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, the chief scientist for the Environmental Defense Fund, a private group, and a longtime soccer-playing resident of Greenwich Village. He said it was important for the park planners to send a signal quickly that recreation is a priority.
Adding a ball feld to the pier would cut into income from leases, he said, but it would increase public confidence in the project. "If Pier 40 goes totally toward commercial development, that could subvert the whole plan," Dr. Oppenheimer said.
Mr. Pataki said yesterday that he would create a task force, which would include community representatives, to examine the merits or drawbacks of having a ballfield on the pier in the years leading up to the construction of the finished park. Under the current plan, the pier is slated to be ringed by stores eventually, with a ballfield in a central courtyard.
He said legislation would not be needed to insure that the amount of open space in the overall plan does not shrink.
In addition, Vincent McGoan, a vice president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, said that no change to the park could be made without preparing a new environmental impact assessment. "There's no hidden agenda," he said.
Even some supporters of the park plan said that Mr. Pataki's support, while laudable, was not enough.
Andre Mele, the environmental director of the Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, a private conservation group, said that even with the pledge from Mr. Pataki, a coalition of environmental groups endorsing the park plan was going to push for legislation in Albany to strengthen the waterfront plan so that more commercial activity does not intrude.
"We'll need layers of protection," Mr. Mele said. "It's like what sailors do: If you don't know the right knot to tie, tie lots of them."

HEADLINE: A New Kind of Detective For the Longer Goodbye;
The Experts of Divorce Get A Sizable Piece of the Action

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The wife? Suing for divorce. The husband? Pleading poverty. In fact, as the owner of a secretive family business, the husband was moaning about the $2 million he'd just transferred to a creditor.
Then it was Richard Friedman's turn. He spent days analyzing the company's books and deciphering the stamps and signatures on the husband's canceled checks. Finally, Mr. Friedman noticed an endorsement written in hurried handwriting that he immediately recognized. 
 "He transferred the money all right, but it was to his girlfriend," said Mr. Friedman, who was hired to represent the wife. "The girlfriend actually endorsed the checks herself."
Mr. Friedman is a forensic accountant who specializes in divorce cases. He is an investigative number-cruncher who assesses the value of privately held corporations and family businesses, and ferrets out spouses' hidden assets.
And during the past few years in New York, Mr. Friedman and other such accounting sleuths have become increasingly engaged in the thriving industry of divorce.
The divorce rate is declining across the nation, but lately, in New York State, the number of divorces is on the rise. Also growing, particularly in Manhattan, is the size of the payouts in high-profile cases, the longevity of big-money proceedings and their financial and psychological complexities, according to lawyers and senior judges.
Census data suggest that nationally about 43 percent of marriages will end in divorce, in comparison with 50 percent a decade ago. But the number of divorces in New York State during the first half of 1996 jumped 9 percent to 29,259, in comparison with the first six months of 1995. The percentage of New York marriages that end in divorce is not known, nor is there a figure available yet for all of 1995, but the increase seems to be continuing.
"We've seen a rising volume in the matrimonial courts, and the colossus of wealth in New York has given us a large proportion of complex cases with complex issues," said Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann, administrative judge for the matrimonial courts of New York State.
And in Manhattan, where most of the state's high-end cases are filed, the number of divorce actions increased in 1996 to 17,300 from 15,800 the year before. Social scientists attribute the increase to everything from the number of aging baby-boomers to the growing numbers of women initiating divorce. They cannot say if the trend will continue. They can say that something of a cottage industry is flourishing in New York, as experts sort out the contentious new subtleties of modern-day divorce.
Divorces are often complex. But Manhattan-style divorce is in a league of its own, thanks, many lawyers say, to the growing numbers of wealthy people filing for divorce, the often well-publicized wrangling among the rich over whose fault it all is, and the battling over what constitutes marital property in a state that has seen some of nation's most sweeping appeals court rulings on the subject.
"A whole new industry has developed with a new class of financially expert -- and very busy -- people such as appraisers and evaluation experts," Justice Silbermann said. "It is becoming a huge part of the city's economy, involving enormous sums."
As a forensic accountant, Mr. Friedman specializes in matrimonial actions. There is no central registry for such investigators, but Justice Silbermann and other court experts agree their numbers are growing. And increasingly they are focusing on the lucrative matrimonial trade in addition to work on civil suits and inheritance cases.
Justice Silbermann and others say there is now a booming business for those who call themselves forensic psychiatrists, who make clinical diagnoses while delving into spouses' prior employment, medical and psychological records; custody advisers, who assess children's relationships to their parents and design parental court strategy; and pension evaluators, real-estate experts and art and antique appraisers, all of whom put values on a spouses' possessions. Although no one can exactly measure the impact on the local economy, most agree it is huge and increasing.
"It has certainly grown to be in the hundreds of millions," said Stanford G. Lotwin, who has represented Donald J. Trump in his divorce battle with Ivana Trump, as well as the investor Carl C. Icahn and Claudia Cohen, the former wife of Ronald O. Perelman. The amount of money that changes hands in big-league New York divorces each year, Mr. Lotwin estimated, "is more than a billion."
In part, this upward spiral has been caused by "a series of New York appeals court decisions that are more and more inclusive in valuing marital estates," said Raoul Lionel Felder, who has represented Iolanda Quinn, the wife of the actor Anthony Quinn, and Robin Givens, the former wife of Mike Tyson.
For example, appellate judges have appraised not only the worth of celebrity but have also said that a license to practice medicine or law has an intrinsic value in addition to the worth of the practice itself. As a result, Mr. Felder said, the marital estate "is now an ever-expanding universe requiring valuations that are more and more complex."
Furthermore, divorce in New York, where marital assets are not automatically split 50-50, "is more complicated than in any other state," said Eleanor Alter, who has represented Christie Brinkley and other celebrities. In New York, divorce "has become a full-employment act for accountants," said David B. Saxe, a New York Supreme Court justice who has presided over matrimonial cases for four years.
Since many big-time divorces are settled and sealed, the business of divorce has often been secret. But recent court documents shed light on how lucrative the industry can be.
Take the recent resolution of a bitter battle between Stuart Kerzner, a Manhattan importer, and his wife, Rina. Certainly the size of the marital estate -- $7,661,483, according to court papers -- was hardly spectacular by New York standards. But the fees were precedent-shattering. Among the five divorce lawyers involved in the case, Mr. Felder was awarded $822,249.58; Judd Burstein $242,500, and Jay Goldberg $75,000.
Mr. Friedman, the forensic accountant on the case, was awarded $274,970.87. Furthermore, Judge Saxe, who presided over the case, noted that payments for other accountants and appraisers warranted "additional expert fees" of $200,000.
In another recent prominent case, Kay LeRoy, the wife of restaurateur Warner LeRoy, asked for lawyers' fees of $200,000, accountants' fees of $75,000 and appraisal fees of $25,000.
In general, Mr. Friedman charges $260 an hour and says that in a major case, "it can cost $10,000 to $20,000 before you bat an eyelash," for work that can get messy. Recently an angry husband made Mr. Friedman spend seven hours "looking at 50 cartons of documents in an unheated warehouse with two inches of water on the floor."
Elin Lake Ewald, president of O'Toole-Ewald Art Associates Inc., has a staff of 10 former museum curators to assess antiques, paintings, china and silver. Matrimonial cases -- some of the most famous in New York -- currently make up a fourth of her business. Her firm charges $300 an hour.
At times, Ms. Ewald has been forced to referee screaming matches. Once, the bitterness escalated when Ms. Ewald's staff judged that a husband's supposed Rembrandt valued at $6 million was a fake worth only $600.
Robert A. Marino, a real-estate consultant who specializes in appraising marital property, charges $250 an hour. "We often work as historians," he said, "assessing the value of property decades and decades ago."
Valuing pensions has also become a realm for specialists. The spouse with the pension often must pay a portion of its value to the partner in a divorce settlement.
"Even for cops and firemen these days, the value of the pension can be so great that after 15 years on the job, they can't afford to buy their wives out," said William R. Burns of Lexington Pension Consultants Inc. on Staten Island.
Forensic psychiatrists charge $200 to $350 an hour and "are being employed more because the courts are identifying the significance of an increasing number of psychological problems" such as post-traumatic-stress syndrome developed after marital abuse, said Dr. Steven A. Fayer, a Manhattan psychiatrist.
In one custody dispute, Dr. Fayer discovered documents proving that a wife had tried to conceal a history of alcoholism. The result: she was allowed shared custody, but only if she sought treatment for drinking.
Another reason for the growth in the divorce industry, Mr. Felder said, is that there are more legal practitioners willing to work in the increasingly lucrative field. "It used to be that divorce was to law what proctology was to medicine," said Mr. Felder, who charges $450 an hour.
For spouses trapped in the business of divorce, the process can be "unbearable," said Iolanda Quinn, who filed for divorce in 1995 after 32 years of marriage to the 82-year-old actor -- and whose life has been ruled by dueling forensic accountants and appraisers ever since.
"It is all so unnecessary, such a waste," the 60-year-old Mrs. Quinn said. "My advice is that people should do anything they can to avoid having a divorce."

HEADLINE: Official Attacks Plan for Mining Project

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: FOLKSTON, Ga., April 3

 BODY:
Standing at the Okefenokee Swamp, an alligator lounging behind him, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt took an unequivocal public stand today against the Du Pont Company's plans to strip mine along the eastern ridge bordering this wildlife refuge.
Mr. Babbitt rejected in advance any and all arguments that plans by the company to mine titanium ore would not harm the 395,000-acre Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge wetland, with its rare wildlife, forests of pine and cyprus trees, and swamps covered with grasses and lily pads as far as the eye can see. 
 "You can study this, you can write all the documents in the world," Mr. Babbitt said, "but they are not going to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that there will be no impact."
"These studies can't possibly yield a conclusion which will be satisfactory to me," he said. "It isn't going to happen."
Mr. Babbitt said the proposed operation posed unacceptable risks to the water flows, as well as the wildlife and vegetation of the wetland wilderness at the headwaters of the Suwanee and the St. Mary's Rivers on Georgia's southern border.
The land Du Pont wants to mine for titanium dioxide, a whitening pigment used in paper and other products, is a nearly imperceptible ridge running down the entire eastern flank of the refuge. Indeed, Mr. Babbitt called it the natural levee that holds the swamp itself in place.
"It is apparent on the face of it that this refuge and this mining project are not compatible," he said while on a tour of the area.
Without waiting for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to apply for the required state and Federal permits, Mr. Babbitt came here to state his rejection of the project that in any case would be years from fruition. This highly unusual public effort by a senior Clinton Administration figure caught Du Pont off guard.
"We are surprised that the Secretary has taken a position before all the facts are known," said Jon Samborski, director of environmental affairs for the mining project. "We would not be proposing to do this unless we were confident that we can operate the project and protect Okefenokee at the same time."
Du Pont figures the cost of building the project at about $150 million and has been working closely with the wildlife service.
The giant chemical company has not yet applied for the required state and Federal permits for mining on the 38,000 acres it owns or leases here for a project that would not begin for several years.
While it was unusual for Mr. Babbitt to try to abort a development project at such an early stage, it was the latest example of the Administration's trying to hinder development just outside the boundaries of national parks, refuges and other sensitive public lands. Last year, the Government blocked a gold mine just outside Yellowstone National Park.
In the Okefenokee Swamp, the DuPont Company would need to sift the ore from the sandy soil. First it would clear-cut sections of trees and peel off a foot-thick layer of topsoil, then build mile-square impoundments and begin to dig. The company would float dredging barges on the brackish water that builds up in these pools to suck up the mucky sand, carving ponds to depths of 50 feet. A floating mill would separate the valuable minerals from the sand, and the unwanted materials would be used to fill in the wounds. After replacing the topsoil, the company would plant new pine seedlings and the operation would move to the next square in the grid, a creeping progression that would last for 50 years.
Fish and Wildlife Service scientists said they were worried that these changes could alter the little-understood water balances, and they warned that even slight changes could cause major effects in the finely balanced ecology of this wetland that is recognized worldwide as a significant biological resource.
John Kasbohm, an ecologist at the refuge, said the mining "threatens the very character of the swamp."
"If you change the hydrology, you change everything," he said. "The stakes are real high, the risks are real high. This mining operation is a very risky business."
The company would have to get permits from the Army Corps of Engineers before dredging and filling wetlands, and the Environmental Protection Agency can veto decisions by the Army Corps, although this power is rarely used. Mr. Babbitt's agency, the Interior Department, which includes the Fish and Wildlife Service and the refuge system, is consulted in these decisions but does not make the major decisions. An environmental impact study would probably be conducted in the deliberations on the permits, and Interior's scientists would play a crucial role in that process.
But Mr. Babbitt plainly has made up his mind already, and his view was only reinforced in a helicopter tour of the region, including a look at a similar mine in Florida.
He urged Du Pont to "do the people of Georgia and the people of the United States who care about God's creation a favor, by simply withdrawing the proposal once and for all."
He said that the titanium is readily available elsewhere, that the few dozen jobs involved are dwarfed by the economic importance of the refuge as a tourist attraction, and that logging timber is an acceptable way to develop the property without risking damage to the swamp.
But he said he was not contemplating any compensation for Du Pont, like trading other land or paying it not to mine. In contrast, when the Administration blocked the gold mine near Yellowstone it agreed to pay Crown Butte, the American subsidiary of the Canadian conglomerate Noranda, $65 million in other mineral rights on public lands.
Environmental groups welcomed Mr. Babbitt's stand, which they said was surprisingly strong.
"You couldn't pick a worse place to put a mine," said Josh Marks, a conservation organizer for the Georgia chapter of the Sierra Club.
Steve and Jo Knight, who last year bought a junk yard near the refuge and turned it into a campground, said they were dismayed by the project, which they thought would jeopardize their investment.
"It could kill the tourism on this side of the swamp," Mr. Knight said after Mr. Babbitt spoke to a crowd at the refuge, where 400,000 people visit every year.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Manufacturing Jobs Lost

BYLINE: By FORD BURKHART 

DATELINE: CLIFTON

 BODY:
About 200 management and blue-collar employees of Givaudan-Roure in Clifton will lose their jobs over the next 18 months as the Swiss company phases out its chemical manufacturing operation here. 
 Some 400 workers in corporate offices will remain, said Kathy DiBenedetto, a company spokeswoman. But the plant will be demolished as part of a consolidation of manufacturing operations in Europe, she said.

HEADLINE: Chicago 7 Survivor Hopes to Be No. 1 in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 3

 BODY:
Early in State Senator Tom Hayden's half-hour campaign video -- a modest effort that is by far the most elaborate media element of his shoestring race for mayor of Los Angeles -- a woman accosts him at a farmers market with a well-groomed husky on a leash.
"Why are places so un-dog-friendly all of a sudden?" she demands. 
 "Oh, the city is hostile to nature in all its forms," Mr. Hayden replies drily.
"If you get to be mayor, are you going to change that?"
Mr. Hayden assures her, "Oh, the city's going to be wild with dogs."
It is only a moment in Mr. Hayden's quixotic bid to lead the nation's second-largest city, but it sums up the madcap, anachronistic feel of the quest. With polls showing him trailing badly behind the popular incumbent, Richard J. Riordan, in next Tuesday's nonpartisan primary, Mr. Hayden doggedly crisscrosses the city these days in a small yellow schoolbus proclaiming "L.A. Not for $ ale," a superannuated subversive with steel-gray hair and a merry prankster's mischievous air.
In the last 10 days, he has accused Mr. Riordan, Senator Dianne Feinstein, and her investor husband, Richard C. Blum, of complicity in the death of a worker on a subway project being built in part by a company in which Mr. Blum has a minority interest. (He declined Mr. Blum's demand for an apology.) He has called Mr. Riordan "a racist" (then apologized and explained that he meant the remark as a sardonic distillation of how the press would report his criticisms of the Mayor as "racially insensitive.")
It would be easy to poke fun at the gonzo tactics of this former '60's radical, former husband of Jane Fonda, former comrade of Cesar Chavez and 15-year veteran of the State Assembly, where he has crusaded on behalf of gun control, the environment and his view of social justice. But it would also be wrong.
For better or worse, this 57-year-old survivor of the Chicago 7 is Mr. Riordan's only real opposition, having joined the fray when more cautious Democratic candidates declined. And he is doing his best to shake up what he calls his "anarchic, sprawling city of enclaves."
"Much as I dispute the laid-back image that Easterners put on us, because we're actually very intense," Mr. Hayden said in an interview the other day, "there's a ring of truth to the description of the city because it's so de-politicized. There is no other city on the Pacific Rim that is in the trouble that L.A. is in: San Francisco, San Diego, Portland, Seattle, Vancouver, they all have vigorous positive neighborhoods, and if you go there they gossip about politics. L.A. is defined as a world in which everything is entirely private, including civic life."
There is a touch of the poet in Mr. Hayden, and on the campaign trail his observation has a poignant ring. On Wednesday, only three reporters trailed him as he stumped through the gritty port area of Wilmington, stopping to protest the layoff of safety workers at an oil refinery, to bemoan the plight of contract truck-drivers who work long hours for steamship lines without regular benefits or salary, and to warn that a city-sponsored coal export terminal under construction would spread harmful particles into the lungs of neighborhood children because the builders refused to cover its open pit.
"He is deeply insensitive to the issue of air pollution and he's an elitist who does not care about the health of people in areas such as this one," Mr. Hayden said of the Mayor before heading off to visit with drug addicts and prostitutes in a shantytown of unpaved, sewerless streets that locals call "the third world."
Asked several times just what he would do differently, Mr. Hayden talked of appointing commissioners more sensitive to neighborhoods, but also seemed nonchalant, once proclaiming, "I don't want to get specific." At one point he walked away distractedly from his own mini-news conference to grab a pineapple protein drink proferred by a supporter.
Mr. Hayden cannot afford standard television commercials, and has relied instead on radio advertisements, including one featuring an endorsement from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and the infomercial video, broadcast a few times on a local cable channel. Local political experts confess puzzlement at his campaign.
"I initially believed that this campaign had very little to do with 1997 and everything to do with the year 2001, when the mayor's office is vacant and term limits mean Hayden will be out of office in Sacramento," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, an analyst at the Center for Politics and Economics at the Claremont Graduate School. "It seemed like the perfect shakedown cruise, but his rhetoric doesn't fit with that strategy."
Mr. Hayden said he simply decided he "could play a more effective role" as mayor than as a legislator, in a climate in which "both parties seem to be abandoning the inner cities as hopeless areas." He also uses more personal, mystic terms, borrowing an American Indian parable to chart his life's progress from rebellious eagle, to competitive midlife coyote to avuncular, experienced bear. "Being a mayor," he said, "is kind of like being a bear."
But the candidate insists he has no wish to be a "noble loser," and dismisses the assertion of his old friend Susan Estrich, who managed Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign, that he is indulging in a midlife crisis.
"Susan is projecting," he said. "The midlife crisis is hers. She's suffering with being a former liberal; I don't have that problem. These critics are really talking about themselves; I'm just their ink blot. They would really like me to stop irritating their conscience. I really think I'm doing what I should at this point in my life and they're not."

HEADLINE: Haiti's Democratic Troubles

 BODY:
Two and a half years after American troops intervened to end a murderous dictatorship in Haiti, that country faces daunting troubles. Its ministries are inept, its Parliament paralyzed and its police quick on the trigger. Yet these problems represent progress of a sort. Haiti has gone from a government dedicated to brutality and corruption to one of inexperience and incompetence. That is a sign that the United States and the international community can best help by staying involved.
President Rene Preval is not a seasoned leader, but he has tried to be a responsible one. He has pushed through a fractious Parliament a desperately needed program to sell inefficient public enterprises and modernize Haiti's economy. The reforms would not only qualify Haiti for international funds that have been held back, but would also begin to lift the economy and help Haiti's poor. 
 The reforms have been blocked largely by Mr. Preval's political mentor, the only man in Haiti with a real political base, former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. While Mr. Aristide in the past has spoken for Haiti's people, his role now is negative. His supporters have brought parliamentary action to a standstill. Ironically, he is joined in his opposition to economic reform by some members of Haiti's elite, who have grown rich from the monopolies they hold in the protected economy.
But Mr. Aristide's opposition also shows that Haiti is in no danger of becoming a one-party dictatorship. A political split over economic policy is an appropriate disagreement in a democracy.
The abuses by the new Haitian National Police are extremely serious. In the 21 months since the United States established the force, police have killed about 50 Haitians. The police must be held accountable for these crimes.
The Government is beginning to do that. The police's Inspector General is investigating the killings. Most of those accused have been fired and some are in jail. This is one reason that the murders do not justify a cutoff of American aid and training. The violence has not been the result of a deliberate policy, as were the thousand murders each year committed by the most recent dictatorship.
The police need more training, resources and leadership. A related problem is Haiti's virtually nonexistent justice system. The Clinton Administration considers the building of a justice system a top priority. But reform efforts have been hurt by an overly centralized program that slights the realities of Haiti's largely rural courts.
For a few more months, Haiti could use the security and scrutiny provided by the 1,300 international troops remaining in the country. Some are due to leave in July, but Canada, which has 750 troops there, has said it will try to stay until the end of the year. The other troops should stay too.
If Haiti is to be able to feed itself and break the habits that come from centuries of occupation, dictatorship and mismanagement, it will likely need economic and technical help for years. It deserves such help. Haiti still faces serious problems. But thanks to the United States and other countries, it is now a democracy with a Government committed to solving them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Cosmetics Heir's Joint Venture Is Tainted by Ukrainian's Past

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ and RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Ronald S. Lauder and Vadim Rabinovich could scarcely be more different. An urbane former United States Ambassador to Austria, Mr. Lauder is heir to a cosmetics fortune, chairman of the board of Museum of Modern Art and a former candidate for Mayor of New York. Mr. Rabinovich, a self-made Ukrainian millionaire, spent nine years in a Soviet prison for theft and has been linked to a suspected Russian criminal figure.
But the two men are joined as partners in a television venture in Ukraine that has raised eyebrows among Western diplomats and businessmen here and in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, both because of Mr. Rabinovich's background and because of the apparently favored treatment the venture received from the Ukrainian Government. 
 The business alliance between Mr. Rabinovich and Mr. Lauder, recounted by principals in the deal and diplomats here and in Ukraine, is not unusual in the free-wheeling capitalism that has taken root in Central Europe and the former Soviet Union. Western companies hoping to wedge their way into previously closed markets often find they must turn to local partners whose ties to the government are essential but whose backgrounds stir ripples.
That can raise problems for publicly traded companies like Mr. Lauder's fledgling Central European Media Enterprises. Such companies have a legal obligation to disclose significant problems with their partners, particularly if they are to have a management role.
Mr. Lauder, the chairman and founder of Central European Media, declined to be interviewed for this article. But Leonard S. Fertig, its chief executive, said the company learned of the allegations about Mr. Rabinovich only after the deal was completed last fall. He said company representatives then discussed the matter with people at the United States Embassy in Kiev and were told there was no reason not to do business with Mr. Rabinovich.
"They concluded, in terms of what they told us, that there was nothing that should prevent us from doing business with him," Mr. Fertig said.
American Government officials acknowledged that embassy officials had told Mr. Lauder and other company officials about Mr. Rabinovich's conviction and his links to Grigory Loutchansky, a Russian whose company, Nordex, is suspected of having ties to criminal organizations. But the officials said the embassy had offered no opinion about whether to do business with him.
Mr. Rabinovich was jailed from 1982 to 1990 for theft from the state. He said in an interview that he had been chief of a construction brigade and had sold goods to private customers. He said he had committed no real crime and had been persecuted for being Jewish. He also said he had cut his ties to Mr. Loutchansky.
Mr. Fertig said the company had made inquiries about its partners in Ukraine before finalizing the deal and uncovered no problems. He said the inquiries had not focused on Mr. Rabinovich because he was not part of management or involved in the operation of the television station itself.
But current and former officials at the United States Embassy in Kiev said that the embassy was not approached by the company about Mr. Rabinovich before the deal was completed in October. A senior European diplomat said his country had cautioned its companies to avoid doing business with Mr. Rabinovich.
Mr. Lauder's partnership is between his Central European Media, which operates television stations in seven countries in the region, and Studio 1+1 Group, its local partner in Kiev.
Central European Media sought to expand into Ukraine a year ago. At the outset, Mr. Fertig said, its representatives were referred to Mr. Rabinovich and his partners by a close adviser and assistant to President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine, who praised the Ukraine group. And when questions arose about the legality of the broadcast license received by the joint venture, the same presidential adviser obtained a letter declaring that the license had been awarded properly.
Mr. Fertig said Mr. Rabinovich was an investor in Studio 1+1 Group and had no role in its management. He said that Mr. Rabinovich's stake in Studio 1+1 was indirect, and that he was not certain how much of the business was owned by Mr. Rabinovich.
A year ago, John M. Deutch, then the Director of Central Intelligence, told a Congressional hearing that Nordex, the Vienna-based trading company founded in 1989 by Mr. Loutchansky, was "an organization associated with Russian criminal activity."
In addition, concerns about his business activities led the British Government to bar Mr. Loutchansky from entering the country, an action he is fighting in court.
Thomas R. Spencer Jr., a lawyer for Mr. Loutchansky, said his client had been subjected to unwarranted and unsubstantiated allegations. He said Mr. Loutchansky and his company had never been involved in criminal activities.
"These allegations have been circulating now for two years, and he has never been charged with anything," Mr. Spencer said. "No one has ever presented proof of the basis for these allegations."
An intelligence summary prepared by a Western Government, and corroborated by senior American diplomats, said Ostex, one of Mr. Rabinovich's companies, had been created as an arm of Nordex, a claim that Mr. Rabinovich disputed.
In the interview in his office in a modern building in Kiev, Mr. Rabinovich said he had worked with Nordex for about a year but had broken off the relationship two years ago because of bad publicity about Mr. Loutchansky. He said his companies, which are engaged in many businesses, had only legitimate interests.
Mr. Lauder, whose mother founded the Estee Lauder Companies, created Central European Media in 1994. He predicted last year that the company would have annual revenues of $1 billion within five years, but it has run up steady losses to date. The company reported last month that it lost $30 million in 1996 compared with losses of $18.7 million in 1995 and $20.5 million in 1994.
When the company sought to enter the Ukraine market a year ago, Mr. Fertig said, its executives were referred to Mr. Rabinovich and his partners in Studio 1+1 by Oleksandra Volkov, an assistant and close adviser to President Kuchma. Western diplomats and businessmen said Mr. Volkov also owned a piece of Studio 1+1, but Mr. Fertig said he was unaware of that investment.
Along with the recommendation from the presidential adviser, the company executives also were impressed by a photograph in Mr. Rabinovich's office that showed him with President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, according to a person close to the company.
The photograph was taken in late 1995 at a Democratic fund-raising party in Miami, Mr. Rabinovich said. He said he had not donated money to the Democrats, but had been invited to the event by Bennett S. LeBow, an American businessman whose interests include the Liggett Group, the big cigarette manufacturer. Mr. LeBow's Brooke Group and Mr. Rabinovich are developing a business center and luxury hotel in Kiev, according to a spokesman for Mr. LeBow.
Last summer, Central European Media negotiated a partnership agreement with Studio 1+1 Group that gave the American company a 50 percent economic interest in the operation, which was broadcasting about five hours a day on Ukrainian television.
Studio 1+1 received a license last fall to expand its broadcast time on Ukraine's commercial channel, UT 2, to nine hours a day, including prime time. The license, also sought by other companies, was issued despite a moratorium imposed by Parliament.
The head of the state agency that awarded the license, Viktor Petrenko, said in an interview that his agency had ignored the moratorium because it knew better than Parliament what was the best policy.
"I'm very happy that we did," Mr. Petrenko said.
Western diplomats said American and Ukrainian lawyers had questioned the legitimacy of the Studio 1+1 license because of the moratorium. Faced with those concerns, Studio 1+1 turned for help to Mr. Volkov, the assistant to President Kuchma. Mr. Volkov obtained a letter from the Ukrainian Ministry of Justice in January that the license was issued legally.
The Ukraine deal is important to Central European Media. In a stock offering last fall, which raised $132 million, the company said the Ukraine partnership had more than doubled its market reach.
A cablegram from the embassy to the State Department in Washington in September raised questions about Mr. Rabinovich's background and said he was "largely considered beyond the reach of the law in Ukraine," according to a copy provided to The New York Times.
Yet Mr. Fertig said his company had heard praise for Mr. Rabinovich as a businessman who is well regarded in Ukraine.
"We know him in the present," Mr. Fertig said. "In the present, the guy claims that half of his income is given to charity. He is extremely active in civic affairs. He is well thought of by people in the Government. We didn't know and really don't know who he was in the past."
