HEADLINE: Protection for Farm Labor

 BODY:
Few laborers have as little clout with their bosses as farm workers. The work is unskilled and the labor pool huge and mobile. Many farm workers are illegal immigrants and therefore reluctant to report employers who do not pay the minimum wage or Social Security or fail to provide water and toilets in the field. Farm wages have been dropping for 20 years.
Because of the political power of big growers, the Federal Government has never been particularly helpful to farm workers. But now Washington is taking two actions that will give farm workers some much-needed protection. The Labor Department's wage and hour division last month announced new rules for growers who employ labor contractors to hire crews. The new rules will make it easier for farm workers to hold growers responsible when the labor contractors cheat them. 
 In addition, enforcement will be strengthened. The wage and hour division now has only three farm labor inspectors in Florida, for example, and they also enforce dozens of other laws. The lack of scrutiny gives employers license to pay workers $2 or $3 an hour and cheat them of Social Security and overtime. The division will add 200 workers in the seven states with the highest immigration: New York, New Jersey, Illinois, Texas, Florida, California and Arizona. They will focus on farm labor, garment manufacturing and janitorial services, which employ large numbers of immigrants.
Congress authorized the added staff to reduce employers' incentives to hire illegal immigrants. The staff will still be too small for adequate inspections, but together with the new contracting rules, the increased presence will help discourage growers from cheating their most vulnerable workers.

HEADLINE: Lawyers in Oklahoma Bombing Hope Rapport With Jurors Pays Off Later

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS 

DATELINE: DENVER, April 4

 BODY:
During this week's questioning of prospective jurors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial, one of the prosecutors, United States Attorney Patrick M. Ryan, asked Juror No. 294 whether his dog, a Labrador retriever, was golden or black. His own dog, Mr. Ryan volunteered, was a golden retriever.
At another point, Stephen Jones, who is leading the defense team, tried to sympathize with Juror No. 639, who said a close friend had died, by noting, "I had a similar experience myself." Then the juror explained that his friend had been killed in a robbery. Mr. Jones's friend had died in an automobile accident. 
 Coming from lawyers who also ask each juror whether he or she could sentence someone to death, the lighthearted questions and comments were anything but frivolous, jury experts say. The exchanges, however brief, give prosecutors and defense lawyers alike a chance to sow the seeds of cordial relationships with the men and women, now identified only by number, who may be chosen to deliver a verdict in the nation's worst terrorist crime.
"They're trying to establish a connection, a bond, in hopes that it might pay dividends at some point in a trial," said Robert E. Precht, the lawyer who defended Mohammed A. Salameh in the World Trade Center bombing and now is director of the Office of Public Service at the University of Michigan Law School.
"Things can go wrong in a trial," Mr. Precht said. "A jury's willingness to forgive a prosecutor or a defense lawyer for a mistake can be a real benefit."
As the trial against Timothy J. McVeigh opened here this week and lawyers for Mr. McVeigh's co-defendant, Terry L. Nichols, who will be tried afterward, listened in the second row, Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court questioned each juror for about 20 minutes. Then, in a procedure that is rare in Federal court, Judge Matsch allowed both prosecutors and defense lawyers to ask their own questions in sessions that sometimes lasted more than an hour.
Many of those questions were part of the lawyers' strategy to connect to the jurors. At one point, Mr. Ryan, who is the chief prosecutor in Oklahoma City, asked Juror No. 134, an avid sports fan, "Did you follow the N.C.A.A.?" adding, "Did your team win?"
The lawyer did not miss a beat when the young man replied, "My team never wins."
Robert Nigh Jr., a defense lawyer, told Juror No. 609, a retiree who likes to paint, "I do a little bit of painting myself." He added, "It's a subject that fascinates me."
All potential jurors had already filled out 40-page questionnaires with more than 150 questions on topics as diverse as their lives and job history, what books they read and what radio stations they listen to, and how easy it is for them to make decisions.
There have been awkward moments when the lawyers, most of whom are from out of state, failed to recognize the common names of employers like the bus company or the power company in Denver, and the jurors had to explain.
As each potential juror appeared in court, Judge Matsch explained, in a slow and friendly way, that the death penalty may be an issue in the case. If there is a conviction in a capital case in Federal court, he told each, the jury not only votes on guilt or innocence, but also on the penalty.
Patiently, repeating himself when necessary, Judge Matsch asked whether they had any religious, personal or moral opinion for or against the death penalty. If not, he asked them whether they thought, as a general matter, that they could consider death as a possible penalty, along with life in prison without possibility of parole or some lesser penalty.
"I don't believe in the death penalty at all, " Juror No. 523, a Denver librarian, said on Thursday morning.
Others waffled. One was Juror No. 762, a nurse who has worked in hospitals for 40 years. She told Judge Matsch on Thursday that she could impose the death penalty, but minutes later told Mr. Ryan that "only God can take a life."
Judge Matsch interjected mildly, "I'm not arguing, but I mentioned that the jury must consider the death penalty and whether that is a deserved punishment."
Mr. Ryan then asked the prospective juror, "Could you come into court and say, 'I sentence that person to die?' "
The nurse replied, "If it comes down to it, yes, depending on the facts."
Mr. Ryan then asked, "When Judgment Day comes, will it be held against you?"
She answered, "I don't know," and added that she would be willing to take the chance.
Joe Guastaferro, a jury consultant from Chicago, said in an interview this week that the possibility of death put "incredible pressure on the whole system, right from the first question in jury selection."
In the Oklahoma City case, Mr. Guastaferro said, "the prosecution has what appears to be an unlosable case and could blow it by not finding out who the person is who might have morals about the death penalty. The defense doesn't want to miss an opportunity to save a young man's life. It's like a pressure cooker. Anywhere there's a loose seam, it will blow apart."
The judge, the prosecutors and the defense lawyers all unearthed problems this week, although only the juror who broke into tears and suffers from a nervous condition was immediately excused. Any others who might be excused for cause -- like Juror No. 306, an unemployed pipe fitter who told Judge Matsch that he did not like the court system and that "in my estimation, you haven't been doing a very good job" -- come up for discussion in the judge's chambers each morning before the public session begins. So far, no information from these meetings has been released.
Potential jurors have been asked for their opinions on gun legislation and whether they had ever attended a gun show. Those with other experiences in the criminal justice system have been examined for evidence of bitterness or a desire for revenge. The stagehand who had once declared bankruptcy, the carpenter who had once been convicted of stealing a car battery, the self-employed window washer who had owed the Internal Revenue Service a large sum, through no fault of his own, all came in for more questions.
"Prosecutors, especially in a death penalty case, want strong law-and-order types," said Jeffrey Abramson, a professor of politics and legal studies at Brandeis University. "But here they don't want people who are too conservative, because it may bring anti-Government thinking. They have two balls in the air."
Mr. Ryan asked Juror No. 838, an investment counselor and former mining engineer who said the Government "indulged in overkill" at standoffs against zealots at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, and near Waco, Tex., whether he would give fair consideration to evidence presented by the Government in this case.
The juror replied, "I'm inclined to be pretty logical and not terribly swayed by emotion."
"We do not want your sympathy," Mr. Ryan replied. "We want you to decide on the evidence. You understand that the Government is not on trial? This case is about whether the defendant committed the crime and which sentence should be imposed, should he be convicted."
Prosecutors also asked jurors whether they could consider only the evidence against Mr. McVeigh and accept the possibility that there would be unanswered questions.
"In the way the Government is going to try this case," said Mr. Precht, the lawyer in the World Trade Center trial, "a lot of it is going to be mind-numbingly boring. The jurors are going to have to listen to hours and hours of highly detailed forensic testimony. Generally, the prosecution is going to be looking for highly intelligent jurors who are not going to be distracted by sideshows. The defense will want jurors who won't be impressed by the Government's blizzard of evidence if they find a conspiracy theory fetching."
Mr. Precht noted that just before the trial opened, Mr. Jones accused the Government of failing to pursue possible conspiracy theories, including the identity of a suspect whose sketch was circulated around the nation. The Government now says this suspect, known as John Doe No. 2, may not exist.
"Jones is looking for someone who says, 'I understand this, but how about John Doe No. 2?' " Mr. Precht said. "The defense would hope for a deadlocked jury, a single holdout. The prosecution must find 12 people who will agree."

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Solid Jobs Market, Pointing to a Stronger Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The unemployment rate edged down to 5.2 percent last month -- matching its lowest level in eight years -- as the reinvigorated economy continued to produce a bountiful labor market for legions of Americans.
While the Government reported today that employers added a slightly less-than-expected 175,000 workers to their payrolls in March, every other economic indicator pointed to strong growth that may well prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again soon. 
 Hourly earnings climbed to a point 4 percent above those of March 1996, the briskest annual increase of the long-running business expansion that reached its sixth anniversary last month. Meanwhile, overtime at the nation's factories was a record 4.9 hours a worker, making it more likely that industry would need to bid up wages further to attract additional skilled workers.
But what was good news for workers sent the bond market into a tizzy, pushing long-term interest rates higher on fears that the Federal Reserve, which only last week decided to raise interest rates for the first time in 14 months, could do so again as early as its next meeting in May. The shaky stock market, divided between worries over higher interest rates and hopes for healthy corporate earnings that are both outcomes of a stronger economy, gyrated wildly. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 6,526.07, up 48.72 points, but only after an initial slide of 72 points at the opening bell. [Page 36.]
The Fed's move last week is now widely seen as likely to become just the first of a series of interest rate increases. Indeed, even Merrill Lynch, which had expected the economy to slow enough on its own to stay the Fed's hand, joined the other camp after the Labor Department issued its monthly jobs report today.
"We are throwing in the towel and now assume that the Fed will probably tighten twice more," Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, advised clients. This, he added, means that the economy should be "slowing sharply" by year's end.
But while many on Wall Street fretted, the Clinton Administration expressed confidence that price increases would be held in check and the economy would continue to expand at a healthy rate.
"The economy is continuing on a path of steady, sustainable expansion with strong job creation and low inflation," Janet L. Yellen, chief economic adviser to President Clinton and a former member of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a statement. She added in an interview, "I don't see any evidence of an acceleration."
Ms. Yellen pointed to the moderate rise in workers on employer payrolls as suggesting that inflation prospects were more benign than many analysts contend.
Not only did payrolls grow by a moderate 175,000, but the February increase was also revised to 293,000, or 46,000 less than initially reported.
Others drew modest comfort from the fact that a slightly smaller proportion of companies added to their payrolls last month than in February, a slight decline in the length of the private-sector workweek despite the rise in overtime.
"I really don't see cost-push inflation in these data," said Lincoln F. Anderson, economist for the Fidelity mutual fund group in Boston. "Companies are not reporting to us that there's a significant earnings squeeze from rising labor costs."
And Ms. Yellen, while acknowledging it to be a crude gauge, said that 4 percent wage growth and 3 percent consumer inflation over the last year should be regarded as in line with productivity improvement, which means that companies should be able to sustain decent profits without having to raise prices.
But many analysts are convinced that higher inflation is on the way. "Inflation is going to creep up," Todd Speiser, a trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, told Bloomberg News, predicting that the Fed was "going to put the brakes on some more in May."
Indeed, much of the report suggested a further tightening of the labor market, including the highest amount of factory overtime, 4.9 hours a week, since this was first measured in 1956 and a record percentage, 63.8, of the nation's civilian population with jobs.
Demand for workers, in fact, is strong enough that many more of the hard-core unemployed have begun finding jobs. The ranks of those out of work more than six months declined 75,000 last month after a 74,000 February drop. This group now accounts for 15 percent of the jobless, down from 16.9 percent in January.
Moreover, the payroll gain, the department said, would have been larger had it not been for a 27,000-job decline in construction that was largely the result of statistical quirks caused by unusual weather shifts this winter. Flooding in the Midwest may have also reduced the total, some analysts said.
Factory jobs climbed 16,000 last month, bringing the increase since September to 74,000, a modest rise but in sharp contrast to a loss of 319,000 from a March 1995 peak.
Almost two-thirds of the payroll expansion was in services, with retailing up 43,000, hospital services up 22,000 and finance adding 17,000, the report also showed.
The department's survey of households, a more erratic measure but the basis for computing the unemployment rate, showed an exceptionally large job gain of 745,000 that was more than enough to absorb an increase of 685,000 in the labor force. An undetermined amount of this increase was said to have reflected the entry of people formerly on welfare.
While there was an unusually big discrepancy between the surveys of employers and of households last month, the two show a close relationship compared with 12 months ago, analysts noted.
At 5.2 percent, the March jobless rate was at the same level as the rate that prevailed from August through October 1996. Before that, unemployment has not been so low since the 5 percent rate of March 1989. The unemployment rate in February was 5.3 percent.
Regionally, joblessness ticked one-tenth of a point lower in the Northeast and South and dipped three-tenths of a point in the Midwest, to 4 percent, the best of any area. The jobless rate climbed three-tenths of a point in the West, to 6 percent.
Some analysts pay particular attention in the labor market report to the index of aggregate weekly hours, which edged slightly lower after a big jump in February.
But this and the other less-than-buoyant figures today did little to diminish expectations that another Fed tightening of monetary policy was already in sight.
"It's almost certain they're going to move again in May," said Dominic Konstam, director of economic research at Credit Suisse First Boston.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Drop Sharply As Labor Data Show Strength

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply after the March employment report showed brisk economic growth and rising labor costs. The data suggested that the Federal Reserve would again have to raise interest rates to contain inflation.
While the gain in the number of new jobs was less than expected, traders and analysts said they were concerned by other data in the report showing sharp rises in hourly earnings and in overtime. The labor cost data are expected to increase the pressure on the Fed, which raised short-term interest rates by a quarter-point last week, to push rates even higher. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended the day down 20/32 , to 9330/32 . The bond's yield, a benchmark for many consumer and corporate interest rates, rose to 7.12 percent, from 7.07 percent on Thursday. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, is the highest since it was 7.15 percent on Sept. 15.
Treasury prices fell after the Labor Department reported that 175,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month. The unemployment rate fell to 5.2 percent from 5.3 percent.
Prices fell even though the payroll number was less than market expectations of more than 200,000.
"The one number in the employment report that the market should have gotten the most comfort out of, the jobs gain, was the one number that was most suspect" because of seasonal and weather-related factors, Steven Landis of Bull and Bear Advisers Inc., said.
"Trying to find a reason to buy in this bearish market is like trying to swim upstream," Mr. Landis added.
Market participants were concerned about data in the report showing a higher-than-expected gain of 5 cents, or four-tenths of 1 percent, in average hourly earnings.
"The average hourly earnings monthly gain of four-tenths of 1 percent does appear to suggest that the impact of previous demand side pressures is finally beginning to impact the overall economy in a wider fashion," said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Mr. Chan noted that the gain in earnings was in both the goods-producing and service sectors.
"Other discomforting aspects of this report were the jump in manufacturing weekly hours and the corresponding surge in the number of manufacturing overtime hours," Mr. Chan said. "These developments tell us that while most of the consumer price inflation that we have been observing to date has been mostly concentrated in the service sector, that may not be the case for long as it begins to spill over into the goods-producing sector as a result of these growing labor cost pressures."

HEADLINE: Japan Pledges To Monitor Its Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 4

 BODY:
Responding to American concerns, Japanese leaders said today that they would try to hold their resurgent trade surplus in check.
The remarks were welcomed by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who was making a one-day visit to Tokyo, in part to urge Japanese officials to take preventive economic measures. 
 Japan's once-gaping trade surplus, after falling sharply over the last three years, has been creeping steadily back up in recent months.
In 1996, for example, the surplus in the broadest measure, the current account, fell 31 percent from the previous year to $58.85 billion, the lowest level since 1990. But in January of this year there was a fivefold rise over the January 1996 surplus to $1.24 billion. And in February, Japan's trade surplus continued rising. Further increases in the surplus could lead to renewed trade frictions between the United States and Japan.
"Avoiding a significant increase in the current account surplus and increasing market access are of enormous importance to the nations of the global economy," Mr. Rubin told reporters today in Tokyo. "The nations of the global economy will be watching with great interest to see how Japan meets these challenges."
Mr. Rubin met Japanese leaders today during a brief stop on his way to the Philippines for a weekend meeting of finance ministers from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
The current account surplus is the excess generated when a country sells more goods and services abroad than it buys. In Japan, it has fallen to 1.4 percent of gross domestic product, from 3.1 percent in 1993.
Japan has been struggling for the last few years to pull its economy out of recession. But American officials have said that Japan's economic recovery should be driven by expansion of the domestic economy, not by increasing exports to the United States and the rest of the world.
A Japanese official said today that Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka had "reaffirmed the objective of providing strong domestic demand-led growth in Japan and avoiding a significant increase in the current account surplus."
Neither Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto nor Mr. Mitsuzuka commented today on specific measures to stimulate the domestic economy.
Prime Minister Hashimoto reassured Mr. Rubin today that Japan's current account surplus would not expand dramatically, Japanese officials said. However, American officials have questioned exactly how Japan will stimulate domestic demand.
The Japanese Government has cut public spending and eliminated income tax cuts. This year, it embarked on an ambitious fiscal austerity plan to reduce its swelling budget deficit, and on April 1 the Government also raised a sales tax to 5 percent from 3 percent.
Still, Prime Minister Hashimoto maintained today that the Government's broad-based deregulation plans would "contribute to the stabilization of the financial system and the sustainable growth of the Japanese economy," according to the Kyodo News Service.
But Mr. Rubin said that he had advised Japanese leaders to consider additional measures if their current macro-economic policy did not prevent a ballooning surplus as the economy grew.
A weakening yen, which has fallen about 50 percent since the spring of 1995, has led to a boom in the exports of cars, electronics and other Japanese products, but Mr. Rubin said he had not discussed currency issues with Japanese leaders.
"I don't believe a nation's currency should be used as an instrument of trade policy," Mr. Rubin said.
Currency traders said Mr. Rubin's comments helped the dollar rise against the yen today because the remarks were less confrontational than they might have been.
The dollar also received a lift from today's employment data in the United States, which traders took to signal that inflation, which undermines the currency, remained under control.
In New York, the dollar hit a six-week high against the yen and rose sharply in most other currency dealings, settling at 124.31 yen, up from 122.65 yen Thursday. The dollar rose to 1.6854 marks, from 1.6685, while the pound fell to $1.6355, from $1.6464.

HEADLINE: Foreign Role in '96 Saudi Bombing Unproven, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John Shalikashvili, said today that the Pentagon did not have sufficient evidence about the bombers who killed 19 American airmen in Saudi Arabia last year to consider retaliation against foreign countries that may have played a role.
"We have a very clear history that we do not let terrorist acts go unanswered," the general said in an interview. "But what we do about it has to be left open until we know really what has happened. And we do not have that information yet." 
 Pentagon officials have suggested in the past that Iran and Syria might have provided support to those who carried out the bombing last June of an apartment complex in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, that housed American pilots and others from the Air Force.
The speculation about a link to Iran grew stronger this month after the Canadian Government arrested an Iranian-educated Saudi man and accused him of driving one of the two cars that accompanied a truck packed with explosives to the site of the bombing.
General Shalikashvili declined comment on the arrest in Canada "because there are negotiations going on," he said without elaboration. But he suggested that the investigation of the attack was far from over, although there was no conclusive evidence so far to show that any particular foreign government had provided assistance to the bombers.
"I will tell you that we're not there yet," he said. "Clearly there are nations out there that support terrorism directly or indirectly, but they have become much smarter about hiding their fingerprints."
"Sure, I'm frustrated," he said about delays in the investigation of the bombing attack at the Khobar Towers apartment complex. But he said delays were understandable, given the increased sophistication and stealth of Middle Eastern terrorists who make Americans a target.
"They are no longer the unsophisticated local dissidents that throw Molotov cocktails," he said. "They are very sophisticated in the whole structure they've set up -- how they train each other, how they call on each other for support, how they move. About the only thing we know is that we must go on the assumption that we will continue to be the victims of terrorism, and that terrorists will hit us again."
Another senior Pentagon official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said that the investigation of the Dhahran bombing was likely to continue for at least several months and that it might never provide concrete evidence of the involvement of a foreign government.
He drew a comparison between this attack and the bombing of a Berlin discotheque in 1986 in which two off-duty American soldiers were killed, and for which terrorists working with Libya were eventually blamed. Two weeks later, the United States bombed Libya in retaliation.
"We retaliated only after we had concrete intelligence information showing the Libyans were involved with the disco bombing," the Pentagon official said. "There's nothing like that here. They're hiding their tracks better than they used to."
General Shalikashvili said military retaliation was only one of several options for the Clinton Administration if investigators found a clear link between the bombing and a foreign government.
"If the issue is what America's choices will be when this investigation is finished -- and if the investigation were to show some foreign involvement -- then I would say that America will have to make the decision what to do about it," he said. "There are obviously diplomatic tools, economic tools, and there are also military tools.
"I do not want to imply what kind of an act we will take. Those decisions have not been made yet."
Asked about the level of cooperation offered to American investigators by the Saudi Government, General Shalikashvili said he was not in a position to comment because the issue had not come up during his conversations with Saudi military officials.
The F.B.I. is overseeing the American investigation of the bombing. In the past, officials at the bureau and the Justice Department have complained that the American investigation was being hindered by a lack of cooperation from the Saudis.
Despite initial enthusiasm that the arrest in Canada last month might signal a breakthrough in the investigation of the bombing, senior Administration officials have since said it is not clear that there is enough evidence against the 28-year-old Saudi, Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, to seek his extradition to the United States.

HEADLINE: Physician, Unionize Thyself;
Doctors Adapt to Life as H.M.O. Employees

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz.

 BODY:
Sixteen years ago, a group of physicians here set up their own health maintenance organization. Two and a half years ago, they sold their practice and the H.M.O. to a California company, getting $3.2 million each. Then, in December, they joined a union to fight the very managed-care company they helped create.
That last decision was unusual, to say the least. The doctors were all specialists at the Thomas-Davis Medical Centers, Tucson's oldest and most prestigious clinic. They belonged to a profession that has always looked down its nose at collective bargaining. And, of course, they were millionaires. 
 Yet here they were, voting by an overwhelming 93-to-32 margin to join the Federation of Physicians and Dentists, an affiliate of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. It was the first time doctors employed by a for-profit managed-care company had unionized anywhere in the United States, according to the federation.
Their motive, it turns out, had little to do with money and almost everything to do with power. "We wanted to be the Mayo Clinic of the West," said Keith Shelman, a specialist in internal medicine and the union coordinator among Thomas-Davis doctors, referring to the famous hospital in Minnesota. But after the Tucson clinic's owner tried to ram through cost-cutting measures and new rules, he said, "there was no choice" but to unionize.
"It wasn't a dollar issue," he said. "It was the issue of not being allowed to be a good doctor."
As managed care has swept the country, with the number of people in H.M.O.'s doubling in eight years to 64 million, everybody involved is trying to cope with the furious pace of change. Consumer advocates complain that profit-driven managed-care providers often deny care to the chronically ill. Congress is debating whether to set Federal health care standards for the companies.
And everywhere, doctors are growing frustrated at their loss of decision-making powers, from gag rules that restrict what doctors can tell patients about treatment options to the practice of releasing patients hours after minor surgery instead of keeping them in the hospital overnight.
To escape such constraints, and to fight shrinking reimbursement rates, some doctors are turning to specialties like cosmetic surgery that are often not a part of managed care. Others, wagering that they can solve the problem by reporting to themselves, are setting up their own H.M.O.'s. And now, a growing number are thinking the once unthinkable: joining together in unions to improve their bargaining power with their new efficiency-obsessed bosses.
"Interest has increased exponentially in the last six months," Barry Liebowitz, director of the Doctors Council in New York, a union of physicians who work in public hospitals, said. "Doctors are having gag orders and drive-through mastectomies imposed on them. They are finding themselves in an economic morass, where professional control translates into economic control."
At Thomas-Davis, the disaffection boiled up suddenly. In 1981, the doctors who owned the clinic set up an H.M.O., Intergroup Health Care. By the mid-1990's, Intergroup Health had become the state's largest H.M.O., with 379,000 members, and the doctors had sold a 40 percent stake to the public. In November 1994, a California company, the Foundation Health Corporation, bought both the clinic and the H.M.O. for $688 million. The 133 physician-shareholders each got Foundation Health stock worth $3.2 million.
The working atmosphere remained relatively benign under the new owners. Then last July, Foundation Health decided to hang onto the H.M.O. but sell Thomas-Davis and another physician group in Sacramento, Calif., to FPA Medical Management Inc. of San Diego for $195 million, a deal that was to be completed by December.
While physicians say Thomas-Davis and its H.M.O. were self-supporting, Foundation Health contended that the clinic did not stand on its own and ran in the red. So, in August, Foundation outlined a plan to chop clinic overhead by $2 million a month. With FPA's endorsement, the plan involved cutting 26 doctors, including specialists such as dermatologists; increasing patient loads, and eliminating records clerks, which forced doctors to type their own charts. It also imposed new bureaucratic restrictions, even denying the obstetrics department chief the freedom to order the type of rubber gloves she wanted.
The physicians rose in revolt. Not only did Foundation Health's plan erode their independence, it bruised their pride. Here they were, they fumed, the elite of Tucson's medical society, and they were being treated like orderlies.
The move to unionize was incited by the iconoclastic figure of Robert C. Osborne, an anesthesiologist in the Tucson area. Dr. Osborne had once made $350,000 a year in his private practice, but his income had shrunk by a third as medical insurers curbed fees, and then plummeted when a local association of anesthesiologists expelled him in a dispute. Last May, he filed for personal bankruptcy, owing $91,000 in Federal taxes.
Feeling he had nothing to lose, Dr. Osborne started a one-man drive last June to interest local doctors in unionizing. "I was kicked out of the marketplace and ruined financially," Dr. Osborne said. "Why not try to make changes? I couldn't be hurt any more than I was."
At first, he generated almost no interest. But when Foundation Health began riling up the Thomas-Davis doctors in August, he took up their cause. Today, he is still in private practice, but finds time to organize nurses and other health professionals, and to educate them about intimidation tactics that he says they are likely to encounter from employers.
The flash point in the clinic's organizing effort, according to Dr. Shelman, came when a senior Foundation Health executive reacted to his complaints by telling him, "If you don't like it, leave." The remark so angered his colleagues, he said, that most of the doctors signed up.
Like the others, Dr. N. Philip Strause 3d might seem an unlikely recruit to organized labor. Dr. Strause, 58, had left a private pediatric practice in Boston in 1990 to join the Tucson clinic with an eye toward teaching and eventual retirement.
"None of us wanted a union," he said. "The administration forced us into it. We wouldn't have to have it if they would treat us professionally. Physicians heard a lot of talk and promises that didn't materialize. The administration was secretive. Our ability to control care was eroded. Our salaries were cut." Dr. Strause was especially upset that the clinic's list of outside specialists lacked a board-certified behavioral pediatric psychiatrist. To get his supervisor's approval to use someone off the list, he said, he sometimes had to threaten that he would advise his patients to seek legal counsel.
Dr. Strause still owns most of the stock he received in the original sale to Foundation, which has gained about 10 percent since then. Paradoxically, he said, that economic cushion is one reason he and his fellow physicians joined a union. "We're the only ones that can afford it," he said.
Even so, around 500 more Thomas-Davis employees, including its nurses and support staff, voted to unionize in February.
The unionization of the Thomas-Davis doctors is being watched closely across the country, and especially in Seattle; Albuquerque, N.M., and Las Vegas, Nev., where similar movements are in their embryonic stages. Until they acted, organized labor had attracted doctors almost exclusively from the public sector. Most of the 3,000 members of the federation, which is based in Tallahassee, Fla., and most of the 5,000 members of the rival Union of American Physicians and Dentists, which is based in Oakland, Calif., are government or university employees. Podiatrists formed a national union last October, also out of frustration with the erosion of their power in managed-care organizations, though they are not medical doctors.
But as the proportion of the nation's 650,000 doctors who are employees rather than private practitioners has surged, to an estimated 42 percent today from 24 percent in 1983, more will turn to unions for the power to bargain collectively, union advocates predict.
So far, the doctors at Thomas-Davis have not won any concessions. Before negotiations on any issues can begin, an FPA Medical Management appeal with the National Labor Relations Board in Washington, D.C., will have to be adjudicated. The company is challenging the doctors' right to organize on the ground that they are supervisors.
"The physicians did not give us an opportunity to show them how we will change things and permit them to run quality, profitable operations," James A. Lebovitz, FPA's general counsel, said.
If the company loses the appeal, the physicians would have limited leverage because they have pledged not to strike, saying a walkout would violate their Hippocratic oath. Even so, Dr. Shelman said, they would have attained their main purpose: the power to bring the clinic's owners to the bargaining table.
Not everybody at Thomas-Davis is a union enthusiast. "The major problem is that the physicians have not made the adjustment from owners to employees," and must now defer to their superiors rather than call their own shots, said Neopito Robles, 65, a surgeon who has been with the clinic since 1968 and opposes the union.
Dr. Robles said the quality of medical care at Thomas-Davis remained undiminished, and he does not believe the union could make it any better. "A number of us are being insulted by this," he said.
Moreover, the American Medical Association remains lukewarm toward unions. Kirk Johnson, the A.M.A.'s general counsel, acknowledged that interest in unions was growing among managed-care doctors who wanted to increase their say in quality-of-care issues. But, he said: "We would defend them if they were challenged. You do not need a union to do that. Once you do, you run the risk that professional values are going to be perceived as not the goal."
Some patients think differently. "If doctors are united, it will give them more power without fear," John Bevan, 67, said outside an adobe-brown Thomas-Davis clinic in Tucson. He detects a deterioration in his care in recent years. In the past, he said, "you got too much attention" from doctors who required seemingly unnecessary return visits.
"Now, you get too little," Mr. Bevan said.
Joan Harphant, 48, a 10-year Thomas-Davis patient with auto-immune disease, said she believed a union would allow doctors to "take charge of their clinics." She said, "Managed care doesn't allow them to treat sick people."

Charts: "Diagnosis: Managed Care"
Dr. Mark Hendrickson, a doctor at Thomas-Davis Medical Centers in Tucson, Ariz., says his support for a doctors' union stems from policies imposed by the corporate owners that affect how he runs his practice. Here are some of his complaints:
 
PATIENT LOAD -- Dr. Hendrickson has been told to increase his patient load from 1,800 to 2,200.
 
SCHEDULING -- With more patients, he must schedule appointments futher and further in advance or send more patients to the clinic's urgent care center.
 
REFERRALS -- Complicated procedures for approving referrals have slowed the process, taking up more of Dr. Hendrickson's time. He is also dissatisfied with the overall quality of the doctors to whom he can refer patients.
 
PAPERWORK -- Paperwork has increased significantly, for everything from referrals to prescribing medication. Instead of dictating his notes, Dr. Hendrickson says he must write them out himself.
 
STAFF -- His medical assistant spends more time on paperwork and less time helping him with patients, leaving the doctor to give instructions on taking drugs and to help with the filing.
 
TIME WITH PATIENTS -- Though he sees the same number of patients each day, the doctor says that all the changes mean that he spends less time with each one.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-7
 
Clinton Holds Rally For Chemical Weapons Ban
President Clinton made a late push to win Senate ratification of the Chemical Weapons Convention. At a bipartisan rally, he shared the stage with James Baker, who negotiated the treaty as Secretary of State under President Bush, and other Republicans and military leaders. The pact, already ratified by 70 nations, will take effect on April 29, with or without the United States' participation. 1
 
Death Stalks Hutu Refugees
Hundreds of Hutu refugees from Rwanda have died from weakness and disease in makeshift camps in eastern Zaire, where about 80,000 of them are languishing. A United Nations plan to airlift them to Rwanda from the Kisangani airfield has been stymied by Zairian rebels, who have barred their way. The rebels, mostly ethnic Tutsi from Zaire, said they feared epidemics and the presence of armed Hutu militia leaders. 1
 
Few Clues on Saudi Bombing
The Pentagon lacks adequate evidence about the bombers who killed 19 American airmen in Saudi Arabia last year to warrant retaliation against foreign nations that may have helped them, said Gen. John Shalikashvili, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. A senior Pentagon official said the investigation into the bombing was likely to continue for months and might never yield proof of the involvement of a foreign government. 3
 
Turkey Lashes Out at Germany
Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey angrily described recent attacks on Turks in Germany as the result of an "anti-Muslim campaign" there. A Turkish woman and her two children were killed in an arson attack in Krefeld, which the Turkish Government listed as the 17th such attack in 1997. German officials rejected the accusation and charged the husband and father of the arson victims with setting the fire. More than two million Turks live in Germany. 3
 
Strikes Proliferate in France
Strikes and the threat of more have swept across France. Pilots, hospital interns and bank employees have stopped work, and truck drivers have threatened to repeat their strike of last November. Unemployment, at 12.8 percent, is higher than ever, and the popularity of President Jacques Chirac has plummeted, according to polls. The strikers object to cuts in wages and state-mandated benefits they have won over the years. 4
 
Inmates Seize Colombia Jail
Inmates angry about prison conditions in Valledupar in northern Colombia released 2 of at least 10 hostages seized in a violent takeover but demanded bulletproof vests and helicopters before they freed the rest. Four guards were killed when about 10 inmates seized control of the prison on Thursday. The two released were a female guard and a teen-age girl who had been delivering a birthday greeting. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 8-12
 
Space Shuttle Lifts Off For Study of Gravity
The space shuttle Columbia was launched on a 16-day mission to study the subtleties of what happens in the absence of gravity. The shuttle, with a crew of seven, lifted off about 20 minutes later than scheduled and was watched by large crowds. 10
 
An American astronaut and two Russian compatriots on the Mir space station began relying on a backup air-purification system after the main device to remove carbon dioxide overheated. 10
 
Changes Reshaping F.A.A.
Under a new policy that has been in effect for only a few weeks, the Federal Aviation Administration is announcing major violations by airlines and the fines levied in those cases. But the agency will still not say how serious some of the violations may be or compare the violations at one airline with those at another. 11
 
Pilots' Contract Advances
A tentative contract between American Airlines and its pilots' union won the endorsement of the group's leaders and will be sent to the union's 9,300 members for a ratification vote early next month. 11
 
Blood Tests Tell Expected Tale
Most of the 39 Heaven's Gate cult members who committed suicide at a California house had taken a lethal combination of drugs and alcohol before dying, the results of blood tests showed. 12
 
Gallo Wineries Win in Court
A Federal jury in San Francisco ruled that the E.& J. Gallo Winery had not tried to deceive consumers by using a bottle that one of California's most successful premium vintners said shared some characteristics of its bottles. 10
 
Cocaine Found Among Bananas
The Alabama State Police found more than 1,100 pounds of cocaine hidden in a truckload of bananas. The police released the driver of the tractor-trailer after concluding he did not know he was carrying the drugs. State troopers made the find while conducting safety inspections on Interstate 65. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION 23-27
 
Getting Concert Tickets Was Wrong, Rowland Says
Gov. John G. Rowland, the first baby boomer to hold Connecticut's highest office, today admitted to violating state ethics laws and blamed a culprit that has swayed so many in his generation: rock and roll. Mr. Rowland has agreed to pay a $2,000 fine for accepting discounted tickets to six concerts from a lobbyist and other third parties. He also said he would donate the value of the tickets -- $1,919 -- to charity. 26
 
Messinger Criticizes Sharpton
The peace that had enveloped the Democratic mayoral contest appears to have been shattered. Ruth W. Messinger condemned the Rev. Al Sharpton for saying he did not consider Louis Farrakhan an anti-Semite, saying such words would "only serve to tear us apart." 23
 
Insurance Overhaul Less Likely

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Jobless Rate Off to 5.2%, Raising Fears of Rate Rise
The unemployment rate edged down to 5.2 percent last month -- matching its lowest level in eight years -- as the buoyant economy produced a bountiful labor market for legions of Americans. 
 Although the Government reported that employers added only 175,000 workers to their payrolls in March, slightly less than expected, every other economic indicator pointed to strong growth that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise rates again soon. [Page 1.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply after the jobs report. The 30-year bond ended the day down 20/32 , to 9330/32 . The bond's yield, a benchmark for many consumer and corporate interest rates, rose to 7.12 percent. [37.]
 
Stocks Rise, Ending Losing Week
The stock market ended its worst week in two years with a fairly impressive gain, despite an employment report that pointed to higher interest rates ahead. After first falling on the employment data, stocks rallied in the afternoon, and the Dow industrials gained 48.72 points to close at 6,526.07. For the week, however, the Dow lost 215 points, or 3.2 percent. The Nasdaq composite also rose sharply -- 22.97 points, or 1.89 percent -- bolstered by a broad rally in technology stocks. Drug and biotechnology stocks also regained some of their earlier luster. [36.]
 
F.T.C. Bars Staples Merger Plan
The F.T.C. rejected the proposed $4 billion merger of two office supply discounters, Staples and Office Depot, in a 4-to-1 vote that set the stage for a possible court battle. The commission, acting over objections from some staff members, voted to seek a Federal court injunction against the merger, which would have created a chain with more than 1,000 stores and $10 billion in annual sales. [1.]
 
Pilot Leaders Back American Pact
Union leaders representing American Airlines' pilots endorsed a tentative contract with the carrier and will send it to their 9,300 members for a ratification vote. Investors took it as a sign that American was on course to put nearly three years of labor strife behind it, and shares of the parent AMR Corporation rose $3.875 to close at $86.375. [11.]
 
Gallo Wins Label Decision
Handing the E.& J. Gallo Winery a victory, a Federal jury in San Francisco ruled that Gallo's Turning Leaf brand did not deliberately duplicate the appearance of Kendall-Jackson's Vintners Reserve, a premium wine, in an attempt to deceive consumers. Kendall-Jackson sued Gallo, contending it had copied its label's multicolored vine leaves and the flared neck of its bottle. The jury said the similarities were common in the industry. [10.]
 
Ukrainian Venture Raises Eyebrows
A partnership between Ronald S. Lauder and Vadim Rabinovich for a television venture in Ukraine has raised eyebrows among Western diplomats and businessmen, both in Washington and in Kiev. Mr. Lauder is an urbane former United States ambassador to Austria and heir to a cosmetics fortune. Mr. Rabinovich, a self-made Ukrainian millionaire, spent nine years in a Soviet prison for theft and has been linked to a suspected Russian criminal figure. Their venture has apparently received favorable treatment from the Ukrainian Government. [4.]
 
France Mired in Labor Trouble
In France, economic troubles are bedeviling the Government of President Jacques Chirac. Unemployment is higher than ever, at 12.8 percent, and every day seems to bring a new French strike. This week alone, pilots of the money-losing state-owned domestic airline, Air Inter, grounded all flights to and from Paris for two days. [4.]
 
Confessions Sell, Publishers Find
In the publishing world, confessions sell. In an anxious and flat sales environment, publishers are buying the real life memoirs of brother-sister incest, drug addiction and cross-dressing seduction. Anorexia is a particularly high-fashion literary theme. [1.]

HEADLINE: F.T.C. Rejects Deal To Join Two Giants Of Office Supplies

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Federal Trade Commission, acting over objections from some staff members, rejected today the proposed $4 billion merger of two office supply discounters, Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc.
The commission voted 4 to 1 to seek a Federal court injunction against the merger, which would have created an office superstore chain with more than 1,000 stores and $10 billion in annual sales. 
William J. Baer, director of the F.T.C. antitrust division, said that the proposed deal was an undisguised and illegal attempt to eliminate competition between the two chains and would inevitably lead to higher prices for consumers.
Today's action reflects a growing aggressiveness in antitrust enforcement by the F.T.C., which was relatively passive during the Bush and Reagan Administrations. But several legal and market analysts said that in this case the commission was moving into uncharted legal territory and they predicted that it would have considerable difficulty swaying a judge to its view.
The unexpected action came after Staples and Office Depot had agreed to sell 63 stores to their only other competitor in the office supply superstore market, Officemax Inc. Commission officials had earlier indicated that such a sale of some stores would address the commission's concerns about the merger.
Thomas G. Stemberg, chairman of Staples, denounced the commission action as "bizarre" and contended that the agency had negotiated with the companies in bad faith. He said, however, that he had not yet decided whether to fight the issue in court.
"I'm flabbergasted that the commission did not vote today to approve this deal," Mr. Stemberg said in a telephone conference call with reporters. "I'm amazed the F.T.C. is allowed to operate in this Alice in Wonderland fashion."
In the last two years, the F.T.C. required several supermarket and department store chains that sought to merge to divest themselves of significant numbers of stores to maintain competition in their regions. Last year, it blocked the proposed merger of the Rite Aid and Revco drugstore chains because, agency officials contended, the combination would leave millions of consumers with no low-cost outlet for prescription drugs.
The commission did allow the merger of two pharmaceutical giants, Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, to proceed last year, but only after requiring that they divest themselves of $1 billion in assets to prevent the combined company from dominating several market segments.
Regarding the Staples case, James F. Rill, who served as the top Justice Department antitrust officer in the Bush Administration, said the F.T.C.'s argument rested on the theory that office supply superstores were a market in themselves, distinct from the much larger market for office goods sold through catalogues, discount chains and stationery stores.
"I find the market definition that's been developed here to be curious and narrow," Mr. Rill said. "If that's the basis of their case, they're in for a horse race."
But the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, who has opposed the deal, called the commission's action a "watershed" and said it was evidence that the Clinton Administration was serious about enforcing antitrust laws. "Today's action is more significant than just this case," he said in an interview. "The F.T.C. does not behave this way usually. Antitrust law has been pretty moribund and now it is stirring again."
Mr. Baer of the F.T.C. said that there appeared to be no way that the proposed combination could be altered to answer the commission's objections. "The vote today reflects a fundamental belief that this transaction as structured is flawed," he said at a news conference. "There isn't a settlement out there that will solve the underlying competitive problem."
Only one or two such merger disputes a year actually go to trial; most are settled or dropped before reaching a courtroom. Over the last 10 years, the F.T.C. has won about 60 percent of the cases it litigated, Mr. Baer said. "The reason is that these are the close calls," he said. "Only the tough ones go to court."
The commission was more closely divided than the 4-to-1 vote indicated. The dissenting commissioner, Roscoe B. Starek 3d, said that the agreement to sell the 63 stores to Officemax would solve the problem of decreased competition in those markets where only Staples and Office Depot now have outlets.
Another commissioner, Mary L. Azcuenaga, voted with the majority to reject the settlement, but she also expressed a belief that the merger as originally proposed was legal.
The staff, too, was sharply split, officials acknowledged, with a number of senior aides recommending that the deal be approved.
Today's setback for the proposed deal sent the shares of Office Depot tumbling $6 each, to $13, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Staples rose 62.5 cents, to $21.875, in Nasdaq trading. Office Max shares were off $1.125, to $11.875, on the Big Board.
James P. Stoeffel, who tracks emerging growth companies for Smith Barney, said of the vote, "Clearly, they're making this a test case based on some econometric models they've developed." He predicted that Staples would prevail in court if it chose to devote the time and money to a long legal battle.
"The F.T.C.," he said, "has fundamentally misunderstood what this business is about and who the competitors are and what Staples's strategy is. They have done a huge disservice to the very people they claim to be looking out for, the consumers."
Consumer advocates cheered the action, agreeing with the commission that elimination of one of the three players in the superstore segment would reduce competition.
Howard Metzenbaum, chairman of the Consumer Federation of America, said that it was "indisputable" that the merger would have cost consumers money and that the plan to sell stores to Officemax would not have substantially altered the effects of the deal. He predicted that the commission would win in court.
At the F.T.C., Mr. Baer cited pricing studies as the basis of the commission's conclusion that the level of superstore competition was the chief variable in the setting of prices for a variety of goods.

HEADLINE: Talking Shop

BYLINE: By Claudia Dreifus; Claudia Dreifus, a contributing writer to the Magazine, is the author of "Interview," to be published next month.

 BODY:
Once upon a retailing time -- 50, 100 years ago -- the great merchant princes came from enterprising Jewish-American families, and they were elegant showmen bringing new ideas to the more insulated corners of America. In today's global economy, store owners often come from abroad, and they remain entertainers. The modern-day shop is a happening. The contemporary merchant is at once a salesman, an impresario and a restaurateur.
 Here, three 1990's retailers -- Stanley Marcus, who was chairman of Neiman Marcus for 25 years and is still a consultant to retailers worldwide; Ingvar Kampard, the founder of Ikea, and Richard Branson, the balloon-traveling force behind the Virgin empire -- talk about how they sell by putting on a show. 
 Interestingly, two of these merchants -- Marcus and Kampard -- do a lot of their own shopping at Britain's Marks & Spencer, possibly the least entertaining store on the planet. Why? "They give good value," Kampard says quaintly.
 
Stanley Marcus, 92. President of Narrowcasting, chairman emeritus of Neiman Marcus.
 
Q: Your family has been in merchandising for more than a century. How would you characterize the state of retailing as we move toward the millennium?
A: It seems to me that the department store is in serious trouble. I'm talking about the rank-and-file stores, with Macy's and Bloomingdale's being something of an exception.
The department store was a product of the 19th century and became a very important institution as America went into the 20th century. It provided show places in developing towns like Terre Haute, Sacramento and Dallas. It was at the department store where people got away from provincialism. But today, they are beset by all sorts of competition -- catalogues, the Internet, discounters and highly specialized stores, like Toys "R" Us.
Around the 60's, the department stores began to be run by controllers, who were looking at every department in terms of profitability. And they said, "We can't make any money on refrigerators or stoves -- let's get rid of 'em."And they did. They did the same thing with electronics. The one classification of merchandise that is the most exciting new source of invention, they got out of. It's my contention that there are some things you have to carry even if you don't make any money on them.
I'd like to put together a think tank of people -- economists, futurists, city planners, a few department-store people -- to discuss reinventing the department store. I have some ideas of my own. For instance, I think that the department store of the future will have to have some kind of entertainment. It will have to develop a way of selling goods at lower markups. But I don't know if it's absolutely necessary for them to meet the discounters' prices -- so long as they offer the public better service and a more tasteful assortment.
 
Q: An entertaining store -- what would that be like?
A: I think food. A variety of food experiences at a variety of prices. And stores may very well present live entertainment. Outside New York, where there's less live entertainment, I could see stores having on-site concerts, offbeat performances that take advantage of the local idiom of expression. Exhibitions are also key -- like showing the origin of design through merchandising. For instance, I'm wearing a houndstooth-check tie. What is its origin? I think people would have a great interest in seeing how fashion originates and how things are made. In Japanese department stores, they dedicate one floor to an art gallery. Or you could have demonstrations of glassmaking or flower arranging, or an exhibition of the drawings of Frank Lloyd Wright.
 
Q: So what you're saying is that stores could become more like museums, while museums seem to be becoming more like stores?
A: Yes. I was in the Metropolitan recently, and I was flabbergasted when I saw the size of their store. They are selling everything from rugs to jewelry.
 
Q: Which stores do you see doing great merchandising?
A: Marks & Spencer. Because as Sir Marcus Seif himself says, they are "obsessed with merchandise." They are constantly looking for things that are newer and better. I also like what Jean-Louis Dumas does at Hermes, and Gordon Segal of Crate and Barrel. They're making a real strong attempt to lead the market to a higher plateau. Whenever you set a taste standard, you are being presumptuous, and these merchants dare to be that.
 
Q: If you were to redesign the suburban mall, what would it look like?
A: It would be located near where people live. A store of the next century could have imaginative vending machines, maybe designed by Disney. They'd wink at you or smile at you when you put your money in -- something to make it fun. You could sell cosmetics, underwear, slippers -- probably 30 to 40 percent of department-store stock -- in a vending machine. The machines would make many salespersons obsolete, and that would bring down the markup.
 
Q: Where do you shop for yourself?
A: At Neiman Marcus. I get a 30 percent discount. I also go to Sears twice a year, to see what's happening there. And I always learn something.
 
Ingvar Kampard, 70. Founder and chairman of the Ikea Group, with 134 stores in 28 countries.

Q: What is your background?
A: I am the son of a farmer who grew up in Augunnaryd, in the south of Sweden. I went to what I guess you would call a trade school. And it was there that I started to be interested in the way factories turn out products for the consumer. When I was about 17, I began to wonder why only the affluent could afford beautiful furnishings. Swedish design was very popular then, but it was too expensive. It seemed to me that if you could reorganize production and distribution processes, it might become possible to sell beautiful items the majority could afford. That was more or less the beginning of the Ikea concept. We started out in mail order and opened a small store in 1958.
 
Q: How do you keep prices low?
A: Well, for instance, the backs of most of our bookcases are not lacquered. For products that we lacquer everywhere, we'll use second-level materials rather than prime quality. Our designers must constantly ask themselves, How can we eliminate a few steps from the production? How can we save money on materials?And we pass on the savings. The designers, for instance, came up with the idea of packing the unassembled furniture into flat boxes, which saves on shipping, storage and assembly.
 
Q: You ask consumers to haul these flat packages home themselves and then assemble them. When I think of assembling it myself, it's a big barrier. Do people resent doing that?
A: Some do. And for them, we have a service: we'll assemble and ship the pieces, at an extra cost.
 
Q: Your stores have supervised playrooms for children, free use of baby strollers, private rooms for nursing mothers. Why the child-friendliness?
A: Because we want people to spend two or three hours in the stores and see what we have. Why push children to shop for furnishings? Who can make a decision with a 5-year-old clinging to their knees? We want to make it easy for young families to get their homes started. Or, put another way, we do nothing to stop people from buying from us.
 
Q: Why do most of the stores have a restaurant and a bistro?
A: For the same reason. We want people to spend time with us, to plan what they buy -- and we want to make all of that easy. We provide pencils and pads and tape measures and information about the various products. We have lockers for coats, tote bags to carry around impulse purchases, plenty of bathrooms, 50 or more sample rooms for people to inspect. So it's nice that they can go into the restaurant, have themselves a Swedish-meatball luncheon and plan how they are going create their living rooms. The store in Almhult, Sweden, even has a hotel with a swimming pool and a sauna attached to it.
 
Q: What's the idea behind all the special events?
A: To make shopping fun, pleasant. We are normally a destination store -- people travel maybe an hour and a half to get to us. Our most popular event is the Christmas-tree rental. You can rent a tree for $20, and when you bring it back we mulch it for your garden and give you a coupon for merchandise. It's a great way to increase traffic.
 
Q: Have you made a mistake that's turned into a fiasco?
A: Recently, we invested in a big sawmill in Russia, and it was a disaster. We lost everything. Also, I must tell you that I am a little bit ashamed of the Elizabeth, N.J., store, because we can't give good service to our customers. There are many queues, and many times it is overcrowded.
 
Q: Where do you shop for yourself?
A: I admire Marks & Spencer. They are very eager to declare, to give very good information about all they sell. They have also a reasonable price level, and you can trust the quality.
 
Q: How much of the culture of Ikea comes from the character of Ingvar Kampard?
A: Well, I'm known as a very thrifty person, and the stores are meant for people like me. I don't fly first class on the airplanes, and the stores' executives don't either. Once, I was in a store in Sweden and I saw cans of deep-fried chicken from Poland. I wondered what the Poles did with the chicken feathers. So I investigated, and it seemed that they were being thrown away. Then we began buying their chicken feathers and using them for stuffing throw pillows.
 
Richard Branson, 46. Chairman, Virgin Group, which includes Virgin Atlantic airline, Virgin Cola, V2 record company and the 13-country, 122-shop Virgin Megastores chain.
 
Q: You started your merchandising career in the 1970's, when you were publishing a youth-culture magazine called Student. Why go retail?
A: Because of an English post-office strike in 1979. I was 19. We had a little mail-order company, which sold records cheaper than everybody else. But then when the postal strike went on for seven weeks, suddenly the business was in danger of going [out] of business. And so I found a run-down empty floor in the back of a shoe shop, and overnight we moved all the mail-order records into it. We had pillows on the floor, headphones so people would listen to the records, and people would be smoking dope, and it was, you know, very much a sort of hippie post-60's store.
 
Q: Till you came along, British record stores were rather stuffy, solemn places.
A: Very stuffy. Moreover, they would sell an [Andy Williams] record next to a Frank Zappa record! There was no discrimination in taste. And, you know, we sold bootlegs and other things that the standard record shops would never dream of touching.
 
Q: Stanley Marcus says the future of retailing lies in stores having good restaurants and running cultural events.
A: I agree. We have live concerts. We have 600 listening areas and 100 laserdisk stations in the New York store. We're setting up Internet areas where people can sit down and play. There are couches in the classical-music section and a grand piano. And a good bookshop and cafe.
 
Q: Where does Richard Branson shop?
A: I don't. I'm afraid I'm a male chauvinist. I hate shopping. My wife, Joan, does the shopping. She goes to a lot of little boutiques. She loves the Gap, Banana Republic, Harrod's, Bloomingdale's.
 Yesterday, I bought something for myself for the first time in 10 years. I was going to the Grammy Awards, and my suitcase didn't turn up on a certain airline and I had no clothes.
 
Q: On your own airline?
A: On my own airline! So I went to Saks and got this Armani tuxedo, with a very pleasant person serving.
 
Q: What will the megastore of the future look like?
A: It will be a giant entertainment complex with a 30-screen cinema, a cafe, possibly a place you can put your children while you're shopping. Plus, the best record collection and a really good bookshop. You ought to be able to go into a Virgin Megastore and spend eight or nine hours there and not feel pressured to buy anything. It will be like a cultural emporium.
Now, the reason we have to do all this is because in the future the consumer will be able to pick up the phone and have records delivered. Films will come through the wires. The only way retailers are going to succeed is to make the whole thing a better experience than what they get by staying home.
 
Q: Retailing experts tell me that the Virgin Megastore at Times Square exists not so much for profit as to establish a New York presence for all your companies. Is that store really just a huge billboard?
A: Well funnily enough, the price of renting the billboard space outside on Times Square would cost us more today than the rent we pay for the whole store. So the store [is] a gigantic billboard.
It would have been worth us doing the Times Square store just to break even in order to get the exposure. Still, Virgin retail is a busines, and, fortunately, a very profitable business. We're opening about 13 new stores in the U.S. in the next 12 months.
 
Q: Do you see yourself as selling things other than entertainment and entertainment software?
A: Oh yes, we see ourselves as branching out into other areas. For instance, about a year ago, one of the airline's hostesses came to me and said that she'd just gotten married, and getting the wedding together had been a tough experience. She wanted to set up a shop called Virgin Bride, where somebody could see the best range of wedding dresses, have makeup and manicures done, people to do the hair, and then they could use Virgin Holidays to arrange the honeymoon and a planner to help organize the reception. If they wanted to get married underwater or whatever, we'd arrange that. So we've just opened Virgin Bride in London, which was her dream. And now we're looking at the fact that mostly about nine months later, all these girls will be pregnant, and we're considering Virgin Babies next. Maybe Virgin Dating. We could have all three.
 
Q: The whole life cycle. How about Virgin Funerals?
A: Virgin [what]?
 
Q: Virgin Funerals.
A: Well, it's something worth looking at. I mean, I never dreamed that we'd now have Virgin Pensions and Virgin Life Insurance and be moving into banking. So we're getting quite close to the funerals anyway.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1013 words

HEADLINE: Vintage Entanglements

BYLINE: By Linda Gray Sexton; Linda Gray Sexton, the author of "Searching for Mercy Street: My Journey Back to My Mother, Anne Sexton," is at work on her fifth novel.

 BODY:

 CARSON VALLEY
 By Bill Barich.
 337 pp. New York:
 Pantheon Books. $25. 
 A successful novelist must also be something of a magician, distracting his audience with grand gestures or intricate small turns, deftly camouflaging the tricks that support his fictional illusions. Usually this is the sort of act that takes many years -- and sometimes many books -- to perfect. But in his first novel, Bill Barich delivers a seasoned performance.
 Then again, Mr. Barich is hardly a neophyte. He's published a collection of short stories ("Hard to Be Good") and a book of essays ("Traveling Light"), many of which first appeared in The New Yorker. He's also written a lively travelogue of his home state, "Big Dreams: Into the Heart of California." In fact, California seems to have been his obsession for many years. Moving from its deserted seacoast towns to its abandoned mills, from the crowded Los Angeles suburbs to the desert interior, he writes about the environment, the people, the way of life, the philosophy, the perspective that is California. In particular, he is fascinated by the contrast between the needs of individual Californians and the relentlessly depersonalized machinery of modern American life.
 Mr. Barich draws on all these concerns in constructing the plot of "Carson Valley." Although the central focus of the novel is a love story, this action is set against a vivid social landscape. Almost every member of his cast of characters is involved, on one side or the other, in the struggle to maintain the independence of a small, old-fashioned vineyard in the wine country north of San Francisco.
 Anna Torelli is the vineyard owner's daughter, a Berkeley graduate who left her father's farm to marry a young lawyer from a family of stockbrokers and surgeons. Following a miscarriage and the failure of her marriage, she has sworn off all romantic entanglements. At the opening of the novel, she has come back to California to care for her mother, who is dying of cancer, and to try to reach a truce with her aging father, Victor, who is ready to relinquish responsibility for his business interests. Somehow, despite all her resolutions, she finds herself drifting into an affair with Arthur Atwater, grandson of one of her father's oldest friends, who has been hired to manage the vineyard.
 Arthur, a resolutely solitary man, lives in a trailer on the edge of the property. Though his previous history includes work as a roustabout, cabbie, carpenter and bartender (and though he has a tendency to disappear on a bender at the first hint of trouble), Anna admires "his integrity in facing the world as he truly was, without any mask." In Arthur, she finds, "there was nothing false. All his actions and convictions, right or wrong, admirable or despicable -- and he could be despicable -- had a wholeness about them, a richness and a roundness, as if he had cast off every imaginary and fantastic version of himself long ago."
 Threading through the narrative of Anna and Arthur's attraction is a history of the valley, coupled with an apprehensive look forward to its future. For as gentrification erodes the boundaries of the small vineyards, big business threatens them from within. Victor Torelli has reluctantly signed a contract with a larger wine company, under whose policies Atwater chafes. "You can trust a computer, or you can trust me," he tells Victor, unable to contain his mounting frustration.
 The economic and class structure of the valley helps to propel the domino-like action of the plot, drawing in not only the big-money vintners with their mansions in the hills but growers like Torelli, upon whom the vintners depend. Also affected, of course, are the field managers like Atwater and his Mexican-American crew boss, Antonio Lopez, as well as the hordes of legal and illegal Mexican laborers who descend on the vineyards at harvest time.
 With easy grace, Mr. Barich moves among the various perspectives of his characters: from Victor Torelli to his daughter, from Arthur Atwater to Antonio Lopez to Omar Perez, a young illegal immigrant. This shifting viewpoint has ethical as well as esthetic consequences, illuminating the individual tragedies of characters like Omar and Antonio, who might otherwise have remained in the background.
 By interweaving these characters' stories, Mr. Barich also allows them to challenge one another: he clearly intends for us to compare the long and solid marriage of Claire and Victor to the budding liaison between Anna and Arthur -- and to the dissatisfied union between Antonio and his common-law wife as they argue about whether he should give up the underpaid work that he loves to take a job with a construction company in the suburbs. Each situation forces the reader to confront the same questions about the truths and lies that are tangled up in romantic and familial love -- but they are seen from quite different angles. And as the characters refine their relationships -- breaking them off, cutting them back, pushing them forward -- the analogy with the work in the vineyard supports the construction of the book as a whole.
 Mr. Barich once lived on vineyard land in a trailer much like Arthur Atwater's, looking down on the same oxbow of the Russian River as the Torelli farm. He has done his research by living it, and the reader becomes absorbed in his descriptions of the vineyard's daily routine as it pushes toward the harvest. There are a few places where the narrative runs close to being overwritten, almost as if Mr. Barich had got drunk on the riches of the countryside around him, but he usually stops short of the brink, contrasting the lush backdrop of the natural world with the crude and quirky qualities of his characters.
 Buttressing his realism, however, there is also a sense of magic. Mr. Barich pulls in fate and luck with an elegant sleight of hand that guides his characters to their difficult destinies and sweeps the novel toward a denouement filled not only with deception, betrayal and sorrow, but with forgiveness as well.
