PUB-DATE: April 6, 1997

SECTION: Section 5; Page 13; Column 4; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2438 words

HEADLINE: Hopscotching Around Asheville

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS; GLENN COLLINS is a reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
AS challenges go, it seemed to have a low degree of difficulty: to plan a spur-of-the-moment tour in October of western North Carolina around Asheville. After all, the region has an abundance of history, woodsy splendor and estimable attractions, not to mention that famous travel-poster highway that winds over the North Carolina border to Tennessee. Surely, organizing a five-day visit could be left to the very last moment.
But in a hasty blitz of armchair planning, my wife, Sarah, and I collided with a baffling reality: The guidebooks we consulted described a bewildering array of options and assumed -- incorrectly -- that we had weeks to linger in the region. The more we read, the more impossible it seemed to design a sampler that would hit the high points in some sensible fashion. 
 How to proceed? We sought emergency advice from friends in Durham. O.K., they said over the phone, You could stay in Asheville. But that wasn't the Smokies. Of course, you could visit the Smokies, but that wasn't at all Asheville. Then there were the scenic treasures of the Flat Rock area south of Asheville, and the glories of the Appalachian region to the northeast. And oh, yes, there was this Tennessee town, Gatlinburg, a sort of Disneyland of the Southern Highlands, described to us as "Reno without gambling, and not to be missed."
Confused as we were, the vacation deadline forced decisiveness. We picked five places to stay almost at random, and trusted to luck. Our goals? To indulge in a maximum of garden-variety tourism, to get in as much good eating as possible, and to add enough hard-core hiking to offset all the eating. Most important, we needed to economize since we'd already tanked our travel budget with an extravagant trip to Italy.
The compromise: We snagged a skinflint air fare, made reservations in expensive restaurants and booked cheap motels.
We got a low fare to Greensboro, half a state away from Asheville, which gave us a chance to explore the huge, exquisitely appointed showroom and, yes, museum at Replacements Ltd. Moments after landing in Greensboro we were accelerating north on I-85 in our rented Corsica to see this $52 million company, which maintains the world's largest inventory of old and new patterns of china, silver and crystal.
For those who are wild about antique porcelain and flatware, which we are, Replacements Ltd. is the Florence of table settings. Just the sight of all that tableware worked up our appetites, so afterward we rewarded ourselves with osso buco and salmon with sweet-potato pancakes in a smart Greensboro restaurant, Undercurrent.
Then the weather changed. Heavy rain was expected to engulf the entire Southeast the next day. Concerned that our scenic-view tour of verdant North Carolina was in jeopardy, we revved up the car and made the three-hour dash to Asheville.
The hill-bound jewel of Buncombe County has often been celebrated as a tourist paradise of stately homes, gracious squares and picturesque downtown streets sporting Gothic Revival and Art Deco architecture. We didn't have time to discover all of the antiques emporiums and cafes, but we enjoyed a tour of the Victorian boardinghouse that is the Thomas Wolfe Memorial.
The house, once owned by Wolfe's censorious mother, was described in "Look Homeward, Angel," and is timeless enough that visitors expect the young Thomas to appear at any moment, offering a prolix assessment of the town that now celebrates his memory. That night, a happy discovery was the restaurant 23 Page at the Haywood Park Hotel, where we had pecan-dredged mountain trout and black-sesame-seared sea scallops.
Our problem, when we returned to our motel, was the puzzler we'd started with: What to see when there is so much there there? Dreading the thought of cracking the guidebooks again, we resolved to take the lazy tourist's way out and collected a bunch of glossy brochures from the motel lobby.
Sarah liked the picture of Chimney Rock Park, dominated by a 2,280-foot-high thumb of gneiss overlooking Lake Lure. "Tourist trap," I said, "I can just tell."
Sarah was insistent, and so was the stationary front: Heavy rain would arrive in the afternoon. This made the slow drive south on I-26 behind logging trucks all the more frustrating. But Chimney Rock was a happy discovery. Tourist magnet though it is, the park is a spectacular privately owned nature preserve. We spent the morning exploring its steep hiking trails and 404-foot waterfall.
To our surprise, we also found that the centerpiece of the Sky Lounge gift shop was a vitrine-cum-shrine to the actor Daniel Day-Lewis and the filming of the 1992 movie "The Last of the Mohicans," part of which was made at Chimney Rock. A kindly cashier gave us a list of the film's other shooting locations and, impulsively, we decided to visit as many as we could.
But the weather front had arrived -- high wind, lashing rain and fog. We wondered: Could we beat the rain westward? We took to local roads and somehow managed to outpace the slowly approaching front. Racing an hour and a half to the Smokies, we hoped to have at least one chance to hike on a dry trail there. At last, booming through the overcast but rain-free landscape of the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, we intersected the Appalachian Trail not far from Newfound Gap.
The A.T., as the trail is known in the hiking universe, is the 2,160-mile path that wends its way from Georgia to Maine. We unceremoniously dumped the Corsica on the shoulder of the road and stumbled onto the A.T. just as the mist rolled in and the storm began toying with the great forest about us.
The fog formed into spitting rain as the front finally arrived. But before us were the reassuring white tree-trunk blazes of the Appalachian Trail. The path was rugged but relatively dry; the ancient trees buffered the drizzle. We hiked several miles -- past steel fences used to keep out wild boar -- encountering no people and no boar.
We decided to turn back only when the light began to fade. When we finally reached the car, our most urgent problem was ravenous hunger. The map suggested that we were but 20 mountainous miles from Gatlinburg. So we continued on the twisty but picturesque Newfound Gap Road, reaching Gatlinburg in less than an hour.
There it was: a hillbilly tinseltown in the mountains. Passing prominent signs boasting variously of 1,000 and 2,000 available hotel rooms, we drove about, awed by a world-class conglomeration of tourist glitz and catchpenny gaud ranging from the Aerial Tramway and Sky Lift to the Celebrity Museum of the Stars and the Guinness World Records Museum.
We settled for what looked to be the least tacky eatery, an ersatz chalet-style dining palace where we were served an indifferent meal of frozen fish and tired roast beef. So we wandered the town some more, admiring the swagger of the wedding chapels where close to 20,000 couples are married every year, and then made the 34-mile drive back to our motel in Cherokee.
It was overcast next morning, threatening but drier. We quickly determined that the town of Cherokee -- home to the Eastern Band of the Cherokee Indians and tribal-owned gambling emporiums -- was the East Coast market leader in beaded moccasins. The friendly staff of the Cherokee Visitor Center directed us to a collection of glossy travel brochures so we could scientifically select our next destination. Rejecting the calls to whitewater rafting and petting zoos, we opted for the "spectacle of Linville Gorge and Falls." During the subsequent two-hour drive, we realized that this was another of the shooting locations for "The Last of the Mohicans."
Rain threatened again as we arrived at the parking lot of the Linville Gorge Wilderness Area. The brochure did not lie: We took several hikes to view a variety of perspectives at Linville Falls, a phenomenal Mixmaster of water pounding down through a tough quartzite ridge.
At the National Park Service Visitor Center nearby, we asked directions to Grandfather Mountain, another natural phenomenon that seemed to be a favorite of the brochure-writing industry. But 15 minutes later, our hearts sank as we approached the entrance to the mountain preserve. The laconic gatekeeper in the booth told us: "There is no view today. And our radio says there's a dark-weather line heading toward us."
We felt it was nevertheless our duty to plunk down the outrageous entrance fee (now $20 for two). We headed to the top of Grandfather Mountain to see its famous mile-high swinging bridge, the highest suspension footbridge in the United States. We vowed to walk it even in a typhoon.
As soon as we reached the summit, the sun emerged hesitantly from the fog. The horizon cleared. We discovered that we were above a glorious immensity of peaks, the southern Appalachian Mountains. We tramped out onto the sturdy but still-scary Swinging Bridge. Yes, it moved with our steps, ringing metallically as we traversed the chasm to the outcrop on the other side.
Scrambling to the summit, high above the cottony mist in the valleys, we gave thanks to the gods of mountains and weather. Owing to the discouraging honesty of the gatekeeper, we shared this perfect Kodak moment with only two other tourists. And before our eyes, an entirely different sector of the Asheville region had been revealed.
That night we stayed in the hamlet of Little Switzerland at the only real hotel we could afford on the trip: the Switzerland Inn, a homey Southern chalet with piney walls, a roaring fire and the woodsy hubbub of conversation in the lobby. The next day we hopscotched west through the overcast back to the Biltmore Estate in Asheville.
George Vanderbilt's famous 1895 mansion is the largest private home in America and it looks as if it very much yearns to be in the Loire Valley. The hefty admission price of $27.95 a person is worth every penny; the 250-room house, its grounds and winery kept us content for a whole day.
That night, in the neighboring sprawl of Biltmore Village, where the original construction workers and tradesmen once lived, we dined in the Criterion Grill, an unassuming local institution serving delicacies such as blackeyed peacakes -- sort of refried beans with a spicy salsa and black bean sauce -- and crab-and-corn flan, with crabmeat, corn, roast garlic and roast red pepper puree.
The next day, there was time for a last hurrah before the long drive to the airport in Greensboro. We headed northeast to Table Rock Mountain, the other-worldly setting for the concluding scene in "The Last of the Mohicans." After urging the Corsica 13 miles on a mercilessly winding gravel road, we parked and hiked 45 extremely vertical minutes to the summit, past rare mountain heather and Table Mountain pines (their bristles require fire to germinate). Our last overview of the region was a mountain panorama bathed in golden sun.
The tedium of the flight home was relieved by a satisfying realization: that only by stumbling around the North Carolina highlands had we been able to make any sense of the area. We knew now that four distinct tourist regions had presented themselves: Asheville itself, and the fascinations of Biltmore; the Flat Rock area to the south; the Great Smokies to the west, and the Appalachian high country to the northeast. We'd cherry-picked them all.
Next time we'll spend a week in each region. Just as the guidebooks had suggested -- had we only been able to comprehend them.
 
Winging it from museum to mountaintop in North Carolina

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 19; Column 1; Education Life Supplement 

LENGTH: 1309 words

HEADLINE: COLLEGE & MONEY;
Surviving the Crush of Student Loans

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL; Saul Hansell reports on banking for The New York Times

 BODY:
It's getting to be a few years after graduation and some of the finer points covered in those 8 A.M. economics lectures are slipping away. Still, you remember enough to notice that your income is looking micro as your bills go macro. The monthly tab on your student loans reminds you of the recurring hangovers from those college homecoming parties.
 If this sounds familiar, you're not alone. With overall consumer borrowing now surging to record levels, more people are finding that their student loans are getting too heavy to juggle; some nine million student loans are in default, according to the United States Department of Education. 
 "We are seeing more people in their late 20's who didn't get the job they had planned for," said Joanne Budde, executive director of the Consumer Credit Counseling Service of San Francisco. Typically, Ms. Budde added, these young adults have several maxed-out credit cards and "a lot of student loans."
 It's true that student loans can burden graduates with debts in the tens of thousands. But the good news is that they can be among the most flexible for borrowers seeking easier terms.
 Chances are that your student loans come from one of two sources: A bank or private lender that granted you a Government-guaranteed loan (a Stafford loan, for example) or a loan made directly by the Government (a William D. Ford Federal loan).
 Both types give you a number of ways to ease the pain of paying off, depending on your circumstances: deferring all payments for awhile, making lower monthly payments for a time or consolidating several loans into one. If you are having trouble making your payments, the first step is to call your lender so you can check out the options.
 To qualify for a deferral, you must have returned to school, or have entered an internship or other training program, or be unemployed or facing various other financial hardships. Returning-to-school deferrals apply as long as you are at least a half-time student. Hardship deferrals last up to three years.
 If you don't qualify for a deferral, apply for a forbearance, under which monthly payments are reduced or even postponed for a period of time. Unlike a deferral, however, a forbearance does not stop interest from accruing.
 If you apply for either a deferment or a forbearance, be sure to include all of your loans. (If you don't know how many you have, hunt up the documents you signed originally or ask your lenders to help.)
 If you don't qualify to postpone some or all of your loan payments in these ways, you may be allowed to switch to other plans that offer lower monthly payments or longer terms -- for example, graduated pay-back plans and programs that tie payments to income.
 But if you have more than one loan, before you take advantage of such programs, you might want to consolidate your loans.
 Consolidation loans are available from the Federal Government's direct loan program and from private lenders alike. Parents, too, can consolidate loans, if they used them to finance the education of several children. But the loans of both parents and their children can't be consolidated together.
 Some lenders offer consolidation loans only to borrowers who have at least one of their student loans from them. Others will refinance anyone's loans. Sallie Mae (1-800-891-4599), the private entity that buys and services many student loans from banks, says it is the largest provider of consolidation loans in the country. Consolidation loans are also available from the Federal Government's direct student loan program. (1-800-557-7392)
 The terms for consolidation loans among the various lenders are similar, but it pays to shop around.
 The direct student loan program charges 8.25 percent for consolidation loans, for example, but Sallie Mae and other private lenders calculate the average rate on the merged loans and round that up to the next full percentage point. (Since most recent student loans carry an 8.25 percent rate, that means a rate of 9 percent.) So even if your lender is a private one, you might want to apply to the direct student loan program for a consolidation.
 Many private lenders, however, do offer ways to reduce interest costs for borrowers -- on consolidation and other types of loans.
 Sallie Mae, for example, will cut the interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point for borrowers who have their payments electronically deducted from their checking accounts. And for customers who make the first 48 payments on time, the agency will cut the rate by 2 percentage points for the remaining term.
 Be aware, though, that the comparative savings resulting from these discounts can be small. Someone with a $10,000 consolidation loan to be paid back over 10 years would save a total of only $169 by taking advantage of both Sallie Mae discounts rather than by paying back at a direct Government loan at the flat 8.25 percent.
 And another caveat: While standard student loans have terms of 10 years, consolidation loans can stretch out to as much as 30 years, depending on the loan amount. And the price of such an extension can be enormous over the life of the loan.
 (Still, you should at least consider the 30-year option. While the normal advice is to choose the shortest student loan repayment period possible, in this heavily indebted time the reverse may be true. People with heavy debts generally would probably do best to arrange the longest payment period they can for their student loans and devote their spare income to paying down higher-rate debts first.)
 Whether you are paying down one big consolidated student loan or a few smaller loans, an alternative to extending the payback period beyond 10 years is a graduated payback schedule. Under this plan, lower payments are made in the first two or four years, followed by higher payments for the balance of the 10 years. For example, if a 10-year $10,000 loan at 8.25 percent has a monthly payment of $123, a borrower in the "graduated" program could pay $69 a month for four years and then $177 a month for the remaining six years. (That initial break, by the way, will add $1,294 to the total interest cost of the loan, bringing the interest cost to $6,012.)
 Another alternative: Borrowers whose incomes are highly volatile or just plain low may want to consider a repayment plan, offered by the Federal direct student lending program, that ties loan payments to a percentage of a borrower's income. In certain cases, this can mean the monthly payment is less than the interest charged -- a circumstance that increases the amount owed. But if the whole loan isn't paid off after 25 years of steady paying, the balance is forgiven.
 Sallie Mae and other private lenders also offer plans where repayment rates are tied to income, but borrowers must at least pay the interest each month and eventually all of the principal.
 Finally, if you are flirting with default on a student loan, you may need to rehabilitate your credit with your existing lender before finding refinancing with a new loan on better terms. This mainly involves making payments that are "reasonable and affordable" for three to six months to show that you are committed to paying back something. Depending on your plight, "reasonable and affordable" can be a level that is far less than the stated monthly payment on your loan.
 With so many financial options available, it's best to try to work out easier payment terms as soon as it's clear that you may have problems.
 Credit bureaus keep track of how many times you are late with your student loan payments. And the more of these black marks you have, the harder it will be to get a credit card, buy a car, rent an apartment or even get a job. Renegotiating the terms of a loan and paying it down as agreed, however, is viewed as responsible.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Linda Cardini;
Rural Portfolio, Partnerships and Jobs

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
LINDA CARDINI, executive director of the Connecticut Rural Development Council, former director of the Northwest Connecticut Council of Governments, is a native of Connecticut educated at the universities of Pennsylvania and Massachusetts who served as a city planner in Toronto, then in the suburbs of Orlando, Fla.
It was the chance to move from urban and suburban planning to something more environmentally based that brought her back to Connecticut. When discussions began three years ago about the state joining a national initiative on rural development, Mrs. Cardini's organization fully endorsed the move. In December of 1994 the Connecticut Rural Development Council was officially organized as a Federally funded group whose mission is to develop and implement strategies that can help improve the employment opportunities, incomes and well-being of Connecticut communities by strengthening their capacity to compete at home and abroad. 
 The council aims to provide coordination among Federal, state and local governments tribal councils, the private sector and nonprofit organizations, from all of which board members are drawn. The goal is to preserve the rich heritage -- physical, economic and social -- of rural Connecticut.
What sets the Rural Development Councils apart from other organizations, in fact, is that they are built on partnerships at a time when government funding for many programs continues to be cut back and partnerships become vital.
Of the 15 regional planning organizations in the state, five of the most rural gained seats on the Rural Development Council whose territory is the state's northwest corner.
In a recent interview in Winsted, Mrs. Cardini discussed the council's plans for the area. Following are excerpt from that conversation.
Q. As a relatively new organization, how do you let people know who you are, and what your mission is?
A. We held a forum last July in Torrington on techniques to preserve agricultural lands and open space. Congresswoman Nancy Johnson said towns in her legislative district needed this information, and so we advertised widely in the 44 towns, and drew about 100 people.
We also allocated funds to hire consultants to prepare a rural resource directory that describes agencies and programs that are potentially available. This will be printed, distributed, and put on the Internet.
In December of 1996, we co-sponsored, with the Connecticut Council of Small Towns and the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation, a forum on rural road and bridge standards. This was requested by the Northwestern and Litchfield Hills regions. We followed that up by being at the State Capitol in Hartford when legislation was proposed, asking for rural road and bridge design standards that emphasize repair instead of new construction. This gives communities the flexibility to respect historic, environmental and esthetic qualities so important in small towns.
We're not around to be adversarial, but to be informed, and inform others, about all sides of an issue. Our name might be misleading, also, because of the word "development." We're advocates for rural communities, not necessarily development.
Q. Do you find that people in Connecticut want development or not?
A. People want jobs. They want to feel there's a future here, for their kids to stay, to grow up, and have jobs. They tend to be more concerned about the quality of development. In towns with a population under 5,000, many are concerned about traffic from commercial development. Kent, for instance, is so clogged on weekends that the average resident doesn't go downtown on Sunday.
We need to balance the need for jobs, affordable housing and retaining the character of each community. Even the nine Northwest towns have very different views about what they want.
Q. What are the specific issues in the Northeast corner?
A. This area may face more of a challenge when the economy picks up because the land is relatively low priced, and the area is a reasonable commute from Boston, Worcester and Providence. Commuters may fine it very attractive.
A forum is in the works to make towns aware of techniques to preserve farmland, such as selling it to the state, or making a plan with landowners to create controlled subdivision and put easements on the rest of the land. You may not necessarily be able preserve the farm, but keep the quality and partial openness of the landscape.
Q. What is the plan for the Connecticut River valley?
A. The Connecticut River Estuary Planning Agency will host the next meeting of the council. We're out-reaching to that area, to see how we can be helpful. Planners from the Litchfield Hills and Northwestern region have asked us to consider organizing training for planning and zoning commissioners on topics like subdivision regulations and limits of their planning authority. We're looking into co-sponsoring some education programs for these boards of volunteers all over the state, including the Southeastern section.
Q. One of the issues that you mentioned was the impediments to businesses that operate out of historic buildings. How can your organization assist with this?
A. If the owner of an older home wants to convert it to a bed and breakfast, complying with requirements of state building codes and fire codes can be very expensive and discouraging to a business that is otherwise compatible in rural areas. If we're trying to encourage small businesses and economic activity in existing buildings, we want to know if there is something that can be done to ease up on such requirements.
The economic subcommittee is pursuing this issue now, at the request of a bed and breakfast owner in the Southeastern region.
Q. More urban areas have access to computerized mapping. What would be the advantage to these rural areas in investing in such technology?
A. The University of Connecticut has a geographic information system. If a town has access to a compatible computer, they can download the information. All towns are in the UConn database, but they need training to let them know about it, how to download it and make use of it.
The advantage is that computerized mapping is easy to update. Land parcel changes and land use changes can be recorded, and it is not usually cost effective for small towns to do this with manually produced maps.
Q. You have mentioned several different subcommittees. Who serves on these and what exactly do they do?
A. There are a lot of different people on the subcommittees. Some are Federal, state and regional public sector employees; serving on the council is part of their job. Others are volunteers from the private and nonprofit sector.
Our mission is to recruit new members. We're supposed to have tribal representation from the Mashantucket Pequots and Mohicans. We're reaching out to the planning and professional community. We also especially want to be in touch with architects and engineers.
Q. In what other ways can you be useful to the small towns?
A. We need to spend time training the chief elected officials in these communities. Most don't have a town manager, and we need to give them lots of information so that they can guide growth, attract new growth, manage change and still retain the rural character that they see as important for their community.
I've focused on the clients as towns, but the other element is local agencies. Are there things happening in a community or region that we could support, like inland wetlands commissions? By pulling people together we can improve resources and training.
Q. Has the Rural Development Council proven effective in other states?
A. This is a voluntary program, but 38 states now belong, including all of New England except Rhode Island. The Rural Development Council has a lot of potential.

HEADLINE: A Character Singer Steps Out of Character

BYLINE: By CORI ELLISON

 BODY:
THE PHOTOGRAPHS lining the foyer of Joyce Castle's compact, serene apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan invariably depict her as part of a group: with family, with colleagues. But on Tuesday evening, Ms. Castle, long the unofficial resident character mezzo-soprano of the New York City Opera, will take an uncharacteristic turn in the limelight, in the company's new production of Gottfried von Einem's "Visit of the Old Lady."
The opera is based on a play by Friedrich Durrenmatt, and Ms. Castle, in the role of the vengeful millionairess Claire Zachanassian, assumes the mantle of bona fide leading ladies from Lynn Fontanne (in a 1958 Broadway production) to Ingrid Bergman (in a 1964 film version) and Christa Ludwig (in the opera's premiere, in 1971). 
 "Yes, I guess it's the title role," Ms. Castle acknowledged. "I am the Old Lady. But to think of it as a star vehicle really doesn't benefit me at all. My way is to find my place in the story and figure out how I fit with the other characters. I'm a team player."
She comes by her team spirit rightly: at the time of her birth, her father was pitching in semiprofessional baseball. Her mother, a home-economics teacher and amateur pianist, started her on piano lessons at 5.
Growing up in Baldwin, Kan., a town of 2,000 some 40 miles southwest of Kansas City, Ms. Castle enjoyed a normal Middle Western youth, busy with church and school choirs, music camp and backyard theatricals. But even then, she was aiming for the stage. "Actually, early on I wanted to be a Hollywood movie star, so I could sing and act as well," she said in her typically deliberate cadences and nasal twang.
She honed her versatility at the University of Kansas in Lawrence, taking advantage of performance opportunities in theater, musical comedy and opera. Soon after graduating, she married the noted furniture designer Wendell Castle and relocated to Rochester, where she pursued graduate studies at the Eastman School of Music. In 1969, she joined the Western Opera Theater, the touring arm of the San Francisco Opera.
Her second marriage, to an American tenor active in Europe, ended after eight years in Paris. Then she returned to the United States and sang for Beverly Sills, the City Opera's general director.
"I remember her audition vividly, and my first impression still holds true," Ms. Sills said. "My mother used to say, 'Some performers bring their own spotlight with them.' And that's Joyce Castle. Before she even opens her mouth, there's this enormous stage presence, like a light around her."
Ms. Castle began her City Opera career modestly in 1983, with a small speaking role in "The Merry Widow." But she came into her own a season later as the charmingly lethal Mrs. Lovett in "Sweeney Todd."
Ms. Sills, realizing what a resource she had in Ms. Castle, made her a veritable pillar of the company in the next few seasons. A gallery of picturesque roles endeared her to the public and to critics alike: the maniacal Madame d'Urfe in Dominick Argento's "Casanova," the mischievous Fata Morgana in "Love for Three Oranges," the lovelorn Katisha in "The Mikado," the dotty Baba the Turk in "The Rake's Progress" and the "easily assimilated" Old Lady in "Candide."
The common denominator amid this diversity is a colorful, outlandish over-the-top verve. "How I connect with these bizarre people I don't know," Ms. Castle said. "But no matter how wild they seem, you have to accept the character as a real person and find a place within you where there's common ground."
For this striking, 5-foot-10-inch mezzo, biology has often been the common ground. "The way I look, my dramatic range and, luckily, my voice seem to match," she explained. "Look at me -- aren't I the perfect ingenue? I'm petite. I have blond, curly hair and blue eyes, just like the girl next door who should get the boy.
"I'm being sort of silly, but there's a little truth in it. Inside, I suppose, there's the person that would have sometimes liked to be the sweet ingenue."
Ms. Castle is finally easing into the dramatic repertory her coaches have long predicted for her. In 1986, she made her Metropolitan Opera debut as Waltraute in "Die Walkure," and she has returned every season since, as the Witch in "Hansel und Gretel," Orlofsky in "Die Fledermaus" and other characters. She recently sang Fricka in Wagner's "Ring" cycle in Seattle, Klytemnestra in Strauss's "Elektra" in Milwaukee and the Principessa in Puccini's "Suor Angelica" in Chicago. Her sizable, wiry, tangy voice is just the ticket for these roles: always supremely affecting and communicative, seldom pretty.
"I REMEMBER STEVE Sondheim coming backstage and saying, 'I just love it when you make your voice all . . . you know, nasty,' " she said. "Now, I don't ever think, 'I'm going to make this tone ugly.' I think about what I'm singing, and things happen on stage from the inside out. And maybe I sacrifice a note here or there. Maybe that's why you don't see me in the Bellini operas."
As Ms. Castle's career expanded, she kept up her connection with the City Opera under another general director, Christopher Keene. "Maybe three years ago, I ran into him in the corridor," she said. "He pointed his finger at me and said: ' "The Visit of the Old Lady." Gottfried von Einem. That's for you.' "
As fate would have it, "The Visit" is one of the first City Opera productions to bear the stamp of the company's new general director, Paul Kellogg, who assembled most of the cast and production team after Mr. Keene's death.
With "The Visit," Ms. Castle fortifies her high profile in 20th-century music. At the City Opera, she has figured prominently in the New York premieres of Mr. Argento's "Casanova," Hugo Weisgall's "Esther" and Bernd Alois Zimmermann's "Soldaten." At the Santa Fe Opera, she has appeared in works by Judith Weir, Krzysztof Penderecki and Aulis Sallinen. She also recently recorded Menotti's "Medium" for Cedille Records.
"I was good at math in school, so I think that's why I've never been frightened of any role," she said. "I did Ligeti's 'Aventures et Nouvelles Aventures' with the New York Philharmonic. That's just diabolical, unless you treat it as a mathematical problem."
Ms. Castle leavens this weighty fare with frothier "crossover" repertory, slipping in concerts of Gershwin, Porter and Bernstein anywhere from London and Stuttgart, Germany, to Jerusalem and Carnegie Hall. She was also selected by Stephen Sondheim to take part in an acclaimed Book-of-the-Month Club recording of his songs.
Typically, her wish list tends toward the quirky. "I'd still love to do the Nurse in 'Die Frau Ohne Schatten,' and the Janacek mothers, those lovely mothers, Kostelnicka and Kabanicha," she said. "And in another life, I'll do 'Turandot' and 'Werther.' I mean the tenor roles."
Could happen. And it could happen in any number of places.
"I've just done my taxes, so I know I was away from New York more than 200 days in the last two years," Ms. Castle said. "That's a lot of moving, but it appeals to me. I'm at home where I am these days. Maybe that comes from maturity. I'm a Gypsy in search of a role."

HEADLINE: Another Millennia Problem: Computer Files

BYLINE: By ADAM L. PENENBERG 

 BODY:
WHEN the year flips from 1999 to 2000 Long Island and the rest of the world could be faced with the computer glitch to end all glitches, potentially a $600 billion problem that could paralyze governments and bring companies to their knees -- all because, until recently, computer systems were designed to read two digits instead of four.
It is called the Millennium Bug or the Year 2000 Crisis and although the roots of the problem are maddeningly simple the economic and legal havoc it could wreak is not. Any company or organization that processes invoices, claims, debt collection and payments could be in for a rude awakening when the calendar says 2000 but the computer reads it as 1900. 
 "The issue isn't whether it's a crisis but how much it will cost," said Ira Morrow, a research director for the financial services industry at Gartner Group, a Connecticut-based high-tech think tank.
"When the City cabs gave wrong receipts on Feb. 29, people said, 'Oh, a computer foul-up,' " Marc Sokol, vice president of advanced technology for Computer Associates in Islandia, said. "Wait until the year 2000 when interest payments bounce or the government says you owe millions of days of interest on your taxes."
According to experts, including Mr. Morrow and Mr. Sokol, if companies and government do not fix the problem, the result would likely be computer chaos, an increase in business failures, debilitating litigation and higher taxes.
But thus far, Long Island business and government have barely begun to seek a cure. And they are running out of time.
"The firms on the Island haven't gotten their act together yet and as the millennium approaches most companies that deal with fixing the problem will be overwhelmed by firms making requests," Jerry Ottomanelli, manager of information advisory services for Ernst & Young, said. "Resources will be stretched. Major clients will be taken care of. Smaller firms won't. And the closer you get to 2000, the more the price will go up."
Software Productivity Research (www.spr.com). in Burlington, Mass., estimates that the Millennium Bug would directly cause 1 percent of Fortune 500 companies, 3 percent of small companies and 5 to 7 percent of medium-size firms to go belly up.
The reason? A lack of money, manpower and technical know-how. According to the New York State Task Force on Information Resource Management, created by Gov. George E. Pataki in January 1996, it would take, on average, one programmer one day to analyze, fix, test and implement one program to make it year 2000 compliant. In an organization with 60,000 programs, it would take 120 people working full time for two years to accomplish the task. Multiplied by every business and government agency with a mainframe in the American economy, the cost might exceed the combined gross domestic product of several nations.
Just getting the government up to code would cost billions. The White House Office of Management and Budget released a report in February that estimates the cost of upgrading the federal government's computers at $2.3 billion, although the Gartner Group puts the price tag at more than 10 times that, at $1.10 per line of code.
"The government's estimates are way too low," Mr. Morrow said. "There is no automated way to do this. It must be done computer by computer. We're not only dealing with 30-year-old code in some cases, but also the interfaces between systems."
The reason for software programmers' reliance on two-digit years instead of four was to save space. In a typical company database, e.g., employee personnel records, every time a date appeared -- date of birth, date of performance evaluation, date of the first day's work -- programmers crammed four digits into two, dropping off the 19 in the year. In a typical database, this amounted to millions of lines of additional memory.
"It was a habit and good programming practice to do this," said Mr. Sokol, who has testified before Congress on the problem. "When we wrote these systems, we had no idea they'd be running fifteen, twenty years later.'
Companies like Ernst & Young and Computer Associates, which counts the State University at Stony Brook and Kmart as clients, expects a growing share of their business to involve helping clients cope with the coming millennium. For a mainframe, this necessitates finding, fixing and rewriting large sections of code. But since this problem can occur in many different systems, anywhere in the software and, sometimes even hardware, and mainframes by nature are customized to the needs of the company, there is no 'silver bullet.'
Computer Associates is not the only company in the millennium game. A whole industry has begun sprouting up to manage the problem. Peter de Jager, a consultant, has a website dedicated to the Millennium Bug (www.year2000.com), which provides information and posts hundreds of advertisements for products specifically marketed to those seeking Year 2000 compliance.
Even insurance companies like Marsh & McLennan have drawn up policies to inoculate companies that either suffer losses or cause other companies to suffer losses.
"We're going to work both ends -- the victim and the victimizer," said Thomas Ruggieri, managing director of Marsh & McLennan Inc. "Even if a company tries to fix the problem, it's easy to miss something. Bringing code up to standard is a painstaking problem: all it takes is one bad line of code."
Marsh & McLennan, which developed the policies in consultation with the Zurich-American Insurance Company and Lloyds of London, plans to provide up to $200 million in liability coverage to companies facing debilitating lawsuits and huge damage claims to companies that are already Year 2000 compliant.
The New York-based insurance broker would also offer protection against a company's own profit-losses and extra expenses incurred from inadequate updating of its computer system. It also plans to cover losses sustained by a client if an outside computer system wreaks havoc with its system.
The American International Group, an insurance company, along with Minet, an insurance broker, has also developed a Millennium Bug policy that Marsh & McLennan plans to use to complement its offerings.
But there is one sector Marsh & McLennan would not offer coverage. "There is no way we would insure either the Federal Government or local governments," Mr. Ruggieri said.
Camaron Thomas, who heads the New York State Task Force on Information Resource Management, is also concerned, but for a different reason. "Local governments feed us so much information and if they aren't compliant, it could screw up our computer systems and vice-versa," Ms. Thomas said. "This is particularly scary when you think about what government provides: welfare and child support collections, tax refunds, government checks, licenses, lists of people under arrest or on parole. It could get real messy."

HEADLINE: Brookhaven Looks for Plans to Deal With Contaminated Water

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
CONCEDING that they may be powerless to stop a 10- to 12-year-old leak of radioactive tritium from a nuclear reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory for at least nine months, Federal officials are pressing plans to deal with contamination that the leak has caused.
In conferring with state and Suffolk County officials, lab officials have said the options to address the worst contamination -- high concentrations of tritium in ground water near the building that houses the research reactor -- are quite likely to be controversial, expensive, exotic sounding and, in some cases, potentially risky. 
 One choice, sometimes referred to as the ice-cube method, would involve freezing contaminated water near the reactor with an underground system of refrigeration pipes.
Other options include trapping the water in impermeable underground walls or pumping it into tanker trucks for shipment to Canada. Another alternative is to do nothing, allowing the tritium to degrade gradually and be diluted by uncontaminated water. Tritium loses half its radioactivity every 12.4 years.
Experimental methods with names like electrolytic enrichment, thermal diffusion, membrane filtration and isotopic exchange have also been discussed.
Last week officials from the Federal Energy Department, the owner of the lab, and the lab said that they were in the early stages of deciding how to proceed. The State Environmental Conservation Department and the County Health Services Department are also involved in the planning.
Any plan would be fully disclosed to the public before being approved, the officials said.
The tritium cleanup tops an array of problems that the 50-year-old lab faces as it tries to rebuild shaken public confidence in its ability to manage the 5,300-acre government complex, a Federal Superfund site since 1989 because of the disposal of radioactive substances and chemicals over many years.
Critics are demanding the permanent closing of the research reactor, which opened in the mid 1960's to produce neutron beams for experiments. The critics said the risks of operating the reactor and the extent of soil, water and air contamination caused by the lab had just begun to come to light.
A spokeswoman for the lab, Mona Rowe, said the tritium problem may possibly be handled under the Superfund cleanup. That effort has involved capping dumps where radioactive materials, including the carcasses of test animals, were buried and sinking wells to track underground plumes of contaminants. Volatile organic chemicals are being stripped from water and released into the air as part of the cleanup.
Officials said the problem of contamination near the reactor building was compounded because tritium, an isotope of hydrogen, was nearly inseparable from water. "We don't have a technology that can reliably and on a large scale pick out the water molecules that have the tritium component," said Frank J. Crescenzo, deputy manager of the lab office in the Energy Department.
A method in which water with tritium would be released into the atmosphere as a mist has been eliminated as a possibility, said Dr. Tara O'Toole, the Assistant Energy Secretary for Environment, Safety and Health. Officials said the method was discarded, in part because they expected it would meet strenuous public objection. Critics of the lab said the release of tritium to the atmosphere was unacceptable.
One critic, Jay M. Gould of the Radiation and Public Health Project in Manhattan, has said that statistical evidence links radioactive emissions from the lab to higher-than-normal rates of breast and prostate cancer in the vicinity of the lab in Upton. The lab vigorously denies that.
Another critic, Fish Unlimited of Shelter Island, is preparing to file a suit, contending that the lab violated Federal laws for clean water by discharging radioactive substances, including tritium, into the Peconic River.
The executive director of the conservation group, William N. Smith, said lab emissions into the headwaters of the Peconic, where the complex is situated, had introduced cancer-causing radioactive substances into waters and marine life in Peconic Bay and may have set off the brown tide algae that decimated scallops beginning in 1985.
Department of Energy and lab officials said the tritium leak, found in December after the lab dug test wells near the reactor, posed no danger to the 3,200 employees of the lab or nearby residential areas. The officials said their first objective was to prevent a plume extending at least two-thirds of a mile from the reactor building from spreading further toward the lab's southern boundary.
Last month they announced plans to pump water at the leading edge of the plume, where tritium concentrations are below Federal standards for safe drinking water, to a recharge basin near the center of the lab property. The officials said that by the time the water with tritium had seeped back into the ground it would be less radioactive and mixed with clean water.
The pumping is tentatively set to begin this month. But officials have agreed to report first to the County Department of Health Services. Joseph H. Baier, an environmental quality director for the department, said the county wanted assurances that the plume had been delineated and that extraction wells were at correct depths.
Mr. Baier said the county also had questions about a carbon-filter treatment that was supposed to remove non-nuclear contaminants from water piped to the recharge basin. He said the department believed that it might be premature to start pumping by this month.
"The tritium has been there for 10-plus years," Mr. Baier said. "If it stays for another month or two there is no danger."
Mr. Smith of Fish Unlimited said the plan would spread tritium to other areas of ground water and allow some particles to evaporate and become airborne.
Dealing with the more heavily contaminated water near the reactor building will be an even greater problem, officials said.
"If we pump that water out, put it in trucks and drive it to Canada, just think of the traffic risks," Ray E. Cowen, the regional director of the Environmental Conservation Department, said. "You have to weigh those risks against the 'no action' alternative."
A spokesman for the Environmental Protection Agency, Richard Cahill, said it was "very early in the process" to decide how to handle the higher concentrations of tritium. "The options are grouped two ways," he said. "One is containment. The other is extraction and disposal."
Federal officials said they continued to believe that the tritium was leaking at a rate of 7 to 10 gallons a day for a 68,000-gallon spent-fuel storage pool in the reactor building.
The officials have announced plans to ship spent fuel from the pool to the Savannah River plant of the Energy Department in Aiken, S.C., in four installments, in May, July, September and November. The pool has to remain full while any fuel remains, officials said.
After all the fuel has been removed, the pool would be drained and repaired. A steel liner would also be added, in accordance with county regulations that the laboratory had failed to comply with.
Energy Department officials say they base their estimate that the pool has been leaking for 10 to 12 years on the distance that the plume of water contaminated with tritium has moved from the reactor building.
"The mistake here is that we should have put those monitoring wells in sooner," Ms. Rowe said. "Now we are basically canvassing the site."
Ms. Rowe said that lab officials now accepted the possibility that the reactor might not reopen and that they were concerned about the effects of the problems on the lab's future.
"I don't think the lab is immediately in jeopardy," she said. "What I see is that people are losing trust in us, and right now there is a sense that they just don't want to tolerate all of these environmental problems anymore."
Thomas Conoscenti, a regional economist, said closing the lab would devastate the regional economy. "You are talking about a lab with a very unique reputation," Mr. Conoscenti said.
But critics said the lab, opened in 1946 at the former Camp Upton, should not operate in what has grown into a heavily populated area.
A safety inspector in the Energy Department, Joseph Carson, wrote in a letter circulated to the media recently that the tritium leak was "inexcusable, if not criminal."
"There were too many warnings," Mr. Carson said, "too many regulations and standards that were ignored or violated, too many lies and unmet commitments and too many involved people who, for too many years, knew that the High Flux Beam Reactor spent-fuel pool -- unlined, with no leak-detection system, with high levels of tritium contaminated water -- was a nightmare waiting to happen to Long Island's fragile environment."
Mr. Carson, who was involved in an investigation by the Energy Department about a fire in the reactor building in March 1994, said he became a whistle blower to protest what he described as a culture at the department that punished those who raised safety questions.

HEADLINE: ATLANTIC CITY;
Counting Heads

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
ATLANTIC CITY set another record in 1996: the city had as many as 34,041,548 tourist visits.
That makes the city the most visited tourist destination in the country, beating Las Vegas, Nev. (29 million), and Disney World (27 million), says Anthony Marino, a senior planner with of the South Jersey Transportation Authority. 
 "We're speaking of visit-trips here, not actual numbers of people," said Mr. Marino, who has compiled Atlantic City visitor statistics since 1978. "If we want to look at it in terms of distinct visitors -- how many people actually visited the city in 1996 -- it goes down to a range between 5 million and 8 million, some of whom come back as frequently as once a month. That's about how many people are keeping the city in business, and of that number, about 92 percent were gamblers, which is a good sign. Not everybody who goes to Atlantic City goes to gamble."
Thanks, in part, to him, Atlantic City has looked good on paper since the Boardwalk's first casino opened to record business in 1978, when Mr. Marino, a former sociology professor at Stockton State College, began compiling the city's most famous statistic.
"I had just started working as a demographer for the Atlantic City Expressway," he said, "and we got a call from the Convention Bureau asking if there was a way to determine how many people were coming to the city because of the casinos. Because I'm good with numbers, it sort of fell into my lap."
He couldn't use gate receipts, as Disney World does, to come up with his number. He could not use hotel stays, the basis of the Las Vegas statistic; most people who visit Atlantic City do not stay overnight.
And although New Jersey Transit, the Federal Aviation Administration, the Atlantic City Expressway, the Greyhound Bus Company and the Casino Control Commission compiled visitor statistics, no one had ever combined them and tried to distinguish the tourists from commuters, businesspeople and pass-through travelers to other destinations.
"I was lucky in one respect: Atlantic City is on an island," Mr. Marino said. "In 1978, there were only four ways you can get to it: by car, bus, limousine or air. When the rail service was restored in 1988, you had five."
In fact, there are six. Pleasure and charter boats from other ports dock at both Harrah's Marina and the Frank S. Farley Marina, opposite Trump's Castle, in the warmer months. Mr. Marino elected not to count "the few hundred" boat visitors because "the figures weren't easily available."
When he finally came up a methodology to isolate visitors, Mr. Marino checked his figures with casino executives. "They said it was close to their own calculations, maybe a little lower," he said. "That it was lower appealed to me because I would much rather have a conservative figure than an inflated one."
In 1978, Mr. Marino's calculation of 6.4 million visit trips "really turned heads in Las Vegas," he said. "It was the first indication that Atlantic City was going to become the tail that wagged the dog because most of that number was generated by one casino" -- Resorts International -- "that wasn't even open for the whole year."
Other demographers and tourism industry officials challenged his number. "Sure, a lot of people were skeptical," he said. "I was grilled for hours by Wall Street brokerage houses. I had all kinds of experts come in and try to tear my number apart. But it was solid."
Progress has not been steady, Mr. Marino has shown. After reaching 33.1 million in 1988, the number of visits declined in 1989, dropping as low as 30.2 million in 1993. "It really wasn't until 1995 that the city set another record, at 33.2," he said.
That number "turned even more heads around," he said. "I got calls from Wall Street brokerage houses like you wouldn't believe. They said to me that my number was the first indication that things were really beginning to turn around in the city after the recession. After that, you had Salomon Brothers and Prudential Bache coming out with reports that Atlantic City was worth a second look, and suddenly all these new casino companies wanted to get back into the town."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Visitors come by land, by air and sometimes by sea, says Anthony Marino, counting Boardwalk-bound cars on the Atlantic City Expressway. (Allen Oliver for The new York Times)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Nostalgia Time: A Beloved Revival Revived . . .

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
A DESIRE to return in thought or in fact to a former time in one's life, to one's home, or to one's family and friends." That's nostalgia, according to the Random House Dictionary of the English Language. Always was, always will be and -- all the rage or not -- it's always with us in some measure, this yearning that time and memory effect.
To chroniclers of the 1970's, a craze for nostalgia explained the unexpected success of "No, No, Nanette," billed in its Broadway revival as "the new 1925 musical." That sleek 1971 version of a creaky 1925 show (which spawned a flop sequel, "Yes, Yes, Yvette") is to play the Paper Mill Playhouse in Milburn from Wednesday through May 25. 
 During rehearsals of the Broadway reproduction, the adapter and director, Burt Shevelove, gave a pep talk to a disgruntled cast fed up with going over the same few numbers over and over, with no script in sight. "The world today is not a pretty place," Mr. Shevelove is quoted as saying in "The Making of 'No, No, Nanette,' " by Don Dunn (Citadel Press, 1972). "It is filled with terrible news every day, of Vietnam, campus riots, pollution, crime, inflation. The audiences that will come to see our show will have heard enough -- much too much -- about all those things.
"We must take their minds off those problems and make them concerned only with this: Will Nanette, this innocent little child, get her wish and spend a weekend in Atlantic City? Nothing else, nothing else at all, is important. This warm, sunny, lovely little show must be our valentine to the audience."
Safely assuming that today's audiences do not lack for disillusionment and seek escape into simpler times, the Paper Mill revival of a revival is in the surest of hands. Look no further for authenticity. During a recent rehearsal in a studio at 890 Broadway in lower Manhattan -- itself rife with nostalgia, having once been owned by Michael Bennett (after his "Chorus Line" success) -- the director, Donald Saddler, guided the dancers in the show's opening number, "Too Many Rings Around Rosie."
"The Paper Mill production will be exactly the Broadway production -- word for word," said Mr. Saddler, whose work as choreographer for the 1971 Broadway "Nanette" won a Tony Award. "And step by step."
In "Too Many Rings," Lucille Early, played by Virginia Sandifur, was perched on a piano, surrounded by four adoring chorus boys. Ms. Sandifur went into her lines. "My husband is going to kill me, but I had a bad week at mah-jongg," says Lucille, who has emerged from behind purple Bergdorf's boxes. She then explains, "There are hats and there are hats, but this, my dear, is a chapeau."
On the sidelines, Helen Gallagher, who won a 1971 Tony Award as best actress in a musical for her Lucille Early, was watching (but what was she thinking?) and practicing tap steps in place for her role as Sue Smith, played in 1971 by Ruby Keeler, one of the three reasons for the nostalgic hoopla over that "Nanette." The other two were Patsy Kelly as the maid, Pauline, and, most of all, Busby Berkeley, the show's nominal but, practically speaking, superfluous production supervisor." "I expect Ruby to come down and help me," Ms. Gallagher murmured. Miss Keeler died in 1993.
Mr. Saddler, who has choreographed various "Nanette" productions, including the London company (with Dame Anna Neagle, who was a 1940 Nanette in one of several film versions) and three national companies with Virginia Mayo, Evelyn Keyes and June Allyson, respectively, and supervised a St. Louis staging that starred Marge Champion.
"I didn't think I ever wanted to do this again," he said during the rehearsal break. "But the Paper Mill production will be as posh as possible, and I knew that I could protect the show. We didn't want to make fun of the period or comment on it, or camp it up -- only recapture it as homage. With respect."
Pointing to 20's magazine pictures and ads taped on the wall, much as he had done to inspire his dancers 26 years ago, Mr. Saddler continued: "There's no other frame of reference for these young people in the chorus -- the body language, the gestures of the 20's. Ladies sit down properly. They don't cross their legs, only at the ankles. A gentleman never stood directly in front of a lady; that was an affront. He turned this way or that. With respect."
In 1947, Mr. Saddler, a classically trained dancer, did the tango with Ms. Gallagher in "High Button Shoes" on Broadway when he played the younger brother of Nanette Fabray, who was replaced by Ms. Gallagher in the Paper Mill production after withdrawing for health reasons. Ms. Gallagher recreated Lucille in a 1973 Paper Mill "Nanette." Kaye Ballard, who plays the dour maid always getting ready to quit (the Patsy Kelly role) appeared as Pauline with Ms. Fabray in a recent "Nanette" production at the Civic Light Opera in Long Beach, Calif. The cast includes two Paper Mill veterans: Eddie Bracken as Jimmy Smith, Sue's philandering husband, whose "three wicked women" are trotted off to Atlantic City, and Lee Roy Reams as Billy, Lucille's husband and Jimmy's lawyer.
I T would be six days before the cast moved on to the Paper Mill stage, where chorus girls would walk on six spinning beach balls with an Art Deco design, just outside the Chickadee Cottage in Atlantic City and Ms. Gallagher would appear atop a double staircase, the refurbished 1971 design by Raoul Pene du Bois.
What are the joys of yesteryear to which Paper Mill audiences crave transport? The turkey trot, the Castle Walk, the polka, the Hesitation Waltz? The time when a lady would forgive anything if a gentleman danced with her? Or the 1971 prices of orchestra seats on Broadway: $12 weekdays, $15 weekends. Perhaps "the patterns and the beauty of dance" that Ms. Gallagher laments as having been discarded in musicals? Or a self-defining song like "I Want to Be Happy"? (Don't forget that the "Nanette" score also includes "Tea for Two.")
All of the above. As David Waggett, the show's assistant stage manager, said: "It's about time this show came back to town."

HEADLINE: New Channels and New Costs for Cable TV

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
MANY Cablevision customers may be confused over new channels that have popped up on their television sets recently, other channels that have changed locations and a sudden rate increase of several dollars a month.
That is because Cablevision is in the midst of a major rebuilding, connecting customers to a fiber optic network that will ultimately increase the number of available channels. 
 Cablevision's recent complete purchase of Madison Square Garden raises further questions about sports programs to be offered on Long Island like what that programming will be and how much they will cost.
"The purchase is new," the chief executive officer of Cablevision, James F. Dolan, said, "and we're looking for the company to be making programming available in different ways."
Of Cablevision's 660,000 subscribers on Long Island, 154,000 have been connected to the upgrade, called Optimum TV, according to a spokesman for the utility, Charles Schueler. Most of those are in Nassau County and western Suffolk County, where the population densities are highest, Mr. Schueler said.
By the end of the year, he added, Cablevision expects 250,000 to 275,000 homes to be connected.
The next areas to be upgraded are the remaining sections of the Town of North Hempstead and the Town of Huntington, with the remainder of the Town of Hempstead and the entire Town of Babylon to be rewired next year.
When the homes are connected, eight new channels appear automatically in the Family Cable service, including MSNBC; Fox News, a 24-hour news channel; a local weather service and WGN, a Chicago station that televises Cubs and White Sox baseball games and movies.
The new connection allows channels like E! Entertainment TV, Bravo, the MSG Network, the Weather Channel and Newsport to expand to 24-hour service, as well as opening access to 22 more optional channels.
The 80-channel Optimum TV plan offers individual channels or packages that cost from $34.95 to $76.95 a month.
Optimum includes ESPN2, the Food Network, the History Channel, the Independent Film Channel, the Learning Channel, Muchmusic, New Sport, Romance Classics, Sega and Starz!
Mr. Schueler said 65,000 customers had bought Optimum packages.
Different areas have different capacities, he said. Some communities have 58 channels and others have 80.
The rebuilding means a more reliable system with better quality, said Joe Azznara, senior vice president of regional operations. The original 30-channel system was built in the 70's.
"A fiber optic network creates state-of-the-art telecommunications," Mr. Azznara said, "which not only offers expanded channel capacity, but the ability to receive cable modem Internet service and interactive TV. In the future we will be able to provide video on demand and deliver residential phone service through cable."
The rebuilding starts with replacing old copper cable. In some cases the wires from utility poles to houses also have to be replaced, Mr. Azznara said.
"One of the most exciting benefits of a system with access to more channels," Mr. Azznara said, "is that it takes away the barrier of having to decide which channels to carry."
For the older systems, Cablevision's programming department surveyed customers to see what they wanted and what made economic sense, Mr. Azznara said, adding: "Our general philosophy is not to remove any channels. But in the older systems we maxed out on channels available. Recently we downloaded several channels that were formerly carried only on Rainbow packages to make them now available on Family Cable."
Those channels include America's Health Network, American Movie Classics, BET and Bravo.
Cablevision increased the charge for Family Cable by 7 percent, to slightly less than an additional $2 a month.
For a growing number of customers, the combination of rising monthly rates and limited programming has prompted the installation of satellite dishes. "Overall it is cheaper to own a satellite than to subscribe to Cablevision," said Jordan Schalk, owner of Sattech, a distributor and installer of satellite equipment in Brooklyn, "and satellites give you more choices in programming and customer features, as well as better picture and audio quality."
Of the four major systems on the market, one, Primestar, is available for rental service, said Mr. Schalk. After an initial fee of about $140 for delivery and installation, monthly packages range from $29.95 for 63 channels to $54.95 for 95, he said, adding that even the basic package includes Disney Channel and MSG.
Russ England, territory director for a local franchisee, Time Warner Primestar, said the business had grown steadily since it started in 1994, but he would not release the numbers of customers.
"Cablevision used to be the only game in town," Mr. England said. "But now more homeowners are choosing satellite dishes for enhanced programming and services. You're not affected by power outages and rate increases like you are with Cablevision. And as of April 23, we'll have access to 160 channels."
The lone problem, he added, is that customers cannot receive local broadcasting from the satellite and have to use regular antennas or buy basic cable service.
"Satellite providers," Mr. Dolan said, "are trying to play catch-up with cable. Cablevision is leading the way in rolling out the most efficient dependable and promising delivery technologies. Our network will bring customers popular new services like Telephony and Optimum On-Line Internet access that simply can't be delivered by satellites."
Cablevision would not release the number of customers who buy different packages, but said Family Cable remained the most popular tier, at a monthly rate of $25 to $30, depending on location.
For homeowners in most of Nassau and Suffolk who do not have access to Optimum TV, Cablevision options begin with Broadcast Basic, which provides 16 channels, for approximately $10 a month.
The next tier is Family Cable, which offers 46 to 56 channels, also depending on location. As an upgrade subscribers can order services a la carte or "build onto" Family Cable. For an additional $5 a month, Spectrum Services offer a choice of four out of five channels, from the Cartoon Network, Comedy Central, Encore, Flix and Sci-Fi.
So-called Premium services -- Cinemax, the Disney Channel, HBO, the Movie Channel, Showtime, Sportschannel and the MSG Network -- can be ordered individually or in combinations.
The monthly rate for the Family Plus One package is $39. For Family Plus Two it is $49, and the Family Plus Three Sports Package costs $54. Again, numbers are approximate and depend on locale.
At the top end of the non-Optimum packages are Rainbow Spectrum, which includes all five Spectrum channels, all sports channels and Cinemax, Disney and HBO for $65.
Rainbow Gold, which adds the Movie Channel and Showtime, for a total of 58 channels, costs $76.
Homes with Optimum TV have wider options, beginning at Broadcast Basic with 20 channels and ending at Optimum Gold with 80.
By contrast, residents of Manhattan, where Time Warner owns the cable service, pay a monthly charge of $14.55 for basic service, with 33 channels, and $31.37 for the 65-channel so-called standard package, the most popular. Customers can add other channels like Cinemax, Disney Channel, HBO, the Movie Channel and Showtime. The first premium channel costs $12.95 a month, the second $9, the third $8 and $6 for additional channels.
In another Time Warner region, Orlando, Fla., the 18-channel basic package costs about $8 a month. The most popular "standard" tier offers 48 channels for about $26. An eight-channel a la carte package runs 99 cents a channel and $3.72 for all eight.
On Long Island the rebuilding is just one part of the telecommunications breakthrough. Mr. Azznara said. The company is testing digital boxes for digital transmissions.
"This is our technological vision for the future," he said. "Programs can be digitized and stored as data in a computer, which will create a library of video. A customer can look at a menu and say, 'I missed "60 Minutes" last Sunday, so I'll watch it on Tuesday.' It will be video on demand."
In December, Cablevision started Optimum On-line Internet access via cable in the northern part of the Town of Oyster Bay, and it is studying residential phone service through cable, said Mr. Azznara.
"All of these services will allow Cablevision to become one-stop shopping for its customers for all of their telecommunications needs," he said.
Enthusiasm over the channel expansion, digital boxes and other new technology could be dampened by pending rate increases to finance the capital investment and the major spending to buy Madison Square Garden. Experts have estimated the cost of that deal at $650 million.
Mr. Azznara said the amount and date for the price increases had not been determined.
"Our bet for the future," he said, "is that many homeowners will want all of these exciting services."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Prosperity at the Wheel on the Route 1 Corridor

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
WITH the supply of office space once again in balance with demand, construction projects for specific tenants are beginning to emerge along the Princeton Route 1 corridor, stretching from New Brunswick 20 miles south to Trenton.
One example is the 235,000-square-foot building planned as part of the headquarters for the eastern region of Raytheon Engineers and Constructors at the 560-acre Carnegie Center in West Windsor. Completion is expected in about a year. 
 The company, whose parent is the Raytheon Company, an engineering, construction and diversified electronics concern based in Lexington, Mass., is also leasing an additional 243,000 square feet of space in two buildings at the park, where it will consolidate most of its three Northeast operations -- now in Manhattan, Philadelphia and Lyndhurst, N.J.
The leases will increase the occupancy rate to 99 percent at the center, where some 1.4 million square feet of space has been built so far, said Roger M. Steinhardt, director of marketing and leasing for the developer, Carnegie Center Associates. When fully built, the park will have 4.5 million square feet of buildings.
"Demand has finally caught up with the supply created in the mid-80's," said Mr. Steinhardt, adding that a 124-room Amerisuite Hotel was also under construction at the center.
Nearby, a Philadelphia-based developer plans a 160,000-square-foot building on 13.8 acres in the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center that it has an option to buy from Princeton University.
"We are seeing more business than we have seen in 10 years," said David Knights, executive vice president of Picus Associates, the firm hired by Princeton University to manage and lease the center. "The market is solid and has returned to normal behavior."
A total of 5 million square feet of space has been built at the center, which eventually is expected to have 11 million square feet.
Mr. Knights said there were 100,000 more square feet of commercial space in the pipeline at the center, which straddles South Brunswick and Plainsboro.
That includes a 153-room Marriott Courtyard hotel and the expansion over time of a biotechnology company from its present 50,000 square feet to 110,000 square feet.
The projects, industry experts said, provide fresh momentum to a market that like others in the state has not seen any major new construction since 1989. "There is a lot of new energy in the system," said Dianne R. Brake, president of MSM Regional Council, a private nonprofit group that tracks growth in Middlesex, Somerset and Mercer Counties.
As of the end of 1995, the latest year for which council figures are available, 61 million square feet of new commercial space were planned for the 32 communities in the corridor. The absorption of 1.1 million square feet of space in 1996 -- continuing a trend that started two years ago -- has left the corridor with few remaining large blocks of prime space.
IN the largest lease transaction along the corridor last year, Bristol-Meyers Squibb , a key participant in the market, took nearly 200,000 square feet. The deal filled the 220,000-square-foot building at 100 Nassau Park Boulevard in West Windsor, which stood nearly vacant for several years.
The leasing activity has pushed up average asking rents, particularly in the corridor's most built-up sector -- generally south of South Brunswick. It also caused a ripple effect in varying degrees throughout the greater Princeton market, where the vacancy rate in the six submarkets is 9.54 percent, said Gerald Fennelly, president of a brokerage firm in Hamilton bearing his name.
That area was hard hit in 1995 by corporate consolidations and relocations. Among the companies that left the area is Mobil, and Lockheed Martin is expected to leave soon.
But there is interest in acquiring the 800,000-square-foot Mobil complex in Hopewell at the southern end of the corridor, said William R. Mate, director of economic development for Mercer County, which is helping to market the site. Michael Kimmitt, a spokesman for the Mobil Technology Company in Fairfax, Va., said that negotiations were continuing with a "prospective buyer," which he declined to name.
At the same time Bristol-Meyers Squibb is selling a 450-acre undeveloped tract at the intersection of Interstate 95 and Scotch Road in Hopewell, where 3.5 million square feet of offices could be built.
"We have been approached by a major corporation to buy the site and discussions continue," said Robert J. Wolfe, president of Picus Associates. The buyer, many brokers said, is Merrill Lynch. While Mr. Wolfe would neither confirm nor deny this, he did say that the financial concern had "no intention of leaving" the 1.3 million square feet of space it occupies and owns in Princeton Forrestal Center.
With an overall vacancy rate of 8.1 percent, down from 18.2 percent about the same time in 1996, the Route 1 corridor is the tightest market in greater Princeton, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage concern. Moreover, the vacancy rate is just 7.5 percent for Class A space.
The 16 percent vacancy rate for the entire 11-county northern and central New Jersey market is about double that for the Route 1 corridor.
STOKING the corridor's activity is the expansion of local companies -- from pharmaceutical and financial concerns to high-technology and biotechnology firms.
"The space left behind is looked upon as the new supply," said Raymond A. Sohmer, vice president at the Princeton office of Grubb & Ellis, a national brokerage firm. Even so, tenants looking for 50,000 square feet or more are having a difficult time finding it, he added.
That was also the case for Raytheon, a newcomer to the area. The company looked at 20 different sites in the Philadelphia and central New Jersey area before selecting the Carnegie Center site.
"We wanted to balance the commute of all employees who will be affected by this change," Charles Q. Miller, the chairman of Raytheon wrote in a statement. "So we looked for a mid-point between the current locations."
The consolidation also will reduce costs and increase efficiency, said Edward J. Powers, a spokesman, adding that as the company grows Princeton offers access to the region's pool of skilled professionals. He said the move, to be completed by the summer of 1998, will bring 1,400 jobs to the area, nearly 1,000 of them new to New Jersey.
Mr. Steinhardt of Carnegie Center said that having 250,000 square feet to offer Raytheon helped seal the deal.
BROKERS say that leasing activity in the Route 1 corridor is expected to continue into 1998, spurring more construction. The state's Department of Labor estimates that employment in Middlesex, Somerset and Morris Counties will grow from 694,865 in 1995, the latest figure available, to 804,100 in the year 2005.
The corridor's drawing card is its central location and proximity to Princeton and Rutgers Universities, said Peter W. Hamburger, a director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. "Landlords have the upper hand now," he said.
Traffic concerns, once a looming issue along Route 1, have also been eased by $200 million in road improvements in the last decade -- among them the construction of several overpasses and the widening of Route 1 south of South Brunswick.
Some $75 million in additional improvements will be completed in the next two years, according to the state's Department of Transportation.
The challenge now is the corridor's lack of available space. The pressure is on corporations to go into build-to-suit properties if they want the Princeton cachet or to move nearby submarkets, said Mr. Fennelly, the broker. Others said companies could also move away from the area.
Average asking rents have increased and concessions to tenants have decreased, said Mr. Sohmer of Grubb & Ellis, noting that rents for Class A space are now $24 to $24.50 a square foot, up from $20 to $21 a square foot a year ago.
The climb in rents is enough to justify new construction, but tight financing will limit speculative buildings from rising, Mr. Sohmer said and other brokers agreed. Build-to-suit deals, or deals with substantial lease commitments from tenants, will be the near-term focus on the corridor.
That is the strategy the Aegis Property Group of Philadelphia will follow for the building it plans at Princeton Forrestal Center. James A Kinzig, a partner in the company, said construction would not start until half the building was leased.
