HEADLINE: Suburbanization of Orthodox Jews

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AT the Westchester Day School in Mamaroneck, Orthodox Jewish youngsters study the Talmud in sunny classrooms overlooking Long Island Sound, learn to apply the lessons of the Torah to their everyday lives and likewise celebrate their heritage by performing Israeli folk dances along the corridors. There, where the kindergarten's guinea pig is lovingly named Yitzhak for the slain Israeli leader Yitzhak Rabin, registration is booming, administrators report.
In White Plains, the crush of the lunch-hour crowd at a kosher delicatessen, the Lexington, attests also to the growth in the numbers of observant Jews in the county. With a little kibitzing, or easy-going banter, thrown in for good measure, corned beef sandwiches are served as the specialty of the house -- all under the watchful eye of a supervising rabbi. 
 At Young Israel of Scarsdale, too, Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein, spiritual leader of the synagogue, could not be more pleased that his flock has increased many fold in recent years -- the result of a successful effort, he said, to "bring a modern song to an ancient text."
The rabbi said that even though the Orthodox Jewish movement dates back more than 3,000 years, contemporary rabbis have been able to attract new members by demonstrating how the age-old rules of the Torah continue to be relevant.
Rabbi Chaim Feuerman, headmaster of the Westchester Day School, said enrollments are burgeoning there and at Jewish day schools throughout the country. The enrollment at his school has jumped to 413 students from 376 eight years ago when he first came to the school, he said, and, based on early registration, enrollments are projected to be as many as 450 for the coming school year.
The statistics are part of what Rabbi Shmuel Greenberg, the spiritual leader of Young Israel of White Plains, calls a new trend in Orthodox Judaism. "The notion that Orthodoxy removes one from the dynamics of the modern world is no longer valid," he said.
With words on their lips like "inclusivity" and "contemporary" and "relevant to all Jews," it was with dismay last week that many Orthodox Jewish leaders in the county heard a statement issued on Monday by a national Orthodox rabbinical organization asserting that the less strict Reform and Conservative teachings followed by most American Jews "are not Judaism at all."
The 600-member, Manhattan-based Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, widely regarded as a right-wing fringe group, is the oldest organization of rabbis in the United States. At a press conference at the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan, Rabbi Hersh Ginsberg, acting chairman of the union, urged Jews affiliated with the Reform and Conservative movements "to abandon their erroneous ways."
But Rabbi Rubenstein, who is the first vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America, the largest council of Orthodox rabbis in the United States, repudiated the statement by the smaller group, saying, "It is not our aim to isolate any Jew."
A statement issued by Rabbi Rubenstein's council, along with the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, said, "We consider the public pronouncement particularly painful in light of the current dangers facing the Jews of Israel and other communities across the world, which cry out for Jewish unity even in diversity."
With 350 families, Young Israel of Scarsdale is the largest Orthodox Jewish congregation in the county, and like many other Orthodox congregations in the county, it has reached out to both observant and nonobservant Jews.
"No synagogue," said Rabbi Rubenstein, "should be only for the pious."
Of the 39,000 Jewish households in Westchester in 1991, 2,000 of them -- or 5 percent -- were Orthodox, according to population studies by Bethamie Horowitz, principal investigator for a 1991 New York Jewish Population Study by the United Jewish Appeal. For all of New York City and Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester Counties, 14 percent of all Jewish adults said they were Orthodox in 1991, the study said. Those are the latest numbers for which statistics are available, but anecdotal evidence suggests the percentages are rising, especially outside New York City.
The recent growth in Westchester of Orthodox synagogues like Young Israel of Scarsdale and the Hebrew Institute of White Plains, which has about 300 families, reflect what Dr. Jeffrey S. Gurock, professor of American Jewish History at Yeshiva University in Manhattan, called "the increasing suburbanization of Orthodox Jews."
Outside of sections of Brooklyn like Borough Park and Williamsburg, the largest suburban concentration of Orthodox Jews is in Monsey in Rockland County. There are also enclaves of Orthodox Judaism in New Jersey and on Long Island. In Westchester, the largest congregations are in New Rochelle, Scarsdale and White Plains.
"As the infrastructure in the suburbs -- the synagogues, the day schools, the kosher eateries, for example -- falls in place, the congregants follow," Dr. Gurock said.
"Orthodoxy used to be synonymous with the lack of a secular education, and as such with the lack of occupational and economic mobility," he said. "While that's still true of some segments, in the last 25 to 30 years, we've seen a rise to middle- and upper-class status of people who have gone through Jewish day schools and gone on to become doctors, lawyers and other professionals and who balance a religious orientation with secular pursuits. The Orthodox Jews of Westchester reflect that."
Take the case of Eric and Roxanne Levine, who moved to White Plains in 1989, joined an Orthodox synagogue and commute to their jobs in Manhattan. Dr. Levine is a sociologist, and Ms. Levine is a lawyer. They are members of the Hebrew Institute of White Plains.
"It was a combination of factors that brought us here -- the desire to get away from the noise of New York City and the wish to purchase a home in a quiet neighborhood within walking district of an Orthodox synagogue," said Ms. Levine, who specializes in immigration law. "In eight years, we've seen quite a growth in the Orthodox Jewish community here. At first, there wasn't even a kosher bakery or a restaurant. Now it's all starting to happen."
Ms. Levine attends a women's monthly study group on the role of the female in Jewish law, run by Rabbi Chaim Marder, the spiritual leader of the Hebrew Institute of White Plains. The rabbi also oversees a monthly prayer group for women, who traditionally are separated from men during religious services but are able to come together one Saturday afternoon each month to read the Torah together and to sing, study and pray.
Although some Orthodox Jews criticize women's prayer services, Rabbi Marder said he sees it "as a window of opportunity to bring women closer into the religion." He continued: "The opponents ask, 'What will it lead to?' and they question whether lines are being crossed. But from my point of view, I understand that it's a struggle for many Orthodox women who are not allowed to run a service."
Debra Hoffman, who attends a women's prayer and study group at Young Israel of Scarsdale, said: "Basically, the traditional services are written by and for men, and traditionally Eastern European women were taught by their mothers at home, so they didn't receive the education that their brothers did. So while in some ways there may be a strong role for women in the religion, there is also a need for them to have a spiritual outlet as well."
While there are no firm numbers on the growth of Orthodox Jewry since the 1991 study, other studies of the baby-boomer generation indicate that in general its members, regardless of persuasion, share an increased interest in religion.
Dr. Levine, 44, who is the associate executive director of the annual campaign of the United Jewish Appeal Federation of New York, said: "For a lot of us baby boomers and for the Generation X'ers as well, we find that religion provides us with a system of values that is enobling and uplifting. The boomers are a searching, sometimes spiritually searching generation looking to match a sense of purpose with a life style that supports those values."
Or as Judy Tretin, a member of Rabbi Greenberg's synagogue in White Plains, said, "In a world with so many distractions, disappointments and pressures, our religion gives us hope and a sense of continuity."
Mrs. Tretin, who is the early-childhood administrator at the Westchester Day School, said she especially looks forward each week to the Sabbath, which Jews observe from sundown on Friday until sundown on Saturday. On that day in most Orthodox Jewish families, no cars are driven, no lights are turned on or off and the usual distractions of the week do not intrude.
"The day is like a festival that I prepare for all week," Mrs. Tretin said. "I don't know what I would do without it. It is the one time my family truly shares together."

HEADLINE: 7 Arts Groups Join In Internet Alliance

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
THE seven largest cultural institutions in the county announced last week that they have formed an alliance in an effort to broaden their audiences.
Making up what is being called the AT&T Westchester Arts Network are the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, Historic Hudson Valley, the Hudson River Museum, the Katonah Museum of Art, Lyndhurst and the Neuberger Museum of Art and the Performing Arts Center, both at Purchase College. They will collaborate on a cultural calendar and a Web page on the Internet and will share resources ranging from market research to advertising dollars. 
 The move to transform these cultural institutions from competitors to collaborators in part reflects the recognition among their directors that there is diminishing government and corporate financial support for the arts and that pooling resources will save each organization money.
But as the institutions began to discuss the idea of an alliance and compared their mailing lists, they made a surprising discovery: though there had always been an assumption that the groups had a large shared audience, they found that in fact the overlap was small -- less than 5 percent of the names were cross-referenced on the seven separate mailing lists, said Howard Herring, executive director of Caramoor.
"It was a real shocker," Mr. Herring said. "Not only did we have very little overlap in our audiences crossing over from different kinds of institutions -- like someone who would visit a historic site and also attend a concert -- but also even within each discipline there was little overlap. Art lovers who would go to the Hudson River Museum might never go to the Neuberger or the Katonah. The same is true with music. People who go to the Performing Arts Center at Purchase don't go to Caramoor."
At first the executive directors were mystified by the behavior of the audience. They speculated that there were psychological barriers at work that sometimes cause people to overlook all cultural offerings in the county, let alone sample what each different institution is presenting.
"I talk to people in northern Westchester who drive past Purchase to go hear 'Orpheus' in New York City rather than here," Mr. Herring said. "Or they'll drive past Caramoor to get to Tanglewood to hear Mr. Previn conduct over a loudspeaker, yet at Caramoor you can listen to him naturally in a lovely setting."
He added that within the county there are also geographic barriers -- Westchester is notorious for its limited east-west travel -- which may discourage people from traveling to more than one or two of the cultural institutions in the county.
But whatever factors were precluding the audience crossover, those forming the alliance began to see the situation as an opportunity: there existed many untapped ticket buyers with an interest in the arts.
"It is encouraging to know that there is a market out there that is predisposed to culture and the arts but that hasn't yet explored everything the county has to offer," said Burns Patterson, a spokesman for Historic Hudson Valley.
The organizations searched for a patron to back their alliance, and AT&T, which has supported the arts in the county in the past, agreed to help not only with the calendar and the Web site but also with advertising and promotion.
"Our long commitment to the county and to the arts creates a natural partnership in a community where many AT&T employees live and work," said Robin Flowers, regional director of public relations for AT&T. "The arts are vital to economic development, and this partnership promises to bring the cultural treasures of this community to a diverse audience."
Each of the seven nonprofit organizations in the alliance attracts an audience of more than 50,000 people a year, but none are at capacity. The alliance has set a goal to increase their cumulative attendance by 5 percent by the end of this year. Mr. Herring estimated that the organizations collectively generate at least $68 million a year in revenues for the local economy.
The new Web site -- www.artsnetwork.org -- is now being designed.

HEADLINE: Support Waning For Social Services

BYLINE: By MAURA CASEY 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago in Willimantic it was common to see coffee cans in stores with the handwritten message: "Support the needle exchange."
The program was operated by activists who used the donations to distribute clean needles to a small number of heroin addicts. The activists were trying to help addicts whose habit of sharing needles is one of the primary methods of spreading the virus that causes AIDS. 
 Last month, Willimantic changed its mind. About 100 city residents attended a hearing in Hartford to ask that the state stop the needle exchange. Opponents of the program included Representative John Lescoe, Democrat of Willimantic, who had initially favored the state's 1994 endorsement and expansion of the program. Similar changes of heart have occurred in several of Connecticut's cities in the last two years.
* In 1995, Hartford's City Council imposed the first formal moratorium on new social services of any major city in the country. The city ended the freeze last year, but not before passing strict guidelines concerning where in the city new social service programs could open.
* Last year, Middletown passed its own ban on any new medical and mental health services; this year it extended that moratorium to January of 1998.
* The city of Groton, alarmed at the potential for social service programs to buy boarding houses that once housed Electric Boat workers, last year imposed a two-month ban on the practice until it could pass more restrictive zoning regulations.
* New London's City Council recently told the Department of Social Services that it did not want a planned satellite office of the department to open in the city, pointedly suggesting that the Social Services Department put the office in Waterford, the town next door.
* In March, the southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments moved swiftly to vote in support of a bill that would require community consent before the state could place a needle-exchange program in individual municipalities. The vote came after the group was told that Connecticut was considering Norwich, Groton or New London as the site of a new needle-exchange project.
Advocates of social services programs say that governments at all levels are offering less support for poor people.
In Connecticut, they say, the cities have traditionally supported social services but now have less and less money to do so. And, say observers, cities are becoming fed up with the unwillingness of affluent suburbs to share the burden of helping poor people.
"We're seeing the abdication of aid by governments, whether state or local," said Alison Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Association for Human Services and director of the Nonprofit Cabinet, a coalition of social service providers.
In particular, she said, the new zoning rules in Hartford concern her. "The impact on social services won't be immediate, but you'll see it over time," she said, as programs close and the restrictions make it difficult for new ones to open.
Middletown's move to curb new programs came after the state announced plans to close several state hospitals in different regions and instead concentrate its mental health services at Connecticut Valley Hospital in Middletown.
That's when the city's Planning and Zoning Commission imposed a moratorium on new services, said Middletown's planning director, Bill Warner. The city successfully sued the state to force it to assess the impact of the consolidation on Middletown. But the issue goes further, he said.
"I definitely think cities are fed up," said Mr. Warner. "Cities have always serviced the needs of the poor. The region doesn't support the cities, but the cities support the suburbs with their services," such as hospitals and other nonprofit organizations.
Richard Brown, New London's City Manager, agreed. When the Department of Social Services announced plans to open a new welfare office in New London, he responded by pointing out that the six-square-mile city is already home to 24 nonprofit organizations and many social service agencies, all of which are exempt from property taxes.
"It is ironic," he said, "that the state and Federal Government doesn't spend money adequately to attract jobs to urban areas, but they'll spend huge amounts of money to renovate a halfway house."
Others made similar observations. Norwich's director of Social Services, Beverly Goulet said, "During the 1970's and 1980's, fewer and fewer jobs were located in cities, and instead of spending money to replace the jobs, government replaced them with social services. We abandoned jobs in cities, but the people who need help are still here. If we continue to neglect urban centers we'll never turn Connecticut around."
Ms. Goulet said that people in cities who have less access to jobs still need a safety net, but that government is less willing now to provide social services on the same scale as before.
Sometimes, Representative Lescoe said, a city's willingness to support services can be eroded by the manner in which government conducts the program. Willimantic supported the needle-exchange when it was a small, local effort, he said, but when the state took over, the project got out of hand.
Instead of involving 17 or 18 heroin addicts, the program eventually distributed needles to 300 addicts, giving out needles whether or not addicts returned used needles. City residents began to find discarded needles, some with blood still in them, on park benches, sidewalks and scattered in residential neighborhoods. People got angry, especially last year when a toddler stuck herself with a discarded needle.
"I'm not against the concept of needle exchanges. If it saves lives, fine," Mr. Lescoe said. "We weren't against the program, we just wanted the state to fix the problems." And that didn't happen, he said.
Mr. Lescoe said he has become increasingly concerned about the impact on cities of shouldering the burden of social services. "Urban areas get every social program. Every time you get rid of one, there's another to take its place. I can see five halfway houses from my porch on Jackson Street," he said. To enable local officials to keep better track of when and where the state intends to put new programs, he introduced a bill to force the state to inform State Representatives and Senators before the state spends money in a municipality, he said. Then, at least, officials could have a chance to react before a program opens its doors, he said.
The answer, say social service advocates and municipal officials alike, is for suburbs to share more of the burden and for city residents to have access to more jobs.
"We need to support our core cities," said Ms. Johnson. "We need to do a better job of providing services in surrounding communities. But building walls higher is not the answer."

HEADLINE: Who Says Service Is No Good?

 BODY:
We wonder which Connecticut the article ("It's a Service Economy, but Where's the Service?," March 16) was referring to. Not the one we know, and we've been right here in the middle of Connecticut for 27 years.
Our cars have always been serviced properly and reasonably. Our local gas station is always ready to help in an emergency. 
 The people who do repair work on our house are sometimes slow about getting here, but they do good work at a reasonable price, and a declaration of emergency brings them running.
Supermarket clerks do make mistakes, but they are corrected promptly and courteously. Nor is shopping in other stores a problem.
As for medical care, the Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown is known for its skillful care and kind, caring treatment. Both of us have been patients there and could not have been better treated.
Perhaps the writer of the article lives in that part of our state that is really a suburb of New York.

GEORGE H. WOLFSON
East Hampton

HEADLINE: Lights Dimming At the Dog Tracks Where It All Began

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
BEFORE casinos on Indian lands. Before jai alai frontons. Before off track betting parlors. Before the wide assortment of games of chance available to bet on in stores and other places througout the state.
Before all that there was Plainfield Greyhound Park in eastern Connecticut, close to the Massachussetts and Rhode Island borders -- the first place in the state where one could legally make a bet, short of buying a lottery ticket. 
 The opening of the dog track in January of 1976 was, after the weekly lottery, the first step in the state's plunge into gambling as a means of raising revenues, ostensibly for education. Largely because of its location, which enabled it to draw bettors from two states familiar with dog racing, Plainfield Greyhound Park did well for about a dozen years. Influenced by that early success, the owner of a jai alai fronton in Bridgeport converted his operation into a dog track when fronton attendance began to falter. Two years later, the Bridgeport dog track -- Shoreline Star Greyhound Racing and Entertainment -- is in bankruptcy and racing has been suspended since Dec. 1, although bettors can still make wagers on televised out-of-state horse races, along with greyhound racing from Plainfield Park.
At the same time, attendance is down sharply at Plainfield, as is the handle, the amount wagered on the dog races. Indeed, the state now pays more money to regulate and subsidize the dog track than it receives in taxes from parimutuel wagering there.
In a recent report, the Division of Special Revenue, which oversees the operation of gambling operations in the state, projected that the state will put out $1.5 million more to regulate the state's two dog tracks during the forthcoming fiscal year than it will receive in parimutuel taxes.
The declining popularity of dog tracks and jai alai frontons have prompted state lawmakers to reconsider continuing to subsidize gambling propositions that the legislature helped create. Adding to the legislators' dilemma is the economic impact the gambling centers have in their areas.
Plainfield Park's decline, like that of dog tracks throughout the country, is mainly attributable to inroads made by casino gambling. In the case of Plainfield Park, the state's two hugely successful casinos, Foxwoods in Ledyard and Mohegan Sun in Uncasville, are less than a half hour's drive away. "Since 1988, the yearly handle, the attendance and the parimutuel tax paid to the state has been declining," said George F. Wandrak, the acting executive director of the the Division of Special Revenue. "And that was four years before Foxwoods opened. Foxwoods merely exacerbated the situation."
Acording to Mr. Wandrak, the handle for the 1987-88 fiscal year totaled $188 million and the attendance was 790,666. By comparison, for the fiscal year that ended last June 30, the handle was $32.6 million and attendance 288,319. Even more significant was the decline in the state's share of the parimutuel tax, which dropped to $490,000 in the last fiscal year from $8.2 million in 1987-88. "That's a drop of 94 percent," Mr. Wandrak said, "but it does not diminish regulatory attempts since the same number of races -- 120 -- and the same number of dogs -- 8 -- still compete in each race."
Mr. Wandrak was referring to the 15 inspectors from the Division of Special Revenue who are assigned to Plainfield Park to conduct kennel inspections, do analyses of the dogs' urine samples after each of a program's 15 races and, in general, to oversee the operation of the privately owned track.
Karen Keelan, the general manager of Plainfield Greyhound Park, said that the handle and attendance have increased this year. "Better weather has helped and so has the fact that we've sold our signal to more facilities outside of the state," she said. That was a reference to the beaming of races from Plainfield to other betting centers.
Ms. Keelan also said that state government projections on subsidizing Plainfield Park are misleading. "They're talking solely about the parimutuel taxes and not including other tax money we generate," said Ms. Keelan, referring to admissions, sales, payroll, property and income taxes that the track generates. Mr. Wandrak conceded that point and noted other benefits to the Plainfield area. "Plainfield Park is a major employer in Plainfield, which, after Hartford, is the second-poorest town in Connecticut," said State Representative Michael Caron, a Republican from Plainfield. The challenge, Mr. Caron said, was for the park to diversify. "We've got to have vision here and do something different," he said. Among the possibilities he suggests are high-stakes bingo games and three-on-three basketball games on which wagers would be made. "They bet on jai alai in Connecticut and hardly anyone understands the game," Mr. Caron said. "But everyone understands basketball, so why not bet on it legally?"
Although Ms. Keelan did not mention three-on-three basketball games as alternatives to greyhound racing, she agreed that Plainfield Park must diversify if it is to survive. "About three-quarters of our space is unused," said Ms. Keelan, whose father was one of the original owners of Connecticut Yankee Greyhound Racing Inc., which owns the track. "And I can see cordoning off an area where minors would be admitted to go to a movie theater, be able to go line dancing, practice golf and do other things."
That, however, would require a change in state law, which now prohibits anyone under the age of 18 from entering a gambling installation during a racing season.
Greater diversity may also be the solution if success is to come to Shoreline Star in Bridgeport. "We need some other form of gaming if we're going to succeed," said Steve Alford, the general manager of the dog track. "We'd like to get slot machines, but it doesn't look like that will happen."
Under a compact worked out between Lowell P. Weicker Jr., then the Governor, and the Mashantucket Pequots, who run the Foxwoods Casino, slot machines cannot be installed at any non-Indian gambling venue in Connecticut. In exchange, the state receives 25 percent of all slot revenues from Foxwoods and, since it opened last year, the Mohegan Sun Casino, too.
Situated alongside the now-vacant Bridgeport Jai Alai fronton, Shoreline Star suspended live racing last Dec. 1 after 13 months of activity. Racing is scheduled to resume on May 1, but, Mr. Alford said, that is contingent on the infusion of money from new investors. "There has been interest," Mr. Alford said, saying that Robert Zeff, the owner of Shoreline Star, has had talks with a number of prospective investors.
Though it is is a state-of-the-art dog racing center, the Bridgeport track drew poorly, averaging about 1,000 to a racing session. "We opened up on several wrong assumptions," said Mr. Alford, who had been the general manager of a dog track in Kansas City, Kansas, which went bankrupt because of competition from nearby riverboat gambling.
"We actually thought we'd be the most successful dog track in the country," Mr. Alford said, "and that traffic would be backed up for 15 miles on I-95 before race programs began. After all, we were going to be the only dog track in the New York metropolitan area and would have 16 million people to draw on. But business was soft at the start and relatively slow for the rest of the year. And the bad winter weather last year hurt us, too."
Of the three parimutuel installations where live competition is held, the Milford jai alai fronton, last of three built in the 70's that is still operating, seems to have fared best. "We had a major drop in attendance after Foxwoods opened, but business has gotten better," said Leonard Meyers, the owner.
Mr. Meyers said the Milford fronton generated $30 million in off track betting last year, of which $1 million was paid to the state in taxes. "O.T.B. accounts for about 40 percent of our business," he said. "And you have to take into account what we do for the local economy. We have about 300 employes and a $6 million payroll, and we're one of the town's top five taxpayers. We think the state should be proud of what we do and should boost us."
If anything, the state may make it even more difficult for the parimutuel installations to survive. Tax reductions may again be available from the legislature, but Gov. John G. Rowland has proposed that the tracks absorb the cost of urine testing, on which the state is paying about $700,000 a year.
Ms. Keelan and Mr. Alford each said that absorbing the urine testing costs would be very difficult. "No other state tests as much as Connecticut does," Ms. Keelan said. "Most other states which have dog racing test only the winner and the favorite if the favorite finishes out of the money."
Mr. Wandrak said he was opposed to any reduction in testing. "We test as extensively as we do to insure the integrity of every race," he said. "It also helps insure the health and welfare of the dogs."
But State Senator Alvin W. Penn, a Democrat from Bridgeport, said, "Maybe we can lower the amount spent by testing on a random basis. And we should look into the possibility of finding facilities that do the testing cheaper," he said. Currently, the urine testing is done at a chemistry laboratory at the University of Connecticut.
Senator Penn, who is a chairman of the General Assembly's Public Safety Committee, which concerns itself with legalized gambling, said he also thought that diversification might be the answer to resolving the plight of the two dog tracks.
And State Representative Moira K. Lyons of Stamford, who is the House Majority Leader, said, "At some point we have to look and see if it makes sense to continue subsidizing facilities that are not generating sufficient revenues.
"We want to be supportive," Ms. Lyons said, "but they're going to have to come back to us with some new concepts; they're going to have to be more creative."

HEADLINE: How the Board Game Got Its Spots

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
MONOPOLY is officially attributed to Charles Darrow, an unemployed Philadelphia heating contractor, although earlier versions of what has been called "the real estate game" date back to the late 19th century. Mr. Darrow's version, from 1929, was at first rejected when he offered to sell it to Parker Brothers. The Massachusetts game company thought the game was too long and had too many rules and no clear-cut finish.
The fact that it was based on Atlantic City streets, landmarks, railroads and utilities was not considered a strong selling point. The game was based on the city's boom in real estate speculation in the 1920's, when stone hotels like the St. Charles, the Ritz-Carlton and the Claridge began to replace the wooden ones in the Boardwalk area. Mr. Darrow was living nearby at the time. 
 When sales of game sets that Mr. Darrow manufactured began to pick up at Wanamaker's department store in Philadelphia, Parker Brothers decided to buy the game to take advantage of what was considered a fad. The company predicted that demand for the game would fade by around 1935.
It was wrong.
Monopoly made both Parker Brothers and Charles Darrow rich. He retired to travel the world and grow orchids. Parker Brothers, now owned by Hasbro in Pawtucket, R.I., hopes a total of 100 million Monopoly game sets will be sold by the year 2000.
When the first legal casino hotel opened in Atlantic City in 1978, Parker Brothers released an updated version of Monopoly that let players build casinos. Called Advance to Boardwalk, it never became popular. Nor is it likely that Parker Brothers' Monopoly CD-ROM version, released last year, will ever supplant the board game, which Hasbro says is currently the most popular 20th-century board game in the world. BILL KENT

HEADLINE: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;
Report Finds Clouds Over Children's Lives

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Social troubles that hurt the health and well-being of New Jersey children are seeping into the suburbs, the 1996 Kids Count report says.
Child abuse, poverty, juvenile crime and infant mortality still occur far more often in cities than in suburbs, and most aid programs continued to be directed at inner-city families. 
 But statistically, the largest jump in these social troubles occurred in the suburbs in the first half of the 1990's, according to the report, released last week by by the Association for Children of New Jersey.
The report is an annual snapshot of the well-being of New Jersey children. It examines 13 factors, including the number of children receiving food stamps and welfare, the number of teen-age deaths, the incidence of child abuse and juvenile crime, the number of babies born with low birth weight, infant mortality rates and other factors. It then compared the incidence of these social problems to previous years.
Overall, New Jersey continues to show scant progress in improving the well-being of its children, said Cecilia Zalkind, the associate director of the children's association. New Jersey again ranked 19th in the country on the national Kids Count report.
"We haven't dramatically worsened, and we haven't dramatically improved," Ms. Zalkind said. "It is as though we've accepted almost a permanent underclass of kids."
Six counties -- Somerset, Burlington, Cape May, Middlesex, Hunterdon and Sussex -- had increases of more than 20 percent in at least four of the factors surveyed. With a few exceptions, the comparisons are made from 1990 to 1995.
Bergen County had the largest increases in problems, with a 116 percent jump in the number of juveniles sent to institutions after committing crimes and a 44 percent rise in the number of child deaths.
Burlington County also hd significant increases, including a 33 percent jump in juvenile arrests and a 58 percent rise in family problems, a term used by the state Division of Youth and Family Services to describe parental problems that could lead to child abuse or neglect.
Affluent Somerset County had the largest increase -- 34 percent -- in the number of teen-agers who gave birth.
Ciro Scalera, executive director of the Association for Children of New Jersey, said that while the percentages had increased in the suburbs, the cities still housed many more children growing up in poverty and surrounded by severe social problems.
In Bergen County, for example, the number of children on welfare jumped 35 percent. But the actual number of Bergen County children receiving welfare is still low at 4,682 when compared to urban areas like Essex County, which has 51,291 children on welfare.
In 1996, 66 percent of children receiving welfare lived in five counties: Camden, Essex, Hudson, Passaic and Union.
Statewide, the number of children on welfare increased 1.7 percent from 1990 to the first part of 1996, the report said. But state Department of Human Services figures show that the number of children currently on welfare is down about 12 percent to 171,000. That reflects the general trend of declining welfare rolls.
The most disturbing statewide trend is the rise in the number of teen-agers placed in detention centers and other residential programs because they have committed crimes. From 1990 to 1995, the number of juveniles committed to institutions increased 14.5 percent, to 1,100 from 961.
There was some good news in the report.
In Newark, the number of teen-age deaths fell 51 percent, while infant mortality decreased 22 percent.
Camden had similar declines, with 6.3 percent fewer teen-agers killed during the period and a 32 percent decrease in infant mortality. Mr. Scalera attributed these declines to population changes in the cities, combined with the influence of some social programs.
Statewide infant mortality rate fell about 16 percent from 1990 to 1994, from 1,086 to 910.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Consolidating Realty Brokerages and Services;
Industry Experts Ponder the Rising Merger Trend

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THE consolidation trend now under way in New York's real estate brokerage and related services offices has some leading industry executives predicting that the business will wind up divided into two groups -- national, publicly traded companies and boutiques representing local clients in local transactions.
The latest wave got started last year when Insignia Financial Group acquired the Edward S. Gordon Company and set about using it as a vehicle to build a national commercial real estate operation. So far this year, the company has announced agreements to acquire the Rostenberg-Doern Company, which covers Westchester and Fairfield Counties, and Frain Camins & Swartchild in Chicago. 
 Two West Coast-based companies with operations in New York, CB Commercial and Koll Real Estate Services, have said they will combine, with CB Commercial acquiring Koll for $145 million in its stock.
The Galbreath Company's top New York official, Bruce E. Mosler, and a group of brokers associated with him have departed to join Cushman & Wakefield amid persistent reports that Galbreath is holding merger talks with the Chicago-based LaSalle Partners.
And there have been questions raised about the future of the area's largest real estate services company, Cushman & Wakefield, which is ultimately owned by a Japanese company, Mitsubishi Estate. Might Mitsubishi be interested in raising capital by selling a company some see as an odd fit in a company oriented toward property investments? The rumors, rejected by Cushman & Wakefield executives, are reflective of the changes taking place in the industry.
"I see more and more consolidation," said Raymond T. O'Keefe, president of Grubb & Ellis New York, the local office of the publicly traded company based in suburban Chicago. "Corporations want to deal with as few real estate companies as possible, so they are looking for the ones that can provide the broadest range of services."
As corporations shrink their headquarters staffs, Mr. O'keefe said, they are forced to rely on outside companies for consulting services. "They need to have someone to help them, evaluate their real estate needs," he said. "Should they own or lease? How to finance transactions? All this requires larger firms with a broad geographic spread."
There is a parallel between the growth in size of companies in other types of service industries and the consolidation of real estate companies, said Steven A. Swerdlow, executive vice president in charge of CB Commercial's New York metropolitan area operations.
"Back while I was still practicing law 15 years ago, I was with what was considered a medium-sized law firm," he said. "It had 50 lawyers. Now a medium-sized law firm has 200 lawyers. Over the last 15 years the advertising agencies have gotten huge. The stock brokerages have gotten bigger and fewer."
With real estate investment trusts supplanting family and corporate ownership of real estate, Mr. Swerdlow said, it is only natural for the real estate services companies to consolidate and look to capital markets for financing to speed growth.
Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate Company, said while it is possible for smaller independent real estate services companies to survive, there are strong forces driving consolidation.
He said Wall Street valued the earnings of a local real estate company at a lower multiple than a national or international operation, which made it difficult to tap financial markets.
He echoed Mr. O'Keefe in saying that national corporations often wanted to deal with one or two national real estate companies who could handle all their needs with a quality of service more even than dealing with multiple, locally managed companies.
SOME costs are fixed, he noted, so spreading them over a larger base of transactions or properties produces economies of scale. He added that consolidators had the opportunity to broaden the range of skills in their portfolios by acquiring firms with established specialties.
In spite of these factors, he said, consolidators have to be sure of what they are buying. "Some people are using this as an exit strategy," he said. "Most regional real estate brokerage companies are run on a superstar management philosophy that requires hands-on management. If those people leave, what have you bought -- desks?"
He said Williams "sees opportunities to ride this wave and we are exploring them," but he declined to offer further details.
Despite the economic pressures pushing toward consolidation, some top executives say the smaller companies will do nicely by emphasizing their detailed knowledge of local markets and customer wants. "I know what my customers want, I have intimacy with my customers," said Robert L. Billingsley, executive vice president of Colliers ABR, which has about 100 employees. "If I get a whole lot bigger, it gets harder to do customer intimacy."
He said smaller companies could make decisions quickly without waiting for permission from corporate boards in distant cities. And, he said, bigger companies are going to run into conflict-of-interest problems by seeking to represent companies that compete with each other.
"If I'm a landlord and one of these big agencies is representing a building across the street, I'm not going to want them to represent me as well," Mr. Billingsley said.
Julien J. Studley, the chairman of Julien J. Studley, Inc., said he was not inclined to increase the size of his company, which has about 250 professional employees in 10 markets across the country.
"The stated goal of companies like Gordon or CB is to make acquisitions," he said. "That is a basic part of their strategy. But I have questions about whether this is going to produce better real estate services."
He said growth by acquisition brought with it the problem of blending vastly different cultures in a business based on people and personal relationships. He noted Insignia's acquisition of the Frain Camins firm in Chicago and said "that firm has no resemblance to Gordon."
"These are not easy mergers," he said, "and it will be interesting to watch to see how it works out."
He said the great virtue of Insignia's acquisition of the Gordon company (for $74 million) was that it established a price for a service company.
"We get approached all the time," he said. "This way we got the valuation without having to do the transaction." He said his employee-owned company was about the same size as the Gordon company before the takeover and subsequent acquisitions.
Some executives argue that outright acquisitions are better than trying to operate nationally through loose alliances and networks.
"IF you have one company, you do business one way," said Mr. O'Keefe, who worked for Cushman & Wakefield and Gordon before joining Grubb & Ellis last year. "The reports will be the same, the analysis of the market will be the same. When you are dealing with employees, you simply have more leverage than if you are working for a network."
Arthur M. Mirante, the president and chief executive of Cushman & Wakefield, said there was no basis to rumors that the company's Japanese parent might be putting it on the block.
"Mitsubishi Estate is a real estate company -- probably the biggest in the world," Mr. Mirante said. "So their ownership of us makes sense. They are real estate guys; that's their only business and they will own us for a long time."
Mitsubishi Estate is the 100 percent owner of the Rockefeller Group, which owns four office towers on the west side of Sixth Avenue facing Rockefeller Center. In addition, the company owns a cleared building site on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets known as "Rock West" and 80 percent of Cushman & Wakefield. The rest is owned by employees.
Mr. Mirante said the parent company was encouraging Cushman & Wakefield to participate in the market.
"We are in the market for acquisitions and have four or five deals under way," he said. In addition to acquiring Mr. Mosler and his group, he said the company had taken over a company called Metropolitan Structure, which had been the development arm of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steven A. Swerdlow of CB Commercial says it is only natural for real estate services concerns to consolidate and seek capital to speed growth. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Frustrated, but Standing Pat

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
PLENTY of investors with carefully constructed portfolios are frustrated by the fact that a single index fund would have provided better returns over the last couple of years.
Even in the tumultuous first quarter, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index continued to be the stock pace-setter. Only 274, about 1 of every 10, diversified domestic equity funds beat the benchmark in the period. Last year, 523 of those funds outpaced the S.& P. index. 
 Among the 64 funds that track the index, the average gain in the first quarter was 2.52 percent, versus an average loss of 1.98 percent for diversified domestic funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services, the fund trackers in Summit, N.J.
 With that kind of showing, it can be tempting to just throw all your money into a big index fund.
But take heed: the five professional money managers who have created hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times are equally frustrated and still holding firm to their diversified approach.
"When the market goes straight up, diversification seems like a dumb strategy," conceded Harold Evensky, an investment adviser in Coral Gables, Fla., whose portfolio gained a scant 0.63 percent last quarter. "Stock investing is 'safe,' bonds are 'dumb,' high-yield bonds are a terrific investment, taxi drivers and other gurus are brilliant, and there is no down -- only up."
When such thinking dominates, a diversified portfolio may be hard to live with in the short run. But, Mr. Evensky added, "Like a house of bricks that's harder to build than a house of sticks, it lasts much better in the long run."
JOHN REKENTHALER, publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago, says the stocks in the S.& P. 500 have already had such a huge run-up that the best opportunities can be found elsewhere.
"Sentiment for the index is as high as it's going to get," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "I expect the next bull market to resemble 1991 to 1993, when smaller stocks and, to a lesser extent, international companies benefited as investors rotated their moneys from safe United States blue chips into other investments."
In the meantime, he is pleased with his portfolio, which rose 0.40 percent for the quarter. "The international funds were above average for their ilk; Skyline Special and Third Avenue Value easily beat the Russell and even Fidelity Export, my weakest performer, fared well for a fund laden with technology."
Mr. Rekenthaler is following Arieh Coll, the recently departed manager of Fidelity Export. He is selling his 10 percent stake in Export and using the proceeds to buy shares in Fidelity Trend, Mr. Coll's new fund.
Because Mr. Rekenthaler believes that the S.& P. 500 companies are in for a hard time soon, he is also moving 5 percent of his assets, now in the Fidelity Fund, to Ivy International. That leaves him with just 15 percent of his portfolio in the Fidelity Fund, his sole United States blue-chip investment.
Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor, in Irvington, N.Y., retains the overall lead among the five managers, with a gain of 82 percent since the contest began more than three years ago, on July 7, 1993. The portfolios have risen an average of 61 percent, compared with an 87 percent total return for the Vanguard Index 500 fund, which mimics the S.& P. 500.
THREE of the five portfolios made money in the second quarter. And in a tribute to their broad diversification and their international components, all did better than the average for domestic diversified stock funds.
The portfolio performance, tracked each quarter by Lipper, excludes sales charges, transaction costs and tax considerations, because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any fund open to new investors and can shift money quarterly, although the portfolios were intended to grow for 20 years.
The leader for the quarter was Mr. Jacobs, with a gain of 3.40 percent. After toning down the risk in his portfolio in December, saying he expected a bear market during the next 12 months, he is sitting tight now.
In fourth place for the quarter, with a loss of 0.28 percent, was Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who created a "socially responsible" fund portfolio. "I continue to believe that a long-term retirement fund for the next 15 to 20 years should be 90 percent in stocks and 10 percent in bonds," he said. "My choices in stock funds continue to be basically conservative, with diversification in global, aggressive and small-cap funds."
But Mr. Brill is making several changes. He is dropping Calvert Social Investment Managed Growth, because of its disappointing performance, and using most of the proceeds to buy shares in MMA Praxis Growth, a growth and income fund from the Mennonite Mutual Aid family, which looks for stocks that promote peace, justice, stewardship and health. He says the MMA manager uses relative value to select stocks, aiming for long-term growth and modest income.
Mr. Brill is adding the Parnassus Fund because of recent changes made by the fund's manager, including his decision to look more closely at how companies manage their growth and to give them less time to perform. Also new is the Vanguard Fixed-Income GNMA fund, creating a 10 percent position in bonds. Though the Vanguard fund is not formally dedicated to socially responsible issues, Mr. Brill noted that its Ginnie Mae bonds were backed by mortgages for middle-income and subsidized low-income housing.
In last place for the quarter, with a loss of 0.41 percent, was Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management and the editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent newsletter in Wellesley, Mass. Mr. Kobren's portfolio was hurt by a 10 percent stake in Fidelity Pacific Basin, which lost 6.80 percent in the period.
He is dropping that fund, which is more than 50 percent invested in Japan, out of concern that Japan's economic recovery will be further delayed by an increase in the country's consumption tax. He is splitting the proceeds equally between Fidelity Real Estate and Contrafund.
Over all, Mr. Kobren says that "while I'm far from being bearish on stocks, I strongly believe that being cautious (i.e., defensive) will, in the longer run, prove beneficial to growth-oriented investors."

SECTION: Section 13; Page 4; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Jinx? What Jinx?

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
DAVID PAGE sounded confident, but maybe a little nervous as well. He and his wife, Barbara Shinn, who own Home, at 20 Cornelia Street, were preparing to open their second restaurant, Drover's Tap Room, at 9 Jones Street. They had completely reconstructed the dining room, they had lovingly oiled the bar, and Mr. Page had even prepared beef jerky and pickled eggs as special snacks for the opening night party last Tuesday.
But there was one nagging thought, one potential fly in the soup. In the last four years, four restaurants had failed at 9 Jones Street. First was Sandolino, an old Village institution that opened there briefly after moving from its longtime location nearby. Then came Caffe Florence, an Italian restaurant. Despite good reviews, it went out of business. Then came two incarnations of a restaurant called 9 Jones. It, too, got good reviews. It, too, closed, twice. Could 9 Jones Street be a jinxed address, one of those legendarily cursed sites where restaurants simply cannot succeed? 
 "I'm a believer in spaces that are jinxed, and it scares the heck out of me," said Mr. Page, whose restaurants elaborate on the Middle American cooking he remembers from his childhood in Berlin, Wis. He paused a moment. "I don't think there's a chance that this place is jinxed, though."
Like alligators in the sewers or cats exploding in microwaves, the jinxed restaurant location is an urban myth. When a series of restaurants fail at a particular site for seemingly inexplicable reasons, the "jinx" is invariably trotted out by those who prefer the supernatural to more earthbound explanations like "undercapitalization" or "traffic flow." Mr. Page himself is a practical businessman as well as a chef. Still, he expresses concern about a colleague, John Schenk, who is opening a restaurant at another legendarily cursed address, One Fifth Avenue. "If Alfred Portale can't create a success there," he said, "that closes the book for me."
Mr. Portale, the acclaimed chef at Gotham Bar and Grill, and Jerome Kretchmer, the primary investor, were not able to make a go of a seafood restaurant there and closed it in June 1994 after a year and a half of struggling. A successor with different owners, Vince and Linda's at One Fifth, didn't fare any better.
"I don't believe in hexes or jinxes," said Mr. Schenk, who hopes his new restaurant, Clementine, will open in late April. "It has everything to do with timing, product and execution."
Mr. Portale hedges on whether One Fifth's failure was entirely rational. "It wasn't a good location for us," he said. "I'm not superstitious, but I used to feel there was a certain energy or aura about that space. There may be ghosts there." Mr. Portale does have his own rules for predicting success or failure. "If you have to go up a flight or down a flight, the restaurant's not going to work," he said. "Traffic flow: people are fanatic about which way the traffic flows on the street. They'll travel across Fifth to Park for lunch, but they won't head west."
Mr. Portale's rules would explain why the restaurant site at 525 Broome Street near the Avenue of the Americas is considered jinxed. Not only is it a flight down from the street, but traffic flows west on Broome. In rapid succession, three restaurants -- Vix Cafe, Tasco do Porto and La Taverne -- have failed there, but does Philippe Lajaunie, co-owner of the last two restaurants, feel there's a curse? Au contraire. He attributes the failures to a lack of organization and supervision. The address itself, promises Mr. Lajaunie, who is in the process of selling the site, is just fine.
Real-estate transactions, of course, could be harmed if a site was thought to be jinxed. So it's not surprising that a broker has a ready rationale for a failed restaurant. "What appears to be jinxed is a place that doesn't fit into a defined market," said Warren Newcorn, executive vice president of Winick Realty Group, which specializes in retail leasing. He cited the Times Square area, where the rule used to be that a restaurant had to be west of Broadway to succeed. "But Artie Cutler, when he did Virgil's, proved you could succeed east of Broadway," Mr. Newcorn said of Virgil's Real BBQ on 44th Street. "Perceptions change, and boundaries move."
It has taken a long time for perceptions to change about 142 West 10th Street, where eight restaurants had failed since 1981 before Scott Bryan and Gino Diaferia opened Indigo in the fall of 1995. "We said, 'We heard it was jinxed,' but we took a chance on it," said Mr. Bryan, who is also the chef at Luma in Chelsea. "We didn't put in a ton of money, so we thought, why not?"
So far, Indigo has succeeded, both critically and commercially. It's been a much different experience for Mr. Bryan than for Diane Forley, who was the chef in one of the failed incarnations, Oggi Domani.
"It's one of those unexplained New York phenomenons," Ms. Forley said. "Some people have theories about walking east or west and I think that that had something to do with it."
Ms. Forley, who said she believes locations really can be jinxed, is doing much better now as the chef and owner of Verbena on Irving Place. "Knock wood," she said.
Anne Rosenzweig, who owns Arcadia and the Lobster Club on the Upper East Side, not only believes in jinxed locations but also seeks them out. "Both my restaurants were jinxed," she said. "People think of me as the jinxed-space person." Ms. Rosenzweig is attracted by the challenge of succeeding where others have failed. "It's like real estate," she said. "If you look at an apartment in horrible condition, you imagine what it could be."
Drover's Tap Room has been open almost a week, and Mr. Page is optimistic. The restaurant's been busier than expected, and things have gone smoother than he'd hoped. He chalks it up to his secret weapon: opening on April Fool's Day. "If you believe in jinxes," he said, "you also have to believe in sneaking past them through the back door."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Drover's Tap Room, top, and Indigo, above, have so far succeeded in hard-luck sites. (Photographs by Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

Recalling that Casey's, a posh restaurant, had been successful there in the late 1960's, he had high hopes. Here are the nine restaurants that have been there since, the approximate years they were open, with Mr. Desmond's comments.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Proposed Greenmarket Site Ruffles Co-op Feathers

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
By all accounts, the Greenmarket on West 70th Street was a good idea that never really took off. Tucked in front of Public School 199 between Amsterdam and West End Avenues, it never caught the attention of the pedestrians who pack the busier avenues.
In four years, this lack of visibility has forced farmers to reduce their supplies from truckful to trunkful. Even then, many still had to lug home excess produce. This year, only one of the original six farmers has signed on to return for the coming season, which begins in June. This lack of enthusiasm has prompted the market's operator to threaten to shut down if it is not moved to a more visible spot. 
 "It's not economically feasible to keep the market open," said Tony Mannetta, the assistant director of Greenmarket, a nonprofit organization that runs the markets throughout the city. "We operate farmers' market, not a farmer market."
Mr. Mannetta and supporters of the market say an ideal spot would be half a block east, on Amsterdam Avenue, where the wide sidewalks and high visibility would draw more customers. But that effort is fiercely opposed from residents of One Sherman Square at 201 West 70th Street, a luxury co-op directly behind the proposed site.
They said such a move would worsen congestion on the already crowded avenue, draw outsiders into the neighborhood, deter merchants from leasing the commercial spaces in the building, bring competition to the neighborhood's struggling grocers and reduce property values in the building.
"I believe Greenmarkets are a wonderful thing, but I don't think they should be placed in the main thoroughfare," said Debbie Stevens, a co-op resident. "I don't want it to become a regular street fair."
Community Board 7, on whose approval the move depends, is evenly divided, with 16 members voting for the proposed site and 16 opposed, with 1 abstention.
To end the impasse, Debra Asher, an aide to Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, proposed last Thursday that the Greenmarket be temporarily moved to an open triangular area on the east side of Broadway between 72d and 73d Streets.
Diane Bradtcher, chairwoman of Community Board 7, said the board would discuss the new proposal soon. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUNDVIEW;
A Slow Climb From the Ashes

BYLINE: By ANDREA K. WALKER 

 BODY:
Zheng Shou Ping smelled the smoke as he slept with his family in the basement of his Chinese restaurant. Joy K. Chwe got a call from the alarm company in the early hours of the morning. And Lance Bernardine first learned of last month's devastating fire in Soundview from a morning newscast.
The blaze all but destroyed the 10,000-square-foot building on Westchester Avenue where they and seven other merchants rented space. By daybreak all that remained of the small businesses they had painstakingly built was ashes. Last week the faint smell of smoke still lingered in the air. The building's blackened skeleton sat where there had been thriving businesses, a painful reminder of the ruinous night. 
 Many of the merchants, like Mr. Ping, who lost his eight-month-old business, the Wo Hop Chinese restaurant, had no fire insurance. They are struggling to rebuild their businesses. Mr. Ping wonders if he will ever open another restaurant, but the city's housing agency helped find an apartment for him and his family.
Dwight Williams, a spokesman for the Mayor's office, said two of the merchants had applied for the $50,000 in low-interest city loans and five for the $1,000 emergency grants. The city and the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation offered to help the merchants find new locations. But Kevin Nunn, president of the development corporation, said only one business, Titehead Unisex Barber, had asked for help in relocating.
Mr. Bernardine, one of four barbers who ran Titehead, said he and his partners were looking for other work, but were eager to move back to their old location where they had a strong customer base. They were reluctant to borrow money for a temporary location. "We don't feel like having to pay a loan back," he said. Ms. Chwe, the owner of Juno, a shoe store specializing in designer sneakers and boots, is in a better position than the other merchants. She is already at work on renovations on a building across the street from her old location. Using money from fire insurance and emergency grants and loans from the city, Ms. Chwe signed a one-year lease at the new location but hopes to move back to the previous site. "It's going to take more than a year to rebuild," she said, "but I'm going to move back. I've been here for more than 17 years and I want to stay."
Michael Vecchi, the city's Chief Fire Marshal, said that the cause of the fire was still under investigation, but it appeared to have been accidental. ANDREA K. WALKER

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Want the Fast Lane? Try Russia

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
TALK about a new world order. Russia is the undisputed leader, and Japan is in the cellar.
Such is the state of affairs in the worldwide market for stocks. The newest emerging markets, with all their volatility, are enjoying a burst of growth, while established markets are generally languishing -- at least for anyone buying in dollars. 
 "Investors are finding the highest returns from countries which are just on the cusp of moving from an economically repressed regime to an economically reforming or free regime," said Bryan Johnson, co-editor of the 1997 Index of Economic Freedom, published by the Heritage Foundation and The Wall Street Journal.
Probably no one knows that better than Arpad Pongracz, manager of the Vontobel Eastern European Equity fund. He has chalked up the best performance for the last four quarters among international stock funds, with a gain of 59.6 percent, by investing in the former Soviet bloc.
 "I consider these countries more capitalistic than many Western European countries today," said Mr. Pongracz, who was born in Hungary and lives in Switzerland. Companies in European nations like Italy and Germany rely more on bank loans than on stock issuance for financing, he said. By his reasoning, regions whose companies issue stock to raise capital are more capitalistic.
The stock market capitalization of the Czech Republic represents about 32 percent of the gross domestic product there, versus 28 percent in Germany, Mr. Pongracz said. (By comparison, capitalization exceeds 100 percent of the G.D.P. in the United States.) The percentages are far lower in Hungary, Poland and Russia than in the Czech Republic, he said, but they are moving in that direction.
In fact, Russia was one of the most profitable places to invest in the first quarter of 1997 as it was in 1996. The other profit centers were in what used to be called the third world: Hungary and the rest of Eastern Europe, the Mideast and parts of Africa and almost the whole of Latin America. Among emerging markets, only those in Asia have been dragging their heels so far this year.
The Morgan Stanley Capital International indexes for emerging markets in Latin America, Europe and the Middle East each rose more than 17 percent in the first quarter, led by Russia, with a 48 percent gain; Turkey, with 42 percent, and Brazil and Hungary, at 24 percent each. Emerging markets in the Far East, meanwhile, gained less than 2 percent.
Among funds that invest in a variety of emerging markets, the best performances of the last quarter were recorded by Glenmede Emerging Markets and Federated Emerging Markets, each of which gained nearly 14 percent. The Federated fund is also a leader for the 12 months, posting a total return of more than 31 percent.
As surely as emerging markets dominated the international arena in the first quarter, Japan was crushed. Owing to the failure of the Japanese Government to revive the nation's flagging economy and to the continuing decline of the yen against the dollar, many funds with Japan in their names -- including DFA Japanese Small Company and Fidelity Japan Small Companies -- racked up double-digit losses.
Europe rallied, meanwhile, but the dollar's strength slashed net returns to American investors by nearly two-thirds. The Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Index jumped 11.6 percent in local currencies, but only 4.4 percent in dollar terms.
Now that the American stock market is swooning, interest in foreign markets is bound to increase. And the spotlight is shining on the hot emerging markets, despite the considerable risk.
"The outlook for emerging markets, not including Asia, is very good," said J. Mark Mobius, who is based in Hong Kong and manages several open- and closed-end funds for the Templeton Franklin Group.
AT the Vontobel Eastern European Equity fund, which has $160 million in assets, investors gained more than 16 percent in the quarter, thanks to Mr. Pongracz's heavy weighting in Russia and Hungary. The two countries still account for more than 55 percent of the fund's assets, but that portion is shrinking. The manager is adding to his stake in Poland, and is taking some profits in Hungary. On Russia, he remains a raging bull.
"Russia continues to offer the largest array of strongly undervalued securities -- companies of practically global significance as far as their strategic position is concerned in various mineral resources, such as oil, natural gas, nickel and copper," he said. "I wouldn't be surprised if this market doesn't double again over the next two years."
He is not the only money manager who finds capitalism thriving in unfamiliar places. Grace Pineda, who runs Merrill Lynch & Company's Latin America portfolio as well as the company's Middle East/Africa fund, says she is looking for companies that are restructuring in these regions. The latter fund has two-thirds of its assets in Egypt, Israel and South Africa. "These are frontier markets," Ms. Pineda said. "The idea is to go to countries that are putting through the kinds of reforms that have been successful in other emerging markets."
That theme is echoed by Robert Meyer, manager of Morgan Stanley Latin America, a $60 million fund that had a gain of more than 47 percent in the last 12 months.
The recent advances in Brazil, Argentina and Mexico are "not a bubble," he said. "We're seeing government step out of the economy, the end to what for most of this century has been a very heavy dose of government regulation, intervention and ownership.
"This is a long-term process where restructuring is unleashing efficiencies and earnings growth, and that's what drives stock prices up."
In Asia the story is quite different. Taiwan has been rallying for more than a year, in large part because interest rates are at their lowest level in a decade and are stimulating the economy. But Singapore and Korea, both major suppliers of components for personal computers, are suffering because of weakness in high technology.
Geoffrey Wong, chief investment officer of Koeneman Capital Management, which is based in Singapore, said that valuations are relatively high on Chinese and Hong Kong stocks, which rallied last year. The rest of the region looks even less attractive, he said.
Mark Bickford-Smith, co-manager of the $2.2 billion T. Rowe Price New Asia fund, said a shift in foreign growth has begun.
"Even though Asia is still growing significantly faster than Latin America, it is the changes at the margin which are significant," he said. "In both Eastern Europe and Latin America you are seeing an improvement in the relative momentum of economic growth."
Of course, Latin America and Eastern Europe have emerged from obscurity only recently, and they might easily slip back. And the high returns in the regions come with considerable risk, including the risk that political coalitions will collapse and economic growth will sputter.
A note of warning was sounded by Barton Biggs, the global investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. "The Japanese economy is far from perfect," he said, "but it's in a lot better shape than the Russian economy."

His fund, the leader in the international stock category for the 12 months ended March 31, with a gain of 59.61 percent, had allocated stocks as follows at the end of the year.
 
Hungary 36.6%

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A 401(k) With One Big Gun Is One Big Risk

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
STEER clear of shareholders in Mercury Finance, a car-loan company. They may be grouchy, and with good reason: In late January, Mercury disclosed that its earnings had been overstated by more than $90 million over the last four years. So in the quarter just ended, the stock wound up as the Big Board's biggest dud, down a whopping 78 percent.
The grouchiest of these shareholders may be none other than Mercury Finance's own employees. Of a total of about 1,900 workers, nearly 900 are enrolled in the company's 401(k) plan. And according to plan data for 1994, nearly two-thirds of the plan's assets were invested in Mercury Finance's own plummeting stock, which finished last year at $12.25 a share but closed on Friday at just $2.25. 
 (More recent data on the plan will not be available from the Labor Department until next month or later.)
In the wake of the January disclosure, the company, which is based in Lake Forest, Ill., and operates out of more than 275 offices in 31 states, has replaced top executives and scrambled for credit, and it is facing more than 50 shareholder lawsuits. These dark times are a far cry from the days when the inclusion of company stock in the 401(k) plan was met with worker enthusiasm.
"It was a wonderful thing," said Michael P. Harrington, former president of Mercury Finance and now chairman of the First Enterprise Financial Group in Evanston, Ill. "We were quite excited about the company's prospects."
Company loyalty was not the only reason for the smiles. Mercury has had great success in selling car loans to people with blemished credit ratings, and investors knew it. "The stock was doing quite well," said Walter Vonch, a senior manager who left the company in 1995 and now works in Phoenix. Indeed, the stock was up 53 percent that year alone.
But now the enthusiasm has turned to fear that the Mercury Finance situation may turn into an object lesson in overreliance on one stock. "I feel very badly for the employees," Mr. Harrington said. "I'm sure there are a number of employees who've been hurt with their retirement funds."
At the end of 1994, the Mercury Finance 401(k) plan had nearly $3.85 million in the company stock option. With the plan's total value then at about $5.88 million, the option accounted for 65.5 percent of assets. In 1993, Mercury stock accounted for even more: 69 percent of the plan.
Joseph Kopec, a company spokesman, said the 401(k) plan was valued at $10.5 million at the end of 1996. "I can't tell you the value now," he said, but if company stock accounted for 65.5 percent of the total then, as it did in 1994, the stock's drop through Friday would mean the plan's value had shrunk to just $4.9 million or so.
And if an employee of Mercury Finance had, say, a $10,000 401(k) portfolio that mimicked the plan's 1994 allocations, the stock's fall would have caused the portfolio to shrivel to just $4,653.
ONE reason for the great dependence on one stock may be the small number of investment options in the plan, which is administered by the company. Besides Mercury stock, workers were offered just one other equity option, a diversified growth fund. The only other active options were a money market fund and a guaranteed income contract.
In 1994, about $68,000 of plan money was in a fund, now closed to participants, consisting of stock in the Banc One Corporation, which is now the plan trustee. The plan's assets also included $80,000 in a participant-loan fund.
At the end of 1994, besides the 65.5 percent in Mercury stock, the plan assets were divided as follows: 18 percent in the guaranteed investment contract, 8.5 percent in the equity fund and 5.5 percent in the money market fund. Plan loans and the Banc One stock represented just 2.5 percent of plan assets.
Magnifying the reliance on the company's stock, most Mercury Finance employees do not have a traditional pension plan to fall back on. The company offers a pension, but because of length-of-service requirements, only eight employees qualify for it, Mr. Kopec said.
Of course, even if the 401(k) options are few, there are options. And plan participants themselves chose how to divide their contributions to the plan. "It was up to individuals how they wanted to make their investments," Mr. Kopec said.
Whatever the cause, the bottom line is that betting mostly on one stock is perilous. "I support employee ownership of stock, but having an exclusive retirement vehicle with more than 50 percent of the assets in one security is just too risky," said Douglas L. Kruse, an economist at Rutgers University who studies 401(k) plans.
The employees of Mercury Finance have other things to fret about -- like the future of their company. Now in default on $500 million in long-term debt and about $400 million in short- and intermediate-term debt, the company is operating on a $50 million short-term loan arranged by the Bank of America. The loan is due on June 10.
Opinions differ on the company's prospects. "I think the cards are stacked against them," said Thomas Kmiotek, a debt analyst at the Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Company, which recently downgraded the company's debt to indicate the defaults on payments. "History shows that these situations get so difficult that the only way to satisfy everyone is to pack it up and liquidate."
But Mr. Kopec said the company was "guardedly optimistic." He said that the Bank of America loan had provided Mercury Finance with "breathing room" and that the company was making progress raising cash as a result of a recent agreement to sell its insurance subsidiary for $72 million.
THE Labor Department, which is responsible for overseeing retirement plans, declined to comment on whether it was investigating the Mercury Finance situation.
"Obviously, it's of concern to us," said Alan D. Lebowitz, a deputy assistant secretary at the agency's Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration. But under Federal rules, he said, there is nothing wrong with heavy reliance on company stock in 401(k) or other defined-contribution plans. "Unless you find abuse, these kinds of plans are perfectly lawful," he said.
That's the problem, said Michael S. Gordon, an employee-benefits lawyer in Washington.
"There's nothing in current law that really provides adequate protection to employees in these situations," Mr. Gordon said. "The question is how many times this has to happen before something is done."
