HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Blue-Collar Workers, and Hands-On Investors

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
ARRY YOUNG watches the stock market like a hawk. He logs onto the Internet almost every day, taps a few keys and pulls up his stock portfolio. That is, if he's not tuning into CNBC for the financial news.
Kevin Rynn is not much different. He got into the market in the late 1980's, and since then he has been perusing annual reports and leafing through the business sections of newspapers. He has owned a variety of stocks and mutual funds and is "very big on" learning more about those risky bets, sector funds.
You have probably heard such stories before. The two men in question are probably business executives, right?
Wrong. They are blue-collar workers. Mr. Young, 56, drives a forklift truck for the Mead Corporation, the forest products company in Dayton, Ohio. Mr. Rynn, 39, is a carpenter for Nastasi & Associates, a construction firm in Garden City, L.I.
Whether the notion that blue-collar workers are seldom active investors was ever true, it seems to be less true now.
According to Federal Reserve statistics, the nonretirement investments of skilled blue-collar workers have grown faster than those of most other workers, at least in percentage terms. In 1992, the median value of the stocks owned by these workers' families was $4,000; for mutual funds, it was $5,100. By 1995, these sums had risen to $4,800 and $10,000 -- increases of 20 percent and 96 percent, respectively.
But many of the most active blue-collar investors are hardly newcomers. "I got into the market in February 1990," said Mr. Young, who, with his wife, Flip, has retirement or nonretirement investments in 13 mutual funds and a handful of individual companies. "My brother was really big in the stock market, and then my wife was kind of encouraging me."
Mr. Young, who lives in Chillicothe, Ohio, about 60 miles south of Columbus, grew up in a family with eight children and a father who, remembering the Depression, always stressed the need to save. "My father said the first thousand you save will be the hardest," Mr. Young recalled.
The Youngs are well past that point now. They invest about 16 percent of their pay -- Mrs. Young is a data base manager at Lockheed Martin -- in their respective 401(k) plans. They also funnel $300 a month each into various mutual funds. Although they would not reveal the size of their portfolio, they said that their account at the Vanguard Windsor fund, their largest, was worth about $60,000, and that their overall holdings have had average annual returns of 10 percent since 1991.
Besides Windsor, their mutual funds focus primarily on equities, from the T. Rowe Price European fund to Janus Mercury, a domestic mid-cap growth fund. Their individual stocks include Mead, Lockheed Martin and Borland International.
Being active investors, however, does not guarantee success. This year, the Youngs invested in bank stocks through the Invesco Strategic Financial Services fund, but after early gains, the shares "nose-dived," Mr. Young said. "That's what happens with a sector fund," he said. "You can make lots of money fast, and you can lose lots."
But Mr. Young is already sizing up his next profit opportunity. "I think tech stocks are going to be the thing to jump in with because they've been beaten down," he said.
And he is optimistic about the market, both because he thinks the economy is sound and because he remembers what happened last year.
He missed out on a "ton of money" in 1996, he said, after Elaine Garzarelli, the market guru renowned for forecasting the 1987 crash, predicted last July that the market was about to sink again.
The market had already fallen some when Ms. Garzarelli, who runs the investment firm Garzarelli Capital, made her announcement. So on July 25 -- a date the Youngs will not soon forget -- the couple cashed in most of their holdings.
Right then, of course, the market rocketed higher and continued to do so for months. As a result, "I didn't do so good in 1996," gaining just 5 percent, Mr. Young said.
But in early January, the Youngs re-entered the market, choosing many of the same investments they had abandoned earlier. While Mr. Young says he is "greatly concerned" about the market's recent faltering, he is taking a buy-and-hold approach now.
"You don't have any choice but to ride it out," he said.
That is not the strategy chosen by Mr. Rynn, who years ago gave up his outdoor hobbies for the world of investing.
Like Mr. Young, though, Mr. Rynn is no novice. "I opened up a brokerage account with Charles Schwab in '89 or '90," Mr. Rynn said. "I went from fishing magazines to finance magazines."
When he began, he said, he did not know anything about Wall Street. He thought Morgan Stanley was a pitcher for the Boston Red Sox. (That was Bob Stanley.)
But now Mr. Rynn, who has both retirement and nonretirement investments, is more experienced. He would not reveal the size of his portfolio, but his nonretirement assets range from shares in PBHG Emerging Growth, a small-cap fund, and in Janus Worldwide, a global fund, to stock in health care companies like Abbott Laboratories and American Home Products.
As this equity-heavy portfolio suggests, Mr. Rynn does not flee from risk. "With stock, it's more risky, but it's more rewarding," he said.
In February, though, Mr. Rynn, who is married and has two children, sensed that clouds were gathering when the market became volatile and technology stocks fell. So, a month ago, he cashed in all his domestic holdings.
"Right now a lot of my money is in a money market account, positioned to be moved. But waiting," Mr. Rynn said.
He is pleased that the last two weeks have proved him right, but he is still optimistic about the market. "I don't know if it is going to go further south," he said.
The recent market fall has an ironic cast for Jack Keleher, 54, a packaging-machine mechanic at Cambridge Brands in Cambridge, Mass., a division of Tootsie Roll Industries. Mr. Keleher said he gave up horse race-track gambling about a decade ago for something a little less risky.
"I wasn't a degenerate gambler," he said. "I just liked the challenge of trying to figure things out. My idea of enjoyment was getting up Saturday morning and crunching the numbers in The Daily Racing Form."
Mr. Keleher and his wife, Peg, have about $150,000 in 401(k) accounts and other retirement assets. As for nonretirement money, since 1989 they have been putting $30 to $50 a month into the market through an investment club that they formed with some relatives. Meeting once a month, the club is active but lacks rigid rules.
"If my sister doesn't do an assignment, I can't tell her to take a hike," he said.
The club, whose holdings total about $36,000, favors large, established companies like Conagra and Texaco.
"We like stocks that have a history," Mr. Keleher explained. "I'm not that smart to be on the cutting edge, but I look at a company and if the dividends and the sales are going up and it's been around 10 years, I've got a good shot at making money." As for the recent market downturn, he is not bailing out. "We're not market timers," he said.
This conservativeness stems partly from his concern about fulfilling family obligations. "We shouldn't get too speculative," said Mr. Keleher, who has three grown children and a 16-year-old.
His co-workers are impressed by Mr. Keleher, who reads Investor's Business Daily and turns on CNBC soon after waking at 7 A.M. Or, at least, they used to be.
"They're sick and tired of it," Mrs. Keleher said. "They say, 'Don't mention investing around Jack because he can go for three or four hours.' "

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2246 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Mutual Fund Lesson: How It Feels to Lose

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
FOR millions of mutual fund shareholders, the first quarter of 1997 was like no other. They lost money.
Not since the fourth quarter of 1994 had mutual funds that invest in stocks and those that buy bonds lost money in the same quarter. In the ensuing two years, the number of Americans who own shares in mutual funds has grown by a third, to 63 million. That means millions of neophyte fund investors have never experienced a bear market, nor had they ever, until this year, suffered a quarter in which the value of both their stock and bond funds declined. 
 In the first three months of 1997, the average domestic stock fund lost 1.7 percent of its value, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company in Chicago, while the average bond fund dropped 0.3 percent.
And since the end of the first quarter, things have grown worse. The Dow Jones industrial average fell in three of the five sessions last week, and long-term interest rates climbed to their highest levels in six months. In the coming months, mutual fund investors will play a big role in determining the health and direction of the financial markets.
Signs of nervousness are starting to appear. AMG Data Services, a company in Arcata, Calif., that tracks cash flows, reported on Friday that equity mutual funds suffered a net outflow of $328 million in the week ended on Wednesday. Funds that invest primarily in growth stocks -- that is, shares of companies with rapidly growing earnings -- lost nearly $1 billion, the third consecutive week of outflows for that category.
On Wall Street, however, plenty of people remain convinced that mutual fund holders will stand fast even through a stock market correction of 10 percent to 20 percent and that cash flows to mutual funds will continue to support stock and bond prices.
"The global economic situation couldn't be brighter for long-term holders of financial assets," said John Cleland, chief investment strategist at the Security Benefit Group, a Topeka, Kan., investment company that oversees $2 billion in fund assets. Because so many mutual fund shareholders are investing through retirement plans, they are focused on long-term goals, and therefore "cash flows are not going to dry up, and they are not going to reverse," Mr. Cleland said.
CERTAINLY, there were some bright spots in the most recent quarter. International stock and bond funds, particularly those that invest in emerging markets, held up well. The average international stock fund gained 2 percent, and funds investing in Eastern Europe and Latin America were the strongest in the equity sector. On the bond side, funds investing in high-yield, or junk, bonds also reported gains for the quarter.
But for many stock fund investors, the pain in the first quarter was even worse than the averages suggest. Small-cap growth funds, the group that logged the best performance for most of the last two years, declined 12.5 percent on average. According to Morningstar, a dozen diversified stock funds lost more than 20 percent each.
As fund companies begin to send out their quarterly performance reports to investors, shareholders in many of the hottest funds of the last two years will find that their investments have lost money -- and not just over the most recent quarter.
Take the Stein Roe Capital Opportunities fund, which soared 51 percent in 1995. That red-hot performance attracted more than $1 billion in new money last year, and the fund continued to perform strongly, with a return of 20 percent. In the most recent quarter, however, the fund lost 18 percent of its value, leaving just about anyone who invested since the end of 1995 in the red.
Similarly, the Twentieth Century Vista fund, part of the fund family now known as American Century, wowed investors in 1995 and 1996 as it gained an average of 25 percent a year and its assets nearly tripled, to $2.2 billion. But in the first quarter of 1997, the fund lost 18.9 percent of its value, wiping out nearly all of its profits back to June 1995. Anyone who has invested since June 1995 has, at best, broken even -- and more likely lost money.
Investors who bought shares of the T. Rowe Price Science and Technology fund after September 1995, when the fund was one-third its current size of $3.1 billion, have probably lost money. A first-quarter loss of almost 14 percent wiped out nearly all the gains of the fund for the previous 15 months.
Robert J. Markman of Edina, Minn., who manages three mutual funds that invest in a portfolio of other funds, has a theory about how many investors will react when they realize that more than a year's worth of gains have been erased in one quarter.
"They will panic," Mr. Markman said. "The average investor who bought into these funds is going to look at his wife and say: 'Helen, we can make 5 percent in a money market fund. We don't need this kind of risk.' "
One factor that will greatly affect investors' responses is whether their expectations were realistic to begin with, Mr. Markman said. "People don't have to lose 20 percent to 30 percent before they'll pull their money out," he said. "All they need is to have their expectations not met."
RECENTLY, investors have set their expectations extraordinarily high. In a nationwide survey of 750 mutual fund investors conducted for Montgomery Asset Management, a San Francisco mutual fund company, respondents said they expected an average return of 16 percent this year on their mutual fund investments. Over the next 10 years, they forecast an average annual return of 22 percent.
"That is absolute folly," said R. Stephen Doyle, chairman of Montgomery Asset Management, which oversees $4.2 billion in fund assets. "Those kinds of expectations could lead to some unhappy and distressing consequences" if stock prices continue to fall.
Since Montgomery conducted the survey, in late February and early March, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen about 470 points, or about 7 percent. In the survey, 63 percent of those questioned said they would do nothing if the Dow dropped 350 points, or about 5 percent. Nearly three-quarters of the respondents said they expected the Dow to finish this year above 7,000.
Many fund investors, Mr. Doyle noted, will need substantial returns from now until the end of the year "just to get even," much less match a 16 percent expectation. Over the longer term, the respondents' expectations are more than double the average annual return produced by stocks over the last 60 years. If the average portfolio contains a healthy dose of bonds, which historically have produced lower returns than stocks, investors' expectations are even less likely to be met.
The last time mutual fund investors poured huge amounts of money into a sector of the mutual fund industry, only to turn and flee when their expectations were not met, was in the early 1990's.
In 1993, investors committed a record number of new dollars to bond funds: $113 billion, or 19 percent of the assets in those funds at the end of the previous year. The heavy inflows came at the end of a three-year period of rising bond prices and falling interest rates.
But in March 1994, when bond prices began to fall sharply after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, bond fund investors began to flee. And they continued to do so for 14 of the next 15 months.
Some analysts say a similar disappointment in the equity markets will cause investors to move money away from stock funds, where most of their new cash has been going recently. Last year, investors contributed a record number of dollars to equity mutual funds: $221 billion, or 17 percent of the previous year's assets. The record amount came in the sixth year of a period in which the major stock market averages never fell 10 percent below their record highs.
THROUGH Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average was nearly 8 percent below its high-water mark, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off its peak by more than 7 percent.
Undoubtedly, more mutual fund shareholders than ever are investing for retirement, rather than for a shorter term. That explains, in large part, why Americans have greatly increased the amount of their financial assets in stocks.
According to data compiled by the Investment Company Institute, equity holdings accounted for 31 percent of the financial assets of American households at the end of 1996. That was up from 17.8 percent at the end of 1990, the start of the bull market's latest sprint.
To be sure, that was not the biggest commitment ever by households to equities. From 1963 through 1969, equity holdings exceeded their current level, peaking at 33.8 percent of household financial assets in 1968.
But even now, some financial advisers are recommending that individuals scale back their equity holdings. "We're clearly moving into a defensive mode," said Louis P. Stanasolovich, president of Legend Financial Advisors of Pittsburgh.
"We don't believe that the stock market is going to fall 50 percent," Mr. Stanasolovich said. "But we do believe a 10 percent to 20 percent correction is in the cards over the next 12 months. We're making sure our clients have some money in international securities, in real estate funds, and some cash on the sidelines for buying opportunities."
For the remainder of the year, Mr. Stanasolovich said, he has greatly scaled back his expectations. "If we make some money, great," he said. "But we are aiming not to lose a lot."
Individuals who invest in mutual funds are not the only ones who might be scaling back their stock investments in the coming months to reduce their exposure to equities. According to figures released by the Federal Reserve last month, the portion of assets in state and local government employee retirement funds that is invested in stocks rose to 55 percent at the end of 1996 from 38 percent five years earlier. Similarly, the equity portion of private pension funds rose to 44 percent from 38 percent.
If sales by institutional investors cause continued weakness in stock prices, will mutual fund holders swim against the tide, continuing to put money into equities? Recent signs are less than encouraging.
The latest statistics from AMG Data Services and Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a fund tracking service in Santa Rosa, Calif., show that money has already begun flowing out of aggressive-growth funds and technology funds in recent weeks.
If the experience of the fund categories that are already leaking money is any indication, the low recent levels of cash reserves at fund companies will probably aggravate the situation.
The aggressive-growth funds, for example, held only 4.4 percent of their assets in cash at the end of February. That is the lowest level since at least the beginning of 1984 and may well have contributed to their declines in recent weeks.
LAST June, just before small-cap stocks went into a tailspin, the aggressive-growth funds had 7.7 percent of their assets, or $18.7 billion, in cash. That cushion allowed the funds to go into the market after the worst of the selloff and pick up their favorite stocks at relatively cheap prices.
At the end of February, however, these funds had cash balances of only $12.4 billion. With money flowing out in each of the last three weeks, the funds have had much less buying power.
Fund companies have maintained that they are not concerned about the relatively low levels of cash on hand. But a recent study by Towers Perrin, the pension and retirement plan consulting firm, raises questions about how well fund companies are prepared to handle any unexpected outflow of cash from investors.
Of 27 big mutual fund companies surveyed by Towers Perrin, only six had made arrangements to borrow money from an outside source or from other funds within the same family to finance redemptions. Brian E. Hersey, director of investment manager research at the firm, said that demonstrated a "level of comfort that is unwarranted" in light of changes in the fund industry and the speed with which financial markets move these days.
Although a growing number of mutual fund shareholders have made their investments through 401(k) plans or other tax-deferred retirement plans, "I don't think you can assume that those investors are not going to panic," Mr. Hersey said. "The '800' numbers are going to work for them as well," he said, referring to the toll-free telephone lines that allow investors to switch their assets among money market, stock and bond funds.
It is easy to forecast gloom and doom when short-term trends appear menacing, said Mr. Cleland of Security Benefit. But his bullishness was unshaken even by last week's decline. He noted that the stock market adjusts quickly today and said that a correction of 10 percent to 20 percent and a subsequent recovery could occur in three to six months.
"I think we are going to have good first-quarter earnings on balance, which will provide a floor for market valuations," Mr. Cleland said. "And before the summer is over, the market will recognize that significant inflation is not out there."
Indeed, by late last week, some bargain hunters had started to scoop up technology and other small-cap stocks that have been so battered. On Friday, large-cap stocks rebounded, too. Mutual fund investors have been conditioned in recent years to buy when the market dips, in expectation of a rebound. Some investors apparently thought they saw the bottom last week.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 45; Column 3; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1949 words

HEADLINE: It's a Cold, Cruel World, And Guys Need to Talk

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
AT first glance, the knot of men, dressed in a fashion arc from faded jeans to sports coats and neckties, standing around a table bountiful with icy beer and fast-food fajitas, appeared to be little more than aging fraternity boys in an off-campus romp. At any moment, it seemed, their chorus of belly laughs and bawdy one-liners could give way to a belching contest.
But no. There would be none of that in this comfortably furnished Upper West Side brownstone. The five friends, all in their 30's, had come to spend the next two hours on more sober business: to wrestle, no less, with the post-feminist tangle of what it means to be an American man in the closing years of the 20th century. 
 The men, most of whom became friends while students at Wesleyan University, have held these loosely structured gatherings every other Monday for almost five years. They call themselves Mariner's Gate, taken from a corner of Central Park where they once gathered to formalize the group -- sort of a consecration, as Beck Lee, a cherubic, 36-year-old theatrical press agent, put it.
On this night, when they settled down to talk -- serious, but not somber -- no subject was taboo or unworthy of examination from their unabashedly male perspectives, be it financial woes or dating wars.
"We like to challenge each other to grow and sort of shed some of the layers of acquired repression that holds us back in our lives," said Mr. Lee, who talked openly at the get-together about his anger and disappointment with a much younger woman who stood him up on a date. (He got a sympathetic hearing, albeit with body language that hissed, "I told you so.") The group, Mr. Lee noted, has helped him maintain his fighting spirit in the sometimes treacherous trenches of work, love and family.
The men of Mariner's Gate are hardly alone in regularly turning to one another for guidance and solace. They are part of a leading edge of small, urban-based men's support groups quietly reconstructing themselves from a blueprint of masculinity and duty that they are busy redrawing. "Men are really trying to find their bearings," said the Rev. Tom Cushman, an associate rector at St. James-Episcopal Church on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Three groups of eight men each meet weekly at 7:30 A.M. at the church to slip in some meaningful dialogue before work. "I can't tell you how much need there is for men's groups," Mr. Cushman said. "There is so much isolation in this country, so few places where you feel that you belong and can be yourself."
Support groups like these, many of whose members are professional and middle-aged, are cropping up across the country like early-morning whiskers, meeting in homes, restaurants or churches.
Members of New Warrior Network, a national men's group, which says it has 10,000 members, 220 of them in New York, splinter off into small weekly gatherings to discuss how they can become better husbands, better fathers or just simply better men. The Internet's World Wide Web is brimming with lists of men's groups with names like Men Assisting, Leading and Educating (MALE), Men Talk, Inside Men's Lives and Real Men.
(For those who may not be ready to share their emotions with other men, the Internet also carries advertisements for therapists specializing in just that. "Are you tired of doing it alone?" asks Gary Plep, a clinical social worker and co-founder of the Northern California Men's Center in Campbell.)
Through the ages, men have bellied up to the bar with buddies, swapping war stories about sports and women. But these new talkfests, with scheduled times, set members and clear agendas, are something far less muscular and less salty.
There is a "revolutionary difference in the kind of exchange that is going on now," said William S. Pollack, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and the director of the Center for Men at McLean Hosptial in Belmount, Mass.
"It is a more open, more emotional sharing of a deeper sense of self between men that many of us, until the 80's or so, were brought up not to do," he continued. "Men are going against all the gender stereotypes, a kind of gender blanket that we have been smothered under, one that tells us to be stoic, not to express pain, not to be vulnerable."
In the wake of cultural changes writ large by the women's movement, of shifting definitions of family and two-income households, some men say they are turning to each other in search of a practical paradigm on which to model their behaviors and attitudes.
"This is a time of transition," Mr. Lee said. "This is a time of realignment, and a lot of men are throwing up their hands in frustration and are withdrawing from the battle."
Generally, women have long understood the value of support groups. "They are aware they have an uphill battle," said Robert Bly, 70 and the guru of the modern men's movement. "They have been devalued for centuries."
Most men, on the other hand, have viewed these sometimes touchy-feely sessions of male togetherness with suspicion and derision, particularly their antecedent, the sweat-lodge, drum-beating rituals that Mr. Bly extolled in his 1991 best seller "Iron John: A Book About Men." (Yes, they are still venturing into the woods under Mr. Bly's auspices.) Part of the resistance, Mr. Bly said, is that "men feel they are at the top of the heap anyway, so they don't need to support one another. The interesting thing today is the groups are leaderless, getting together and meeting every week or two weeks and talking."
For the last two years, Gerry Migliore, a public relations manager in New York, has been organizing "Boys Night Out." Despite its name, the group of five or six members deals with the serious business of talking about their problems.
The idea evolved out of a meeting Mr. Migliore called together in 1994, frustrated that while he could express his concerns with his female friends, he couldn't share them with his male friends. He appealed to a few to join him to talk about their perceptions of manhood. At the gathering in an Upper West Side apartment, five men cooked a meal and spent the summer evening near an open bank of windows recalling defining moments in their lives.
Today, "Boys Night Out" is often held in bustling Manhattan bars where the conversations, replete with machismo trappings of fine cigars and 10-year-old brandy, could easily be mistaken for old-fashioned man talk about sports and office machinations. "We talk passionately about religion and politics, our feelings about mortality," Mr. Migliore, 53, said.
Mortality came up when one man was troubled by a chronic pain in his leg. "All of our clocks are winding down," he said. "And as I get older, I find that the spiritual things are more important to me."
Another member, a decade his junior, piped in that he refused to think about death. "We as men have a lot more play in those years between birth and old age," he said. "It's about how we live, how we manage our stress, how we tap into the power of our relationships."
And no one raised an eyebrow when one group member told another that he should try to be less of a teacher to his wife and more of an accepting husband.
"We're honest like that," Mr. Migliore said. "I don't think that would be that easy if we had an auditorium filled with men."
Mr. Migliore was referring to groups like Promise Keepers, the national Christian-based men's group that in recent years has drawn more than two million men to stadium rallies.
"The stadium conferences are so visible, so they get all the media attention," said Mark DeMoss, a national spokesman for the group, which combines male bonding with religious inspiration. "But the real work of Promise Keepers takes place outside the stadium walls in small groups of men. Men are changing because men are talking."
Craig Hernick, the director for the New Warrior's center in Louisville, Ky., said he had never trusted men. He would pal around, go out drinking and watch football games on television with his buddies.
"Guys all my life were the foe," said Mr. Hernick, who became a Warrior five years ago. "They were people to compete against on Little League, for the girlfriend, the job. I looked to women for emotional and personal support."
Now, every Friday, Mr. Hernick, 43 and married, spends two to three hours with his support group. Sometimes, they simply meet at an amusement park and ride the roller coaster, again and again.
Mr. Hernick recalled how his small circle helped a member deal with the death of his father from a lingering illness. "We are a group to support one another, to either cry on or celebrate with," he said.
Mariner's Gate was founded by a newly married man who was about to become a father and who was worried he would lose touch with men and their influences as his life grew more domestic. "From the beginning," said one member, Kevin Osborn, 37, "it was touted as a men's group with a higher function."
At the Mariner's Upper West Side session, one member talked about how he had just received an ambiguously worded letter from a former girlfriend. He spoke in a low, flat tone, his gaze wandering. "I'm frustrated with the fact that I have not been meeting the right kind of lady," he said. "I want to just stay on track, waiting and being available for somebody I can have a real relationship with."
"You're not calling her?" he was scolded.
"No, I'm not calling her."
Another member, who had heard disappointing news at work, spoke at his turn: "The amazing thing was that I'm hearing this news and I didn't sink into a bottomless pit of depression."
The group nodded approvingly.
"We find it very comfortable to sit in our lair and sort of scratch at each other's wounds," Mr. Lee said later.
And how do the left-behind women react? Susan Kiley, Mr. Osborn's wife of seven years, occasionally complains when she has to put their three children to bed by herself. "But I'm certainly not jealous about it," she said. "Their meetings are not something I need to be a part of.
"I don't think he discusses that much of his home life," she said, more question than statement.
"My wife calls us the International Boys Club for Men," one Mariner said. But, he added with a grin, "she's glad I belong to it."
 
The Minutes
 
MEMBERS of Mariner's Gate, a men's support group, answer to fanciful nicknames at meetings and take turns doing tasks like writing the minutes.
 
Here is an excerpt from a report on a recent meeting:
The brotherly Tex Bro-D spoke of working like a dog in Brooklyn, of schmoozing like a hog in the city of angels, and of winning an award in songwriting.
Virgil spoke of his odyssey (shouldn't that be Homer?): navigating the rocks of unemployment, resisting a siren's call. Will her temptations prove irresistible? Virgil needs a guide (perhaps Dante) through the inferno of agency reps. The city of angels also calls to him. Or should he rest in the shade of the Buttonwood Tree?
Hef spoke of struggles with partying, with sleep, with health. Abandoned by two of three women, he dissed one for dissing him. Hef also hears the call of a siren: wisely though, when she reached out, he pulled his hand back, fearful of getting burned.
No longer blocked and locked, Deano confessed a surge of creative energy (none of which was on display on that night). His inspiration led to the initiation of a new quartet. But will it be brass or strings?
The five turned inward, exploring the notion of identity. It's not of our own making, one said. It springs forth from our vision, our aspirations, and others' vision. That's how we earned and learned our names.

PUB-DATE: April 6, 1997

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1050 words

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton, Moralist;
The President as Vice President

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOT for many a day has a President tried as hard as Bill Clinton to save Americans from their bad habits, like smoking and drinking, no matter how much zeal other Americans have brought to crusades against this vice or that.
Calvinism, it is true, lay at the center of life in the early years of the Republic. "It is not quite accidental," observed the British historian D. W. Brogan, "that the first great American novel deals with the public, legal punishment of adultery, and The Scarlet Letter has been more read than its lesson has been digested." 
 But after the Civil War, organized religion became a less propulsive force in American politics. The exception was the Prohibitionist movement during and just after World War I; its success stemmed in part from religious fervor but also from the anti-German (and thus anti-beer) feelings of the day.
At no point in this century have Presidents appointed themselves chiefs of the vice police. Most have found it politically expedient, if not personally uplifting, to attend church on Sunday and hold the occasional prayer breakfast. But that is not the same thing as seeking to make the nation more virtuous by dint of legislation, which most politicians have avoided since the unhappy experience of Prohibition.
 
Prohibition and Hypocrisy
 After the ratification of the Eighteenth Amendment in 1919, outlawing alcohol, hypocrisy reigned in the White House and on Capitol Hill. Harding drank as much as he gambled. Hoover took refuge in platitudes, calling Prohibition "a great social and economic experiment, noble in nature and far-reaching in purpose." And FDR, on whose watch the amendment was finally repealed, was a diligent consumer of the sundown martini (two, if Mrs. R wasn't watching).
Now comes Mr. Clinton, a President with a surprising and very different approach. Consider how much he has taken on just in the last year or so:
Immediately after his re-election, he denounced as "simply irresponsible" the liquor industry's decision to resume broadcast advertising after a voluntary ban of half a century. By doing so, the President said, the industry would expose children to temptation "before they know how to handle alcohol." When that produced no results, he asked the Federal Communications Commission last week to look into the matter.
Mr. Clinton's new anti-alcohol crusade parallels his fight against tobacco. Last August, surrounded in the White House Rose Garden by children wearing T-shirts reading "Tobacco-Free Kids," he announced that the Government now considers nicotine an addictive drug, subject to regulation. Last month, he announced rules requiring ID checks of buyers under the age of 27.
In addition, the President has sought to give the Government a role in regulating pornography -- on television, through the V-chip, and on the Internet, through the omnibus Telecommunications Reform Act, signed in February 1996 -- despite the protests of a dwindling band of liberals who accuse him of trampling Constitutional guarantees of free speech.
And after California and Arizona voters last November approved local ballot initiatives declaring marijuana legal if used for medical purposes, the Administration threatened doctors with sanctions if they prescribed the drug for patients. That, too, brought protests, with prominent physicians arguing that the Government was intruding into the sacred doctor-patient relationship.
For all his popularity at the polls, Mr. Clinton is not viewed by the electorate as a moral beacon. In opinion surveys during last year's Presidential campaign, his Republican rival, Bob Dole, consistently won higher marks for personal rectitude. Mr. Clinton has been accused of womanizing and of shady business practices. But his personal history, as well as today's political climate, offers clues to his new stance.
Mr. Clinton is the son of an alcoholic, and he has a brother who has used drugs, so he knows the havoc that addiction can wreak on people and their families. In addition, he is a doting father, cognizant of the vulnerability of children, and he is married to a woman who has focused on children's causes.
It is the focus on children that makes political crusading against sin acceptable, at least for the moment, because the well-being of the young in a world increasingly full of dangers is as big a preoccupation of Democrats as of Republicans, as much a concern in small towns as in big cities, as high on the agendas of the secular as on those of the religious elements in society.
 
A Low-Cost War
 From the viewpoint of politicians with activist leanings but a tight budget, like Mr. Clinton and many of his closest advisers, cracking down on smoking and alcohol abuse, attacking the pornographers and merchants of violence and seeking with full fanfare to head off any move to legalize marijuana have obvious appeal. Issuing governmental regulations and pounding on the bully pulpit don't cost much, at least at the beginning.
Nor is the President's party likely to lose much campaign money. As the South has become more Republican, tobacco money has tended to flow disproportionately to Republicans -- by almost a five-to-one ratio in 1995-96.
So far, furthermore, Mr. Clinton has refrained from launching a campaign against gambling, the vice of choice of his late mother, who loved the ponies. The powerful gambling lobby gives heavily to politicians. In taking on the distilled-spirits companies, he has made no moves against the beer and wine industries, which advertise copiously on television and mount big lobbying efforts in Washington. Noting that beer is the first choice of kids who drink, Karolyn Nunalee of Mothers Against Drunk Driving observed caustically, "Basically, alcohol is alcohol."
The question is how far public support will enable this Presidential assault on vice to go. The manners and morals of a people can never be molded by legislation or governmental decree; if what government does harmonizes with public sentiment, if it is seen to address genuine evils, the law will be upheld. If not, it will be ignored or, worse, laughed at, as happened not only with Prohibition but also with attempts to keep books like Ulysses and plays like those of Eugene O'Neill from a supposedly tender public.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

STOCK MARKET
It's Falling? Well, Naturally
So did you think stocks would keep rising forever? Investors hoped so; it's pathetically easy to make money that way. But the interesting thing about the market's slide in the last week or so is that no one seemed truly surprised. They knew the party had to end, and now it was ending -- or at least taking a break. Surprise would have been silly. Oddly, though, when the job numbers came out on Friday -- the unemployment rate down again, a gain of 175,000 jobs -- that strength should have caused investors even more worry that the Federal Reserve would tighten the screws by raising interest rates again. But no. The Dow rebounded somewhat.
 
WIRELESS DREAMS
Airwaves: A Bonanza Deflated
The idea had everything: not only was it high-tech, but it would put billions into the threadbare Federal purse. Simply auction off the airwaves needed for all those wireless-communications gadgets overrunning our lives. But did the Government, dizzied by that free money, get carried away? Perhaps. The first auction went fine -- the licenses went to big guns like AT&T and Sprint, cash on the line. But at the second auction, the F.C.C. welcomed risk-loving entrepreneurs with open arms, asking just 10 percent down and payments spread over a decade. And yes, on paper, it took in $10.1 billion, and the budget balancers were glad. But much of that money turns out to be pie in the digital sky, for the buyers are having trouble paying, with one -- Pocket Communications -- even filing for bankruptcy last week. The F.C.C. threw up its hands and stopped collecting payments while it sorts all this out.
 
THE CORPORATE GAME
A Sweet Boss? Can't Be
So you want to be a corporate bigwig and get all those nice stock options? Well, there are a few rules. You must always think of the bottom line, and if that means getting fancy new equipment and ditching a few hundred workers, so be it. You dump older workers in favor of lower-paid younger ones. And you pay your workers as little as the market will bear. By these standards, Marvin Eisenstadt is a dismal failure. At his Brooklyn company, Cumberland Packing, which makes Sweet 'n Low, he gleefully ignores every rule, using old equipment, saving hundreds of neighborhood jobs and rarely dismissing anyone. "We don't always have to make business decisions," he said. "I have to sleep at night." The company isn't a failure, though; there's such demand for those little packets of sweetener that Cumberland is doing just fine. And in the long run, one business school professor said, its way of doing things "might be profoundly wise."
 
LAYOFFS
The Personal Touch
Here, on the other hand, is what is often the American way: CPC Specialty Foods in the Bronx, which turns out Melba toast, has about 200 employees, many of whom have been there 10, 20, even 30 years. Or at least it did until Wednesday, when workers arrived to see a list of about 45 names posted on a wall -- those who were out of a job. "No warning, nothing," said one man who saw his name on the list. "I'm still in shock." The bakery is for sale, said CPC International, but the job cuts were unconnected -- they were seasonal, it said. That worker had been there nine years.
 
TOBACCO WARS
Fighting Smoking With Taxes
There's a simple way to cut teen-age smoking, tobacco foes say: just make it more expensive. So for the moment, at least, anti-smoking crusaders are zeroing in on raising state and Federal taxes enough so the price of an average pack would go from $1.80 to $4.23. And that, they hope, would make it prohibitively costly -- economists estimate that every 10 percent price increase means a 12 percent decline in the number of teen-agers who take up smoking. State taxes now vary from Virginia's 2.5 cents a pack to Washington State's 82.5 cents, but the goal is to raise the average to $2. In the past, given the tobacco industry's heavy lobbying, many state legislators would have turned a deaf ear, but sentiment is shifting markedly with all the publicity surrounding Liggett's acknowledged recruiting of young smokers. Even most smokers, polls show, now support higher taxes.
 
APPLE COMPUTER
A Mighty Vote of Confidence
Hold off on those Apple Computer obituaries for the moment. Yes, the company has big troubles, slipping two steps back, it seems, every time it inches ahead. But Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has a different take on its situation. It's "bad," he said, "but not that bad," and it's "a heck of a company," with "a loyal base of customers." This was no idle chitchat, for Prince Walid had put his money where his praise was, just paying some $115 million for 5 percent of Apple. A poor investment? "They said the same thing about Citibank," said the Prince, who invested $800 million in Citicorp in 1991 and even after selling many of his shares has a $5 billion stake.
 
WATERFRONT REALITIES
The Hudson! Of Course!
Sometimes New York is downright uncivilized. The Hudson, one of nature's marvels, is at its elbow -- the city wouldn't even be here without this river -- but decade after decade it treats it with contempt. While other cities do glorious things with their waterfronts, the strip south of 59th Street (south, that is, of Donald Trump's latest playground) is a mess, a hodgepodge of parking lots and rotting piers. After the epic Westway battle -- which lasted, if memory serves, just over a century -- nature-loving types got the city to commit $100 million to a waterfront park. The plan couldn't go forward without the same amount from the state, though, and last week Gov. George E. Pataki decided to commit the money.
 
ON-LINE BLUES
A Dangerous '800' Number
"Look, Ma, no busy signal!" If you hear those words, and the topic is America Online, you'd better reclaim your place at the family computer -- quick. Yes, the kids might have gotten lucky and dialed into America Online's local access number on the first try (yeah, right!), or they might have heard about an "800" number that was never busy and used that instead. What they probably didn't hear about was the extra access charge for using the "800" number. (And if they did, well, parents are made of money, aren't they?) The bills are coming in, though, and people are discovering that the nice manageable $19.95 a month is turning into hundreds of dollars. Refunds? Possibly, but don't count on it.
 
DEADLINES
Tax Break, Peruvian-Style
Last Wednesday was the tax-filing deadline in Peru, but about 50 Peruvians had a problem: they were still being held hostage in the Japanese Ambassador's residence. Now you'd think that Peruvian tax collectors would just worry about those people later -- let them get past some problems that were, well, a bit more serious than tax forms and not set any formal deadline. Alas, no. The tax office said last week that the hostages, if and when they went free, would have exactly 30 days to do their civic duty.

HEADLINE: Fat Cat Spat;
Look Who's Carping Most About Capitalism

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT wasn't long ago that the most astringent critiques of capitalism came from the left. Armed Zapatista guerrillas in the Mexican jungles and the fast-disappearing Socialists of Japan complained that leaving the world to the ruthless efficiency of the market not only made fat cats fatter and the impoverished poorer, but it also undercut human dignity and skewed national values.
They lost the argument. Save for odd corners of the world like Cuba and North Korea, the ideology of the market economy reigns supreme. Political leaders vying for investments from overseas cut their budget deficits and privatize industry to satisfy the most feared figure on the international scene: the bond-rater from Standard & Poor's, whose thumbs-down in the global coliseum signals the world's biggest investors to take their billions elsewhere. 
 Now the inevitable backlash to market-worship is well under way. But to really hear the excesses of capitalism denounced, listen to some of the world's confirmed capitalists. Perhaps fearful that the side effects of economic globalization are more severe than anyone thought, or that they could spin out of control, prominent members of the monied classes and their conservative allies are questioning whether markets have become too unfettered. The only hitch is that they can't agree on the nature of problem, to say nothing of what to do about it.
Evidence of this rethinking is everywhere. The latest meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland -- which views itself as the world-class assemblage of the free-market elite -- was devoted to ways of ameliorating the worst consequences of economic competitiveness. George Soros, the man who broke the British pound and assembled a $2.5 billion fortune, seized the cover of The Atlantic Monthly recently with a rambling account titled "The Capitalist Threat."
The "uninhibited pursuit" of laissez-faire ideology, a perplexed-sounding Mr. Soros reported, results in a loss of equilibrium. Education and other features of civilized society that don't promise a quick return on investment get short shrift, and nations become "preoccupied with their competitiveness and unwilling to make any sacrifices for the common good." Mr. Soros does not advocate the bar-the-door approach to free trade that other billionaires -- Ross Perot or Sir James Goldsmith, for example -- have urged. But he takes the view that governments have to reclaim their power from the markets.
The new critics have their conservative cheerleaders, though some of those bring a different agenda. There is William Bennett, the conservative's minder of values, who worries less about disequilibrium than about the erosion of national decorum.
Hollywood's production line of sex and violence has been Mr. Bennett's easiest target, but now the debate has moved on to regulating the Internet -- and made odd bedfellows. In defending the Communications Decency Act before the Supreme Court last month, the Clinton Administration found itself allied with the Christian Coalition and Senator Jesse Helms in support of the regulatory state. And it was fighting not only the American Civil Liberties Union but the United States Chamber of Commerce, which warned in a friend-of-the-court brief that the United States would put itself at a competitive disadvantage if it began regulating the ultimate expression of global free enterprise.
 
Echoes From the Past
 None of these arguments is new; there are echoes of Tory conservative thought and the Progessive Era tame-the-oligarchs movement in all of them. What's surprising is that many of the new concerns come from the oligarchs themselves, who see that globalization is causing instability that could unmake the market revolution. And some come from conservatives whose rallying call in the 80's -- shrink the government and save the markets -- has turned into gospel. Even Bill Clinton says the era of big government is over.
But victory left the victors divided. Libertarians persist in defending the untrammeled markets. Patrick J. Buchanan and Ross Perot struck a different chord with arguments that economic integration, starting with the North American Free Trade Agreement, impoverishes working Americans and impinges on American sovereignty by letting "faceless foreign judges" review American laws challenged by our trading partners. Meanwhile, those who worry about income inequality, job insecurity and pornography on the Net talk about getting the Government to intervene.
The same divisions, and odd alliances, can be found wherever politicians, labor unions and business executives believe they have lost their ability to control market forces. Not surprisingly, political leaders find it hard to give up the power that comes from running, and interfering with, a national economy.
In Europe, it is no longer just labor leaders who argue that global competition threatens the Continent's social safety net. Now the chief executives of some of Europe's biggest industrial enterprises are voicing nervousness about the European Monetary Union, the world's most ambitious attempt to erase national boundaries. In Germany, some industrialists are protesting the strict budget-cutting requirements that are part of the deal for countries that want to enter the monetary union. They talk about inflation and unemployment, but their real fear is that Europe's common currency, the Euro, will prove far more unstable than the German mark -- meaning that Germany will be dragged down by lesser economies.
Then there are the South Koreans, who waxed enthusiastic about the wonders of global competitiveness in the 70's and 80's, as American companies moved production there. Now the same forces that brought suburban manses and sports cars to the industrial tangle of Seoul are moving to China and India, scared off by wages that shot up during the democracy movement. When South Korean companies rammed a bill through the Parliament that would allow them to move operations out of the country just as the Americans were doing, the protests grew so ugly that President Kim Young Sam had to go on television to apologize. The law is being amended.
"What we're seeing in the backlash overseas is a reaction to the American style of quick downsizing to become instantly more competitive," said Clyde Prestowitz, who heads the Economic Strategy Institute here. "For decades executives in Europe and Japan have been inculcated with the thought that they have a responsibility to maintain employment and social stability, and now they find this in direct contradiction to the global imperative."
So how much of this backlash is warranted, and how much is driven by the torrent of globaloney about economic integration? The answer is a little of both. Paul Krugman, the M.I.T. economist, says the importance of global markets is overstated because "pontificating about globalization is an easy way to get attention" at conferences like Davos. And politicians, of course, have good reason to throw up their hands and blame mysterious global forces for their national economic woes. France springs to mind.
But it is also clear that globalization's effects have been understated by many economists because they are maddeningly hard to measure. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's chief economic adviser until a few months ago, agrees with estimates that 20 to 25 percent of the growth in wage inequality in America comes from the global market, in which even a complex job can be done half a world away -- say, having software written by an Indian engineer. Such nervousness could explain why Vice President Al Gore, backpedaling on the wonders of globalization, has fallen silent about the need to extend free trade agreements.
 
No One to Make the Rules
 Ultimately, taming the excesses of a global free market is going to be next to impossible because no one can agree on who should do the taming. Who would mandate a minimum wage and create a Social Security system for the world? Who would tell India that it can't build car factories because there are already too many sport utility vehicles polluting the world? Who would rule that Washington should be allowed to regulate what children can see on the Internet, but that China should not be allowed to regulate what dissidents can say on it? These are the "disequilibriums" dividing fans of capitalism around the world. They aren't going to get any easier.

HEADLINE: When Money Talks, Orwell Is Listening

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
AS stock prices tumbled last week, serious discussion erupted as to whether things were really getting better. Or at least that's what you might think if you assumed that Wall Street types use words to mean what they usually mean. The question being asked was whether a stock market "correction" had begun. And certainly, no one would oppose having things corrected.
Why call falling prices a correction? To some extent, it is part of a trend, which has been going on for decades, to make bad economic and financial news sound as good as one possibly can. Politicians are happy to get in on that trend. So are brokerage house analysts, who are often quoted in the financial pages. It is, after all, their job to sell securities. And that job is not made any easier if things sound too bad. 
 On a daily basis, the favored terms of Wall Street make any stock market movement sound good. Sometimes there is a "rally," which means prices are rising. Other days see "profit taking," which means prices are falling because so many people were selling stocks, but it sounds so good. Sometimes the phrase profit taking is used even when a stock has fallen so far that it is inconceivable that any living person has any profits to take.
Companies these days rarely go "bankrupt." Instead, they are "restructured," which sounds ever so much better even if it often means the same thing.
It works in the economy, as well. Once upon a time, the economy suffered occasional "panics," a term that was not a bad description of how investors reacted. But that term was replaced by the much gentler sounding "depression," which had been used to mean economic downturn for a century but only came into wide usage after the 1929 stock market crash. After all, we've all been depressed occasionally, and we've eventually gotten over it.
The 1930's depression destroyed the Republican Party for generations. So politicians decreed there could never be another one. Since then, there have only been "recessions."
Financial words that begin life as mere euphemisms mysteriously acquire mathematical rigor. A recession now has an official definition: two consecutive quarters in which the nation's economic output declines. Except nobody admits that anything declines; the preferred term is "negative growth." Even in a recession it sounds better to have some kind of growth.
Similarly, a correction is viewed as a decline of at least 10 percent in a stock market index. (The Dow Jones industrial average has not had one of those since 1990, a record-long period, but it is now down 7.9 percent from its peak, reached March 11, so one could come any day.)
If a correction lasts long enough, it eventually becomes a bear market, although you can be sure Wall Street will resist admitting such a thing until it is quite obvious. (The use of the bear as a symbol of falling prices dates from the early 18th century, and evidently predates the use of a bull as a symbol of rising prices. The Oxford English Dictionary speculates it may have come from a proverb about the risk of selling a bearskin before the bear is caught.)
After the mid-1970's recession, the worst one since World War II, even that word briefly became forbidden in official Washington. Alfred E. Kahn, the Cornell economist and adviser to President Jimmy Carter, dealt with the prohibition by using the word "banana" when he meant recession. Everyone had a good laugh. So far, recessions are still allowed in discussion.
But they terrify politicians. President Clinton owes his job, in no little part, to his success in blaming George Bush for the last recession. No doubt Al Gore cringes whenever an economist suggests that a recession might appear in the next few years. Since he can't control the economy, perhaps Mr. Gore should simply seek a new term. Might we suggest "growth pause"?
A decade or two ago, a stock that collapsed and then recovered a bit was not said to have "snapped back," today's label. The move was instead called a "dead cat bounce," which is the idea that anything will bounce a little if dropped from high up enough.
But that term is rarely used these days. It might encourage more investors to engage in profit taking.

HEADLINE: The World;
Searching for an Enemy and Finding China

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A SOVIET analyst, Georgi Arbatov, once warned that Mikhail Gorbachev was going to do something unforgiveable to the United States: take away its enemy.
But Mr. Arbatov underestimated American ingenuity. In the last few months, a number of members of Congress, leading and following the opinion magazines and the think-tank symposia, have been working to invent a new enemy, China. Sparked by unconfirmed suspicions that the Chinese sought to meddle in the American political campaign, enough confusion and domestic politics now swirl around the topic of Beijing to make even a Cold Warrior's head spin. 
 The argument is that the United States could be cooperating in its displacement from Asia by helping China grow in wealth and military potential. This is a variant on the Leninist notion that the capitalists will sell the revolutionaries the rope to hang them. It also builds on the recurrent American fear of an Asian power rising up to challenge American dominance in the Pacific, a role played first by fascist Japan, then by Communist China, then by an economically booming Japan, and now, again, perhaps, by China.
But does that reflect the real relationship between China and the United States? A number of powerful thinkers in Washington say it does not. They say the fears presume a hostile relationship largely because they overestimate Beijing's capacities while hardly looking at all at China's weaknesses and poverty.
This is not to say that China is not a nasty place. Political dissent has been quashed there and democratic activists are jailed on flimsy grounds; the leaders are a narrow group of autocrats who use power ham-handedly and hand out multi-million business contracts to Boeing or Airbus for political gain; state-owned businesses only obey copyright agreements when threatened; the military is backward but ambitious and sells missiles to countries like Iran that Washington doesn't much like.
 
Behaving Badly
 And it is not to say that China's growing influence, both economic and military, will not create problems for America and Asia. An aggressively nationalist China nursing past humiliations is going to be a major power in the next century no matter what Washington does.
But even those who are pessimistic about China understand that it is not a great power now, and that some of its nastiness stems from the anxieties of a narrowly based central leadership with decaying political legitimacy.
And there is a big difference between acknowledging that the Chinese Government behaves badly and believing that it represents a clear and present danger. Put another way, there is a difference between having faith that the United States will be strong enough to rein in China's ambitions and influence its behavior for some time to come, and fearing that China is already so implacable that America can only confront and contain it.
Despite Chinese denials -- and the obvious fact that other countries, from Israel to France to Taiwan itself, do their best to influence American politics with money and espionage -- the scandal has helped convince many Americans that China is an enemy.
But Winston Lord, who recently left office as Assistant Secretary of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, warns against such an approach. "It's inevitable and healthy to have a debate on China and its future," he says. "But there is a tendency to exaggerate China's threat and demonize it, almost out of nostalgia for the Soviet Union. We shouldn't assume China's hostility in the next century, which could be self-fulfilling and wrong, any more than we should assume China will be benign. We have to be firm, tough, seek cooperation and keep our powder dry, while shoring up alliances."
Zbigniew Brzezinski, a former Carter Administration National Security Adviser and no softie on Communism, says something similar: "Our fashion is to have the enemy of the year. China is big, it's large on the map, it's yellow, so there is an under-the-surface racist element, and it fits very nicely an obsessive state of mind. I imagine it will last a couple of years, because China is big enough to sustain this obsession."
At the same time, senior American officials say, China's rush toward development has created severe tensions for a post-Deng leadership that could just as easily spin China into rival provincial fiefs as create an aggressive superpower.
Robert B. Zoellick, who was an Under Secretary of State for James Baker, says capitalism has improved living conditions for hundreds of millions of people, while undermining the legitimacy of their leaders.
 
Freedom and Tension
 "The Chinese enjoy more freedom, choice and opportunity to learn about the world than they did when the United States re-established ties" 25 years ago, he said. He then lists the "momentous tensions" China's nervous leaders are trying to manage: between Beijing and the provinces; the mainland and Hong Kong and Taiwan; private and state-owned enterprises; urban and rural populations; and decayed political legitimacy and an increasingly pluralistic public. America needs a strategy, he argues, "that matches a China that will be in a condition of flux for decades, not just years." But the current controversy, senior American officials freely admit, is putting a freeze on any important initiative in relations, making a vote for permanent favorable trade status for Beijing impossible this year. It is also threatening to postpone China's entry into the World Trade Organization, which the West wants.
One result of the fight is that the Clinton Administration, after fumbling through its own contradictions on how to handle China, human rights and trade, is now having to defend dealing politely with China at all. Its case was not helped by Vice President Al Gore's painful awkwardness in his public sessions with Chinese leaders, his failure to speak forcefully about human rights and his refusal to visit Hong Kong, as House Speaker Newt Gingrich cheerfully did.
But just as cheerfully, Mr. Gingrich acknowledged to The Wall Street Journal that China has changed. If some Republicans are searching for an enemy, he added, "I don't think China is that enemy."

HEADLINE: After the Shouting;
A Minimal-Impact Minimum Wage

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
UP close, the thunder of last year's debate over the minimum wage seemed as portentous as the shots fired on Fort Sumter.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy called an increase in the $4.25 minimum hourly wage "the overarching issue of our time and the election." The Republican House Majority Leader, Richard K. Armey, a former professor of economics, said, "Study after study demonstrates" that hikes in the minimum wage shut out the neediest job seekers. He vowed to fight an increase "with every fiber of my being." And Republican Senator Hank Brown of Colorado warned that the resulting jobless teen-agers would trigger "a crime problem and a juvenile problem of epic proportions." 
 The increase kicked in Oct. 1. Now, six months later, the Government's employment report suggests that the fulminations were mostly hot air. Last month's 5.2 percent unemployment rate was the lowest in five months. The new wage is a boon to some working poor. But the wage increase has had little effect elsewhere.
 
A Hill of Beans
 Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute, which has union support, said, "Despite the vehemence of the debate, a minimum wage increase is throwing a pretty small pebble in a very large pool." Mark Wilson of the conservative Heritage Foundation agreed, "The economics of the minimum wage doesn't matter a hill of beans to anybody."
Looking for re-election last year, Congress and the White House ordered the first increase in the wage in six years. That upped the standard by 50 cents an hour to $4.75 last October with another 40-cent rise to $5.15 this July.
For a full-time worker who earned the old $4.25, that means a raise of $1,800 a year and an incoming exceeding $10,000 for the first time. People earning up to $5.15 an hour account for around 10 million of the nation's 129 million workers.
Most people's pay, however, is rising by a barely perceptible clip, suggesting that the increase in the minimum wage has little ripple effect. Last month they averaged $12.15 an hour, 24 cents more than in September and 47 cents more than a year ago.
As for looming unemployment, finding a job has rarely been easier. Since September, a robustly growing economy has pulled nearly two million more people into jobs, including 124,000 more of those dreaded jobless teen-agers.
None of this surprises most economists, who say that the law of supply and demand still works, that employers will hire fewer workers when the minimum wage rises a lot as it has sometimes in the past. But most say this latest relatively small increase in a very low minimum wage has a minimal impact on jobs or the economy. At most, a higher minimum might discourage employers from hiring an additional 200,000 workers while they raise the pay of many more.
So why the big debate? One reason was business as usual: Congress responds to pressure groups like labor unions, which favor higher wages, and groups like fast-food chains, which hire most minimum-wage workers and want to hold down wages. This time a political skirmish became a brawl over ideological fundamentalism.
Having won control of both houses for the first time in four decades, Republicans wanted to take a symbolic whack at Government intervention in the economy. They tackled the orthodoxy that says all wages plunge without a minimum wage.
In setting a minimum wage, Mr. Wilson of the Heritage Foundation explained, government intrudes upon the freedom of employers and workers to negotiate the terms of a job. "Slowly but surely," he said, "they're taking away your liberty to mutually make employment decisions. I dare say that's socialism. It's government paternalism at its worst."
 
Battle of the Economists
 To lend credibility to their ideology, both sides drew on distinguished economists. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich seized upon the work of two Princeton professors, Alan Krueger and David Card.
Both economists had looked at employment in fast-food shops in New Jersey and Pennsylvania before and after New Jersey raised its minimum wage above Pennsylvania's. Employment in Pennsylvania didn't change, they found, and it even grew slightly in the New Jersey shops.
Mr. Reich used their study to show that an increase would not lose jobs. Mr. Kennedy, sensing a popular issue, began pushing a wage rise to the top of the Democrats' election-year agenda.
Meanwhile Richard Berman, executive secretary of the Employment Policies Institute, a research group financed in part by the National Restaurant Association, sent payroll data from some of the same restaurants to two other distinguished economists, William Wascher of the Federal Reserve and David B. Neumark of Michigan State University. They came to the opposite conclusion, discerning a slight decline in jobs at the New Jersey restaurants.
For all four economists the operable word was "slight." But in political debate such distinctions became mountains and the economists themselves became targets of partisan ridicule.
"We tried to be cautious" in reporting the analysis of Mr. Berman's data, Mr. Neumark said. "Our conclusion was: this had to be looked at more." Lobbyists, though, blew their findings out of proportion, he said. "It was obnoxious."
Mr. Card said, "I've sort of had it. I've sort of decided I'm not working on the minimum wage any more."

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform's Other Victims

 BODY:
Among this country's 30 million low-wage workers without high school degrees, there is widespread fear that the new law requiring welfare recipients to work will cost them their jobs. Many economists say that relatively few workers will be displaced. But there will be suffering because the influx of low-paid workers will drive down the wages of those who already have jobs.
About four million welfare recipients will go to work either in private-sector jobs or -- if states assume responsibility -- in workfare, which pays the recipient welfare benefits in exchange for cleaning parks or other public-service work. If the economy stays strong, labor markets can absorb three or four million more workers without shoving aside existing workers. Over the past 20 years, unemployment rates have dropped even as millions of baby boomers flooded the market. More work for some does not mean less work for others. Welfare recipients will not just occupy a job slot. They will also earn income to spend on goods that other workers must be hired to produce. 
 The new law is not, however, without risks. Employers could afford to soak up the baby boomers because wages fell. Hiring welfare recipients at lower wages will also be profitable. Four million new workers might seem a small addition to a labor force of 130 million. But most of them are concentrated in only a few regions, and because they will compete for the jobs that require little education or work experience, the influx of welfare recipients will create downward pressures on wages in those areas. Prof. Harry Holzer of Michigan State estimates that wages for unskilled workers across the nation could fall by an average of 10 percent.
If Congress could guarantee that the economy would remain forever strong, the new welfare law might make sense. Nearly everyone could work, even if wages fell. But the economy will at some point slow down. Many unskilled workers will lose their jobs, joining welfare recipients unable to hold a steady job in a lengthening unemployment line. Under the old law, they could collect food stamps for as long as they needed help. Under the new law, childless adults can lose their food stamps in a matter of months. Cash benefits for parents could be cut off after two years.
The states could step in to fill the void created by Congress. But judging from past experience, most states will not want to raise the necessary taxes because they fear losing their competitive edge in the hunt for new industry. When Congress ripped away the safety net, it had no idea how much fear and desperation it would cause.

HEADLINE: An Endgame for the Mideast

 BODY:
President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright like to talk about America as the indispensable nation, the only country with the power and prestige to help bring peace to troubled regions like the Middle East. They now have a chance to deliver on that grand image. The unfinished peace between Israel and the Palestinians is near collapse and Washington's role as avuncular mediator will no longer suffice. Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright must make some hard decisions and take some political risks to end the conflict.
They can begin tomorrow when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel comes to the White House. Both Mr. Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, have mismanaged the peace effort in the weeks since the two sides reached a milestone agreement on the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the West Bank city of Hebron. Israel has imperiously proceeded with a housing construction project in East Jerusalem and Palestinian terror attacks have resumed in Israel. 
 With trust disintegrating and violent confrontations resuming, the entire step-by-step approach to peace no longer seems promising. Still, if there is no other route open, Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat, with a powerful push from Washington, may have to return to the phased peace plan outlined in the original Oslo agreements three years ago.
But another, more daring option may be available if the White House is willing to bear the risks involved. It is to move directly to intensive negotiations on a final settlement. That would mean negotiating permanent boundaries between the areas of Israeli and Palestinian control and defining the respective rights of the two peoples in Jerusalem.
It would require deciding whether Jewishsettlements in the West Bank and Gaza should be uprooted, annexed to Israel, or transferred to Palestinian rule with security guarantees. Final settlement talks must also determine whether the Palestinians win a full-fledged state of their own, or must accept some limits on their sovereignty.
A drive for a final agreement would probably require continuous high-level talks with active American participation, not unlike the 1978 Camp David marathon led by President Carter. Though the idea may seem improbable in the tense climate that now prevails, it should not be dismissed. Some conditions are favorable. Mr. Netanyahu is pushing for the idea, and the White House seems willing to consider it. The two main Israeli political parties have begun to sketch out elements of a politically sustainable Israeli bargaining position. Mr. Netanyahu even seems prepared to discuss the formation of a Likud-Labor coalition government, which would free him to make some difficult concessions.
Palestinian leaders, while wary of skipping past the remaining land transfers due under Oslo, have recently been thinking creatively about final-status issues. On Jerusalem, for example, Mr. Arafat now talks about a Vatican City-type arrangement that would not require a redivision of the city. Others have ventured further, suggesting a new Palestinian capital that would lie inside metropolitan Jerusalem but outside present city limits.
Compromises on Jerusalem and the other issues will be painful for both sides, and impossible without sustained pressure and encouragement from Washington. They will have to honor Israel's need for military security and legitimate Palestinian aspirations to national dignity.
Before any kind of talks can begin again, Mr. Arafat must unequivocally restate his opposition to terrorism and back up his words with consistent actions. Mr. Netanyahu should respond with constructive gestures in the economic sphere -- for example, allowing the opening of the Palestinian airport and seaport facilities in Gaza. Nothing, however, will happen without the direct and active involvement of Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright. America can only be the indispensable nation if its leaders are prepared to make it so.
