HEADLINE: From Asia, the Real Clinton Scandal Is His Prices

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
From Asia, the accusations of influence-peddling at the White House look a bit different. The immediate reaction is often not outrage but surprise -- at the low American prices.
Corruption and gift-giving to curry favor are widespread in most Asian countries. And a few highly publicized scandals, including cases that involved former presidents of South Korea, have highlighted what is widely accepted here: the practice is entwined with building relationships and doing business, and the amounts are usually far greater than the sums that have sparked uproar in Washington. 
 Corruption may be no more widespread in parts of Asia than in other rapidly developing regions, like Latin America, but it has come into the spotlight because of links to President Clinton's campaign fund-raising. And it is clear that the development boom that has transformed East Asian economies has sent the price of influence soaring.
A result is that some executives here are struck mostly by how inexpensive it reportedly is to gain access to the President. A $100,000 contribution will not get a visitor a night in the Asian versions of the Lincoln Bedroom, or probably even a presidential green tea, or even a glass of water. Indeed, such an amount might be regarded as so puny a donation as to be insulting.
Take Yang Chung Mo, a South Korean business executive who in the 1980's was asked to contribute to the fund-raising efforts of Chun Doo Hwan, then the country's President. According to accounts of the episode in The Joong-ang Ilbo, a major Korean daily newspaper, Mr. Yang contributed $386,000, which was regarded as a paltry sum.
President Chun is said to have been furious at the offering and at Mr. Yang's disregard for accepted norms (on other occasions, Mr. Yang paid by check instead of cash). And after all, Mr. Chun had dropped hints to Mr. Yang that another executive had donated $3.8 million.
So Mr. Chun, who is now in prison for corruption, was said to have punished Mr. Yang by effectively destroying his conglomerate, the Kukje Group, which was then one of South Korea's largest. At the time, Mr. Chun ruled as a dictator, so the case was never prosecuted. Kukje went bankrupt in 1985, and its pieces were scattered among other conglomerates whose executives had dug more deeply into their pockets.
"If they want to influence policy, I don't think they would think in terms of $100,000," a prominent Asian-American said of tycoons in Asia. "They would think in much larger amounts of money. A hundred thousand is too small an amount to think it could influence Clinton policy."
Politics is as costly a process in much of Asia as it is in America, and so politicians -- with the same distaste as in America -- feel obliged to turn to companies and wealthy individuals. Likewise, family members of influential figures in Asia, from Thailand to Taiwan and Indonesia to South Korea, sometimes see their roles as gatekeepers, and they take tips at the door.
In China, the son of a Politburo member confided a few years ago that he was accepting a $400,000 share of a company in exchange for lending his family's support for a commercial project. The idea was that officials would favor the company if they realized that the family had a stake in it.
"You just don't do business without sending a few bucks the way of your friends," said a foreign banker in Hong Kong.
Contributions from Asians and Asian-Americans have been at the center of the controversy about White House campaign financing, but many Asian-Americans and Asians complain that the focus is misplaced. They say that the uproar is a result of bias.
One businessman in Asia who met Mr. Clinton said that at his breakfast meeting at the White House there were other foreigners, from the Middle East and elsewhere, but by far the greatest scrutiny had been directed at those with Asian names.
"I find a lot of 'yellow peril' invective in the way this is reported," said Eugene K. Galbraith, who handles global research for HG Asia, a brokerage firm, and who spent 16 years in Indonesia before moving to Hong Kong last year. Mr. Galbraith said the same search for influence could be seen in other parts of the world without a strong legal tradition.
In such places, where various laws are interpreted loosely or simply do not exist, relationships have become a crucial means for doing business. "It doesn't have so much to do with Asia as with political systems in which the rule of law is not sufficient," he said. "You've got to know the people to get things done."
Yet the executives acknowledge that influence-peddling is widespread in Asia, and that the custom of spreading around a million dollars here and a million there is hard to shed when dealing with the United States. Just as most Americans probably do not regard it as theft if they use a paper clip from the office, many Asian executives find it difficult to get excited about sums in the thousands of dollars.
In Indonesia, for example, one public stock offering recently involved a demand for some $50 million worth of shares, under a special financial arrangement, to a family member of President Suharto, according to an executive familiar with the deal. The executive and others say that the practice is not uncommon.
In South Korea, former President Roh Tae Woo has been imprisoned and convicted for, among other offenses, raising more than $350 million in illegal contributions. Of that sum, two companies contributed $31 million each, local newspapers say.
In China, a former Deputy Mayor of Beijing, Wang Baosen, committed suicide two years ago when he came under scrutiny for having amassed $37 million in payoffs. In Japan, a former political boss, Shin Kanemaru, was arrested after a police raid on his home turned up cash and gold bars worth some $25 million.
In Thailand, corruption has been one of the main reasons for dissatisfaction with several Thai leaders, from Chatichai Choonhavan, in the early 1990's, to Prime Minister Banharn Silpa-archa, voted out last fall.
Sometimes money that changes hands or is deposited into a bank account clearly violates the local laws, and in most countries bribery is against the law. But on many occasions the exchange is highly subtle or the laws are simply neglected.
In Asia, a "voluntary contribution" or an expensive gift may be offered in return for a specific change of policy. More often the donations are a way of currying favor and assuring access in the long run.
Using money to cultivate relationships with powerful or prominent figures is considered a legitimate business practice. Sometimes the aim is not so much influence-peddling as prestige-peddling.
Likewise, in the United States, the aim of donations to the Democratic Party in many cases may have been to win President Clinton's ear or that of his aides rather than a specific quid pro quo, executives say. Over and over again, executives talked about money not as bribes but as nutrients to cultivate relationships. No word comes up more than "relationships."
"Most of the Chinese people view more the relationship and the integrity than the money," said Joseph Chiang, a director in the China division of the Lippo Group in Hong Kong. "If you and I are friends, I wouldn't think twice to use money to change your mind. Relationships and integrity are of utmost importance to most of the overseas Chinese businessmen."
That view was echoed in interviews with executives throughout Asia.
"If you look at the pattern of overseas Chinese who invest in China, they always contribute, building schools or hospitals," said Roderick W. Macneil, who runs his own firm doing business in China. "They surely wouldn't do it if they didn't have long-term interests in the town or locality. But it's not the case of 'I'll build a hospital in exchange for taking 50 percent of your port.' There's no direct quid pro quo."

HEADLINE: Within Little Havana, A Change in Accents;
Other Hispanic Groups Growing in Miami

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 5

 BODY:
In Little Havana's Maximo Gomez Park, named after the 19th-century Cuban patriot, the boisterous crowd of regulars, all in their 60's, 70's and 80's, interrupt their domino game only to go get a cortadito, Cuban coffee. They call one another "brother" or "partner" in Spanish, trade stories about past adventures and talk politics but rarely argue. They are all staunchly anti-Castro.
The scene at Domino Park, as it is more commonly known, is quintessential Hispanic Miami, one of the images that has defined this city, where Cuban immigrants have dominated in numbers and clout since the 1980's. 
 But within the same blocks, another Little Havana can be found -- the one with St. John Bosco Church, where the Cuban pastor tends to a parish that is 68 percent Nicaraguan; with La Esquina de Tejas restaurant, where most of the waitresses are from Honduras, Uruguay and Peru, and with the local Sedano's Supermarket, where customers reach past the Cuban black beans to the yellow cornmeal for Colombian arepas, sweet corncakes.
The Little Havana of today underscores a change that demographers say took hold in the 1980's and continues in the 1990's -- in Miami, Hispanic does not mean just Cuban anymore.
Cuban-Americans remain the largest Hispanic group, about 60 percent of the one million Hispanic residents in Dade County, Miami's metropolitan area. They also derive political and economic power from being, in the words of a Princeton University sociologist, Alejandro Portes, "the oldest, the most naturalized, the richest and the most solidarized" Hispanic group here.
But over the last two decades, new immigration and higher birth rates among other Hispanic groups have dramatically altered the composition of the Hispanic mix and given Miami a broader Latin American identity, demographers say.
They have also made the area's economy heavily dependent on international commerce, given politicians another group to cater to -- the non-Cuban Hispanic voter -- and maintained Spanish as a well-entrenched language, although with different accents.
So different that Alex Chamizo, 36, a Cuban-American whose family has owned La Esquina de Tejas for 30 years, says he feels "the way the Anglos felt when the Cubans came."
The immigration after Fidel Castro's revolutionary victory in 1959 turned Dade County, whose Hispanic population was only 5 percent in 1960, into a Hispanic stronghold. By 1990, 49 percent of the two million residents were of Hispanic descent. In 1995, the University of Florida estimated that the county's Hispanic residents had grown to 1.1 million, or 56 percent of the population.
But in the latest part of this demographic transition, another shift occurred. While Cubans accounted for 91 percent of all Hispanic residents in the county in 1970, the percentage dropped to 59 percent by 1990, despite a doubling of the Cuban population, to more than 550,000. The fastest-growing group during this period was what the Census Bureau lumps together under "other Hispanics," mostly Central and South Americans.
The Census Bureau released figures last month showing that Dade County would be losing population if not for immigration, which added nearly 200,000 residents from 1990 to 1996. Statistics from the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Dade County School District show that a significant number came from Colombia, Nicaragua, Peru, Honduras and the Dominican Republic, as well as Cuba and Haiti.
Hispanic sections in other large urban centers around the country like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago have also grown more diverse as the Hispanic population undergoes explosive growth that is expected to make it the nation's largest minority by 2005. But the impact has been greatest in Miami, where the Hispanic culture has become dominant.
In this most unassimilated of metropolitan areas, where the Hispanic majority is mostly foreign born, the diversity has transformed Miami into a Latin American center where billboards in Portuguese announce Brazilian drinks, international businesses like shipping, banking and travel are major employers and the main Spanish-language daily, El Nuevo Herald, reprints articles from 11 Latin American newspapers.
El Nuevo Herald's decision to begin publishing articles last month from newspapers like Venezuela's El Universal and Panama's La Prensa was aimed at giving readers "a more genuine flavor to the Colombian or the Venezuelan story," said the publisher, Alberto Ibarguen.
The idea reflected market realities -- about half of the newspaper's readership in Dade and Broward Counties is of Hispanic descent other than Cuban-American, he said -- but also Mr. Ibarguen's own interests. He was born in Puerto Rico, of a Puerto Rican mother and a Cuban father, has lived in Colombia and Venezuela and is married to an Argentinian.
"I'm representative of what this city is becoming," said Mr. Ibarguen, 53.
Nowhere are the changes more evident than in immigrant enclaves like Little Havana, the first stop for many newcomers, where the famed Cuban block party, Calle Ocho, (Eighth Street) had as its theme this year Festival of the Americas and where about half the storefronts have sprouted signs advertising travel to Central America or food staples like Salvadoran pupusas, grilled corn pancakes with stuffing.
At St. John Bosco Church, which opened in 1963 to tend to the religious and social needs of Cuban exiles, the founding pastor, Msgr. Emilio Vallina, says his Central American parishioners of today are poorer, lacking the Government aid or refugee services given to the Cubans when they first arrived.
While many new arrivals strain social services in the short term, their ties to Latin America have attracted more business and tourism, said Mayor Alex Penelas of Dade County. Every new flight that an airline adds to its routes, he said, creates 40 jobs.
Mayor Penelas, 35, American-born but of Cuban descent, was elected last year in an example of the consolidation of Cuban-Americans' political power in an area where they still lead in voter registration. But while most Hispanic elected officials here are Cuban, Mr. Penelas, a Democrat, said those elected countywide, like him, could not have won without building coalitions among five main blocs of voters: black, Jewish, Anglo, Cuban and non-Cuban Hispanic.
Political experts say that Hispanic groups like the Puerto Ricans and the Dominicans tend to vote more Democratic than Cuban-Americans here, but that others, like Colombians, seem to be just as Republican. All groups, however, often come together to elect Hispanic candidates regardless of party affiliation, the experts said.
Certain issues like welfare reform have also caused Hispanic groups to unite in the past. With more younger Cubans voting Democratic, according to voter samples, "in a way the Hispanic population in Dade County is up for grabs," said Dario Moreno, a political science professor at Florida International University.
The Hispanic gains in numbers and power have been accompanied by an exodus of non-Hispanic whites, who made up about 30 percent of the county's population in 1990, and increasing frustration among black residents, who comprised about 20 percent and are now the most vocal in trying to insure political and economic participation.
But grumblings of dissatisfaction are also heard among Hispanic groups, from those who perceive the Cuban-Americans as giving preferential treatment to one another in jobs and government programs, or who have grown tired of the constant drumbeat against Castro's Cuba. "The challenge, of course, is to make everybody feel that they're part of this community," Mayor Penelas said. "There's no doubt about it. That's a challenge."
In this population mix, cultural clashes underlying a nation's prejudices inevitably come to the fore occasionally.
In Little Havana, the banning of a Puerto Rican singer from performing at the Calle Ocho festival last month because of his embrace of a famous songwriter from Cuba prompted the ire of Puerto Rican civic leaders.
Last year, when the president of the Latin Chamber of Commerce blamed newcomers, including recently arrived Cubans, for the trash piling up on Little Havana's sidewalks, he drew angry retorts from Nicaraguan organizations.
Intermarriages and voting patterns, however, show more cohesiveness than meets the eye. Julio Ospina, 57, a Colombian pawn shop manager, has married five times -- three times to fellow Colombians, once to a Cuban and once to a Peruvian, his current wife.
"Latins are very extroverted," he said. "It's easy to meet people here. To label somebody based on what country they're from is ignorant."
Leoncio Lazo, 70, a Domino Park regular for 17 years, agreed. "The Cuban generally gets along with everybody," Mr. Lazo said. "The only one he never gets along with is the Communist."
A number of the most active Hispanic organizations, including the Colombian American Service Association and the Puerto Rican Chamber of Commerce of South Florida, are nevertheless forming a coalition to give non-Cuban Hispanic residents a louder voice for their various interests.
"It's not us versus them," said Juan Carlos Zapata, 30, president of the Colombian association and a member of the Dade County Community Council, "but the time has come to say we want the same opportunities to do what you did."
In an area where change is the only constant, it may not be clear until the 2000 census whether Cuban demographic erosion continued through the 1990's, experts say. Because of the 1994 accords between the United States and Cuba that allow for a steady migration of at least 20,000 Cubans each year to this country, there is talk among sociologists of a "re-Cubanization" of Miami.
But as younger generations grow more Americanized, the question is what cultural imprint Miami can expect. The tone will be pan-Latin, sociologists say.
"Little by little, when the population becomes more American and less immigrant, they'll develop more of a sense of being Hispanic or Latino and will develop more unity," said Silvia Pedraza, a sociology professor at the University of Michigan and an expert on ethnicity. "Having the cities become more diverse is the first ingredient in the development of a Hispanic identity in the United States."

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: The Doctor as Investor -- A special report.;
For Biggest Hospital Operator, A Debate Over Ties That Bind

BYLINE: This article is by Martin Gottlieb and Kurt Eichenwald, with computer analysis by Josh Bar banel. 

 BODY:
The offer made Dr. Richard Rubinson uneasy. Shortly after the Columbia Hospital Corporation took control of the Miami hospital in 1993 where he had long practiced, the company gave him and other doctors the chance to buy up to 20 percent of the institution by investing up to $150,000 each. As investors, the company explained, the physicians would share in the hospital's financial risks and rewards.
Such investment offers are common in American industry. Yet to Dr. Rubinson, the former president of the Dade County Medical Society, medicine is not just any industry. He feared that his interests as an investor might conflict with his duty as a doctor to act in the best interests of patients. Columbia's investment deals, he felt, gave doctors "the implicit understanding that the more patients there were, the more the return on your little piece would be." 
 It was, the 60-year-old thoracic surgeon said, "a message I just didn't want to respond to." He declined Columbia's offer.
In the last few years, several thousand doctors have been offered such investments by Columbia, now known as the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest health care company, with about 350 hospitals and hundreds of other medical facilities. Some, like Dr. Rubinson, have begged off. Many others have not.
Hospitals, of course, have long recruited doctors with generous enticements -- like signing bonuses, consulting contracts and outright purchases of their practices. For Columbia, able to bring vast wealth to the courting game, these deals have been instrumental in the drive to dominate medical marketplaces.
But, because their financial returns are tied directly to those of their hospitals, the doctor-investors are stepping into different and, to many health care experts, troubling territory. Not only do they raise the kind of ethical issues that so worried Dr. Rubinson; some of the investments are raising legal questions as well.
In recent months, Columbia's financial relationships with its doctors have come under heightened legal scrutiny. The Federal agency that runs Medicare is examining whether Columbia doctor-investors are violating a Federal conflict-of-interest law when they send patients to services like home care that are operated through hospitals where they have stakes. Many of the investors in El Paso were served with search warrants as part of a Federal inquiry involving the company. And a doctor who invested in a Columbia partnership in Texas has sued the company, saying that some of its deals with physicians violate the law.
To examine the investments' effects, The New York Times analyzed referral patterns of 62 doctors in the Miami area. Since Columbia does not make partnership records public, the study was based on limited information. But it showed that after investing, the doctors as a group referred more patients than before to Columbia hospitals and fewer to competing hospitals. Columbia called the study flawed and said investments did not influence admissions.
Though a handful of far smaller companies also offer doctors investments, Columbia has used them from its inception and is their most forceful proponent. After putting a hold on such plans for several years, while absorbing hundreds of new acquisitions, Columbia has started to offer them again.
Bringing doctors on as investors, the company's executives say, is nothing more than an effort at smoothing the often-fractious relationship between hospitals and physicians. They say the investments give doctors an identification with the company's mission. This, they say, leads to savings -- because the investors are thus more prone to listen to reasonable plans for economies -- and to improvements in care that come through the cooperation with the hospital that is needed in the era of managed care.
"We believe that physician integration is best achieved if we -- Columbia and doctors -- have a common vision of our future and share in governance, risk, reward and ownership," said Dr. Frank M. Houser, president of Columbia Physician Services.
But many medical professionals look at this new doctor-hospital relationship and come away asking questions like these:
With hospital administrators pressing to cut costs, will doctors with investments acquiesce more easily to cuts in nursing care and other services? With hospitals increasingly forced to accept fixed payments for care, no matter how much they actually spend to provide it, will doctors shrink more readily from ordering medically beneficial but costly tests and treatments?
And will the investments influence where doctors send patients? Especially, will they tend to refer patients who cannot pay, and others with costly cases, to hospitals where they do not have a stake and refer the more profitable ones to their investment hospitals? And will they tend to send patients to outside medical services in which the company has a stake, even if such treatment is not medically necessary or could be provided more effectively elsewhere?
Some of these issues are akin to ones faced by the far larger, and steadily growing, number of physicians who receive fixed payments for managed care patients and so have an incentive to limit treatment.
In interviews, many doctor investors said the investments had no effect on the way they treated patients.
"The thing that drives physicians on where they send people is where they can get their best care," said Dr. Magdalena Averhoff, an investor in Columbia Cedars Medical Center in Miami who is on the company's national board.
But in a brief written in support of the Texas doctor's lawsuit against Columbia, three of the country's most prominent physicians argue that by their nature, the investments confound a doctor's loyalties.
The investments, along with other incentives, "take physicians into uncharted waters, where conflicts of interest abound and the separation between business and professional aims is obscured," wrote the doctors, C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General; Arnold S. Relman, former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine, and James S. Todd, former executive vice president of the American Medical Association.
"No longer are physicians the trustees solely for their patients' interests," they wrote. "They become in addition agents for a corporate enterprise which regards patients as customers."

The Enticements
Long String of Lures For Local Doctors
Landing Dr. Jerry Enis, a Miami orthopedic surgeon, was a coup for Columbia. When he left Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach in 1992, he took more than 250 patients a year to two Columbia hospitals.
Dr. Enis said he saw Columbia's executives as "pioneers" committed to improving medicine. In joining Columbia, Dr. Enis also became an investor, with $45,000 in Cedars Medical Center and $15,000 more in Miami Heart Institute. But what tipped the balance, he said, was a package of perquisites including the $2.5 million purchase of a struggling office building he owned.
"It was enough of a stimulus for me to make the change," he said. "I would be a provider for the Columbia hospital system and bring my patients there."
With deals like these, Columbia follows a well-worn, legally sanctioned path. Long before investment deals were offered, hospitals wooed doctors with lucrative benefits.
Benefits vary widely. For example, in El Paso, records show, one Columbia hospital paid large consulting fees to a number of doctors -- about $500,000 in 1994 to 10 doctors alone. In Tampa, Fla., Dr. R. R. Vijay, a heart surgeon, receives $90,000 a year for his work as a medical director; he uses two-thirds of it for a helicopter to take him to work.
Yet such deals can unnerve some doctors. Consider Dr. Jerry Niernberger, a family practitioner in Wichita, Kan., who was saddled with $40,000 in student loans. When talks on a joint venture fell apart between Columbia and the group practice where he worked, the company began picking off the group's physicians with handsome offers.
Dr. Niernberger's contract with the practice imposed strict financial sanctions if he joined a competitor. But he said Columbia offered to pay the penalty if he joined a company hospital. Beyond that, he said, the company's package included a large guaranteed increase in income, a signing bonus and the retirement of student loans.
"That money was sitting there," Dr. Niernberger recalled. "My life would be so much easier." But in the end he balked. Working for Columbia did not appeal to him, and as for the offer's extravagance, he said, "I felt pretty uncomfortable about that."

The Investments
A Crucial Element From the Beginning
From Columbia's earliest days, winning doctors' loyalty with investments was as important as wooing them with attractive financial offers. With the investments, Columbia brought to hospitals the kind of arrangements sweeping through American medicine, with doctors owning pieces of businesses like labs and CAT-scan centers.
The company offered the investments at 15 of its first 23 acquisitions. Then, as now, Richard L. Scott, Columbia's chairman, explained their rationale as simple.
"If someone has an ownership interest in something, they take pride in that, and so they will try to have whatever impact they can," he said last year. "It's really less that physicians invest, and it's more that we offer them the opportunity to be our partner."
But loan records from Citicorp, one of Columbia's bankers, show that at their inception the investments were seen as a way to insure that doctors would send patients to Columbia rather than to rivals. Because of that, Citicorp viewed the investments as a central rationale for approving a $54 million loan to the company for its first hospital acquisitions, in El Paso.
In a 1988 memo, for example, Michael E. Wendling, a Citicorp officer, noted enthusiastically that Columbia planned to "increase market share through the use of physician partnerships to capture existing patient flows from competing hospitals."
In June 1988, Mr. Scott wrote Mr. Wendling that the partnership plan would help the company increase its admissions. "Based on the census controlled by the new physicians subscribing to limited partnership units," as well as that of earlier investors, he wrote, "we believe we have more than sufficient physician support to meet our projections."
For months, the El Paso partnership plan directly linked investments by doctors and new admissions. One document explaining the partnership investments cited the example of a hypothetical doctor who could expect $41,538 annually on a $30,000 investment. That extraordinary return was mainly based on the assumption that the doctor would bring in $600,000 worth of patient business.
When the Texas Medical Association called that link unethical, Columbia dropped it.
In an April 1989 letter to Representative Pete Stark, a California Democrat critical of the partnerships, Mr. Scott defended the investments as intended solely "to improve the quality of health care services." He added, "There is no evidence that El Paso Healthcare System influenced the physicians to change their referral patterns."
That is not what the company's bankers thought. Even after the direct link between admissions and investment returns was dropped, the bankers saw the partnership as a key to filling beds. "Substantial cash flow is paid to physicians" through the partnerships, Mr. Wendling wrote in July 1989. "This is good in that it has helped boost volume."
Mr. Stark's outrage over that era of medical deal-making led him to write two laws sharply curtailing doctors' ability to invest in medical facilities where they refer patients.
But Columbia was able to continue offering investments because of an exemption in the Stark laws that lets doctors have stakes in hospitals, as opposed to enterprises like home health agencies and laboratories. The intent, in part, was to promote the growth of rural medical services. The company interpreted the exemption as allowing investments in hospital networks, effectively giving referring doctors ownership of services in which they could otherwise not invest. It is this aspect of the investments that Medicare authorities are investigating.
In Corpus Christi in 1992, the passage of the second Stark law appeared to imperil doctors' investment in a Columbia CAT-scan center. Partnership records show that Columbia folded the CAT-scan service into a local hospital, and traded the doctors' old shares for a new stake in the hospital.
"Indirect ownership didn't change anything," said Dr. James Thompson, an investor in the CAT-scan center.
And so, in Mr. Stark's view, Columbia has taken his law and "turned it upside down."

The Impact
A Debate Over Effect On Patient Care
When Columbia offered shares in Cedars in 1993, Dr. Howard Katzman and his partners invested $15,000. Turning a profit, the surgeon said, was not the point. "My group invested for one reason only: we felt it was important for us to show our dedication to the institution," he said. "It allows you to have some influence over the planning."
The investments usually work like this: Columbia sets up a partnership that owns a hospital or group of medical facilities; doctors with admitting privileges -- and a handful of administrators -- can buy up to 10 partnership units for $10,000 to $15,000 each, giving them aggregate ownership of up to 20 percent; as Columbia executives see fit, the doctors receive distributions from the hospitals' cash flow.
Some doctors claim returns of far more than their original investment in a few years; others say they would have done better buying Columbia stock. Doctors at Cedars say that last year a $15,000 investment led to a $4,000 payout -- a higher return than those seen by most investors in the stock market.
If doctors leave the hospital or are incapacitated and cannot practice, they must sell their shares back. If they divorce, they must sell. Columbia does not want any outsiders to have ownership.
The chairwoman of the American Medical Association, Dr. Nancy W. Dickey, said another aspect of the plans, limiting the offerings almost exclusively to doctors, appeared to violate the group's ethical guidelines.
Many experts say these limitations indicate Columbia's intentions: to influence behavior. Columbia executives say, though, that the investments are too small to affect doctors' medical decisions. They added that, with the huge growth of managed care, doctors have less ability to decide where their patients go.
His group's investment, Dr. Katzman said, "has not influenced where we put patients one speck." Dr. Averhoff, the Florida physician, said the investment had not altered her admissions either. She said any differences in her referral pattern stemmed from such factors as patients' preference and managed care agreements.
Because Columbia, citing privacy concerns, refuses to provide names of its doctor-investors, it is difficult to analyze whether investments change admitting patterns. But using limited records on file in Florida, The Times examined admission patterns of 62 investors at Cedars and Miami Heart, which both offered investments in 1993.
In order to best examine the effects of the investments, The Times sought to identify doctors who had not bought into previous Columbia partnerships. Admissions patterns of the 62 doctors indicated that they had no previous connection with two other hospitals with investment plans that were merged with Cedars and Miami Heart.
The study found that between 1992 and 1995, their annual referrals to the Columbia hospitals where they invested rose 13.4 percent, while their referrals elsewhere dropped 22.4 percent. Within the pattern, doctors' practices varied widely. Excluding the referrals from Dr. Enis, the high-admitting orthopedic surgeon, the pattern still held, with admissions to the investment hospitals increasing 6 percent over the period and decreasing by 11 percent to other hospitals.
David L. Manning, a Columbia vice president, produced a company study of University Medical Center in Tamarac, Fla., that he said showed that investments had not influenced admissions. He called the Times survey "highly questionable" and said it was based on "what appears to be a biased sample of physicians." The study was flawed, he said, because it did not account for such factors as physician specialty, the impact of managed care contracts and patient preferences.
But John Cuddeback, an associate professor of health policy at the University of Florida who developed a hospital "report card" for the state, said The Times had used criteria "well above" those employed in the medical industry for decision-making. The results, he said, established "some degree of evidence that there's a difference of behavior" that calls for further study.
To some, the reason for such changes is self-evident. "It's as if you go into a car diagnostic clinic and the guy also has a car-repair facility," said John T. Cusack, a lawyer for nonprofit hospitals. "Lots of times he's going to tell you the car has to be fixed."
But to others in the field, the investments can have subtler consequences. With doctors on Columbia's side, they say, it is easier for Mr. Scott to undertake the cost-cutting initiatives sweeping the industry. "He had to seduce the doctors to be on his side of the trench warfare so when he lays off some nurses they're not going to shoot at him, they're going to be with him," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University. "Doctor investments were a key to that."

The Questions
Financial Favors Lead To a Doctor's Doubts
As investigators sift through documents seized from Columbia in El Paso, a stack of papers sits in a Houston courthouse, spelling out accusations of impropriety in Columbia's deals with physicians. The papers stem from a lawsuit brought by Dr. Thompson of Corpus Christi. In it, he contends that the company violates Medicare laws prohibiting kickbacks to doctors for their referrals.
The financial incentives spelled out in Dr. Thompson's lawsuits included cut-rate office space and far more. Columbia sent him on fishing and hunting trips. Columbia also sold him a $15,000 stake in its Corpus Christi network, he says, and gave him a $500-a-month no-show consulting job to pay for it.
"I was told that the consultant fee would go on until the investment cash was paid back," said Dr. Thompson, who produced copies of pay stubs. "There was nothing I did that merited a consulting fee."
The break point for him came after what he described as a Columbia favor to other doctors -- at his expense. Columbia let an obstetrics group bar all but obstetricians from delivering babies at the hospital. That shut out Dr. Thompson, whose practice heavily focused on obstetrics.
He consulted a lawyer and sued. In August, the case was dismissed on a technical ruling that did not address the substance of his allegations; he is appealing.
A number of influential parties have written briefs in his support, including Dr. Koop, Representative Stark and the Justice Department.
While none of those parties could attest to the truth behind Dr. Thompson's contentions, they forcefully spoke of the legal and public policy importance of the issues he raised. Columbia declined to comment because of the pending litigation.
But Dr. Thompson was left with simple questions. "It all makes you question every admitting decision you make," he said. "Am I doing this for the right reason, or am I doing this for the wrong reason? It is just kind of a burden to think about."
 
How the Study Was Done
 To analyze the behavior of physician investors in Florida, The New York Times obtained disclosure statements filed by Columbia/HCA hospitals with the State of Florida listing investors who referred patients to outpatient services.
It then matched these names against state and Federal physician license and identification numbers, and then against a file of more than 1.1 million patient discharge records in Dade County from 1992 to 1995.
The study focused on the behavior of new investors in a Columbia/HCA investment plan at two hospitals, Cedars Medical Center and the Miami Heart Institute. Because the company declined to provide any information about investors, the study used hospital records to select doctors who were attending physicians at these hospitals, but had no connection with two other hospitals where investment plans were already in place. About a third of all investors identified from disclosure forms were included.
The study may also have missed some doctors who invested in hospitals but were not listed on the Florida disclosure forms, and is subject to errors in the way hospitals listed investors and admitting physicians. JOSH BARBANEL

HEADLINE: Once the Hope of Secular Turks, Ex-Leader Is Now Widely Reviled

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 5

 BODY:
When Tansu Ciller became Prime Minister of Turkey in 1993, millions of Turks joined Western leaders in rejoicing. She seemed the ideal figure to lead her country toward the next century: an English-speaking economist, a woman in a Muslim country, and a dedicated secularist in a region where fundamentalism was making steady gains.
Much has changed in four years. Today Mrs. Ciller is Foreign Minister and a leading member of a coalition Government headed by a Muslim-based party. Many Turkish political leaders accuse her of forging the alliance to shield herself from a series of inquiries into her personal finances. 
 "They haven't formed a government partnership but a partnership in crime," asserted Mesut Yilmaz, the main opposition leader. Mr. Yilmaz was Prime Minister in a short-lived coalition with Mrs. Ciller that fell apart last spring after he indicated that the would support an investigation of the charges against her.
Parliamentary investigators, leading political figures and Turkish newspapers have been examining how Mrs. Ciller and her husband, Ozer Ciller, became multi-millionaires. They have raised questions about her statement that she inherited more than $1 million in cash and gold from her mother, a woman whose former neighbors have described as a penniless pensioner.
Mrs. Ciller's critics have also examined the purchase in 1992 of $1.5 million worth of properties in New Hampshire by an American company headed by her husband. They say Mr. and Mrs. Ciller enriched themselves through illicit use of Government funds in her years as Prime Minister from 1993 to 1996. Some opposition figures have even suggested that Mrs. Ciller once held American citizenship, which if true could complicate her political position here. They have sued in Federal court in New York to obtain her passport records.
While the United States has declined to confirm or deny the existence of such documents, it is fighting the legal action. The State Department has said that disclosing any foreign official's passport records could cause "great disadvantage, and perhaps personal and familial danger, abroad."
Mrs. Ciller has denied any wrongdoing. Tim Platt, her New Hampshire lawyer, said she has never held an American passport or been an American citizen. Mr. Platt also said her investments in the United States comply fully with American law.
Some aspects of Mrs. Ciller's rise to the status of a multi-millionaire, however, remain unclear. She has said, for example, that some of her wealth stems from wise investment of the $1.1 million inheritance from her mother, who died in 1995.
But neighbors of Muazzez Ciller said this week that she had lived near poverty in a shabby Istanbul apartment, and doubted that she could have left such a substantial sum.
"This poor woman was sick and barely had enough to eat," said one resident of the building where the elder Mrs. Ciller lived. "We used to do her shopping, wash her dishes and help her cook because she couldn't afford a maid. She got in trouble with the landlord because she was always late with the rent. If she had any money, I'm sure she would have used it to make her life a little easier."
Mr. Platt said that the elder Mrs. Ciller had made "personal and life style choices" not to spend her savings. "The fact that she held cash at home or in a safe deposit box is not inconsistent with the practice of people in her society at the time."
Questions about Mrs. Ciller's finances were of little interest outside Turkey until June, when she astonished many world leaders by agreeing to join in a coalition government with the Islamic-oriented Welfare Party. Until then she had bitterly attacked Welfare, calling it a fundamentalist threat and vowing never to cooperate with it.
Under the coalition agreement, the Welfare Party leader, Necmettin Erbakan, became Prime Minister and Mrs. Ciller became Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister.
After the alliance was sealed, Mr. Erbakan's supporters in Parliament helped Mrs. Ciller defeat a series of proposals -- some of which they themselves had filed while in opposition -- that would have referred questions about her wealth to the Supreme Court.
The move in Parliament has led critics to charge that a deal has been struck under which Mrs. Ciller keeps the Welfare party in power and, in exchange, it protects her against judicial investigation.
Charges of corruption and abuse of power began to swirl around Mrs. Ciller as she ended her term as Prime Minister. In recent months the charges have become a major topic of public discussion. This year Mrs. Ciller has faced a series of parliamentary votes on charges that she illicitly diverted funds from several Government-owned companies, including an electric utility, an auto manufacturer and a hotel chain. The closest vote, however, came not on motions based directly on those charges but on one that asked the Supreme Court to investigate the source of her wealth.
Mrs. Ciller agreed to an interview in February to discuss the charges against her, but canceled it moments after Parliament voted 270-263 not to send charges against her to the Supreme Court. The vote was along party lines. Afterward her office provided a statement that said:
"The parliamentary commission conducted an extensive inquiry into Mrs. Ciller's finances, releasing publicly numerous confidential tax returns and financial documents which she provided voluntarily. The commission issued a report of over 300 pages and cleared her of any improprieties. The Parliament has confirmed that finding and the matter is now closed.
"Parliamentary inquiries into two other allegations, which were clearly of a political nature, have also resulted in a finding that she acted properly. She has been fully cleared of all charges. No other inquiries involving Mrs. Ciller are now pending."
Under Turkish law, Parliament cannot reopen any investigation within one year after it has been closed. But some Turks believe the charges against Mrs. Ciller will not fade away.
"These dossiers will be opened sooner or later and taken to an independent judiciary," predicted Mehmet Kececiler, deputy chairman of the opposition Motherland party.
Many former allies of Mrs. Ciller say they are furious at her for having formed a coalition with the Islamic party against which she had campaigned so strenuously. Among them is Husamettin Cindoruk, one of the patriarchs of Turkish politics, who is a former chairman of her True Path party and served as president of Parliament from 1991-95.
"Tansu Ciller is what allowed the Welfare party to come to power," Mr. Cindoruk said. "She agreed to form a coalition with Welfare because they promised they would shield her from investigations. This has brought great trouble to Turkey."
Mrs. Ciller has explained her decision to form the coalition Government by saying she serves as a check on Prime Minister Erbakan, assuring that he does not stray too far from Turkey's secular traditions. There is evidence that she has succeeded on several occasions. Mr. Erbakan, for example, has bowed to her wishes and dropped his proposal to allow female civil servants to wear veils or head scarves.
Aides to the Prime Minister have defended his decision to form a coalition with Mrs. Ciller. As the top vote-getter in the December 1995 election, he was at the center of bargaining to form a Government.
"He had the plurality, he was the No. 1 candidate," one senior official said today. "He was ready to form a coalition with anyone. He tried from the beginning with each party. He tried it first with Mesut Yilmaz, but it didn't work out. Then he took up the effort with Ciller."
Turkish news reports based on reviews of the Cillers' property holdings here, which include homes, apartment buildings and large plots of land, put their net worth in the tens of millions of dollars. Mrs. Ciller says that she and her husband built their fortune largely from the inheritance from her mother and another of several hundred thousand dollars from her father.
Among the Ciller family's investments was the purchase in the early 1990's of a Holiday Inn in Salem, N.H., and the Granite State Business Center in Hooksett, N. H. The property was bought by GCD, a New Hampshire company. Mr. Ciller and his family have a controlling interest in the company, according to Mr. Platt, the New Hampshire lawyer.
The $1 million purchase was paid for with five treasurer's checks, according to copies of the checks provided by the Turkish opposition. Mr. Platt declined to say how that money was raised, and whether it was borrowed.
Mrs. Ciller attended colleges and taught for a time in the United States, but she has steadfastly denied reports that she held a United States passport for a time. Her lawyer, Mr. Platt, said she could not have done so because she lived in the United States for less than the required five years.
A New York lawyer who represents a member of the Turkish parliamentary commission that investigated Mrs. Ciller, Jerrold L. Morgulas, has filed suit in Federal court seeking release of Mrs. Ciller's passport and immigration records. A Federal judge hearing the case expressed deep skepticism about that suit in a recent hearing.
In addition to the accusations of financial impropriety, Mrs. Ciller has been touched by one of the most serious scandals in recent Turkish history, which began unfolding in November when a senior police official was killed in a car crash along with a convicted heroin smuggler who was being sought by Interpol.
Also in the car was an influential member of Parliament from Mrs. Ciller's party. Questions about what they were doing together quickly resulted in the resignation of the Interior Minister, a close ally of Mrs. Ciller, and led to a series of disclosures about Government sponsorship of death squads during the last 20 years.
Several of the most spectacular "mystery killings" occurred while Mrs. Ciller was Prime Minister, and some politicians say they suspect that officials of her Government may have ordered or approved them. Many of the victims were suspected of maintaining ties to the separatist guerrilla army that calls itself the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K.
Evidence that has come to light since November suggests that senior Government officials approved such killings. There has been no proof that Mrs. Ciller was involved, but several political figures have publicly accused her.
"In November 1993 Mrs. Ciller said at a press conference that she had a list of businessmen, artists and other people who were helping the P.K.K.," said Esat Canan, who was a member of Parliament at the time. "She said she was going to eliminate this problem. After that, people started to get killed one after another. I think there is a connection. If she knew the names of people who were guilty of illegal acts, why didn't she have them brought to trial?"
This year, officials of several European governments have charged that Turkish drug traffickers seem to have enjoyed official protection. "There have been incidents where information definitely got back to drug dealers," said Tom Sackville, a British Home Office minister.
A German judge who was hearing a case against three accused Turkish heroin smugglers told reporters in January that he believed the smugglers had "personal contacts" with Mrs. Ciller. Pressed for details, he said he would give none until he issues his verdict.
The Turkish Foreign Ministry filed a diplomatic protest after the judge made his charge, describing it as "an unproven, unfounded, totally unacceptable allegation."

HEADLINE: In Fujimori's Peru, Economy Grows As a Democracy Is Left to Wither

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 5

 BODY:
On this day five years ago, President Alberto K. Fujimori stunned this country when he disbanded Congress and the courts to seize sweeping powers that he said were needed to end corruption and terrorism that were rampant in Peru.
While the rest of Latin America was abandoning military dictatorships, Mr. Fujimori deployed tanks and troops outside the Congress and the Palace of Justice, suspended the Constitution, and imposed harsh measures to combat terrorism and revive the faltering economy. 
 Today, despite the hostage crisis at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here, Peru is undeniably a safer, more economically viable country. Many Peruvians say they believe that those successes are the direct results of Mr. Fujimori's "autogolpe," or "self-coup."
But while Mr. Fujimori was overwhelmingly voted to a second term in 1995, many of his authoritarian policies remain in place.
The police have broad powers to arrest anyone they suspect of terrorism. People accused of terrorism are tried in military courts where there is no due process.
Many political experts say Peru is less democratic today than it was before Mr. Fujimori assumed emergency powers on April 5, 1992.
"Democracy before the coup was very weak in Peru, but five years later I am convinced it's even weaker," said Carlos Basombrio, director of the Legal Defense Institute, a leading human rights group.
"The legacy of Mr. Fujimori's coup," he said, "is that the Peruvian Army now has more autonomy than any military in Latin America, the judiciary is less independent and has more Draconian laws on the books, and there is no real political party system to speak of."
Many leading politicians and scholars here and abroad say that Mr. Fujimori could have accomplished his goals without abolishing constitutional rule and that by doing so he made Peru a country where power is heavily concentrated in the executive branch.
They cite the lack of civilian control over Peru's military, which Mr. Fujimori has repeatedly absolved of widespread human rights abuses committed during its crackdown on leftist rebels, and Peru's judicial system, which under Mr. Fujimori's control has convicted hundreds of Peruvians of terrorist acts and sentenced them to long jail terms.
"The way Mr. Fujimori sees the world is: 'We will do it my way or we won't do it at all,' " said David Scott Palmer, who teaches Latin American politics at Boston University.
"Compromise and negotiation are not part of Mr. Fujimori's calculation, and whether it comes to democracy or negotiating an end to the hostage takeover, his reactions are part of the same continuum that began with the imposing of martial law in 1992," Mr. Palmer said.
Indeed, some foreign diplomats and relatives of hostages who are being held by Marxist guerrillas here have expressed concern that Mr. Fujimori's autocratic style has been a major stumbling block in resolving the crisis, now nearly four months old.
Last week, mediators between the Peruvian Government and guerrillas reached the outline of a tentative agreement to end the standoff, by which the rebels would give up their captives and leave Peru in exchange for a chance at early parole for some of their jailed comrades.
But as the details of the pact were being worked out, Mr. Fujimori backed away from it. Diplomats familar with the talks said he had become concerned that he would appear to have given in to a major rebel demand -- freedom for their jailed colleagues.
"While we have respect for our President, we are worried that he has not learned how to compromise, especially when human lives are at stake," said the wife of a high-ranking Peruvian Government official who is being held hostage, speaking on condition of anonymity. "We are afraid that if Mr. Fujimori will not compromise, he could resort to a military solution."
Mr. Fujimori, whose office did not return telephone calls requesting an interview, has said that his actions in 1992 were the only way to save the country. He said Congress and the courts had refused to endorse reforms needed to fight terrorism.
Martha Chavez, a Congresswoman who is in Mr. Fujimori's party, said declaring martial law was the President's only feasible option five years ago because Congress was gridlocked and would have taken too long to approve the needed measures. "What Mr. Fujimori did five years ago was valiant, brave, and absolutely necessary to save Peru," she said. "Have we forgotten so quickly what life was like during that time? Bombs were exploding all around us. We were afraid to venture outside."
Mrs. Chavez said Mr. Fujimori's "coup" gave Peruvians hope that the Government could defeat terrorism, particularly in the provinces where civilian patrols were established with the military to resist guerrilla groups that were wrecking havoc on rural villages.
Opinion polls have shown that most Peruvians approved of Mr. Fujimori's dissolving of Congress and the courts, which were seen as corrupt and detached from the people. The President's popularity skyrocketed after the capture in September 1992 of Abimael Guzman Reynoso, leader of the Shining Path, a Maoist guerrilla group, and the subsequent capture of 30 other leaders.
But many political analysts say that while Mr. Fujimori deserves much credit for curbing terrorism and revitalizing Peru's economy, those achievements have been incorrectly tied to his "self-coup."
"Mr. Fujimori has done an excellent job of convincing the Peruvian people that the coup was necessary to defeat terrorism and accomplish other reforms," said Cynthia McClintock, a professor of political science and expert in Latin America at George Washington University. "The truth is that long before the coup took place, the Congress and Mr. Fujimori were close to an agreement on the judicial and economic reforms and that the intelligence unit that would eventually capture the guerrilla leaders was already in place."
Mr. Fujimori's critics say he is beholden to the generals who backed him in 1992 and has failed to bring the military under full civilian control.
A former Cabinet member who is still close to Mr. Fujimori said the President wanted to replace Gen. Nicolas Hermoza, who has served as commander of the army since 1991, but that Mr. Fujimori cannot act because General Hermoza is revered within the armed forces and does not want to leave.
In return for the military's support, Mr. Fujimori persuaded Congress to pass a broad amnesty law last year absolving the military of human rights abuses committed during its fight against guerrillas.
"Fujimori and the military were partners in the coup d'etat -- they made a pact to govern together and keep each other happy," said Lourdes Flores Nano, a Congresswoman from the opposition Popular Christian Party.
"We say it's time to end this joint venture between the President and the military and allow free democratic rule," Miss Flores said. "So far, Mr. Fujimori has been unable to do this."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 38; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: THE RENT DEBATE: THE OVERVIEW;
Studies Suggest Tenants In Upscale Neighborhoods Would Be Hit the Hardest

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
Half a century after it was introduced and six weeks before it could pass into extinction, rent regulation in New York remains a thoroughly contested policy. Landlords and tenants disagree in fiercely emotional and often surprisingly personal terms not only about the system's philosophical merits, but also about how it actually works and what would happen if it expired.
Underlying their bitter differences, however, are some basic realities. 
 Landlords have suggested that the effects of deregulation on rents would be modest. Yet for many tenants, even a 10 percent rent increase could be significant. And a recent study of deregulation sponsored by a landlord association put the average increase for a rent-stabilized apartment at more than 13 percent.
Tenant groups have, for obvious political reasons, tried to portray the battle over the rent laws as one that affects residents of all neighborhoods of New York City, where most of the state's rent-regulated apartments are located. But the effects of lifting the rules that regulate 1.1 million apartments would clearly be felt disproportionately in different parts of the city.
In some of the city's poorest neighborhoods, rents might hardly be affected at all, while in the most fashionable areas, huge increases would be a virtual certainty. The same landlord-sponsored study predicts that rents would rise by almost 30 percent in Greenwich Village and by more than 50 percent on the Upper West Side.
Both sides acknowledge that rent regulation encourages tenants to stay put, even as they disagree sharply about whether this is a good thing. Landlords argue that many rent-regulated tenants hold onto apartments longer than they need to, which in turn causes shortages and forces other tenants to pay higher prices. Tenants argue that the lack of turnover promotes stability and preserves the complex texture of many New York neighborhoods.
Without rent regulation, "you would lose any kind of economic integration," Michael McKee, the rent law campaign manager for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, said.
There have been battles over rent regulation in New York in the past, but few have been as fierce or as anxiety-ridden as the current one.
For the first time in recent memory, one of the state's legislative leaders, the Senate Majority Leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, has declared his opposition to renewing the regulations. And Gov. George E. Pataki, whose position on the issue has often seemed purposefully ambiguous, has said that he is willing to allow the rent laws to lapse when they expire, or "sunset," on June 15.
Almost without exception, economists side with those who oppose rent regulation; artificially holding down the price of housing, they contend, inevitably limits the supply for everyone. Even liberal-leaning economists who favor some sort of housing subsidies see rent regulation as wrongheaded because it does not benefit those who need it most.
"Economists who don't think of themselves as conservative would still say this is a very inefficient way to redistribute income," Alan Auerbach, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, said.
At the same time, even many opponents of regulation acknowledge that lifting the rent laws alone will not solve New York's chronic housing shortage. Already, new buildings that have not received special tax breaks are not subject to rent regulation. Yet even in relatively good economic times, residential construction in New York has lagged behind that in other cities.
Perhaps just as significantly, economic principles and astute politics do not always go hand in hand, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani demonstrated last week when he vowed to march with tenants in Albany. While there are many New Yorkers outside the system who might benefit from ending rent regulation, those inside the system care more about the issue and are better organized.
"The people who are harmed don't even know they're being harmed," Peter Salins, an urban economist who is provost of the State University of New York and an outspoken critic of rent regulation, said. "So they can't act as an interest group."

A Confusing Patchwork
A Mix of Laws Regulating Rents
 Although New York's rent laws are frequently lumped together under the term "rent control," the laws are actually a patchwork of state and city regulations of which rent control is only one piece. All told, the regulations cover roughly half of the city's rental apartments and 2.5 million tenants.
The city's rent laws cover two types of apartments. The first group, rent-controlled housing, covers apartments built before 1947 where the tenants have been in continuous occupancy since 1971; the definition of the word "continuous" is a flexible one. Many people in rent-controlled apartments pass them on -- both legally and illegally -- to relatives, people who tenants say are relatives, and even friends. According to the latest city housing survey, there are slightly more than 70,000 rent-controlled apartments left. Of all the regulated housing, these apartments tend to have the lowest rents.
The city's second category, rent-stabilized housing, covers apartments built between 1947 and 1968 as well as some more recent apartments for which landlords have sought special tax benefits. There are roughly 290,000 of these, and their rent increases are set each year by the Rent Guidelines Board. Last year, the board allowed increases of 5 percent for one-year leases and 7 percent for two-year leases.
It is the state, rather than the city, that regulates the largest group of apartments. These are apartments that were built before 1947 but no longer fall under rent control because the tenants have not been in continuous occupancy. There are roughly 760,000 such apartments in New York City, and another 60,000 in Nassau, Westchester and Rockland Counties. These are also known as rent-stabilized apartments, and in New York City their rent increases are also determined by the Rent Guidelines Board.
Together, the city and state have taken a few thousand apartments out of regulation under so-called "luxury decontrol," which went into effect in 1993. These are apartments with rents above $2,000 a month and tenants with annual incomes of more than $250,000.
Luxury decontrol has proved difficult to administer, and it is estimated that many apartments eligible for decontrol are still, in fact, under rent regulation.
Just last week, Mayor Giuliani, with a great flourish, signed a bill extending the city's rent regulations for three more years. At this point it is unclear how the city's regulations would be affected if state rent regulations were allowed to expire.

After Deregulation
In Manhattan, Rents Could Rise Sharply
Mary Sibak, 60, has lived with her husband in a one-bedroom apartment in Hell's Kitchen for 36 years. Her rent is $171 a month. She does not work, and her husband, who is employed in a warehouse, brings home less than $400 a week, she said.
Standing outside her building, on 44th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues, Mrs. Sibak said she had heard about the debate in Albany and was deeply distressed. "The day they raise the rent is going to be just terrible," she said. "People are going to be on the streets."
Rent regulation is often debated on an anecdotal level. But for every anecdote about a Hollywood star who keeps a rent-controlled pied-a-terre, there is a string of stories about people like Mrs. Sibak, who have held onto their apartments simply because they cannot afford to leave.
"Where are you going to move?" Mrs. Sibak asked.
That ending rent regulation would have a significant impact on a neighborhood like Hell's Kitchen, and indeed throughout midtown and lower Manhattan, is beyond question. The reasons are to a certain extent obvious: the more desirable the location, the more pressure on rents.
The city's own research shows that rent regulation has held down rents in Manhattan more than anywhere else.
According to the city's most recent housing survey, the median unregulated rent in Manhattan in 1993 was $1,030 a month. By comparison, the median was $400 a month for a rent-controlled apartment and $620 a month for a rent-stabilized apartment. In the Bronx, the median unregulated rent was $600 a month, while the median rent-controlled rent was $349, and the median rent-stabilized rent was $450.
Manhattan also has a disproportionately large number of rent-regulated apartments; roughly a third of all stabilized units are in Manhattan.
But how the effects of ending rent regulation, or phasing it out through so-called vacancy decontrol, would play out through the rest of the city is more difficult to gauge.
This difficulty is perhaps best illustrated by the very different results predicted by two recent studies. Both were sponsored by the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's largest landlord association.
The first study predicts that, under deregulation, the typical stabilized rent in midtown and lower Manhattan would increase by 6 percent, or $43 a month.
Throughout the city, in all five boroughs, the typical stabilized rent would rise by only 2 percent, or $7 a month, this report argues.
The second study assumes that deregulation would compel landlords to spend significantly to upgrade apartments, and it reaches a dramatically different conclusion about the impact on rents.
That study predicts that in the first several years following deregulation, the average rent of a former rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan would rise by $175 a month, or 22 percent.
Meanwhile, it forecasts that the average stabilized rent citywide would increase by 13 percent, or $90 a month.
Tenant groups argue that both studies probably understate the impact of deregulation. And they further contend that what matters is not only the size of the increases but also the income of the tenants affected.
"Yes, there's a bigger spread in Manhattan," Mr. McKee, of the Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, said.
"But that doesn't mean there's no difference outside of Manhattan. And for the people who are living in those neighborhoods, it's a very significant difference."

Lessons of 1974
A Brief Experiment With Rent Decontrol
 New York is one of the few remaining cities in the country that still has rent regulation; most municipalities got rid of their systems after World War II. Boston, another long holdout, lifted its controls in 1994.
But at least in theory, even in New York rent regulation has always been considered temporary, as the continual "sunsetting" of the rent laws attests.
In 1971, New York briefly experimented with ending rent regulation; under a measure passed by the State Legislature that year, all apartments under rent regulation were to be deregulated as soon as the existing tenants moved out. The experiment, however, was short-lived; in 1974, the Legislature passed the Emergency Tenant Protection Act, which placed formerly rent-controlled apartments under state rent stabilization.
As with most every other aspect of rent regulation, the effects of this experiment are hotly contested.
The experiment took place during a time of increasing inflation and rising fuel prices, and many argue that it was too short to draw any reliable conclusions from it. Nonetheless, the experiment has had -- and continues to have -- a significant impact on the debate.
A 1974 report by a commission headed by then-Assemblyman Andrew Stein argued that the experiment was a failure, Decontrol, the report maintained, had caused rents to shoot up, but had "neither stimulated new building construction" nor "spurred renovation." Tenant groups continue to cite this report as evidence that deregulation would lead to price-gouging but little improvement in the city's housing.
Landlords, however, maintain that the Stein Commission misrepresented its own findings. They continue to point to a rise in new construction in 1972 as a sure sign that housing in New York would improve as a result of decontrol.
The Stein Commission, according to the Rent Stabilization Association, "reached conclusions based on a political agenda, and not on the facts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Supporters of rent regulation picketed the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, in March as he met with other Republicans in Manhattan. Mr. Bruno favors ending most rent controls in the next two years. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

As city, state and census data make clear, the stakes are huge: more than a million apartments are regulated. SECTION: Section 8; Page 3; Column 1; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Referee Draws Her Line on the Court

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THE maiden challenge came in the very first summer pro league game, when one overgrown adolescent took exception to a foul. The complaint began with "Man," ended with "call," and in between contained a couple of four-letter embellishments, which the referee intuitively knew could not be ignored.
"Technical foul," the ref said, index finger targeting the culprit, who was only about to make things worse. 
 "What's a woman doing here anyway?" he whined.
Dee Kantner's explanation was dismissively short and sweet.
"I am, you're not," she said. "You're gone."
As power doesn't necessarily beget respect, 36-year-old Dee Kantner understands that her prospective employment as one of two female officiating pioneers in the National Basketball Association next season is likely to be a tricky business. She and 32-year-old Violet Palmer of Los Angeles, both of whom called last Sunday's Old Dominion-Tennessee women's national championship game, are scheduled to join a group of professional martyrs trained to take much abuse, but not too much.
It is difficult enough for men working men's games to make split-second decisions on when the line of fair comment has been crossed. Next season, Kantner and Palmer will establish the guidelines for women. Actually, they will make them up as they go along.
"Hopefully," Kantner said from her home in Charlotte, N.C., "I'm intelligent enough to determine whether it is respectful or disrespectful."
In developmental leagues and two N.B.A. preseason games last fall, Kantner considered it just part of the banter and byplay when players addressed her as Legs, or complained about a "women's call," or when one player impishly pleaded with her that "we need a little lovin' down at the other end."
She does not expect players and coaches to be gender blind. "Off the floor, they can open the door for me, I don't care," she said. "On the floor, I just want to be recognized as someone doing the job."
That this would even be an issue for Kantner or Palmer, that we have nearly reached the millennium without a woman's officiating a major men's sport, speaks to a mind-set of fatuous denial. If players don't believe that women can effectively officiate their games, how do they explain that so many of them, as products of single-parent homes, have had lives totally dependent on Mom?
Come to think of it, there may be one person on the face of the planet who, in the heat of battle, might be spared Anthony Mason's evil eye. His mother, Mary.
That said, competence and acceptance are two different things. These last couple of years have on various basketball levels brought outrageous and thuggish abuses of officials. Are kids imitating what they have seen Dennis Rodman and Nick Van Exel -- to name two N.B.A. ref-strikers -- do on television, or does the N.B.A. merely reflect a young America that is awash in violent imagery, in many cases beginning at home?
Probably both. For sure, the N.B.A.'s rowdy young have been influenced by a rap culture that is often degrading to women, which may help explain why Kenny Anderson, during the Chicago-Portland preseason game, reportedly responded to a foul call by telling Kantner to keep her eyes on the game and off his pants.
Kantner said she recognized that Anderson "was clearly testing her." The following morning, she picked up a Chicago newspaper to discover that Michael Jordan (female consumers, take note) was just as clearly judging her.
"Too slow," Commissioner Jordan opined. "She got in the way."
"The one time I got in the way, I had no place to go," Kantner said. She added that if her quickness were an issue, then bring on her male counterparts. She'd be happy to race.
One person's good call is another's grounds for protest. Officiating, Kantner knows, is a far more interpretive craft than her day job as an engineering sales rep. But there is one component to her "game" that she will not even debate, and that is conditioning.
It is a source of pride for a 5-foot-8-inch, 145-pound multisport athlete who attended the University of Pittsburgh on a field hockey scholarship. And it is one reason Dale Brown, who recently retired as Louisiana State coach, invited her at the 1991 National Sports Festival to officiate an exhibition that fall between L.S.U. and Australia. Ground was broken and, before long, she was in an N.B.A. officials camp, she and 75 men.
At the women's Final Four, Tennessee's Pat Summitt said she did not see coaching men as a "step up." Summitt, a five-time national champion, earns more than Tennessee's men's coach. Juggling her sales job with about 80 major college women's games a season, Kantner has spent a good part of the last 10 years working on five or six hours' sleep. This is about better opportunity, for her and -- with many N.B.A. officials facing tax evasion charges and possible unemployment -- perhaps for others like her.
"People say, 'Do you know what you're in for?' " she said. "I say, 'Let's hope I'm not completely shell-shocked.' "
That is just her little joke. She expresses supreme confidence and talks of her "responsibility" to the N.B.A.'s call as if it is a calling. The players may answer her calls, too, as long as they do so with respect.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 26; Column 1; National Desk
