HEADLINE: Town Pins Hopes on Superfund Site

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: ANACONDA, Mont., April 4

 BODY:
When the last vestiges of copper mining and smelting here closed in 1980, left behind were a towering smokeless smokestack, hundreds of unemployed smelter workers and a landscape strewn with a century's worth of hazardous waste.
Now revitalization efforts are under way. This company town without a company is not looking toward copper to breathe life back into its languishing economy, however, or any other kind of mining, for that matter. 
 It is looking at golf.
As the fairways and tees green up next month, an $11 million, 200-acre golf course designed by Jack Nicklaus will open in this down-at-the-heels industrial town of about 10,000 people.
It is an unlikely place for such state-of-the-art golfing. The 18-hole course is sandwiched between a low-income housing project and the Cedar Lanes Bowling Alley, beneath the mountains on the edge of town that have been denuded by decades of noxious smelter fumes.
Anaconda sits about a mile in elevation and its winters are long. There is still a little snow on the course. Major markets are a long way off; the nearest metropolitan area with a population of one million is Salt Lake City, about 500 miles away. The whole state of Montana has fewer than 900,000 people.
Even more unusual is that the undulating course is part of the reclamation of an Environmental Protection Administration Superfund site and sits on top of the ruins of the old smelter. In fact, the Old Works Golf Course has an industrial smelting theme that carries right down to the black slag, or smelting waste, used in the bunkers and the cranes and old heavy equipment scattered around the grounds.
"It's the first Superfund golf course," said Derf Soller, superintendent of the course for Golden Bear Club Services, which is owned by Mr. Nicklaus and which manages the course. "It's absolutely safe. It's a low-level Superfund site. It's not radioactive. The metals in the soil are inert and the whole site has been capped."
Reclamation of the site cost $30 million and was paid for by the Atlantic Richfield Company, which bought the Anaconda Copper Mining Company in the 1980's. Elaborate steps have been taken, with consultation by the E.P.A., to make sure arsenic and heavy metals in the soil do not affect people and do not get washed off the course to contaminate nearby Warm Springs Creek. Sheets of plastic lie under the fairways, bunkers and greens, and all water drains into a contained artificial lake. Most of the ground was covered with crushed limestone, which in turn was capped with 16 to 18 inches of clay and which was then covered with six to eight inches of sand.
"It's safe," said Charlie Coleman, project manager for the site for the E.P.A. Making a golf course on a Superfund site, he said, is part of a trend toward using reclaimed land, rather than just fencing it off.
"You can't just pick up this volume of waste and move it somewhere," Mr. Coleman said. "It's too expensive. Our goal is to make these properties useful."
Despite the improvements, great care was taken to keep the flavor of the days of the smelter intact.
The greens and fairways, for example, lie on land that stretches in front of the ruins of two 19th-century smelters. The ore mined from the "Richest Hill On Earth" by the Anaconda company in Butte, 26 miles away, was hauled here for processing. The brick clubhouse has been built in a style of local historic architecture, and replica period street lights are being placed in the parking lot. Each hole bears the name of something to do with the smelter, such as Crusher, Silver Mill, Flue No. 5, Slum House and Anode.
Parts of the course sit on top of "heap roast" piles, mounds of charred, coal-black rock that were set afire decades ago to reduce ore into copper.
The sand traps, or bunkers, meanwhile, are actually called slag bunkers. The fill came from a mammoth pile of coal-colored residue left over from the days of the giant smelter. "The ball sits up on it real nice," Mr. Soller said. "Jack thought it was great."
The brick stack from the smelter towers over the town and the course. The smelter itself has been torn down.
The new economic course Anaconda is charting is a symbol of change in the West these days.
As mining and other traditional heavy industries diminish, towns are hoping to cash in on the booming tourist business.
Anaconda needs a ray of light in its bleak economy. The population of Deer Lodge County, of which Anaconda is the largest city, has dropped from a peak of almost 19,000 people in 1960 to 10,000 today. Numerous historic brick buildings from the 1800's sit boarded up and abandoned.
It remains to be seen whether the course, which is one of three in the area, will help the local economy much, and so far it has not sparked much new development. There are only about 50 motel rooms in town.
Mr. Soller is optimistic. More than two million tourists travel between Glacier and Yellowstone National Parks on nearby Interstate 90 in the summer, he said.
And with the greens fee for 18 holes around $28, the course should be a draw. Most Nicklaus-designed courses cost $70 to $100, Mr. Soller said.
Bill Edwards, the owner of the Cedar Lanes Bowling Alley, said it certainly could not hurt his business. "The summer months are slow for bowling," Mr. Edwards said, above the din of the crash of pins. "We've been out here in the middle of nowhere for a long time. This should bring a lot more people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A new golf course in Anaconda, Mont., was built on the ruins of a copper smelter, and the bunkers are filled with smelter residue instead of sand. The land was reclaimed through the Federal Superfund program. (Walter Hinick)
 
Map showing the location of Anaconda, Mont.: Some hope a golf course will revitalize a rundown industrial town.

HEADLINE: THE RENT DEBATE: BATTLE;
War of Nerves in Albany

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 5

 BODY:
Thousands of frightened and angry tenants are expected to swell the marbled corridors of the State Capitol in the coming week, demanding a stay of execution for the laws that limit rent increases on one million apartments in New York City and its suburbs.
Few issues in recent decades have generated such fear and loathing toward state government, since few issues so directly touch so many people, most of whom live in New York City. A change or a lapse in the regulations -- which are scheduled to expire after June 15 -- could cause rents to rise for thousands, perhaps millions, of tenants, undoubtedly straining the ability of many to stay in their homes. 
 With Albany's leaders vehemently at odds over whether to extend, revise or abolish the laws, there have been no negotiations, no offers of compromise -- just threats from Republicans to let the laws expire and demands from Democrats to keep them unchanged.
Most economists say that the rules hold down the housing supply, but opponents of deregulation contend that they keep neighborhoods stable. A middle ground seems unreachable. And tenants' anxieties are growing.
But in that anxiety lies the key to understanding the political strategies driving the rent war. Combatants on all sides are out to harness people's fears, trying to put the mounting panic to their best political use. Which raises the all-important question: who will use it most effectively, and who will be burned trying?
Leading the charge for opponents of the laws has been the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, an ardent advocate of deregulation who has called for ending rent protections over the next two years, except for the elderly, disabled and poor. With characteristic hyperbole, he has described rent regulations as more destructive to New York City than an atom bomb explosion and has predicted that lifting rent restrictions will spur developers to build new apartments and rehabilitate old ones by the thousands.
Mr. Bruno and other Senate Republicans received more than $200,000 in campaign contributions from groups representing landlords last year, though he says those donations did not influence his stance against rent restrictions.
Mr. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, has threatened to let the existing rent laws expire after June 15 if his demands for their abolition two years from now are not met -- something he can singlehandedly do by blocking any bill in the Senate that would extend the rules.
If Mr. Bruno succeeds, the rent protections that now benefit more than two million New Yorkers would expire after June 15. That does not mean rents would immediately go up, but once leases expire, landlords could begin the process of raising rents to market levels.
Though Mr. Bruno has said repeatedly that he did not want to frighten anyone, it is patently clear that fear is at the core of his strategy. He is, after all, counting on Democrats -- who are the laws' staunchest defenders -- to come limping to the bargaining table out of pure dread that the rules will lapse.
There, he hopes, they will accept this bargain: that weakened protections are better than no protections.
Mr. Bruno underlines this strategy almost every time he speaks on the issue by reiterating his intention to let the laws die after June 15. The Democratic-controlled Assembly has already passed legislation to extend rent controls, but of course it takes both houses to pass a law (as well as the Governor's signature).
On Monday, Democrats in the Republican-controlled Senate say they will move to bring a bill extending the rent laws to the Senate floor; Mr. Bruno has said he will block it, which would reinforce his threat to let the laws expire in June, unless Democrats bow to his will.
Asked in a recent interview what would happen if the Democrats failed to take his threat seriously, he replied, "If they are stupid enough to do that, they will make the biggest mistake that they have made this year."
He added that the Democrats "have tested me a number of times," and lost.
Not that Assembly Democrats are without considerable power. They can -- and clearly will, if necessary -- hold up the budget and every piece of legislation pending in Albany this session if Mr. Bruno refuses to consider a compromise on rent protections.
The Democrats also believe that tenants' fears will work to their political advantage. Not by moving Mr. Bruno, whose power base is upstate and who has little to lose by alienating New York City tenants, but by pressuring Gov. George E. Pataki to rein in the majority leader, his fellow Republican.
Mr. Pataki, the Democrats reason, wants to expand his very small base of support in New York City in preparation for his 1998 re-election campaign. Gutting or abolishing the rent laws will cause a huge backlash against the Governor, and his political handlers will simply not accept that, the Democrats contend. And the Democrats have made it clear that they will do their best to focus blame on the Governor.
Mr. Pataki won office in 1994 with scant support from New York City voters, and might again. But that is always a risk, especially since the large turnout upstate in the last election was unusual and Mr. Pataki, who won the vast majority of upstate votes, probably cannot count on either the large turnout or such overwhelming support again. And he is said to harbor higher political aspirations; unpopularity in New York City would presumably not help his future.
"If the laws expire, it will be the Governor's inaction that brings that out," said the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, the Legislature's most powerful Democrat, in a recent interview.
Of the three leaders, Mr. Pataki is, in many ways, in the most awkward spot. He is under growing pressure from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been speaking out more forcefully on the matter, to preserve the laws. Even Mr. Pataki's political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- who is also up for re-election next year -- has criticized Mr. Bruno for stoking the public's fears.
But that fear could work to the Governor's benefit, as well. Mr. Pataki has tried to cast himself as a mediator, the lone moderate capable of finding a middle ground -- even though his long-term support for ending rent controls on vacant apartments puts him much closer to Mr. Bruno's end of the spectrum than Mr. Silver's.
Under Mr. Pataki's script, public panic will make it easier for him to push for a compromise -- and, in the end, appear the savior for millions of tenants. "He's saying, 'When it's time for the cavalry, I'll come riding in,' " said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute in Hamden, Conn. "He'll be John Wayne."
But the political risks are also much greater for Mr. Pataki. Voters almost always blame governors more than legislators for Albany's failures -- so he is more likely to be the target of tenants' wrath if the rent laws lapse or are severely weakened.
The Governor's aides say he is fully aware of the Democrats' strategy to hold him accountable for changes to the laws. But they say Mr. Pataki will not be pressured into simply extending the rules because he believes they should be gradually phased out -- though he has refused to say exactly how.
As if to send a message to the Democrats that he will not blink first as the June 15 deadline approaches, Mr. Pataki said recently, "I hope it doesn't take something like the expiration of laws to force serious negotiations. But if it does, it does."
With all sides locked into a game of chicken, there have been no negotiations, nor even talk about holding negotiations. Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver have not budged from their positions and Mr. Pataki has been keeping mum on his, trying leave himself wiggle room for a final compromise.
But what that compromise might be is anyone's guess. Several possibilities float on the horizon. One option is to expand the policy known as luxury decontrol, where controls are ended for more expensive apartments rented by wealthier people.
Another is moving toward the type of system now used in Los Angeles, where restrictions on rent increases apply to occupied apartments, but rents are allowed to jump to market rate whenever units are vacated.
These are things no one is willing to discuss because no one wants to be perceived as caving in to the other side. The battle lines are drawn, the combatants frozen in place, waiting for someone else to move first. And tenants sit on the sidelines, biting their nails.
"This is all designed to make tenants and their supporters panic and give in and swallow some poison-pill amendment," said Michael McKee, director of the rent-regulation campaign for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "And we are prepared to fight right through the summer if we have to."

HEADLINE: Donald E. Maude, 55, Economist Known as Inflation Policy Expert

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Donald E. Maude, chief economist of the United States unit of Scotia Capital Markets in Toronto and a former senior economist for Merrill Lynch, died on March 27 at New York Downtown Hospital. He was 55.
The cause of his death was a heart attack, his wife, Kathleen Gustos Maude of Shrewsbury, N.J., said. 
 Mr. Maude first gained attention as a financial economist in the late 1970's, when rising oil prices and tightening credit sent the nation's economy into one of the most turbulent periods of the postwar era. From 1978 to 1984, as he rose to the post of chief financial economist at what is now Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, Mr. Maude was frequently sought out by the news media for commentary on the effects of the Federal Reserve's anti-inflation campaign on financial markets.
As the economy became less unsettled in the mid-80's, the employment prospects for financial economists became more so, and Mr. Maude held positions at several Wall Street firms before finally joining Scotia Capital Markets in 1992. At Scotia, owned by the Bank of Nova Scotia, he was chief United States economist and a member of the board of Scotia Capital Markets (U.S.A.) Inc., its American subsidiary.
He continued to be sought out by the financial media for his views on economic developments, and appeared frequently as a guest commentator on "Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser" and on CNBC, the financial news cable channel.
Mr. Maude, a resident of Shrewsbury, was a former member of the board of trustees of Monmouth College, where he received his undergraduate degree in business administration in 1963. He received his master's in economics from the University of Missouri in 1965.
Mr. Maude was a member of the Money Marketeers of New York University, the Downtown Business Economics Club and the National Association of Economists.
Besides his wife, he is survived by a son, Kevin L. Maude, and a daughter, Alison K. Maude, both of Shrewsbury; a brother, Lawrence P. Maude of Fort Washington, Pa., and a sister, Judith M. Steiner, of Miami.

HEADLINE: Allen Ginsberg, Master Poet Of Beat Generation, Dies at 70

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON

 BODY:
Allen Ginsberg, the poet laureate of the Beat Generation whose "Howl!" became a manifesto for the sexual revolution and a cause celebre for free speech in the 1950's, eventually earning its author a place in America's literary pantheon, died early yesterday. He was 70 and lived in the East Village, in Manhattan.
He died of liver cancer at his apartment, Bill Morgan, a friend and the poet's archivist, said. 
 Mr. Morgan said that Mr. Ginsberg wrote right to the end. "He's working on a lot of poems, talking to old friends," Mr. Morgan said on Friday. "He's in very good spirits. He wants to write poetry and finish his life's work."
William S. Burroughs, one of Mr. Ginsberg's lifelong friends and a fellow Beat, said that Mr. Ginsberg's death was "a great loss to me and to everybody."
"We were friends for more than 50 years," Mr. Burroughs said. "Allen was a great person with worldwide influence. He was a pioneer of openness and a lifelong model of candor. He stood for freedom of expression and for coming out of all the closets long before others did. He has influence because he said what he believed. I will miss him."
As much through the strength of his own irrepressible personality as through his poetry, Mr. Ginsberg provided a bridge between the Underground and the Transcendental. He was as comfortable in the ashrams of Indian gurus in the 1960's as he had been in the Beat coffeehouses of the preceding decade.
A ubiquitous presence at the love-ins and be-ins that marked the drug-oriented counterculture of the Flower Children years, Mr. Ginsberg was also in the vanguard of the political protest movements they helped spawn. He marched against the war in Vietnam, the C.I.A. and the Shah of Iran, among other causes.
If his early verse shocked Eisenhower's America with its celebration of homosexuality and drugs, his involvement in protests kept him in the public eye and fed ammunition to his critics. But through it all, Mr. Ginsberg maintained a sort of teddy bear quality that deflected much of the indignation he inspired.
He was known around the world as a master of the outrageous. He read his poetry and played finger cymbals at the Albert Hall in London; he was expelled from Cuba after saying he found Che Guevara "cute"; he sang duets with Bob Dylan, and he chanted "Hare Krishna" on William F. Buckley Jr.'s television program. As the critic John Leonard observed in a 1988 appreciation: "He is of course a social bandit. But he is a nonviolent social bandit."
Or as the narrator in Saul Bellow's "Him With His Foot in His Mouth" said of Mr. Ginsberg: "Under all this self-revealing candor is purity of heart. And the only authentic living representative of American Transcendentalism is that fat-breasted, bald, bearded homosexual in smeared goggles, innocent in his uncleanness."
J. D. McClatchy, a poet and the editor of The Yale Review, said yesterday: "Ginsberg was the best-known American poet of his generation, as much a social force as a literary phenomenon.
"Like Whitman, he was a bard in the old manner -- outsized, darkly prophetic, part exuberance, part prayer, part rant. His work is finally a history of our era's psyche, with all its contradictory urges."
Allen Ginsberg was born on June 3, 1926, in Newark and grew up in Paterson, N.J., the second son of Louis Ginsberg, a schoolteacher and sometime poet, and the former Naomi Levy, a Russian emigree and fervent Marxist. His brother, Eugene, named for Eugene V. Debs, also wrote poetry, under the name Eugene Brooks. Eugene, a lawyer, survives.
Recalling his parents in a 1985 interview, Mr. Ginsberg said:
"They were old-fashioned delicatessen philosophers. My father would go around the house either reciting Emily Dickinson and Longfellow under his breath or attacking T. S. Eliot for ruining poetry with his 'obscurantism.' My mother made up bedtime stories that all went something like: 'The good king rode forth from his castle, saw the suffering workers and healed them.' I grew suspicious of both sides."

An Authorization For a Lobotomy
Allen Ginsberg's mother later suffered from paranoia and was in and out of mental hospitals; Mr. Ginsberg signed an authorization for a lobotomy. Two days after she died in 1956 in Pilgrim State Hospital on Long Island, he received a letter from her that said: "The key is in the window, the key is in the sunlight in the window -- I have the key -- get married Allen don't take drugs. . . . Love, your mother."
Three years after her death, Mr. Ginsberg wrote "Kaddish for Naomi Ginsberg (1894-1956)," an elegy that many consider his finest poem.
Strange now to think of you, gone without corsets & eyes, while I walk on the sunny pavement of Greenwich Village,
downtown Manhattan, clear winter noon, and I've been up all night, talking, talking, reading the Kaddish aloud, listening to Ray Charles blues shout blind on the phonograph
the rhythm, the rhythm -- and your memory in my head three years after -- . . .
"Kaddish" burnished a reputation that had been forged with the publication of "Howl!" three years earlier. The two works established Mr. Ginsberg as a major voice in what came to be known as the Beat Generation of writers.
Mr. Ginsberg's journey to his place as one of America's most celebrated poets began during his college days. He first attended Montclair State College. But in 1943, he received a small scholarship from the Young Men's Hebrew Association of Paterson and enrolled at Columbia University. He considered becoming a lawyer like his brother, but was soon attracted to the literary courses offered by Mark Van Doren and Lionel Trilling, and switched his major from pre-law to literature.
At Columbia he fell in with a crowd that included Jack Kerouac, a former student four years his senior, Lucien Carr and William Burroughs, and later, Neal Cassady, a railway worker who had literary aspirations. Together they formed the nucleus of what would become the Beats.
Kerouac and Carr became the poet's mentors, and Kerouac and Cassady became his lovers. It was also at Columbia that Mr. Ginsberg began to experiment with mind-altering drugs like LSD, which would gain widespread use in the decade to follow and which Mr. Ginsberg would celebrate in his verse along with his homosexuality and his immersion in Eastern transcendental religions.
But if the Beats were creating literary history around Columbia and the West End Cafe, there was a dangerous undercurrent to their activities. Mr. Carr spent a brief time in jail for manslaughter, and Mr. Ginsberg, because he had associated with Mr. Carr, was suspended from Columbia for a year.
In 1949, after Mr. Ginsberg had received his bachelor's degree, Herbert Huncke, a writer and hustler, moved into his apartment and stored stolen goods there. Mr. Huncke was eventually jailed, and Mr. Ginsberg, pleading psychological disability, was sent to a psychiatric institution for eight months. At the institution, he met another patient, Carl Solomon, whom Mr. Ginsberg credited with deepening his understanding of poetry and its power as a weapon of political dissent.

Becoming a Protege Of the Poet Williams
Returning home to Paterson, Mr. Ginsberg became a protege of William Carlos Williams, the physician and poet, who lived nearby. Williams's use of colloquial American language in his poetry was a major influence on the young Mr. Ginsberg.
After leaving Columbia, Mr. Ginsberg first went to work for a Madison Avenue advertising agency. After five years, he once recalled, he found himself taking part in a consumer-research project trying to determine whether Americans preferred the word "sparkling" or "glamorous" to describe ideal teeth. "We already knew people associate diamonds with 'sparkling' and furs with 'glamorous,' " he said. "We spent $150,000 to learn most people didn't want furry teeth."
The poet said he decided to give up the corporate world "when my shrink asked me what would make me happy." He hung his gray flannel suit in the closet and went to San Francisco with six months of unemployment insurance in his pocket. San Francisco was then the center of considerable literary energy. He took a room around the corner from City Lights, Lawrence Ferlinghetti's bookstore and underground publishing house, and began to write.
During this period, Mr. Ginsberg also became part of the San Francisco literary circle that included Kenneth Rexroth -- an author, critic and painter -- Gary Snyder, Michael McClure, Philip Whalen, Robert Duncan and Philip Lamantia. He also met Peter Orlovsky, who would be his companion for the next 30 years.
His first major work from San Francisco was "Howl!" The long-running poem expressed the anxieties and ideals of a generation alienated from mainstream society. "Howl!," which was to become Mr. Ginsberg's most famous poem, was dedicated to Solomon, and begins:
I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness, starving hysterical naked,
dragging themselves through the negro streets at dawn looking for an angry fix,
angelheaded hipsters burning for the ancient heavenly connection to the starry dynamo in the machinery of night. . . .
Mr. Ginsberg read the poem to a gathering arranged by Mr. Rexroth, and those present never forgot the poem, its author or the occasion.
Mr. Rexroth's wife privately distributed a mimeographed 50-copy edition of "Howl!" and in 1956, Mr. Ferlinghetti published "Howl! and Other Poems" in what he called his "pocket poets series."
With its open and often vivid celebration of homosexuality and eroticism, "Howl!" was impounded by United States Customs agents and Mr. Ginsberg was tried on obscenity charges.
After a long trial, Judge Clayton Horn ruled that the poem was not without "redeeming social importance."
The result was to make "Howl!" immensely popular and establish it as a landmark against censorship. The outrage and furor did not stop with the sexual revolution. As late as 1988, the radio station WBAI refused to allow "Howl!" to be read on the air during a weeklong series about censorship in America.
There were almost as many definitions of Beatniks and the Beat movement as there were writers who claimed to be part of it. As John Clellan Holmes described it, "To be beat is to be at the bottom of your personality looking up." But if the movement grew out of disillusionment, it was disillusionment with a conscience.
Mr. Ginsberg tried to explain the aims of the Beats in a letter to his father in 1957: "Whitman long ago complained that unless the material power of America were leavened by some kind of spiritual infusion, we would wind up among the 'fabled damned.' We're approaching that state as far as I can see. Only way out is individuals taking responsibility and saying what they actually feel. That's what we as a group have been trying to do."
On another occasion, he described the literary rules more succinctly: "You don't have to be right. All you have to do is be candid." Mr. Ginsberg was nothing if not candid.
As he wrote in "America," another 1956 poem, which took aim at Eisenhower's post-McCarthy era:
America I've given you all and now I'm nothing
America two dollars and twentyseven cents January 17, 1956
. . .
America this is quite serious
America this is the impression I get from looking in the television set
America is this correct?
. . .
Mr. Ginsberg said the poets who formed the prime influence on his own work were William Blake, Walt Whitman, Ezra Pound and Williams. He declared he had found a new method of poetry. "All you have to do," he said, "is think of anything that comes into your head, then arrange in lines of two, three or four words each, don't bother about sentences, in sections of two, three or four lines each."
His disdain for poetry's traditional rules only gave ammunition to his critics. James Dickey once complained that the "problem" with Allen Ginsberg was that he made it seem as if anybody could write poetry.

Traveling Widely For Two Decades
Mr. Ginsberg used the celebrity he gained with "Howl!" to travel widely during the next two decades. He went to China and India to study with gurus and Zen masters and to Venice to see Pound. On his way home, he was crowned King of the May by dissident university students in Prague, only to be expelled by the Communist Government. He read his poetry wherever he was allowed, from concert stages to off-campus coffeehouses.
He was in the forefront of whatever movement was in fashion: the sexual revolution and drug culture of the 1960's, the anti-Vietnam war and anti-C.I.A. demonstrations of the 1970's, the anti-Shah and anti-Reagan protests of the 1980's. In 1967 he was arrested in an antiwar protest in New York City, and he was arrested again, for the same reason, at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1968. He testified in the trial of the so-called Chicago Seven.
Through it all, he kept writing. After "Kaddish" in 1959, major works included "TV Baby" in 1960, "Wichita Vortex Sutra" (1966), "Wales Visitation" (1967), "Don't Grow Old" (1976) and "White Shroud" (1983).
In his celebrated career, Mr. Ginsberg received many awards, including the National Book Award (1973), the Robert Frost Medal for distinguished poetic achievement (1986), and an American Book Award for contributions to literary excellence (1990).
In 1968, Cassady died of a drug overdose. Kerouac died of alcoholism the next year. By the mid-1970's, Mr. Ginsberg had helped start the Jack Kerouac School of Disembodied Poetics of the Naropa Institute in Boulder, Colo., a Buddhist university where he taught summer courses in poetry and in Buddhist meditation. He also was becoming one of the last living voices of the Beat generation and the keeper of the flame.
In 1985, Harper & Row published Mr. Ginsberg's "Collected Poems," an anthology of his work in one volume that firmly established the poet in the mainstream of American literature. The poet again made tours, showing up on television shows, but this time he was in suit and tie offering a sort of explanation of his work.
"People ask me if I've gone respectable now," he said to one interviewer. "I tell them I've always been respectable."
During another interview, he confessed: "My intention was to make a picture of the mind, mistakes and all. Of course I learned I'm an idiot, a complete idiot who wasn't as prophetic as I thought I was. The crazy, angry Philippic sometimes got in the way of clear perception.
"I thought the North Vietnamese would be a lot better than they turned out to be. I shouldn't have been marching against the Shah of Iran because the mullahs have turned out to be a lot worse."
But despite his suit and tie, the censors continued to look over Mr. Ginsberg's shoulder. During the interviews, David Remnick, then of The Washington Post, accompanied him to CBS's "Nightwatch." A producer, unfamiliar with the poet's work, asked if he would read something on the show.
"How about reading that poem about your mother?" she suggested.
" 'Kaddish,' yes. Time magazine calls it my masterpiece," Ginsberg replied. "But I don't know. . . ."
The poet pointed to a word in the poem he doubted would make prime time. As Mr. Remnick reported, the producer's eyes glazed over and there was a long silence.
"Your mother's . . .?" the producer said in horror.
"Couldn't we just bleep that part out?" the poet offered, always helpful.
"No," the producer said.
"It's O.K.," the poet replied. "I've got other poems."
 
Social Conscience Plus Sex and Drugs
What sphinx of cement and aluminum bashed open their skulls and ate up their brains and imagination?
Moloch! Solitude! Filth! Ugliness! Ashcans and unobtainable dollars! Children screaming under the stairways! Boys sobbing in armies! Old men weeping in the parks!
Moloch! Moloch! Nightmare of Moloch! Moloch the loveless! Mental Moloch! Moloch the heavy judger of men!
-- From "Howl!" (1955-56)
America I still haven't told you what you did to Uncle Max after he came over from Russia
I'm addressing you.
Are you going to let your emotional life be run by Time magazine?
. . .
It occurs to me that I am America
I am talking to myself again.

 -- From "America" (1956)
And how Death is that remedy all singers dream of, sing, remember, prophesy as in the Hebrew Anthem, or the Buddhist Book of Answers -- and my own imagination of a withered leaf -- at dawn --
Dreaming back thru life, Your time -- and mine accelerating toward Apocalypse,

HEADLINE: Mojave Park Supporters Fight Plans for Dump

BYLINE: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFF

DATELINE: JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., April 3

 BODY:
Rugged canyons, sagebrush and sunburned plains stretch in a majestic void across the Mojave Desert. But if you hike among some of this arid preserve's most desolate slopes and thorny wilderness, the spectacular view comes to an abrupt, ugly end.
The abandoned pit of the Eagle Mountain iron mine, two miles outside the park, to the southeast, is the focus of an intense dispute between developers who want to fill the enormous hole with trash, and environmentalists who fear that a dump would harm the fragile desert habitat. Fueling the debate are questions about economics, location and aesthetics that mirror the conflict over encroaching development near many of the nation's most revered natural and historic treasures. 
 Donna Charpied, a critic of the Eagle Mountain plan, gazed at the scarred hillsides of the mine the other day from her jojoba farm near the rustic town of Desert Center and spoke of the potential damage to wildlife in the park. She lamented that her organically grown crops -- bushes whose seeds are used for oil in items like cosmetics -- could become contaminated and that the tranquil way of life in the scrub-covered Chuckwalla Valley would be altered for as long as the dump is open, an estimated 75 years.
"When it's 128 degrees here -- and that's not uncommon -- it's going to stink," Ms. Charpied said. "You can go to Los Angeles if you want to see more smog and Pampers hanging on trees."
The Riverside County Planning Commission is holding hearings on Eagle Mountain and will decide whether to recommend that the project be approved within a few months. County supervisors will then take up the decade-old issue and make a final ruling.
If the $150 million plan is carried out, Eagle Mountain will receive up to 20,000 tons of trash a day from Southern California, mostly by rail. Under the plan, garbage will be buried in nearby canyons or emptied into the 1,100-foot-deep, 1 1/2-mile-wide East Pit gouged by Kaiser Steel between 1947 and 1982, long before Joshua Tree's southeastern boundary was expanded to surround the property on three sides.
Even supporters say the landfill would affect the area's environment. The debate is over how much, and whether the project would infringe on the experience that visitors expect from this unique landscape known for its twisted Joshua trees, vast blue skies and blissful quiet.
Ernest Quintana, superintendent of the park, has been a critic of the plan from the start. He predicted that ravens, attracted by the trash, would flock to Joshua Tree and prey on threatened desert tortoises, and that glaring lights, plumes of dust and tractor noise could scare off the timid bighorn sheep that leap between boulders in the nearby Eagle Mountains.
In the end, however, the National Park Service has no jurisdiction over the area. Some of the land is privately owned and some is controlled by the Federal Bureau of Land Management.
"I'm just asking developers and supervisors to use their common sense," Mr. Quintana said. "Visitors to that part of the park go there expressly to put on their backpacks to be one with nature."
Rick Daniels, president of the landfill's developer, the Mine Reclamation Corporation, counters that his company would do everything possible to mitigate potential damage, including paying $1 per ton of garbage to preserve natural habitats. He promised that the company would bury trash every day, pave roads to eliminate dust and collect windblown garbage inside the park.
Mine Reclamation also signed an agreement with the National Park Service, agreeing to several environmental safeguards beyond what is normally mandated by law, like financing independent research to monitor the dump's effect on Joshua Tree. Mr. Daniels added that Eagle Mountain would generate 1,500 jobs and help alleviate a landfill shortage that is anticipated when several dumps close in coming years near Los Angeles, about 200 miles to the west.
"People would like to think that the trash they put out at night is picked up by the tooth fairy," he said. "I challenge anyone to find a better use for that property."
Crisscrossed by power lines, dune buggy tracks, prospectors' shacks and fighter jets on low-level practice runs, the Mojave Desert is far from the unblemished American West of movie lore. The sprawl could increase if several proposed development projects ever go through.
Ward Valley, near the Colorado River, is listed as a future underground nuclear waste storage site. The Army is planning to add 331,000 acres to its National Training Center at Fort Irwin to stage tank maneuvers. And two companies have proposed separate landfills to compete with Eagle Mountain, one on a dry lake bed 150 miles east of San Diego, the other near Amboy, 250 miles east of Los Angeles.
Relations between preservationists and developers in the Mojave have been especially testy since 1994, when Congress set aside nearly 1.4 million acres of land under the Desert Protection Act. Rather than protecting Eagle Mountain, the legislation designated it an appropriate site for a landfill.
Its location near a remote, roadless corner of Joshua Tree insures that few visitors would ever see the dump once it opens.
When told of the plan, Michael Williams, a hiker from Los Angeles, rolled his eyes and sighed. Then after pausing for a moment before lacing his boots and heading down a dirt trail, he added: "You have to put garbage dumps somewhere. But no matter where it goes, someone is bound to be upset."

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
Speedway Off to a Bumpy Start as Winston Cup Arrives in Texas

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, April 5

 BODY:
The folks at Texas Motor Speedway, which has its inaugural races this weekend, like to point out that eight Texas Stadiums could fit into the track's infield. Maybe so, but what really matters is whether some of that Jerry Jones-Dallas Cowboys marketing magic finds its way into the place.
O. Bruton Smith, the owner of Speedway Motorsports, which built and operates the $120 million track, is surely trying. In bringing Nascar racing to the Dallas-Fort Worth marketplace, Smith is holstering some big numbers: more than 150,000 seats, opening-weekend attendance that should exceed 250,000, a television deal with CBS that he says pays $4 million annually, and those new stadium money-makers, personal seat licenses. 
 With all that cash being tossed up like dust in a Texas tornado (did we mention the 76 track-side condominiums under construction that will sell for $275,000 to $575,000 apiece?), the raison d'etre for it all -- a 1.5-mile circle of asphalt about 20 miles north of downtown Fort Worth -- could almost get lost in the whirl.
Unless, of course, you are one of the people expected to drive around the place at about 190 miles an hour. The Winston Cup drivers who will race in the Interstate Batteries 500 Sunday -- and their minor league brethren in today's Busch Grand National Coca-Cola 300, which was won by the Winston Cup veteran Mark Martin -- haven't yet issued their decree on Smith's stately pleasure dome.
"When the race is over, there's going to be some people who love it and some who hate it," said Darrell Waltrip, who starts 14th today in the 500-miler.
One who might fall into the latter category is Ricky Craven, who fractured his right shoulder blade and sustained a concussion in a crash on the fourth turn on Thursday. That corner was the one predicted to be the James Dean bend by most drivers after early test runs. And during today's Busch race, Randy Porter hit the Turn 4 wall on Lap 66; he was taken to a hospital for precautionary X-rays.
Waltrip scoffed at the earliest dire predictions, made by colleagues after rain stopped the first day of group tests last month. "Some of those comments came from guys riding around in rental cars with the windshield wipers on," he said.
Nonetheless, Waltrip agrees that the turn -- which funnels onto a double-dogleg front "straightaway" -- could be trouble. "It's a little tight off of Turn 4," he said, "and the tri-oval on the front stretch doesn't lend itself to passing and side-by-side racing. Still, I haven't raced there yet, so I don't know for sure."
And when he does today, it will be cautiously. "Normally, you're a little apprehensive at first coming to a new track because you don't know the limits," Waltrip said. "Either you have to be the victim, or sit back and watch and say, 'I guess that's not possible.' "
One thing that turned out to be impossible as the opening weekend approached was holding school. The speedway traffic -- cars on the narrow rural highways can go only one way in the morning and the other way in the evening -- took care of that. The local school district decided to cancel classes for two days.
The idled student body did not even have to figure out how to sneak in; 5,000 free tickets, each accompanied by a soda and a hot dog, were there for the taking.
The Northwest Independent School District would gladly swap the free passes and franks for some tax revenue from the track, but it is not getting any. The property that the track occupies is owned by the Fort Worth Sports Authority, a quasi-public corporation set up by the city, and is leased back to Speedway Motorsports for $50,000 a year in an arrangement that exempts the track from property taxes.
The school district, estimating it is losing $1.5 million a year in revenue because of this arrangement, sued to collect the taxes, lost and has filed an appeal.
Fort Worth, in its quest to develop the desolate land around Ross Perot Jr.'s Alliance Airport, a booming corporate airfield on the city's northern fringes, has granted about $200 million in tax abatements to firms that have relocated there, near the speedway. Although the track is tax-exempt, Speedway Motorsports estimates it will have an annual economic impact of $160 million in the area.
The school district isn't having any of that. The students had to go to the track to get the free tickets after the district refused to distribute them. "What the race track does with their tickets has nothing to do with the school, and we'd like to keep it that way," said Larry Hutto, vice president of the Northwest school board. The district did keep the $500 check that the speedway sent as a donation after the school band played at a track function.
While the district is out tax revenue, about 125 families who lived in a mobile-home community that is now an RV parking lot for the track are out more. They were uprooted by the sports authority, which used its power of eminent domain to claim the land. And that has led to the other big dispute surrounding the track. Several homeowners are going to court, challenging the authority's offering price for their land -- and the subsequent higher offer awarded them by an arbitration panel -- as grossly unfair.
One homeowner was offered $18,000 by the authority, a figure later raised to $78,000 by the three arbitrators. That's still far below what the property would be worth on a square-foot basis as part of an industrial tract, said Robert Cohen, an attorney representing six homeowners.
Tom Higgins, the assistant secretary-treasurer of the sports authority, said: "You have to understand the method of condemnation. What you're condemning is a trailer lot. You're not condemning a hotel or a factory.
"We acknowledge it's a very difficult situation because you're talking about people's homes. But there's a law, and we followed the law."
As to Cohen's argument that the property could be worth a lot more as an industrial site, Higgins replied, "What it could be is a parking lot, and that's what it is."
Not really. This area of the state was inundated with over 2.4 inches of rain from about 6 P.M. Thursday to 6 P.M. Friday, and most of the parking areas at the 950-acre speedway (they had not been paved yet) were too muddy to be used. That meant the traffic-management plan that the speedway and police had worked on for months had to be scrapped at the last minute. The speedway has hired about 300 buses to shuttle fans from off-site parking areas, as well as 15 tow trucks to rescue fans' vehicles stuck in the ooze.
Traffic was a nightmare, nonetheless, as police reported five-mile backups on the interstate that feeds into the speedway. Fans were advised to leave as early as possible on Sunday. Good idea, but consider this: as if fate hasn't mocked the speedway enough this weekend, Sunday happens to be the only 23-hour day all year, what with the shift to daylight time.
The rain has disrupted the racing schedule as well. Qualifying for the Interstate Batteries 500 was called off today (even though skies had cleared) when water started seeping onto the track surface from the point where the crash wall meets the pavement.
And when the Winston Cup cars tried to get in some much-needed practice this morning before the Busch Grand National race, the pavement started disintegrating in one of the turns, forcing a halt.

HEADLINE: Pass Go, Collect Millions

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
IT doesn't take long for most visitors to the Boardwalk and Park Place to notice something familiar about the street map. Atlantic City's boulevards, named mostly after the states and bodies of water, bear more than a passing resemblance to the Monopoly game board.
The resemblance is intentional. America's most famous board game was indeed based on Atlantic City. Boardwalk and Park Place are still among the most valuable properties around, if only you could buy them. 
 While gambling has existed here in some form or another since the city was founded in 1854, Atlantic City's traditional path to the pot of gold has been the buying, selling and developing of real estate. So much feverish dealing inspired Charles Darrow, an unemployed plumbing contractor, to base Monopoly, his real estate trading board game, on Atlantic City street names, landmarks, utilities and other features. Darrow's game, designed in 1929, described a city for sale, where everything, from building hotels on public property to getting out of jail, was possible to someone with cash. Now, with as much as $10 billion in total casino investment expected by 2005, one would think that in 70 years, the game has changed.
Not quite.
In today's Atlantic City, winning is a lot like winning at Monopoly. More important than having money or property is the ability to outlast the competition, especially since most of the money gamblers lose in Atlantic City does not stay in town. Although the rules and the players have changed over the years, the game has stayed the same. While the gambling industry is making more money than ever, Atlantic City has become New Jersey's smallest town with big-city problems: unemployment, racial divisiveness, a decaying retail center and a general residential flight to the suburbs.
"The contrasts in the game are still, by and large, visible in Atlantic City," says Howard Kyle, director of the Atlantic County Planning Department and an amateur historian who is a native of the city. "Go to Park Place" -- priced at $350 on the gameboard -- "and you'll see a busy, thriving resort. Go to Baltic Avenue" -- $60 on the board -- "and you'll see some of the same problems you'd find in any major Northeastern city."
Many of the landmarks on the Parker Brothers game board still exist in Atlantic City. (Mayor James F. Whelan has a deluxe Monopoly set in his City Hall office.) And every few years someone comes up with a scheme to use Monopoly symbols as part of an urban renewal project. Portions of Baltic and Mediterranean Avenues are now called Fairmount and Melrose, respectively. Illinois Avenue is now Martin Luther King Boulevard.
There is still land to buy on Baltic and Mediterranean, but the big money is no longer in building a few houses, or even a hotel, and collecting rent. It seems the only people with cash in their pockets at the end of the day are the owners of tall, floodlighted casino hotels with parking garages.
"The big way the board has changed, obviously, are the casinos," says Jack Plackter, a lawyer specializing in development. "But most of the casinos still don't know how to play Monopoly. They haven't protected their borders by buying up property that would keep competitors away and give them the room to expand."

The Players: Impresarios And Empire-Builders
Only one casino mogul "really knew the game," Mr. Plackter said, "and that was Jim Crosby." James M. Crosby, the founder of the city's first casino, Resorts International, bought land all over the city, especially around Resorts. "In the early 1980's, he had so much land he had almost total control of what was happening in the South Inlet," a blighted area covering city's the northeastern corner, Mr. Plackter said. "MGM and Sun International, the companies coming into the city now, are fighting over a lot of the same land so they can get that kind of control, but there simply isn't enough room for both of them to get what they want."
Mr. Crosby died in 1986, and his heirs sold Resorts and most of his land holdings to Donald Trump. Mr. Trump now holds majority ownership of four Atlantic City casinos as well as the Steel Pier, more than any other company or individual in Atlantic City. In promoting those properties, he has become as famous as the mustachioed, top-hatted "Rich Uncle Pennybag" of the Monopoly game, if less avuncular.
As a player, Mr. Trump combines unequal parts of Barnumesque self-promotion and fingernails-on-chalkboard intimidation, insisting on not playing until the rules are rewritten in his favor. A big backer of Republican politicians, he has halted all improvements planned for his casinos and is currently suing numerous state agencies to stop the construction of a commuter tunnel that he believes will benefit the once and future Monopoly whiz, Steven A. Wynn.
Mr. Wynn is credited with reviving interest in the city with his decision in 1995 to build a casino in Atlantic City. Mr. Wynn is acquiring 155 acres of city-owned land in the marina district without charge from the city but must pay $15 million in cleanup and site improvement costs, of which he may recoup $8 million in state toxic waste cleanup credits. He has made all of this contingent on the building of a $330 million crosstown car tunnel, financed partly by the state, that would chop up sections of two residential neighborhoods.
Mr. Wynn plans as many as three casinos for the marina site, including Le Jardin, a branch of his successful Mirage chain. He also owns Boardwalk frontage at Albany Avenue and part of the marina waterfront next to the Trump Castle (soon to be renamed Trump Marina) casino.
"If you want to win, you're two and a half years too late," says John Huber, a commercial Realtor in the city. "The news that Steve Wynn was going to come in and build a casino here set off another buying wave in the Inlet and along the Boardwalk that may even have begun to taper off."
Like Mr. Trump, Mr. Wynn doesn't like to play until the rules are rewritten in his favor. Unlike Mr. Trump, whose empire depends heavily on revenues generated from his Atlantic City casinos, Mr. Wynn can still decide not to play, thanks to his Las Vegas casinos, and lose only a few million dollars in legal and public relations fees.

The Corporation As Gamesman
But the biggest player in the city's current Monopoly game is Hilton Hotels, which already owns property on the Boardwalk and Park Place. A former loser (Hilton's Rainbow casino became the Trump Castle when Barron Hilton was denied an casino license in 1995), Hilton is now the largest gambling company in the world, thanks to the financial legerdermain of its chairman, Steven Bollenbach (who dug Donald Trump out of bankruptcy barely six years ago), and Arthur M. Goldberg, a Jersey boy who merged his Bally's casinos in Atlantic City and Nevada with Hilton last year to create the largest gambling company in the world, with 18 facilities worldwide, two in Atlantic City. Hilton also owns acres of parking lots around its Atlantic City Hilton casino at Boston Avenue and the Boardwalk, and large, buildable parcels on both sides of Pacific Avenue near Park Place. The company is finishing an expansion of its Bally's Park Place casino and may also acquire the financially troubled Claridge casino hotel.
As a player, Mr. Goldberg, a Monopoly fan and backer of Democratic political candidates, tends to keep quiet until he's ready to pounce, and he can be effective at derailing city improvement projects that don't directly benefit his properties. As president of Hilton's gambling operations, he may become the newest winner if he succeeds in a $10.5 billion hostile takeover bid for ITT Corporation, owner of Caesars.
Even before ITT bought Caesars in 1993, Caesars Atlantic City casino was more profitable than the more famous Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.The company is building an expansion abutting Bally's Park Place; it also owns the Ocean One Mall, a retail and amusement pier at Arkansas Avenue, and a Boardwalk-front parking at Martin Luther King Boulevard and Park Place, where it plans to build an enormous Planet Hollywood casino.
Last year ITT, under its chairman, Rand Araskrog, showed that it could play Monopoly with the best. A 500-room Doubletree hotel going up opposite the city's new Convention Center, partly financed by Caesars, magically became a Sheraton, scheduled to open in November, when Caesars bought out Doubletree's portion. That the Sheraton chain is also owned by ITT was not lost on anyone. Unless it capitulates to Hilton, ITT now has a lock on hotel business from the city's new convention hall. Although huge conventions of Elks, Moose and other lodges were held in Atlantic City when Darrow designed the Monopoly game, his board doesn't show how important it has become to be close to a large convention facility.
Of all the casinos, Harrah's Atlantic City is in the best shape to survive the turbulent next decade, followed by Tropicana and Showboat. Content to sit in its own corner of the marina district, Harrah's, which got a black eye when its Jazz casino in New Orleans failed in 1995, has enough land and cash to have more than 2,000 hotel rooms by the year 2002, making it the largest hotel in the state. (Tropicana, with 1600 rooms, is currently the largest.)
Newcomers include MGM Grand. Headed by Al Luciani, a former Atlantic City Golden Nugget executive, the company expects to open a casino and theme-park complex in the South Inlet section in two years. The South African company Sun International, under Sol Kerzner, is buying several acres south of the former Merv Griffin's Resorts, which it hopes to turn into an ocean-themed Atlantis casino in 1999.
Before Mr. Trump is crowned the current Boardwalk king, it should be noted that his casinos, as well as those of Resorts International (then owned by Mr. Griffin), filed for bankruptcy at the close of the 1980's. The Sands, owned by Texas-based Pratt Hotels, and the Claridge have been in financial difficulty for two years. Another casino, the former Playboy, changed its ownership and name before running out of money. (It was later purchased and reopened in 1996 as the Trump World's Fair Casino.)

Monopoly Updated: A Reality-Based Fantasy
This is what might happen if you were to play a 1997 version of Monopoly, set in a city poised for its next big wave of casino-fueled rebirth.
 
PASS GO, COLLECT $200 Passing Go in the modern Atlantic City requires you to apply to the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority, a state agency that gives away billions in tax money -- a little more than a penny from every dollar lost -- from the casinos' gross gambling revenues. Grants from the authority are supposed to go to projects and activities that will improve the city or benefit the elderly and the handicapped. But with so many court challenges over the years, the lawyers may turn out to be the only clear beneficiaries of the casino boom.
 
THE PROPERTIES One of the peculiarities of Atlantic City's Monopoly landmarks is that they have retained their value over time, give or take a few zeros. Land along Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues, blocks from the Boardwalk, would sell for $10 to $12 a square foot, said Mr. Huber, the Realtor who admits to having played more than his share of Monopoly over the years.
BOARDWALK AND PARK PLACE These and other properties offering Boardwalk frontage along the miracle mile between the Showboat and Tropicana casinos are still the most expensive, $40,000 a square foot. Go 10 blocks up the Boardwalk, into the South Inlet, where of MGM Grand want to build a casino complex, and the price drops to $100 a square foot. Mayor Whelan says he hasn't ruled out using the city's power of eminent domain to help MGM get more what it wants at a lower price.
 
HOUSES Because of environmental upgrades and "soft costs" for permits and other legal matters, a three-bedroom house in the Inlet section can cost $150,000 to $210,000. If you build a housing development, you can qualify for money from the Casino Reinvestment and Development Authority, reducing your cost but requiring you to sell some of your houses to low-income families.
 
HOTELS The city's only new non-casino hotel in two years, the 500-room Sheraton is connected to the new convention center. Due to open in November of this year, it cost $87 million. But casino hotels change the game. Now, a typical Atlantic City casino hotel with 1,000 rooms and 100,000 square feet of casino space will cost at least $450 million. So far, the record is $1.3 billion that Mr. Trump paid to build the Trump Taj Mahal during the days of junk bond debt with double-digit interest. Gamblers lose $1.5 million to $2 million at the Taj Mahal every day. Before you count your chips, remember that it takes state and local agencies at least two years to process and approve the paperwork for a casino hotel. "Soft costs" have been variously estimated as 10 to 25 percent of the total investment.
 
CHANCE The worst luck you could have is for your high-rolling gamblers to win big. Among the other bad tidings to casino developers have been riparian claims (somebody digs up an ancient map of the town that shows a tiny creek used to run under your casino; pay the state $250,000, as the old Playboy did); an auto accident that closes your parking garage (lose $400,000 a day, as the Claridge did last summer, when your customers go elsewhere); a popular entertainer's defection to another casino (when Frank Sinatra was still performing, his presence could raise a casino's gross by several million dollars every night he was in town); a contractor's ties to organized crime (next time ask about Cousin Vinnie; pay $50,000 fine); a sexual or racial discrimination suit (as much as $500,000, settled out of court by several casinos); a hostile takeover (costs for poison-pill defenses: $50 million), and a unionization drive ($500,000 in consultation costs and management overtime to defeat it). Among the new cards to add to the pile would be those that grant permission to tear out your lounges and add slot machines; bless you with air rights so you can extend your casino over a public street; venture into Chapter 11 bankruptcy so that you don't have to pay your bondholders and creditors all you owe them, or have the city of Atlantic City use its power of eminent domain to condemn a property that you need for your casino expansion. On a different space, change the get-out-of-jail-free card to "deregulation."
 
COMMUNITY CHEST The former Community Chest is now the Atlantic County Chapter of the United Way, the city's single most popular charity among casino employees.
 
LUXURY TAXTen percent of a hotel room's bill goes to a fund for civic improvements. Casinos also pay nearly 70 percent of the local taxes collected in Atlantic City. An additional 8 percent of the casino gross goes to a general fund that, before it was pillaged by the state Legislature, was supposed to benefit the elderly and the handicapped. And don't forget the redevelopment authority's cut. Beyond which there is a tangle of permits, processing fees and legal complexities.
 
FREE PARKING No longer free. The casinos charge a state-mandated $2 that is supposed to pay for projects to improve the city, specifically a corridor project to link the new Convention Center to the Boardwalk. Elsewhere, parking meters and three-hour parking limits for non-residents cause the city to issue about 90,000 parking tickets a year.
 
THE RAILROADS The Short Line was a bus line, not a railroad. Of the Monopoly railroads, only the Pennsylvania Reading did come to Absecon Island, as did the Camden & Atlantic. Darrow split the Pennsylvania Reading into two separate railroads to fill up the board. Today, New Jersey Transit commuter trains use rights-of-way cut by the Camden & Atlantic, the city's first railroad, which steamed into town in 1854. Once Atlantic City's most important source of visitors, the line is now a money-loser for New Jersey Transit. The game might be updated by making one of the railroad spaces a charter bus company bringing in day-trippers who mostly play the slot machines.
 
UTILITIES The Electric Company, based in Pleasantville, jolts enough juice into the animated signs in front of the Trump Plaza and Caesars parking garages each use enough electricity to power a small South Jersey town. The Water Works is the Atlantic County Municipal Utilities Authority, which regularly wins awards for the purity of its water.
 
JAIL The one square everybody hates now takes you out of town. The Atlantic City Police Department has small holding facilities, but most people arrested in the city are moved to the Atlantic County Correctional Facility in Mays Landing, a 30-minute drive away. The Get-Out-of-Jail-Free card, a relic of the days when political bosses ran the town, is obsolete. If you need help, the phone number of city's best-known criminal lawyer, Edwin Jacobs, is in the book.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 13, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article last Sunday about Atlantic City development and real estate misidentified the chairman of the MGM Grand. He is J. Terrence Lanni, not Al Luciani.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Cigarette Papers;
Why the Tobacco Industry Found Taxes Hazardous to Its Health

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
RECENT weeks have been tough for the tobacco industry, ever since one of its major manufacturers, the Liggett Group, broke ranks and admitted that marketing campaigns had been aimed at teen-agers, and that it had known for decades that cigarettes are dangerous.
Hoping to capitalize on public revulsion at these disclosures, anti-smoking advocates are pushing legislation in 19 states to raise cigarette taxes by as much as a dollar per pack. Polls, by the advocates on both sides and by independent survey organizations, consistently show overwhelming public support for increased excise taxes to reduce consumption. 
 For years the tobacco industry fought regulations like those aimed at banning or restricting smoking in buildings or cigarette giveaways, but the industry apparently viewed these skirmishes as a useful way to keep the debate away from something it feared much more -- higher excise taxes, which would discourage smoking, especially by teen-agers.
Internal documents from the Tobacco Institute, the cigarette manufacturers' trade association, and the Philip Morris Companies, plus testimony by a Tobacco Institute vice president, indicate that the industry has long feared excise taxes.
Now anti-smoking advocates, with financial support from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J., and the American Cancer Society, among other organizations, are pushing the Federal and state governments for higher excise taxes on tobacco.
Various anti-smoking advocacy organizations provided the documents quoted below. The first was released in litigation, and others, all on company stationery, were sent to the groups anonymously. Several have been cited in other news reports. The company involved, Philip Morris, has not disputed their authenticity. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON
A September 1981 internal memo at Philip Morris warned about a Federal report concluding that raising taxes would significantly reduce smoking among youths. The memo about the National Bureau of Economic Research report was written by Myron Johnston, a company economist, to his boss, Harry G. Daniel, who at the time was manager of research on smoking by teen-agers.
Because of the quality of the work, the prestige (and objectivity) of the N.B.E.R., and the fact that the excise tax on cigarettes has not changed in nearly 30 years, I think we need to take seriously their statement that . . . if future reductions in youth smoking are desired, an increase in the Federal excise tax is a potent policy to accomplish this goal. . . .
[The authors] calculate that . . . a 10 percent increase in the price of cigarettes would lead to a decline of 12 percent in the number of teen-agers who would otherwise begin to smoke. . . .
Among teen-agers the prevalence of cigarette smoking is highly correlated with income (from either allowances or working) while there is no similar correlation between smoking prevalence and income among adults. . . . It is clear that price has a pronounced effect on the smoking prevalence of teen-agers. . . .
We can never look with equanimity on increases in the excise tax, but because of demographic trends and the improved economic outlook an increase at this time would probably be less harmful than it would have been at any other time in the past decade.
The industry nevertheless redoubled its efforts to head off tax increases. In December 1989, during the Bush Administration, an internal Philip Morris memo recounted the company's lobbying efforts, naming tobacco-state politicians through whom it intended to exert pressure. The memo plays down a report on a possible tax-hike recommendation from the Administration.
Discussions were held with officials of the White House and Treasury Department, who assured us that: a) there are no plans to raise cigarette excise taxes as part of the FY 91 Budget exercise, b) the tax study alluded to in The Wall Street Journal was a mid-level, what-if exercise containing a number of politically controversial tax changes available should the coming tax debate produce calls for revenue increases, c) no such recommendations for tax policy changes have reached either [Treasury] Secretary [Nicholas] Brady or [Budget] Director [Richard] Darman for their review.
Contacts were made with Congressional allies to enlist their support in contacting the Bush Administration to oppose cigarette taxes. Those contacts included Senators Helms, McConnell, and Warner and Representatives Bliley, Coble, McMillan, Bateman, Rogers, Ballenger, and Bunning [all Republicans, from North Carolina, Virginia or Kentucky]. All agreed to contact the Administration via phone or letter to protest. Ballenger immediately called the Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, Ken Gideon. . . .
We have asked Senator [Howard] Baker [Republican of Tennessee] and his associates to enlist Governors Campbell of South Carolina and Martin of North Carolina to contact the President via letter and remind him of his no-excise-tax-on-cigarettes campaign pledge. We are awaiting their responses. In addition, the Senator continues to have phone discussions with the Administration on this issue. The President has assured Senator Baker previously that he remains opposed to new cigarette taxes. . . .
It appears that our alert to Members of Congress [has] yielded dividends. At a minimum, the Treasury Department has been put on notice that tobacco excise tax increases will meet strong resistance from President Bush's Southern allies.
In March 1990, an internal Philip Morris memo from James W. Dyer, the chief lobbyist in Washington, to David Greenberg, a Philip Morris vice president, claimed success in muting criticism of tobacco by Dr. Antonia Novello, President Bush's nominee for Surgeon General, as she prepared for confirmation hearings:
We have intervened with the White House, OMB [Office of Management and Budget] and HHS [Department of Health and Human Services] to urge that Dr. Novello take no position on any pending anti-tobacco legislation. We stressed to her handlers and to interested parties that we were interested in making sure she focused on non-tobacco health problems. We were successful in that both of our objectives were met.
The next day, at the hearings, however, Dr. Novello vowed to fight the tobacco industry and later she called tobacco companies "death dealers." By mid-1990 higher excise taxes seemed in store. A May 1990 memo expressed alarm over a meeting on the Federal budget planned for Houston that July:
It is prudent to assume that there will be a budget summit, and that excise tax increases are viewed as acceptable tax increases. . . . Therefore, our grassroots, grasstops, employee communications, TBN [the reference is unexplained], etc., should go into high gear now. We should activate every tool at our disposal immediately. I have a feeling this is not a test, this is the real thing.
A Philip Morris memo a few days later gives advice on political contributions aimed at heading off a tax increase:
I have been contacted by Fred Malek [a Bush political adviser] and his staff, all of whom are currently planning the 1990 Houston Economic Summit on July 9 through 11. They are soliciting corporate sponsors. . . . If we contribute cash, I would suggest a minimum donation of $25,000. . . .
And the next month a memo to Kathleen M. Linehan, the No. 2 executive in Philip Morris's Washington office, urged support for four Republicans in the 1990 Congressional elections. All but Bill Schuette won.
Craig Jones [Craig T. James of Florida] -- . . . he is very conservative, pro-business, anti-tax, endangered species type who is pro-tobacco. . . .
Bill Schuette [Michigan] -- I'd give up all the rest to give this guy money. He's in the forefront of the anti-tax movement, our food crowd loves him and he has an excellent chance.
Paul Gillmor [Ohio] -- Former Speaker of the Ohio House, he is a chain smoker who will vote with tobacco. . . .
Chris Cox -- Has moved to the forefront of the anti-tax movement in the House because he has introduced the balanced budget amendment that the business community is rallying round. The trouble is, he's a California Republican, therefore, suspect on tobacco. . . .
In pre-trial testimony last February in a lawsuit brought by Mississippi to recover tax money spent on tobacco-related illnesses, Ronald C. Morris, vice president of the Tobacco Institute, gave the industry's position on taxes:
The Institute is opposed to cigarette taxes. . . . is not opposed to improving health care. [But tobacco companies] are opposed to funding it. It's bad public policy to use an excise tax dedicated to fund a growing need. You have a declining revenue potential with a growing need source. It is just not good public policy. . . . We would support a broad-based tax to pay for indigent health care.

Daniel. He was manager of technical planning information for Philip Morris, not manager of research on smoking by teen-agers.

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 22; Column 1; Education Life Supplement
