HEADLINE: Players Don't Show Colleges The Money

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN; William C. Rhoden is a sports columnist for The New York Times

 BODY:
For Steve Smith, the dream came true in the spring of 1991 when he became that needle in a haystack, the one in a million who managed to reach the National Basketball Association. Mr. Smith was drafted by the Miami Heat on the first round and was the fifth player selected overall. The draft culminated a brilliant career at Michigan State University and a long hard climb from the inner city of Detroit.
 During his rookie season in the NBA, Mr. Smith's dream was shattered when his mother died of cancer. His older sister, Janice, had been fatally shot when he was 8 years old. But this was different. Clara Bell Smith was his best friend, nurturer, confidante, sage -- his coach. 
 For six seasons after his mother's death, Mr. Smith, a 6-foot-7-inch guard for the Atlanta Hawks, looked for a substantial way to commemorate her memory. He wears a tattoo of a bell on his right arm that he touches before shooting a foul shot. He has given away $70,000 a year for tickets so that youth groups can attend Hawks home games. He donates $50 for each three point shot he makes to the Atlanta-based Make-A- Wish Foundation, which grants wishes to terminally ill children. But nothing seemed substantial enough to honor his mother's memory. He wanted something more enduring.
 "I just kept running different things through my head," Mr. Smith, 28, recalled recently.
 Last November Mr. Smith was contacted by Kirk Gibson, the former Detroit Tiger baseball player and MSU alumnus about contributing to a $6 million campaign to build a student athlete center on campus. A light went on in Mr. Smith's head: This was it.
 At the time, he was negotiating a lucrative contract with the Hawks, to whom he'd been traded in 1994. The contract was for a whopping $50.4 million over seven years; by the time Kirk Gibson came along, Mr. Smith was ready to put his money where his heart was. After several meetings between his attorneys and Michigan State University officials, Mr. Smith contributed $2.5 million toward the construction of the building. -- the largest known contribution from an active professional athlete to his alma mater.
 Substantial gifts to colleges and universities are certainly nothing new. What makes the Smith gift highly unusual, however, is its source: a college athlete alumnus.
 Of all the groups of alumni, professional athletes are among the least likely to be associated with making hefty gifts to their respective schools outside of the athletics department.
 At a time when even minimum salaries of professional football, basketball and baseball players are well into six figures, university officials have begun to recognize the universe of professional athletes as a relatively unexplored frontier. And as Mr. Smith's gift creates a few ripples in this universe, many development officers wonder why they have not tapped into this resource before now.
 The more pertinent question is why haven't more professional athletes given more generously to universities.
 The question is more complex than it appears and addresses a troublesome aspect of the relationship between big-time athletic programs and universities.
 Many universities use their scholarship sports programs to curry favor with alumni and with boosters. The schools use football and basketball programs to enhance the image and imagery of the university by using sports as a vehicle for national advertising.
 In the midst of all this stands the recruited athletes. They have become a peculiar combination of entertainer, gladiator and student who put themselves through school by utilizing the labor intensive skills they have honed for years. The mutual, but ill-defined backscratching between the university and recruits has created a hybrid called the student-athlete. It has also created an ambivalence toward the university by athletes who look at the profits -- direct and indirect -- that the university derives from sports programs.
 "Sometimes athletes have the feeling that they have given to their university by playing ball," said Charles Webb, the vice president of development at Michigan State University.
 Wayne Baskerville, director of development and alumni relations for the University of Michigan's athletic department, brought up another more contemporary consideration.
 "A big problem with athletes giving is that so many of them are leaving school after their first or second year, and they are not having an opportunity to develop any connection with the school," he said.
 Some student athletes, particularly in football and basketball, say that those athletes who do remain on campus for four years are sometimes stigmatized by being on a so-called "free ride." Many speak of alienation from the general student body and say they tend to bond primarily with with one another.
 These feelings are often more pronounced in African American athletes who attend predominantly white colleges. In many cases, the athletes would not have chosen the school nor the school the athlete but for athletics. One development director who asked not to be identified said, "A lot of black athletes don't feel a connection to the school. In many cases they feel they've done a lot more for the university than the university has done for them. They say 'The institution has kept me isolated, kept me in practices during the season, workouts and training after the season, the athletic dining hall, then study hall' -- all of it is centered around the athletic complex. As a result they don't go to a lot of social events. They feel more loyalty to the team than they do to the university."
 For many athletes, being asked to give money to the university is one more maneuver to exploit a resource. With the large number of African American athletes participating in revenue producing sports of football and basketball, much more attention has to be paid to the athletes' on-campus experience.
 Mr. Webb said that Smith's substantial gift could signal a breakthrough.
 "I have no question this gift will raise the consciousness of our other athletes," he said. "We've already had three or four others say 'I want to do something. I may not be able to do it at the level of Steve Smith, but I can do something.' That's all we can ask." He added: "Sometimes I don't think we as development officers have been as aggressive, or have worked with our athletes as closely as we could have."
 Paul Blodgett, vice president for development at the University of Southern California, agrees.
 "I don't think we've given it the attention it warrants," he said. "Do I think we've done a particularly good job of that here? No," he said referring to cultivating athletes as donors. USC has a rich tradition of producing professional athletes. Currently the school has 46 former Trojans playing in the NFL, six in Major League Baseball and one in the NBA.
 "We've certainly talked about it," Mr. Blodgett said. "And we've talked about individual names. When you have individuals with significant wealth, you have to deal with that person's relationship to the university and did he or she have a good experience."
 Mr. Smith said that he enjoyed his experience at Michigan State. Although he stayed for four years, he needs a few more hours to graduate. But he said he plans to return after retirement.
 Yet fond memories and good times were not what attracted Mr. Smith to the building project. The hook was a provision that allowed donors who contribute more than half of the construction costs of a building to have that building named in their honor. Mr. Smith had a grander idea: He told the university that he wanted the building named in honor of his mother.
 Ground breaking for the Clara Bell Smith Student Athletes Academic Center took place on March 1. According to Mr. Webb, Mr. Smith's gift marks the first time that a donor has asked that a building be named for someone else.
 "This was great because it allowed me to give back in a lot of ways," Mr. Smith said. "I named the building after my mom, I gave back to Michigan State, which helped me get to where I'm at, and it allowed me to give back to my high school." Mr. Smith also has endowed an annual scholarship to Michigan State for the best student at Pershing High School in Detroit. "That was the most exciting thing for me," he said.
 Mr. Smith grew up in the Detroit inner city, He is the second of three children and the only boy. His father, Donald, drove a bus and his mother stayed home and raised their three children.
 Mr. Smith said the reason he began a scholarship fund at Pershing was to give non-athletes with good grades but limited funds an opportunity to attend Michigan State.
 "A lot of kids I know in my area had the grades to go to Michigan State but did not have the financial means to get there," he said. "So instead of going to Michigan State and struggling, they'd go to a community college where they could maintain themselves financially and concentrate on academics. This scholarship will allow them to go to the university and concentrate on the books."
 Mr. Smith's gift to his university may be the largest but it is not the first. Last year Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls gave $1 million to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill to create a new research institute on families in the School of Social Work. A year earlier, Jamal Mashburn of the Miami Heat, established a scholarship fund for economically disadvantaged students with a $500,000 gift to the University of Kentucky.
 But, some development officers wonder, how can they encourage more giving?
 "In the case of the institution, usually those who are involved in the fundraising enterprise don't have the relationship with the athletes," said Robert Hill, the vice president for communications at Syracuse University. "The people who had the relationship, like the coach, don't concern themselves with fundraising. So usually institutions conduct their fundraising programs without any significant involvement from these coaches who are really the ones most likely to get a positive response." As an example, Mr. Hill points out that the athletic department's fundraising campaign has a goal of $10 million. Of that, $7 million already has been raised. Of the major gifts, only two came from varsity athletes who made their money playing professional ball: Lawrence Moten and Sherman Douglas, both of whom are African Americans. They contributed to the Jim Boeheim Scholarship fund. Of the 100 donors to the general athletic fund, 15 were former athletes in varsity sports, though most participated in non-revenue sports. None of the donors made their money playing pro sports.
 But, Mr. Hill said, a number of African American athletes have begun to rejoin the fold. Jim Brown, the Hall of Fame running-back-turned-actor is one example. Mr. Brown refused to participate in any Syracuse affairs until 1983, Mr. Hill said -- nearly 25 years after he graduated.
 During one drive to bring black alumni back to Syracuse, Mr. Hill said, he canvassed every African American athlete who ever played for Syracuse and invited them to campus. "Just to get them involved and say 'Hey, you own this Orange, too'," he said, referring to the school colors. "They enjoyed being able to come back and gripe about how rough life was when they were here, to the point where they were seeing that it wasn't like that anymore. There had been substantial changes." Syracuse currently has eight players in the National Basketball Association (two are white, six African American), and 15 athletes in the National Football league (eight African Americans, seven whites).
 Darryl Daniels, a North Carolina-based agent said one of his clients, Charles Way, a running back with the New York Giants who attended the University of Virginia, preferred to contribute money to an African American organization rather than to the university. Mr. Way, an engineering major, contributes to the National Association of Black Engineers.
 "I like him doing that -- that's empowering an African-American organization," Mr. Daniels said. "What I'd like to see happen more is giving money to the black engineering group and the United Negro College Fund. A lot of money that is given back to the university, give it to a positive African American entity."
 But Mr. Hill at Syracuse counters that if alumni give the money to the university, the university will direct it to an engineering student. "What I say is you can give to the institution and earmark it for black students studying engineering. You can help the kid and help your alma mater."
 For some development officers, the answer is simply that athletes are no different from other alumni.
 "If you look at the pattern of individual giving generally, people under 50 may make contributions but they're not really thinking of making large contributions because they're still thinking about acquiring wealth, accumulating wealth, not so much about giving it away," said Mr. Blodgett of USC.
 Mr. Smith said that while he is not at the income level of someone like Michael Jordan, his gift to Michigan State won't hurt his wallet.
 "It's not going to make a dent because growing up, I never thought I'd have it," he said. "It hasn't hurt me because I know how to live without it."
 Finally, Mr. Smith said, he feels a sense of completion -- that his real dream has been fulfilled. Because of his donation and the new student athlete center, he senses that his mother's spirit will live on for generations.
 "She was a giving person," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the special Education Life section on April 6 about donations by professional athletes misstated the gift-giving preference of Charles Way, who plays for the New York Giants. He says he has no preference for African-American organizations over the University of Virginia, which he attended.
The article also misstated the given name of Mr. Way's agent. He is Deryle Daniels, not Darryl.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 66; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2136 words

HEADLINE: Superstore Inflation

BYLINE: By Richard Panek; Richard Panek is writing a social history of the telescope, to be published next year.

 BODY:
The superstore -- that cropland-encroaching or square-city-block-swallowing shrine to seemingly limitless supply -- is shaping up to be the defining shopping experience of the 1990's. It has established the scale that shoppers now demand and a strategy that retailers giddily emulate, and it has done both to an extent that would have been unimaginable only 10 years ago. Whatever bigger was, now it's more.
Superstores have gone from zero to $550 billion in annual sales, or fully one-third of the nation's retail revenue, in 10 years flat. In fiscal year 1996, Home Depot, the leading home-improvement superstore chain, showed a record $938 million profit on $19.5 billion in sales, a 28 percent improvement over the previous year's record profits; Staples, a $106 million profit on $4 billion in sales, or a 44 percent improvement. Borders, the No. 2 bookseller in the nation, has been opening new superstores at the rate of one every nine days; Barnes & Noble, the leading bookseller, one every four or five days; Staples, two a week. For Home Depot, nearly three a week. 
 That's three new-from-the-foundation-up pieces of real estate, each stocking 40,000 to 50,000 different kinds of building materials, home-improvement supplies and lawn and garden products, each with a garden center that by itself covers at least 20,000 square feet, each week.
Where only yesterday there was empty acreage, suddenly there are superstores selling books, sporting goods, home furnishings, athletic wear, baby products, bed and bath supplies, toys, consumer electronics, pet supplies, even off-the-rack bridal gowns. In some fields, the term no longer suffices; in the
grocery trade the distinctions include conventional-format stores, warehouse stores, superstores, superwarehouse stores, combination food-and-drug stores and hypermarkets. As Richard S. Tedlow, a Harvard Business School professor and the author of "New and Improved: The Story of Mass Marketing in America," says, "I'm not sure what people mean when they use the term superstore."
Over the years in popular parlance it has applied to anything from an ultra-inclusive Wal-Mart outside Madison, Wisc., to the ultra-exclusive Emporio Armani on Madison Avenue. It definitely comes in a big box -- "big box" is a Wall Street synonym, in fact, for four walls that house a wealth of consumer goods. But in recent months, thanks in part to the Federal Trade Commission's highly publicized resistance to the proposed merger between the Staples and Office Depot superstore chains, its meaning has begun to settle on a specific breed of big-box retailer, one that lives by a singular code.
Category killers, they are called. They sell one kind of merchandise, and they sell it at deep discount. By buying from suppliers at high volumes, they don't just give the local competition a run for its money -- they eliminate it by design. As an enterprise with a responsibility to stockholders and a board of directors, the superstore exists on the scale it does for one reason only: not to sell the proverbial better mousetrap but to be the last mousetrap seller standing.
That's the theory, anyway. In practice, superstores often don't succeed in killing all the competition. They eliminate the small and the weak, all right, but in another way superstores create competition. After all, there's nothing like a highly visible, phenomenally successful business venture to invite rivalry. Ten years ago, Home Depot -- "the quintessential category killer," as Forbes magazine put it -- had the home-improvement superstore field to itself; by 1996, there were a dozen such chains. At the end of the day (or decade), all that's left standing are other superstores.
What happened in the office-supply category is typical to the point of being instructive -- and for some observers, instructive to the point of being cautionary. On May 1, 1986, in Brighton, Mass., Staples opened the first office-supply superstore in the country. Six months later, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Office Depot followed suit. Within three years, 15 office-supply superstore chains were competing, and already the battlefield had claimed its first casualty, Office Station. Today, that competition has narrowed to three superstore chains, and if the Staples-Office Depot merger that was first proposed last September goes through, there will be just two -- just like 10 years earlier, in the fall of 1986.
But what a difference a decade makes. The office-supply deal would create a chain of more than 1,000 superstores in 47 states and 10 foreign countries -- big enough to attract the attention of an F.T.C. already suspicious of superstores. Last May the agency charged that Toys "R" Us was using its 20 percent share of the toy market to pressure suppliers not to sell products to competitors; now the F.T.C. has flagged a merger between the No. 1 and No. 2 office suppliers for having all the makings of a monopoly.
Market share is an elusive concept, depending on who's doing the defining. Staples maintains that at $10 billion in annual sales, even the new company would account for only 5 percent of the $185 billion office-supply industry. Less generous (and less advantageous) estimates might adjust that market share to 8 percent of a $125 billion industry. The F.T.C. action, however, raises the question of which industry we are talking about here -- the entire office-supply marketplace, including the corner pharmacy's half-aisle full of pushpins, protractors and, yes, staples, or the $23 billion superstore market, of which the newly merged giant would command a 44 percent share?
Clearly, the F.T.C. favors the latter interpretation. The press release announcing the regulatory commission's complaint states that office-supply superstores "offer consumers the convenience of one-stop shopping for a wide variety of office supplies, computers and computer-related products, and office furniture at deep discount prices." They are "unlike any other retail stores in the United States."
In other words, the category killers have succeeded so well that they have created a new category: themselves.
More, it turns out, was the easy part. More categories overall, more variety within each category, more inventory within each variety; 10,000 square feet of books; 50,000 square feet of CD's; 120,000 square feet of home furnishings. To enter a superstore is to know what the scale of Olympus or Eldorado must have looked like in the imaginations of mortals.
And then what? Achieving critical mass was a relatively simple matter: raise money (Wall Street has been an early, ardent, unwavering advocate of the category-killer concept), buy real estate, build boxes, fill them with inventory; customers will show up if only to witness the spectacle, and they'll look around, and they'll buy. They'll even come back.
But will they keep coming back? Will a superstore be able to distinguish itself from its competitors sufficiently so that it will become not just a novelty but a necessity? That's the tricky part, and that's where the superstores have had to get creative.
It's no longer enough to have the widest selection of CD's at the lowest prices. That's why Wow!, a 60,000-square-foot West Coast combination of the Good Guys consumer-electronics store and Tower Records, features an $80,000 home stereo system on which classical connoisseurs can sample the latest releases at length and at leisure. That's why the 75,000-square-foot Virgin Megastore in Times Square offers 250 listening and viewing posts, in addition to live performances, a bookstore, a travel agency, a cafe and a movie theater. That's why no self-respecting video or audio retailer is complete without a giant video screen -- or better yet, 25 video screens generating one gigantic image, which doesn't even have to match the soundtrack. Like the stores themselves, these screens are doing one thing while saying -- or not saying -- another.
"People are looking for a store that makes a statement," says Professor Tedlow of Harvard Business School. Note that he says "makes a statement," not "has something to say." That's because what a superstore has to say for itself is pretty much what most any retail operation has to say: buy, buy, buy. Its fundamental appeal might be the promise to save you time and money, but in fact, it depends for its survival on its ability to keep you on the premises and buying more than you came in for -- in retail jargon, the "look around a while" factor and its "add-on item" impact. As one executive summarized his superstore's strategy: "Stay longer, sample more and visit more often."
Sometimes the distraction is sustenance. If a shopper is going to spend the two or three hours most super-
stores bank on, the retailer had better provide food and drink, or that customer is bound to wander off. Sometimes this distraction is seduction. An overwhelmed customer is a passive customer, and a passive customer is suggestable -- turn here, go there, hold that, buy this. Either way, the distraction is what transforms the superstore into a destination.
Both Barnes & Noble and Borders have announced that their strategy through the end of the century is to focus on opening stand-alone superstores while cutting back on the older, smaller mall stores. And why not? These days, a bookstore is a bookstore, food court, music shop and newsstand rolled into one. Not only does it give the customer plenty of incentive to spend more time and more money on the premises, but it does so by keeping for itself the discretionary income that used to get spread around nearby stores in malls. During the superstore run-up in the early 1990's, according to one industry survey, mall traffic was down 14 percent, and a recent report estimated that 15 percent of conventional malls would go out of business by the end of the decade.
What happened to office-supply superstores will happen among other categories. After undergoing a meaningful process of consolidation," as an analyst puts it, the No. 1 and 2 players will remain, and maybe a third." But the specialty shop has not outlived its usefulness. For all their overwhelming inventory, superstores provoke a question of almost Zen-like clarity: What about consumers whose choice is not to have a choice? What if all a shopper wants is, as one retail analyst puts it, "to go on an errand instead of a shopping excursion?" In the cyclical nature of retail, the superstore is creating a demand for the very store it puts out of business -- the small single-category specialty shop.
"Consumers like having an alternative," says Maureen McGrath, a vice president in the research department at Smith Barney. "They want to have the convenience of buying a screwdriver without having to cross a 300-foot parking lot and a 125,000-square-foot superstore. Superstores are great; that's a great way to spend an afternoon. But that's a lot of square feet to be covering if all you need is a box of nails." Still, even mall developers now are routinely including one or more category killers to serve the anchoring function that department stores once did, while keeping a handful of specialty shops to meet the traditional needs of customers.
The category killer has indeed become a distinct breed of retailer, as the F.T.C. suggests. It's a place to shop, yes, but a place to linger, too, to take a family on a Saturday afternoon, to meet a friend for breakfast, to steal a few minutes for yourself on the way home from work, to daydream, perhaps, over a magazine and a cup of coffee that's infinitely more aromatic than anything at the local coffee shop. In this respect, the superstore is no different from the suburban shopping center before it, or the downtown department store before that. In the midst of all the hyperbole -- "super-," "mega-," "hyper-," "giga," "-max," -- it has been easy to overlook a simple fact. Sure, a superstore is a stationery shop or hardware store writ huge. But far more to the point, it's also a mall writ small.
Most Americans of a certain sentimental bent still harbor a soft spot for the mom-and-pop shop. Show them the shell of a department store in some middle American downtown, and they'll feel a pang for the distance between what a community must have imagined its future would be and what it has become. Even the once-unstoppable mall, as it exhibits signs of mortality, can evoke a fleeting nostalgia for a postwar period of economic expansion and optimism. But when the time comes to bid farewell to the heyday of the superstore -- and come it will, one day deep in the next century -- what will we be mourning?
Bigness, no doubt, but bigness of a type peculiar to the late 20th century, an era when it was still easy to believe that more was more, not less.

HEADLINE: Cable Ruling Endangers Access to C-Span

 BODY:

To the Editor:
On March 31 the Supreme Court upheld the 1992 Federal law requiring cable television systems to carry local broadcast stations (front page, April 1). 
 While wishing to support local media, both Congress and the Court fail to recognize that in some instances cable systems have been required to carry locally originated home shopping channels at the expense of C-Span, arguably the most effective televised channel that consistently serves the goals of an informed citizenry. C-Span estimates it has access to 3.5 million fewer viewers since the "must-carry" law went into effect.
That the Court held in favor of broadcasters on economic grounds and the need to support the broadcasting industry as much as on First Amendment grounds is disturbing. This is why Justice Stephen G. Breyer, voting with the majority, felt compelled to add a separate opinion disagreeing with the Court's questionable economic analysis.
In the dissenting opinion, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said that the Court "trivializes the First Amendment issue at stake in this case" by deferring to "a highly dubious economic theory."
Only a ham-handed Congress, and a Court prepared to overstep its authority and use economic hypotheses to meddle with economic policy, could pass and uphold a law that is supposed to serve the larger public good by encouraging, nearly forcing in some instances, cable systems to drop C-Span.
 
ROBERT KUBEY
New Brunswick, N.J., April 3, 1997
 
The writer is an associate professor of communication at Rutgers U.

HEADLINE: Film Studios Play a Game Of Summer Maneuvers

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 6

 BODY:
Will the Walt Disney Company blink and move its summer action film "Con Air" off its current opening date, June 6, because 20th Century Fox has defiantly moved its "Speed 2: Cruise Control" to the same weekend?
Will "Titanic," probably the most expensive film ever made (rumored at as much as $180 million and climbing) be completed in time to meet its current scheduled opening date, July 2? 
 Will Steven Spielberg's "Lost World: Jurassic Park," which opens on May 23, obliterate other movies opening in the weeks that follow?
Summer fever has seized Hollywood. "Studios Get Summer Sweats," said a recent headline in Variety. William Mechanic, chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, put it another way. "Nowhere to run, nowhere to hide, practically every weekend is booked," he said the other day.
Perhaps a dozen and possibly 14 or 15 films are opening this summer, each of which will cost, with marketing, well over $100 million. Never before have so many blockbuster movies been released in a single year, no less a single season. The result is a panicky game of chicken Hollywood style, in which studios position themselves for the best opening dates in the summer, the season of peak moviegoing in the nation.
"It's not a business for the weak at heart," said Robert G. Friedman, vice chairman of the Paramount Motion Picture Group. "You have to constantly watch the market and be flexible enough to change."
Given the sometimes perilous economics of the movie business, positioning for a single weekend is extraordinarily important. "We all know we can pretty much determine what your picture will do overall based on your opening weekend," said John Goldwyn, another top Paramount executive. "It's terribly important to own a weekend so you can get as much of the audience you're targeting."
Mr. Mechanic, at Fox, went one step further. "Unfortunately it's reached a point where your fate is written after the first matinee in New York," he said. "It's almost reached a point, one shot and you're out."
The result of this concern, some call it alarm, about opening weekends is a ferocious summertime competition among studio executives to position, to compete, to joust and feint over opening dates.
Early on, two films, Universal's "Lost World: Jurassic Park" (opening on May 23) and Warner Brothers' "Batman and Robin" (June 20) staked out their opening weekends. Every other studio ran for cover: no executive or film maker wanted to release a blockbuster film on those dates or even the following weekend.
Mr. Spielberg's "Jurassic Park" and the Batman franchise have proved to be enormously lucrative and now have built-in audiences. The early Hollywood buzz is that the new "Jurassic Park" is the film to beat this summer, while the new "Batman" (with George Clooney) will probably open to a huge weekend box office, but will quickly run into trouble from the competition.
But Barry Reardon, president of distribution at Warner Brothers, said with a laugh: "I'm not one bit uneasy. Look, everyone has cleared out in front of me. In back of me, I've got 'Hercules,' which is for kids, and 'Out to Sea,' which is Walter Matthau and Jack Lemmon and, essentially 'Grumpy Old Men' on a ship. I'm not worried."
Mr. Reardon's lack of concern is probably justified. Disney's animated "Hercules," which opens on June 27, is aimed at parents with young children, while Fox's comedy "Out to Sea," which opens on May 30, is targeted on the older audience that has made the "Grumpy Old Men" movies successful. Neither audience is the prime "Batman" crowd, which is mainly teen-agers and 20-somethings.
Certainly the most discussed shift so far -- and more shifts will undoubtedly take place in the next few weeks -- involves the decision by Fox to abruptly change the opening date of "Speed 2: Cruise Control." (Instead of terrorists taking over a bus, as in "Speed," the new film has bad guys taking over a cruise ship.) Initially the film was set to open on July 2, but two big films are to open that weekend, which is probably the busiest four-day period of the moviegoing year.
The two Goliaths are Sony's "Men in Black," a sci-fi adventure starring Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith, and "Titanic," the James Cameron epic about the ill-fated liner. "Titanic" is so expensive that it is being financed by two studios, Fox and Paramount.
Mr. Mechanic, at Fox, decided to move off that date and placed the new "Speed" against Disney's "Con Air," which opens on June 6. That action drama, starring Nicolas Cage, involves mayhem on a plane carrying convicts. Both films are colliding head on in pursuit of the same audience: young men.
There may be some personal issues involved. It is known around town that senior executives at Fox and at Disney are not too fond of each other and are in open competition. But Mr. Mechanic denied this.
"We moved the movie because it was a great date," he said. "It wasn't about 'Con Air.' Besides, we have an action movie with Sandra Bullock: we have a big female audience here, too."
Although rival studio executives said that Disney would probably decide to move the opening of "Con Air," Richard W. Cook, chairman of the Disney Motion Picture Group, said that this was not so. "We basically settled to open two weeks after 'Jurassic' and two weeks before 'Batman,' " he said. "We settled on that day and we're not going to move."
Adding to the unease this summer is "Titanic," whose cast includes Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet as lovers aboard the doomed ship. (A musical about the Titanic is scheduled to open on Broadway on April 23.) There are rumors aplenty that the movie will not be completed by Mr. Cameron in time for release on the choice July 4th weekend.
The options? It could move to July 11 against another blockbuster, Warner Brothers' "Contact," the Robert Zemeckis film starring Jodie Foster and Matthew McConaughey, based on the Carl Sagan novel, or to the following weekend when several smaller films are to open, or to July 25 when two more mega-expensive movies are to open: Sony's "Air Force One," starring Harrison Ford as a President threatened by terrorists, and Warner Brothers' "Conspiracy Theory," an action film in which Mel Gibson plays a conspiracy-obsessed New York taxi driver who meets up with Julia Roberts as a Justice Department lawyer.
In the meantime the jockeying continues. Fox recently moved one of its costlier movies, "Alien Resurrection," with Sigourney Weaver and Winona Ryder, to the autumn to avoid the summer onslaught.
"Are we getting nervous now?" asked Tom Sherak, chairman of the 20th Century Fox Domestic Film Group. "I'm sleeping less and less."

HEADLINE: Latins See Dickering on Sale of Jets to Chile as End of U.S. Ban

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's decision last week to allow the Lockheed Martin Corporation to submit a technical bid for sales of F-16 fighter planes to Chile is being widely viewed as the end of a United States ban on high-technology arms sales to Latin America.
While Administration officials say that President Clinton has not yet approved any sale of fighter planes to Chile, they acknowledged that permitting Lockheed to discuss technical and pricing information on the F-16 with the Chilean Government gives a strong indication that the United States is on the verge of relaxing the ban. 
 "It is very rare for the Government to release this data and then not allow the sale to go through," said an Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The final decision is still under review, but we wanted to allow American companies to submit bids to Chile before its March 31 deadline."
In Santiago, Gen. Fernando Rojas Vender, head of the Chilean Air Force, expressed joy that the United States had allowed American weapons makers to take part in the bidding, saying Lockheed's technical bid on the F-16 was "a very important step forward."
Chile, which is seeking to buy at least 20 advanced fighter planes, has said that it is interested in Lockheed's F-16 but that it is also considering buying planes from other countries that have no restrictions, including Swedish JAS-39 Gripen and French Mirage 2000-5 fighters.
Even Argentina, which has opposed lifting the United States weapons ban for fear of a regional arms race, has shifted its position, apparently conceding that United States arms sales to Latin America are inevitable.
A spokesman for Argentina's Foreign Ministry said on Friday that while his Government is still strongly opposed to a regional arms buildup, it is not concerned whether the United States removes or maintains the ban, especially since Argentina has no conflicts with its neighbors.
Military analysts said Argentina initially opposed relaxing the United States ban because it could not afford to buy the advanced weapons because of sharp budget cutbacks.
Argentina's military spending has declined 75 percent in the last 10 years after the country's return to democracy from military dictatorship. Meanwhile, Chile, which has the strongest economy in Latin America, has increased its military budget, which by law receives a substantial percentage of the country's copper revenues.
The analysts have said that the sale of F-16's would change the balance of air power in South America to favor Chile, which would have technology far superior to Argentina's, unless the Argentines also came up with the money to buy F-16's.
"This is about military prestige," said Wendy Hunter, a professor of political science at Vanderbilt University. "Argentina doesn't think that if the Chileans get new F-16's that they will come charging over the Andean ice field and attack them. Argentina is embarrassed because by comparison it has very little money to spend on new weapons and believes that without superior firepower, it doesn't have prestige."
While Argentina, a close United States ally, is publicly saying that it is no longer concerned about the possible lifting of the American arms ban, Government officials from both countries confirmed that Argentina is still lobbying the Clinton Administration not to allow the sale to Chile, or at the very least to permit the sale of less-advanced F-16's.
Indeed, some Chilean military officials have said that they are worried that in its final decision, the United States will not sell Chile the latest generation of F-16's, a move the Chilean military officials said could force them to take their business elsewhere.
Administration officials said the decision to allow Lockheed to bid for Chile's fighter planes was due mainly to pressure by United States weapons contractors who maintain that the arms ban is preventing them from competing in a potentially lucrative market that is open to foreign competitors.
The American weapons contractors cite Peru's recent purchase of a dozen Russian MIG-29's at a cost estimated at $350 million -- business the weapons contractors say is needed to preserve jobs in the United States.
But critics of relaxing the United States arms ban say that democracy is still very fragile in Latin America and that many countries do not have full civilian control over their armed forces and thus are ill equipped to regulate the new military technology.
They point to Peru's MIG purchase as another sign that the military can override other domestic and even regional concerns. While other South American countries have larger air forces than Peru's, United States analysts who assess the balance of power in Latin America said that Peru's Russian MIG's were the most advanced. The Russian MIG-29 fighter performs air interception and air-to-ground missions, military analysts say, that are not very useful in the kind of jungle wars that Peru has fought.
"While I don't see an immediate arms race developing in the region, I do see these advanced weapons purchases contributing to destabilizing relations between countries," said Sarah Walkling, a senior analyst for the Arms Control Association, a Washington-based research agency.

HEADLINE: Marshall Journal;
Tourists Shrug Off a Hepatitis Alert

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: MARSHALL, Mich., April 5

 BODY:
Of all the things that can go wrong for a tourist town, national publicity about an outbreak of infectious disease has to rank near the top of the list, right up there with losing a few bathers to shark attacks.
But this peaceful, 167-year-old town in south-central Michigan seems to be shrugging off its unwanted moment of fame as the epicenter of an outbreak of hepatitis A. Bed-and-breakfasts like the National House Inn, which occupies an elegant brick building erected in 1835 in the center of town, were full. And there was plenty of activity this weekend at the many antique stores and other shops along Michigan Avenue, the main street, which still looks much as it did a century ago. 
 Tourists either said that they were not worried about the widely reported outbreak or had not realized that this town had been hit the hardest. Everybody seemed to have heard that it had only been linked to frozen, contaminated Mexican strawberries served in school cafeterias.
"We haven't had any contact with the children," said Helen Kreuze, of Battle Creek. She was spending her honeymoon at the National House Inn with her husband, Nelson, a retired computer programmer. "They really did a good job of giving immunizations, so there shouldn't be a problem."
The Rev. Rodney Buzzard, of Auburn, Ind., who sat near the Kreuzes in the inn's breakfast parlor on Saturday morning, said he had known of some hepatitis cases in Michigan but his eyebrows rose and his jaw dropped when he was told that 97 of the 185 cases nationwide had occurred in this town of 7,000 people.
After a brief pause, Mr. Buzzard decided that might mean some bargains besides the antiques. "I'll bet the best place in the world to order strawberries is Marshall," provided they are fresh, he said.
Dr. Craig N. Shapiro, a hepatitis expert at the Federal Government's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, said that visitors to Marshall would not be risking infection unless they stayed in the home of someone with the virus. "A general tourist who is traveling there doesn't have to worry," he said.
Hepatitis A is transmitted through close personal contact, food, water and human waste. Nobody can know whether any tourists have caught the virus here, because it has an incubation period of two to seven weeks. But the odds are extremely low, Dr. Shapiro said, because the virus has affected only students and teachers who ate the contaminated strawberries, rather than local restaurant workers, for example.
Hepatitis A typically produces flulike symptoms and jaundice. The disease is usually mild and can last a few weeks. Nine students and school employees were briefly hospitalized here.
Marshall has weathered setbacks before. Founded in 1830 and named for John Marshall, the former Chief Justice of the United States, the town almost became Michigan's capital. The main advocate, State Senator James Wright Gordon, optimistically built a Governor's mansion here in 1839, a two-story house in the Greek Revival style.
The mansion, now occupied by a chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, is in a neighborhood known here as Capitol Hill. But Lansing became the capital after the State Senate defeated Marshall's bid by a single vote in 1847.
Halfway between Detroit and Chicago, Marshall boomed when the railroad arrived in 1844 and then suddenly suffered an economic collapse when the main railroad switching station was moved in 1872 to Jackson, 30 miles to the east. The town has changed little since then, mainly because of a wealthy industrialist whose family made a fortune selling what they called "rupture appliances" -- belt-like devices commonly worn by hernia sufferers before modern surgical techniques were developed.
The industrialist, Harold C. Brooks, became Mayor in 1925 and for 60 years poured his money into preserving the mid-19th-century brick buildings, which have attracted tourists ever since. There are even a few stone buildings, like the three-story Darling and Daughter Variety Store on Michigan Avenue, which has a mansard roof and a facade lavishly decorated with Corinthian columns and a large stone balcony overhanging the sidewalk. In 1991, the Interior Department designated an area that included 867 buildings here, including downtown, as a National Historic Landmark District.
Restaurants like the Coffee Pot, a diner in the middle of town where the popular roast beef and mashed potatoes special is just $4.65, are still housed in the old brick buildings. At midday on Friday, local mechanical engineers from a test course for trucks on the outskirts of town were trading jokes at the restaurant about the hepatitis outbreak.
But one of the engineers, Douglas Nielsen, spoke for the group and many town residents when he stood up to leave after lunch. "Of all the cities in the United States," he said, "why did it have to happen here?"

HEADLINE: Broadening the Appeal of Classical Music Radio

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
A year ago, Rick Cohn was considering how to recast a low-rated classic rock radio station in Tulsa, Okla. There, commuter trips last no longer than two singles, a jingle and a newscast. His station was competing with 32 others, including 6 rock stations, in a market with just $30 million a year to spend on radio advertising.
When he heard a pitch from SW Network, a Sony Corporation unit with a classical music format modeled after Top 40 rock radio, Mr. Cohn, the station's general manager, was skeptical. Classical music "was not even in my realm of consciousness," he said. 
 He got an eye-opener when audience research showed "there was a hole bigger than Dallas" among Tulsa radio listeners. The Oil Patch city, which takes pride in its symphony, ballet and opera, had been without a classical music station since 1994.
When Mr. Cohn told his bosses at Shamrock Communications Inc. he wanted to unplug rock for Rachmaninoff, "they thought I'd gone tipsy."
But a year after switching to the nation's only syndicated, 24-hour classical feed, Mr. Cohn's station, KCFM, has seen its advertising sales rebound and its audience grow by 50 percent, to a 2.9 percent share of the market.
Some listeners reacted patronizingly to SW's playlist of short recordings, but hundreds more were delighted. Some wrote letters, pledging to support the station's advertisers. One of the station's clients, a local BMW dealer, is pulling ads from competing stations and buying more on KCFM. And the Tulsa symphony credits the station with reversing a decline in ticket sales among younger patrons.
"We've got the wind at our back," Mr. Cohn said.
Tulsa is one of SW's most successful footholds. The fledgling network with 11 affiliates from Monterey, Calif., to Kennebunk, Me., is trying to bring classical radio to large numbers of people by redefining the standard repertory with familiar movie soundtracks, symphony excerpts and breezy disk jockeys who forgo announcing orchestral credits.
It is a strategy heavily influenced by baby boomer demographics and the new economics of radio-industry consolidation. So far, acceptance is slow, but the format has created controversy among the nation's traditional classical radio broadcasters, who mostly create their own programming.
Called SW Classical, the format drops some staples of classical radio, including opera and live concerts, as well as soundtracks exceeding 52 minutes during the day. SW loosely modeled the format from the programming developed in the early 1990's at Classic FM, a successful London station now owned by GWR Group P.L.C. of Britain.
Anthony J. Rudel, SW's programming vice president, called the format a contrarian play for group owners, who can now control up to five FM stations in the largest markets. His argument is that broadcasters that own several stations in a market can broaden their audiences without cannibalizing the listeners of their mainstream rock stations.
"The format is from album rock," said Mr. Rudel, a former program director at WQXR-FM in New York, which is owned by The New York Times Company. "This isn't groundbreaking. Our problem is to sell over the hurdle that classical is for old people."
In truth, SW is battling on two fronts. To win converts in places like Tulsa, industry analysts say SW must disprove the industry stereotype that classical radio wins an older audience unattractive to advertisers. It is an audience of interest to SW's parent, which owns several recording labels, include Sony Classical. Mr. Rudel must also win over critics, who accuse him of "giving the listeners pablum" for classical programming.
Saul Levine, owner of KKGO-FM, a Los Angeles classical music station, said: "To me, that's an embarrassment. We don't take a movement and say, 'Here is some Brahms.' " They're in effect saying, 'We don't want to tax your mind.' "
In a matchup that will be closely watched in the industry, Mr. Levine intends to go on the air this month with a new station broadcasting original programming to San Diego from a Tijuana, Mexico, frequency, XBACH-AM. SW's newest affiliate, KFSD-FM in Escondido, Calif., went on the air in February.
"We're going to beat them with traditional classic music," Mr. Levine said.
Mr. Rudel scoffs. "The old-style stations approach classical music like a museum. Don't touch. Don't enjoy.
"We're in the entertainment business; we make it interesting," continued Mr. Rudel, the son of the opera conductor and director Julius Rudel and the author of three books on classical music.
SW is alone among commercial syndicators in supplying 24 hours of classical programming, although National Public Radio and Public Radio International also syndicate classical programs to noncommercial member stations. SW, like ABC Radio and Westwood One, also supplies short segments of entertainment news to 800 stations in a barter-for-time arrangement.
Syndicators make a living selling national ads on their shows. Since SW's classical affiliates cumulatively are still too small for a national advertiser, stations pay for programming and sell their own ads, Daniel J. Forth, SW's president, explained.
About 460 stations play some classical music. Only 40 are commercial. As only commercial stations draw Arbitron rankings, quantifying the market for classical radio is a guess at best.
The format seems to be benefiting from use of classical recordings in film and television and a shift in baby boomers' musical tastes, said Robert Unmacht, editor of the M Street Journal, an industry newsletter. In the 240 markets surveyed by the Arbitron radio ratings service, classical radio is on seven-tenths of 1 percent of the stations, but wins 1.4 percent of the listeners, he said. By contrast, 15 percent of the Arbitron-ranked stations play country music, but they draw just 11 percent of listeners.
Conventional radio research focuses on how to split a genre like rock into classic and alternative. But in one unusual study, the nation's top three formats -- country, news talk and oldies, respectively -- failed in popularity contests. Classical came in second to Motown when audiences were asked their preferences for individual music selections, said Jon A. Coleman, a radio consultant in Research Triangle Park, N.C., who conducted the research.
"People intellectually say they want more variety," Mr. Coleman said. "Behaviorally, that's not how they respond. The reality is they want what is familiar.
"Tony's notion," he said, referring to Mr. Rudel, "is that classical music is part of our lives. We just don't know it. He wants to tap into that."

HEADLINE: THE RENT DEBATE: THE GENERAL;
Bruno, in Private War Room, Sees Himself as Pragmatist

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 6

 BODY:
For the first time since the early 1970's, the state laws that regulate apartment rents are in serious jeopardy. In a legislative year that resembles a minefield, rent is making the loudest bang, tying up talks on the budget, taxes and welfare, looming as a serious campaign issue and exposing deep divisions among Republicans.
It has come to this because of one man, Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, whose district near here has more farms than apartments. Previous Republican leaders here deferred on the rent issue to the political weight of millions of tenants, but Mr. Bruno, the affable, silver-haired former owner of a telecommunications business, has declared war. He has vowed to phase out regulation over two years, and said that if he did not get his way the current rent laws would not be renewed when they expire after June 15. 
 Rent regulation "is the best example of government at its worst that I can point to in this state," he said in an interview on Friday. He argued that it has discouraged new construction, worsening the housing shortage -- and thus, paradoxically, driving up rents -- and effectively forcing residents of unregulated apartments to subsidize those in regulated apartments. He said that deregulating the market would stimulate construction, adding $5 billion to the New York City economy over a few years.
Mr. Bruno's insistence has several Republican senators, from New York City and its suburbs, fearful that killing rent regulation would cause a backlash against them.
The first major test arrives Monday, when the Senate votes whether to take up a Democratic bill to extend rent laws for another four years. Mr. Bruno has vowed to keep the bill bottled in committee, and even the handful of Republican senators who favor rent regulation are hesitant to oppose him.
"As far as we're concerned, Monday is a litmus test," said Michael McKee, the rent law campaign manager for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "They can either support Joe Bruno or support the tenants."
Others, notably Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, have played down Monday's vote, stressing that it is only the beginning of a lengthy fight.
Mr. Bruno -- who cheerfully concedes that his district has no rent-regulated units -- insists that his opposition is a matter of principle.
Government "is over-regulatory, to the detriment of the majority of people," said Mr. Bruno, who was first elected to the State Senate in 1976. "I got into politics to try and do something about that."
Mr. Bruno, 67, from Rensselaer County, said his opposition to rent rules is a natural extension of a view of government that calls for lower taxes, less regulation and letting the free market hold sway. As evidence of his conviction, he noted that he began calling for an end to the rent laws a decade ago.
With one notable exception -- Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker -- few of the most involved people on either side of the dispute, from legislators to landlords and tenant organizers, doubt that Mr. Bruno's position is a genuine matter of belief.
"I think he sincerely believes the ultra-right-wing view of things, and is quite sincere when he says things would be better without rent regulation," Mr. McKee said. "I think he's out of his mind, but I believe he believes it."
Of course, it could be in everyone's interest to say so. The Republicans and landlords want to portray Mr. Bruno, a powerful ally, as a man of principle. And the Democrats and tenant groups would like nothing more than to make him out to be a Gingrichian ideologue.
At stake is rent stabilization, which begun in 1968 and which caps rents and rent increases for 1.1 million apartments, and rent control, the World War II-era system that imposes more stringent controls on 80,000 apartments. Most of the affected units are in New York City, where almost half the rental apartments come under one system or the other.
Mr. Bruno argues that the wealthiest renters benefit most from rent regulation, a contention aggressively contested by the tenant groups and Democratic lawmakers. It is the tenants living in Manhattan, "between 92d Street and 52d," he said, who "are the ones that are taking advantage of the system. I don't blame them. I don't fault them. The system allows it, and they're the beneficiaries."
Mr. Bruno said he understood people's fears about eliminating the system, but he insisted that, overall, deregulation would lower rents.
"They don't focus on the merits: Is rent stabilization good or bad? It's all emotional," he said. "The concept of government regulating people's lives is wrong when it's not necessary."
One of the few players in the drama who publicly questions Mr. Bruno's sincerity is Mr. Silver, who sees in the Senator's intransigence a covert strategy by the Senate leader and Gov. George E. Pataki. By this view, Mr. Bruno is the Governor's stalking horse, taking an extreme position that will allow Mr. Pataki to ride to the rescue with a compromise that eliminates some rent regulations but allows him to take credit for having saved the rest.
"Maybe the Senator is out there being a front man for a position the Governor advocates," Mr. Silver said.
Both the Senator and the Governor insist that this is not the case. But Mr. Pataki has added to such speculation by saying that he would broker the dispute rather than take sides, while indicating that he, too, wanted to end regulation, but more gradually.
Mr. Bruno's critics also note that last year, landlords' groups like the Rent Stabilization Association and the Neighborhood Preservation Association contributed more than $700,000 to state campaigns, overwhelmingly to Republicans, and that this figure does not include contributions made by individual building owners. Of the money donated by the landlords' groups, $174,000 went to the New York State Senate Republican Campaign Committee, controlled by Mr. Bruno.
"Any opponent of anything usually ends up saying, 'You're a tool of the contributors that oppose my point of view,' " Mr. Bruno said..
Three years ago, before he became majority leader, Mr. Bruno waged a successful campaign removing apartments from rent regulation if the rent was over $2,000 a month and the tenants earned more than $250,000 a year in two consecutive years. Some legislators speculated that Mr. Bruno would eventually settle for lowering that income limit, but he insisted he would not. Except for talking about a longer phase-out of rent laws, and making exceptions for the poor, elderly and disabled, he has not softened his position since announcing last December that he would force an end to the controls.
He warned that Mr. Silver and others questioned his resolve at their peril. "If they think they're going to take me to June 15," Mr. Bruno said, "rent control is going to cease overnight."
Lawmakers said they could not recall a leader of either house of the Legislature, from either party, who held so firmly on an issue that put his followers in political jeopardy.
But Mr. Bruno argued that the threat to Republican Senators had been overstated. "I don't believe that any one, single issue will ever affect an election, not one issue," he said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE PLAYERS: How They Stand"
The positions of the three main players vary in the debate over New York State's rent laws, which expire after June 15. Here is a brief description of each:
THE SENATE MAJORITY LEADER, JOSEPH L. BRUNO, REPUBLICAN OF RENSSELAER COUNTY Mr. Bruno has staked out the strongest position against the rent laws. Under his plan, any unit that became vacant after June 15 would be decontrolled, a policy known as vacancy decontrol.
He would expand the existing policy known as luxury decontrol, allowing rents of more expensive apartments occupied by wealthier tenants to reach market rates. And by mid-1999, he would decontrol all units, except those occupied by elderly, disabled and poor tenants.
ASSEMBLY SPEAKER SHELDON SILVER, DEMOCRAT OF MANHATTAN Mr. Silver has called for simply extending the current rent laws, and would even strengthen certain protections for tenants. But he has not ruled out expanding luxury decontrol to more units as a compromise.
GOV. GEORGE E. PATAKI, REPUBLICAN Mr. Pataki has tried to keep his position on the rent laws vague, saying he wants to broker a deal between Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno.
But he has called for gradually ending some, and possibly most, rent regulations -- though he would maintain protections for elderly, disabled and poor tenants. And he recently acknowledged that he supports vacancy decontrol.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO PRESS ISRAELIS TO ASSIST THE PALESTINIANS

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Minn., April 6

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met with King Hussein of Jordan here to discuss eroding confidence in the Middle East peace effort, President Clinton prepared today to push Mr. Netanyahu to make good on his promises to improve the lives of Palestinians.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Netanyahu will meet in Washington on Monday in a hastily arranged effort to stem the rising distrust between Palestinians and Israelis and to bring stability to the region. One proposal is to construct new Arab housing in East Jerusalem. Nearly three weeks of demonstrations and violence have followed the Israeli decision -- despite American opposition -- to build new Jewish housing in mostly Arab East Jerusalem, at a place the Palestinians call Jabal Abu Ghneim and the Israelis, Har Homa. 
 Mr. Netanyahu has proposed breaking the cycle of violence by moving directly to intensive negotiations with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, on the final political status of Jerusalem and the Palestinian Authority, and he discussed that proposal with King Hussein, recuperating here after a prostate operation at the Mayo Clinic on Saturday.
In a short briefing with reporters after the meeting at the clinic, Mr. Netanyahu said that the King was recovering and that he wished him well. "He is a good friend of peace and of Israel," he said.
Mr. Clinton, partly on the King's advice, is leaning away from dramatic gestures like final-status talks, fearing that proposals not well prepared will fail, causing further damage, senior American officials say. "Right now we're looking at more short-term confidence-builders," an official said. "We've got to get Netanyahu and Arafat talking again."
The Americans also want to know if Mr. Netanyahu, who leads the conservative Likud Party, is serious about trying to form a government of national unity with the Labor Party, as he has sometimes suggested. Mr. Netanyahu has lost popularity in Israel, and a unity government would be better able to negotiate and ratify a final settlement with the Palestinians that could give them a limited form of statehood and a capital in part of Jerusalem.
"I wouldn't rule out something dramatic, like a Camp David summit, down the road," a senior American official said. "Obviously our position would be different if there's a unity government. But what is vital now is to restore confidence on both sides -- so that the Israelis feel safe from terrorism and the Palestinians feel there are visible benefits from the peace process."
To help restore confidence quickly, Mr. Clinton will push Mr. Netanyahu to announce and begin construction of Arab housing alongside the new Jewish housing in East Jerusalem, American officials said. Mr. Netanyahu has said he will not stop the Jewish construction.
So the Americans, despite their view that changes to Jerusalem should be a part of the final-status talks, do not expect him to reverse himself, as he also refused to do in September when the Israelis opened an archeological tunnel near a major Islamic holy site in the Old City, setting off deadly clashes that killed some 80 Palestinians and 15 Israelis.
But the Americans want at least a private promise to avoid construction on disputed land during peace talks. On Saturday, Mr. Arafat demanded that Mr. Netanyahu stop "the Judaization of Jerusalem" by construction of settlements. He has sent Hanan Ashrawi, a well-known Palestinian official, to consult with Washington.
Mr. Clinton will also push Mr. Netanyahu to make good quickly on other confidence-building measures listed in the Hebron accords. Those include opening the airport in Gaza so Palestinians can travel abroad without going to Israel or Jordan; safe passage between Gaza and the West Bank; access to port installations for faster transit of goods; an easing of restrictions to allow greater economic activity in the Palestinian Authority, and more permits for Palestinians to travel to jobs in Israel.
Mr. Clinton is also pressing Mr. Arafat to forswear violence and terrorism and to resume security cooperation with Israel, to build up Israeli confidence shaken by the renewal of suicide bombings.
Israeli officials say Mr. Netanyahu wants Mr. Arafat to make an absolute commitment to stop violence if peace talks are to resume. Mr. Netanyahu has charged that Mr. Arafat gave "a green light" to the militant Palestinians of Hamas to use suicide bombers against the Israelis in response to the Har Homa decision.
While not supporting Mr. Netanyahu's charge, the Americans have also demanded that Mr. Arafat give "a red light" to terrorism and violence. But the Palestinians complain that their newly empowered police force is being asked to keep the peace so Israel can build more settlements in Jerusalem without negotiating Jerusalem's status. They say Mr. Netanyahu, through provocations like Har Homa, is trying to destroy the Oslo accords and then blame the Palestinians.
After meeting Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Clinton and his special envoy, Dennis B. Ross, will consult the Arabs. They want Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat talking again, and if that can occur in the context of confidence-building measures, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright may make her first trip to the Middle East to preside over the occasion.
"She will carry a lot of capital with her first trip to the region, and we don't want to waste it," a senior official said.
Mr. Arafat is skeptical about Mr. Netanyahu's offer of accelerated final-status talks in the next six months, with a Camp David-style summit meeting if necessary, and then, if all fails, a continuation of the gradual Israeli troop withdrawals laid out in Oslo. Mr. Arafat is concerned that Mr. Netanyahu is simply trying to avoid the peace agreement's formula of gradual troop pullouts and increasing autonomy for the Palestinian Authority. Under Oslo, the final-status talks are supposed to be concluded by May 1999.
King Hussein's Prime Minister, Abdel Salam Majali, said Jordan "has no problem beginning final-status talks provided the steps spelled out in the Oslo accords for autonomy proceed" on schedule.
Mr. Majali was with Mr. Netanyahu at the clinic, and said the Israeli's visit "is a generous gesture toward King Hussein and Jordan."
Meeting King Hussein last week, Mr. Clinton said he was "prepared to do anything I can" to get the peace effort "back on track and move it forward." With Mr. Netanyahu about to arrive, he said, "the less I say about it, the more likely I am to have some success," citing a time frame of "the next two to three weeks."
Mr. Clinton "is very energized on this," a senior aide said. "He wants to make a difference. But while there is a clear sense of urgency here, we also need to do this right."
That was also King Hussein's advice. He said the Americans should be more aggressive as "the arbiter" in shaping a just peace, and not merely be "the messenger" among the parties.
Ms. Albright would be welcome in the region, the King said, adding, "But I think it would be better if she visits at a time where there could be a visible result and some progress."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1754 words

HEADLINE: The Market vs. Larry Flynt;
Hustler Losing Out to Cable, Video and Web

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
The movie appeared in theaters as "The People vs. Larry Flynt." But as Larry Flynt himself has observed, it might have been called "$60 Million Worth of Free Advertising."
These days, Mr. Flynt's empire can use any free help it gets. He has been placing increasing emphasis on what is euphemistically called the "men's sophisticates" magazine category, even as the cost of renting a raunchy video can be cheaper than the $5.99 cover price of Hustler and as sexually explicit cable television channels and Web sites vie for his target audience. As a result, Mr. Flynt's operation seems to be falling behind in the swiftly evolving X-rated market. 
 Hollywood limelight aside, Larry Flynt Publishing Inc., solely owned by its namesake, is so secretive that financial information on the company is as wispy as the clothing on a centerfold model. But there are signs of trouble.
Within the last 18 months, the company has sold or closed a handful of magazines created for a more mainstream market, like Super Cycle and Maternity Fashions. The new focus: a group of 20 titles that -- with a few relatively staid exceptions like PC Laptop and the music-oriented Rap Pages -- is skewed toward sexually explicit publications like Leg World and Busty. Retrenching to this hard-core core is a risky strategy at a time when large chunks of the readership are finding the same photography and mindset through other media -- often for less.
Circulation is down, an especially damaging situation for a company that relies heavily on single-copy sales, rather than subscription or ad sales, for its estimated $100 million annual revenue. The flagship, Hustler, sold two million copies a month in 1976. But these days Hustler's press run is less than a million copies, and on average more than half are returned unsold, according to the 1996 statement of ownership on file at the Long Beach, Calif., postal service branch, where the company is required to submit audited figures to receive second-class postage privileges.
The skin-magazine business generally is "not as hugely profitable as it was," said Reed Phillips, a principal in DeSilva & Phillips, a New York investment bank that advises media companies. "The corner video store has made a big difference for these magazines." Playboy and Penthouse have also seen their circulations plummet in recent years.
"The readers are aging with the owners," says Martin S. Walker, chairman of Walker Communications, a longtime adviser to media companies. "They're not keeping up with the fantasies of youth."
By all accounts, Mr. Flynt, who declined to be interviewed for this article, runs an autocracy that allows him to make business decisions virtually unchallenged. There is no clear explanation why he has not followed a path similar to magazines like Playboy and Penthouse, which, under similar pressure, have inched their way toward a certain self-defined degree of respectability and have branched out. A full 58 percent of Playboy Enterprises Inc.'s estimated $7.6 million profit for the fiscal year that will end in June, for example, will come from its cable and video businesses, and just 18 percent from Playboy magazine.
Instead, Mr. Flynt has chosen to stay focused on print and on making Hustler "the most outrageous magazine out there" -- in the words of Hustler's executive editor, Allan MacDonell, to whom Mr. Flynt referred all questions.
Nor is there a clear explanation for the sale late last year of one of Mr. Flynt's chief assets, the Flynt Distribution Company, which handled the newsstand placement not only for Flynt publications but also for others, including newsstand copies of The New York Review of Books.
Mr. MacDonell said Mr. Flynt started the distribution business in 1976, when the magazine -- then only two years old -- had a circulation of 3.8 million and the founder "saw the checks that were going to the distributors."
Last year's decision to sell the operation was made to focus once again on the magazines themselves, Mr. MacDonell said.
Neither Flynt nor the buyer -- the Curtis Circulation Company of Hackensack, N.J. -- would disclose the price paid for the distribution company. But Mr. Phillips, whose investment firm was not involved in the transaction, sees the sale itself as a likely sign of financial trouble.
"It probably wasn't working, economically," he said. "It would be advantageous to have your own distribution company. Certainly, if it was doing all right, and they were satisfied with it, they would have kept it."
To be sure, Flynt Distribution could make for strange rackfellows. Michael Johnson, manager of direct sales and subscriptions for The New York Review of Books, said that under a contract acquired through purchase of another distributor, Flynt had handled about 5,000 copies of his publication's 140,000-copy press run. Unfortunately for The Review, the readers frequenting newsstands that carried Hustler and its spinoffs were not necessarily a literary crowd.
"We were such an odd title for them," Mr. Johnson said. "If we had relied on them for real distribution with profits attached to it, we would have failed miserably." His publication saw much better results through direct sales, he said.
Anthony DiBisceglie, director of client services for Curtis Circulation, said interest stemming from the movie had lifted sales of Hustler, though he refused to give specific numbers.
But Mr. Phillips said any uptick like that might be only a brief surge. "If they pick it up and it's not for them," he said, "it will be a one-time thing."
Approval from the masses has never been a priority for Mr. Flynt, who owned a chain of striptease bars in the South before starting Hustler in 1974. Circulation quickly soared, but so did public hostility. While on trial on obscenity charges in Lawrenceville, Ga., in 1978, a sniper shot him in the back outside the courthouse. The man who claimed credit for the crime, John Paul Franklin, was apprehended six years later.
Despite -- or perhaps because of -- the notoriety, Flynt Publishing has performed well enough over the years to gain respect from some quarters.
"Anyone who makes millions, it can't be all accidental," Mr. Walker said. "So I'm sure Flynt has a lot of business smarts. What was it Mark Twain said -- you can never go wrong by underestimating the American people?"
Whether that underestimation remains profitable, though, is unclear. Mr. MacDonell would not comment on what the earnings are on Flynt Publishing's $100 million in revenue, other than to say "we've got a pretty good ratio there."
John Harrington, who publishes a newsletter that tracks newsstand sales, said he thought profits were probably very good. "They're not paying a great deal in editorial or other marketing costs," Mr. Harrington said. "There are a bunch of specials that they sell, recycling that same editorial material."
There are no outside estimates of Hustler's circulation or advertising pages. But "we do pretty well with ads," Mr. MacDonell said. "We had 71 pages of paid ads in the July '97 issue of Hustler," which recently went to press. None of the ads were for cars, liquor or cigarettes, the holy trinity of other men's magazines. "It's all phone sex and mail-order," he said. "There might be one ad for balding."
But with licentiousness comes a certain editorial license. "We don't worry about offending anybody," Mr. MacDonell said. "We're not going to offend these mail-order companies."
Mr. MacDonell said Hustler includes serious articles, although the May issue features articles on the life of a porn-film star and the latest sexual fetish involving toes.
"You have to give them more than what they get from a video," Mr. MacDonell explained. "With the magazine, they will read. I get letters back, so I know they read. Hustler appeals to the brain as well as the sexual instincts."
The ads Hustler does sell are cheap, comparatively speaking. The prices peak at $25,000 for a four-color, full-page, while the 50 top-grossing magazines charge an average of $82,861 for the same kind of ad, according to statistics kept by the Publishers Information Bureau, part of the Magazine Publishers Association. Magazines with circulation comparable to Hustler's average $43,805.
"They are definitely below what you might call an industry average," said Judith S. Jorgensen, a spokeswoman for the association.
Although still not involved in video and cable television, the company is becoming more active on the Internet's World Wide Web, Mr. MacDonell said, where it already has on-line versions of Hustler and three of its other magazines.
The on-line Hustler (www.hustler.com) closely resembles the magazine in terms of tone and content, namely the editorial preoccupation with female anatomy. The site charges a membership fee of $12.95 a month, plus additional fees based on time spent on line.
"It's very inviting because there aren't any paper costs and not much production cost," Mr. MacDonell said. "A lot of it is reinterpreting what you've already designed. We have a four-person staff for the Internet alone." That may not sound excessive, but Hustler magazine has long been produced by a staff of seven.
But it is not as if Hustler has cornered the on-line sex market. "In a space like this, it has an awful lot more competitors than it does on the newsstand," said Scott Smith, director of digital commerce for Jupiter Communications, a Manhattan technology research firm. "There have got to be thousands."
New technology notwithstanding, it is hard to gauge the future of Larry Flynt Publishing. Unlike Hugh Hefner, for example, who propelled his daughter, Christie, through the ranks to chairman and chief executive at Playboy, Mr. Flynt, who is 54 years old and uses a wheelchair as a result of the 1978 shooting, does not appear to have cultivated a publishing heir among his five children from three marriages, although two, Larry Jr. and Theresa, are currently working there. Nor has he designated a successor from outside the family.
Would Hustler, then, fade away when its founder is no longer interested in running it?
"It's very hard to think of anyone within the established media who would buy it, because it's got that attached stigma," Mr. Phillips said. "If a magazine like that were for sale, more than likely someone outside the industry would buy it. It would be an ego buy. It really has to be someone who wants to live that life style, like buying a baseball team."
