PUB-DATE: April 7, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3157 words

HEADLINE: THE MILLENNIUM BUG -- A special report.;
Computers Are the Future But Remain Unready for It

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER with LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: CHIPPEWA FALLS, Wis.

 BODY:
They hear the heavy footfall of the approaching millennium at the Mason Shoe Company. And they wish it would just go away.
Like virtually every American enterprise large and small, public and private, Mason Shoe depends on its computer systems to manage the daily flow of information and paper. A bank of Hewlett-Packard 9000 computers orders materials, schedules manufacturing, pays bills, processes receipts and fills mail orders. 
 Nearly every document the company creates carries a date. That's a problem. A big problem.
As with hundreds of thousands of computerized operations around the world, unless something is done, and soon, on a dark cold night at the end of December 1999, the clock at Mason Shoe will strike 12 and the calendar will spin backward to Jan. 1, 1900 -- and Mason Shoe's computer, utterly confused, could make the company's business grind to a halt.
This 750-employee shoemaker in northwest Wisconsin is suffering its own small share of a looming global quagmire known as the year 2000 problem or the millennium virus, as it is also called (even though the millennium technically does not begin until 2001). And as of April 5 of this year, computer programmers at Mason Shoe and around the world had 1,000 days to effect a cure. One estimate of the collective cost runs as high as $600 billion.
Briefly stated, this is the problem: The software on many computers employs a two-digit shorthand for the date, so that the year 1982, for example, is written as 82. Unless the date fields are changed to reflect the arrival of the new century, computers will interpret "00" as 1900, with potentially frightening results.
Indeed, doomsday scenarios have become a staple of the computer industry trade press. Many articles read like works of science fiction, with images of satellites falling from the sky, a global financial crash, nuclear meltdowns, hospital life-support systems shutting down, the collapse of the air-traffic system and a wayward ballistic missile.
But despite such prophecies, almost all of the dozens of computer experts interviewed by The New York Times expect the life-threatening problems to be dealt with beforehand. And while they concede that unanticipated troubles could arise, most say the millennium will probably end not with a calamitous computer crash but with many expensive and disruptive headaches.
Without proper attention now, manufacturers could grind to a halt as their inventory systems break down. Customer orders could go unfilled. The Internal Revenue Service computers could begin spewing out millions of false tax notices. Bank records of loans and mortgages could become fouled up. Stock transactions could fail to clear.
Trying to prevent this will be costly. Sally Katzen, the White House official responsible for coordinating Federal year 2000 computer conversion efforts, estimates the cost of bringing Federal computers up to date at $2.3 billion over the next two and a half years. She acknowledges that that is probably a fraction of the true cost.
The Gartner Group, a Connecticut technology consulting company, estimates the global cost of year 2000 conversion at $300 billion to $600 billion, based on the overwhelming size of the job and the late start by most governments and businesses. Gartner's calculation of the Federal Government's portion of the bill: $30 billion.
John Lubs, president of Mason Shoe, is reluctantly budgeting $500,000 to reprogram his computers, all money straight off the company's bottom line.
"It's not even as satisfying as fixing a roof," Mr. Lubs said resentfully. "We get absolutely nothing out of it. We get to stay in business, that's all."
 
Troubled Legacy
A Quick Fix Fails to Appear
 How did we reach this Information Age impasse?
Many of the world's computers -- and many of the automated systems driven by them, from bank vaults to traffic signals to nuclear-tipped ballistic missiles -- record dates in a six-digit format: YYMMDD. Such date fields are embedded deep in the basic code that runs computer operating systems and applications software.
This shorthand way of recording dates is a bequest from computer programmers of years past. Although long recognized as a potential problem, it was largely ignored until recently as a result of denial, delay and misplaced faith in a quick technological fix.
Most recent computer hardware and software has been designed to recognize the difference between 1900, when Rockefellers and Carnegies bestrode the economy, and 2000, the era of Wal-Mart and Microsoft.
And yet much of the world's computer data -- fully half, by some reckonings -- still resides in programs that can identify the decade, but not the century.
No one has yet devised a silver bullet to attack the problem, a nifty program that would search out and convert every date field in a computer's operating system or software. Every computer system and every program that is date sensitive must be opened up and changed to become year 2000 compliant.
There's nothing glamorous or mysterious about the task. It is boring, grinding and ultimately unsatisfying work, like resetting the VCR and microwave clocks when daylight saving time begins. You get nothing new; only the opportunity to eat the same frozen dinners and watch the same shows.
And despite claims from dozens of computer vendors, there is no single software tool that can be used to find and fix faulty date fields, except in the simplest computer applications. One of the biggest concerns of data processing managers is that even if one computer system is fixed to accommodate the century change, it can easily be contaminated by noncompliant data imported from other computers.
Most computer users, like Mason Shoe, have developed their systems over years, customizing programs from a variety of sources to handle unique jobs, from processing millions of dollars in credit card receipts to scheduling production of men's dress shoes in sizes 8AA to 13EEEE.
The result is millions of one-of-a-kind computer applications around the world and an incredibly labor-intensive job of fixing them.
Mason Shoe's year 2000 problem -- like much of the world's -- began in the 1960's when it purchased its first computer system, an I.B.M. mainframe programmed in the then-current Cobol language.
Over the years, Mason grafted a variety of applications from a variety of vendors onto the central computer processor. Many of the companies that supplied the software are no longer in business and the technicians who installed and ran the programs have long since moved on.
Three years ago, company officials decided to upgrade their computer systems, buying a Hewlett-Packard networked system to run all the company's data processing programs. The Hewlett-Packard system was year 2000 compliant when installed, but rather than purchase all new software, Mason executives decided to "import" the custom-designed programs from the old I.B.M. machine -- virtually all of them written in Cobol, a language spoken by very few modern computers.
The decision seemed sensible at the time, making the conversion job cheaper and faster than it otherwise would have been. But the immigrant Cobol code brought with it a deadly stowaway -- the year 2000 virus.
When Cobol was in wide use, computers had a tiny fraction of the memory and disk space they do today. In an effort to conserve that precious space, programmers limited date fields to six digits, two each for year, month and day, assuming that the hardware and software would be replaced long before the end of the century.
But Cobol and other "legacy" systems proved more durable than their creators imagined.
Carl Lijewski, Mason Shoe's director of data processing, learned of the company's problem in 1995 when he attended a year 2000 conference for corporate computer specialists. He raised the issue before senior executives and asked for $50,000 to begin attacking the problem.
"We kind of pooh-poohed it when Carl first brought it up," Mr. Lubs said. "We kept asking him what this $50,000 was about. But he finally convinced us we'd better pay attention."
It turned out that the money was just a down payment on a bill that ultimately would be 10 times as much.
A good portion of that sum will go to Allegiant Legacy Solutions, a Blue Ash, Ohio, consulting firm that much as classics scholars keep nearly extinct ancient languages like Aramaic and Latin alive, specializes in Cobol and other now-obscure computer languages.
Mason Shoe hired Allegiant when executives discovered that they could not handle the job of scanning and scrubbing the company's three million lines of computer code by themselves.
An Allegiant programmer, Howard Hawkins, commutes by air once or twice a month between Blue Ash and Chippewa Falls, charging $1,200 a day plus expenses. Mr. Lubs considers the cost barely short of extortion, but feels he has little choice but to pay it.
"This stuff runs the business," Mr. Lubs said of his computer systems.
 
Unexpected Durability
Computer Code Lives Too Long
George Luntz, the president of Allegiant, knows that he and his fellow "Cobol cowboys" are not the most popular vendors in America right now. But he insisted that no one suspected in the 1960's and 1970's when they wrote programs with six-digit date fields that they would still be in use in the late 1990's.
"This has brought out all the conspiracy nuts, just like the Kennedy assassination," said Mr. Luntz, a 41-year-old South African-born former I.B.M. systems engineer who has been a computer programmer since he was 19. "I assure you, there was no conspiracy. We felt the useful life of these systems was 5 to 10 years."
But now, Mr. Luntz finds himself competing with Fortune 500 companies and the Federal Government for the services of Cobol programmers. His company has 25 employees, and he is advertising on the Internet for more, particularly programmers who speak the ancient mainframe languages of Cobol, Fortran and Assembler.
Mr. Luntz said that qualified Cobol programmers now demand annual salaries of $100,000 to $200,000 -- and the price is going up. Which is why he predicts that his firm's $1,200 daily rate for Cobol consultants is likely to double over the next 18 months.
"People have been saying for years that Cobol is dead, but most of the money will be spent fixing Cobol systems," Mr. Luntz said. Most universities and trade schools no longer teach Cobol and other old languages, but many young people pick it up at job sites where it is still used. And many retired programmers are going back to work, lured by the premiums being paid for their services.
"I get approached all the time by E-mail by people who say they're coming out of retirement to code," said Mr. Luntz. "They are out there and they are in demand, believe me."
One group of formerly retired Cobol programmers printed up T-shirts reading, "The Dinosaurs Are Back." The back of the shirt reads, "And We Are Angry."
 
A Very Big Task
Winners Will Get An Early Start
Peter de Jager, a Canadian computer expert who, in 1993, was one of the first to sound the year 2000 alarm, recently conducted a survey of business progress in addressing the problem. He found that no more than a third of private companies know exactly what they have to do to fix their systems and when they are going to do it.
"The rest are just beginning," he said.
The winners will be those companies that started early. They will not be competing for programmers whose prices are escalating rapidly and will have sufficient time to test their efforts.
"We think it could become a competitive advantage," said Steven L. Sheinheit, a senior vice president in charge of corporate computer systems at the Chase Manhattan Bank. He said that early completion of the year 2000 conversion job could give the bank the opportunity to acquire companies, or at least parts of companies, weakened by mishandled conversion projects.
Chase began working on the problem in 1995 and is confident that it will be ready for the changeover by the end of next year, allowing it to devote all of 1999 to testing, officials there said. The company expects to spend between $200 million and $250 million on the project -- about 5 percent of its total spending on information technology over that period.
Chase has bought software that identifies about 80 percent of the date references in computer code; the rest must be searched manually, bank officials said.
"The difficulty is not changing the code but testing it. If you change one line, you have to test the whole system," Mr. Sheinheit said.
Experts estimate the cost of testing -- both internally and with an organization's suppliers and business partners -- to be 50 percent to 60 percent of the total conversion price. That is why many of today's cost figures are probably low, they say.
The testing process involves a form of time travel in cyberspace. One must advance the computer's calendar to a date in the 21st century, then run the system both forward into the new century and backward to the 20th century to assure that calculations run smoothly.
That sort of trial is the only way to be certain that, for example, a bank's computers can correctly calculate mortgage or credit card payments that cross the century line. A consumer can run such a test by setting a VCR clock to Dec. 31, 1999, and programming it to record a program the next day.
There are three possible outcomes with such testing, according to Richard M. Kearney, the KPMG Peat Marwick partner in charge of the consulting firm's global year 2000 practice.
The first is success, in which the computer recognizes the new date and functions properly.
Otherwise, one of two things can happen, Mr. Kearney said. "The computer may not execute commands at all -- and that's the best thing that can happen," he said. "The alternative is they will run the calculations and come up with all wrong answers, in which case you have a very serious problem" -- ranging from millions of rejected credit card transactions to a huge data processing breakdown.
But one organization's problem is another's business opportunity. Lawyers are gearing up to sue companies that fail to complete their conversion projects and whose noncompliant data infect the systems of organizations with which they do business. Potential legal liabilities also arise for consultants and vendors whose fixes don't work.
And one enterprising insurance consortium is offering a millennium insurance policy to protect against year 2000-related foul-ups. The Minet Group and the American International Group are offering a policy with coverage limits as high as $100 million to cover business losses resulting from failed conversion efforts. But buyer beware: Purchasers of the policy must deposit as much as $80 million with the insurance companies to get $100 million in coverage.
 
High Stakes
I.R.S. Must Get It Right
On any given day, Mason Shoe has two people working on year 2000 conversion. The Internal Revenue Service has 700.
"We have an enormous problem, which may be unprecedented in its complexity," Arthur A. Gross, who is responsible for the I.R.S.'s information systems, said. "We can't get it wrong, because there won't be enough time to do it over."
The tax collection agency has more than 50 different computer systems running 19,000 separate applications from more than 62 million lines of program code. And that is just for the core business of processing 200 million tax returns and collecting $1.4 trillion in Government revenue.
Mr. Gross guesses that it will cost $155 million to bring those systems up to date by the turn of the century, but he acknowledges that his estimate may be low.
The agency runs an additional 30,000 programs on minicomputers and desktop machines for less critical functions like storing records and answering taxpayer questions. Mr. Gross said he had no idea of the scope or cost of converting them. "We don't know what we don't know," he said, adding that many of the systems will simply be discarded because they would be too expensive to fix.
Meanwhile, the challenge at the Pentagon -- and the stakes -- are exponentially greater. The military has 9,300 computer systems running 112,000 programs, according to Emmett Paige Jr., the Defense Department's top computer executive.
Mr. Paige told a Congressional committee last month that the Pentagon was about halfway through the process of assessing the scope of the problem, but that it had already identified 560 computer systems that it would eliminate rather than try to make them year 2000 compatible.
He said that the current estimate of conversion costs was $1.1 billion, but that he expected the cost to rise as the millennium draws near. Officials said that the estimate did not include all the costs of fixing computers at the National Security Agency, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon's "black" or supersecret weapons programs.
Bruce McConnell, a senior official of the Office of Management and Budget working on the year 2000 problem, expressed confidence that the Government's most important systems will be converted, tested and working properly on Dec. 31, 1999.
"I don't think we'll get everything done, but I hope we'll get everything done that has to be done," Mr. McConnell said.
But Bruce Hall, research director for the Gartner Group, said that Mr. McConnell, like most other technology managers, was probably underestimating the magnitude of the task he faces.
"It's like one of those Whack-a-Mole games at the carnival," Mr. Hall said. "Problems keep popping up faster and faster."
 
Laying Blame
No Warning From Vendors
Up in Chippewa Falls, Mr. Lubs is looking for someone to blame for his year 2000 hassles -- the companies that sold him his hardware, the technicians who installed the applications programs, the itinerant programmers who customized them for his shoe business.
"No one warned us about this date problem when they sold us these systems," Mr. Lubs said bitterly, shaking his head. "They created this problem and they won't admit it."
Mr. Luntz, the millennium-bug exorcist, contends that Mr. Lubs is laying blame in the wrong places. The year 2000 problem is not the product of a devilish computer industry plot, Mr. Luntz said, but rather of the unexpected longevity of computer programs and of the procrastination of industry and government officials.
Some other priority always came first, he said.
"The approach was in the great American tradition of 'We'll fix it when we have to, we'll delay it until the final payment is due,' " Mr. Luntz said. "Well, we've reached the final payment. This is the 30th year of a 30-year mortgage. They have to fix it -- and fix it at once."

TOMORROW: How investors hope to profit, and some pitfalls that may loom, as companies zero in on the year 2000 problem.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mason Shoe in Chippewa Falls, Wis., is budgeting $500,000 to reprogram its computers for the year 2000 and beyond. (Matthew F. Witchell for The New York Times) (pg. D11)
 
Charts: "Detecting Dates Amid the Data"
 
Computing's so-called year 2000 problems is a legacy of the 1960's and 70's, when programmers using software languages like Cobol conserved precious memory by using two-digit dates for the year -- 67, for instance, instead of 1967. The "19" was assumed. Unfortunately for thousands of companies like Mason Shoe, many of those old Cobol programs are still in use. And so, unless every date reference is revised in millions of lines of Cobol code across the land, on Jan. 1 2000, the computers will assume it is the year 1900. Changing the dates isn't the hard part; the challenge is determining which lines of computer code actually contain date-relevant data. The excerpt below, from a Cobol program that helps Mason Shoe track customers and sales calls, illustrates the challenge of finding and fixing the Year 2000 problem.
 
1. SEARCH: Poring over a printout containing thousands of lines of code, a programmer checks for commands likely to affect dates. MOVE DATIME is a likely suspect. The year-specific digits embedded in DATIME's underlying code can then be modified.
 
2. IDENTIFICTION: The next step is to trace all subsequent commands affected by MOVE DATIME, to insure that the underlying data code gets updated in these commands, as well. Commands with direct links to MOVE DATIME are fairly easy though laborious to trace . . .
 
3. PURSUIT: . . . but the real challenge is to ferret out all subsequent points in this program where a date-affected command like TA-LAST-CALL may interact with other commands. These subsequent date references may also need modification. This virus-like expansion can require the programmer to seek and destroy hundreds of date problems within this single program.
(Source: Allegiant Legacy Solutions) (pg. D11)
 
 
"What Could Happen"
Ideally, the millenium bug will have minimal effect on the average person. But if the debuggers are not diligent between now and Jan. 1 2000, the problem could intrude into everyday life in ways like these.
 
Your telephone service is terminated because of errors in date calculations.
 
Your driver's license expires becuse the motor vehicle department cannot recognize dates after Dec. 31, 1999.
 
Your broker miscalculates your capital gains, bond payments and other transactions because of faulty dates.
 
Your department store rejects your credit card because your payment is 100 years overdue.
 
Your bank's automated teller swallows your card, thinking it has expired.
 
Your Social Security payments are cut off because the agency computers miscalculate your age.
 
Your tax payments are erroneously billed as overdue by the I.R.S.
 
Your mortgage payment arrives late because the bank's computers fail to note the century change.
 
Your home VCR fails to record a show because it mistakes the year.
 
Your car's dashboard "Service Engine Now" light falsely indicates that the car is due for a tune-up.
 
Your pharmacy refuses to refill your prescription because the computer says it has expired.
 
While elsewhere . . .
 
Bank vaults refuse to open.
 
Building security systems fail, refusing to read coded cards or keys.
 
Production schedules at all kinds of manufacturing facilities are corrupted by improper-coding.
 
Automatic elevator programs crash, freezing high-rise elevators.
 
Airline flight schedules are thrown into disarray because of flaws in the air traffic control system computers. (Illustration by Al Branberg/The New York Times) (pg. D11)

HEADLINE: City Hall Deal Ties Subsidies To Job Growth

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In a sign that New York City may be strengthening its ability to retain corporate employers without doling out costly incentives, a European financial company that had threatened to move to Connecticut will remain in Manhattan and will get tax breaks only if it expands its local work force.
The agreement, with ING Barings, a British-Dutch financial services company, is the city's first deal that links subsidies solely to job growth, city officials say. Under the deal, the company has agreed to move more than 800 workers to an office tower on East 52d Street and expand its payroll in return for $5 million in tax breaks and other incentives. 
 In recent decades, the city has typically awarded multimillion-dollar incentive packages to keep employers from deserting the city for other areas where taxes and other costs might be lower. But the ING deal includes no up-front incentives, something city officials attribute to a stronger local economic climate and the relative lack of available office space in the suburbs.
Still, the city continues to negotiate incentive packages with other businesses, particularly larger Wall Street companies whose loss would pose a blow to the city's status as a global financial center.
Under the ING deal, no benefits will be awarded for the current payroll at the company, as was the case in every other so-called job retention deal over the last 25 years. ING Barings is expected to add 870 new jobs over the 15-year term of the deal, according to Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman for the city's Economic Development Corporation. If the company goes ahead with that hiring, it could receive up to $3.4 million in sales tax exemptions and $1.65 million in energy discounts, she said.
But exactly how many people are now employed at ING Barings, a division of the Dutch ING Group, is of some question. Ms. O'Leary said that ING Barings will "retain 841 jobs" in New York, while Lane Mitchell, a spokeswoman for ING Barings, said the company employs 957 people, up from 788 in January 1995. Ms. Mitchell declined comment on the city deal until it is formally approved -- as expected -- by the Economic Development agency's board tomorrow.
"With the changes in the New York City economy under Mayor Giuliani's leadership, we have begun to focus much more on job growth with the benefit packages than on job retention," Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said. "We are also trying to reduce the cost per job of the benefits in recognition of the change in the economic climate."
ING Barings, which occupies a total of 200,000 square feet of space at 135 East 57th Street and 667 Madison Avenue, will be moving to about 290,000 square feet at 55 East 52d Street, near Park Avenue.
The city's agreement with ING Barings marks the 26th "retention deal" struck by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration since January 1994, and in those deals, the city says it has retained 57,400 jobs. Companies like Republic National Bank, Capital Cities/ABC, Travelers Inc., Conde Nast and PaineWebber have received a combined $500 million in tax breaks and other incentives after threatening to leave Manhattan.
More recently, the city has tried to strike a tougher stance in negotiating with companies over tax breaks in recognition of both the city's improving economy and the shrinking amount of office space available in the suburbs. Certainly the $5 million package granted to ING Barings pales in comparison to the $183.9 million subsidy provided to the New York Mercantile Exchange.
But that has not stopped companies from lining up at the city's door to demand benefit packages. ING Barings threatened to move 500 back-office jobs to Stamford, according to Ms. O'Leary of the Economic Development Corporation. Standard & Poor's, a bond-rating agency and financial information service, has threatened to move as many as 2,000 jobs to Jersey City, unless the Giuliani administration grants sales tax exemptions and other incentives in lower Manhattan.
Some urban planners, including the Regional Plan Association and the Citizens Budget Commission, have criticized the granting of such tax breaks, because, they say, the incentives provide advantages against competitors in the same industry. And, they say, the subsidies shift the tax burden from the large corporations with the clout to get the benefit packages to small- and mid-sized companies that make up the backbone of the city's economy.
"With the financial services boom, it's not clear why the city should be subsidizing any financial services firms," said Ray Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit research organization. "But a giveaway conditioned on job growth is certainly better than one conditioned on job maintenance."
Like many financial companies, ING Barings has seen a spectacular increase in revenues over the last few years. Last Thursday, ING Barings reported that its net profit had soared 25.4 percent in 1996 to $1.97 billion, over 1995.
ING Barings will be moving to space vacated by Credit Suisse First Boston after the investment bank received a $50.5 million subsidy package to support its move to 11 Madison Avenue, between East 24th Street and East 25th Street. First Boston has brought new life to a neighborhood that had been hurt by layoffs and transfers by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and by New York Life.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Women's Hockey: No Fights, Just Skating

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: KITCHENER, Ontario, April 5

 BODY:
Her family had season tickets to the Chicago Blackhawks. Her brother, Tony, would eventually play in the National Hockey League. The boys in the neighborhood accepted her, and Cammi Granato assumed that the N.H.L. would accept her, too. Then, one day in junior high, her mother took her aside and explained the hockey facts of life.
"I wanted to play for the Blackhawks," Granato said. "My mother told me I was a girl and that was a boy thing. I cried. I loved hockey just as much as the boys did." 
 A dozen years later, women's ice hockey has gained international acceptance and authentication on its own terms. For the first time, the sport will be an Olympic medal event, joining two other first-time sports -- snowboarding and curling -- at the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan. Granato, 26, is a star forward on a hockey team that, with Canada, will be an Olympic favorite and try to sustain the gold-medal momentum generated by American women in basketball, soccer and softball at the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
That momentum was evident this past week at the women's world hockey championships as the United States advanced to the title game in what is serving as the qualifying tournament for the 1998 Winter Games in Nagano, Japan.
[On Sunday night, Canada defeated the United States in overtime, 4-3, for its fourth straight title.]
Both the United States and Canada qualified for Nagano, along with three of the other eight teams here -- China, Finland and Sweden. Japan, as the host country, received an automatic berth to complete the Olympic field.
Checking -- the use of bodies to impede the other team -- is not allowed in the women's game, which places a premium on the skills of skating, passing, stick-handling and playmaking. It is the equivalent of below-the-rim basketball, a fluid, finesse game that avoids the fighting and clutching and grabbing of men's hockey.
The women's skill level is such that Tara Mounsey, a defenseman from Brown University, was voted the best high school player in New Hampshire, man or woman, in 1996. In a 10-0 rout of Sweden on Thursday that secured the Olympic berth, Karyn Bye of River Falls, Wis., contributed a hat trick, three goals, and Granato scored twice as the United States outshot the Swedes by a stunning margin of 73-4.
"With the Olympics, people will know women play hockey and they will be shocked to see that we can play at that Granato said. "We're not trying to play a men's game. What we're trying to do is be recognized for our own game and respected for it, too. We don't have to be 6-4, 220 pounds."
The American women have traveled similar paths on their pioneering expeditions toward Olympic acceptance. They grew up in the East or in the Midwestern hockey belt of Michigan and Minnesota. They learned the game playing with their brothers and other boys. Some, like Vicki Movsessian, a defenseman from Lexington, Mass., first took to the ice on figure skates.
"My personality was too gritty for those outfits they had me wearing," Movsessian said.
One day, her father was sharpening her figure skates and he filed right over the toe picks. She told him: "Don't worry about it. I'm not going back."
Many of the American women played on boys teams from youth hockey through high school. Some had an easier time than others in gaining acceptance from opposing teams and parents. Stephanie O'Sullivan, a forward from Dorcester, Mass., had to tuck her hair inside her helmet and take the name of Steven on one youth team; Kelly O'Leary, a defenseman from Auburn, Mass., once played a tournament as Kevin O'Leary.
The youngest American player, Angela Ruggiero, 17, is a junior at Choate prep school in Wallingford, Conn. Most of her teammates played at Ivy League colleges or at other Eastern schools, such as Providence and Northeastern, which have varsity teams. Erin Whitten, the starting goalie from Glens Falls, N.Y., has played in several men's professional minor leagues.
"Playing against men, you're at the bottom rung of the ladder and you scrape to get playing time and respect," Whitten said. "There's a lot of satisfaction when you gain that respect. But people look at me and some say I shouldn't be there because I'm a girl. Or, 'She's doing the best she can, but she's still third string.' With the women, I'm one of the elite players. It makes a big difference when we all have that respect. Winning an Olympic medal with the women's team would be way more satisfying than simply being part of a men's team."
Unlike women's basketball, the Olympic afterglow will not help light the way for a professional women's hockey league. The Olympics will be the summit for these careers. So, many of the Americans, eligible for training grants between $10,000 and $20,000 from the United States Olympic Committee, have delayed school, careers and their lives as they try to make the final roster for Nagano.
Lisa Brown-Miller, of Union Lake, Mich., resigned from her job last June as head coach of Princeton's women's team to follow her Olympic dream. Instead of going on a honeymoon two summers ago, she went to a hockey training camp.
Brown-Miller said her husband told her, "I don't want you sitting on the couch and watching the Olympics and saying to yourself, 'If I had stuck with it, I'd be there.' "
Women's hockey first appeared in Canada in 1892; Canadian television recently identified the oldest active player in the country as Mabel Boyd. She is in her 70's. The Canadians defeated the Americans to win the previous three world championships, with the first title coming in 1990. Twice in the early 1990's, goalie Manon Rheaume participated in exhibition games with the Tampa Bay Lightning of the N.H.L. Canada's current team is so skilled that Rheaume, now 25, was cut from the women's squad a week ago.
The Americans are catching up. In this decade, the number of women playing hockey in the United States has jumped from 5,533 to 20,555, according to USA Hockey, the national governing body. Three years ago, Minnesota declared women's hockey a varsity sport on the high school level; this season, 67 teams registered to play.
On the college level, women's hockey is an emerging sport on the 25th anniversary of Title IX, which forbids discrimination on the basis of gender. The sport perfectly fit the International Olympic Committee's pressured need to add more women and women's team sports to the Winter Games.
Finland, a three-time bronze medalist at the world championships, is considered the other medal favorite at Nagano. But China, which lost, 6-0, to the United States in the semifinals, has made an intriguing emergence since 1992. Coach Zhang Zhi Nan said that only 70 women in the entire country play on an elite level, all of them from the northern industrial city of Harbin. Still, the Chinese have developed an assertive style, based on hard work and from watching videotapes of N.H.L. games.
The men in the former Soviet Union once dominated Olympic hockey, but the Russian women's team is struggling with inexperience and financial problems now that the country's sports machine is no longer greased by state support. Russia's top player, Yekaterina Pashkevich, has followed the lead of many Russian figure skaters by coming to live and train in the United States. She coaches the women's club team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
When she began playing as a girl, Pashkevich said, people told her parents, "Your daughter is weird." The national team is only three years old, and Russian players struggle, she said, "because the economy is bad and people can't buy equipment and pay for ice time."
On a tour of the United States several years ago, the Russian women had to rely on the charity of American prep schools to improve their shoddy equipment. But the failure to make the Olympics may now turn away sponsors and kill the women's program outright, Pashkevich said.
"If a team is not going anywhere, no one wants to spend money," she said.
It is quite another story for the Americans. Cammi Granato is now one step closer to fulfilling a goal that began when her brother Tony played in the 1988 Winter Games. A onetime New York Ranger, he now plays for the San Jose Sharks.
"I was 16; I wanted so bad to be an Olympic athlete," Cammi Granato said. "Should I try basketball? Volleyball? It's great now to have a chance to get there playing hockey. It's a dream come true."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Netanyahu Visits King On Way to See Clinton
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met with King Hussein of Jordan at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., where the King was recuperating after a prostate operation. They discussed the troubles of the Middle East peace talks. President Clinton will hold a hastily scheduled meeting with the Israeli leader in Washington today; he is expected to push Mr. Netanyahu to make good on his promises to improve the lives of Palestinians. A1
 
China Cracks Down on Pirates
China's copyright police have begun pursuing and arresting pirates of compact disks, after years of ignoring demands for action from the United States and elsewhere. Since a concerted effort began in December, the authorities in one province say, more than 100 offenders have been arrested and 28 underground factories shut down. Dozens more factories are believed to exist, but many have suspended production. A1 

Embassy Plan in Berlin Stalls
Architects of a new American Embassy on a prime site in Berlin said plans for it had been put on hold because of a lack of money. The new embassy was being financed from the sale of other American-owned properties in Germany, but the money has only trickled in. The building was expected to be finished by 1999, when the German Government moves back to Berlin from Bonn. But now diplomats are reluctant to say when it might be ready. A4
 
90 Killed in Attacks in Algeria
Attackers armed with knives, axes and guns massacred about 90 people in Algeria in less than two days, witnesses said. The attacks, which survivors attributed to various Islamic factions, all took place within about 60 miles of the capital, Algiers, the same area where security forces have been waging a fierce offensive against the militants. It was some of the worst violence since the insurgency began five years ago. (AP)
 
New Goals on Environment
Environmental ministers from 53 countries plan to open talks at the United Nations this week on setting new targets in fields ranging from conserving fresh water supplies to limiting chemical pollution as the fifth anniversary of the Rio Earth Summit meeting approaches. Their aim is to reach enough agreement over the next three weeks to allow world leaders to endorse their decisions at a special session of the General Assembly in June. A3
 
Hapsburgs Return to Sarajevo
Descendants of the Hapsburg Archduke Franz Ferdinand, whose assassination in Sarajevo set off World War I, visited the Bosnian capital for the first time since the assassination. At the site of the killing, Otto von Hapsburg and his son Karl unveiled a simple post that read, "Let peace rule the earth." The spot was once marked with a plaque honoring the assassin, a Serbian nationalist who opposed Hapsburg rule. A4
 
NATIONAL A10-13, B8
 
Generator Problem Forces Shuttle to Turn Back
The seven astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia were forced to cut their trip short by 12 days and prepare to land tomorrow because a power generator on board was deteriorating and could explode. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said there was no immediate danger, so the craft did not need to return today. The crew shut down all non-critical equipment to conserve power. A10
 
Rowhouse Fire Kills Five
Two adults and three children died in a fire that consumed a West Philadelphia rowhouse. The ruined building then collapsed, injuring eight firefighters who were inside. The fire was controlled within an hour, but a woman and three of her five children on the second floor and a man in another apartment were killed. Fire officials said the fire resulted from a faulty electrical outlet where a space heater was plugged in. A13
 
Storm Cripples Upper Plains
A blizzard stranded travelers on the northern Plains and made life miserable for volunteers sandbagging towns threatened by floods in Minnesota. Two people were killed in Wisconsin. Snowdrifts as high as 20 feet closed hundreds of miles of highways in Wyoming, the Dakotas, Nebraska and the eastern edge of Montana. Dikes failed along the Red River in Breckenridge, Minn., which was swollen by melting snow from previous storms. B8
 
Forum for Candidates-to-Be
Most of the Democrats who are considered possible candidates for governor of California next year attended the state party convention, but all but one kept their intentions secret. Senator Dianne Feinstein and Leon E. Panetta, the former White House chief of staff, were the most familiar faces there. But only Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis made his intentions plain, attacking the presumptive Republican nominee, Attorney General Daniel E. Lungren. A11
 
Two Die in Boat Accident
A pleasure boat carrying 11 people sank under a barge 100 yards from a Coast Guard cutter in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., killing two people. The 25-foot rented boat was taking on water when it went under the barge about 3 P.M., said Petty Officer David French of the Coast Guard. The condition of the injured could not be learned. The accident occurred on the Intracoastal Waterway, which runs up the Atlantic coast just inside the shoreline. (AP)
 
Kidnapped Boy Is Sought
Widespread publicity generated hope and telephone tips in the case of a 10-year-old boy who was kidnapped at knifepoint outside his house in the rural community of Beaumont, Calif. The boy, Anthony Michael Martinez, was taken Friday by a thin white man, 25 to 30 years old, with blue eyes and a mustache, who asked him to help look for a lost cat, officials said. Family members have been ruled out as suspects, the authorities said. (AP)

Without Big Tax Breaks, Company Still Chooses City
A European financial company that had threatened to move to Connecticut decided to remain in Manhattan instead, even without a large package of up-front tax benefits from the city. The company, ING Barings, will get tax breaks only if it expands its local work force. City officials said the deal was the first of its type and was made possible by the stronger local economic climate and a shortage of office space in the suburbs. B1

A police officer shot and killed a 16-year-old high school student who the police say was wielding a machete in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan. The police defended the shooting, saying officers felt their lives were in danger. But some residents who said they witnessed the encounter said the shooting appeared unjustified, and small crowds gathered on streets in the neighborhood, where shootings by police officers have provoked violence before. Seventy-one illegal immigrants were arrested at a New Jersey perfume factory, just two days after new, far-reaching immigration laws took effect. Officials said that the timing of the arrests was coincidental, and that no "mass roundups" were planned as a result of the new law.

New York City agreed to sell 76,000 Garden State Parkway tokens to a New Jersey bus company. Motorists had used the tokens instead of quarters in city parking meters. They are worth 35 cents in parkway toll booths, but the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the parkway, refused to buy them back from the city.

A Brooklyn undertaker opened New York City's first full-scale funeral parlor for pets. He plans to charge $300 to $1,500 for a coffin, a service and two hours of viewing, compared with $2,500 to $5,000 for funerals for humans. B3

Bank to Buy Stockbroker

HEADLINE: Volcano Captured Corn, Chilies and House Mice

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
IT was early evening in the rainy season when the villagers felt the ground shake and then probably trembled themselves at the sight of blasts of steam in the distance. They dropped what they were doing and fled, abandoning their thatch-roofed huts, fruit trees in full ripeness and unwashed dinner dishes.
That was 14 centuries ago, around the year 590. The people saved their lives but lost their village, which was buried virtually intact under more than 16 feet of fine ash from an erupting volcano half a mile away. Only now are archeologists digging through the ash, at the site they call Ceren in present-day El Salvador, and finding remains of the village so well preserved that it has been stamped with the inevitable sobriquet of Central American Pompeii. 
 Paleoethnobotanists, in particular, are having a field day. At Ceren, these specialists in the uses of plants by early people have uncovered stores of ceramic vessels filled with beans, squash, cacao and other plant foods -- dried but still recognizable after all these centuries. They also gathered charred seeds, burned in the volcanic heat, which could be identified under the microscope.
As they examined the site in finer detail, botanists have even identified plants that had disappeared, though not without a trace. Some left delicate impressions of leaves, seeds or stems in the ash. Some that had completely decomposed left cavities in the packed ash. The cavities served as molds, which, when filled with dental plaster, produced clear replicas of plants. In this way, plaster casts re-created the corn cribs filled with unshucked ears as they looked the evening the volcano struck.
Archeologists and botanists said Ceren is revealing for the first time much about the everyday lives of ordinary people in sixth-century Mesoamerica: their dwellings and crops, what they ate and how, their economy and how it contributed to the classic period of Maya civilization. Most explorations have concentrated on the grand ceremonial centers of the Maya rulers and priests.
"What we learn from Ceren," reported a team of scientists led by Dr. David L. Lentz of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, "is that people living on the fringes may have made a contribution to the development of Mayan culture by producing surpluses and providing resources necessary to sustain the larger centers."
The director of Ceren excavations, Dr. Payson Sheets, an archeologist at the University of Colorado at Boulder, said the stores of food, the abundance of finely painted ceramics and the evidence of trade goods showed this to be a prosperous community of farmers. In one of the more humble households, archeologists counted more than 70 ceramic vessels.
"It's surprising, but also sad," Dr. Sheets said in an interview last week. "The standard of living 1,400 years ago was higher than it is now among the peasants of El Salvador."
Such archeological discoveries at a farming community, important under any circumstance, are especially rare in tropical climates where moisture spells rapid decay for all organic materials, thatch, twine and the dinner beans, unless they happened to be sealed in the dry, airless depths of ash. The bean collection from Ceren is one of the largest found at any Mesoamerican archeological site.
The existence of the buried village first came to light in 1976, but it was more than a decade before intensive excavations got under way. So far, 11 buildings have been uncovered: dwellings, an obsidian workshop, a food storehouse, a sauna for ritual sweat baths, a religious center and a community hall. The structures had adobe walls and roofs of thatch made from a type of grass that is now extinct, apparently killed off by alien grasses from the Old World. Found in the surviving thatch were the bones of mice that had infested the roofs.
Ground-penetrating radar surveys have detected the sites of many more dwellings, leading to estimates that 200 to 300 people lived in the village. Researchers are not sure if these were Mayans or members of local ethnic groups, either Lenca or Xinca. The nearest major center of Maya culture, then in its heyday, was Copan, about 60 miles away in Honduras.
Whoever they were, these people had made this site in a fertile valley their home for several centuries. Archeologists can almost pinpoint the time it all came to an end.
It was the rainy season of July or August, because evidence of fully ripe fruits of that time of year was found in abundance. It must have been early evening, probably between dinner and sleep. The men had certainly returned from work in the corn fields, because their tools were stacked near the dwellings. Food was still in pots on the hearths. Some serving bowls were empty but unwashed, still bearing the marks of people eating a semisolid substance, possibly corn meal gruel, with their fingers. And it was before they had retired for the night, or else their sleeping mats would have been rolled out.
In an interview and a report in a recent issue of the journal Latin American Antiquity, Dr. Lentz said that an analysis of the plant remains showed that Ceren had developed a diverse agriculture of orchards, household gardens and large corn fields. At least at this time of year, they had a variety of foods to eat: corn, several kinds of beans, squash, chili peppers, avocados, nuts, cherries and other fruits. They drank cacao, the favorite beverage of the Maya. They got their animal proteins from deer, ducks, dogs and freshwater mollusks.
Dr. Lentz and his colleagues concluded that the Ceren farmers "had at least as varied a diet as the Maya nobility" living at Copan. Most of these foods would be familiar to Central Americans today. But Dr. Lentz said, "We had no record of chilies anywhere in the Mayan realm -- here we find thousands of them, just everywhere, hanging from the rafters."
Cotton appeared to be a major crop, he said, with the fibers used not only for the villagers' own clothing but for trade. They may have used cotton cloth as exchange material for obsidian, exotic ceramics and other imported goods found at the site.
The botanists also found evidence that the people were grinding cotton seeds to extract the oil, possibly for cooking. Although it has never been demonstrated that the Maya knew about cottonseed oil, Dr. Lentz said, they probably did use it for cooking because they had few other sources of oil. Their only domesticated animals were dogs, turkeys and ducks.
Dr. Lentz, who also directs ethnobotanical research at the City University of New York, was joined in his work on Ceren by Dr. Marilyn P. Beaudry-Corbett, a ceramicist at the University of California at Los Angeles; Dr. Maria Luisa Reyna de Aguilar, a botanist in San Salvador, and Dr. Lawrence Kaplan, a biologist at the University of Massachusetts at Boston.
"Ceren provides part of the answer to the question of how the Maya were able to develop and maintain such large ceremonial centers," Dr. Lentz said. "These farmers were producing the agricultural surpluses that probably contributed to the civilization's wealth and culture."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Getting Drugs, Getting High: Same Old Same Old

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

THE STORY OF JUNK
By Linda Yablonsky
325 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.
So how does a girl get from Point A to Point B: from a wholesome childhood in an all-American suburb to a grungy life as a heroin addict and dealer in Greenwich Village? How does a nice girl end up smuggling heroin from Thailand in condoms pushed up her rectum? Well, this is the tale Linda Yablonsky sets out to tell in her chilling if sometimes tedious first novel, "The Story of Junk." 
 Certainly this novel couldn't be more timely. After all, stories about middle-class heroin use have become a regular feature on television news magazines, heroin chic has become the fashion world's newest craze and "Rent," a musical about life among the users, transvestites and would-be artists of the Lower East Side, has become a hit, as has "Trainspotting," a high-spirited movie about Scottish heroin addicts directed in the style of Richard Lester's Beatles films.
As for "The Story of Junk," its gritty portrait of heroin addiction stands in sharp contrast to the Technicolor effusions of "Trainspotting" and "Rent." There are alarming stories about friends passing out from overdoses, buying methadone that other addicts have spit into bottles and dying of AIDS. There are gruesome descriptions of addicts covered with sores and bruises, trolling the mean streets of Alphabet City looking for a fix, and equally gruesome descriptions of what it feels like to go cold turkey. Even Ms. Yablonsky's more upbeat stories have a way of depressing the reader: endless days and nights spent in cold apartments and hot restaurants, listening to people with "great haircuts and shiny suits" talk about their habits and say things like "I think death must be bliss."
"While other drugs work to alleviate pain, excite the mind or otherwise trick the senses," her narrator says, "heroin plays with the soul -- or whatever it is makes a person uniquely appealing and distinguishable. Like an enveloping shadow dissolving day into night, it sneaks across your vision and tries to put it out, whatever that joy is by which you live, it creeps inside and pushes you down, making you smaller and smaller, a tiny flame burning down."
Framed by the unnamed narrator's arrest and interrogation by a narcotics officer, "Junk" jumps back and forth in time to tell the story of how she reached this point. We learn that she is an aspiring writer and sometime restaurant cook who was attracted to the bohemian world of New York, so different from the middle-class world of her youth. We learn that her dabbling in heroin led to a habit and that that habit, in turn, led to dealing. We also learn that her regular customers are "chippers and partyheads, overachievers, friends," in other words, the artists, musicians and poets she hangs out with in SoHo and the Village.
"A junk-bond boom on Wall Street is flooding the underground economy with a steady flow of disposable cash," the narrator of "Junk" says of the 1980's. " 'Discretionary income,' they call it, and some of it trickles down here. The world seems made of junk: junk money, junk food, junk stores, junk powder. I got into junk at just the right time."
Writing in edgy, serviceable prose, Ms. Yablonsky gives the reader some evocative snapshots of the worlds her characters frequent: a Village restaurant "hung with paintings and other works of art by the better-known clientele" and equipped with a huge walk-in fridge that also serves as a drug parlor; Avenue B, where there are "bodies slinking in and out of guarded doorways, diving through holes punched in concrete walls, wiggling into gaps in the sidewalk deep as wells, shooting up in empty lots, nodding on the hulks of abandoned cars." She provides some voyeuristic glimpses of their lives: being checked for track marks by suspicious dealers; taking Valium, codeine and Darvon to overcome the pain of withdrawal, and yards and yards of stoned conversation.
None of this talk is terribly interesting, as the narrator, who has become privy to her clients' secrets, observes: "I'm hearing the same things too many times; I don't want to hear them anymore. I don't want to know who steals what to get money for their drugs. I don't want to know who they lie to or why. I don't want to know who's dying or who's getting famous."
This, in the end, is the problem with this novel. Though Ms. Yablonsky proves she can be a vivid storyteller when she has an real story to relate (like her narrator's smuggling trip to Thailand), and demonstrates an anthropological flair for recording the mores of the downtown drug scene, her narrative often devolves into a weary recitation of drug buys, drug busts, drug parties: the deadening routines that frame an addict's life. As for the characters (the narrator's lover, Kit; the narrator's former lover Rico; the narrator's drug source Angelo; even the narrator herself), they, too, tend to blur into one another, all of them obsessed with junk: where to get it, how to ingest it and occasionally how to kick it.
As Ms. Yablonsky, herself, writes: "Everyone's got a story to tell, and most of those stories will change in some way, every time they're told. Not this one, not the story of junk. This one's always the same."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Above 125 Yen And Also Soars Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose above 125 Japanese yen for the first time in more than four years yesterday and surged against the German mark, powered by the lure of higher interest rates in the United States and optimism over Europe's single-currency plan.
The dollar was also helped by an easing of trade friction between the United States and Japan, following Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's trip to Tokyo, and by rallying American stock prices. 
 The dollar hit an intraday high of 125.80 yen, the strongest since mid-January 1993, before settling in New York at 125.56 yen, up from 124.31 yen on Friday.
Against the mark, the dollar rose to 1.7109 marks in New York, up 1.5 percent from 1.6854 Friday and the highest level in a month.
Currency traders said the growing attraction of higher United States interest rates was an important catalyst for the dollar's advance, which began with a surge of dollar-buying in Japan. Higher interest rates make yields more attractive on dollar-denominated securities.
Traders also bought the dollar in reaction to Mr. Rubin's remarks on Friday and again yesterday, in which he asserted that currency rates should not be used as tools in trade disputes.
His statement calmed concerns that the United States might want a stronger yen and a weaker dollar, which could help narrow Japan's widening trade surplus with the United States by making Japanese goods more expensive here. As a result of his remarks, traders largely ignored a report that showed that Japan's trade surplus rose in February for the second consecutive month.
The dollar got another lift from a meeting of European finance ministers over the weekend in the Netherlands. At the meeting, the German Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, appeared to soften his stance about strict entry criteria for Europe's single-currency plan, which is to start in January 1999.
Mr. Waigel's apparent shift dampened speculation about a possible delay in the introduction of the Euro, which will displace the mark as Europe's predominant currency. The mark had recently drawn strength as a haven should the single currency plan encounter trouble.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Dumb and Whiney

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
We are fortunate today to have with us Dr. B. B. Braithwaite, the eminent authority on self-help, diet, getting rich quick and finding spiritual peace in 30 days. Dr. Braithwaite has kindly agreed to answer a few questions from our readers.
First, Doctor, can you explain to Baffled Baseball Fan why our Government refuses to let our teams play baseball in Communist Cuba while leaning over backward to encourage our businessmen to toady for big bucks in Communist China? 
 "Gladly. All Communism is bad, but Cuba's Communism is worse than anybody else's Communism. We have spent 40 years trying to abolish it, and it still refuses to disperse. Why reward such insolence by letting Cubans enjoy our national pastime?
"China, on the other hand, not only picks up the bill for our excessively costly elections, but also provides our retailers with cheap tennis shoes for which they can charge us ridiculously high prices. Without ridiculously expensive cheap tennis shoes, Americans might never again be able to get out of the car and walk around the block."
While on the subject of China, Dr. Braithwaite, perhaps you can answer this one from Irked Russian: Why enlarge NATO to surround Russia more tightly, now that Russia has gone capitalist? Isn't it more sensible for NATO to surround China now that China is the world's most heavily armed Communist power? Want to tackle that, Doctor?
"What an innocent you are, Mr. Irked Russian. The United States is full of voters of Eastern European extraction who despise and fear Russia in any form. To harvest their votes, politicians must move NATO ever closer to the gates of Moscow.
"As for China, think for a moment what this proud, highly aggressive, heavily armed, repressive and nasty regime might do if we extended NATO to its very borders. You, Mr. Irked Russian, could end up without any incredibly expensive cheap tennis shoes."
Doctor, will you tell Mr. Sorehead why he should not be cross with Alan Greenspan? He says every time he gets a job Alan Greenspan says too many people have jobs and raises interest rates to throw him, Mr. Sorehead, out of work again.
What advice, Doctor, can you give this churlish prole to make him feel more kindly to Alan Greenspan?
"Just this, Mr. Sorehead: Keep whining about Alan Greenspan and you'll be known as a common scold. Do you think Alan Greenspan has a personal grudge against you? Don't be a dunce.
"Alan Greenspan is an economist. Do you think economists harbor grudges against people? Nonsense. Economists are not interested in people. When they look at the world, they do not see people, they see statistics.
"To Alan Greenspan, as to all economists, you, Mr. Sorehead, are not Mr. Sorehead at all. You are a number. A very interesting number, to be sure, but just a number. So for heaven's sake, man, quit blubbering, buck up and start acting like a number."
While we are on economics, Doctor, perhaps you can you answer this question from Going Nowhere. He wants to know why his pay never goes up more than an inch a year while the pay of C.E.O.'s constantly increases by leaps and millions.
"Isn't the answer obvious? Who decides who is going to be paid what? The answer, my dear Going Nowhere, is: C.E.O.'s decide. Consider the harsh work they are required to do:
"Slashing payrolls. Exporting jobs to cheap-labor areas like Mexico, India, Texas. Chairing conferences on greater efficiency and higher productivity. Merging. Acquiring. Going into bankruptcy.
"Is this your idea of easy work, Mr. Going Nowhere? Would you sacrifice your inch-a-year pay increase to shoulder these trying and painful tasks, even though they offered you millions every year?
"Would you risk failure with its humiliating headlines about your getting only $70 or $80 million in severance pay for doing a rotten job? If so, Mr. Going Nowhere, quit complaining and get to Harvard Business School right away for an M.B.A."
Thank you, Doctor. I'm sure your wisdom will lead us all to spiritual peace before the month is out, if not a 10-pound weight loss.

HEADLINE: Rise in Consumer Debt Rate Slowed to 6.7% in February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Americans continued borrowing at a moderate pace in February after building debt in January at the fastest rate in six months.
Consumer debt rose at a 6.7 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate in February, to $1.21 trillion, after increasing at a 10.3 percent rate in January, the largest since July, the Federal Reserve said today. 
 The report was slightly stronger than analysts had expected because the rate for January was revised up from an earlier 8.4 percent estimate.
It fit with other evidence suggesting that economic growth in the first quarter continued at around the robust 3.8 percent rate of the fourth quarter.
Consumer spending, supported by strong job growth, is powering the economy right now. It represents about two-thirds of overall activity. Borrowing by consumers has grown every month since May 1993.
"I don't think this number suggests that consumers are splurging, but it fits in with the economy starting out quite strongly," David C. Munro, an economist with High Frequency Economics, said.
Much of the increase in borrowing came in credit card debt, which grew at a 12.7 percent annual rate in February after surging at a 21.6 rate in January, the biggest gain in 16 months.
Automobile borrowing slowed, however. It increased at a three-tenths of 1 percent rate after rising at a 3.1 percent rate in January.
Other consumer debt rose at a 5.5 percent rate in February after an advance at a 2.9 percent rate in January. This category includes loans for mobile homes, education, boats and vacations.
Economists believe that Americans' borrowing binge will begin to slow this year.
They expect the Federal Reserve, which increased short-term interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point late last month, to continue to increase the cost of borrowing in an effort to slow economic growth and prevent inflationary imbalances from developing.
And there are signs that consumers are reaching their limit. Personal bankruptcies topped a million for the first time ever last year.
And the percentage of credit card holders behind on their payments at the end of 1996 rose to the highest level on record.
"There will be some progressive weakening of consumer credit demand," Mr. Munro said. "We'll see smaller increases rather than reductions."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A World of Corruption and Personal Enrichment

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
If you got the impression over the years that the Mexican Government was a stew of corruption, nothing in "Murder, Money and Mexico" is likely to change your mind. Tonight's edition of "Frontline" tells of influence-peddling, money laundering, drug dealing, murder and associated activities by the Salinas political family, which appears to have set a record, even for Mexico, of self-enrichment.
Although the program doesn't come up with much in the way of hard new evidence, it offers an abundance of allegations, speculations, suspicions, suppositions and plausible surmises about the doings of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who has fled his country, and Raul Salinas de Gortari, his brother, who is being held on the charge of murdering a sometime political ally. 
 The hour should have particular interest for audiences to the north. The narrator reminds us that Carlos Salinas, described as "the brainy one" of the family, earned a doctorate in political economy at Harvard University and still has admirers for the free-market policies he brought into the presidency in 1988. A professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who served as an adviser to President Salinas says, "If he ran a corporation, you'd buy the stock."
Washington invested in him because he favored Nafta, the North American Free Trade Agreement. There's the former Mexican President strolling with President Clinton and being applauded by Congress.
Among Mexicans whose investment in Mr. Salinas paid off were a select group who got hold of valuable properties sold by the state during privatization. They did exceedingly well despite their country's economic collapse. North American businessmen may have enhanced their fortunes.
As for Raul Salinas, there is evidence that he laundered hundreds of millions of dollars, possibly with the help of Citibank and probably with the help of his loved ones. Interviewed about charges that some of the fortune she helped to spirit out of Mexico was protection money from drug dealers, his wife says, with no credit to Claude Rains, "I was shocked, shocked!"
Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the United States Government's head drug fighter, was also shocked, shocked when Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, Mexico's chief of drug enforcement (praised by General McCaffrey for his reputation for integrity), was arrested for being on the drug-cartel payroll.
The fund-raising methods of President Salinas in 1993 may stand as an inspiration to American politicians. An investigator reports that the outgoing President invited Mexico's 30 biggest businessmen to a dinner at which they were asked to contribute $25 million apiece to his anointed successor's campaign. And he didn't even have to offer them a room for the night.

HEADLINE: Commerce Chief Will Lead Trade Trip With New Rules

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley will lead a trade mission to Latin America next month, his first and the first under new rules intended to eliminate politics from the process of selecting businesses that take part, the Commerce Department announced today.
The Secretary's entourage will stop in Brazil, Argentina and Chile to exploit what Mr. Daley described as "unprecedented opportunities for United States business" arising from economic reforms and trade liberalization in the three countries. 
 Two delegations of 12 to 15 members will be formed, officials said, based on their companies' prospects for business development and the Government's effort to obtain diversity of company size, products and location, as well as to include members of minorities.
But while the new rules opening up the selection process do not bar individuals from making donations to political candidates, they pointedly state that "an applicant's partisan political activities (including political contributions) are irrelevant."
The trip is the first since the department announced the criteria for its trade missions -- a step that was taken in the wake of allegations, which have not been proved, that former Secretary Ronald H. Brown rewarded financially supportive friends with places on foreign trips. Mr. Brown, who was killed along with 34 others on a trade mission to Croatia last April, often responded to those charges by noting that many of these executives were contributors to both parties.
Selection of the companies rests with a Commerce Department panel composed largely of career employees whose recommendations will be reviewed by a five-member board that includes a senior Department lawyer. Mr. Daley will have no say in the matter. Applications are due on April 25.
The South American mission, May 11 to May 19, is in three distinct parts.
The first three days will be in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo followed by participation in the third annual meeting of the Americas Business Forum, a private-sector group that fosters hemispheric economic integration, at Belo Horizonte, Brazil.
Then Secretary Daley travels to Buenos Aires and returns to the United States by way of Santiago, Chile.
The separate delegations of 12 to 15 members are to accompany the Secretary for the Brazil and the Argentina-Chile segments, with some executives from each likely attending the meeting in Belo Horizonte, for which the department does not select participants.
In an interview, Mr. Daley said the choice of Latin America for his first trade mission came easily. "There's lots of growth going on," he said. "Our competitors are spending a lot of time there."
He added that he hoped to organize as many as four more missions this year, with Asia and Europe the most likely destinations and India and Canada also under active consideration.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Show Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices recovered yesterday from Friday's sharp fall, bolstered by a strong dollar and by thin trading.
The gains ended a slide prompted by the March employment report on Friday, which showed brisk economic growth and higher labor costs, indicating that the Federal Reserve would again have to raise interest rates to stem inflation. But yesterday's modest rally did not reflect any change in sentiment among investors, who still expect another rate increase by summer. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 21/32 yesterday, to 94 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.06 percent, from 7.12 percent on Friday.
A rise in the value of the dollar caused a short-covering rally in the bond market that lifted prices early in the afternoon before they retreated, analysts said.
"The dollar's strength helped bonds, especially its gains against the yen," said Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
A stronger dollar makes dollar-denominated securities more attractive to foreign investors, who have been increasingly drawn to the United States Treasury market, according to recent data.
Foreign investors acquired a record $370 billion in United States fixed-income securities in 1996, up 68 percent from 1995, the PSA, the Bond Market Trade Association, said yesterday, citing preliminary Treasury figures.
But the afternoon gains in Treasury prices were held in check as investors remained cautious ahead of some key economic data, especially reports on producer prices and retail sales on Friday.
"For this week, retail sales in particular are the concern," Mr. Jones said. "The market is obviously waiting to see if another tightening has to be priced in."
Larry J. Wipf, a vice president and economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis, said, "Once the Fed starts raising rates, multiple-rate hikes are par for the course."
"Although a couple of additional tightenings appear likely, a repeat of 1994, when the Federal funds target was increased seven times for a cumulative rise of 300 basis points, is not expected," he said. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Elsewhere in the market, the Government will sell $8 billion of its inflation-indexed notes today, through a reopening of its initial issue in January.
Interest rates at yesterday's regular weekly bill auction were down as good investor demand raised the price of buying short-term Treasury debt as those wanting to buy outstripped supply.
The rate for a three-month bill dropped to 5.14 percent, from 5.18 percent last week, while the rate six-month paper slipped to 5.30 percent, from 5.31 percent. Following are the results of yesterday's bill auction:

HEADLINE: Staples and Office Depot to Fight F.T.C. Merger Challenge

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc., asserting that Federal antitrust officials do not understand the office supply business, vowed today to "vigorously contest" the Federal Trade Commission's decision to challenge their proposed $4 billion merger.
Thomas G. Stemberg, the Staples chief executive, said in a statement that the F.T.C.'s conclusion that the merger would result in higher prices and decreased competition was based on a small sample of product prices and a flawed theory of the office products market. 
 "We believe an unbiased court of law will understand the merits of our case," Mr. Stemberg said in a statement.
The commission voted 4 to 1 on Friday to go to Federal court this week to block the proposed combination, which would have created a office supply giant with more than 1,000 stores and $10 billion in annual sales.
F.T.C. officials said that they planned to file a motion seeking an order temporarily restraining the merger in Federal court in Washington later this week.
Both sides' positions appeared to be hardening following the vote on Friday. William J. Baer, chief of the F.T.C.'s antitrust bureau, said that there did not appear to be any way to structure the merger to address the commission's concern that the deal was anti-competitive.
And Mr. Stemberg, who called the panel's decision "bizarre" and "absurd," indicated that the companies would pursue the merger regardless of cost. He said that the companies would seek an expedited hearing in Federal court to resolve the matter before the merger agreement expires on May 31.
The agency complaint is based in large part on pricing studies and econometric models that officials say demonstrate that Staples, Office Depot and the only other company in the superstore business, Officemax Inc., compete only against each other, and not against other suppliers of office goods.
F.T.C. officials have argued that eliminating one of the three competitors will violate Federal antitrust laws and will inevitably lead to higher prices.
But Mr. Stemberg contended that the combined company would control less than 6 percent of a highly competitive and fragmented $185 billion office supply industry. He said that the merger, if it was allowed to proceed, would not end price competition for office products because they would continue to be sold by such giant retailers as Wal-Mart, warehouse clubs and several large nationwide catalogue dealers.
"Staples and Office Depot are committed to our mission of bringing even lower prices to our customers" after the merger is completed, Mr. Stemberg said.
