HEADLINE: City Comptroller Signs Off On Deal to Protect Water

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Declaring that New York City's $2.2 billion plan to protect its upstate water supply from pollution could still "prove to be a disastrous and expensive failure," City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi yesterday opened the way for the city to pay the first $86 million to dozens of communities around the reservoirs.
Since last fall, Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat, had criticized the deal for its lack of firm controls both on pollution sources and on how money from city water users would be spent. 
 By withholding his approval -- which was necessary because the Comptroller must sign off on any financial settlement of a lawsuit against the city -- Mr. Hevesi could have delayed the water-protection deal, which was largely worked out by Republicans, including Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and representatives of largely conservative upstate villages, towns and counties.
Mr. Hevesi said he decided to approve the accord once city, state, local and Federal officials agreed to changes that he and some private environmental groups had sought.
"We've made this a better deal," he said yesterday. "But it is just a beginning, not an end. If this agreement is not implemented in good faith and with an eye toward meticulous detail, it could all fall apart."
The Comptroller planned to release a 33-page report today on the strengths and weaknesses of the watershed plan, highlighting the recent changes. A copy was obtained by The New York Times.
Mr. Hevesi's move endorsed political detente between the city and its upstate neighbors, even as he expressed skepticism about the merits of major elements of the accord intended to insure the long-term purity of the city's water.
Under the plan, over the next 15 years New York City will buy thousands of acres of land to shield its 19 upstate reservoirs from pollution, improve sewage treatment in the watersheds, and subsidize "environmentally sound" economic development. The first payment of $86 million on April 21 will be for improving sewage treatment systems.
In return, Federal environmental officials have granted a long-term waiver from rules that would otherwise require the city to build a giant $5.1 billion filtration plant for its reservoirs west of the Hudson River. The city is already under a Federal order to build a smaller plant for $600 million to filter water from its more polluted Croton reservoirs.
The improvements were on three fronts, Mr. Hevesi said: better science, better accounting, and prolonged involvement by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which was to have turned oversight over to state health officials in five years. Now the E.P.A. will monitor the deal for 10 years, he said.
Mr. Hevesi said that even with the changes the plan still could allow too much development to take place in sensitive watersheds and that money could still be wasted.
"For every potential initiative in the plan that should lead to pure water, there's another provision that frightens me," he said. "Particularly troubling is allowing additional sewage into clean water."
Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, lauded the moves by Mr. Hevesi, but pointed out that New York City remains the only large city in the United States that allows any treated waste water into its reservoirs. More than 100 plants pump treated waste water into reservoirs that supply nearly 9 million people in New York City and other communities with drinking water, he said.
Mr. Hevesi added that the agreement still relies heavily on the good faith of upstate communities that for decades have had an antagonistic relationship with New York City. Nothing in the accord would prevent a new lawsuit in the future, even though it settles the lawsuits that were already in the works, he said.
Terms of the revised pact also include an independent study by the National Academy of Sciences of the impact of the plan on water quality. A senior New York City official involved in the watershed negotiations said Mr. Hevesi's insistence on the study and other changes at first inflamed representatives from upstate communities, who felt they had reached a deal last fall.
The official said: "We didn't want to upset the delicate balance we'd struck after all those months of talking. But we wanted the Comptroller on board on this. We didn't want any more controversy."
A key step toward gaining Mr. Hevesi's approval was adding more detail to 32 contracts under which the city will spend money not only on tangible changes like fixing ailing sewage treatment plants, but also $59.9 million on loosely defined programs to foster "environmentally sound" economic development and $13 million on a "good neighbors" fund that is almost completely unfettered.
City auditors will now have access to documents to account for expenditures, and the workings of upstate groups created to supervise watershed programs will be open to more scrutiny, Mr. Hevesi said.
A senior official in the Pataki administration, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said, "There are several good things in this agreement that wouldn't be there if the Comptroller hadn't negotiated for them. We're happy for that, because on many of these points, he took the same position the Governor took -- having more accountability and audits."

HEADLINE: China Warns Denmark On Resolution

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 7

 BODY:
China bluntly warned Denmark today that relations between them would be "severely damaged" if Denmark pressed ahead with plans to sponsor a resolution condemning Beijing for human rights abuses before a United Nations commission in Geneva.
The warning comes after several European Union nations withheld support for the resolution. 
 "If Denmark insists on doing this it will end up the biggest loser," China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Shen Guofang, said in Beijing. "We still hope Denmark will think seriously about the consequences of such action. I can say relations will be severely damaged in the political and economic trade areas."
China issued its threat after France refused to back the resolution, which the European Union has presented to the United Nations Human Rights Commission every year since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
In doing so, France argued that dialogue is preferable to confrontation with China, but the decision clearly signaled France's unwillingness to jeopardize its commercial relations with Beijing.
The French move came as President Jacques Chirac was preparing to visit Beijing next month, and it followed a recent $2 billion order from China for Airbus passenger jets, which are partly built in France.
Germany, Italy and Spain also withheld their endorsements of the resolution condemning China's human rights record, making it impossible for the European Union to sponsor it as a group.
Last week the Netherlands, which holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, warned other members that the group's inability to sponsor a resolution this year would undermine its credibility. The failure could also set back the European Union's hopes of developing a common foreign policy.
In the past, although resolutions critical of China have been put forward, Beijing has always succeeded in blocking them, usually by persuading the 53-nation Commission to pledge to take no action, which in practice prevents the resolution from coming to a vote.
Although the Danish resolution has little chance of passing, the United States said today that it will back it.
"I was in Geneva last week lobbying against the no-action motion," said Bill Richardson, the chief American delegate to the United Nations. "We want a full public debate on the human rights situation in China. And we will be supporting the Danish resolution."
While Danish diplomats said the Government had not yet agreed on the resolution's precise text, they said it would probably be similar to last year's version, which was comparatively weak.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unions Demonstrate Near Office Building

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Union construction workers demonstrated yesterday outside a downtown office building that they said a developer was transforming into apartments using state tax incentives but with nonunion labor.
About 4,000 men and women, many on their lunch break from nearby work sites, jammed three blocks outside 80 John Street, waving the pennants of dozens of locals, shouting slogans and holding signs like a handwritten one that asked, "Can I have a fat tax break when I'm unemployed?" 
 The developer of 80 John Street, WSA Equities, is converting the former Travelers Insurance building, a 70-year-old tower of 24 stories, into 147 rental units, using a two-year-old state tax-incentive program that has spurred the development of more than 1,100 apartments in lower Manhattan. Union officials said they had lobbied for the tax incentives to create more construction jobs for their members.
Edward J. Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, said the developer and its contractor were conducting the renovations at night to avoid being seen, paying workers less than the prevailing wages for union labor and denying them health-care coverage and other benefits. William Achenbaum and Fred Oliver, principals of WSA Equities, did not return a call to their Garden City, L.I., offices after the rally. The phone number for the contractor was disconnected.
Donald J. Trump, the developer; Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller, and Louis Coletti, president of the Building Trades Employers Association, each mounted a flatbed truck to speak in support of the unions.
 DAVID M. HALBFINGER

HEADLINE: Most Doubt a Resolve to Change Campaign Financing, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

 BODY:
While a significant majority of the American people believe that fundamental changes are needed in the campaign financing system, most doubt that President Clinton and Congress are sincerely committed to changing it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The President is nevertheless maintaining his strong personal standing with the public, the poll found, despite months of sometimes withering accusations of improper campaign fund-raising tactics. 
 In contrast, Vice President Al Gore has suffered a sizable loss of favorability as the controversy over campaign finances has grown.
Almost 9 of 10 people surveyed see a need for fundamental changes in fund-raising procedures, or even a total overhaul. But only 3 in 10 believe that the President really wants change, despite his announced commitment to it. The resolve of Congress is subject to even greater doubt, with only 23 percent of the public convinced that the lawmakers, for all their talk, actually want to change the current laws.
While Mr. Clinton's commitment to change is being questioned, his personal standing remains strong as Congress gears up for hearings into his 1996 re-election practices. The telephone poll registered a 56 percent job approval rating for the President, largely because of his handling of the economy. That is only seven points below his personal high, registered by CBS News after his second inauguration.
The campaign financing issue gained momentum after the President's re-election with a steady stream of disclosures about the wide net that had been cast by the Clinton-Gore team to reach affluent donors to the Democratic Party. Accounts about a chain of high-priced fund-raising events at the White House, and sleep-over privileges in the Lincoln Bedroom for favored guests, stirred Republican accusations that the President had put White House perquisites up "for sale." Controversy only increased with news that the Democratic National Committee had had to return sizable donations because of questions about their true source and that White House invitations had gone to such figures as a foreign arms dealer and a twice-convicted felon later imprisoned for drug smuggling.
Asked about Mr. Clinton's campaign fund-raising practices, 44 percent of respondents said he had done nothing wrong, while 20 percent judged his activities unethical and 12 percent illegal. Despite his general approval rating, two of five Americans said they thought the President had made or changed policy decisions as a direct result of money he raised from major donors.
The public's general suspicion about politicians' dependence on donors was underlined when 75 percent of those polled estimated that "many public officials" generally made or changed policy positions as a result of political donations. Still, 78 percent were opposed to strict public financing of campaigns as a cure, saying it would cost taxpayers too much.
In contrast to the President's job performance rating, Vice President Gore's favorability rating fell to 25 percent, a drop of 24 points in the last three months. (A majority of Americans withheld an overall opinion, as is typically the case with Vice Presidents.) Mr. Gore has come under special scrutiny for soliciting donations in telephone calls from the White House and at a gathering of Buddhist temple-goers. He has been faulted, in turn, by political observers for seeming less skilled than Mr. Clinton in defending ambitious Clinton-Gore fund-raising techniques.
In many ways, the poll suggested that the public's views on campaign finance were still taking shape. The full details of what occurred during the Presidential campaign have yet to be laid before the public in the hearings scheduled by Congress this spring and summer. Moreover, because the public has rarely been surveyed in depth on campaign finance, any shift in its views is difficult to measure.
And, for all the heat that the issue is generating in Washington, the public is far from rating campaign law overhaul a compelling priority in comparison with crime, schools and the economy. In fact, only 2 respondents, of the 1,347 polled, cited campaign fund-raising when asked to name the nation's most important problem.
"What they do in Washington really doesn't affect me," said Frank Zupancic, a 47-year-old auto mechanic from East Lake, Ohio. "I have to go to work every day, and all they want to do is get deeper in my pocket."
Further, only 12 percent of respondents said they had been following news of the issue "very closely," and 43 percent complained that the news media had been spending too much time on it.
Whatever public reaction may develop from the Congressional hearings, the poll, conducted last Wednesday through Saturday, shows that Americans already sense that there is a clear advantage enjoyed by incumbents under the current system. Three of five estimated that political challengers faced a more difficult time than incumbents under the big-dollar financing pressures of modern campaigning.
Some jaded comments were offered by respondents in elaborating on their replies to the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. "Too many politicians are getting rich," said Nade Wiese, a 60-year-old electrician from Steamboat Springs, Colo. "They don't want to change things because there is too much money they can put in their pockets."
As a "top priority" solution, the public favors effective campaign disclosure (54 percent) more strongly than limiting either campaign spending (23 percent) or special-interest contributions (28 percent). On specific proposals for changing the system, more than three of five favor significant free television time for Presidential candidates, while 70 percent favor cutting, to $1,000 from $5,000, the maximum that a political action committee can spend on a single candidate.
"The special-interest groups spend millions to get their point across, and people like me aren't heard at all," said Pam Elliott, a 42-year-old woman on disability in Dyersburg, Tenn. "Money talks."
A 57 percent majority endorsed a need for Congressional hearings, with Americans especially troubled by the possibility that foreign governments might have tried to buy influence through campaign contributions. The foreign threat, already a priority in the Congressional investigations, was rated most troubling by 45 percent of respondents, larger than those who cited special-interest donors (25 percent) and wealthy individuals (21 percent).
"I don't feel it's so important where the money comes from as long as it's within the United States," said Gene Fultz, 66, a retired computer analyst in Norfolk, Va. "The money from outside the country is another issue. That kind of influence is questionable."
At the same time, the public clearly does not want the Republican-controlled Congress to restrict its focus solely to the Democratic campaign. Almost 9 of 10 people said the hearings should investigate the fund-raising activities of both parties.
Republican Congressional leaders contend that the Clinton re-election drive, with its zealous emphasis on a boost of "soft money" donations to the Democratic Party, committed most of the campaign abuses last year. In the early months of the scandal search, the Democratic National Committee has already returned or promised to return more than $3 million in questionable donations. The Times/CBS News Poll, however, found that 77 percent of the public rated the Clinton campaign's financing tactics to be common to both political parties.
For all the doubts about the resolve of both parties to change the system, only 8 percent of the public thinks the current laws work well and need only minor changes. Virtually all the rest endorse fundamental change (50 percent) or complete overhaul (39 percent).
"It would settle things down if Congress did something about it," said Harris Spear, a 75-year-old retired personnel manager in Eugene, Ore. "They could get back to work and do what they're supposed to be doing."

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 2-5 with 1,347 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for either men or women taken as a group, it is plus or minus four percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in question wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: A Leader Needed on Rent Control

 BODY:
In just 10 weeks the laws protecting more than a million tenants in New York City from unrestricted rent increases will expire. Already the State Legislature is in a familiar uproar over one of the most emotional and complicated issues it will face this year. Yesterday, as tenant groups protested, the Republican-controlled Senate rejected a Democratic attempt to renew the current system of controls. That was a sensible step, because the existing setup is outmoded and unfair to tenants and landlords alike. But the process cannot stop there. What is needed now is an agreement to phase out rent control over the long term with protections for those tenants who need it the most.
Rent controls, which began as an emergency measure during World War II, have managed to survive in New York City because of the huge number of tenants who are voters. But phased decontrol makes sense economically and as a matter of fairness to citizens who pay for housing in the open market. Controls have also deprived owners of the money to keep up their properties or build new ones. This undermines the city's tax base and, at the extremes, creates an absurdly inequitable system protecting some well-to-do tenants at the expense of others. The entire system is presided over by a cumbersome and expensive bureaucracy. 
 On the other hand, swift decontrol of rents would produce hardship for middle-class families vital to the preservation of some neighborhoods. Some poor tenants would suffer, although rents in many low-income neighborhoods are already as high as the market will bear. With abrupt decontrol, middle-class tenants in Greenwich Village, the Upper West Side and other parts of the city might suffer increases of as much as 50 percent. The best answer is to phase out controls over several years while officials monitor the effects of the transition to a market system. Other logical steps would be to protect low-income tenants with gradual adjustments to market prices, while more speedily decontrolling rents for the wealthiest tenants, especially those in underpriced apartments.
The impasse and turmoil in Albany this year derive from predictable posturing by all sides. The Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, is threatening to let rent legislation expire altogether if the Democrats do not go along with some reasonable phasing-out of controls. With the vote yesterday, in which most Republicans from the city went along with efforts to block the extension of current law, Mr. Bruno proved he could take the political heat to demand a change in the current system. The Republicans are rolling in campaign contributions from landlords, but they need to raise their sights now and signal the acceptance of a more modest removal of controls. At the same time the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, whose base is in New York City, should come up with a sounder approach than simply renewing the status quo.
Where is Gov. George Pataki in all this? That is a very good question. While Mr. Pataki has made it clear that he does not like rent control in general, he has refused to take a position on what should replace it. Instead he offers himself as a broker to negotiate differences between the Assembly and Senate. The current situation demands a Governor who is willing and able to lead. He could put forward his own plan and become more than just a passive presence in Albany. Indeed, if he brokers a deal on rent control, then he could move to making one on the state budget, which is now a week overdue.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Bankers Trust's Deal a Bet on Growth-Company Prosperity

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
With its planned acquisition of Alex. Brown & Sons, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation is making a couple of bets.
The first is that the volatile health care and high-technology industries will continue to prosper -- thus leading to a need for underwriters both to take their fast-growing companies public and to help with other capital demands. 
 Bankers Trust is also assuming that the larger companies in these industries will want to go to a big integrated securities firm -- like a combined Bankers Trust-Brown -- for their investment banking needs, rather than smaller, more specialized competitors like Robertson Stephens, Hambrecht & Quist, Montgomery Securities or Cowen & Company.
Seeking to grow beyond its specialties in derivative securities, debt financing and foreign exchange trading, Bankers Trust agreed on Sunday to a $1.7 billion takeover of Alex. Brown, the nation's oldest brokerage firm, which is known for its research and banking skills in the high-technology and health care fields.
"Health care, high technology and telecommunications and media are three critical areas," for the combined firm, said Ted Virtue, a senior managing director at Bankers Trust, yesterday. "I think both from an industry and a product perspective the two firms fit perfectly together."
The Bankers Trust-Brown combination has also put a premium on specialty investment banks that similarly focus on health care and high technology.
The shares of Hambrecht & Quist, which is based in San Francisco, for example, closed at $20.875 yesterday, up $3, as investors speculated that it might soon become an acquisition target. Analysts also said yesterday that Montgomery Securities, Robertson Stephens or smaller firms with well-developed franchises in those businesses might soon attract bidders.
"From an industry point of view," said Joan S. Solotar, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the Bankers Trust deal for Brown "highlighted the scarcity of good properties for acquisition." Ms. Solotar added that even larger firms -- like Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, Bear Stearns and A. G. Edwards -- might attract the interest of buyers as banks and financial companies attempt to build their own investment banking franchises.
Shares in Alex. Brown rose $10, to $63.125 yesterday, after jumping a combined $11.75 on Thursday and Friday. That prompted several market professionals to speculate yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission might investigate to see if investors had traded on confidential information. John Heine, a spokesman for the S.E.C., declined to comment on the matter yesterday.
American investment bankers specializing in high technology have already drawn the interest of foreign buyers. Deutsche Bank A.G. hired a high-technology investment banking team from Morgan Stanley & Company last year.
And Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank that owns First Boston, in late March paid an undisclosed sum for a 25 percent stake in Volpe Brown Whelan & Company, a small investment bank that specializes in high-technology companies. The two partners have agreed to establish a $100 million merchant banking fund to invest in high-technology companies.
Some critics and competitors questioned yesterday whether a Bankers Trust-Brown combination would be able to retain the loyalty of Brown's growth-company clients, which tend to prefer the firm's specialized approach.
"This is not the model that we believe is in the best interests of the corporate customer," said Daniel H. Case 3d, the president and chief executive of Hambrecht & Quist, which, like Alex. Brown, specializes in the health care and high-technology sectors. Mr. Case said that his firm was eager to remain focused and independent, contending that it was in the best interests of its clients.
Mr. Virtue dismissed such criticism. "Clients are still going to get the same specialty focus" from the combined firm as they did from Alex. Brown, he said, noting that in the past some Brown corporate clients had left after outgrowing the Baltimore firm's financing capacities. That, he said, would be less likely to happen with the new firm.
"The Microsofts that move from their initial public offerings to the more developed stage will need debt as an alternative to capital as they mature as a company," Mr. Virtue said. Bankers Trust, he argued, could cater to such client needs, offering full-service investment and commercial banking.
The rationale for the takeover, Bankers Trust said yesterday, was "to make one-stop shopping a reality for Bankers Trust and Alex. Brown's clients."
The acquisition certainly brings Bankers Trust a swath of new businesses. Alex. Brown has 95 analysts covering 829 companies, heavily concentrated on technology, health care and other growth companies; its 150 investment bankers have built a thriving business in the market for initial public offerings, where it now has about a 5 percent share.
Brown also has a successful retail stock brokerage with about 450 brokers serving rich clients and producing commissions averaging about $800,000 a year. In addition, the firm has an investment management arm with assets of $12.5 billion.
But the transaction drew additional criticism yesterday, notably for the hefty price that Bankers Trust is paying: more than 2.5 times book value. Shares in Bankers Trust dropped $2.75, to $79.50, yesterday.
Both parties to the merger are niche players, with Bankers Trust focusing on leveraged finance to Brown's health care and high-technology specialties, said Peter K. Gonye, a longtime securities industry executive who is now a principal at Egon Zehnder, an executive search firm in New York.
Consequently, Mr. Gonye said, the combined firm would be vulnerable to a downturn in the securities markets. Indeed, he argued, the combined firm looked like "a one-trick pony" that could easily stumble in a tougher economic environment.
Mr. Case of Hambrecht contended that Alex. Brown would now become part of "a transaction culture" that might lead to the loss of its specialist expertise and long-term relationships. This, he added, should thus be an excellent time to hire disgruntled Brown bankers.
"We believe that Alex. Brown is too big to be little and too little to be big," Mr. Case said, meaning that he thought Brown had grown too big to remain a specialty firm, but did not have the financial muscle to compete with the biggest investment banks.

HEADLINE: Companies Are Finding Tasty Profits in Fancy Food

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In the large white kitchen, a woman with a white apron stirs a plastic tub of deep red tomato sauce and black olives. Next to her, a woman squeezes dollops of black beans onto dough. Not far from her, another woman delicately closes the tiny bean hors d'oeuvres with her fingers.
For many years, most of these pates and hors d'oeuvres made at Dufour Pastry Kitchens Inc., a rapidly growing specialty food factory tucked between gritty meat packing plants on Manhattan's West Side, ended up on the tables of New York's restaurants. Now they are just as likely to end up on tables in Montreal, Bermuda, Aspen, Colo., and Honolulu. 
 "We didn't want to be a small cottage industry," said Carla Krasner, who, with Judi Arnold, founded the business in 1984.
Dufour Pastry Kitchens is not alone in its strategy. Over the last few years, dozens of local fancy food manufacturers have started exporting to national and international markets. Because of improved packaging, overnight delivery services, a growing appetite for high-end food and an increasing cachet of things made in New York, dozens of companies are moving beyond New York.
"This has happened quietly, not because of any public policy initiative but because local businesses have taken advantage of advances in distribution and communications," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center. "There's a genuine recognition now that food production in New York tends to be small and inventive and innovative."
The number of such manufacturers has grown from only a handful a decade ago to more than 60 now, including such well-known names as Balducci's, H & H Bagels East and Junior's World Famous Cheesecake Inc. But the trend has gone largely undetected because many of the exporters are small, private and family-owned.
Another problem, perhaps, has been defining what is often called gourmet food. One suggestion: food that is more select, expensive and dependent on special attention or handling, said John P. Roberts, president of the National Association for Specialty Food Trade, a Manhattan-based trade group that is the host for fancy food exhibitions.
Nevertheless, there are some strong indicators, including these:
*In a survey of local specialty food manufacturers, the Industrial Technology Assistance Corporation, a nonprofit group, found that the proportion of New York products sold outside of New York climbed from 10.8 percent in 1992 to 26.1 percent in 1996. Four months ago, the group began a program to help these manufacturers increase their products' shelf life and to automate, said Ken Bicknell, the group's field engineer for food, beverage and consumer products.
*In the last 10 years, the number of New York-based specialty food manufacturers belonging to the National Association for Specialty Food Trade, has nearly tripled to 68, Mr. Roberts said.
*D. I. Group, a Batavia, Ill.-based company that distributes specialty foods to Europe, works with more than 60 New York City fancy food manufacturers, up from less than 20 in 1988, said Ernest Mahaffey, president of D. I. Group.
*Tech Pak Inc., a packaging company in Peabody, Mass., estimates that the number of New York clients using refrigerated gel packs to ship fancy food has jumped 10-fold to more than 100 in 8 years, said Coleby Mantz, marketing manager for Tech Pak.
Examples abound. Balducci's mail-order business, started in 1992, now comprises 24 percent of all its sales, offering items like stuffed butterflied lamb. Three-quarters of its mail-order business comes from outside New York City, up from half only five years ago.
H & H Bagels East opened a shipping office in December to handle out-of-town requests to England, Ireland, France and Israel; already, there has been a 50 percent increase in orders. One customer is Jimmy Kaperonis, a former New Yorker who now lives in Athens. He has ordered boxes of plain, cinnamon raisin and poppyseed bagels on several occasions at about $200 a shipment. "I miss them very much," Mr. Kaperonis said. "Everybody likes them and no one here makes them."
Only a few years ago, Michel's Magnifique sold 80 percent of its pates and terrines to New York establishments; now, it sells only 17 to 20 percent, with the rest going to places like Venezuala, Curacao, Mexico and Finland. Since 1993, Sylvia's, the famed Harlem restaurant, has been distributing its renowned barbecue sauce to a growing number of United States markets, as well as Japan, South Africa and England. Another noted restaurant, Sarabeth's, has watched its jams and condiments become an export item, increasing from zero only a few years ago to up to 1,000 cases a year.
"New York City has this allure of being the big city that has everything unique," said Amiram Dror, who, with his wife, Debra Miller, owns Black Hound New York, which has seen its exports climb sharply.
Of course, specialty food exporting can cost twice as much to ship overseas, and sometimes the process is complicated by local customs regulations. But Mr. Roberts anticipates growing demand since people are developing more sophisticated tastes and it is easier to order. Some worry, however, that the blossoming business may soon reach a crossroads.
Mr. Moss says that when exporters get bigger, they will need more space and tax and other incentives if they want to stay in New York.
The city says that it is aware of the "niche" nature of the fancy food business and that it has already offered financial assistance to one such company, International Delights, said Russell A. Harding, executive vice president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
Importers, meanwhile, say they have noticed that customers seeking fancy food who used to demand only food from overseas now are just as satisfied with domestically produced high-end food.
"At one time, gourmet food used to be the purview of the importers," said Tim Metzger, vice president of sales and marketing for the Gilway Company, a specialty food importer in Paramus, N.J. "Now, it's not the case, not at all. Whether it's from Brooklyn, N.Y., or Dijon, France, it almost doesn't matter."

Chart/Photos: "SAMPLING: Selling the Fruits of the City Abroad" lists several of New York's gourmet food manufacturers that have turned more to national and international markets. In general, the price can double if shipped overseas.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Students Take Hospitality

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The Hospitality Consulting Group of Coopers & Lybrand, the Manhattan accounting firm, is getting an extra hand these days from three sophomores from the Frederick Douglass Academy, a public high school in Manhattan.
Quefe Arner, 15, of the Bronx; Gabriela Orochena, 16, of Manhattan, and Shameen Robinson, 15, of the Bronx are among 140 student interns at travel-related businesses in New York City this year, participants in a program run jointly by the city's Board of Education and the private sector. 
 Administered by the board's Academy of Travel and Tourism, the program, which is duplicated nationwide, tries to interest students from six high schools in careers in hospitality, said Richard Graziano, the academy's director. Students take seven courses offered by their schools, from geography to economics to tourism, and receive paid internships at one of 40 companies, including public relations and accounting companies, hotels and travel agencies.
While the three students at Coopers & Lybrand are doing mostly clerical tasks for now, the chairman of the company's hospitality services unit, Bjorn Hanson, said he planned to give them bigger challenges as their skills developed in the next two years.
"We hope to have them working on spreadsheets and drafting sections of reports," he said. "I hope they get a real sense of all aspects of our business."
 LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: A Gain in Jobs Would Justify Higher Inflation

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If anything, Bob Herbert's "Bogeyman Economics" (column, April 4), which advocates risking higher inflation to create more jobs, understates the justification for promoting economic expansion. 
 Recent studies have found that even if unemployment went as low as 4.5 percent, there would be only a modest rise in inflation -- maybe two percentage points over a three-year period; that there is no loss of national output from rising inflation until rates hit 10 percent, and that in the last two years, thanks to lower unemployment, wage rates for lower paid workers have been increasing faster than the national average.
Thus, even when inflation rates begin to rise, there is no reason to curtail the economic expansion.
There are no output losses to the nation and the benefits from the expansion will disproportionately go to the neediest workers.
Particularly in a period when low-skilled women are being thrown off welfare and affirmative action is being weakened, it is imperative that employment opportunities and earnings of lower paid workers increase even if there may be adverse consequences for Wall Street investors and bondholders.
 
ROBERT CHERRY
Brooklyn, April 4, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Brooklyn College.

HEADLINE: A Gain in Jobs Would Justify Higher Inflation;
Keeping the Poor Down

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bob Herbert argues that our economy is constantly manipulated for the benefit of the wealthy, and to the detriment of the poor ("Bogeyman Economics," column, April 4). 
 In fact, greater democracy is a most frightening prospect to the wealthy.
As informational television and computers help create a more informed, better educated and more determined group of people on the bottom of the economic scale, the wealthy seem to be busy thinking of methods and justifications for keeping the poor "in their places."
Beneath the pseudo-economic doomsday babble, there exists the frightening prospect that if a great many of society's have-nots become aware of their rights and learn to fight for them, there will be a forced sharing of money and power. The information age makes this a more imminent possibility.
As Mr. Herbert points out, we should be alert for those who claim to protect us from economic disaster but who seem to be striving mightily to maintain our present levels of poor and unemployed. A democratic nation cannot survive on such a strategy.
 
MICHAEL J. GORMAN
Whitestone, Queens, April 4, 1997

HEADLINE: A Kremlin Telltale Expose From the Provinces

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 7

 BODY:
Most government officials wait until they are out of office to publish kiss-and-tell memoirs. Others let it all leak out while they are still on the job.
But a well-known Russian politician has gone one step further: he wrote a memoir critical of President Boris N. Yeltsin's administration before he even stepped into the Kremlin. 
 The politician, Boris Y. Nemtsov, 37, the popular Governor of Nizhny Novgorod, was appointed First Deputy Prime Minister in charge of free market reform three weeks ago and instantly became the shining star of a new economic team led by Anatoly B. Chubais.
This week the Russian publishing house Vagrius is expected to release "A Provincial Man," Mr. Nemtsov's account of his experiences as Governor, which is loaded with acid assessments of his new superiors in Moscow.
In Mr. Nemtsov's view, Mr. Yeltsin is a typical Russian czar, bold but often careless and out of touch. The man he reports to directly, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, is in his view "a good man," but "not quite ready to be Prime Minister in a crisis."
Mr. Nemtsov is not at all sheepish about his somewhat tactless literary debut.
"There are people who urged me to remove everything about Chernomyrdin," he said rather gleefully in an interview. "I said, 'No, let it all be there.' "
He did order his publishers to add a note explaining that the book was written before he joined Mr. Chernomyrdin's team.
Mr. Nemtsov, whose was assigned the formidable tasks of fighting unfair monopolies, fixing Russia's collapsing pension fund and reforming the housing system, called his new job a "kamikaze mission." But with bravado and close attention to his image as a populist and maverick reformer, Mr. Nemtsov seems to be positioning himself for an even more ambitious future.
Intelligent and engaging, Mr. Nemtsov is the darling of Russian reformers and Western economists who admire his efforts to introduce market reforms to backward Nizhny Novgorod.
Though he stoutly denies any plans to run for President, he hardly fits the arch title of his memoirs, "A Provincial Man." No other Russian governor has hobnobbed with the likes of Bill Clinton, Andrei D. Sakharov and Margaret Thatcher.
In the interview he irreverently referred to the former British Prime Minister as "babushka," the Russian word for Grandma. When soliciting her views on privatizing state monopolies and introducing private pension plans, as he recently did, he calls her Baroness.
He writes less admiringly of Mr. Clinton, describing him as "naive." He complained that Mr. Clinton "views Russia and particularly me solely through the prism of American interests."
A few days after being appointed, Mr. Nemtsov announced that he had persuaded Mr. Yeltsin to force Government officials to sell their Mercedez-Benz and Volvo cars at auction and use only Russian-made Volgas, which are in fact made in Nizhny Novgorod.
As reform measures go, it did little to cut Government spending or even increase Volga sales (the director of the ailing car company said the addition orders for limousines would only be a drop in the bucket), but it was a quick, crowd-pleasing way to get attention.
More recently, Mr. Nemtsov has taken up the more challenging battle of promoting an anti-corruption decree that would require companies to bid in open tenders for Government business, whether it be supplying the army with boots or huge construction contracts. Currently, Government contracts are awarded in secret, with large kickbacks to bureaucrats.
The politically delicate decree had existed in draft form for more than two years, but never made it all the way through the tangled and often feuding Russian bureaucracy to Mr. Yeltsin's desk.
"Mr. Yeltsin asked me why this decree had never been discussed in his office," Mr. Nemtsov recalled. "I said, 'I don't know, I've never been in this office, but my idea is that it has to be done immediately.' "
Mr. Nemtsov said he had pushed the draft through by forcing bureaucrats in the Russian Parliament to sit down in his office and not leave until they had signed off on it. He said he then personally rang every clerk in the Kremlin to make sure it did not get sidetracked, and confidently predicted that it would be approved by Mr. Yeltsin this week.
His is the kind of brash self-confidence that causes some of his older, more battle-scarred colleagues to roll their eyes.
"Anyone who says they are sure that they can get Yeltsin to sign something by a certain date is either very stupid, or really inexperienced," said a top administration official who was deposed in the recent Cabinet shuffle that led to Mr. Nemtsov's appointment. "He is smart, but he still has a lot to learn."
His breezy, often amusing and immodest book even includes a mention of his encounter with the actor Richard Gere, who visited Nizhny Novgorod in 1995. The tall and handsome Russian Governor confessed that he was baffled why women all over the world were mesmerized by the "short, skinny" actor. But he allowed that the two Russian women escorting Mr. Gere "were truly beautiful."
Under a chapter heading titled "What I Adore," Mr. Nemtsov wrote, "Women."
But it is his critiques of leading Russian politicians that are most likely to tantalize Russian readers. He described the powerful Mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, often cited as a likely presidential candidate, as "a cautious political figure who pretends he is the chief manager, builder and street-sweeper of Moscow."
Mr. Nemtsov depicts himself as anything but cautious.
The Governor accompanied Mr. Yeltsin on a notorious trip to Berlin, during which the Russian President drank too much and, among other things, snatched the baton away from the conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic.
"He behaved badly, horribly, everybody knows about it," Mr. Nemtsov wrote. "We had a tense conversation. He didn't like it that I allowed myself to reprimand him." He added that Mr. Yeltsin did not hold a grudge.
Mr. Nemtsov, who says he took the Cabinet job mainly because Mr. Yeltsin and his daughter Tatyana pressured him heavily to do so, acts like a man who has nothing to lose. Indeed, he asked for and got a salary of $1,000 a month, which, however modest by Western standards, is considerably more than Mr. Chernomyrdin's average monthly Government wage of $770 a month.
On the other hand, unlike Mr. Chernomyrdin, a former chairman of Gazprom, the giant gas company, Mr. Nemtsov cannot rely on private resources. His book advance was $5,000.
He insists that his willingness to risk his popularity by working for the Kremlin is proof that he does not have presidential ambitions.
"It would be better for me to run the way Clinton did -- directly from the post of Governor," he argued. "The fact that I accepted this job shows I don't have such plans because it is difficult to gain positive points in this job."
But Aleksandr I. Lebed, the outspoken former general who was dismissed after a brief, noisy stint as national security adviser, was not politically damaged by his ouster. If anything, it enhanced his reputation.
When Mr. Nemtsov began his reform efforts in Nizhny Novgorod five years ago, he relied heavily on grants and consultants from Europe and the United States. In his book, Mr. Nemtsov adopted some of the West-bashing tone that is increasingly popular in Russia. He denounces American imperialism and even criticizes ordinary Americans for smiling too much. At home, however, he is often cast as a Westernizer.
Mr. Nemtsov does not deny it -- or back away from lofty comparisons.
"Everyone knows I speak English, including your President," he said. "I usually say, there was a great czar in Russia, Peter the Great. He was not ashamed to go to Holland to study the European experience. Everything good in the West should be in Russia, and everything bad in the West, say, drugs in Holland, should stay there."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 10, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov of Russia incorrectly described the officials whom he forced to sign an anti-corruption decree. They work for the Government of Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, not the Russian Parliament.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars vs. Yen Again And Is Strong Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose above 126 yen for the first time in four and a half years yesterday and surged against other currencies, too, after Japan's trade minister suggested that he was not too concerned about the dollar's recent gains.
The remarks by the minister, Shinji Sato, came one day after the dollar surpassed 125 yen for the first time since January 1993, and were interpreted by foreign exchange traders as a signal that neither Japan nor the United States would intervene to halt the dollar's ascent for the time being. 
 The dollar was also helped by the third consecutive day of gains in the American stock market as well as by broad weakness in the German mark, which suffered from growing expectations that Europe's single currency would be introduced as scheduled in 1999, as well as news that the German labor market remained weak in March.
"The dollar is seeing strength beyond the scope of what one would have expected," said Jim Powers, vice president of foreign exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landes Bank in New York.
The dollar hit an intraday high of 126.52 yen, the strongest since August 1992, before settling in New York at 126.23 yen, up from 125.56 yen on Monday. The dollar cost 1.7143 marks, up from 1.7109 and the highest since March 6.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin helped inspire the latest surge in the dollar last Friday when he said in a visit to Japan that countries should not use exchange rates as weapons in trade disputes. That was viewed as a sign that the United States was not uncomfortable with the dollar at these levels, even if it was starting to widen the Japanese trade surplus with the United States by making Japanese exports more affordable in this country.
Mr. Sato accelerated the demand for dollars yesterday by telling reporters, "We can't do things every time the dollar goes up by 1 yen."
The dollar was helped further by the unemployment news from Germany, which weakened the mark. Although the jobless rate fell to 11.7 percent last month from 12.2 percent in February, the decline had been expected and was affected by seasonal factors.
Remarks by Guntram Palm, a senior member of Germany's central bank, also put pressure on the mark. Mr. Palm told reporters he believed "more than ever before" that Europe's planned single currency would start on time, taking away the mark's role as Europe's most stable currency.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Prices Move Higher As Drop in Supply Accelerates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Copper prices rose yesterday after a larger-than-expected drop in stockpiles renewed expectations that demand would keep supplies lean.
On other markets, wheat prices rose and soybeans fell. 
 The London Metal Exchange said yesterday that its copper inventories had fallen 6,475 metric tons, to 167,125 tons as of Monday. Analysts had generally expected a decline of 2,000 to 4,000 metric tons. (A metric ton is 1.1 ton.) The exchange's copper stockpile is now 48 percent lower than it was a year earlier.
The decline provided the latest evidence that demand for copper is strong. Builders are the largest consumers of copper, and last week, the Commerce Department reported that American construction spending rose 2.3 percent in February, the second consecutive increase.
"Stockpiles are falling because demand in the U.S. is still fairly good and the recent economic data are very constructive," said William O'Neill, director of futures research at Merrill Lynch in New York.
Copper for May delivery rose 2.15 cents, to $1.069 a pound, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. On Monday, copper prices fell to their lowest point since Feb. 4 amid concern that rising interest rates in the United States would curb demand.
Wheat prices rose as a Chinese purchase from Canada raised hopes that other buyers were set to place orders.
China recently bought 500,000 to 1.5 million metric tons of Canadian wheat, traders said, and could buy as much as 100,000 additional tons. Algeria, Egypt and Iran are also expected to order a total of about 650,000 tons soon, traders said.
The sales put added pressure on worldwide supplies. The International Grains Council expects global inventories to total 100 million metric tons by June 30, among the lowest levels of the last 20 years.
Wheat for May delivery, which would come from last year's crop, rose 1.5 cents, to $3.82 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Soybeans fell on concern that demand for the United States supply would fall as record harvests are expected in South America.
July soybeans fell 14 cents, to $8.535 a bushel.

HEADLINE: A Photography Curator Narrows His Focus;
After 29 Years of Displaying Others' Work, John Szarkowski Returns to His Own

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
When John Szarkowski was reminded that it was during his term as director of the photography department at the Museum of Modern Art that photography was recognized as a high art, he responded drily, "Is that what went wrong?" He never did seem entirely happy with new developments in the medium in the late 1970's and 80's, so perhaps the remark was not entirely ironic.
From 1962 to 1991, Mr. Szarkowski (pronounced shar-KOV-ski) presided over photography's ascent to the higher echelons of art and the upper ranks of the art market. Now a director emeritus, he was for almost three decades the most powerful curator in the field; there were not many others for a good part of his tenure. 
 He consistently presented photography as an art form of a level of modernism and importance comparable to that of other work in the museum. His position, and his extraordinarily elegant writing, meant that he set the standards and the course of taste for a large audience that had not ventured into the area of photography before.
Before coming to New York from Wisconsin and assisting the medium onto the glory track, Mr. Szarkowski was a photographer himself, but he did not photograph much during his years at the Modern. Curators seldom do; their cameras languish while the museum calls.
So, of course, he returned to his first love as soon as he stopped answering. The result: a book called "Mr. Bristol's Barn, With Excerpts From Mr. Blinn's Diary" (Abrams). An exhibition of Mr. Szarkowski's photographs of the barn opens tomorrow and continues through May 10 at Pace Wildenstein MacGill at 32 East 57th Street in Manhattan.
Not that he spent the 29-year interim pining. "The Modern was a very demanding job, and an interesting job," he said. "I was very lucky. There were wonderful new photographers then, and wonderful old photographers nobody had seen." For starters, the museum had never before put on one-man shows of Brassai, Bill Brandt or Andre Kertesz.
"God, it was easy!" said the man who did.
In the late 50's, Mr. Szarkowski photographed and wrote the texts for two books: "The Idea of Louis Sullivan," an appreciation of the architect's work, in 1956, and "The Face of Minnesota," in 1958. He won two Guggenheim Fellowships; the first supported the work on the Sullivan book, the second a photographic project in the Canadian wilderness that he never quite finished. (The place was so remote, it could be reached only by canoe, with frequent portages. Mr. Szarkowski, now 71, says he does not think he will go back.)
His more recent subject is the barn on his farm in East Chatham, N.Y., which was built by hand down to the last joint and rafter more than a century ago, when the farm was owned by Abel Bristol. The diary, written by a nearby farmer, Philo Blinn, around the time of the Civil War, makes a crackling case for the difficulty of the small farmer's life in the 19th century. On his 39th birthday, Blinn wrote that he was almost an old man, on his 40th that he had "all the while been so very busy getting ready to live, or in other words, getting something to live on, that I have never thought to improve, to value, to enjoy the present."
Mr. Szarkowski has recorded the barn's hand-hewn geometries and hand-carved graffiti with the clear, straightforward, respectful approach to nuances of fact that characterized so much 19th-century photography. That is precisely what he values most highly in the medium.
In 1958 he wrote, "I want to make pictures possessing the qualities of poise, clarity of purpose and natural beauty, as these qualities were achieved in the work of the good wet-plate photographers," like Mathew Brady, William Henry Jackson and Timothy O'Sullivan.
It is easy to understand why the Modern organized six shows of Atget's utterly clear and totally poised work under Mr. Szarkowski's aegis. Even the sardonic view of the late 20th century that he introduced in a 1967 show called "New Documents: Photographs by Arbus, Friedlander, and Winogrand" flirted with the terms poise, clarity and beauty, but gave them a new edge and precariousness.

Hunting for Images Of the Outdoors
Mr. Szarkowski retired at the museum's mandatory age but neither broke step nor slowed down. As soon as he left the Modern, he began forming a photography collection from scratch for Paine Webber on the theme of land use.
"It has proven a whole lot harder than I thought," he said. "You'd be astonished at how few good pictures that have to do with farming, fishing, mining, logging there are."
He sometimes sends students scurrying off to local historical societies or to the Federal Department of Agriculture to root out pictures of campers, wheat farming and railroad spurs. Such images, he laments, are being allowed to fall off their original glass plates because they do not fit a narrow view of art.
He is nearly finished with another book, on the photographs and writings of Liberty Hyde Bailey, the patron saint of American horticulture. He also hops about the country teaching, at the University of Arizona, Florida International University, the University of Kansas, Williams College, Yale and Harvard.
"Florida was especially good," he said. "Those great Caribbean students, they understand something that other students don't, that art is supposed to have something to do with play, with fun, with dancing. They don't make the mistake of thinking they have to think the thing out before doing it. Maybe it has something to do with the weather."
These teaching stints have convinced him that there are a lot of good young photographers out there, which is not the same as photographers who change notions of what the medium can be. Mr. Szarkowski seriously doubts that there is anyone under 40 today as good as the best photographers over 50 or 60. Maybe, he said, now that he is no longer obligated to look, he is just not looking hard enough. But having responded to the spirit that was abroad in the late 1960's and 70's, and having put it on the world map, he is singularly reluctant to give it up.

Careers Aimed At the Galleries
Students today, he said, understand that they might conceivably make their living selling pictures in art galleries, an idea that did not raise its head until quite recently. So they check out what is being sold, which generally persuades them that the big ticket is self-expression and individuality. Even if they realize that they have not lived long enough to be all that different, they do their best to invent a distinction or to inflate their limited experience to marketable proportions.
"Most of this work, I admit," Mr. Szarkowski said, "seems to me quite tedious and a little sad."
He went on, "It does seem to me that awareness of the galleries has not been altogether salutary for the young photographer." A pause. "Having said that, I would also agree that no other opportunity that has faced photographers within my memory has been altogether salutary either."
He has a solution: "The best way to be a photographer is to be rich." Stieglitz, Strand, and Cartier-Bresson all had some money. Dorothea Lange, who was married to Paul Schuster Taylor, an economics professor, used to speak jokingly of her Taylor Foundation grants.
"Maybe," Mr. Szarkowski said, "photographers should become insurance executives like Wallace Stevens and Charles Ives." Visions of W. Eugene Smith and Diane Arbus compiling actuarial tables dance through the air.
When Mr. Szarkowski began photographing, he wanted to make pictures that would be socially useful, as most people did during the Depression and World War II. After the war, people thought "this was the great opportunity for photography," he said. "This new medium, pictures and text together, proposed a new opportunity to explain life to the world."

The World Will Do As a Starting Point
In 1960, when he canoed into Canada, Mr. Szarkowski hoped to save a wilderness by photographing it, but the idea of social usefulness lost its luster for documentarians over the next few years.
Now, he said, "if you want to save something from exploitation, don't photograph it." And he is convinced that "socially useful" is a decidedly inferior point from which to start out to be an artist.
For him, the world will do fine to start with, and exploring it for some new perception rather than illustrating what is already known is still the best mode of attack.
Mr. Szarkowski recalled that Garry Winogrand, the master of the quickly snatched street photograph, had no objection to people setting up pictures; if they came up with interesting images, more power to them. Winogrand said his problem was that he did not have enough imagination to think up anything half as insane as what he saw on the street all the time.
In 1989, when photography turned 150, Mr. Szarkowski paid tribute with a show and a book called "Photography Until Now." He organized the history of the medium in terms of major technical shifts like photomechanical reproduction that changed the means and often the distribution of images.
The most recent technical change, digitization, has not registered strongly on his viewfinder: "I have absolutely no interest in the fact that you can make a photograph with the Empire State Building where the Chrysler Building is. You have always been able to do that, with scissors."
Mr. Szarkowski conceded that the computer may change photographic styles, but he cannot believe it will change the fact that an individual's view of what is really interesting and important in the world is what makes a picture worth attention. For that matter, he said, "most photographs, whether they shift buildings or not, are not very interesting."
The director emeritus is still actively on the prowl for the few that are.

HEADLINE: Blacks Left Baseball Behind in Rural South

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While baseball's history of racism may help explain declining black interest in the game as Brent Staples claims (" 'A White Man's Place to Be,' " Editorial Notebook, April 8), the great black migration from South to North has likely played a larger role. 
 When most American blacks lived in the rural South, playing fields were plentiful, and blacks who moved North retained their affection for the game. But their children and their children's children have had to adapt to the exigencies of city life. Concrete basketball courts, unlike verdant baseball diamonds, can thrive in cramped urban spaces. It's also cheaper to play basketball -- no gloves or bats required -- than baseball.
Today the spacious suburbs, with plenty of room and money for the national pastime, breed a growing number of professional baseball players and fans. And the suburbs remain disproportionately white.
This geographic reality -- rooted in an economic reality that is the legacy of American racism -- is the likeliest cause of black Americans' turning away from baseball and toward other sports, particularly basketball.
 
ERIC COLUMBUS
Cambridge, Mass., April 8, 1997

HEADLINE: Nothing Fails Like Success

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan, a senior editor at The New Republic, is the editor of "Same-Sex Marriage: Pro and Con," a reader.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At first blush, John Major and Newt Gingrich are about as different as two politicians could be. For six interminable years, John Major has mercilessly bored the British public, his fathomless grayness now an emblem of English ennui. Newt Gingrich, on the other hand, bursts with messianic enthusiasm that alternately inspires and bewilders. One exudes the charisma of a mildly panicked bank manager; the other the maturity of a student debate coach.
But for all their differences, Mr. Major and Mr. Gingrich face a similar predicament. Both are the first true conservative leaders to emerge in Britain and America after the cold war, and both have presided over an unprecedented consolidation of the conservative gains of the 1980's. And yet, despite these real achievements, both have been rewarded with approval ratings of around 30 percent and political parties in revolt. Torn apart by their fellow conservatives, both leaders have become symbols of how fragile Anglo-American conservatism has become. 
 Yes, of course, both Mr. Major and Mr. Gingrich made their fair share of personal errors. Mr. Gingrich fatally overplayed his hand in the budget negotiations of 1995 and 1996. Mr. Major began his second term with a disastrous attempt to peg the pound to the Deutsche mark, resulting in Britain's humiliating expulsion from the European Monetary System. And neither has exactly been an elegant communicator of his ideas or goals.
But a very good case can be made nonetheless that their achievements vastly outweigh their howlers. Without Mr. Gingrich, the realignment of 1994 would never have happened. Without him, a balanced budget and welfare reform would never have been shoehorned into President Clinton's agenda.
Mr. Major, too, has quietly overhauled the British economy, ridding it of the boom-bust cycle of the last 50 years, reducing unemployment to half Europe's average, squeezing inflation to Japanese levels and reforming Britain's sclerotic health care and education systems. By their deft positioning, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Major have also spawned those facile figures, Mr. Clinton and Tony Blair, the British Labor Party leader, whose policies have become flattering shadows of the men they profess to scorn.
And how did conservatives reward their stalwart leaders? For the most part, they have torn at their throats, stabbed them in the back and pushed them to the edge of political extinction. Washington these days is full of off-the-record quotes denigrating the Speaker's leadership and even his sanity. For his part, Mr. Major has been pilloried by the right, in Parliament and in the press for the last five years.
Sure, both leaders have failed to provide the ideological coherence and excitement their supporters remember from the 1980's. But they have failed to provide it because the ideology that inspires their followers bears little relation to the post-cold war reality these leaders actually have to face.
In America, Mr. Gingrich is increasingly isolated from the religious and economic right. The fundamentalist right demands a constitutional amendment to ban virtually all abortion. The economic right demands deep tax cuts as well as a balanced budget. Any governing conservative knows that these things are pipe dreams in conflicted, modern America, and so tries to tack around or toward them.
Bob Dole was impaled on these two unrealities -- taking positions on both abortion and taxes that managed to be both uninspiring to his base and unconvincing to everyone else. And Mr. Gingrich's attempts to square the circle -- by deftly avoiding social issues and tactically delaying tax cuts in favor of a balanced budget -- has only furthered his isolation on the right. From Jack Kemp to Ralph Reed, from The Wall Street Journal to William Kristol's screeds in The Weekly Standard, the derision is deafening.
In Britain, the conservative ideologues have found a tougher litmus test. Their Elysian equivalent to a constitutional abortion ban is a declaration of war on the European Union and a complete restoration of Britain's national sovereignty. (They have mercifully forsaken restoration of the British Empire.)
But any governing conservative knows that these are not realistic options. Britain cannot simply withdraw from Europe without heavy economic cost. Moreover, in the modern world, the complex interdependence of nations is not an idea whose merits are to be debated; it is a fact.
So Mr. Major has tacked to and fro, trying to find a way between Europe's bad policies and Britain's real interests. For this effort, he has been rewarded with scathing contempt from the Tory ranks. The public sees his dithering; the party sees his betrayal, and the electorate will likely see to his political demise when elections are held on May 1.
But the truth is, both Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Major are the true conservatives. They recognize that, after the cold war, clear-cut ideological crusades are no longer easy ventures and that, in the wake of conservatism's recent gains, pragmatic consolidation -- and tactical advance -- is by far the best policy.
Now that the Labor and Democratic parties have moved much closer to the Tory and Republican consensus, the game is no longer a race to the extremes; it's a chess match for the conservative center. And that requires the kind of pragmatic politics that ideological conservatives find as inimical in America as Europhobes do in Britain.
There are, of course, no viable alternative conservative leaders to either Mr. Gingrich or Mr. Major, because there isn't really a viable alternative politics. Kempism failed in 1996. The women of America are hardly likely to rally to a party led by Dick Armey or Pat Buchanan. Popular mavericks, like Senator John McCain, would never win over the party base.
And in Britain, the campaign has shown that John Major is still the most popular Tory around.
But none of that seems to matter to the new Robespierres of the right. In Britain right now, the right wing has effectively hounded its own competent, intrepid leader off the edge of the political cliff. In Washington, it seems only a matter of time before the purists of the party do exactly the same thing.

HEADLINE: An Improved Watershed Deal

 BODY:
The one official who could have delayed and possibly derailed the historic agreement between New York City and upstate communities to protect the city's water supply has now approved it. Alan Hevesi, the City Comptroller, spent nearly six months reviewing every line of the deal and demanding changes, but it was time well spent. The agreement he formally approved yesterday provides for much tighter controls on spending and for periodic scientific reviews that could lead to stronger regulations down the road.
This is not to take anything away from the original plan unveiled last fall by Gov. George Pataki to protect water quality in the city's upstate reservoirs. With the assistance of his chief counsel, Michael Finnegan, the Governor persuaded upstate residents -- in exchange for a huge cash transfusion from New York City -- to go slow on commercial development and accept other restrictions to spare the watershed from further degradation. The city, in return, would be spared the cost of building a $5.1 billion filtration system. This was a political breakthrough, ending years of upstate-downstate hostility. But as the City Comptroller, Mr. Hevesi is obliged to insure that the money is well spent. His fine-tuning improves the chances that it will be. 
 Under the plan, over the next 15 years New York City will buy thousands of acres of land to shield its 19 upstate reservoirs from pollution, spend over $1 billion to build or improve sewage treatment plants near streams that feed the reservoirs, and subsidize "environmentally sound" economic development in the surrounding hills and valleys. In return, Federal officials have granted the city a long-term waiver from rules that would otherwise require filtration.
Mr. Hevesi's amendments will give city auditors much greater control over how and where the money is spent. He also insisted on continuing Federal oversight and on a series of independent scientific studies, the first of which is due in 1999, to monitor water quality. If the scientists say that water quality is not improving, the city can seek to change the terms of the deal.
A few upstate politicians are not happy with Mr. Hevesi's efforts to increase the city's ability to monitor the agreement and demand midcourse adjustments in the future. A few environmentalists, meanwhile, complain that some provisions in the agreement, including the rules governing new sewage treatment plants, are still too weak. Mr. Hevesi himself warns that the deal is merely "a beginning, not an end," and that it will fail unless all concerned live up to their promises.
Less than a year ago, however, there was no deal at all, and few prospects of achieving one. There is now in place an arrangement that will provide the towns and hamlets of the watershed with an economic boost and provide city residents, if all goes well, with a steady supply of inexpensive, high-quality drinking water. The plan is well worth the effort required to make it work.
