HEADLINE: What Vanity and Casual Fridays Wrought

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
After years of blue suits, Patrick Yalung has started to think about clothing and has come to this conclusion: he likes it.
"Before, I had all dark suits and all white shirts," said Mr. Yalung, a 38-year-old executive for Wells Fargo in Phoenix. "Now, I get pants with patterns in them and wear them with a sport coat. I guess you could say I've become a little more fashion conscious" -- and willing to spend more on clothing. 
Even as sales of women's apparel have fallen in recent years, sales of men's clothing have been rising. Between 1989 and 1996, sales of men's clothing grew 21.3 percent, to $41.2 billion, a record high, while women's apparel fell 10 percent from their record high, $84 billion in 1989, according to Tactical Retail Solutions, a market research firm in New York.
There is other evidence of men's expanding closets. Figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and trade organizations confirm that men's spending has been rising faster in recent years.
Of course, women still spend nearly twice as much on clothing as men do; this week, women's designers have been strutting their stuff on New York runways, beckoning that huge market. But many retailers at all price levels report that their men's business -- particularly in brand-label sportswear -- is now growing faster than or at least as fast as their women's.
At J. C. Penney, for example, men's sales have grown at a rate of two percentage points faster than women's over the last four years. At Nordstrom Inc., men's wear now accounts for 18 percent of the company's sales, up from 16 percent in the first half of the decade. At the Neiman Marcus subsidiary Bergdorf Goodman, the only real growth is in the men's shops, said the company's chairman, Stephen C. Elkin.
Some makers are also cashing in. Just yesterday, the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, renowned for its preppy sportswear, said it would offer stock to the public and boasted of 15 percent growth in its men's wear business.
Men's clothing has traditionally been the last purchase out of the family budget -- after clothing for the rest of the family. But that has been changing for several reasons.
One is the increasingly casual workplace. It was not so many years ago that men had two basic uniforms: suits for work, and jeans and sweat shirts for the weekends. But when the concept of casual Fridays -- and sometimes other weekdays, too -- became a mainstay at a significant number of American companies, many men found themselves without the proper wardrobe.
Suddenly, they actually had to think about what they would wear. "Going casual allowed me to be a little more creative," Mr. Yalung said.
They started looking at clothing like cotton pants, knit shirts and sport coats, and buying them in big numbers. "What we have noticed is that there is a sea change in fashion consciousness in guys," said Isaac Lagnado, the president of Tactical Retail Solutions. "Casual Friday brought a whole new wardrobe with it."
Even political figures have adopted the trend, he said. "You see Al Gore wearing appropriate yuppie casual clothes like pressed khakis, the right casual shoes and a nice sport shirt," he said. "What is more, some of this is actually quite expensive."
Another reason for the change is that while apparel has historically been the domain of women -- retail experts say women pick out roughly half of men's clothing alone -- men are increasingly taking an interest in their own wardrobes. "Men are beginning to shop like women used to shop and women are shopping more like men once did," said Rick Gallagher, vice president of the National Retail Federation. "Women are not driven by fashion as much anymore, but men on the other hand are probably the most label-driven consumers that exist in America."
This trend may go hand in hand with the fact that many men, particularly baby boomers, have been worrying more about their appearance and doing something about it, through plastic surgery, workouts at health clubs and special creams and scrubs that make them feel younger.
"I think the vanity factor is important here," said Therese Byrne, publisher of Retail Maxims, a newsletter in New York. "Men really have historically been the most vain. If you look at the 15th and 16th centuries, they dressed more frilly than women. Somewhere in the 19th century this got annihilated. Now, it is back, bigger than ever."
Men "have been disempowered at work somewhat, so how are they going to feel good about themselves?" Ms. Byrne said. "With clothes. And in the aging of America, men have gotten more ridiculous than women with the hair implants and the eyelifts. They think a woman can get a job over them if she looks younger or fitter or stronger at 40. So they're doing it all, too."
Frilly it isn't, but Tommy Hilfiger's clothing line is among the more striking successes in attracting the increasingly clothing-conscious man. Knit shirts in bright colors and jackets emblazoned with his own name in huge letters are wildly popular among urban and suburban teen-agers alike, as well as middle- and upper-middle-class men who like the sporty, versatile looks and the status of the label. Tommy Hilfiger sales rose from $107 million in 1992 to $478 million in 1996 -- a 347 percent increase.
It is sportswear that attracts men like Dennis Huffman. "I absolutely enjoy shopping for clothes," said Mr. Huffman, 35, operations manager of a small electronic components distribution company in Atlanta, where he does not have to dress up. "It makes me feel good in the same way women do when they buy clothes." While Mr. Huffman spent his 20's in T-shirts and jeans, the last few years he has stocked up on Calvin Klein jeans and Ralph Lauren shirts.
"Once I got out of school," Mr. Huffman said, "I shaved and started making a little money and started noticing big time that there was a difference between being well dressed and not well dressed."
Fueling the men's apparel business at the upper end of the market is a small sliver of mostly wealthy men who rebel against casual looks, loading up on six-button suits, bright imported ties and fussy Edwardian styles that distinguish their wearers from their khaki-clad colleagues at work.
For instance, at Ermenegildo Zegna, a maker and retailer of men's upscale clothing based in New York, the chief executive, Richard Cohen, said revenues that hovered around $400 million for a few years have grown in the last year to closer to $550 million, bolstered by the sales of $1,500 suits of cashmere and other luxury fabrics and $110 geometric-patterned ties.
To be sure, total women's spending on apparel in 1996 was $75.4 billion, Tactical Retail Solutions found, nearly twice the men's figure of $41.2 billion. But spending by women has slowed as they have increasingly diverted their dollars to things like their homes, travel, personal care and children, and as clothing prices have been restrained by lower demand and far too much supply.
By contrast, as men's desire for clothing, particularly brand-name goods, has risen, men's clothing prices have been creeping up. The average price of a man's polo-style shirt is about $17 in this country, Mr. Lagnado said, whereas five years ago it was closer to $12.50. But women's tailored dresses have fallen from an average of $80 to closer to $45 over the same period.
Casual, office-friendly clothing has clearly led the rise in men's spending. While sales of men's suits fell 11 percent between 1994 and 1996, for example, sales of sport coats grew 14 percent, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm in Port Washington, L.I. Sales of casual slacks grew 14 percent over that period, while sales of dress slacks dropped 4 percent.
And while dress shirts gained a respectable 12 percent in sales, knit sport shirts jumped 22 percent, according to NPD.
Retailers and manufacturers have with some success been offering men clothes that can make the transition from a casual workplace to a Saturday-evening dinner. Three years ago, for example, the Haggar Corporation rolled out a line called City Casuals that combines sport jackets with cotton twill pants and knit shirts; the company says the line has grown at about 15 percent a year.
Hartmarx, a maker of men's suits, recently introduced sportswear lines under the Hickey-Freeman and Hart Schaffner & Marx names. There are wool pants, gabardine patterned slacks, knit shirts and sport jackets. Colors are lighter and brighter and most of the clothes are meant to be mixed and matched, just as women have done for years with separates like jackets and skirts.
"The kind of retailers we would like to see buy these products are buying them," said Hartmarx's chief executive, Elbert O. Hand.
Bloomingdale's, part of Federated Department Stores, has tried to create private-label lines that match the sensibility and quality of the brand-name merchandise it sells. Its best-selling line emulates Ralph Lauren's preppy, highly classic sportswear.
"These lines are extremely strong," said Stuart Glasser, the executive vice president in charge of men's collections. "It is the strongest growth in the men's store."
Meanwhile, upscale retailers are already talking about a backlash against casual dress.
"Casual? I'm not a big fan of it," said David Damiba, 25, who works on Wall Street and says he spends about $5,000 a year on thick ties, brightly colored shirts and six-button suits. "I would rather wear a tie. I like coming in dressed up."
Men's styles tend to change more slowly than women's. But for the first time in the 10 years since Giorgio Armani dressed the working man in baggy suits, men's clothing has a silhouette that is slimmer, more tailored and accented with the types of comfortable fabrics women have favored for years.
"This is the most exciting time in men's wear since the late 60's and early 70's," said Stan Tucker, fashion director for Saks Fifth Avenue, a unit of Investcorp. He said the rise of English-looking tailored fashions was experiencing "double-digit growth."
Fashion, of course, is a highly cyclical business, and spending on it goes the same direction as the economy. So the boom could be short- lived. "Men have the need to fill their wardrobes up, so there is some pent-up demand," said Peter Simon, the director of apparel at the NPD Group. "But there is nothing to tell me that sales of men's clothes will continue its rapid pace untethered."

HEADLINE: Ukraine Staggers on Path to the Free Market

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
Despite hundreds of millions of dollars of American aid, Ukraine is stumbling badly in its transition to a free-market economy, and diplomats and foreign executives blame rampant official corruption, which they say is remarkable even by standards of the region.
In recent weeks several major companies have abandoned Ukraine, following Government actions that diplomats and business people say favored companies in which Ukrainian officials hold personal stakes. 
 The situation has become so serious that some American officials say the $250 million in annual United States aid to the country should be cut off, or made conditional on showing definite progress on curbing the corruption.
"It's all rooted in one thing -- total, unequivocal corruption," David Sweere, an American businessman said of the obstacles facing foreign companies trying to operate here.
Mr. Sweere said the Government's confiscation last fall of all grain produced in the country cost him $5 million, because farmers who owed him grain were forced to turn over their harvest to Ukrainian authorities instead.
Mr. Sweere, who has been trying to break the Government's stranglehold over Ukraine's potentially lucrative agricultural sector, said he has received death threats.
In a confidential cable provided to The New York Times, the American Embassy termed one case involving the abrupt termination of a broadcast license held by an American company "a study of corruption."
It was, the embassy added, "illustrative of the serious difficulties" facing American businesses trying to operate in Ukraine, including such giants as Cargill, Monsanto and Coca-Cola.
[In Washington, the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign appropriations is to hold hearings on Wednesday on American aid to central Europe and the countries of the former Soviet Union. Clinton Administrations officials said they are expecting some pointed questions about Ukraine and reports about the corruption.]
"Serious difficulties," American officials and Western executives say, is diplomatese for corruption. In a series of cables to Washington over the last six months, the embassy described the business environment here as marked by bribes, threats and violence.
American and Ukrainian officials estimate that as much as $100 billion has been spirited out of the country by profiteering officials; if the money were brought back, the country's foreign reserves would nearly double, an American official said.
Ukraine, roughly the size of France in area and population, is now the third-largest beneficiary of American aid, after Israel and Egypt, receiving more than $1 billion since the country's independence in 1991. In that time, the country's standard of living has plummeted -- the average monthly income is about $80 -- while senior Ukrainian officials have become multimillionaires.
All this has prompted some American officials to suggest tight restrictions on aid as the only way to get the Government to get serious about reform. It is an idea, the officials concede, which would run into resistance in Congress, where there is a strong Ukrainian lobby.
When Leonid Kuchma was elected president in 1994, he spoke out strongly against corruption, and under pressure from the World Bank, instituted a number of reforms. For a while there was optimism among Western businesses and diplomats. But now, they say, the Government has regressed and the situation is worse than ever.
As an example, one businessman said he will need licenses from three agencies for a pesticide project, and each license, he said, would give another official the opportunity to demand a bribe. Among the reforms the World Bank had insisted upon was a reduction in the number of licenses.
While Mr. Kuchma himself is considered relatively clean, at least by the prevailing local ethic, some of his closest advisers are muscling in on legitimate businesses, diplomats and business people said.
Pavlo Lazarenko, Ukraine's Prime Minister, is among the many Ukrainian officials who, business people and diplomats say, have made millions through private business dealings while holding public office. Mr. Lazarenko declined a written request for an interview.
According to Western intelligence agencies, Mr. Lazarenko has an interest in United Energy Systems, which has a license to import natural gas and oil. In a country that uses more natural gas than Germany and France combined, this alone nets him an estimated $200 million a year, diplomats and businessmen said.
Business people and diplomats have also raised questions about a decree last August that required farmers to deliver their grain to the state, instead of selling it privately. The state paid the farmers around $85 a ton, at a time when the world market price was close to $200 a ton.
More than five million tons were delivered to the state, which in turn earned as much as $500 million in profits. Diplomats and executives said the proceeds were divided among various public officials.
This is a country that desperately needs foreign investment in order to modernize famously inefficient Communist-era industries, and to raise itself out of its economic cesspool.
But instead of coming in, companies are leaving.
Earlier this year, Tate & Lyle, one of the world's largest sugar producers, shut its refinery in Odessa, after the Government suddenly banned the importation of sugar cane, the only kind the factory could process. The British company had invested $5 million in modernizing the rundown plant, and 1,100 workers now are unemployed. A press spokesman declined to discuss the reasons for the company's departure from Ukraine.
The beneficiaries of the decree are domestic sugar beet growers, inefficient state-owned operations, in which Government officials have economic interests, according to diplomats and business people.
Potentially, one of the most lucrative enterprises in this country of 52 million people will be the sale of mobile phones. Recently, the Government awarded three licenses, one to a company called Kiev Star. Its owners include an adviser to Mr. Kuchma, a Cabinet minister and a Ukrainian with links to organized crime, said officials from two Western countries and a Western businessman close to the Government.
With that, Motorola, which had plans to invest $500 million to build the telecommunications system, announced that it was giving up on Ukraine. "Motorola cannot continue to invest in Ukraine when the Government is constantly changing the rules of the game," the company's spokesman said at the time.
Sometimes, the pressures against foreign investors are expressed overtly, as Joseph Lemire, an American businessman, discovered when he disputed the Government's ruling over a broadcast license for his radio station, Gala Radio.
One night soon after, Mr. Lemire said, he was driving home after dinner at Uncle Sam's, a trendy new watering hole here. A car forced him to pull over and three burly men with automatic weapons drawn demanded that he go with them.
Mr. Lemire refused, an act that most business people here would consider foolhardy.
The American Embassy later determined that the men who accosted Mr. Lemire were police officers, and the 40-year-old former banker turned entrepreneur has no doubt that their intent was to threaten him.
Mr. Lemire was fighting back after the Government had revoked Gala Radio's broadcast license -- just as the station was beginning to turn a profit. They gave it to a competing station in which Ukrainian Government officials have a financial interest, according to Western diplomats and Mr. Lemire.
A Ukrainian arbitration court then ruled that the National Council of Radio and Television Broadcasting, which regulates the airwaves, had acted illegally in taking away Mr. Lemire's license.
The council was not deterred.
"We reject the court's reasoning," the head of the council, Viktor Petrenko, said in an interview.
Mr. Lemire said bitterly, "There is no desire by the Ukrainian Government to ever have foreign investment."

HEADLINE: Canadian Chief Remains Quiet About Quebec

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 8

 BODY:
Even with a national election widely expected before summer, it is rare for Prime Minister Jean Chretien to say much these days about the most divisive issue in Canada: the separatist movement in Quebec.
Mr. Chretien freely talks about Canada's shrinking deficit and rebounding economy. But he has said little about how Canada would stay united if Quebec's leaders hold another separatist referendum, as planned, before the year 2000. 
 During his first official visit to Washington today, Mr. Chretien focused almost exclusively on efforts for smooth relations between the United States and Canada. It was President Clinton who, when asked about Quebec, reiterated his support for a united Canada.
After three decades of uncertainty over Quebec and a harrowingly close vote in an October 1995 referendum, many Canadians want to put the Quebec issue out of their minds. But the threat of a Canadian breakup is lately generating a lot more attention, and worry, outside of Canada.
In two recent international conferences -- one held at Wilton Park in England and the other at Tufts University near Boston -- Quebec's separatist movement was compared to more violent nationalist efforts like those in Northern Ireland, India, Sri Lanka and Burundi.
"Just by the virtue of having Canada placed in context with these countries says that despite the protestations of Quebec to the contrary, the threat of a unilateral declaration of independence does raise the possibility of conflict and violence," said Robert Lecker, a professor of English at McGill University in Montreal who took part in one of the conferences.
David Payne, a Quebec official who also attended one of the conferences, suggested, however, that the separatist movement in Quebec is included in such discussions because it shows how using democratic processes like the public referendum can help avoid violent conflict.
"Quebec is generally seen as a model of democratic access to sovereignty," Mr. Payne said. "In no way whatsoever was there an intimation of violence."
In their formal talks today, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Chretien discussed trade issues, disagreements over Cuba and international subjects like the expansion of NATO and peacekeeping missions in Bosnia and Haiti. On Monday, the two countries agreed to meet specific targets for reducing pollution in the Great Lakes.
In Canada, the lack of a pressing agenda for Mr. Chretien's Washington trip led to the widespread assumption that the visit was intended to provide a boost for the coming election, which the Prime Minister is expected to call for early June.
Mr. Chretien's Liberal Party is expected easily to maintain the commanding majority it has held in Parliament since the last election, in October 1993. In recent speeches he never fails to mention that Canada's federal budget deficit has been sharply reduced and that unemployment figures have recently dropped.
The issue of Quebec's threatened separation usually does not come up.
"This threat ought to be Chretien's central concern," wrote a Toronto Star columnist, Rosemary Speirs. "He can't continue to place the issue of Quebec separation on the back burner, as he has tried to do for the last three years, and he wants to do in this election."
Quebec was not on a back burner at a February conference on conflict prevention and violence at Wilton Park, an estate in West Sussex where the British Government has held top-level and confidential meetings since the end of World War II.
In a working group session to analyze the root causes of tensions and conflicts, Canada was studied, along with Burundi, Kenya, South Africa and Sri Lanka.
Professor Lecker of McGill gave an address about rising tensions among English-speaking Quebecers and the threat of secession by non-French-speaking parts of Quebec if the province tries to leave Canada.
"An African leader asked if we knew what the copycat syndrome is," Mr. Lecker said. "Then he remarked that that if Quebec can secede unilaterally, then Africa is lost."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Sale of Inflation Notes Hurts Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday under the weight of more data showing strength in the economy and disappointment over the latest auction of the Government's new inflation-indexed securities.
Traders said that because of the negative environment, in which investors assembled defensive positions, only the strength of the dollar prevented further losses. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, by which many lending rates are set, dropped 1 3/32, to a price of 94 6/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.10 percent, from 7.06 percent on Monday.
At the Treasury's sale of $8 billion of 10-year inflation-indexed notes, investors displayed less-than-expected demand, driving the price down. The notes yielded 3.65 percent, higher than the 3.62 percent traders expected and higher than the 3.449 percent in the Government's inaugural sale of the notes on Jan. 29. The auction was a reopening of the first issue in January, and was intended to build liquidity, or an active market for the new securities, which protect the value of an investment from inflation. The notes are sold in a so-called Dutch auction, or single-price format, much the way the two-year and five-year notes are sold. That means the notes are awarded at the highest yield needed to sell all the securities.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said, "Since bidding was not as aggressive and retail demand was less than what we saw in January, the Street had to underwrite a lot of this issue themselves."
The bid-to-cover ratio of 2.26 to 1 -- representing the level of demand for the notes -- was far short of the 5-to-1 ratio at the first sale. And the total of noncompetitive bids for the notes was only $36 million, compared with $157 million in January.
In addition to the weakness of the auction of inflation-indexed notes, a report showing that wholesale sales rose in February, another sign of strength in the economy, weighed on the Treasury market.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the report "showed there is a considerable amount of steam left in this economy."
The report showed that sales rose 2.1 percent in February, more than the gain of three-tenths of a percent that analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News expected, and that wholesale inventories were unchanged.
"It's clear that inventories are quite lean," Mr. Chan said, "which indicates that unlike the case that has existed in prior late stages of an expansion, inventories are unlikely to help much in slowing the economy."
That means, he said, that investors in the Treasury market will have to rely on a slowdown in consumer spending or further interest-rate increases by the Fed to rein in the economy and prevent inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. One hint of whether a slowdown in consumer demand will occur will come on Friday when the Government releases its report on retail sales in March.
Traders said that the strength of the dollar, which helped bond prices rise on Monday, limited yesterday's losses. A rising dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like government securities more attractive to foreign investors because of the potential for profit gains in currency translation. Also, interest rates in the United States are attractive vis-a-vis those in some other countries, particularly Japan.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 10-year inflation indexed notes:

LENGTH: 1829 words

HEADLINE: For US Airways, A Softer Landing?;
Chief Seeks Harmony, for Now, As He Tries to Cut Labor Costs

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
It is the story of the airline industry these days. With carriers generating record profits, many union workers want raises, testing their leverage against executives who say big pay increases would make their airlines less competitive. Pilots and managers have squared off at American and United, and Continental's pilots said last week that they wanted a 38 percent raise.
In this atmosphere of confrontation, the approach of Stephen M. Wolf, chairman and chief executive of US Airways, is an ambitious departure. Mr. Wolf wants to lower costs sharply, but he wants to do it with labor's help. As he tries to turn around the airline, which has lost $2.4 billion in the last decade, he has vowed that there will be no power struggle. 
 "No one has any leverage," he said in November.
That, at least, is the appearance Mr. Wolf has managed to keep up since taking over US Airways a year ago. But in reality, this industry is driven by leverage, and Mr. Wolf is emerging as one of the more subtle practitioners of the art. If Mr. Wolf does not get his way, he is likely to use measured steps, such as the steady shrinking of the airline, to win an agreement with labor leaders without direct confrontation.
This week, Mr. Wolf kicks off a series of meetings with employees at which he will undoubtedly try to persuade them that more drastic measures are needed -- sooner rather than later -- to bring US Airways' high costs in line with those of rivals.
And in a letter to shareholders in the company's just-released annual report, Mr. Wolf wrote that the airline was approaching "a fork in the road."
Clearly, one path heads toward a cost-cutting deal. The second direction, though, would surely not be the status quo. Timothy Ross, an analyst at SBC Warburg, said that to get the attention of labor leaders Mr. Wolf might start cutting unprofitable routes.
That task will become less costly after June, with the expiration of a "no furlough" clause in the pilots' contracts that pays them whether the airline needs them or not. "He may give a glimpse of the iron fist that is inside the velvet glove," Mr. Ross said.
Such a strategy would represent a subtle but important distinction from Mr. Wolf's years as chief executive of United Airlines, where he threatened layoffs and asset sales, with deadlines often attached, if labor did not go along with his plans.
Indeed, if Mr. Wolf is successful in lowering costs by working with unions, not battling them, it will mark a rare victory in this industry. After all, this goal has eluded most executives, who have been seen either as too confrontational -- a frequent criticism of Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of the AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines -- or too conciliatory, an oft-repeated description of Seth E. Schofield, Mr. Wolf's predecessor at USAir.
"It is hard to find the right formula," Philip Baggaley, an analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said.
Mr. Wolf's determination not to fight also hints at what motivated him, in January 1996, to take over US Airways, the nation's sixth-largest airline, a clear step down after running United, No. 1. Mr. Wolf appears to be trying to secure his place in the history books simply as a savvy builder of airlines, and not also as a long-time foe of labor.
Mr. Wolf has long shown a lack of interest in talking about himself, and has declined all requests for interviews since coming to US Airways. Yet what he says and does tend to be calibrated as precisely as a jet-engine blade. And thus far, his actions and words have led to remarkable progress: US Airways is more prosperous than ever, with record profits of $263.4 million last year.
Still, it is always easier to get concessions from labor in times of crisis, so the hard part for Mr. Wolf may just be starting.
Like most airlines, US Airways has benefited in recent years from a strong economy and a more disciplined approach to limiting its supply of seats. That gives airlines more control over pricing, and they have raised fares sharply, particularly for last-minute travel. US Airways also has a lock on many routes in the Northeast, where a large percentage of its passengers are business people who pay the highest fares.
Such profits make it difficult for workers to swallow the notion that cuts are urgently needed. All three major unions at the company are negotiating new contracts, and Mr. Wolf is saying to them, in effect: Work with me, and this airline will be bigger and better than ever.
If union leaders have any doubts, they are not sharing them publicly. Mr. Wolf has asked them not to negotiate in the media, and calls to officials representing flight attendants and mechanics were not returned. A spokesman for the pilots, Jim Gardner, said only, "From top to bottom, all of us at US Airways are committed to successfully and profitably meeting our competitive challenges."
Innocuous as that statement sounds, there appears to be some truth to it, at least for now. Though US Airways retains the cost structure that is the industry's highest, it is by many measures a better airline under Mr. Wolf.
For years, USAir, whose name Mr. Wolf changed earlier this year in hopes of giving it a more international flavor, lived up to its reputation as a second-rate airline. Its poor showings in on-time arrivals, customer complaints and lost baggage were often explained away as the result of flying in the congested and weather-beaten Northeast. Service was unpredictable, even on small things like drinks. On one flight, passengers would get an entire can of soda; on the next, they would get a glassful.
Now, key performance yardsticks are posted throughout US Airways' operations, and they have improved sharply. In on-time arrivals, the carrier jumped from eighth a year ago to first by January. It ranked fifth in both consumer complaints and lost baggage in January 1996; this January, it improved to second in complaints and third in lost bags. And the drink policy, among other things, has been standardized. Passengers are served a glass, but can have the whole can if they ask.
"Mr. Wolf has put a professionalism in our company that we've never really had," said Christopher O. Taylor, a flight attendant for the airline for 10 years. "Our airline is starting to look crisper."
Many ideas flowed out of task forces led by Rakesh Gangwal, US Airways' president and a former Wolf lieutenant at United. At every turn, the results of these cooperative efforts with rank-and-file employees are praised by the company -- employee newsletters are filled with such slogans as "Helping Out" and "Moving the Needle."
So far, Mr. Wolf has stuck to his strategy of managing with carrots, not sticks. He has produced a business plan that includes the enticing prospect to employees of more international flying. In the last year, US Airways has started service to Rome, Madrid and Munich.
He also placed an order in November for as many as 400 Airbus aircraft. He made the order contingent, however, on getting concessions that would lead to, as the company said in its recent 10-K filing, "a significant reduction" in labor costs.
Labor expenses at US Airways represented 43 percent of its total costs in the 12-month period ending in September, compared with 37 percent for all major United States carriers. One reason for the high costs is that from its earliest days, US Airways has been run much like a family business, with employees given certain benefits denied those at other airlines. Pilots, for example, have a great deal of flexibility in changing their schedules, which adds administrative costs.
Though all three union contracts are under negotiations, the mechanics and the flight attendants have told management it must first cut a deal with the pilots before they will consider concessions themselves.
For their part, leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association are showing few signs of softening to a proposed 12.5 percent pay cut. Robert Gaudioso, the union chairman who seemed to ally himself with Mr. Wolf at a meeting in November with analysts and reporters, was defeated in a recent election and replaced by Jon Bryan. Mr. Bryan, once a business professor who taught airline operations, will most likely have some suggestions for management on how to run the company more efficiently.
It is not that the unions are unwilling to make concessions. The sticking point has been what they want in return. In 1995, the company and labor leaders worked toward an accord in which the major unions would get stock, profit-sharing and board representation. But, the company says, the pilots made extra demands and the deal fell apart.
The latest talks have been complicated by Mr. Wolf's proposal to compete against Southwest Airlines , Delta Express and Valujet by setting up a separate division with lower costs, into which it would shift as much as 40 percent of its flights.
Mr. Wolf has said in employee newsletters that he considers the advance of low-cost rivals "truly distressing."
"If we don't have a competitive response in place very soon," he added, "it will be a serious issue."
Some analysts say that Mr. Wolf may reach a modest deal with labor, declare victory, then go ahead with the aircraft order. But at the analysts' meeting in November, Mr. Wolf and Mr. Gangwal repeated that they would strike just one long-term deal rather than going back to employees for more concessions later.
Thus far, Mr. Wolf has shown that he means what he says. With no labor agreements on the horizon, Airbus said in January that it would no longer guarantee delivery of 57 planes in 1998 and 1999.
The next step for Mr. Wolf could be grounding one or two plane types, slicing costs by simplifying US Airways' hodgepodge fleet. To employees, such a move might test the definition of "not fighting," but Mr. Wolf would no doubt take the position that he had no choice.
He does have a choice about whether he even needs to be at US Airways. By all accounts, he earned tens of millions of dollars at United, which is owned by the UAL Corporation. And last year, according to US Airways' proxy, his compensation package totaled $5.8 million, including restricted stock that is to vest over a period of four years.
But for now, Mr. Wolf appears to be seeking a less tangible payoff than a paycheck. Though he can claim credit for helping reinvent United as an employee-owned company in July 1994, he was thanked by being immediately replaced with an executive chosen by labor leaders, Gerald Greenwald.
If Mr. Wolf hopes to be perceived as a pioneer in working with unions, it will take an unqualified success at US Airways that includes the support of labor, said Joseph R. Blasi, a professor of management-labor relations at Rutgers University.
"He's afraid that people think he achieved cooperation with labor at United by default," Mr. Blasi said. "If he does it a second time, he will prove his real genius."

HEADLINE: A Fed Official's Romance Raises Issue of Conflict

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
What happens when a top Federal Reserve official who helps set the nation's interest rates becomes romantically involved with a leading investment banker?
For E. Gerald Corrigan, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company who is a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Cathy E. Minehan, the current president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, that question has taken on new urgency after another former Fed official cast doubts on the propriety of their relationship. 
 Mr. Corrigan, in an interview yesterday, said that he and Ms. Minehan were painfully aware of the potential pitfills and had gone to extraordinary lengths to avoid them. Starting in the fall of 1995, Mr. Corrigan said, he and Ms. Minehan worked out arrangements designed to insure that their relationship did not present either of them with a conflict of interest.
The romantic relationship between Mr. Corrigan and Mrs. Minehan began a little less than two years ago, Mr. Corrigan said. While it was not a secret, this week John P. LaWare, a former Fed governor, was quoted in The Boston Globe questioning whether the relationship might not be in the best interest of the Federal Reserve.
Yesterday, in a telephone interview, Mr. LaWare, who retired from the Fed in May 1995, explained his thinking: "I have the highest regard for their integrity, but the very fact of their relationship runs the risk of creating impressions that there may be conflicts of interest."
Mr. Corrigan, 55, joined Goldman, Sachs in January 1994, six months after resigning from the New York Fed, whose president holds a permanent voting seat on the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee.
(The Open Market Committee consists of the seven Washington-based Fed Governors and the 12 Fed regional presidents. All members attend the meetings, which are held roughly every six weeks, but only five of the 12 regional presidents are entitled to vote at any one time.)
As one of the nation's leading bond traders, Goldman, Sachs frequently invests its own capital in Government securities, effectively making bets on the Fed's monetary policy and the direction of interest rates. Mr. Corrigan was named a partner at Goldman, Sachs late last year.
As president of the Boston Fed, Ms. Minehan, 50, sits on the Open Market Committee. Before being named to the post in July 1994, she was the Boston Fed's first vice president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Corrigan, asked about the issue, replied that he and Ms. Minehan had discussed their situation with J. Virgil Mattingly, the Fed's general counsel, and lawyers at Goldman, Sachs, as soon as their relationship started to become serious.
"I can't speak to John LaWare's statement, but we really have gone to great length with the attorneys to cover every base," he said. "On many occasions I have said to Mr. Mattingly: 'Is there anything else that you want to know?' "
Fed officials said yesterday that they could recall no other instance where a voting member of the Open Market Committee had encountered similar potential conflicts of interest because of a personal relationship. But, in an age of many two-career couples, there have been some other sensitive issues involving senior Fed officials.
For instance, David W. Mullins Jr., the former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Mary Ann Gadziala, his then-fiancee and now wife, drew attention in 1994. Ms. Gadziala, a lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Business Week that year that she had ignored approaches from law firms and banks about prospective jobs because she was concerned that they might create an appearance of impropriety. In another case, when Sam Cross worked as a senior official at the New York Fed and his wife was a lawyer at Citibank, they both signed letters agreeing not to discuss Fed matters, Fed officials said.
Reading from a statement, Mr. Corrigan said: "We have been repeatedly assured that steps we have taken to avoid conflicts of interest have been appropriate and satisfactory. As necessary, we will remain in consultation with the lawyers in the future."
Under the arrangement, Mr. Corrigan said, Ms. Minehan avoids anysupervisory or regulatory oversight involving Goldman, Sachs. Moreover, Mr. Corrigan and Ms. Minehan "do not discuss issues involving monetary policy," he added, and he does not "directly or indirectly participate in any decisions at Goldman bearing on investments in Government securities."
Mr. Corrigan said that his work at Goldman basically fell into two broad categories: external work with Government clients helping advise them on bank reform and other matters related to financial regulation, and internal work for Goldman's risk management committee related to legal compliance and financial controls.
"Goldman, Sachs is satisfied that appropriate steps have been taken by all parties to guard against any potential conflicts of interest," Robert J. Katz, the firm's general counsel, said. "We explained to the Fed's lawyers what Mr. Corrigan does at Goldman and particularly that he has nothing to do with our trading."
Fed officials in Boston, New York and Washington yesterday referred questions on the matter to Mr. Mattingly, the general counsel. "Obviously it raised some issues because of his position and her position," Mr. Mattingly said. For one thing, Mr. Mattingly said, Ms. Minehan "must accept no gifts from Goldman, Sachs." The Fed also set rules concerning Ms. Minehan's public appearances with Mr. Corrigan. "She is not to appear at all in any kind of situation, client situation, where he is trying to solicit clients," he said.
Mr. Mattingly added that he saw nothing wrong with Ms. Minehan's attendance at a recent conference sponsored by Goldman, Sachs. There were many senior Fed officials at the conference, which dealt with issues important to the Fed. "These two people have met every request that the Boston general counsel and I made," Mr. Mattingly said.

HEADLINE: Bias Charge Rejected on Display of Breasts

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
To Adele Buzzetti, the proprietor of the Cozy Cabin, a 20-year-old topless bar in Queens, and her part-time employee, a dancer and a poet who calls herself Vanessa Doe, the city's law restricting sexually oriented businesses discriminates against female dancers. The regulation, which enumerates certain body parts that may not be exposed or touched, forbids the baring of the female breast. It is silent, however, on the question of the male breast.
Are not male breasts also alluring? asked Ms. Buzzetti and Ms. Doe, who brought a sex-bias challenge to the law in Federal court, saying that the law prohibits women from dancing topless, but not men. 
 On their behalf, Lenore Tiefer, a psychologist who specializes in human sexuality, argued that male chests have been increasingly eroticized in recent years. She mentioned a current Diet Coke ad showing women ogling a man, a Ray-Ban sunglasses ad featuring the Olympic runner Michael Johnson in all his pectoral splendor, and the emergence of Calvin Klein underwear models who now rule billboards where the buttoned-up Marlboro Man used to roam.
But yesterday, a Federal judge in Manhattan upheld the constitutionality of the law. The reason, he said, is that in their impact on society, male and female breasts are separate and not equal.
"One does not have to be either a psychologist or a sociologist to recognize that, if it were widely known that 10 topless women were walking down Park Avenue and 10 topless men were walking down Madison Avenue, the effect on the traffic on Park Avenue would be substantially greater than on Madison Avenue," wrote the Federal District Court judge, John S. Martin Jr.
And the effect on local traffic is exactly what the regulation is about, said the judge, a former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He rejected the plaintiffs' argument that the 1995 zoning ordinance also restricted their First Amendment right to free expression. Citing two Supreme Court decisions on the zoning of sex entertainment businesses, he said the purpose of the city's carefully drawn law was not to curb the dancers' performance but to protect neighborhoods from the impact of the clubs, like crime, reduced property values, and an apparent decline in the community's character.
He also said that despite the explicit ban on female breasts, the regulation did not necessarily permit clubs like Chippendales, which feature male topless dancers, to do business in protected neighborhoods, pointing out that it bans "human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely concealed." In this regard, he said, the regulation did not reveal an anti-male bias.
"These provisions simply recognize that there are anatomical differences between males and females which in our society elicit different reactions," he wrote.
Ms. Buzzetti declined to comment on the decision, said Stephanie Alter, a lawyer in the firm bringing the case, who deplored the ruling. "The effect is economic," she said. "They've just eliminated a group of jobs for women."
Judge Martin's ruling has no immediate impact on the regulation, which has also been challenged in state courts. Its enforcement is temporarily suspended, until an appellate court issues its ruling.

HEADLINE: Rise in Merit-Based Aid to Students Alters the Landscape of the College Market

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
If you aced the college boards, do we have a bargain for you! That's the not-so-subtle message sent this month to tens of thousands of high-achieving high school seniors, who have been offered hefty college scholarships in spite of the ability of their families to pay full tuition.
And increasingly it is second-tier private colleges that are making the offers, a new study shows. Their liberal use of merit-based aid is slowing the trend toward the ever-greater concentration of talent in more elite institutions. 
 But there is a darker side to this triumph of market forces.
"The big worry is that schools will divert funds that would otherwise go to needy students," said William Bowen, head of the Mellon Foundation and former president of Princeton University.
Squeezed by parents looking for more bang from a tuition buck, educators in recent years have discovered the realities of the competitive market -- a market in which merit scholarships (economists refer to them as discounts) are a key to keeping good students and attracting better ones.
A survey of 379 colleges and universities, to be published in the fall ("The Student Aid Game," Princeton University Press), shows that merit-based aid grew at a 13 percent annual rate during the 1980's, even after adjusting for inflation. And there is reason to believe that the pace has accelerated since.
"Nobody pays retail anymore," said Thomas Williams of Group USA/Nowel-Levitz in Iowa City, management consultants specializing in colleges.
That is welcome news for parents with comfortable incomes who nonetheless shudder at the prospect of paying more than $20,000 a year in tuition.
At the top of the college pecking order stand a few dozen institutions able to skim the cream from the applicant pool and then offer whatever discounts are needed to make tuition affordable to everyone they admit. In 1991 the antitrust division of the Justice Department did force eight Ivy League colleges to abandon their formal agreement to limit aid to those in need, a limit that had applied even when the colleges were competing for budding Einsteins and Updikes. But little has changed: almost all the aid granted by top colleges remains need-based.
"The high moral ground is held most easily when it is buttressed by money and prestige," said Gordon Winston, an economist at Williams College.
In contrast, most private colleges are feeling the pressure to use discounts to attract the best and the brightest. In some cases, discounting is purely defensive.
"We don't try to hit home runs with merit aid," said Michael McPherson, president of Macalester College in St. Paul and a co-author of "The Student Aid Game." Instead, Mr. McPherson said, the goal is to keep his high-cost institution ($24,188 in tuition and fees next year) competitive with the array of good public universities in the region.
Denison University in Ohio is following a similar route, offering discounts of $3,000 to $5,000 (from a full price of $25,620 in 1997-98) to all applicants who graduate in the top half of their high school classes. Enrollment has risen sharply since the policy was adopted in 1994, increasing total tuition revenue by a fourth in spite of the cut in average revenue per student.
In other cases, though, discounting is part of an ambitious strategy to create a virtuous circle, providing irresistible bargains to high achievers in the expectation that they will, in turn, attract better students and faculty. Among the most aggressive in this category: George Washington University and Emory University.
Using merit scholarships to break into a more selective crowd requires deep pockets. "It takes a huge inducement" to attract the best students, said Paul Krugman, an M.I.T. economist, as well as many years to change the academic reputation of a university. "That's why the persistence of college rankings is so high."
But the strategy does occasionally succeed. In the early 1980's, Trinity University in San Antonio bid for a place in the academic limelight by offering free tuition to all National Merit scholars. It no longer does, said Estelle Frerichs, the university's director of financial aid, at least in part because it no longer needs to: in 1993 some 35 percent of the freshman class had scored above 600 in the College Board verbal test, and 65 percent had scored above 600 in the math test. Ms. Frerichs cautions, however, that while a college can attract good students with merit scholarships, "you can't keep them" unless you meet their expectations.
The growth of merit discounting is obviously manna for students from families that would not qualify for need-based aid. And because merit discounts are usually contingent on continuing academic excellence, the practice creates incentives for students to spend more time studying and less time drinking beer.
Morton Schapiro, a dean at the University of Southern California and co-author with Mr. McPherson of "The Student Aid Game," argues that aggressive merit discounting also serves a broader public interest, by spreading the talent beyond the elite institutions. While he acknowledges that there is virtually no research on whether high-achieving college students can motivate low achievers, Mr. Schapiro notes that a host of studies have found that egalitarian placement does raise average performance in primary and secondary schools.
One question casting a pall over what would otherwise be a celebration of freer markets in higher education is whether merit discounts will reduce the aid available for the neediest students. The most comprehensive evidence comes from survey data in "The Student Aid Game."
While need-based aid as a portion of all institutional aid did fall by one-eighth from 1983 to 1991, the total size of the aid pie grew fast enough to keep needy students ahead of the trend. Indeed, the 10 percent real annual growth of need-based aid far outpaced tuition.
What is more, the survey showed that virtually none of the new merit aid was handed out by private colleges and universities that ranked among the top fifth for academic selectivity. Thus, while the "rich" may have got richer through merit aid, they managed to do so only by scaling back their ambitions to attend an elite college. More important, the poor apparently did not suffer in the process.
The final verdict on merit aid is not in, however. Thomas Kane, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, noted that revenue lost in competing for students might be inducing colleges to increase class sizes, skimp on laboratory equipment or eliminate less popular departments.
It is also possible that without the pressure to provide merit aid, colleges would have narrowed the gap left by the Federal Government's declining commitment to need-based financial aid.
"We have no way of comparing what is with what might have been," Mr. Schapiro allowed.
Donald Kennedy, former president of Stanford University, is deeply pessimistic that need-based aid will remain sacrosanct, as all but a handful of colleges are drawn into the very serious game of tuition discounting.
"While more dollars will flow to students," Mr. Kennedy predicted, "some very needy ones will be deprived."

HEADLINE: Federal Appeals Court Upholds California's Ban on Preferences

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 8

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court here upheld the constitutionality of California's Proposition 209 today, ruling that the voters were well within their rights to ban the use of racial and sex-based preferences in affirmative-action programs run by the state.
The unanimous decision by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit overturned an injunction issued by a Federal District Court judge to block the implementation of the ballot measure shortly after its approval in November. 
 "A system which permits one judge to block with the stroke of a pen what 4,736,180 state residents voted to enact as law tests the integrity of our constitutional democracy," one of the judges, Diarmuid F. O'Scannlain, wrote in the higher court's opinion today.
The strongly worded ruling went considerably further than either side had expected. And though it may prove to be only one turn in a long and complex legal battle over affirmative action, supporters of the initiative said they expected the decision to have an immediate effect on the widening national campaign to end decades of race and sex preferences in government hiring, contracting and education.
"I think that we have a long way to go, but the decision of the Ninth Circuit is a crucial one," said Ward Connerly, the Sacramento businessman who led the political campaign for the ballot measure. "It's a nail, it's a spike, it's a dagger in the coffin of preferences. I and those who fought so hard on behalf of 209 are ecstatic about it."
The ruling could allow Proposition 209 to take effect in 21 days. But representatives of the civil rights groups that have opposed the law said they would soon file an appeal before all 19 sitting judges of the Ninth Circuit. If they lose there, opponents of the initiative said, they will take the case to the United States Supreme Court.
President Clinton, who had ordered the Justice Department to join the court fight against the initiative, seemed to concede today that an important battle had been lost. At a White House news conference, he said supporters of affirmative action would have to "regroup and find new ways to achieve the same objective."
"I believe if states are precluded from trying to take appropriate steps that are not quotas and that do not give unqualified people a chance to participate in whatever it is -- economic or educational life -- but do recognize the disadvantages people have experienced, I think that will be a mistake," Mr. Clinton said.
The Ninth Circuit's support for Proposition 209 did not come as a great surprise because of its generally conservative leanings.
Judge O'Scannlain and one of his colleagues, Edward Leavy, were both appointed to the bench by President Ronald Reagan. The third judge in the case, Andrew J. Kleinfeld, is a Bush appointee who is viewed by some legal experts as one of the most conservative members of the Federal judiciary.
By contrast, the judge who issued the preliminary injunction, Thelton E. Henderson, is a Carter appointee who once served on the board of the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California. Judge Henderson was considered sufficiently liberal by supporters of the initiative that they focused much of their legal energy on trying to have him removed from the case.
Lawyers on both sides had accused their adversaries of "shopping" for sympathetic judges. But proponents of the ballot measure could scarcely believe their luck when their request for an emergency order suspending the injunction came before a randomly assigned three-judge panel that appeared to be considerably to the right of the Ninth Circuit's ideological center.
The California Civil Rights Initiative, as the affirmative-action measure is formally called, sought to bar the state government from bringing racial or sex considerations to bear in the decisions it makes in giving out jobs, letting contracts or granting admission to state universities. The measure was approved on Election Day with 54 percent of the vote.
In granting a temporary restraining order on Nov. 27 to opponents of the initiative, Judge Henderson argued that there was a "strong probability" that it might be unconstitutional. In issuing the preliminary injunction on Dec. 23, he said it would violate the equal-protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because it would eliminate only those programs that benefit women and minorities. By contrast, the advantages sometimes given to, say, Army veterans who apply for state benefits would be preserved.
The Ninth Circuit rejected that argument out of hand, saying that the initiative addressed matters of race and sex "in a neutral fashion."
"As a matter of 'conventional' equal protection analysis, there is simply no doubt that Proposition 209 is constitutional," Judge O'Scannlain wrote.
The appeals panel had originally been expected to rule on the motion for emergency relief and then send the appeal to a separate group of randomly selected judges for fuller review. Instead, the motions panel kept the case itself.
Its decision today went well beyond the narrow question of whether Judge Henderson had acted properly in granting the injunction, and it seemed to rule out the possibility that even if the injunction was lifted, the case would be sent back to the District Court for a trial on the ballot measure's merits.
"The only issue before the Ninth Circuit seemed to be whether the preliminary injunction was wrongly granted," said Erwin Chemerinsky, a professor of constitutional law at the University of Southern California. "But the court went ahead and decided on the constitutionality of Proposition 209.
"The Ninth Circuit has said here that the facts alleged by the plaintiffs, even if true, don't add up to a constitutional violation," he added. "If you follow this, there is no point to a trial."
Robert C. Post, a constitutional law expert at Boalt Hall School of Law at the University of California, noted that although the case might yet return to the District Court, Judge Henderson would have to rule in a manner consistent with an appeals decision that dismissed most of the precedents he had cited in the case.
"They are saying that Prop. 209 is not a burden to equal treatment," Professor Post said. "They are saying that it is equal treatment."
The lead attorney for the civil rights groups opposed to the law, Mark Rosenbaum, said the appeals court decision flew in the face of "decades of mainstream Supreme Court law."
"It doesn't just force women and minorities to the back of the bus," he said. "It boots them off altogether."

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN ZAIRE;
As Rebels Gain in Zaire, Mobutu Declares Emergency and Imposes Military Rule

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 8

 BODY:
Moving to preserve the power that is rapidly slipping away from him, President Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's longtime dictator, declared a state of emergency throughout the country today, replacing civilian officials with military administrators.
Mr. Mobutu's move, which in fact will give him nominal control over only five of Zaire's eight provinces, came as civilian opposition to his authority continued to grow in the capital and an armed rebellion appeared poised to make new gains in the countryside. 
 The leader of the rebellion, Laurent Kabila, addressing a jubilant crowd today in Mbuji-Mayi, the diamond mining capital of central Zaire, stepped up his threat to Mr. Mobutu's rule by ruling out any power-sharing agreement with the Government and promising to train his guns quickly on Kinshasa, the national capital.
In testimony today before the House of Representatives, the Clinton Administration's Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, George Moose, said of recent events in Zaire, "It is clear that Mobutu, the Mobutu regime, is a thing of the past."
At Mbuji-Mayi, the site of the rebels' latest major victory, Mr. Kabila told a crowd of tens of thousands that his fighters were already as close as 150 miles to the capital. He ruled out any future role for Mr. Mobutu.
But as much as Mr. Mobutu's declaration of a state of emergency was a response to Mr. Kabila's stunning battlefield advances of recent weeks, it was equally a reply to sharp new pressures on the 66-year-old leader brought by a newly appointed Prime Minister who has challenged the President's once unquestioned authority here.
Since Mr. Mobutu reluctantly appointed him Prime Minister last week, Etienne Tshisekedi, a popular, longtime opponent of the President, has moved to dissolve a Parliament packed with supporters of Mr. Mobutu and selected a Government that includes no allies of the President.
Mr. Tshisekedi's boisterous supporters have enjoyed the run of the streets in Kinshasa since Monday, frustrating security forces who have sought to intimidate them and preventing members of Parliament from meeting to remove the new Prime Minister even before he could assume his official functions.
Mr. Tshisekedi's aides have called for a huge demonstration of force on Wednesday to march the Prime Minister to his new offices, and Mr. Mobutu, who still retains the allegiance of several key army units here, seems to have decided to intervene to stop his longtime foe from taking effective power.
"We have to save the furniture," said one close assistant to the President. "He is taking his responsibility before history. Kabila said he is about to take Kinshasa, and Tshisekedi is racing him to the finish line. The risk is a conflagration that will serve as the pretext for an invasion."
Hundreds of Western troops, including American, French and Belgian soldiers, have been positioned just across the Congo River in the Congolese capital, Brazzaville, in preparation for the evacuation of Westerners living here. Since the deployment of those forces began, all sides in the Zairian conflict have expressed fears that foreign political intervention was being prepared.
The terms of the newly decreed state of emergency, which was flashed on television screens this evening without comment, were not announced. But an aide to Mr. Mobutu said they would include a curfew and a strict ban on political activity.
A senior aide to Mr. Tshisekedi said tonight that the Prime Minister's march to claim his office would go ahead as planned, setting the stage for renewed conflict in the streets of the capital.
For the second day, Kinshasa was the scene of rowdy street protests by supporters of Mr. Tshisekedi. They attacked the homes and vehicles of members of Parliament who have begun efforts to unseat Mr. Tshisekedi.
At least one member of Parliament was beaten by a street mob, and a former minister of Mr. Mobutu's was dragged from his car, robbed and beaten near Parliament after he was mistaken for a legislator.
Mr. Tshisekedi was appointed to the office of Prime Minister last week for the third time, in an effort by both supporters and enemies of Mr. Mobutu in the capital to blunt the rebel advance by handing the Government to a popular politician.
Mr. Mobutu's effort to save his 31-year-old rule also came as Mr. Kabila, the rebel leader, is feeling more confidant than ever after seizing the home of Zaire's lucrative diamond industry last weekend and encircling the capital of the country's southern copper belt, Lubumbashi, on Monday. Mr. Kabila vowed to speed up his bid for power.
"Our next objective is the capital, Kinshasa," Mr. Kabila told the rally in Mbuji-Mayi, 600 miles east of here. "All of the evil in this country is decided in Kinshasa."
With an estimated $20 million in official monthly receipts for diamonds and far more money believed to be made through the black market trade, Mbuji-Mayi is Zaire's richest source of hard currency and represents a huge economic boost for the rebellion.
As Mr. Kabila's forces closed in on Lubumbashi, nearly 1,000 miles to the southeast, units of Mr. Mobutu's Presidential Guard were reported to be offering sporadic resistance.
While officers of the Presidential Guard said they had prevailed in several skirmishes with the rebels, Western diplomats here gave them little chance of holding out. And in an unusual announcement, the state radio in Kinshasa seemed to agree today, calling the fall of Lubumbashi "a matter of hours."
Throughout Zaire's six-month civil war, Government troops have typically fled at the approach of Mr. Kabila's forces, pillaging each city as they flee.
Perhaps to insure a measure of dignity in peace talks that adjourned indefinitely today in South Africa, the Government recently sent loyalist units of the Presidential Guard, a heavily armed and relatively well-trained force that is drawn almost exclusively from Mr. Mobutu's northern Ngbandi tribe, to mount a symbolic defense of Lubumbashi.
"They will put up a show, perhaps, but the city is basically undefendable at this point," a regional military expert said.
Coming fast on the heels of Kisangani and Mbuji-Mayi, Lubumbashi's fall would leave Kinshasa as the only major city in Government control. Mr. Kabila now asserts that his forces have advanced deep into two of the four remaining provinces that have escaped their control, including Mr. Mobutu's fief of Equatoria.
For many analysts here, the most imposing potential showdown looming in Zaire is one between Mr. Tshisekedi and Mr. Kabila, who has pointedly refused offers from the new Prime Minister of a number of important ministerial posts.
Mr. Tshisekedi is a native of East Kasai Province, the site of Mbuji-Mayi. And Mr. Kabila's speech and reception there today were being closely watched throughout Zaire for signs of how the contest for power between the two men would play out.
Witnesses to events in Mbuji-Mayi said Mr. Kabila had been received as warmly there as he had been in other major cities recently captured by his forces. But in his speech today, the rebel leader was careful not to make blunt criticisms of Mr. Tshisekedi in one of the Prime Minister's strongholds.
"Tshisekedi's place should not be with Mobutu, but against Mobutu," Mr. Kabila was reported by the BBC as saying. "We are all in the same trench against a common enemy."

HEADLINE: Gino P. Santi, 81, Developer Of Pilot Ejection System, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Gino P. Santi, a Brooklyn-born Air Force engineer who developed the modern pilot ejection system, died on Thursday at a hospice near his home in Dayton, Ohio. He was 81 and had spent most of his career at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base there.
His wife, Dorothy, said the cause was bone cancer. 
 Almost from the moment man first began to fly planes, people started wondering how to get back down to earth in one piece when things went seriously wrong with the machines.
Parachutes were an obvious solution, and easy enough to use when a pilot could step out on the wing of an open cockpit and leap free of a slow-moving craft. But as planes got faster and closed cockpits became the norm, a combat pilot would often not have enough time to remove the canopy, hoist himself out of his seat and jump before crashing.
And even when he did have time, if the powerful centrifugal forces created as the plane spun out of control did not pin him to his seat, he was likely to be killed or seriously injured when the tail section of his own plane slammed into him or fouled his parachute lines. Those fates that befell more than half those who bailed out of planes in World War II.
Although a prototype system to hurl a pilot free of the cockpit was developed as early as 1910, it was not until the 1930's that work began in earnest on ejection systems.
In part perhaps because Mr. Santi was still in college, studying for bachelor's and master's degrees in civil engineering at City College, some of the early technology seemed almost quixotic: a behind-the-seat pusher, for example, that pilots dubbed the meat grinder because it tended to push them through the propellers.
Then there was the Howard Hughes solution. His mammoth wooden Spruce Goose was equipped with a device to fling a pilot down through a hatch, hardly the direction of choice for a low-flying combat pilot in distress.
The Germans developed an explosive catapult system in World War II, but the explosion often killed pilots or broke their backs. Almost as soon as he went to work on the problem for the Air Force in 1947, Mr. Santi, who had become familiar with aviation engineering during four years with the forerunner of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, came up with his first breakthrough, the use of a controlled explosion that gave the pilot less of a jolt even as it hurled him higher than the German version had.
Mr. Santi's work at Wright was carried on in secrecy lest word of his approach leak out to the enemy: the Navy, which was also working on ejection systems. Millions of future development dollars were at stake, and when the Air Force won the race when the Santi system was perfected in 1949, the Navy somewhat churlishly adopted a British system.
Over the next decades, Mr. Santi, who served two stints of active duty but spent most of his career as a civilian employee of the Air Force, continued to improve the ejection system for use on increasingly fast jet planes, often by overcoming confirmed skeptics with solutions that left them scratching their heads in wonder.
Among other things, he developed the use of the rocket to propel ejection seats and insisted on a design that would eject a pilot safely from the ground, an audacious goal he achieved in part by having the parachute unfurl as the pilot was hurtling upward.
His later designs included automated electrical systems, in which the operations of the complex ejection system vary with air speed and altitude.
One of Mr. Santi's most startling achievements was the development of an instant ejection system in which the pilot is catapulted safely through the canopy, a development so advanced that it was even adopted by the Navy, whose carrier pilots often do not have time to wait for the canopy to be blown away.
Although his last project, a 1978 modification, is still the Air Force standard, Mr. Santi did not always see the full potential of his inventions, like the rapid-inflation air bag he developed in the 1950's to separate a pilot from his seat, long before it became an automotive safety staple.
For all his work on futuristic systems, at home Mr. Santi was a meticulous handyman who kept his sights firmly on the past. His wife, for example, is still using what may well be the nation's oldest operational washer-dryer, but, as she noted yesterday, she no longer drives the 1963 Pontiac station wagon Mr. Santi kept running for close to 25 years.
"I wrecked it," she said.
In addition to his wife he is survived by a son, Victor, of Dayton; four daughters, Janice Shandera of Lincolnville, Me., Martha Heil of Fairfield, Ohio, Linda Roth of Cincinnati and Laura Santi of Columbia, Md.; a sister, Ismene Lindsey of New Milford, N.J., and 11 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Paying for One Big Party

 BODY:
Politicians make it a business to be sensitive to the most minor wobbles of public opinion. Yet in recent weeks, the leaders of Washington's all-inclusive Incumbent Party have been assuring each other that Americans do not really care about campaign-finance reform. The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll this week exposes their lie. It offered a startling portrayal of a nation that, far from being indifferent, yearns for abolition of a system clearly viewed as corrupt. By ignoring such warnings, Congress deepens the public's already considerable disgust and cynicism.
It is hardly surprising that the respondents in the Times surveys do not see President Clinton or Congress as advocates of reform. Though the economic boom still boosts Mr. Clinton's approval rating, he and his inner circle have no credibility as campaign reformers, and for good reason. Vice President Al Gore, who distanced himself from Whitewater, has seen his ratings plummet following exposure of his own active role in fund-raising. The new chief of staff, Erskine Bowles, who was expected to turn the page on the Arkansas shenanigans, has now been called to testify by the grand jury looking into the possible payment of hush money to Webster Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General. The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, remains low in the estimation of voters because of his own financial irregularities. 
 Of the major figures in Washington, only Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, remains personally unmarred by the recent fund-raising scandal. It is thus increasingly difficult to understand why he would want to huddle with Mitch McConnell of Kentucky under the umbrella of special-interest politics. At the very least, he should be leading the charge for broad and open-ended investigations of campaign fund-raising irregularities by the Congressional committees. Given the problems of the White House and the Speaker, unentangled players like Mr. Lott -- or Democrats like Richard Gephardt, Bob Kerrey and John Kerry -- have a real opportunity to serve the country and their own ambitions.
This page has long argued that what some analysts interpret as voter indifference is actually voter cynicism. That is a sentiment that politicians ignore at their peril, for it will inevitably lead to challenges from reformers within or reckless mavericks like Ross Perot from the outside. Mr. Lott would serve the G.O.P. by dropping his support of Senator McConnell's efforts to undermine the reform legislation sponsored by Senators John McCain of Arizona and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin.
Mr. McConnell says he does not want to abridge the freedom of businesses and wealthy individuals to give to the candidates of their choice. That defense of legalized bribery was undercut by a separate poll that came out last week in Business Week, surveying 400 top business executives. About 70 percent of them said they had contributed money in the 1996 political campaign, and 68 percent said they wanted to end the unlimited corporate and individual contributions to political parties known as "soft money." It thus turns out that the very people who are shaken down for the money that corrupts Washington would prefer an honest Congress. In other words, the only thing preventing representative government from producing a new age of reform is the representatives. Don't they read polls inside the Beltway anymore?
