HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OFFERS $18 BILLION MORE IN MEDICARE CUTS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration offered today to make additional cuts of $18 billion in projected Medicare spending over the next five years to help reach agreement on eliminating the Federal deficit, people involved in the budget negotiations said today.
In saying that it was willing to compromise further on Medicare, the issue that has most divided the Administration and Congressional Republicans through two years of budget wars, the White House was clearly seeking to appear flexible as the two sides began their first serious negotiations since their impasse in late 1995 led to a Government shutdown. 
 The Administration had previously proposed a plan that it said would cut the growth of Government health care spending for the elderly by $100 billion over five years, while the most recent Republican offer was $158 billion over six years.
"There is a serious intent here to show that we want to get this process off to the right start," said a senior Administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Republicans said that they welcomed the Administration proposal but that they wanted to study it further. They said they had offered their own proposals, which they did not specify, for narrowing the gap between the White House and Republican plans for slowing the growth in Medicare spending and averting a long-term financial crisis in the program.
Today's meeting on Capitol Hill, attended by the leaders of the Congressional budget committees and members of the White House economic team, was the first of several scheduled over the next week.
President Clinton has proposed meeting directly with the Republican leadership at the White House next week in an effort to give the process further impetus.
Expressions of optimism by both sides early this year have given way in the last month to predictions that the effort to eliminate the deficit by 2002 was on the verge of collapse. But with both parties eager to strike a deal, the Administration and Congressional Republicans have been conducting quiet preliminary talks for several months even as each tried to pin the blame on the other for the apparent lack of progress.
Both sides said today's discussion had improved the atmosphere and the prospects for a deal, although they must still address myriad other differences, like the size of any tax cut and the depth of spending cuts in military and domestic programs.
"I would assess it for an opening round as a very successful three-and-a-half hour discussion," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Budget Committee.
Franklin D. Raines, the White House budget director, told reporters after the meeting that the two sides were "making progress in that we are moving forward with discussions and we are seeing common ground."
President Clinton had already made one effort at compromise on Medicare this year, saying the day after his inauguration in January that he would move halfway to the last Republican proposal. Mr. Clinton said that compromise would reduce Medicare spending by $100 billion over five years or $138 billion over six years.
But the Congressional Budget Office analyzed Mr. Clinton's plan and found that it would save $82 billion over five years, or $18 billion less than Mr. Clinton said. Republicans have insisted that the budget be balanced using the budget office's analysis rather than on the slightly more optimistic assessments of the White House's Office of Management and Budget.
In today's meeting, Administration officials essentially offered to accept the Congressional Budget Office analysis on Medicare. They presented specific proposals to increase the savings from their plan, mainly by reducing payments to hospitals and other health-care providers, so that their plan would yield $100 billion in reduced spending over five years even under the Congressional Budget Office's assumptions.
Mr. Clinton used the Republican proposals to reduce the growth of Medicare spending as a major theme in his effort to recover from the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994 and to win re-election last year. His continued move toward compromise -- without the Republicans having made any specific counteroffer -- is likely to generate grumbling or worse from liberal Democrats.
White House political strategists have kept a close eye on Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House, who is a likely challenger to Vice President Al Gore for the party's Presidential nomination in 2000 and who has shown a willingness to clash with the Administration.
It is unclear whether the White House can win enough support from Democrats to pass a compromise budget if the party's liberal wing objects. Similarly, Republicans remain divided over how hard to push for deep spending and tax cuts, and Republican negotiators are looking back over their shoulders at their party's right wing, which had vowed to oppose any deal that does not significantly reduce the size and role of the Federal Government and provide sweeping tax cuts.
Republican leaders including Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, have threatened in recent days to declare the President's budget proposals dead and to proceed with their own if there is not progress in the negotiations with the White House in the next week.
But Republicans have so far not produced their own budget proposals, which would require spending reductions to pay for proposed tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Wants to Fix Nafta, Not Sabotage It;
Consider the States

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As Thomas L. Friedman says (column, April 3), President Clinton and Vice President Gore must make a more vigorous effort to convince Congress and the country that freer international trade is essential both to our economic progress and our foreign-policy objectives. 
 However, Mr. Friedman's advocacy of "reasonable programs" to assist and retrain the minority of American workers who might lose jobs in the transition falls short of the Presidential commitment essential to progress toward an open world economy.
President Clinton needs to insure that the trade policy advantageous to the nation is also advantageous to every state.
Such a pledge would be more effective in garnering support for free-trade agreements than the one to marshal support for Nafta.
The political viability of a dependable free-trade strategy requires a domestic development strategy to backstop it.
 
DAVID J. STEINBERG
Alexandria, Va., April 3, 1997
 
The writer was president of the U.S. Council for an Open World Economy, 1974-89.

HEADLINE: DANGER ON THE LINE: A special report.;
Standards for Gas Pipelines Unchanged Years After Blast

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: EDISON, N.J., April 8

 BODY:
Three years after a natural gas pipeline explosion destroyed eight apartment buildings here, Federal investigators say little has been done to toughen pipeline safety standards.
In particular, the investigators say, the Department of Transportation regulators who oversee gas pipelines have failed to impose specific standards the investigators recommended for pipeline toughness, for the frequency and types of inspections and for installation of equipment that would allow operators to shut off gas from a broken pipe. 
 The regulators have "a poor history of responding to our recommendations in a timely manner," said James E. Hall, chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, an independent investigative agency.
"We have a good working relationship in terms of being able to sit down and discuss our concerns," Mr. Hall said. "However, I feel that they are slow in implementing the changes that we feel are necessary."
The safety board's function is to make recommendations, not to impose regulations, but in its report on the Edison pipeline accident, the board said, "Many Federal pipeline regulations are no more than general statements that lack sufficient guidance to pipeline operators about necessary actions to achieve a safety objective."
Over half the heating oil, gasoline and other petroleum products used in the United States is transported through 1.8 million miles of pipeline. Although most of the pipelines lie in remote areas, some pass through populated regions on their way to cities.
Both industry spokesmen and critics agree that fatal pipeline accidents are rare, and, indeed, only one death has been linked to the explosion in Edison, which occurred on March 23, 1994. According to records from the Federal Department of Transportation, 21 people died in pipeline accidents in 1995, as opposed to 41,000 on the nation's highways.
But safety board reports detail accidents in which a significant loss of life was narrowly avoided. In the New York area, a natural gas pipeline exploded in the Bronx in 1989, destroying two buildings, incinerating 50 cars and killing two people. Two years later, a propane line ignited in upstate New York, leveling a dozen homes in the village of North Blenheim and killing two residents. The Edison explosion caused $25 million in damage, injured nearly 100 people and displaced 1,500. The one fatality was a 32-year-old woman who died of a heart attack shortly after the explosion.
In a 1996 follow-up report on several pipeline accidents, the safety board said the number of such incidents had remained constant since 1986. But, the board went on to say, "The potential threat to public safety from such releases has become more severe in recent years as residential and commercial development adjacent to both natural gas and hazardous liquid pipelines has accelerated."
Industry spokesmen and regulators maintained that the safety board had overstated the dangers and potential problems.
Kelley S. Coyner, the Department of Transportation's deputy administrator in charge of pipeline safety, said the office is researching the safety board recommendations and has already made improvements in some areas. In particular, she said, the Government has strengthened regulations requiring contractors to call for information about buried pipelines before beginning excavation work. Because outside damage is the predominant cause of pipeline breaks, Ms. Coyner said, regulators believe that decreasing excavation-related accidents is the most effective way to improve safety.
"You look at the things that are going to do the most to reduce the likelihood of an accident and the consequences when one does occur," she said.
Regulators also point out that the budget of the Federal Office of Pipeline Safety, which regulates the pipeline industry, nearly doubled after the Edison explosion. From $19 million in 1994, the budget jumped to $37 million in 1995 and $32 million in 1996 and 1997. The agency had 30 inspectors in 1994; by the end of this year, it plans to have conducted 57.
Ms. Coyner said the pipeline regulators "work very closely" with the safety board, but also have the responsibility for producing regulations that are practical and effective. Like all regulators, the Office of Pipeline Safety must balance safety concerns with economics and engineering practicality, she said.
"We have a different perspective than they have," she added. "It is our view that there is a lot more to preventing accidents and minimizing the cause of them than just looking at the last accident."
 
The Cause
Focus on Digging In 1994 Blast
The pipeline that runs behind the Durham Woods Apartments in Edison was built in the early 1960's to meet an increasing demand for natural gas in the Northeast. The steel pipe, which is 36 inches in diameter, is part of a 10,000-mile network stretching from Texas to New York. owned by Texas Eastern Transmission Corp., based in Houston.
When Texas Eastern's engineers built the pipeline, they studied 10 routes to find the best path to avoid residential areas. Even as the pipeline was being constructed, the company altered the route several times to avoid development.
But the company could not control the new construction that spread across New Jersey farmland and squeezed in along the pipeline route. The Durham Woods complex was built in 1984.
As part of a company inspection program, which exceeded Federal requirements, a pilot from the Texas Eastern company was flying along the pipeline's route through New Jersey twice a week. The pilot was supposed to make sure that no unreported excavation or construction threatened the line.
Safety board investigators later said that the flights were sufficient to detect new construction, but failed to note work at existing industrial sites.
The investigators have said they believe excavation at a nearby asphalt plant may have gouged and weakened the pipeline in Edison. The excavation was never reported and investigators still do not know when, or by whom, it was done.
Near midnight on March 23, the pipeline finally buckled. The metal shattered under the tremendous pressure of the gas. With a muffled boom, rocks and pipe fragments flew into the air and rained down on the rooftops of the apartment complex.
The sound of the blast and of the rocks hitting the buildings proved to be a blessing. Many residents said they were awakened by the noise and were able to flee. Within two minutes of the initial explosion, the gas ignited, and flames soared 500 feet into the air. The roofs of several nearby apartment buildings ignited almost immediately.
Residents, many in pajamas and nightgowns, fled on foot as the buildings and cars in the parking lots burned. The huge fireball, visible for miles, sowed fear throughout the area. In the hour after the explosion was first reported at 11:55 P.M., more than 200,000 calls came into the Edison Township 911 system.
Within half an hour of the explosion, firefighters were able to prevent the blaze from spreading through the apartment complex. But there was little they could do about the primary fire, which was fed by a stream of natural gas.
At 12:07 A.M., an operator at Texas Eastern's compressor station in Lambertville, N.J., called the company headquarters in Houston to report low pressure in the pipeline.
"My God," the operator said, according to the safety board's report, "I can see a fireball in the sky toward Linden."
The Texas Eastern operator then dispatched an emergency team to the site of the fireball, but the gas continued to flow because the company had no way to shut off the gas remotely. The gigantic fireball continued to burn as gas workers, attempting to reach a manual shut-off valve, had to negotiate heavy traffic caused by people fleeing the explosion. The team finally reached the shut-off valve about five miles from the explosion. They shut off the flow of gas at 2:25 A.M., about two and one-half hours after the explosion.
The apartment buildings destroyed in the fire have since been rebuilt and are once again occupied.
Texas Eastern has also tightened its security procedures, increasing the frequency of aerial and ground patrols and adding 68 remote-controlled valves to pipelines in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The company plans to install 25 more valves by the end of this year, said John Barnett, a spokesman for Texas Eastern.
Mayor George A. Spadoro of Edison, who recalls watching fire engines melt from the heat of the blaze, said the town "ducked a bullet" that night.
"The fact that we had no substantial loss of life was a miracle," he said. "If it had happened 900 feet down the line, it would have been an instantaneous incineration. People would have been trapped."
 
The Aftermath
Trade Groups Cite Regulatory Costs
The safety board tracks how often nine transportation agencies, ranging from the Federal Aviation Administration to the Coast Guard, follow its recommendations. Of those agencies, safety board records show, the Office of Pipeline Safety ranks second lowest, after the Coast Guard.
But industry groups say the safety board often makes recommendations that are impractical and do little to increase actual safety. In fact, trade groups say industrial standards and guidelines, which are used in construction and maintenance of pipelines, already meet the goals the safety board wants regulators to adopt.
"The pipeline companies use practices that are above and beyond what the regulations require," said Terry Boss, a vice president of the Interstate Natural Gas Association of America. He said that companies typically spend twice as much on safety programs as Federal regulations require.
One of industry's most common complaints is that regulatory standards often do not keep pace with technology. Mr. Boss said, for example, that companies use measures that provide greater safety than Federal requirements in areas like pipeline toughness and damage prevention.
Mr. Boss said the safety board recommendations do not reflect what is practical or feasible for pipeline companies. Pipeline regulators, on the other hand, try to balance safety requirements with business's ability to carry them out, he said.
"N.T.S.B. has the goal to be a safety agency with no idea of cost-benefit," Mr. Boss said. "They essentially thrive on controversy on these sorts of things."
 
The Responses
Congress Rejects A Strict Safety Bill
During Congressional hearings on the Edison explosion in 1994. Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, said: "The Edison accident should never have happened. We need to acknowledge Edison for what it is: a breakdown in the regulatory and safety program."
The Congressional hearings produced a bill adopting the recommendations made by the safety board, including remote shut-off valves for urban areas and more stringent inspection of pipelines.
"What we tried to do was respond to what we saw as the weakness of the situation and try to establish a framework that would provide serious safety requirements," said Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, one of the bill's sponsors.
Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a New Jersey Democrat who was a primary sponsor of the legislation, said the bill was not introduced until the end of the session in 1994. He said the sponsors expected to take the matter up at the beginning of the 1995 session, but the big Republican victory in Congress changed the course of the legislation.
"The new majority came in with the 'Contract with America' ideology, which is no more regulation, get government out of our lives," Mr. Pallone said. "The pipeline safety act became the first victim of this new philosophy."
Mr. Pallone said the longer the bill languished in committee, the less chance it had of eventual passage.
"Historically, both Congress and the agency are disaster oriented," Mr. Pallone said. "After a few months or a few years, the incentive becomes less, and the industry keeps saying these things are not necessary, and we do not want to be placed under these restrictions."
The 1994 bill did not pass, but in 1996, Congress approved the Accountable Pipeline Safety and Partnership Act. It contained fewer of the measures recommended by the safety board. The sponsors of the new law argued that it allowed industry greater flexibility in working with the regulations.
The law, which was opposed by environmentalists, requires that regulators perform a cost-benefit analysis before enacting any new regulations. Mr. Pallone and environmental groups contended that this presents an obstacle to any new regulation by making it subject to costly legal appeals. Supporters say the cost-benefit analysis is nothing more than the typical procedure used by regulators for years, and argue that it forces the Government to adopt practical regulations.
While Mr. Pallone and several other Congressmen said the law would do little to increase public safety, others said it contained several positive steps, including increased financing for pipeline regulators and provisions to protect pipelines from outside damage.
"There are several provisions that I support and that can help, and will help to improve the public safety," Senator Lautenberg said during a floor debate. "At the same time, however, in my view, the legislation should go farther."
Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, the sponsor of the 1996 law, declined to comment. But during debate over the legislation, Senator Lott said the other proposals would "add unnecessary layers of regulations in direct response to specific atypical incidents."
On the other hand, the Senator said, the 1996 law gives more responsibility to pipeline operators, who "have a direct and compelling reason to work hard to keep their systems and the public safe.
"There will always be some who will argue that the Government must spend more and more money for safety concerns," Senator Lott said. "My response is that safety is not just a function of how much the Government spends. I believe the critical factor is how the money is spent, not how much."

HEADLINE: Apparel Industry Group Moves to End Sweatshops

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A Presidential task force that includes human rights groups, labor unions and apparel industry giants like Nike Inc., Reebok International Ltd. and L.L. Bean has reached a groundbreaking agreement that seeks to end sweatshops by creating a code of conduct on wages and working conditions, including a maximum 60-hour workweek, for apparel factories that American companies use around the world.
The task force has also agreed to set up an association to oversee monitors who would inspect apparel factories worldwide and give a seal of approval to companies that comply with the code of conduct. 
 Task force members vowed to follow the code in the factories they use in the United States and abroad. Participants said they hoped that dozens of other American companies would commit themselves to meeting the standards, and that the effort would eventually lead to a work standards for the clothing industry worldwide.
The members reached agreement at a seven-hour meeting on Monday, attended by Gene Sperling, chairman of the President's National Economic Council. Task force participants said President Clinton hoped to announce the agreement next Monday at a White House ceremony where he will be flanked by industry, labor and human rights officials. Mr. Sperling, who refused to confirm details of the agreement, said, "The progress that's been made represents a unique and historic step to eradicate sweatshops here and around the world."
He said the diverse group of members "were willing to sacrifice each of their sense of what was perfect to achieve something for the common good."
Companies that comply with the code will be able to put a label or tag on their clothing assuring consumers that it was not made in a sweatshop.
Linda Golodner, the co-chairwoman of the task force and president of the National Consumers Federation, said, "The benefit for everyone is what the whole task force was about: that's to make sure consumers can purchase goods that have not been made in a sweatshop and make sure that there's a process in place to check that factories are not sweatshops."
The agreement came after weeks of meetings in which the apparel companies clashed with labor and human rights representatives about minimum wages and maximum hours in factories and who should monitor the factories. Task force members said they are still debating some wording in the proposed guidelines.
Roberta Karp, the task force co-chairwoman who is general counsel at Liz Claiborne Inc., said, "Industry, human rights, labor and the Clinton Administration shared a commitment and our collective work will result in improved working conditions around the world."
Underlining the difficulty of reaching an accord, the task force agreed on an ambiguous standard for wages, saying that while factories that American companies own or contract with should pay the minimum wage in the countries where they are located, there should be a link between wages and the basic needs of workers. Several labor and human rights representatives on the task force contended that in countries like Haiti, the minimum wage is too low to support a family.
At Monday's meeting in Washington, the most hotly debated issue was working hours. The corporate members, which included Nicole Miller, Patagonia and the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, agreed to a maximum 60-hour workweek with several wrinkles: that the maximum standard workweek would be 48 hours in countries that do not already have a standard of fewer hours, while the maximum number of overtime hours required of apparel employees would be 12.
The two labor unions represented were the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees and the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Jeff Ballinger, president of Press for Change, a labor rights group that has often deplored the working conditions of shoe factories that American companies use abroad, said the 60-hour maximum was an important step forward.
"If orders are backlogged or if there's a rush, many times workers will have to work 65 to 70 hours a week for weeks on end," he said.
The agreement on maximum hours will even affect factories in the United States, where there is a standard 40-hour workweek, but no limit on how many overtime hours can be worked. Under the new code, participants would agree not to force employees in their American factories to work more than 12 overtime hours beyond the 40-hour workweek.
The task force, which was set up last summer, reached an agreement early on child labor. Factories should not use workers under 15, although in some countries they would be allowed to employ 14-year-olds.
In addition, in an industry where workers often say they are hit, fondled or shouted at, the task force agree on anti-harassment provisions that human rights representatives praised. The code states that all workers be treated with respect and "no employee shall be subject to any physical, sexual, psychological or verbal harassment or abuse."
In one of the major sticking points, labor and human rights members said they wanted human rights groups or church groups to monitor factories, while corporate members said the monitors should generally be accounting firms with international offices, because such firms can easily operate anywhere.
Under the deal, companies could choose accounting firms to serve as monitors but those firms would be asked to work with human rights groups.
Task force members said that they needed to work out many details over the next such months, including how the governing association will be structured, who will serve on it, who will finance the association and the monitoring, and what labels would be put on clothing to show they were not been made in sweatshops.
Stanley Levy, a Los Angeles lawyer on the task force who represents apparel companies, said, "It's a difficult task to get all the parties to reach an agreement that sets worldwide standards."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 10, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about an agreement on workplace standards for apparel factories reached by a Presidential task force misidentified its co-chairwoman, Linda Golodner. She is president of the National Consumers League, not the National Consumers Federation.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Lighter Side of Downsizing

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
The new series "Fired Up" comes with a topical premise and an edgy lead character, just what most sitcoms lack. Sharon Lawrence (far from her role as the smart but dowdy Sylvia Costas on "N.Y.P.D. Blue") plays Gwen, a chic, aloof public relations executive downsized out of a large company. When she is finally forced to apply for unemployment, the woman who takes her application asks, "What brings you here, Duchess?"
But this promising concept soon turns into another silly sitcom device. Gwen's put-upon assistant, Terry, was also let go. In the first show, the destitute Gwen moves into Terry's large Manhattan loft, which they share with Terry's brother, Danny. The women start a public relations company as equal partners. Before long, "Fired Up" becomes a matter of the actors trying to rise above the contrived material. 
 They do that surprisingly well. Ms. Lawrence has sharp comic timing (though she doesn't really need to drop her voice to Tallulah Bankhead depths to make her point). As the middle-class Terry, Leah Remini is down to earth without being condescending. But only Mark Feuerstein, as Danny, seems completely comfortable. That may be because Danny, an aspiring writer who works in the bar beneath their apartment, is a slightly more believable character from the start.
Tonight's mildly amusing show cranks up the show's premise. But future episodes, though not terrible, never offer the sharp writing this series needs. When Gwen decides to sell her share of a racehorse, the ending is sentimental. The series is scheduled to run in the cushy Thursday night slot after "Seinfeld" through May 15. Long before then the abrasive Gwen shows signs of softening and becoming one more mushy sitcom character.
 
FIRED UP
NBC, tonight at 9:30
 
Arleen Sorkin and Paul Slansky, creators and co-executive producers; Victor Fresco, Kelsey Grammer and Rudy Hornish, executive producers; Thom Bray and Michael Ross, supervising producers; Linda Teverbaugh and Mike Teverbaugh, consulting producers; Barbara Dorio, producer; music by Mark Mothersbaugh. Pilot directed by James Burrows. A production of Grammnet Productions in association with Paramount Network Television.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Again as Japanese Seem Unfazed by Lower Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar reached another four-and-a-half-year high against the Japanese yen and a three-year high against the German mark yesterday, propelled by the prospect of rising American interest rates and an apparent lack of concern at central banks over the dollar's strength.
It was the dollar's fourth straight day of solid gains, and the momentum of the rise emboldened many traders to join in the buying, especially as the currency passed its 1997 high of 1.7210 marks. 
 "You've got interest rate differentials working in the dollar's favor pretty much around the world," said Ron Hudson, vice president for corporate sales at the Royal Bank of Scotland in New York. For foreign investors looking for the best return, he said, "you want to stick your money in dollars."
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar touched an intraday high of 126.93 yen, the strongest since August 1992, before settling at 126.77 yen, up from 126.52 on Tuesday and up 3.4 percent since Friday, when the rally began. Against the mark, the dollar reached an intraday high of 1.7272, the strongest since March 1994, before settling at 1.7245 marks, up from 1.7143 on Tuesday and up 2.3 percent since Friday. It rose, as well, against the British pound, which eased to $1.6194 yesterday from $1.6260 late Tuesday.
The dollar has been rallying on a combination of higher American interest rates -- which draw investment into this country, increasing the demand for dollar-denominated instruments, continuing economic sluggishness in Japan and Germany, and an apparent easing of trade friction with Japan since Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin's visit there last week.
Currency traders bought dollars starting early in Asian dealings, encouraged by the lack of any official Japanese warnings over the yen's decline. On the contrary, comments from senior Japanese monetary aides have suggested that they are not overly concerned.
The influential head of the Finance Ministry's international finance bureau, Eisuke Sakakibara, reiterated yesterday that it was desirable for foreign exchange rates to reflect economic fundamentals, and his remarks implied to traders that intervention was not warranted.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Italian Silk Industry Upset By a New U.S. Trade Law

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: COMO, Italy

 BODY:
If you sport a silk scarf with a "Made in Italy" label, chances are that not only was its silk yarn spun in China, but it was woven to fabric there, too.
Raw silk has not been produced in Italy since the 1950's. But the pride of the 200 or so textile companies that make this northern Italian city to silk what Maine is to lobsters is their skill in finishing raw silk, dying and printing it, then transforming it into ties, scarves and other apparel that fetch high prices in elegant shops around the world. 
 Since October, however, these companies, which produce 90 percent of Europe's silk exports, have been in conflict with the United States over import legislation enacted last year by Congress. For if that legislation was strictly enforced, much of Italian silk would have to be marked "Made in China."
"Imagine saying this was made in Brazil," said Guido Tettamanti, the secretary of the Italian Silk Association, pounding his desk with a fist, "just because the trees grow there that provided its wood."
The law that upsets Como was enacted to prevent the growing business of "goods shipped through third countries," said Jay Ziegler, a spokesman for the United States trade representative in Washington. The practice undermines the American economy and hurts American textile workers, the law's proponents say, because it allows dealers to skirt quotas on textiles from low-wage countries like China. Piero Costa, an economist with the Italian textile industry group Federtessile says that not companies specializing in cotton goods like sheets or pillow cases are also threatened.
Under the legislation, which took effect in July, at least four steps in the processing of fabrics, like dyeing, printing or stiffening, must be done locally for a product to qualify as made in Italy, and not China. The issue is painful, because the United States has emerged in recent years as Italy's biggest customer for silk, and the principal growth product, scarves, is notably vulnerable because often little finishing is required to transform rough fabric from China into Italian scarves.
Moreover, because of the high price silk fetches, it accounts for a disproportionately large share of the Italian textile industry's export earnings. In the first 11 months of 1996, silk fabrics accounted for less than one-tenth of 1 percent of exports by weight but by value almost 5 percent.
To be sure, the law has thus far blocked few if any European products from entering the United States. But European industry officials like Mr. Costa say the uncertainty it creates discourages growth, and thus in February they prevailed on the senior European trade official, Sir Leon Brittan, to issue an ultimatum to the United States either to take steps to change its provisions, or face a European complaint to the World Trade Organization.
In informal negotiations, the United States is seeking "mutual agreement" with the Europeans, Mr. Ziegler said, though he did not say what form this might take. Washington's main concern, he said, is the effectiveness of a bilateral textile agreement with China that was renewed in January for four years.
What makes the American action particularly painful is that it adds to pressures on the industry that derive from recent changes in Chinese policy. Rather than sell raw silk to the Italians, who weave it and use it to produce the fabrics that go into apparel by luxury designers like Gucci or Valentino, China is increasing efforts to weave large amounts of silk in China and sell it directly on world markets. In 1985, Como's silk makers imported 3,900 tons of raw silk and 600 tons of woven fabric from China; by 1995, raw silk imports dropped to 3,150 tons, while the amount of imported fabric almost tripled, to 1,644 tons.
The result, the Italian silk makers argue, is a glut of low-quality fabric that has turned designers and consumers away from silk. This comes at a time when silk, according to fashion experts like Francesco Lussana, the right-hand man to the designer Gianni Versace, has already lost ground to materials like synthetics and metallic fabrics. Price is part of the problem, he said, but designers are also turning to new blends like silk and mohair, which are soft on one side and smooth on the other, or crisp mixtures of silk and linen.
Thus, after several years of declining demand, China's raw silk exports slumped in 1996 by 5 percent. Exports of woven fabric dropped by 23 percent, while raw silk production plummeted by 30 percent.
What upsets the Europeans about the spat with Washington is that it gnaws at the united front they feel the West should present toward China on textile matters. By drawing China into the World Trade Organization, for instance, Italy hopes to put pressure on Beijing to dismantle domestic monopolies like the China National Silk Import and Export Corporation, which controls the raw silk trade.
Indeed, by negotiating direct access to raw silk supplies, Italy's silk industry, which purchases about one-fifth of all Chinese production, hopes over the long run to establish a trade group in China to compete with the corporation, whose instinctive reaction to lower sales is often to raise prices. Last year, for instance, when exports collapsed, the corporation imposed a levy of $1 a kilogram to offset lost revenues.
"In a way, we are trying to ride the tiger," Mr. Tettamanti said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The Met markets 'Glory of Byzantium' exhibition to those whose ancestors helped make it glorious.

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
ETHNIC marketing" has become a familiar phrase in the advertising lexicon. All too often, though, "ethnic" is used to mean Asian, black or Hispanic.
But now, several American ethnic groups that marketers have long neglected -- Armenian, Greek, Russian and Ukrainian -- are being actively courted in an advertising campaign that appeals to their cultural, historic and religious identities. 
 The reason? To build attendance at "The Glory of Byzantium," the Metropolitan Museum of Art's show about Byzantine culture at its peak, from the 9th Century to the 13th. The exhibition, which opened last month and continues until July 6, offers 350 icons, mosaics, illuminated manuscripts, ivories, frescoes and other works of art produced primarily by the forebears of contemporary Armenians, Greeks, Russians and Ukrainians. The 1990 census counted nearly 424,000 people of those ethnic derivations in just the five boroughs of New York City.
In a campaign that will continue through April, the museum has bought air time on Greek and Russian radio stations in the New York metropolitan area and full-page advertisements in Greek-language publications like The National Herald and Proini, in Svoboda Ukrainian Daily, in Novoye Russkoye Slovo and in The Armenian Mirror-Spectator and The Armenian Reporter.
"This show gives pride of place to a number of ethnic groups whose treasures have been gathered together here for the first and only time," said Harold Holzer, the vice president for communications at the museum.
The Met's curators traveled to museums, private collectors, churches and remote monasteries in 24 countries to assemble the exhibition. Many of the artworks had not been shown in public before; many had never left the monasteries where they were installed more than 1,000 years ago, and some, from a Greek monastery restricted to men since the 10th century, had never been seen by women.
Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan's director, who has helped organize more than 400 exhibitions over 20 years, said the show was "by far the most challenging and the most important that I have inaugurated."
The advertisements have been tailored to each ethnic group. For Greek groups, they depict a mosaic of St. Andrew from the Archeological Museum in Serres, Greece. For Ukrainian-Americans, they portray "The Deacon Stephen," a mosaic from the Kiev Architectural Conservation Area. For Russian groups, they carry the representation of St. Luke in an illuminated manuscript from the Russian National Library in St. Petersburg. And for Armenian-Americans, they feature an illuminated page from the Zeyt'un Gospels on vellum created in Armenia in the 13th century.
The Metropolitan will not say how much it is spending to promote the exhibition, but experts on institutional marketing budgets who have studied the advertising campaign said it could not be mounted for less than $200,000. While this would be a drop in the bucket for a giant consumer-products company, it is a considerable commitment for a nonprofit institution.
The Metropolitan first dipped its toe in the waters of ethnic marketing with its "Splendors of Imperial China" exhibition last year, when it aimed at Asian-Americans in a campaign so successful "that one out of every five visitors to the show was Asian-American," Mr. Holzer said.
Indeed, "Splendors" won the highest attendance of any show in the world in 1996, according to a study by The Economist, more than the Vermeer show in Washington and even more than the Cezanne show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
"Splendors" attracted 426,757 visitors during its two-month run. "Byzantium," thanks in part to the ethnic advertising campaign, has attracted 127,600 in its first three weeks.
The "Byzantium" campaign is not only the museum's most ambitious foray into ethnic marketing, it is also a rarity coming from a cultural institution. "I can't think of a major American advertiser that has run a campaign in Armenian, Greek, Russian," said Arthur Cohen, a founder and principal of LaPlaca Cohen Advertising in Manhattan, the Metropolitan's agency, which also represents the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Cleveland Museum and the Art Institute of Chicago.
"It took us weeks of interviewing people in these communities to identify the right mix of publications" for the campaign, Mr. Cohen added.
Florence Avakian, a correspondent for both The Armenian Mirror-Spectator and Armenian radio programming on WSOU-FM in New Jersey, said: "I haven't seen other museums doing this. It's a very creative way to raise the awareness of an audience that may not have known about the exhibition."
"Many Armenians have already come to the 'Byzantium' exhibition," she added, "and some of them wouldn't have discovered it without the Metropolitan's campaign."
Given its experience so far, will the Met try ethnic marketing again? "If it's appropriate for the exhibition, we'd do it immediately," Mr. Holzer said. "We are living in a community that is a mosaic of cultures in which such marketing is ideal."

HEADLINE: Iraq Defies U.N. Ban With Pilgrimage Flight to Arabia

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, April 9

 BODY:
An Iraqi aircraft flew more than 100 passengers to Saudi Arabia today in the first open defiance of the United Nations air embargo that has been enforced against Iraq since the Persian Gulf war six years ago.
The Government in Baghdad apparently concluded that like Libya, Iraq was not likely to pay any real price for its defiance. Libya has defied a similar embargo three times to fly pilgrims to Saudi Arabia on its own aircraft. 
 The Iraqi authorities gave no indication whether they intended to send more planes into the skies or whether today's flight was merely a symbolic gesture.
The plane was permitted to enter the airspace of Saudi Arabia after the authorities there were informed that it carried pilgrims bound for the Muslim holy sites of Mecca and Medina, Saudi officials said.
The Iraqis on board, all at least 50 years old, were performing the haj, the pilgrimage that Muslims must make at least once in their lives if they have the means to do so.
Since the gulf war, Iraqis who have visited the holy sites have traveled overland, their only option under the United Nations sanctions.
In dispatching the flight today, Iraqi officials said their motives were humanitarian, but they also hoped to arouse anger across the Muslim world against what the Minister of Religious Affairs, Abdul-Muneim Ahmed Saleh, called "this unfair embargo which the infidel countries have imposed and in which Islamic and Arab countries are taking part."
The American-led allied force that drove Iraqi troops out of Kuwait in 1991 used Saudi Arabia as its principal staging area, and the Saudi Government remains an unabashed foe of the Iraqi Government and its leader, President Saddam Hussein.
But as custodian of Islam's two holiest sites, the Saudi Government has been deeply reluctant to be seen as denying Muslims the right to perform the haj. The Interior Minister, Prince Nayef ibn Abdel Aziz, said that Saudi Air Force jets had escorted the Russian-built plane from the moment it entered Saudi Arabia, but that the journey to the city of Jidda on the Red Sea coast had been authorized "when it became known that the aircraft had pilgrims on board."
An earlier request by Iraq to use its aircraft to fly pilgrims to Saudi Arabia this year had been rejected by the United Nations Security Council, and today's flight is expected to be met with swift condemnation there.
Until today, the effect of the United Nations air embargo on Iraq and no-flight zones imposed across the north and south of the country by the United States and its allies was to leave all of Iraq's civilian aircraft grounded and its airports shuttered.
Before the Soviet-built Ilyushin-76 plane took off from a military air base on the eastern outskirts of Baghdad, the Iraqi authorities staged a farewell ceremony that made clear that the mission reflected official policy.
The foray was only the latest attempt by Iraq to undermine support for the United Nations sanctions, which were imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990 and which have left Baghdad politically and economically isolated.
After lengthy negotiations, the Security Council agreed last year to let Iraq sell limited quantities of oil and use the proceeds to buy food, and Iraq dispatched envoys to Japan, Russia and Europe last month to seek support for a further loosening of the sanctions.
In recent months some Arab countries including Egypt, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates have become increasingly open in hinting that they would support a lifting of the restrictions against Iraq.
But the Baghdad Government has also had to weather new criticism from United Nations officials, who have condemned the country's human rights record and complained that it is failing to honor its commitment to allow United Nations inspectors full access to information about its weapons programs.
As if to minimize any affront that might be caused by today's foray, the Iraqi authorities called attention to the age of the pilgrims, who included 64 men and 40 women. Among those interviewed by reporters in Iraq, several said they were in declining health and could not endure the hardship of the 1,250-mile land journey from Baghdad to Mecca.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Muslim pilgrims prayed yesterday before boarding a plane in Baghdad for a flight to Saudi Arabia. The flight violated United Nations sanctions. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: U.S. Raises Pressure on Mobutu, A Longtime Ally, to Step Down

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
As violence swept through the streets of Zaire's capital today, the White House sharply stepped up pressure on President Mobutu Sese Seko to step aside.
In its harshest comments to date about Mr. Mobutu, a longtime American ally, the White House declared that the end of his autocratic regime was inevitable. "Mobutuism is about to become a creature of history," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, told reporters this morning. 
 But Administration officials said they remain unsure what kind of rule might follow a collapse of Mr. Mobutu's Government and are wary of the intentions of Laurent Kabila, the leader of Zaire's rebels, who now control about a third of the country.
Officials at the White House and the State Department insisted that they were not calling on President Mobutu to resign, but rather for him to help create a transitional government that would hold democratic elections. Mr. McCurry acknowledged that he was skirting the lip of such a request, saying, "Ambiguity is an art form."
But when pressed for elaboration, he added, "I think that it's clear that we have to move beyond President Mobutu and think about how we begin to structure a government that can address the needs of the Zairian people, and that's what the United States is committing to supporting."
Harshly repudiating a leader that successive Administrations treated as an ally for decades, Mr. McCurry defined "Mobutuism" as "the state of disrepair of the Zairian political economy, the sad conditions that many people in Zaire live in now, the lack of effective political representation that the people of Zaire have suffered under for some time."
From the time he took power in 1965, Mr. Mobutu received hundreds of millions of dollars from the United States until Congress, over the objections of the Bush Administration, cut off all direct military and economic aid in 1990. The United States still provides some aid to Zaire through nongovernmental organizations.
The Central Intelligence Agency worked closely with Mr. Mobutu for years, funnelling money through him to pro-Western guerrilla forces in Angola, according to Angolan military commanders and Western diplomats in Zaire.
About 500 Americans remain in Zaire. American military forces are standing by directly across the Congo River from Kinshasa, the Zaire capital, prepared to evacuate them if necessary, officials said. Mr. McCurry said the American troops had been deployed only to help evacuate United States citizens in Zaire, not to play a wider role in a change in government.
As reports came in about spreading violence and arrests in Kinshasa, American officials seemed uncertain about the rapidly shifting political situation there, although they said they remained in contact with Mr. Mobutu's Government.
"We may have a situation where there are two prime ministers in Zaire, or two people who say they are prime minister," Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said.
Mr. Burns appeared to be referring to efforts today by Zaire's Prime Minister, Etienne Tshisekedi, a longtime opponent of Mr. Mobutu, to defy the state of emergency that Mr. Mobutu declared on Wednesday.
Administration officials said the United States had not attempted to send signals through intermediaries to urge Mr. Mobutu to step aside. "We couldn't do that," one official said. "Mobutu could have used it against us with the French." The French Government remains an ally of Mr. Mobutu.
Bernard Valero, the press counselor of the French Embassy here, said France supported negotiations between the rebels and Mr. Mobutu's Government, which are taking place in South Africa. The United States is also supporting that process, hoping it will lead to democratic elections.
An Administration official said that Washington remained unsure whether Mr. Kabila, the rebel leader, will embrace democracy. "There's room for hope, but I don't think anyone wants to be overconfident about that," the official said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Early Gains In Treasuries Fail to Hold

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday, with early gains on the back of a strong dollar evaporating by the afternoon.
In the municipal bond market, a $1.2 billion debt sale by New York City was the center of attention. 
 The sluggish trading in the Treasury market reflected investors' caution ahead of reports on retail sales and producer prices tomorrow. Many market participants expect the Federal Reserve will soon raise interest rates again, and they are looking to the reports for clues on how many times the Fed may act.
"The only good thing you could say about Wednesday's action is that Thursday's will probably be even more dull," said David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data in Boston.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32, to 94 5/32, to yield 7.10 percent, unchanged from Tuesday.
In one of the busiest days of the year thus far for the municipal market, New York's sale accounted for about half of the $2 billion or more debt that states and local government prepared to issue.
About $900 million of the bonds with maturities that range from one year to 30 years were priced through underwriters led by Smith Barney Inc.
The bonds were priced to yield as much as 6.39 percent for a bond due in 2027. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 4.550 percent for an issue due in 1999 to 5.60 percent in 2005, 6.15 percent in 2010 and 6.250 in 2013. Other long maturities included a bond due April 2017 priced to yield 6.31 percent and August 2017 priced to yield 6.30 percent.
An additional $120 million in taxable bonds was underwritten by Morgan Stanley & Company. They were priced to yield 7.440 percent for an issue due in 2003 and 7.480 percent for another due in 2004.
The $900 million of tax-exempt debt and $120 million of taxable debt is rated Baa1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, with the exception of a tax-exempt bond due April 2007, which is insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and rated triple-A.
Sylvan G. Feldstein, a municipal bond analyst with Guardian Asset Management, said there was huge retail interest in the city bonds, which he thought were not priced aggressively, but priced fairly to move in the flat market environment.
In the corporate market, the J. C. Penney Company priced $2.5 billion of debt in a six-part offering through underwriters led by the Credit Suisse First Boston Corporation. The offering is rated A2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
Underwriters priced $325 million of three-year noncallable notes to yield 6.979 percent, or about 40 basis points more than a comparable Treasury security, and $700 million of five-year noncallable notes to yield 7.259 percent, or about 50 basis points over a comparable Treasury. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Penney debt also includes $425 million of 10-year noncallable notes with a yield of 7.60 percent, or about 70 basis points more than a comparable Treasury, and $300 million of 20-year noncallable notes with a yield of 7.998 percent, or about 85 basis points more than a similar Treasury.
There are also $350 million of 30-year debentures with a yield of 8.348 percent, or about 120 basis points above a comparable Treasury, and $400 million in 40-year debentures with a yield of 7.412 percent, or about 50 basis points over a Treasury note due in 2005.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1551 words

HEADLINE: A Continental Divide;
Tensions Grow as Europe Moves to a Unified Market

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Europe's progress toward political and economic unity, glacial though it may be, is opening the Continent to a level of worldwide competition that is unprecedented in its traditionally insular markets. Radical change is shaking some of Europe's biggest industries, leading to widespread job losses.
Philippe Martinez, head of one of France's leading leftist unions, is having none of it. Seated in an office under a poster with the words "To Privatize Is to Destroy," Mr. Martinez typified the anger displayed by those who think that greater European unity and global competition will destroy jobs, income and a sense of security that huge, Government-owned employers and cosseted industries have provided to generations of his countrymen. 
 "The Government's acting like a greedy investor," he said.
The United States, of course, went through a similar upheaval in recent years as corporations cut tens of thousands of jobs to increase productivity and stay competitive. But in Europe, with rigid social structures and traditionally strong labor movements, the tension is even greater.
In Germany, coal miners from the industrial Ruhr basin stormed into Bonn recently to protest cuts in coal price subsidies, a move they say will destroy thousands of jobs. And in Berlin, construction workers demonstrated to protest the hiring of cheap labor from Ireland, England and Portugal.
In France, truck drivers demanding more pay used their vehicles in February to block highways and ports. More recently, auto workers in France and Belgium took to the streets to protest Renault's plans to close a factory near Brussels, cutting 3,000 jobs, and to lay off 3,000 more workers in France.
Indeed, nowhere is the tension more apparent than in France. While European leaders forge ahead with plans for a single market, much remains to be done in France, and the prospect of restructuring and layoffs is spawning a fierce conflict that pits French values against the harsh realities of international competition.
"There is a clear contradiction between our traditions and our recent political decisions," said Eric Barthalon, chief economist at Paribas, the French financial services company. The absence of public debate about that contradiction is what troubles France, he said, "more than our rigidity."
The conflict is vividly clear at Renault, France's largest auto maker, which is trying to return to profitability after a $924 million loss in 1996. Because of an unfortunate combination of poor organization, manufacturing inefficiencies and a reluctance to venture too far from France, the company has become an also-ran in the world market. A planned marriage with Volvo fell through a few years ago, and now Renault faces the toil of getting into fighting trim to take on an expected invasion of Japanese cars.
Louis Schweitzer, the chairman and chief executive of Renault, readily admits that much of its difficulty lies in the poor organization of its factories, where low output and a multiplicity of models built under one roof prevent the economies of scale required to stay competitive.
What Mr. Schweitzer is slower to acknowledge is the effect of bad management decisions, often made under Government pressure. To save jobs in French factories, overseas investment was neglected. In 1987, Renault, whose full name is Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, pulled out of North America, selling a 46 percent share in American Motors to Chrysler.
In the 1990's, a deal to build trucks with Volvo collapsed when it became clear that the biggest changes, and most job losses, would come not at Volvo's plants in Sweden but at Renault's inefficient factories in France.
Some experts even question the Government's wisdom when, in 1990, it appointed Mr. Schweitzer, a former Government official described by one industry executive as a "very intelligent, thoughtful civil servant," yet "not an automobile man with gasoline in his blood."
Not that Renault has been standing still. To cut costs, Mr. Schweitzer has slashed 30,000 factory jobs, roughly a quarter of the total, since 1990. And Renault has consistently turned out exciting new models, from the bright little Twingo subcompact to the more recent Megane Scenic, a sleek van that European motor magazines named 1997 Car of the Year.
Yet Renault's factories remain bloated and costly, and in December Mr. Schweitzer reshuffled top management, hiring Carlos Ghosn, a hard-nosed turnaround artist, and giving him key management duties.
"The average size of our factories is 125,000 cars a year, while all our competitors are at 200,000, and our plants are more complex than theirs," Mr. Schweitzer said in an interview.
While most car makers seek to concentrate on one model at each plant, Renault's compact Clio, for instance, is assembled at five of its nine European sites. Moreover, while Volkswagen and Fiat have built factories in Latin America, Asia and Eastern Europe, Renault remains stubbornly local, with 85 percent of its sales in Europe.
The French Government has for years been gradually selling off control of more than a score of huge enterprises like banks, insurance companies, industrial companies and even Renault itself. Last year, the Government sold stakes in 10 of the largest nationalized industries, and in May shares worth $8.8 billion in France Telecom, Europe's second-largest telecommunications group after Germany's national company, will go on the block.
Moreover, the intertwined ownership common to French business, which tended to cushion executives from the pressure to produce profits, is gradually breaking up. Financial services companies such as Paribas and insurance companies such as Union des Assurances de Paris have begun selling off shares in industrial concerns. Alcatel Alsthom, the telecommunications conglomerate, and PSA Peugeot Citroen, the auto maker, have sold their mutual holdings.
There is a renewed focus on core businesses, and "in the long run we are clearly seeing it helping in our export performance," Mr. Barthalon said.
Change is much in evidence at Paribas. To focus on financial services, Paribas in recent years sold industrial pearls, like shares in the construction supply group Poliet, as well as a retail banking unit. Last year, as banking and investment revenues strengthened, Paribas reported a net profit of $763 million, recovering from a loss of $700 million a year earlier.
But failing to focus on growth, some experts warn, could lead to what Jean-Francois Manzoni, a management expert at Insead, the business school outside Paris, calls a "death spiral."
"You cannot sustain companies that don't create value," Mr. Manzoni said. Yet right now French business leaders, he cautioned, are "only selling pain."
What is driving the change, economists like Mr. Barthalon agree, is the decision to make France part of a single European market.
To cushion its auto industry, France long maintained high barriers to non-European imports -- Japan's share of the French market is just 7 percent, compared with 17 percent in Germany. By 1999, though, those barriers will fall, and the Japanese and South Koreans are gearing up for the onslaught. This month, Toyota announced plans to build a $1.6 billion factory in northern France with an annual capacity of 200,000 cars.
Meanwhile, Mr. Schweitzer rules out any significant mergers, at least for the moment. For Renault to join, for instance, with France's No. 2 car maker, Peugeot, would be " stupid," he said. "We would destroy each other's market share," he declared.
He envisions, instead, further cooperation agreements such as one signed in 1996 with General Motors to jointly make vans starting later this year in France and England, a deal he describes as the "most extensive cooperation" Renault has ever undertaken.
Of course, this talk is not welcome at all at France's powerful labor unions.
Marcel Grignard, the secretary general for miners and metal workers in the CFDT labor union, which represents about 8 percent of Renault workers, says the only way to save jobs at Renault is not to dismiss workers but to shorten working hours. This is what was done at Volkswagen, where in 1993 workers accepted a 28.8-hour workweek, not 36, to save jobs. At Volkswagen, the price was wage cuts of as much as 14.5 percent, which Mr. Grignard is not sure Renault workers would swallow.
And in any case, Volkswagen has had mixed results. Because its plan lacked flexibility, it needed union approval to allow employees to work up to 10 extra hours a week, with a costly 20 percent overtime bonus.
The French Government has tried to create jobs by granting tax relief to businesses that cut work hours and hire more employees, and this has provided some relief. Since 1994, French unemployment has held steady, while 500,000 jobs have been lost in Germany.
But the Government continues to resist proposals by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to reform the labor market by increasing corporate flexibility in setting working hours and reducing the minimum wage, which is $6.60 an hour. After all, the last prime minister to propose a cut in the minimum wage, Eduard Balladur, was forced to backtrack after thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Paris.

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 679 words

HEADLINE: Russian Talks of a Possible NATO Pact

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 9

 BODY:
All but conceding defeat in its long battle against NATO's expansion, Russia agreed conditionally today to put its relations with the alliance on a new footing at a meeting in May with President Clinton and other allied leaders.
After talks with President Jacques Chirac of France about a charter that has been under discussion since December, Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia said today, "We agreed that if the NATO-Russia agreement can be prepared in the coming weeks and if the preparations are satisfactory to all nations concerned, then the signing by heads of state or government of the 16 member states and Russia can take place in Paris on May 27." 
 "We believe plans for enlarging NATO are a very serious mistake," Mr. Primakov said. "But at the same time, we are realists, and we will do our best to get the Russian factor taken into account whatever the course of events." President Boris N. Yeltsin, he said, would come to Paris "with great pleasure" on May 27, assuming the final obstacles to a NATO-Russia charter are resolved by then.
President Clinton is planning to come to Europe on May 28 for ceremonies commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Marshall Plan, the economic aid program that put the western half of the continent back on its feet after World War II.
At that time, Eastern European countries, dominated by the Soviet Union, were invited to take part, but Moscow forced them to decline, and soon competing alliances, NATO and the Warsaw Pact, created a division that lasted until the Berlin wall crumbled in 1989.
The Warsaw Pact collapsed with it, but NATO, led by the United States, is trying to develop a new vocation as a peacekeeping force to insure military, political and economic stability in a region that spawned two world wars.
Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary are expected to be among the first former Communist countries invited to join. Mr. Clinton and other NATO leaders plan to extend the invitations at an alliance summit meeting planned in Madrid in early July.
Any Russian hopes that differences of opinion between President Clinton and key European allies would cause the alliance to shelve its expansion plans were disappointed by the enthusiastic backing Mr. Chirac and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany gave the plans in talks they had with Mr. Yeltsin earlier this year.
When he met Mr. Clinton in Helsinki, Finland, last month, Mr. Yeltsin was prepared to say only that the United States and Russia had agreed to disagree about expansion and to keep working on the charter. By agreeing to the May 27 signing date, Western diplomats said, Mr. Yeltsin has created the expectation that any remaining wrinkles could be ironed out by then.
French officials close to Mr. Chirac and Western diplomats said they had no reason to believe that Mr. Primakov had been promised any new concessions. Mr. Chirac flew to Bonn later today for scheduled talks with Mr. Kohl.
NATO's Secretary General, Javier Solana, now visiting Washington and Ottawa, will go to Moscow next week for more talks on the charter, which Russia originally wanted to be a pact requiring ratification by all signers.
What is emerging instead is a formal agreement falling short of a treaty. It would establish a permanent liaison between Russian military officers and the alliance's commanders in Mons, Belgium, and a consultative council in Brussels.
French officials said the Russians were still hoping the allies would put into writing the pledges they have effectively made not to put nuclear arms or substantial ground forces on the soil of new members, at least under current political conditions.
"We have to agree on not creating infrastructure to enable the forward deployment of those forces," Mr. Primakov said in Paris, indicating that Russia wanted NATO to promise not to build modernized bases that would make it easier to move troops and weapons to the new member countries.
NATO has rejected such a pledge, saying it would make second-class members of the countries that join.
